description:
Great Thai food in a shady neighborhood. What else can you ask for. This place is probably one of my fav. Thai restaurants in San Francisco. 

Thanks for making me a happy jew!
author: David F.

description:
Came by for lunch the other day and it was a tasty experience! Came by around ~11:30 am and managed to be seated immediately, before the lunch rush!

Staff is pleasant and there is some talented staff too if you look carefully!

Started off with the grilled pork shoulder which was tender, fragrant, and flavorful! 

Moved on to the shrimp paste fried rice which was very fragrant, bold, and spicy! The flavor profile here is very similar to what I got in Thailand!

Their fried fish cake is also quite tasty, being a huge portion, albeit on the pricier side at $10+ for 4 pieces! Flavors were excellent!

Parking is available on the street or in a private lot a few blocks down. ...it is the Tenderloin, so the clientele on the street is definitely different!
author: Derek S.

description:
Dish: Shredded Papaya Salad
Cost: $13.95
Rating: 3.75/5
Review: Shredded green papaya salad with chili, tomatoes, peanuts, lime dressing and grilled prawns. I have to always remember that in Thai restaurants, mild is still spicy.  This dish was good, but I've had better. My lazy self wished the cabbage wasn't still in a wedge and shredded so I didn't have to mix it into the sauce and cut it. The sauce for the salad was good - your typically papaya salad mix. The prawns weren't memorable and of course wasn't much portion. It's good, but for the price I probably wouldn't order this dish here again since there's so many other better dishes this restaurant serves. 

Dish: Pad Thai
Cost: $13.95
Rating: 4/5
Review: Pad Thai is probably my favorite Thai dish of all time so I usually order it everywhere I go :p It was good here but not my favorite. It's so pricey for a normal sized portion!

There are 3 locations I believe but this review was from the Larkin Street one in the TL district. Parking can be scarce but not impossible! Located in a sketchy neighborhood so don't leave any valuables! You can make reservations here and I highly suggest making reservations! Came on a Friday night around 7:30pm and was seated in the middle in a communal table setting but there are 4 seaters on the side.
author: Valerie T.

description: The reviews on Yelp got my hopes up but I wasn't impressed. The khan moo (stewed pork leg) was bland. The pad see-ew didn't have that wok sear. Don't get me wrong, the food is good but not great. If you live nearby then I think it is worth going to but I live far and it definitely isn't worth a trip back.
author: Lily L.

description: I've been to Lers Ros for lunch a few times. I would really recommend the  Yum Koh Moo Yang - Spicy lime dressing and roasted quick marinated pork shoulder, basil leaves, chili & rice powder. It's light, it's spicy and combines some really great flavors. I've also tried the pad thai. I think most of their noodle dishes are well made. I really like the atmosphere in the restaurant too. It feels clean, modern and welcoming.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Came here for lunch after trying Kin Khao, which was a rather unique take on Thai food.

Lers Ros does its dishes with authenticity and offers the basic Thai dishes you'd expect to find anywhere, but I found the flavours to be overly salty and not sufficiently sharp as a whole.

That goes for the nam tok, nuer pad prik, and a gai pad phed.

It's certainly not bad, but in my opinion, doesn't live up to the hype.
author: Stanley W.

description:
My friend and I decided to come here for lunch. The place is located in the Little Saigon area on the other side of the Tenderloin, and it wasn't too crowded when we went, but there was a big table. Because of that though, I felt service was a bit slow and we didn't get much attention until after the big table left.

The food itself was okay, I had the two item combo and I got the green curry and the Pad Kra Pow Kai. The curry itself was pretty flavorful, but beyond that there wasn't really anything special about it, just standard of what you would get elsewhere. The ground chicken was just okay, it benefitted from adding a bit of lime and chili to it. 

One of the main drawbacks though is that they didn't provide me with the various chili, peppers etc. toppings that usually come with most Thai meals. Instead I had to ask for some of it on the side, and ended up just getting sliced fresh peppers (which were good, but not what I had expected).

Otherwise an average Thai place, plenty of other great options in the city.
author: Tyler T.

description: BEWARE! UNSANITARY! I ordered a Tom Yum soup and salad to-go, drove 20 minutes home, and opened the soup to find DEAD flys and DEAD fleas floating in my soup. I called the restaurant back to let them know about this and they refused to refund me unless I came back with the food to show them. This is completely disgusting, terrible and might I say dangerous service!
author: Natalie C.

description: So I had walked by this restaurant a few times before and considered eating here, but am always skeptical of a South East Asian restaurant that looks too clean or "hipsterish". My main concern is that is won't be "authentic" enough and possibly be muted down flavor-wise for the mass market. I can say that I was glad I decided to give it a try because it was actually really tasty and had a very extensive menu. Great for meat eaters and vegetarians!
author: Sarah-Jade S.

description:
Cute, modern, and clean restaurant but unfortunately service was extremely sluggish. Took about 30 minutes for our food and the restaurant was pretty empty. Just hubby and I, and another  group of 3 that were already finishing up their lunch. So I couldn't understand why it took so long. We waited for about 15 minutes for our order of papaya salad, waited for another 10 minutes for hubby's pad thai, then another 10-15 minutes for my green curry. Sucks how all the food came out at different times. Over $50 for papaya salad, vegetarian pad thai, vegetarian green curry, and brown rice. Portion size was not worth it.

Papaya salad: too salty
Vegetarian pad thai: too sweet
Vegetarian green curry: too water down, no flavor. 

If you're looking for good authentic Thai/Lao food I suggest Champa Garden.
author: Kristen K.

description:
Such a good place for Thai food!

Three recommendations that are outstanding. First, the Larb Phed Yang, which is a roasted duck with rice powder that gives it a nice crunch. It comes with a little like which goes great. Second, the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob, which is Pork Belly that was perfectly crispy on the outside and super tender on the inside. Last, the Yum Pla Khem, which is  a salty crispy fish which was also delicious. The pepper bits in it can be a bit spicy though, so be warned.

Service was also prompt and the staff were very kind and attentive. Prices may be slightly more than average for Thai food, but definitely worth the price. Would love to come back again and try more things!!!
author: Erin H.

description:
The two blocks stretch between O'Farrell and Eddie has six Thai restaurants to choose from so I decided to start with Lers Ros as it had 4 stars rating with over 2000 reviews. On a Friday evening it was packed to the brim with people waiting outside for a table. I was hesitant to get something but as I simply wanted something to-go I walked in and ordered.

I decided to get the Kuay Tiew Rua ($11.95) which is just a fancy name for Thai Boat Noodle soup. After ordering I paid and then proceeded to wait outside. I waited and waited and then waited some more. Without exaggeration I waited about 40 minutes in the cold for a simple order of boat noodle soup. Each time I asked about the progress I was told it was it was almost done. Finally, when I asked for the order to be cancelled they gave me the soup. 

I good news is that I got 2 containers one with the noodles and the other with the broth which keeps the noodles from becoming soggy. The bad news is that the broth lacked seasoning. It had a ton of spices as I had asked for spicy but they seemed to be simply added to the broth rather than being properly cooked with it. Another issue was that the quantity of noodles in the order was very little and were all clumped together. Goes without saying I did not like what I got. 

Price-wise this was about 20% more than the same dish in Pak Nam Thai noodle bar and 10% less than Lapats Thai Noodle Bar both of which are just a block down the road. Unfortunately, the quality is nowhere even close to what you can get at the other two places. I had high hopes for Lers Ros given its high ratings but I was thoroughly disappointed with my visit. With so many options in its vicinity I doubt that I will return.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
As soon as I sat down, I knew I was gonna come back to this place.  

The decor is cute and the service is attentive and friendly - we went at 11:30pm, close to their closing time. 

We got the basil chicken and yellow curry - pretty conservative choices because it was a late night dinner - both were very tasty. Every bit of the basil chicken was very flavorful and the texture went perfectly with the rice. The chicken in the curry probably could've been more tender. 

For dessert, we went with a pretty popular choice here: fried banana with strawberry ice-cream. It was very well done and not very messy to eat. The outside of the fried banana wasn't crunchy as I expected, it was a stretchy layer of coating with sesame seeds mixed in the flour - which, in addition to crushed nuts sprinkled on top, did make it pretty crunchy.
author: Iris H.

description:
Nah. Overhyped. Way overhyped. Tonight was my fourth visit here within six months. Last two visits were with larger groups, so I definitely had a chance twice to try a large variety of their dishes. I feel I'm "supposed"to like it, because of all the hype and restaurant-generated pr that they definitely excel at. Every single time, though, I left wondering if it was me who ordered the wrong dishes, or if I was just missing something. It wasn't me. This place knows how to pump up the pr, but little else. 

Food - Many dishes were pretty salty, like the frog and their red curry dishes. Eel was cut into super tiny pieces and were small and bony to get any meat off the eels. Fail. Other places have way more meaty slices. Total waste. roast duck was mostly a soggy glob of fat.
 Tried both the chicken and pork pad see yuck (yes, I mean yuck). Strange, the pork one was super salty and the chicken one was bland, but both had mushy flat noodles. These rice noodles can be difficult to cook, especially if they're not super fresh. I suspect the latter is true.  Clearly, not much effort is made into presentation either, as many of their dishes were accompanied with the same sliced cucumbers, tomatoes and cilantro garnish.

 DIshes I did like were the deep fried tofu and the deep fried crab ball-like appetizer.

Service was certainly no stand out. Seems that you need to ask for any and all water refills. Our waitress was polite, but really wasn't able to sufficiently address questions I had about some dishes I was contemplating between. I sensed a language barrier, on her part.

Nothing special at all about the ambiance inside, but...

TOURISTS BEWARE:
Now the ambiance outside, well, anyone coming here needs to know it's really a sketchy hood that has gotten even worst in recent years. If you don't mind walking by people who are shooting up, drugged out, drunk, in need of serious mental health services, or are asleep on the ground propped up against the wall, then you should be fine. And you need to be ok with the more than normal San Francisco stench of urine all over. If that's hip for you, go at it. Not for me. The food, service and atmosphere is so not worth that! And of course, don't forget the higher than normal rate of car break-ins here in the Tenderloin. Knowing all this in advance, I Ubered here.

Gave it more than a fair chance. Way to many better options in the Foodie Bay Area . No return visit here!!
author: Lori N.

description:
After a long day watching Blue Angels air show my friends and I were getting really hungry. A friend suggested that we should check out this Thai restaurant Lers Ros on 730 Larkin St, San Francisco, CA 94109. 

We made a reservation on our way. -- From Fisherman's Wharf you can get there by bus #47 (about 25 minutes ride) and two block walk from Van Ness Ave. -- At the restaurant we were given a table for three, as expected. 

We ordered: Spicy Shrimp, Pad Thai, Beef with Green Curry, Crab Fried Rice, and some beer. 

Food was really delicious! We also asked for some spicy sauce. I liked mixing curry with crab fried rice. The curry was so good that we asked for more steamed rice just to finish it... :-) 

From all the restaurants that I have been to in San Francisco, Lers Ros is most memorable to me by its superb service!!! 

There were three waitresses on the floor. You can easily spot them in red jackets. All of them stayed far enough to give you space but they paid close attention. As soon as you raise your hand, someone would be there to help instantly. I really mean it! 

Also, my glass was always full with water! I even didn't notice when the waitress filled it. I was impressed with such subtle unobtrusive service. 

In conclusion: great food, extensive menu, outstanding service! I will definitely come again.
author: U V.

description:
Great food just a bit slow service. 
We all got our food except a friend had to wait long time!
author: Solia S.

description:
This place was busy! 

We had a reservation but got there early and they sat us right away. We got the shrimp papaya salad that was delicious and fresh. We got the coconut shrimp soup and that was good and nice to have it on a warmer. We ate the tilapia and that was super spicy I couldn't eat it. We got the seafood pad see yew and they accommodated my friend by using a soy sauce alternative. The squid in it was super chewy. 

They spoon out the rice for you and it's really weird so it makes you think that's all you get and they will take it away. 

We finished the meal with durian and mango sticky rice desserts. The durian was mild. The mango was nice and ripe.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Third time here. Food is overly seasoned (too salty) and excessive use of raw onions and raw cabbage turned me off.

Also concerned about lack of Asian diners, which could mean nothing in a city of discerning consumers of every stripe.

I don't think the high prices and the bad neighborhood make the effort to return here worthwhile.

Service is fine. Food comes out at a good pace.
author: Trish W.

description:
Soooo yummy!! 
There are quite a few Thai options around tenderloin area, but this one rly takes the cake for me. Slightly pricey, but they have great lunch specials. One page allows you to select 2 entree combos vs just 1. 

I was gonna order the tom kha soup on a cold day, but I saw seafood and curry together and was sold. This was on the 1st lunch special page where you can only pick 1 entree. See my picture. Comes with salad and rice, which you can opt for brown if you ask. The curry didn't look like much, but the flavor was so on point!!! So good, only wish I had more. The salad dressing is also light but yummy. all the ingredients were fresh and the restaurant is clean and well maintained.

I found this place on yelp and suggested it to our team for a work holiday outing (my manager is the best!) And our entire party of 8 loved their food.

They allow reservations, though they don't get too crowded til around 1pm. Beware when calling, the Thai accent is quite thick!

I will definitely be returning !  Their menu is intense, 100+ items. They also serve up specialty exotic meats, like alligator, venison, quail, boar, frog... and of course vegetarian options too.  The options are endless ;)
author: Angela C.

description:
Really cool decor in a modern setting. For me food was only so so! Place is in a shady area but it's ok. Service was ok but a little bit of attitude from some. 

The crispy pork belly was extremely average and too salty. The Nuer Yang - beef with lime juice was also too salty and tasted like lime juice from a squeezy bottle not fresh. 

On the whole I think it was overpriced and caters to the tourists more than the authenticity of being a Northern Thai restaurant.
author: Mark J.

description:
Our waiter, Jeremy, seriously is the coolest dude I've ever met.  So friendly and attentive and very helpful about what items to order on the menu.  He made this experience such an enjoyable one.  He made sure that our entire dining experience was perfect, that the food was tasty and cooked to perfection and made us just as happy as possible.  I would come back JUST to have him serve us again.  

We came here on a Sunday around 1:00pm for lunch.  There was not many people at all, very slow Sunday afternoon.  
Be mindful of the area you have to walk through to get to this amazing restaurant.  The Tenderloin is pretty rough and I don't recommend anyone walks through here at night time and if you do have to, make sure you have somebody to accompany you. 

We ordered many different foods of which all were delicious.
1. Pad See Ew (w/pork): the noodles were rich and tender.  Very enjoyable, it is hard to finish this entire meal though... I tried to stuff myself and regretted it later. 
2. Thai Curry Puffs: GET THESE.  They are amazing and so soft, sweet, savory, and crispy all at the same time.  YUM!
3. Chicken Satay: pretty good.  Just some average tasting chicken on a stick (lol) but tasty nevertheless.
4. Red Curry dish: A friend ordered this and said it was the best curry he's ever eaten.  (he even later went to a different thai restaurant to compare he two red curries and mentioned later that Lers Ros tasted wayyy better ;) )
5. Moo Preaw Warn: a sweet and sour pork dish.  Tasty and sweet.  
6. Mango Sticky Rice:  So much sauce and such perfect texture.  The mango was so ripe and juicy and this was honestly just the best part of the meal. ( so sad I was stuffed already to be able to enjoy this desert to the fullest extent) BUT I'm glad we tried it.  It's very good.

If you want good, authentic thai food Lers Ros takes much pride on their food.  I definitely will be back because my first experience here was 5/5 (:
author: Tori G.

description:
Delicious! I highly highly recommend the:

-Quail with sweet and spicy sauce,
-Fried fish with a savory mango dipping sauce,
-Crab fried rice,
-Vegetarian Tom Yum soup

You won't be disappointed! Sorry no pictures. We ate everything :)
author: Mary Y.

description: My favorite Thai food spot in the city for both a nice evening out and for delivery.   We frequently go there before the symphony (they are super fast).
author: Charles L.

description:
Lers Ros is a lovely little Thai place with lots of options.

FOOD:
+ Koh Moo Yang ($12.95): Grilled slices of pork shoulder served with chili and rice powder sauce. If you have to get anything from Lers Ros, GET THIS. This is so so so good! The pork is flavored really well and very tender, and the sauce just makes it that much better. 

+ Pad Thai ($12.95): On the menu, this automatically comes with prawns. I don't know if there's an option to substitute the prawns for another type of protein, but I was ok with prawns. Yes, I know. How uncreative of us-- going to a Thai place and ordering Pad Thai. But in our defense, we wanted to order the Pad Thai because it's something that all Thai places typically serve and we wanted a benchmark dish to compare to other places. This may have been a mistake, as I thought the Pad Thai was only so-so here. It wasn't terrible, but it also wasn't the best that I've ever had. 

+ Kang Karee (Yellow Curry) ($13.95 with rice place, a la carte $14.95): Another staple dish. This was pretty tasty, though pretty expensive for the amount that we got.

If I'm being honest with myself, for the food that we ordered, this is probably more of a 3.5 for me when I take into account taste and price, but maybe we didn't order the right dishes? The Koh Moo Yang was amazing, so I give props for that.

tl;dr: Location is not the greatest, but I would come here again to try some other dishes. Would definitely get the Koh Moo Yang again!
author: Lillian Z.

description:
All really good, legit Thai food but...SUPER SPICY!! All of us had our mouths on fire haha. My favorites were the special fish, pad see ew (I've had this plenty of times elsewhere but here it was bomb), and the crispy pork. Yum!! I'd say those are the must get items imo. 

The soups were also delicious, Tom Kha (spicy, mix with rice!) and Tom Kha Gai (coconut Thai chicken soup). 

Nice that they dimmed the lights and played happy bday for our friend. Docking a star for not being seated until 40 minutes after our reservation on a Saturday night. Otherwise, delicious Thai food :)
author: Raquel Y.

description:
If you're taste buds are used to salty anything then this is ur place. Not mine.
Lots of rice may neutralize it.
author: Julian D.

description:
Favorite Thai food in the city. 

Must Tries:
Crab fried rice.
Crispy chicken with ginger rice.
Sparerib appetizer.
author: Kerwin L.

description:
Yum yum yum. Had dinner with a group of friends last night and was so grateful for my meal. Everything was delectable. 

Had ordered:
Koh Moo Yang (Grilled slices of Pork Shoulder, served with chili & rice powder sauce)
Kang Daeng w/rice & chicken (Red curry with Thai eggplant, bamboo shoot , red bell peppers, kaffir lime leaves)
Pad See-Ew w/beef 
Lers Ros special combo plate (Green Papaya Salad with Grilled Shrimps, BBQ Chicken, Served with Sticky Rice)
Mango Sticky Rice

I can't remember the last time I ate family style at a restaurant and liked every dish. Not a single one was a downer. 

Lers Ros' minions, Flavors and Freshness, dominated my mouth last night. Frankly, I submit defeat graciously. 

I'd frequent this restaurant if I could/didn't live an hour away. All in all- it is a fantastic dinner choice and I say you should go. Gets busy though, so keep in mind that. We had reservations for 5 people last night, but still had to wait 15 minutes before being sat down. Other than that, service is great. If you're into that constant water filling thing, then you'll like it here. Just go go go.
author: Mimi N.

description:
I feel like its grown in popularity but the quality went down. I haven't been back in few years and I remember it being better. I had the red curry with tofu/veggies and it was overly sweet. I never had a sweet Thai curry before and thought it was weird. There was barely any tofu either. Friends who got other dishes thought it was so-so. 

Service was decent, not bad. Pretty crowded with lot of take out orders and wait time for larger party 20-30 minutes.
author: James H.

description: Great lunch specials. Whenever I am in town I make a special stop here for some ridiculous thai food.
author: Anthony B.

description:
We ordered catering food from Lers Ros at Larkin for our baby shower last weekend. So happy to have chosen them.

Ordering on the phone was super easy. We ordered from Menu D (only vegetarian) for 10 people and Menu A (regular) for 15 people. They were very nice to exchange one item from menu A with menu B - the chicken satay appetiser instead of the moo phing.

They came on time on the day of the party and food was well packed. Everyone loved the food.  

Pad Thai, Moo Pad Makuer (Stir-fried eggplant, pork, green bell peppers, with garlic chili sauce and basil), Kang Keaw Wan (Green curry with vegetables and sliced chicken & Galingale) as well as the vegetarian Pad Pauk Raummit (Stir-fried mixed vegetables in bean sauce) was the first one to finish along with Kang Dang Pak (Red curry with vegetables and tofu) was delicious as well. 

All in all, food was delicious so very happy with the choice. It turned out to be $18 per person plus tax so quite reasonable.

Looking forward to visiting the restaurant and have the sit down experience after the great catering service. Highly recommend the catering for parties.
author: Heliana M.

description:
Such a fresh papaya salad n brown rice. One of the best spots open up late. After hours, 
Shrimp was so fresh as well.
author: Tania A.

description:
My absolute favorite place to get Thai food -- scratch that, even when I'm not craving Thai food, this is one of the first places to pop up in my head when it comes to restaurant choices.

This location is in a bit of a gritty area, but it's the closest location to me. If I'm feeling particularly lazy, I just call in my order and pick it up. There is a bit of a language barrier sometimes, depending on who picks up the phone, so I try to keep my questions and requests a bit more basic. I've also dined in here and have found the service to be just fine. 

I've had:
1. Red curry (with duck and also with beef separate times) - very creamy, with a lot of flavor and a bit on the spicy side. I've noticed that they do not ask you how spicy you'd like this, and when it comes out, it's a little on the spicy side, however, it's not too spicy for me to handle. I absolutely love this with the duck, as the meat is so tender. I don't recall much about the beef, so I feel like that was just fine.

2. Tom yum soup - very good here. The perfect amount of sour.

3. Papaya salad with prawns - I love love love the papaya salad here. My bf is not a fan of it as it's made with a bit more fish sauce than other Thai places, however, I do not mind this at all. One time, I requested this to be spicy, which was the worst decision I have ever made in my life. My mouth was on fire; I actually started picking out the Thai bird peppers in the salad and eventually ended up with a huge mound of peppers. In short, do not get this spicy.

4. Pad Thai - Slightly better than your typical pad thai. Good flavor plus the lime on the side adds the sour element that I love. However, it's just pad thai, you know?

5. Stir fry pork belly - one of the famed items here. I thought it was good and a nice choice out of your "typical" Thai orders. I was hoping the pork skin would be more crunchy, and some of the pork pieces were a little dry (just some!). In all, still good, but I don't feel the need to order it again.
author: Jacqueline V.

description:
I got delivery via Postmates.  Food was not great.  

Rolls were fine.
Garlic spareribs terrible - very tough.
Pad Thai - noodles were a bit mushy and not much flavor.
Eggplant was okay.  

I really wanted to like this place and delivery was fast.  But I will not order again..
author: Sharon P.

description: Honestly came here because everything else in the downtown area vicinity was closed at the time. They have an eclectic menu- from traditional Thai food to rabbit and alligator. Wasn't too adventurous this day and also questioned where they would get fresh alligator or rabbit from.  Went with the Thai spicy shrimp paste tray, pad kee eu, and papaya salad with shrimp and Thai iced tea. The noodles, salad and tea were great! Can't say I've ever had bad versions of these. The shrimp tray I would pass on. Wasn't what I was expecting. Overall not bad. Good traditional Thai food. Would go back to try more of their menu.
author: Linda H.

description:
We came with a medium sized group and ordered a variety of things, and were pretty happy with everything that came our way.

I had a crispy chicken served on a bed of garlic and ginger rice.

Also would recommend any of the noodle dishes, and also a Thai puff pastry appetizer.
author: Shourjo D.

description:
There's so much hype about Lers Ros in sf, but the food is just so bland for its price. It's missing a lot of the flavors that make thai food so delicious! Portion size is also on the smaller side.

Curries aren't that flavorful, and papaya salad is so so. I do like the tom yum koong and friend banana desert, though. 

The Larkin location is Great for accommodating big groups in terms of seating, but remember to over order if you're trying to feed everyone.
author: Dee Dee T.

description:
Came to Lers Ros many, many years ago before they became popular and remodeled and remembered this place as a very sweet, local and authentic Thai restaurant.  We were in the TL neighborhood over the weekend and decided to come here for any early dinner.  We were seated right away and the prices on the overwhelming menu definitely skyrocketed!  Everything was over $13+, even for appetizers.  Fine, I guess it's the cost of living in SF, right?  

We were genuinely overwhelmed with the 2 different menus and asked the waitress for some recommendations.  She pointed like 20 different things (very fast) and didn't really help narrowing down the choices.  

We ordered 4 dishes for 4 of us to share.  One of the waitress's recommendation was a crispy pork belly in sauce.  Their crispy pork belly is basically the Chinese roast pork smothered with sauce.  The sauce was tasty but I didn't think it was so special to warrant a $16 price tag.  The crab fried rice, the Pad See Eew and the Yellow Curry were all, meh.  I didn't think the dishes were that spectacular and the service was also almost non-existent.  

An additional star shaved off their ratings due to the poor design of their tables/chairs and bathrooms.  The chairs are basically wooden stools so (1) they are very uncomfortable because you can't lean back and (b)  you don't have any place to hang your purse or your coat.  It's the most unrelaxing environment at a restaurant I experienced, having to balance my bulking jacket and my purse on my lap the whole time!  * we had 4 people and were seated at a table with 4 chairs/stools.  

The bathroom is upstairs and the ceiling is so low I walk in fear that I will hit my head somewhere and I'm only 5'7".  All that time I'm thinking how is this legal and pass the building/planning department.  

So yeah, not coming back anytime soon.
author: Jannie Q.

description:
Great authentic flavors. 

I am so surprised that I've never heard of this place until recently. The food is so good here! I came here for lunch because my best friend was raving about the dry noodles. 

Yes. Get the dry noodles because they are amazing. There is so much sweet, sour, and salt and yet it's not overpowering at all. I seriously recommend this dish. The noodles were cooked well and I loved the sauce. Mix everything up well before consuming. 

We also ordered the duck salad. If you like the gaminess in duck, you'll like this. It's a mixture of flavors and textures that are so addicting. 

We also ordered the tom yum because we couldn't skip out on it. It was good. I don't remember it being as amazing as the dry noodles, but still very good. 

The curry puffs were a yummy way to start. It was a nice shareable item while we waited for the other goods. 

I would definitely come here again. I have no idea where else they sell that dry noodle, but I know I'll be craving it.
author: Tina Y.

description:
The hotel recommended this place.  First off the location is a bit dicey, but once you get past that you're in for some really awesome Thai food.  Was on holiday in SF and I heard the Asian food is quite good over here.  I had also been craving some really good Thai as I had yet to have some actual authentic Thai food, have pretty much been settling so far.  Came for lunch and it was pretty quiet - a Tuesday.  This place has a bar as well if you want to have some drinks.

Actually we ended up coming back here again so this review is for both visits.  We ordered the Pad Thai with Shrimp, Lunch special with Chicken Red Curry and Kai Pad Khing and on the second visit the Pad See Ew with Beef, Green Curry and Kao Pad.

Pad Thai with Shrimp ($12.95) - I was a bit worried this was going to be overly sweet or something, sometimes you can't tell even when a place has really great reviews.  I asked for extra spicy and it was perfect - just the right amount of spice and it tasted soooo good!!! Really awesome and proper authentic Pad Thai, they had infused the spice so it wasn't just chillies all over the place - definitely recommend trying this dish, it was a standout.
Lunch Special, Red Curry Chicken and Kai Pad Khing ($11.95) - The ginger in the Kai Pad Khing was really fresh and strong - in a good way.  But I would suggest not getting the lunch specials/combos, they seem like they're quite standard, you can't make any changes like asking for extra spicy so guess they must be buffet style - go a la carte.  It wasn't bad but tasted a bit food courtish (not a word I know).
Pad See Ew with Beef ($12.95) - At first the waitress said that they couldn't do extra spicy for this but got her to check with the chef, as I got the Pad Thai extra spicy the day before so was sure they could do the same for this - and they can.  Again another awesome dish, great taste and good spice level - it was quite spicy but just right   Wouldn't suggest beef though, was a bit chewy, would try the shrimp next time.
Kang Keaw Wan - Green Curry ($14.95) - Really great too, flavourful and good quantity.
Thai Fried Rice ($11.95) - Delicious, just like the Kao Pad in Thailand, Australia and NZ - both of which also have super authentic Thai places.

Quantity - Great quantity, we couldn't finish it all, of course on the second day we did overorder.
Ambience - Small casual scene, went during weekday lunch times so not sure how it is during dinner time.
Service - Great service, accommodating and attentive.
Spice - 4/5, Perfect amount of spice, actually bordering on a 5 since I did ask for extra but it wasn't an overkill which real Thai hot can be.
Taste - Amazing, reminded me of the authentic Thai which was on every corner in AU and NZ and which I haven't had in the longest time.

Overall the best Thai I've had in US so far, and I've tried a few now in Atlanta, Dallas and NJ.  This place was so good we had to have it again, actually had it 3 times as we ordered it through uber eats for dinner as well - it's that good and couldn't risk trying something else that I wouldn't love.  Get the Pad Thai, I'd say it was the best item I tried and seems to be a signature dish for the restaurant.  And if you like spice, go ahead and ask for extra spicy, it's worth it
author: Jacqui H.

description: Highly recommend this place. They easily accommodated my group of 10 even with a delay in our groups arrival. The menu was extremely thorough and had so many options to keep everyone in the group happy. We had the papaya salad, which was pleasantly less spicy than most places, chicken satay, tom yum soup (the mushrooms were very tasty!), along with pad kree ow noodles, a red curry, Thai fried fish, and one chicken daily special, and it was plenty for about 7 of us that were sharing. Highly recommend all the dishes that I tried (the vegetarian ones). I also loved all the vegetarian options.
author: Neekta H.

description:
Good Thai food for an ok price! You know it's authentic because they use so much fish sauce that's the first thing you smell once you step inside the restaurant.

Between 2 people, we got the red curry with duck (since everyone raved about it) and the pad see ew with beef. The red curry was good, not too spicy, but wasn't anything too special IMO. The pad see ew had a LOT of beef that I wish there was more noodle. Guess that's really a non-issue....

Ask for the chili sauce and condiment platter because it has pickled jalapenos which I love to put on stuff.
author: Sally L.

description:
I don't live in San Fran but I have visited this restaurant each time I've visited and it always hits the spot. 

My FAVORITE dish of theirs is a soup with a lemongrass broth - it is the most amazing soup that I've ever had. The flavors are perfectly balanced and tantalize your palette.

This place has ruined Thai food for me because I know the other places I go to back home will not be like this!
author: Rebecca F.

description:
Pad Thai Noodles with Crab is delicious! 
Just wish I could get more crab meat and egg with it :D
author: Ariene S.

description: I really wanted to like this place. Service was excellent. But the food was just meh. My wife is Thai and we both enjoyed the sausage. But the BBQ chicken was average for me and her steamed fish was too sour. And it's definitely not a bargain eats place in the TL. $119.00 for dinner. SMH. And yeah the chairs/stools are ridiculously uncomfortable.
author: Hugh J.

description:
Great Thai food place! 

When I mean good, it's not any Thai food place with pad Thai or pad sea wee all the time. Lers Ros has variety of selections of Thai dishes when you want Thai food but not only pad Thai. 

Highly recommend the Fish dish&the lettuce wrap.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Walked in on a Wednesday @ 10:30 and found plenty of seating... 

It was pretty late & I didn't want to over do it so I ordered #45 spicy veggies w/ tofu - yes, a tiny bit on the salty side but definitely delicious!!! 


Will be back to try more options :-)
author: Lilia R.

description: The best ever Thai food I have eaten in my life and I have eaten a lot of it. Everything we ordered was fabulous. This is my new place to go to.

This version of Lers Ros was my first introduction to this now burgeoning restaurant chain, and there's a casual ambiance that separates this location from it's more refined Hayes Valley and Mission sites.  I tend to think of this location as being great for a casual lunch with friends, while the other two locations may be better suited for a romantic date.  However, in both of the sites I've tried, the Thai food served is always on point.

One of my favorite items is the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob, which combines pork belly sections with basil leaves in a lightly spicy sauce.  The way that they keep the skin delightfully crispy while keeping the pork tender is a feat of magic, and my only complaint would be that on my most recent visit, they held back on the spice despite my request (don't worry, Lers Ros-I can handle the heat).  The service is good though somewhat impersonal; you will probably have several servers attending to you during the evening.  However, the food is a standout, and I definitely will be back again and again!
author: Keith H.

description:
The BEST service in the world and it actually smells like Thailand inside. 
Quality ingredients and sooooooo GOOD. It's my go to place to take my friends and family when they visit me. 
Sounds super basic but my favorite dish is the crust chicken in fried rice with chili dipping sauce. #57 on the menu. But there's a lot of fun menu items like frog legs, curry puffs and more. Go and expand your horizons!
author: Anne P.

description: Have been coming here for a couple of years ! Lers Ros has the best Thai food in all of California. The Tom Yum soup is delicious and lemony. They have a couple of other locations here in San Francisco all with great service and amazing food !
author: Michelle A.

description: My fiancé and I had to walk quite a bit from union square to get to this restaurant but it was the only Thai restaurant in the area with good reviews. So after a long walk to get this restaurant we were expecting some really good food and I have to say that the food did not disappoint. And you can never go wrong with Singha beer with some yummy curry!
author: Amaneet G.

description:
Place - the location is not safe. It is in tenderloin. There are many homeless near here. Inside, the interior is clean and modern. There are many tables and a bar. But chair is not comfortable. 

Taste - always great food. Lunch menu is good. The plate came with a small salad. Salad was fresh. The taste is not same with normal thai testuarent like house of thai, better than others. I ordered seafood one and pork one. Both were great. Source made harmony with ingredents. But the amount of food was little bit small. I needed more. 

Service and Price - Service was good. and Price was reasonable.
author: Da Won L.

description: The amount of times I've been to this restaurant is unaccounted. Love this casual Thai cuisine. Their service, the restaurant ambience, the cost is all perfect. They bring out the food pretty fast so it's a great option for lunch between work hours. I love their fresh coconut that I always get. With that I get the prawns with basil and chili. Great combination.
author: Julia J.

description:
I would never have found this place had it not been through a friend's recommendation, and I'm so glad we gave it a go. The menu is HUGE, almost too big, but very authentic. It's a nice ambiance without being formal, but it's cozy with long communal tables in the middle and a bar when you walk in, so I'm sure it's a neighborhood haunt for many. It was the first time I've seen Chang on the menu since I was in Thailand so I got one of those and my go to: pad kee mao with shrimp. The portion was huge, and very fresh flavors with a generous portion of shrimp. My friends ordered a duck stir fry and truly one of the best pad thai I've ever tasted. 

The service was a little odd, the duck came out first, followed 5 minutes later by my noodles, then 10 minutes later the pad thai, so I'm not sure if it's all meant to be shared or if the kitchen was just backed up that night. It's definitely a rough neighborhood, but far better than many of the other thai restaurants in the area.
author: Lauren M.

description:
I've been wanting to try out this restaurant for a long time and we finally got our chance tonight. It was definitely worth the wait and the entire experience was amazing. The decor was classy and very welcoming. They were a little busy when we arrived but we got a table fairly quickly. The service was great and they were able to answer all of our questions easily and with a smile on their faces. Everyone seemed to be enjoying themselves and having fun. The food was very tasteful, flavorful, visually appealing, and plenty. We got a few items to share and none of them disappointed.

I would highly recommend this place at any time and will definitely be stopping by again.
author: Camera P.

description:
Lers Ros would always be my go to for Pad Thai and crispy pork belly with basil. Those two dishes are my top favorites. Try their Larb too...you will enjoy it. I like the fact that the taste never changed and that their prices are reasonable.
Try Lers Ros...they are so good you will thank me for my review.
author: Ka K.

description:
There are several locations and this one is by far the worst of what is a really good Thai food chain. Besides the seriously bad location, everything from the layout to the service to the food was subpar.  

Since we were a group of 20, we made reservations in advance and instead of giving us the large long table (which was unoccupied) they split our group into 2 sets of 10 which was just logistically a nightmare. In addition, the food came out at all different times, which normally would have been fine except that our 3 vegetarian friends, who had ordered first, literally had to wait for an hour and a half for their food. I live near the Hayes Valley location, and have gone often enough that I've tasted many of the more popular dishes. That being said, this location did not balance the flavors well. Many dishes lacked the wonderful complex, savory aspects that the same dishes at other locations have. Other dishes were just way too spicy and overall, I would recommend by-passing this place and consider going to the Hayes Valley location.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Sunday evening around 8:30. We had originally been planning on grabbing ramen at Mensho, but since the wait was pretty ridiculous, we gave up and came to Lers Ros instead. Given that this place is pretty popular, I was expecting a short wait for our group of 3, but we got seated within minutes.

I opted for a lighter meal as I wasn't too hungry. The garlic and pepper rabbit on their daily specials menu caught my attention, so I went with that as it's been years since I last had rabbit meat. The server warned me that the dish would be very bony, but I grew up eating meat off of bones, so I wasn't too worried. Both of my friends ordered different curries.

Our food came out within a reasonable amount of time. The garlic and pepper rabbit was indeed full of bones like our server had warned me, so keep that in mind if you're looking to get it. It was exactly what I wanted though, which was something light to nibble on while my friends ate. 

There wasn't too much meat on each piece, but it was extremely garlic-y, to the point where I couldn't taste any other flavors on the meat (or the natural taste of the meat itself). It was overly salty too, so I had to eat each bite of the meat with some rice. It took me a while to get through all the pieces, since they gave a generous amount for this dish and I had a lot of pieces to go through.

My friends seemed to enjoy their green and red curries, respectively.
author: Dianna H.

description: What a great find! This place is right down the street from me and was a gem! We got pad see ew, bbq pork skewers, and fried rice. We took this all togo. I always get pad see ew where ever I go and this place does an amazing job! I asked for medium spicy and it still wasn't spicy enough for me I will ask for hot next time. We asked for hot sauce on the side but they wouldn't give us anymore then one small portion cup. The bbq pork skewers were fantastic! The chili lime sauce is to die for! I would go back for the sauce alone! The pork was perfectly cooked not too dry and very flavorful! The fried rice was normal but still good! Price is very normal high but worth every cent! Our totally got the three dishes was $42. I'll be back... probably sooner then I think!
author: Megan M.

description:
Service was exceptional! The food was excellent as well. 

The duck over rice (#58) had the right amount of lean to fat meat ratio, so the texture and flavor worked together well! The chili sauce that comes with it was also super good! 

I ordered the pork belly (#62), and I have no regrets! The pork belly had super crispy skin and melts in your mouth fat. The overall flavor was just perfect, and I highly recommend this! :)
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Lers Ros is a bougie Thai place that has a comprehensive list of dishes. It's has quality food but at a steep price. On top of the priceness, it's located in a rough neighborhood, SF's very own cultural epicenter, the Tenderloin. The food itself is very good. Portions are a bit smaller than you would expect for the price. If I was unfortunate enough to be in this neighborhood and wanted Thai food, I might take refuge in Lers Ros. 

Service is quick and friendly. The venue is clean and chic, minus the shitty Tenderloin on the outside.

I ordered the:
Crispy pork belly - the pork belly was the best!
Papaya salad
Pad lad ra
Sticky rice with mango
author: Sean W.

description:
We went here after watching broadway at the Orpheum Theatre. This place stays open till late and was pretty much walking distance from the theatre.

The food was good. We really loved the thai curry puff though the sauce was too sweet - a 5/5 for sure. The fish cake was decent - not too great but a 3/5. The flat noodles with chicken were okay - 3/5. Overall a decent place for late night meal comparing to other American fare like bars and Burger King.
author: Rohit R.

description:
Came here for dinner before meeting friends at a karaoke place nearby.

It was late...around 9PM when we arrived, and found the dimly-lit Thai spot to still be full of people in large groups at the communal tables and smaller couples and groups seated at the smaller tables. There was amazing service that was so attentive, from the beer pouring to the smiley servers who came by to refill out waters and check on our food! 

I loved their red curry, which was filled with tons of veggies and green eggplant that looked just like limes! Boo enjoyed his duck in the red curry, and we also ordered a side of garlic rice to go with our curry. The pad thai was also very huge in portions, and filled us both up. We thought the sauce used was too sweet, but very flavorful. Fresh thai food here, and not too fancy or romantic for a casual night out!

I haven't found my favorite SF Thai spot, but Lers Ros is my favorite casual thai spot in Tenderloin that is still affordable and perfect in portion. If I'm looking for more of a modern and bougier Thai spot, Kin Khao is still my favorite spot to go for craft Thai.
author: Jodi H.

description:
The mango sticky rice was AMAZING, greatest asian dessert ever. We ordered one with the dishes to come out at the same time, so we started with it and then ordered another afterwards. (We were 2 people.)

We ordered the garlic rabbit and garlic frog which were really similar but I'd recommend the frog more. Definitely one of the better Thai places I've been to.

The service here was very good.
author: Xi W.

description:
Lers Ros might be a tad spendier than a run-of-the-mill hole in the wall, but they do offer a huge variety of dishes with some unusual ingredients (at least for Americanized palates when it comes to Thai food) such as rabbit, alligator, and venison. 

I tried the kang phed yang - a red curry with roasted duck, bamboo shoots, red bell peppers, tomatoes, and chunk pineapples - and found it a decent dish overall. Not out-of-this-world mindblowing, but definitely not bad. The portion size was reasonably modest when taking the price into consideration.

Service was courteous only to the extent necessary, and was otherwise just a bit checked out, despite the relatively empty venue when I showed up. It's rare that I have a Thai meal that I don't thoroughly enjoy, but something just seemed missing for me. If I'm with folks that insist on coming here, however, I'll be sure to try more of their many, many menu items.
author: Vincent L.

description: Our SF guide recommended this place, and as it was a short walk from our hotel, we decided to go on our last night in town... we're so glad we went. Great atmosphere, great service and great food. If ever back in town, we'll definitely be back.
author: Maria R.

description: Plastic bag found in food! Disgusting. Rude service - not allowed to sit where we want in an EMPTY restaurant.
author: W S.

description:
Stopped by for a quick dinner before a concert at the American music hall. Some of the best Thai I've ever had. 

We ordered the spicy shrimp and eggplant, pad see ew, and green curry. I loved all of it. 

Pad see ew is a hit or miss dish; kind of tastes different everywhere but this dish was spot on. The spicy shrimp and eggplant was also really killer and is my new favorite Thai dish. 

If you are in the city and looking for Thai this is a must try.
author: Shay I.

description: Craved late night Thai and this place stays open till midnight. Ordered the beef red curry which was very tasty and creamy and the chicken satay was just ok slightly bland. My friend had the chicken fried rice and she loved it.
author: Ara A.

description:
My first meal after moving to SF :-)

We met here for a casual meet up and Lers Ros did not disappoint... the lunch specials are great

Chicken Satay - Two chicken skewers with peanut dipping sauce and pickled cucumbers/onions... the peanut dipping sauce is one of the best i've had and paired well with the chicken

Green Curry with Pork - nice heat and good amount of vegetables and pork... the coconut milk added creaminess to the curry

Lers Ros is known as a great thai spot and will be part of my rotating list of regular restaurants
author: Peter H.

description: The foods come in big portions.  Some of the waiters seem to confused with our order. Overall the foods are good.
author: Nui W.

description:
I like the setting, but it can get busy. My friends & I were squished at a smaller table in order to be seated, but I am thankful they did that for us rather than making us wait.

We ordered a plum sake and it was delicious! It wasn't too sweet or too strong, so it was a great way for us to have a drink with our meal.

The food was excellent! I can't remember exactly what we ordered but I do remember being impressed by it all. I would definitely return on a date night or a night out with friends.
author: Hanna J.

description:
Mainly speaking for the 5 spice duck. 

Ordered through caviar, when my order arrived I was so bumped that for over $14 I only got 5 small strips of duck and it was literally ALL FAT and zero meat. The skin wasn't even crispy which was even worse.
author: Aliah A.

description: I enjoyed my experience at Lers Ros, definitely one of the better places in San Francisco for some authentic tasting Thai food. There was a slight tendency for the food to be a bit oily, which made me feel a bit queasy after sharing a couple of dishes with friends. All in all, pretty decent place -- I don't understand the extreme hype to be honest but it's a place worth checking out.
author: David Y.

description: Three words: Durian Sticky Rice. I've been to Lers Ros thrice, once for lunch and twice for dinner and every single time the food has been pretty good but not mind-blowingly good--EXCEPT for the durian sticky rice dessert. Yeah, yeah, yeah, most people say it "smells like vomit" or "smells like rotten eggs". It smells like a lot of things, guys. (Did you really think the King of Fruit got its title by just smelling like one thing?! Please.) So why would you want to deliberately put something that smells suspicious in your mouth? Glad you asked, I have 3 good reasons: a) nowhere else in San Francisco (or this continent) will you find this tropical fruit, b) it's seasonal, so Lers Ros doesn't even always have it, and c) it's the most deliciously sweet and rich fruit you'll ever try. Ever. No fruit on the face of this planet is as rich in flavor as the durian. You can hold your nose if you can't stand the smell, but you have got to try it. And it goes oh so incredibly well with the sticky rice. I mean, what doesn't go with rice, sticky or not? Such a versatile grain! I'm clearly Asian, guys, shut up. In all seriousness though, don't fill up on the curries or noodles, because you're gonna want to eat some more rice with that durian.
author: Rie U.

description: We came for graduation dinner and the food and service was excellent for party of 9 on a game night.  The price is reasonable too!
author: Suzanne C.

description:
Mango sticky rice - absolutely amazing!!!  Highly recommend!!! You can't go wrong there!!

However,

The durian sticky rice was the nastiest thing I have ever tasted. We should have known... it smelt so bad when we received it and it was wrapped twice in plastic bags. Hahaha. It was almost comical how bad it was. 
Please please don't get it. I still feel queasy thinking about it.  
Apparently, durian is an acquired taste that I won't be acquiring!

Everything else is delicious!!!
author: Nisha M.

description: Okay, not fantastic. Had pad thai, papaya salad (extremely salty), fried ribs, and crispy chicken over garlic ginger rice, thai ice tea (extremely sweet).  None of it worthy of returning.
author: Diane H.

description: We went there last and the food and service was great!  I am posting pics and the cold duck with lettuce was awesome!  Loved all of these dudes and the sticky mango rice was great!  Price for the 4 of us was less than $90 plus gratuity.
author: David S.

description: Probably one of the best thai places I've been. The flavors explode. Friendly service. The whole sea bass cooked in a concoction of basil, seafood broth, garlic, lemon grass, and cilantro is off the hook!
author: Mel B.

description: Really good food . Me and my girl loved it . She has to eat GF and it was bomb and she had options which is nice
author: George M.

description: Their soups are really great! Amazing flavors, species and fresh veggies! I loved it! Great choices for vegetarians and it's a must try restaurant if you are in the neighborhood!
author: Premila M.

description:
We came here for the second dinner of the day and the place was packed on a Tuesday night. We ordered a bunch of appetizers for the group to share. Pretty much every dish we ordered was tasty and seems pretty authentic. I recommend getting sticky rice to eat along with your food! So much better than white rice. 

Nuer Tod (Fried Sun-Dried Beef) This tastes kind of like beef jerky to me as it was chewy. You'll like this dish if you like beef jerky. It comes with a chili sauce that you dip your meat in. The sauce is spicy, but super good. 

Kor moo yang (Grilled Pork) The dish contains mouth-watering pieces of pork shoulders. They were soft, tender, and flavorful. It also comes with a spicy dipping sauce like the Nuer Tod. I liked this one better than the beef dish above.

Nam tok moo (Thai Spicy Pork Salad) This was my favorite dish. The pork was crispy and crunchy and godly. 

Thai Herb Sausage. The sausage had a lot of spices in it and was pretty good.

Kana moo grob (Stir Fried Pork Belly and Chinese Broccoli) This was unbelievably delicious!! It features crispy pork belly (three whole layers of pork) with Chinese broccoli stir fried with garlic and possibly oyster sauce. Fattening, but delicious.

Yum talay (Thai Seafood Salad) This was my least favorite dish among what we ordered. The seafood is half-cooked and mixed in for the salad. There was not a lot of taste in it.

After I've finished eating, my lips were kinda burning from the spiciness of all the foods, but so worth it! Dip everything in the sauces!
author: Julia K.

description: A really good thai place that I highly recommend for you to try! I ordered the food home, quick delivery. Great for vegetarians. Their green curry and pad thai were delicious. Their fried tofu appetizer had a little less flavour. Definitely a place to check out if you're in the mood to try thai!
author: Ashish S.

description: I've been to the 16th St Lers Ros many times and have always wanted to come to the original. I was able to make a same day reservation for 2 for 8pm. It's a livelier atmosphere here, more casual whereas 16th st feels more intimate. The food was Yum!  The flavors just explode in your mouth. We ordered smoked pork shoulder appy, the dry Tom Yum soup noodle and pepper chicken.  We've had these before at 16th st and they were Yum there. Here, all the flavors were kicked up a notch- flavor explosion in mouth!  Could def see these pairing well with drinks and could imagine this being awesome street food, right in the streets of Thailand.
author: Kathryn C.

description: Came to SF to watch Les Mis. But before the show its a must to grab a bite. I love exploring the many restaurants the city has to offer but there is one restaurant i always find myself coming back to! Lers Ros!! Its like 4 blocks from civic, so its a decent walk to build your appetite. On your walk to the restaurant you'll pass bu the street natives and the smelly smells but what can you say...its San Francisco. The restaurant is small in size but you can fit a a nice party. It has a cool color scheme that makes the environment stress free. Its small so i hope you don't mind giving up a little personal space but then again in San Francisco personal space does not exist. The food is phenomenal! I LOVE getting the spring rolls because their peanut sauce is off the hook. I think they have a pretty good peanut sauces and i've tried a few so take my word! I ordered the number 57 (Kao Pad Kai Tod). Its crispy chicken over fried rice with their vinegar sauce! F**** delicious! The chicken had a thin layer of crispy batter that made the chicken and vinegar combo the best. The fried rice was perfect and i've tried a lot of different Thai Fried Rices so take my WORD! I had to take a bite before the pic but it was sooooo worth it. definitely will need a nice J to end this meal with a happy ending!
author: Irvin R.

description: Wow, prices are $3-6 less online than they are when you walk 2 miles to get here for a "cheap thai night". Just like bangkok  service somewhere between mediocre and bad. Yikes
author: Lily F.

description:
This is for a phone take out order. The restaurant itself isn't very big but there seems to be plenty of seating for small parties (2 ppl). It's dimly lit. For some odd reason that I can't fathom - the speakers are placed near the cashier's and you really have to scream at the waitress there to be heard. We had screamed our orders when we had placed the order via phone call, under the assumption there was a full house. There wasn't. It was a miracle that the waitress even heard the phone now that I think back on it. 
Regardless, the food was pretty good. We got the duck larb, pad see ew, and green curry. The duck larb was my favorite. Slightly sour, full of spice and flavor, all rolled into a cabbage slice. YUMS. Then the pad see ew (vegetarian) satisfied my noodle craving. The green curry was so spicy, perfect for those who don't mind burning a few taste buds here and there. I can totally see us getting takeout from here again. It's not the cheapest Thai place either so try to keep it to once a week order.
author: Michelle R.

description:
Ordered to-go.

Parking is very scare in the area, come prepared.

Quick service, pretty good Pad See Ew.
author: Tom P.

description: A classic, no-flare Thai restaurant in the Tenderloin district. We loved the house special combo dishes, which allowed us to try a variety of Thai appetizers. The Panang curry, satay chicken, and fried rice were all delicious. The kind, thoughtful service made our experience even more wonderful.
author: Sally C.

description:
[Update: As part of menu renaming (?), unfortunately this Yum Nam Tok dish got removed this week (July 3rd). Such a shame since I have been ordering it literally every other day. Pork Shoulder Salad can be an alternative, but the meat is not the same. Also some of the menu price got more expensive too now that its name has changed. I will probably continue to order anyways since it's so hard to find a Thai restaurant this good, but the removal of my favorite dish and the increase in price will surely make me think twice before doing so.]

Just wanted to confirm again after visiting several other Thai restaurants in SF that Yum Nam Tok Moo (Thai Spicy) here is really the best! I usually don't eat vegetables in general but the DRESSING is just so tasty that I end up finishing everything. The pork is very tender as well. 

The flavor can be considered quite intense, especially if you are not familiar with northeastern Thai food. I recommend ordering this with rice so you can mellow out the flavor as much as you can take comfortably.
author: Gott P.

description: I really like this place.  The food is a step above your usual Thai places.  Very wide selection and lots of items that are rather unusual (boar, alligator, rabbit, quail).  It's a casual place, a little noisy but quite nice.  The waitstaff is friendly and helpful.  I had the fried whole trout and it was done to perfection...crispy and not at all greasy.  A nice little oasis in the Tenderloin.
author: steve r.

description: I can't believe it. The Tom Yum Soup is nothing like I've ever tasted before. It was sour to the max and spicy to the max where I almost died. I felt like the girl felt me and took it away once she saw I was dying.. when the bill came, of course it was still on it and the lady said we finished everything. Wtf when she took it away it was still a FULL BOWL. UGH I've never felt so wronged my whole life. DM me if you want more detail but please!! DO NOT COME HERE!!!
author: Vanessa Y.

description:
Very very underwhelming. 

We went in and sat down pretty quickly. Ordered and about 15 minutes later someone comes out and says that one of the items we ordered is out. Kinda seemed like a long wait to find that out but oh well. 

Garlic quail-2.5/5 very garlicy which is great. Very little meat and dipping sauce was boring

Tom kah-2/5 we sent the first one back because it had a pound of salt. Second one had a gallon of lime juice. We didn't send it back tho

Peanut chicken 4.5/5. Very good. Small portion. Needed another veggie besides spinach

Fried trout-3/5 boring without the sauce. Sauce was good and spicy 

Green curry- 3/5 we actually ordered red but didn't send it back. It was okay. Like small and spicy. Loaded with carrots but I'm not a rabbit sooo. 

Everything also needed onions. I'm used to onions with Thai and was sad they weren't there. 

They give huge portions of rice tho.
author: Dani G.

description:
A few of us came here today. Only my 2nd time here but the food is YUM.

Love the Crispy Pork Belly!!
author: Linda W.

description:
Great food but yellow curry portion was kind of small. They gave us extra brown rice which we didn't order but changed us 2.50$ for it- not sure why. Service was really quick. It was a little loud there and we couldn't hear the servers that well- great spot though! 
We got there around 7 and didn't need a reservation to have a seat. It got a little crowded when we were leaving so a reservation closer to 8pm might be needed.
author: Ash S.

description: Great mostly healthy food, very quick service. For San Francisco quite affordable. Everything seemed to be freshly prepared. We will definitely revisit this restaurant.
author: Wally Z.

description:
Love this place!

My bestie has been raving about their special noodles for the longest time so we just had to stop by on our recent trip to SF. It's located on a somewhat busy street so parking can be a bit painful, but that comes with the territory of being in the city. Don't forget to feed the meter!

We ordered:
- Thai curry puff- Crunchy, fluffy, and bursting with flavor. The peanut dipping sauce is to die for! Just the right amount of creamy and sweetness. My condolences to those with a peanut allergy.
- Lek Tom Yum Haeng (specialty rice noodle w/ fish cake and roasted & minced pork)- Nice and neat presentation. At first glance I was hesitant it might be dry and I'll have to add my own seasoning because I did not see any type of sauce.. But its all concentrated at the bottom so mix well! The flavors fuse together so perfectly that I struggled with every mouthful fearing I would get closer and closer to finishing my bowl. The roasted pork was amazing with extra crispy skin and soft meat. The last few bites had to the best with all the pork bits and chewy noodles soaked in sauce at the bottom of the bowl. Ugh, never knew food could make me feel this type of way.

Ambiance is trendy and hip. I can already picture myself coming back here again for the noodles and to try the rest of the menu.

*Sauce for the noodles have a bit of a spicy kick so consider trying it first before adding any extra chili.
author: Thuong D.

description:
Lers Ros, 5 stars all the way! I've been here multiple times and hope to come back multiple times more time!  

Wonderful wine selection as well as beers and sakis, probably, I tend to stick to rosés - personally - which they have also, yay!  

And start with these:

The Venison - if u dare!
The coconut soup - never have we been so happy!
The sun dried beef, aka the fancy beef jerky;)
The ginger-garlic rice, just trust me, I know my rice!

Ok, enjoy! You're welcome;)
author: Monica E.

description:
We made the trek all the way over here for this Thai spot. I have to say, it's definitely a top choice for Thai food, although not in the best part of town. For two, we ordered the Pad See Ew with Beef ($13), Red Curry with Roasted Duck ($15), BBQ Marinated Pork ($11), and a side of Jasmine Rice ($2). Not a single item disappointed, which is amazing. We started with the BBQ pork skewers, which came in four huge pieces. The grilled flavor topped with their spicy sauce was so delicious. Be careful if you can't handle spicy, though! The pad see ew is a classic that I always order at any Thai restaurant and it was hefty and delicious. But my shockingly favorite dish here had to be the red curry! Make sure to get the rice for the curry, which just compliments the dish so well between the roasted duck, bell peppers, pineapples and cucumbers. The curry is packed with flavor that had me sipping it straight off the bowl. 

We were stuffed by the end of the meal despite still wanting to eat everything because it was so good. We took the pad see ew to-go, which was still just as delicious as leftovers. I had to say that the food here is delicious. A couple things I'd advise for management is a place to put our bags/jackets because the chairs are basically stools --awkward. Also, the restroom is in the back, up the stairs, past all the "Employee Only" signs. I felt so lost finding the restroom, so just an FYI.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Ccame for dinner on a Sunday night with a friend and had about a 20min wait. Since there was only 2 of us we only got a couple dishes - pad see ewe, duck curry, brown rice, and mango sticky rice.

Everything was pretty good. Have definitely had better versions of these dishes at other places, but it was ok. Duck curry was spicier than I thought it would be, and the pad see ewe could've had more flavor. Mango sticky rice was good too. Not amazing, but no complaints here! May come back to try other dishes people reviewed.
author: Betty M.

description:
3.5 Stars.

I had really wanted to try Lers Ros Thai for years. The yelp reviews are pretty stellar. Furthermore the KQED check please showed Lers Ros Thai as an amazing place.

In reality the food was just okay. It was way over salted( I think they might use MSG as well..not sure though). I was thirsty for 6 hours afterwards. I also was not thrilled by seeing the pest exterminator leave the kitchen (gulp). Not cheap for sure and I cant understand why. The neighborhood is one of the cheapest in SF. 

Their food was pretty good but I would not say wow and when you consider that most of the dishes are in the $12.95-$14.95....I just don't see it.

I personally prefer thai time ( which is half the price and just as good) or KhanToke which has great food and amazing atmosphere.
author: David G.

description: Great thai food overall! I tried the chicken pad thai which was full of flavor and comes with a lot of bean sprouts. The yellow curry was also flavorful and delicious, but the pad kra prow moo krob (#62) was the winner for me. It's stir-fried pork belly with crispy rind and basil leaves. The pork belly was juicy and soft but had the crispy rind which added to the texture and the basil gave it a nice herby flavor. The sauce is a little sweet too, and made the dish perfect to eat with rice. It's not in the best location and I was a bit nervous to be street parking in the area, but it's still worth checking this place out!
author: Jeana Y.

description: I got the Thai curry puffs, sauvignon blanc, and pork shoulder salad (koh moo yang). All the food tasted excellent, except the khao khua (rice powder on top of the salad) was very hard and verging on unpalatable. It should have been dry toasted and ground in a mortar and pestle. In any case, the service was excellent (even at 11pm) and the flavors were 10/10.
author: JT N.

description: We had a reservation for 6:45 tonight and arrived a few minutes early. There was a four top open, initially we thought it was for us, after 20 minutes, rather than giving it to us, they joined it to another top for a party of 6 that had walked in after us. I asked why he sat another party since we had a reservation, he gave a lame excuse that I called BS. Took about 30 minutes to finally be seated. Service was decent and quick. Food was good, nothing as great as we expected given all the 5 star reviews. Their chicken Pad Thai and Tom Yum soup were their best dishes. Overall, not really worth the hype and definitely not worth the wait.
author: Michelin K.

description: Delicious Thai food in a really cute, clean restaurant. Loved their veggie pad see ew and sweet and sour tofu. Tofu texture was silly and the dishes were packed with flavor. Their house red is quite drinkable too. A deal at $9/glass. For dessert we had the mango sticky rice. Not too sweet and just the right portion size. Would definitely come back again for a great dining experience!
author: Evonne L.

description:
This food is very fresh, beautifully presented, and tasty.  I ordered thru Caviar:
  
1 * Pad Sweet and Sour Rice Plate with Shrimp = $13.45:  4 shrimp size 21-25 per lb. Comparison to picture item on menu - double the rice, half the veggies and shrimp.
1 * Fish Cake = $11.95 - delicious, small tablespoon of cucumber salad.
1 * Eggplant with beef  = $14.95 - very good, large amount of slightly chewy beef.
SF Bag Fee: $0.10
Service Fee: $7.62
Delivery Fee: $0.00
author: Rosie H.

description:
I came here with friends for dinner. I'm glad that my friend made reservations. It got packed after we sat at our tables. The Thai food was a hit and miss for me. It is still a fun place and a good place to eat. There were cute quotes on the walls about food. Food does feed our soul and I truly believe that it brings people together. Our party had the:

1. Spare ribs - they are punched with great flavor
2. Combo platter with the chicken & papaya salad -loved the papaya salad. Chicken was a bit hard to eat/share with a group of people
3. Pork and green beans - not what I expected
4. The seafood soup - spicy and warm, but light
5. Pad see ew - average, but loved the addition of salty duck egg
6. Mango sticky rice - dessert. I'm not a big fan of mango. Sticky rice was good, but I was so full after the meal.

LERS ROS.
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description:
Food taste is average (not at all like the name which means Excellent taste )
We had vegeterian food viz. Fried tofu, yellow curry and mix veg & tofu with peanut sauce. Everything was edible but not great so I gave 3 stars. 
Service was good, no issues with that.
author: Nikunj K.

description:
Deep fried trout (butterflied) arrived with an absolutely delicious dip consisting of chili, pepper, green papaya, onion, fish sauce and lime juice.

The very simple eggplant and tofu dish was well executed with perfectly cooked eggplant in a garlic-intense sauce.

Both dishes are characterized by very clean yet intense flavors.
author: M Y.

description: Not sure how to rate this place. I love it and have been going for a long time. I would probably go back but the last time I got super sick from the food. I have been to a few of their locations and still think the one on Larkin is the best which is the one I got sick from. I have not been back since but hope quality improves a bit.
author: Oren H.

description:
A friend and I randomly discovered and stumbled into Lers Ros Thai last night and boy did we get lucky. Considering the 1200+ reviews and 4 stars to boot, we figured this would be a great option for dinner. It's located in a "seedy" part of town but, I happen to think that the Vietnamese, and Thai located in this area might be the highest density of great Asian food in SF. Just my take.

Anyway, we were promptly greeted and seated by super friendly staff. The place was packed and it was close to 9pm so that was a great sign. Immediately we noticed the pungent smell of fish sauce that encapsulated the room, and it was heavenly!

It's a crazy long menu with what seems unlimited dishes so it took us a minute to figure out what we were going to eat. Pro tip: when your waitress is ready to take your order, just do it by the number located next to the dish. Don't try to speak Thai. ;) We ended up choosing the following and they were all fabulous: 

Papaya Salad with Shrimp - perfectly spicy and balanced because of the fish sauce. The shrimp wasn't overcooked and butterflied, making it super tender.

Pad See Ew w/ Chicken - These might have been the best noodles I've had in San Francisco. Trust me, this is a must order. 

Duck & Pineapple Red Curry w/ Brown Rice - The curry was super flavorful and the skin was left on the duck making the dish amazingly fatty and rich. 

All in all, this was easily a five star experience and I encourange anyone who is craving Thai food to order from Ler Ros Thai. Bomb dot com.
author: Benjamin F.

description: Went again for lunch after many years and it has changed a lot.  While they still have many items that aren't on a lot of other Thai restaurants the quality has gone down a bit while the prices have gone way up.  We had lunch on a holiday there and spent about $60 for 2 people before tip and with no alcohol, and we weren't that impressed with the food overall.  A sign of the times maybe but at least keep the quality and flavor from before.
author: justin p.

description:
A Check Please discovery I took visiting SF friends to. We arrived fairly early---around 6:30. Place was pretty empty but filled up. Every dish at every table looked great. We ordered 4-5 courses. Was some of the best tasting Thai food I've ever had. We ordered medium spicy and could have gone hotter.

Extensive menu with lots of vegetarian options. Service attentive. Decor tasteful. Seems like many of the guests were regulars.
author: don m.

description: I've ordered for about a year and the last two orders ive felt their coconut Curry (red and yellow) were not fresh.  Everything else was fine/
author: Dave W.

description:
Lers Ros Thai is a great lunch option for those who work in the Tenderloin or Civic Center area!

They have awesome rice plate lunch specials, but the best thing to order is the combo lunch specials! You get to choose 2 main dishes that come with rice and a side salad. The combo lunch specials are right under $10 and the rice plates range from $9-$12. 

For the combo, I've tried the yellow curry with chicken, red curry with chicken, kai phad king (ginger chicken), and the pad makuer tofu (spicy garlic eggplant and tofu). My favorites of the four are the red curry, which is sweeter than the yellow curry, and the pad makuer tofu! There are so many options on the combo menu list that I'm sure I'll find other favorites soon. 

Service was great and they even let me sub my rice for more salad. The menu says "limited substitutions" so I'm glad I could get away with that. The interior and decoration is nicer than most places in the Tenderloin as well. Great spot for lunch!
author: Tara A.

description:
This place has the most delicious Beef Salad (Yam Nam Tok). I've been to a lot of Thai restaurants and nothing compares to this, not even their 16th st location! Servers are always nice and accommodating as well. 

Overall a great place to have lunch or dinner.
author: Charly B.

description:
Really great food at a very reasonable price for SF. There's been a lot of new Thai restaurants on the scene (Farmhouse, Kin Khao) but Lers Ros remains my fav. Last visit, I came without a reservation and a couple minutes before my friend who arrived just on time. The hostess said a table would be open shortly and was nice enough offer to hold it for up to 10 mins. Luckily, my friend popped in just after and we were seated shortly.

Service was pretty attentive about the good things like refilling water and not too pushy about adding more to your order. The entrees are filling but not too heavy and I love that you can get it a la carte without rice for cheaper, which I don't eat rice anyways. Most entrees are $9 - $14 and filling. The only downside is the food is a touch too salty for my taste.

Tom Kha Kai - Really fresh and vibrant lemongrass flavor. The coconut milk broth is the right amount of richness without being overly creamy.
