My only complaint is it it's sometimes overly salty, especially when you get to the bottom. Admittedly, I have really positive associations with this soup, it's so comforting and warm, my ideal soup for recovering from a cold.

Larb Phed Yang - Roasted duck salad. A good amount of soft and fatty duck pieces but the seasoning is on point. So much umami and flavor, tangy kick from the lime, mildly spicy chili, a little sweetness from the onion and scallion. Rice puffs add a little crunch as well. The lettuce you can scoop it into and wrap it around was crisp too.
author: Truc N.

description:
Lers Ros was recommended to us by a local, we were in line at another restaurant with a long line and long wait.  So, we came here at 5 pm.  by the time we were done... there was a 10-15 minute wait.

He recommended three dishes... 
1) Larb Phed Yang  
  roast duck Salad -
   eaten like a lettuce wrap.  full flavor
2) Koh Moo Yang, 
   grilled slices of pork shoulder,  w/ chili and rice powder sauce. 
   it was firrm, but not overly tough.  complimented will with teh chili and 
    rice powder       
3) Chicken with red curry.
We added 
4) Pad Thai

We were warned that they can do traditional hotness, so we tried medium hot for our dishes and it was perfect... just the right amount of heat....it left  a nice glow in our mouths.
All the ingredients were very fresh,  well prepared and cook to show the best of each dish.

We would come back again, if we are in the city.
author: H-John T.

description:
I had very high expectations for this place, everyone speaks so highly of it. We finally managed to come and we were quickly seated. The menu was pretty deep and had a lot of vegetarian option.

We ended up going with Pad Thai with prawns and a vegetarian green curry.
The biggest disappointment was the Pad Thai, it was overly sweet and was nothing special. As for the vegetarian green curry,  I must say it was out of this world. 

Perhaps I got Pad Thai on a bad day, but we so many great Thai restaurants in the tenderloin I don't know if I'll be back.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: The lunch combo is quite a steal especially in the SF downtown area a few blocks away from the civic center! The red curry is definitely one of the better ones in the Bay Area with some Thai kick, and to me that is enough to go with a whole plate of brown rice. But as we are certainly striving to consume less carbs, there are many vegetables to choose from. My mixed vegetables with tofu tastes pretty home styled except the tofu smelled a lil questionable. But since I'm still healthily writing this comment two days after, I will question my paranoia instead. The basil chicken is flavorful and appetizing too ! Certainly a spot I would revisit, for the curry, generous portion and comfortable environment. Just be sure to arrive before the lunch crowd around noon ! Kap kun kap !
author: Chean L.

description: I feel like you can't go wrong with Asian food in the Tenderloin. I've been to all three locations of Lers Ros and I think this one is the best. The interior is much nicer than what it looks like outside. My friend loves Lers Ros, so we try to go when he visits. If we don't go to this one, we go to the one in the mission. Their soup is great, their papaya salad is delicious. My friend always gets the bbq pork and papaya salad and loves it. Definitely a place to go to if you're in the Tenderloin.
author: Julie L.

description:
I must say that I really like this place. First impressions are already memorable as soon as you walk into the doors. They have very simple furniture which makes you feel like you're getting real Thai street food. I love the quotes they have on the wall as well. 

We ordered some pad thai as well as Tom kha soup. Both weren't as spicy as we liked but that's okay since...I haven't actually been able to find any spicy thai food here compared to Portland. The flavor though was definitely great. The pad thai came in a rather large portion and was sauced well. It was definitely affordable at $12, but doesn't necessarily stand out like Osha Thais. 

The tom kha though, was superb. It came out on a flaming pot, which is awesome because I hate when my soup cools down during my meal. It wasn't too much coconut like some places have, and slightly sour but they give you plenty of meat, as well as mushrooms. It was also a very large portion for only $12.95 and I had to take some home. 

Overall, this place is definitely homie and has decent Thai food. I would love to come back to try some of their speciality items, and their prices are a big selling point for me.
author: My N.

description: Customer service was horrible Uber eats delivery was even worse nightmare to deal with order was wrong would not recommend to anyone.
author: Jackie L.

description:
This is the best thai food spot I've had in SF thus far, but I've only gone to 23 of them so far. I keep hacking at the list but it feels like there is no end in sight! 

The papaya salad here is especially note-worthy. Give it a shot and you wont be disappointed.
author: Leo I.

description: I am never disappointed with the food here. Its always been consistent and delicious. Never had problems with order or ingredients. Price is reasonable.
author: Snl L.

description: There service still remains bad, but I can't stop myself from loving there food so updating the rating just for there food! Service can surely be improved.
author: Ankit M.

description:
Review is for takeout only.

After hearing nonstop about Lers Ros for the longest time, I figured it would be a good choice for some takeout while watching the Oscars with friends. 

We ordered the fried tofu, pad see-ew (vegetarian and pork), som tom poo (papaya salaid with dried shrimp and crab), larb phed yang (duck salad), and kang keaw wan (green chicken curry). It is worth noting that none of the curry or salad dishes came with rice, and you had to order it separately. It came out to about $75, which I think isn't too bad if we were sitting down, but for takeout, it's a bit much.

The fried tofu appetizer was fine, although it might be worth ordering fresh, since it tends to get soggy when trapped in a takeout container. The papaya salad was excellent, although I just wish there was more of it for $10. The duck salad was also decent, but there just didn't seem to be enough duck, especially since the duck wasn't really deboned. Both pad see-ew dishes were pretty on point, but I also feel that flat noodles are the easiest to execute from a takeout/delivery perspective. The green chicken curry had some really good flavors, but was a touch too greasy for my tastes. 

Overall, we found the food delicious, but given the smaller portion size, it's hard to find the value. I'd probably order from Lers Ros again if I was was jonesin' for Thai food, but wasn't feeling particularly hungry. Perhaps I might be underestimating the costs of Thai food in San Francisco, but it just didn't seem like a good deal. I also like House of Thai when it comes to takeout, but the good thing about Lers Ros is that their delivery seems just a touch faster and the food quality is just a little better, so you can take that into account.
author: Eric J.

description:
Brought my bf here for a date, we had a reservation and got seated quickly. The tables are communal style and the place is cozy and bustling, but it didn't feel too crowded.

We get thai food a lot, so this was a refreshing take on a classic meal for us.

We got the raw crab papaya salad - my bf LOVED it. It was a little too fishy for me - which is unusual. We also got a tom kha and curry, both which were delicious. Spice levels were just right.

The waitresses are also beaaaautiful, we kept trying to guess if the 2 female white servers there were twins or just did their makeup the same. *shrugs*
author: Maymie C.

description: Majority the foods are good, love the services, but just a little hard to find parking spaces and please be very careful about the surrounding areas since there are so much homeless people around.  Take Uber/Lift is the best suggestion.
author: M P.

description: Had the green curry chicken with rice, was very good, i like the coconut taste in the dish! The only thing is I ordered it mild and it was still pretty spicy, had the chicken curry pastry puffs for appetizer, was really good but barely any chicken in it.
author: Yasmine K.

description:
I should've stuck to the Pad See Ewe or ordered the Garlic Quail (on the 2016 7x7 Big Eat List)!! I came with co-workers for lunch, and made reservations for a Friday at 11:30, but it wasn't necessary since they had plenty of seating at that time. We tried:

-Thai Curry Puff ($9.95): Good, but not amazing. Definitely very filling since you had puff pastry on the outside and potato on the inside. I wouldn't order this again.
-Crab Roll Cake ($12.95): Just ok since it didn't have much crab flavor- skip!
-#62 Kra Prow Moo Krob ($12.95, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=5MH2h9OqFMTuOlHkO7tQpA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): I love pork belly, but this was the version with crispy skin, which I'm not a big fan of. The sauce had good flavor, but I wouldn't get this again.
-Thai Iced Coffee ($5): Super sweet!! It was definitely strong tasting, but too sweet for my liking- skip! 

Service was friendly and efficient, and we got our food pretty quickly. All my other coworkers seemed to really enjoy their dishes, so I was the only one that didn't have an awesome experience this time around. I'll likely be back to get the Pad See Ewe and/or the Garlic Quail! Parking isn't too bad in this area but all of the spots are metered.
author: Amy D.

description: We ended up at this place as it's highly rated and we were just hanging out in the city looking for good dinner. Ended up ordering bunch of thing but loved the Tom yum soup. Basil chicken was bomb too. My vegetarian friend had spicy tofu and drunken noodles, her experience was alright. They do have good on point service and smiles all around.
author: Ray C.

description:
This restuarant is different from the other Thai places I have been to.the seating is communal styled, for a vegetarian the place does not smell great... they have a noob wine collection. But the food is fresh and wholesome. We ordered:

The fried crab cakes: fried well but the spices almost overpowered the meat. Would have confused it for chicken easily.. but it still tasted like good chicken. 

The spring rolls: tasted good. Go great with the sweet honey chili sauce 

Chicken potstickers fried: now this was a good dish.  Lightly fried served with peanut sauce, the flavoring right and subtle 

Rice plate with green curry and vegetables: the green curry was very light and not thick. It had enough vegetables with tofu and was served with fresh steamed rice. Apart from being spicy ( I had to down my wine) it tasted very fresh and satisfying. Very home cooked meal feel. 

All in all for the place, service, ambience and prices, this place was impressive.
author: Nayana R.

description:
Ordered food here through Postmates. Between time of ordering to when I got the notification that the driver was on the way, I must say it's pretty fast. Almost too fast that I wondered whether the food was pre-made beforehand and just warmed up. 

We ordered the pad kee mow which was okay but tasted more like pad see eww so I was a little disappointed hat I didn't get what I was expecting but it was still tasty. The only thing was they added too many bean sprouts to it and it seemed the noodles were missing. The other dish we ordered was the beef pad peht which has all these chilies and lemongrass. Taste was super authentic. 

Overall prices were good but to-go portion was a little smaller than I thought.
author: Melissa L.

description: Delicious & authentic. Love their food. Reminds me of home cookin'. If you want thai chili peppers with fish sauce, just ask for it. Service was great. Had their Thai sausage, Pad Thai, Ground pork with rice place, Duck Larb, Pork Belly. Yum. I'm craving about it already. I'll definitely be back when I'm in the area and try more items.
author: Amy H.

description: This was my first time visiting this Thai place & I would very much like to say, it definitely lived upto my expectations! We had ordered red curry, Pad thai (eggless) & spicy tofu - loved loved loved it. It was one of the only places open until 4pm for lunch which was very convenient. Since everything closes at 3pm for lunch. Highly recommend this place for Thai lovers!
author: Rajvi A.

description:
Food is good but don't count on their online reservation system for same-night bookings. They copy over their online bookings at 5pm and go to paper-only and won't know you exist if you show up with an electronic reservation you made after that point.

We had to wait in line as if I'd just shown, up despite having a reservation. I wish their booking system reflected that and kept you from booking or at least mentioned it.
author: Anton E.

description: I have a pretty decent spice tolerance but even their mild no-spice food was so overly spicy in the curry that it just killed the flavor. Be mindful when you order.
author: Josh B.

description: Super delicious food. Authentic Thai taste. Their food is homemade and never from Frozen. I ordered ChuChee Shrimp , perfect creamy curry sauce  with fresh shrimp reminded me Thailand.
author: Wirunna W.

description:
Came here back in 2013 and just went back last night. For 2 years, I used to live in LA where I was exposed to their amazing Thai town and community with excellent access to Thai food. Just to put this out there, Thai food in LA is a whole 'nother beast that cannot be compared in the same league as any other Thai food (such as in SF). Now that I've returned to SF and had my first Thai craving, I'd have to say that Lers Ros did satisfy my hunger. 

Between my bf and I, we ordered originally 3 dishes, but then added on the 4th when we realized that the dishes were on the smaller side (ugh). But in the end, we were glad that we ordered all 4 because we did really want to try a little of everything.

1) Pad Thai w/ Shrimp - this restaurant is able to execute the dish very well. The gravy with the noodles is on point here - they provide a lot of gravy, which goes great with the soft noodles. Nothing is worse than Pad Thai with no gravy, so it's dry...yucks. But this place does it well. I wasn't a huge fan of the shrimp though. Perhaps if they used the jumbo shrimp it would've turned out better.

2) Eggplant with tofu - Great dish! This dish might convince you to become a vegetarian. It's super spicy but so delicious. It has the red bell peppers, red chili peppers, basil, eggplant and large squares of tofu. YUM.

3) Green curry - decent dish. My bf and I were deciding between the green and red curry, and wanted the spicier one - and the waitress said green curry. To be honest, it wasn't spicy at all, maybe mild if anything lol. But it was pretty good. 

4) Garlic shrimp - pretty good, but nothing like what I've had in LA. The shrimps were that same medium size that they used in the pad thai, and I wish they were the jumbo ones. Also, it would have helped if the shrimps were deep fried too (well, when would that never help? lol)

If you are big rice eaters like my bf and I, you'll have to order an additional rice, which has never really happened to us at a Thai restaurant before. Usually they give you that large silver rice bowl which has at least 5 bowls of rice, but the silver bowl they gave us only gave us maybe 2, so we had to order more. 

Service was excellent. Really loved our waitress who was very sweet and smily. I'd definitely come back here if I had my Thai craving again. Probably the best Thai food in SF.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Iced Thai coffee & Thai iced tea are incredible! Kao Pad rice plate with crab is delicious. The spicy papaya salad is fresh, get it spicy for extra flavor. Service is great and helpful.
author: Sergio S.

description:
Lers Ros has quickly become one of my favorite Thai restaurant in SF.  All due solely to the Duck Larb Salad (a bit fatty but so flavorful) and the Pork Shoulders (amazingly pungent dipping sauce)  5/5 stars for both dishes! 

Other dishes I've tried:
Tofu Pad See Ew- 4/5
Beef Red Curry- 4/5
Shrimp Pad Thai- 5/5
Prawns Stir Fried with Garlic- 5/5

Be smart and call in for a reservation ahead of time when you want to come in.  They'll usually accommodate you as it does get crowded...even for a weekday.   When I'm lazy and don't want to make the trek out to the Tenderloin, i'll order via Caviar for delivery.  Use my referral code below for $5 off your first delivery. =)

https://bnc.lt/l/7TPsiMk2Tr
author: Melanie N.

description:
Another authentic Thai spot that I like! The food is fresh and taste like home.
Service is friendly and warm.
author: Sasathorn R.

description: Nice late night Thai eatery. The service somewhat ok. It depends on the mood of servers. Foods taste good. ambience not so much
author: Supa S.

description:
The decor is really nice. Waiters are nice too.
But the food was below SF standards. Don't get the rabbit; they fried-nuked mine.
I will not return.
author: Hung Q.

description:
Came here because my usual Thai place- Regent Thai was closed.

I ordered the Thai Tea, Pad See Ew and my bf ordered the Curry Chicken and Cashew Nut lunch combo.

I really enjoyed my Pad See Ew, it was flavored pretty well and delicious. Him, on the other hand did not really enjoy his lunch combo. I thought this place was ok, but probably would not be back unless in the area or convenient. 

I think overall we prefer Regent Thai for the price (cheaper $6.26 vs $10 a plate), easy of location, and overall menu.
author: Jessica S.

description: Good Thai food and very authentic. All staff very friendly with you and they're have some Thai drink but don't have full bar here. All the foods cooking so fast and nice presentation too. I think you can walk-in but if you wanna make sure they're have table for you just booking.
author: Somphop S.

description: A Thai restaurant that is as tame/wild as your mood calls for. There are traditional dishes found on any standard Thai menus, but you can also opt for "exotic" meats such as rabbit, venison, alligator, frog, and RAW pork! Extensive menu that will take a while to eat through. The Crab Roll Cake is a stand out: Succulent crab and pork are mixed with bits of crunchy water chestnuts that provide a wonderful contrast of flavor and texture. All that is wrapped in bean curd skin that is fried to crunchy perfection. The homemade plum sauce is unctuous and brought out the sweetness in the crab/pork. I tried the Pad See Ew - solid, but I will probably try the Pad Kee Mao next time. I look forward to visiting again to try the more unusual dishes.
author: Puay K.

description: If you want something to eat but can't really decide on what, can't go wrong with a good Thai dish. This Thai place on Larkin street looked very fancy inside and had a good ambiance to the place. I enjoyed my pad see ew and a Thai tea with a couple of friends.
author: David K.

description:
This is my favorite Thai  restaurant very good food 
good services 
Best crab cake for starter 
But !
Bad parking area 
Not confortable chairs and noisy restaurant 
Peoples are too loud 
But I will go back to try more from the menu
author: Christelle L.

description: The food was very fresh and good. Our waitress suggested a duck dish that was delicious. She let us know the skin could be removed which we did. The sauce was full of flavor.
author: Pam T.

description: If you're a Thai food lover, this is a great place. The Chicken Satay was yummy. I would recommend that for appetizers. I had the chicken Pad Kee Mao which was nice. I'm a big fan of desserts. I loved the Fried banana with ice cream. It's one of my favorite Thai desserts and this place didn't disappoint at all.
author: Shashank R.

description: Mind altering Thai meal in a casual atmosphere. Tom kha gai had half oyster mushrooms. Basil squid was like no other. You just have to go. We will be back!
author: Semiprecious G.

description: I came in for an early dinner because I'm staying at a hotel in the Tenderloin and wanted to be back before dark.  I thought the service was good.  Attentive, but not overly so.  I ordered the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (pork belly rice plate) and it is one of the best things I have eaten in quite a while.  The pork was tender, with a crispy rind, and absolutely delicious.  It had a very nice balance of heat, spice, and savoriness.  If I were local, I would almost certainly become a regular of Lers Ros.
author: Chris B.

description:
Great food, great service, great experience!   We have not been to too many Thai places and our kids have never been.  We were in San Fran for a few days and we saw this place was worth a try.

We started with the Spring Rolls and   Chicken Satay and they were really yummy.  We tried the Coconut Water as it was served directly out of a coconut.....we did not love this but I am sure people who like Coconut Water would love it....just not our thing as we just wanted to try it.

For main course we had Pad Thai (we had a veggie, a chicken, and a spicy beef---it was spicy but not awful--but not for the weak).  

All in all we loved it and we were glad we went.  Parking is tough and not in the best neighborhood---but don't let that stop you!!!
author: Vinnie M.

description: This place has fresh and excellent Thai Food. Came here with a friend on a typical Sunday, there was no wait and we were seated immediately. Don't leave without trying the papaya salad. My favorite salad!!
author: Ella C.

description: Wow, wow, wow, this place is absolutely fabulous. Super yummy food and it's open late. You absolutely must have the smoke shoulder pork with hot chili sauce
author: Capt R.

description: I've had Green Curry, Durian Sticky Rice, Tom Yum Kung, and few others. Overall it was good. Would visit again.
author: Yeseul S.

description: Fantastic Thai food! I'm from Orange County and this has been my favorite Thai experience. The tom yum soup was extremely tasty and flavorful. The top sirloin beef plate was extremely delicious as well! Our hostess for the night was fantastic as she took our order early while we waited for our table and was very attentive. Would highly recommend this place!
author: Andy M.

description:
I recently visited Thailand in December and the food there was amazing. Ever since I've been back I'm yet to taste pad Thai that tasted just as good as Thailand spots.. Then I came here. The food here is authentic and impressive. I wished they had a place like this in San Diego because this place is amazing!! 

Food wise: authentic as they come. Try the pad Thai here and it's just like being in Thailand.

Ambience wise: it's busy but it's a quality sit down location

Service: they were friendly and quick with the food.

Price: average pricing. For the quality, I might have been willing to pay more since it tastes so much better than everywhere else

Overall: this is a place that is a must go if you like Thai food.
author: Ronnie S.

description:
This is the spot for real Thai food. We have been to Thailand recently and found the food there to be quite a bit better than even the best Thai restaurants we had tried in the states. We had no idea how americanized Thai food is in the US. 

If you have a real hankering for some authentic Thai, this is the place for you.  Everything we had was decadently prepared and the service was superb as you would expect from a real Thai establishment.  

I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who loves Thai food. The quality of ingredients was top notch and the flavors brought me back to the land of smiles. I will be dining here very frequently!
author: Dan G.

description: This place has very fresh Thai Food. The staff is great and very helpful if you have questions on what to try. Amazing food and great ambiance. An awesome venue to host a group dinner.
author: Myla S.

description:
Came here with 3 of my co-worker friends after watching a late night movie at AMC Van Ness. It's only a few walking blocks away from the theater, however when we got out of the restaurant around 11pm on a Tuesday night walking the streets is unsafe if you are going alone. Lots of pan handlers, drugees, and other fiends out.

I tried the Alligator dish, coconut drink, and a shot of cold sake, which was around $30+ right there. Our party of 4 bill was $92 + I  left a $20 cash tip. 

The Alligator meat was a little tough and chewy. I thought the way they served me was kind of weird. We all had empty plate settings on the table, but they gave us our entre dishes on separate plates as well. The rice was in a giant metal container and the waitress served me with a serving spoonful on the empty plate. She also put the rice metal container next to my friends dish, so I had no clue that was for me. Lol

They have a few dishes I'd probably go back to check out: frog chunks (which doesn't really sound appealing), rabbit, and a boar dish.

I thought it was weird near the end, this guy asked us if we wanted our water refilled, 3 of us said yes, but he only filled one cup. 

I most likely won't be coming back to this place again. I'd rather find another place that has exotic dishes to go to. 

If I had to recommend coming here, I'd tell friends to only go there earlier and not later at night although they open until midnight, if they're going for the food. 

This place is great for drinks though. They have noodle items around $15, they have tofu noodle dishes for Vegetarians, the Alligator dish I had was $23, which I thought was reasonable. So to sum, I'd go back here for the drinks. They have a wide variety of alcohol you can order.
author: Eddie T.

description:
CATERING REVIEW: Everybody has long known that Lers Ros is the best Thai in the city. I wanted to update my review for their catering service, and especially give a shoutout to the awesome Jasmine from the Lers Ros team. 

I recently catered from Lers Ros for a 125 person event in San Francisco, and I had so many guests tell me afterwards how much they enjoyed the food - thank you! 

The team at Lers Ros is really efficient and pleasant to work with, they are super responsive to email, worked efficiently with our event coordinator to ensure load in, serving ware, and all logistics were taken care of, and most importantly -- the quality of catering food is equally as good as dining in or delivery. I highly recommend considering Lers Ros for your next event. 

Thank you again to the Lers Ros team for ensuring that everything went without a hitch, for feeding us so deliciously, and for being so easy to work with!
author: Sonja L.

description:
Came here during the busy rush hour dinner without reservations. Had to only wait for about 15 minutes or so at a party of 3. Place was what you call fine dining compared to most Thai restaurants I've been to. 

This place was definitely more upscale, which made the experience more enjoyable if you wanted to have an intimate conversation with your date. You don't really have to worry about the entire restaurant hearing your conversation due to the noise level. 

We ordered the Thai Iced Tea, which came out sweet and delicious. We decided to do family style so we ordered a couple dishes so that way everyone can share. 

The Pad Thai and Pad See-Ew were both really amazing. Each dish had an enjoyable flavor to it that Gabe uniqueness to the dish. I kind of wished instead of saying medium, get something with a bit more heat. 

We also ordered the Kang Karee, which had an extremely flavorful Coconut Milk curry flavor to it that makes me want to drink the whole dish. I don't normally eat curry but this dish was one of the best I've had. 

I highly recommend this place if you're craving true authentic Thai food, be prepared to pay the price but it's definitely worth it!
author: John L.

description:
I'm way behind the times, but it's finally great to get a meal of Ler Ros Thai under my belt.  

Long receiving accolades at their Tenderloin location and now expanded to three locations, Ler Ros Thai has been on my hit list for the longest time.  I love Thai food yet also think it is one of the most overdone cuisines with the majority of Thai restaurants being forgettable and also blueprints of each other in terms of menu and flavor.  

There have been some standouts.  I've long loved Marnee Thai when I lived in SF and I also loved King of Thai's more street food like take on fried rice plates and soup noodles that you rarely see at more mainstream Thai restaurants.  

I've also been burned by a couple of critically acclaimed spots, most memorable Lotus of Siam in Las Vegas that boasted unusual flavors and unique dishes that were quite different from every Thai restaurant but that I simply did not like and found mediocre.  

Enter Ler Ros.  With dishes like their famous pork belly and duck larb salad as well as their more exotic fare of alligator, frogs, and fresh deep fried fish, I knew I'd likely have a very unique meal.  I ordered a sampling of all their popular items and if I had more time, I'd likely have sampled even more from their impressive 100+ item menu.  

#9 - Koo Moo Yang - Smoked Pork Shouder Appetizer.  Rich and fatty and perfect to dip in the tangy and savory sauce.  It's a great appetizer, but like many of the dishes decadent.  I definitely should have ordered plain white rice or soup noodles to counteract all my rich dishes.

#25 Duck Larb Salad - 7x7 Magazine's famous item and worthy of the hype.  I've tried Larb Salad at Champa Garden and while it was tasty, I didn't love it.  The roast duck here is so good and there are so many herbs, onions, and spices, that it's easy to see why this is a hit.  It's a flavor explosion.

#37 Roasted Duck Red Curry - this is a more mainstream item and I wanted to see how flavorful their curries were.  It was excellent.  Lots of depth and a slight tinge of heat with the medium spicy version.  Great with white rice and with lots of vegetables to balance the fatty duck.

#54 Kao Pad - Fried Rice with Crab Meat.  I love this dish at King of Thai and it's similar here. Nice wok heat.  Lots of crab meat.  A touch oily but order some white rice and you'll have better balance. 

#62 Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob - another must order from most people.  It's crispy pork belly (or Chinese roasted pork) stir fried with herbs including basil.  The sauce is delicious. The pork pieces are super fatty and delicious.  You'll gain a million calories but it's definitely worth ordering once you're here.

#76 - Pad Kee Mow - I usually order Pad See Ew or Pad Thai, but most recommend to try this noodle dish instead.  It's a touch spicy and more flavorful and salty than the other milder dishes.  Overall, good but not as strong as their notable items.  

Pluses from Ler Ros is that they have free delivery over $25 and within 2 miles of their locations and it comes all nicely packaged and hot.  

Overall, I loved my meal here and while there is a lot of fatty, fried, and oily items, I think eating in house I'd order more soups or white rice to balance all the amazing flavors.  But the hype fit the bill and I'm glad to have added Ler Ros to my repertoire.  

Ler Ros accepts credit cards, including Amex.
author: Randy F.

description: Went for dinner on a Sat night.  Ordered a bottle of wine and it definitely was bad/sour (sadly it wasn't caught in the initial taste).  The server was constantly reaching over me to pour water/move dishes/etc to the point where she was leaning on me.  Lastly they delivered food for my table (4 total) in waves and mine never came.  After 10 minutes of my friends eating I had to flag down the server to bring it up.  She went to the kitchen, came back and asked what I ordered, then went back to the kitchen.  Finally she came back and said they forgot.  The food came out quickly but it was not actually what I ordered.  At that point I didn't care - I was hungry and never was going to come back.
author: Sam E.

description:
IMPORTANT:  This place is closed everyday between 4-5pm.

That fact is not listed in their hours of operations.  We, luckily, arrived at 3:45pm and was kindly informed their kitchen would be closing at 4.  On a Saturday at that time there were about 10 other people in there.  So it was not too busy.

The service was great from the moment we got in the door until we left.
The food was really good.  I can't say it was the best I every had, but I was near the top.  We were not disappointed.
I think because everyone else had already gotten their food, and the kitchen was about to close, the chefs had nothing going on.  So our food came out in about 5 minutes after ordering it.  That was awesome because we were famished.  I am not sure if the speed is always like that.

We got in at 3:45, ordered, ate, payed, and was out the door by 4:15.  Super Fast.

My only real gripe was that I order my Chicken Pad Thai "Spicy."  It did not come even close to spicy.  Maybe they thought, "Oh... he wants it 'Caucasian Spicy.'"  It tasted like normal Pad Thai.

$29.80 - Chicken Pad Thai, Tom Kha Kai, Side of white rice and an iced-tea.
author: Cap P.

description:
So darn good. I lived a couple of blocks away from here a couple of years ago and this was my guilty pleasure. I was in town visiting with my husband and we made it a point to come here for an early-ish dinner after a day of walking. We arrived around 6:30 and probably waited around 20 mins (not bad at all). Now the neighborhood is absolutely sketchy, but being a previous resident I was fully prepared. My guests, on the other hand, were traumatized.

This place has a lot of exotic meat such as alligator, quail, frog legs, etc which i have tried in the past but this time we had a finicky 13 year old with us so we laid off the unfamiliar.

We ordered a beef pad see ew, seafood Tom Yum soup ( it was 60 degrees outside), fish cakes, and a whole fried tilapia in chili sauce with a side of brown rice. Everything was amazing as usual, but i guess the server didn't put in our request for the spice level on the fish entree as it was mild mild mild. Also, the only downside to the meal was that the soup was very overpriced for the measly portion and it arrived with coconut cream mixed in, which wasn't mentioned on the menu. The mister has a strong distaste for anything coconut so we had to send it back. But seriously, $15 for a medium sized bowl of soup is a bit much. 

In any case, this will remain an all-time, albeit expensive, thai spot whenever I visit my old hood.
author: R H.

description: Omg favorite Thai restaurant in sf.no doubt,food is amazing. Server is super super nice. Usually went to there to get lunch special.
author: Clancy Y.

description:
BEWARE WHEN ORDERING PORK BELLY

Ordered to-go pork belly for pick up. When I arrived home, I opened the box to see that the entire pork belly was just FAT. **It was 1.5 inch of PURE FAT with a barely visible strip of meat** (refer to picture)

I called to alert the restaurant that the kitchen had served me pure fat. Someone named Fang promised over the phone that we would get fully refunded and an exchange for the inedible order. However, after I made the 30 minute drive across the city and back to the restaurant in the Tenderloin to exchange my order, they did NOT honor their promise. 

I regularly order from this location but this time the service and food handling of this situation were terrible. It is unacceptable to serve PURE FAT, to try to pass it as pork belly, and to charge customers money for this. Lastly, it is unacceptable for a restaurant to not honor their promise after a customer has driven all the way back to the restaurant.
author: Truc D.

description: Went there this past weekend. The waiter was very attentive. One of my favorite Thai spot in San Francisco.
author: Liz G.

description:
Great presentation, food and service 
Will probably be back to eat lunch here I am not too certain about coming here for dinner 

It's a go to when your eating out with a big group at lunch hour
author: MariaAnne V.

description: Amazing. Great service. Not overpriced. I wish i lived near this place to go all the time
author: Taylur H.

description:
Pad pek nok- amazing fresh fried quail I. Noodles.  I must warn all the other shares plates from my group were delightful but everything was uber spicy, so you always have to ask for at least one level of spice below what you customarily order.   I would come back here a million times if I could.  
Also seating is very limited, surrounding neighborhood is questionable and a bit u comfortable for the faint hearted and the reservations are hard to get.  (Long wait for dinner, short for lunch).
author: David C.

description: We had the red curry, pad Thai , yellow curry, chicken satay and a bottle of merlot. We are extremely happy with the food service , food,wine  and price.
author: Kori B.

description: I did not realize this gem was in my neighborhood all these time. A friend introduced me and I am completely in love. Super none typical thai food. I find it is a bit pricy. Some dishes are very salty, so rice is a great compliment.
author: David Dat T.

description:
Tl,dr: I've ordered delivery and eaten onsite twice; I like it. Good food, friendly staff, somewhat sketch outside. Good dinner before a show at The Orpheum, Symphony Hall, etc.

Order:
Chicken Satay
Yum Nam Tok (Beef)
Tom Kha Kai
Lek Tom Yum Haeng (Favorite!)
+ 2 other dishes

When: 
Wednesday night, table of 6, reservation made two days in advance.

Pros:
+ Staff is friendly, attentive, always kept our water glasses filled.
+ Food was tasty. 6 dishes for 6 people was a good amount, had one leftover box. 

Cons:
- The area outside of the restaurant can be a little sketch; I've seen some bad/weird things (dog poop,  etc) on the sidewalks. 
- Space can be a little tight (:shrugs: It is SF.). I kept my bag over my shoulder since we were on stools and there weren't table hooks or really any space to put it down (except if you're ok with putting it on the ground).
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Thai is one of my favorite Asian cuisines, so I was excited to check out Lers Ros Thai during my visit to San Francisco. I made reservations for 3 on a Sunday night around 8PM. Thank goodness I thought ahead! The place was jammed packed with people waiting around for tables to open up.  We were seated around 5-10 minutes after our reservation time. 

The menu is pretty extensive - so much to choose from and they all sounded and looked (from Yelp pictures) amazing. We decided to order family style and share 3 dishes - the papaya salad (medium spice level), crispy pork belly, fried trout. 
All three dishes were outstanding! The papaya salad and crisp and fresh with just the right amount of heat. I'm glad we didn't choose my normal Thai spicy because the medium definitely had me sweating. The pork belly was very well executed. Great flavors and tender meat with the crispy skin. Good size portion as well for the three of us. The trout was fried to perfection and served with a delicious spicy vinegar sauce. 

Service was quick and straight to the point.  The space is small and simple, but the food is far from that. Check it out! You won't be disappointed if you're a fan of Thai food.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Nice looking restaurant. Food is well prepared and served quickly. Prices were so reasonable as well. Definitely will be back.
author: Claire D.

description:
Lers Ros has much better Thai food than most places in SF. No, it isn't cheap even though it's in a crappy neighborhood but this is SF and should be expected.

We started with Koh Moo Yang - slices of grilled pork shoulder. I loved the texture of the pork and the sauce was a great complement to the pork.

I love pork and we also ordered Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob - crispy pork belly with basil. I expected the pork to be less chewy/saucy and crispier but overall the flavor was delicious.

We soaked up the sauces with Crab Fried Rice. My date chose this one and I was pleasantly surprised by how good it was.

Even though we were full, we didn't want to leave without a dessert. We settled on the Fried Banana with Pistachio Ice Cream. Yum!
author: Yi Z.

description:
Very good but I've had better, especially if you're going to venture into a rough part of town, I had hoped for slightly more authentic. Regardless, above average food, super friendly wait staff; but, 

the pad kee mao is 4/5 (not hot enough, but that's my preference)
 the chicken fried rice is 3/5 bland
Tom yum 4/5
 fried banana ice cream 5/5. Delicious
author: Nick J.

description:
Our first time at this restaurant. Parking was hard to find but that is normal in san francisco.
We were greeted nicely & seated quickly. We were given good time to browse the menu & decide on the food. We tried the two items menu for our lunch.  The portions is good size for me being asian & loves rice. If you are controlling your diet then you may need to bring the leftovers home. Food is good, if ordering curry...level of spicy starts at medium. The bbq chicken is very tasty with slight sweetness (good for people who is not into spicy). Thai ice tea is also good. The other added perk was when we are trying to look for our waitress to buy togo bbq chicken for my kids, another person quickly came over (looks like the bartender/manager), assisted us & process our order. it came in time we finish our food. Last, i forgot my papers & waitress immediately ran after me to return my belongings.
author: Charrie E.

description: one of the best restaurants i've ever been to. i recommend eating here if you're ever in san fran!
author: Shay H.

description: This has become my go-to takeout or delivery spot, and it's easily the best casual Thai restaurant in San Francisco. It's a great place if you only like the classic dishes, but also great for more adventurous eaters as well. My favorite dish is the stir fried pork belly!
author: Benjamin A.

description:
Dang, this place is so delicious. We ordered the papaya salad, fried fish, pad kee maw, beef riblets, mango sticky rice, durian sticky rice. All the dishes were so flavorful with just the right amount of spice. This is the best thai place ive had!
Ambiance was simple and service was good as well. Still thinking about that papaya salad today! Yum.
author: Kiwi T.

description:
OMG I didn't know what I was getting myself into when I picked this spot to meet a friend for lunch. And I really didn't know what I was getting myself into when I picked just any old street to get there. I should have known to take O'Farrell or Market, but noooooo, I walked straight through the (fragrant and colorful) heart of the Tenderloin. What a noob.

My #17 pork salad came with plenty of untrimmed sliced pork (complete with chewy tendon and a layer of fat), scallions and onion on a leaf of lettuce, with a wedge of cabbage on the side. My place setting came with a fork and spoon, so I wasn't really sure how to eat the cabbage. Let's just say it wasn't pretty, to be polite, but my friend didn't seem to care about my lack of daintiness. 

My friend's Pad Thai with prawns was yummy. Carbs and sugary sauce. The sauce was a bit sweet (maybe too sweet, I dunno...), and the scrambled eggs were nice and fluffy. The noodles had a good bite. 

Overall, a decent not overly-Americanized Thai lunch option at an affordable price. I didn't love it, but I didn't hate it either, so I don't see myself returning to Ler Ros Thai more than a few times a year.
author: Liv K.

description: Loved everything about this restaurant. Excellent spot. Food is well prepared and served quickly. I particularly enjoy the Pad Kee Mao! Truly authentic Thai food!
author: Trace O.

description:
I guess this place is pretty popular? There's some kind of hype to it. So we were on our way to House of Thai, and just passed by this place and decided to go here instead. This place is more nicer and more of a date spot. 

We ordered the crab fried rice, beef pad Thai and he got some kind of combination plate (which was huge)- ended up calling it a kings combo because there was so much food on one plate, I think it was the grilled chicken, rice, curry and salad. He said he liked it. The crab fried rice had a lot of crab in it, which was good, but the garlic flavor just over powered the entire plate. It was aright, could have gone without it. The pad Thai was really good though, even though I think the chicken would have tasted better than the beef. 

The seating here is where I am giving them less stars. Maybe it's because we got seated by the door and it was super cold, but also because the seats suck. They are little single benches with no back lol. Super uncomfortable. My date is over 6' and he was calling them midget chairs. Maybe next time I go here, I'll sit at the bar. There's a TV and seats with backs on them lol. All in all, this place was a lil average. Maybe when I go back, my opinion will change. We'll see!
author: Jamie B.

description:
All around, this is a great Thai restaurant. It is much nicer the second you step into the actual place than what it seems to be from the outside. You are served immediately and always answered with a smile. 
I recommend getting anything with chicken in it. Everything with chicken was cooked to perfection. The seasoning in my curry was the right amount of coconut and that's truly an accomplishment. Crispy chicken plates came with this amazing fried garlic rice. Could probably eat that rice on its own and be satisfied. The spice in the food is definitely present as well without making the dishes unbearably spicy. 

The only reason it is not 5 stars was because one of the noodle soups ordered was sorta bland. Had to add some fish sauce to make up for it. Also got sticky rice with mango and was disappointed. The sticky dressing was soooo watery. Felt like I was eating mango rice soup?? No thanks!!
author: Sara L.

description:
So many choices, yet I still always pick the plain ones/not adventurous. The first time I came here I had the tom kha soup.  The flavors were ok, but I wasn't wowed, but this is probably because the flavors got old after having so much of it. The portion is huge, so I recommend sharing with a group! The bf had the duck with rice platter and it was delicious. On another visit, I ordered the duck again. 2 people in our party got the dry tom yum style noodles, 1 ordered the pad thai and another got the rad na. My duck was okay, but not as good as I had remembered. The dry tom yum noodles were my favorite! A lot of good flavors. My friend raved about the pad thai and the other said the rad na was okay.

Prices are decent for the portion size.
author: Noelle H.

description:
When in doubt, eat Thai.

I had just arrived in the city with one of my best friends and we were looking to meet up with another good friend but the hangry was setting in and we needed to eat. We can always agree on Thai so we looked up Thai spots on Yelp and found Lers Ros Thai. We called ahead to make a reservation as suggested by a reviewer on Yelp since it was dinner time, but when we arrived 30 minutes earlier than expected they were able to accommodate us at the bar which was fine with us since we really wanted to eat. 

The menu is pretty large including all the typical Thai fare plus some regional dishes that I've never heard of before which was cool. I ended up ordering the Pad Kra Pao with rice and the girls ordered Pad See Ew and Pad Thai. The Pad Kra Pao was really good but super spicy! I ordered it mild and I consider myself a fan of spice, but the dish was almost too spicy to eat. I had to alternate with eating plain rice and drinking lots of water to get through the dish. It was so hot! I didn't get to try the other dishes the girls ordered but they were both satisfied.

The service was really attentive-- they were quick to refill our water glasses and when we wanted our leftovers to go they packed our dishes for us. In my book its really hard to have bad Thai food, but the dishes here were delicious and well priced. Definitely a winner!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I have been coming here ever since this was the only Lers Ros location -- before all the hype from SF's 7x7 magazine, before it was even on the map for what it has morphed into today: overpriced hipster Thai food. Let me take you back when this was my go-to Thai place that served up the most amazing Thai-style street food. Having been to Thailand and also being able to speak the language fluently and raised in this culture, I know my Thai food. The food was always consistent with the perfect balance of flavors that highlight the spicy, salty, sweet, and sour that is so characteristic of Thailand's cuisine. 

Now, fast forward to the new Lers Ros where it has expanded into the more chic neighborhoods (think Hayes Valley) and gotten lauded by more than one major foodie publications. I get that food prices have increased, and I do not mind paying good money for great food, but I do take issue with paying good money for not-so-great food. 

Food: We ordered a smorgasbord of the usual just to see if it would meet our earlier expectations, and I have to say that while I love that extra bit of sour in my dishes, I felt that the chef was having one hell of a day because it was as if she dumped the whole pint of lime juice into the majority of our dishes. You really had to wince as you took each bite, and the funny thing was that the heavy-handed sourness was apparent in nearly all the dishes we ordered. 

Appetizers/Salad:
- Some Tum Koong (Papaya salad with grilled shrimp) - Spicy, but too sour.
- Koh Moo Yang (Grilled pork shoulder) - Pork was tender, but the portion was definitely not commensurate with the price tag. Also, the chili dipping sauce was way too sour.
- Larb Phed Yang (Roasted duck salad larb) - Normally, this is my FAVORITE dish on the menu (partially bc this dish essentially put them on the map), but dang, they plucked and squeezed all the limes from one tree into this dish so I could barely eat it.

Soup:
- Tom Kha Gai (Coconut chicken soup) - Again, way too sour. Normally, the flavors are balanced and I love how they serve it in a fire pot and sprinkle some chili oil on top. 

Entrees:
- Pad See-Ew (Flat Noodle Chow Fun) - This was the ONLY dish that was well balanced and perfectly charred. We actually took this dish home because we loved it so much.
- Pad Ka-na Moo Krob (Crispy fried 3-layer pork belly with Chinese gailan) - This dish was way too salty as it was prepared that day. Normally, it's also one of the best things on the menu for me since the pork is nice and crispy and the gailan is so fresh. Also, you can ask them to top it with a fried sunny side up egg for the authentic experience.

Price vs. Value: Our bill came up to $100+ (with tax & tip) for lunch, and it appears that everything on their menu is pegged at an average price point of close to $12. Times have definitely changed; I just wished the consistency of the food had not done the same. If you want to try it for yourself, be my guest. Just don't complain if you have to blink a few times as you take a bite. And then, once more when your bill comes out.

Service: The service is great. Very prompt and attentive and I have to give it to Lers Ros for not changing this aspect of their business.
author: Chan K.

description:
Outstanding food. 

Competent service. 

Urban atmosphere. 

Shithole neighborhood.  Total shithole neighborhood.

Good luck parking your car around there and whatever you do, hide them valuables BEFORE you park, or better yet, take them with you.  SF is now one of the top cities in the country for car break ins.  Way to go local government.  Maybe soon you'll reach the rankings of Oakland or Richmond.  SF now reminds me of NYC post-Dinkins.  Rudy Giuliani, SF needs you.  ;-)   

Good times in sF!
author: Anthony D.

description: Good food. Bad location. A little pricey. Have had better Thai food for a lot cheaper. Customer service was excellent though and the interior is nice. Good place to have a quiet dinner, however, the presence of a lot of homeless people in the area makes this place not too safe to go to esp at night. The city has to do something about this huge problem because it is not good for small businesses like this one. Even if I want to recommend this place, it is unlikely that I would due to safety concerns.
author: Ana B.

description:
Best Pad Thai in SF. Hands down. 

But a bit pricey if you think about it....
If you're looking for some great culturally authentic Thai food, this is the place.... 

Problem is only to find parking in a neighborhood that is less safe... Otherwise, bring some friends along and you're ready to have culinary experience. :)
author: Xin Cheng W.

description: Hands down my favorite Thai restaurant in the Bay. Love their Pad Thai, curry, soups, and everything i've had here. Food comes out super fast and service isn't bad for an in and out place.
author: Jane P.

description:
Mass chaos here...tight spaces, long lines, and pissy staff!
That and this is in the Tenderloin...so you hold your breathe a little when you walk to your car or when you're waiting outside...

The menu is a nightmare to go through....I highly recommend spending some time reading it before coming or while you're waiting...cause once you sit down, the wait staff expect you to order right then and there....

The irony is that the corner table where we were originally waiting was taking their sweet time leaving even after paying the bill and having their table cleared.  Seriously...I understand you might be on a date and trying to seal the deal for the night but do that elsewhere!!! Such rude people and yet the staff did nothing to hurry them along...

The pork loin was delicious but not worth the stress of coming to this place. That was the only memorable thing of the meal.  

The rabbit and crocodile were beyond horrible! We each took a bite and left everything else....
Don't get me wrong...we've had delicious versions of these dishes elsewhere and even in Thailand itself...they are messing up here....

I really don't understand the hype...this is not worth the frustration and starvation...
author: David W.

description:
Best Thai Food in the Bay.

Just try their meat dishes. Every of their meat dishes was delicious. I have tried the pork shoulder, the rabbit meat, the duck salad, as well as some main stream dishes such as Pad See Ew or Fried Rice. All of them were good.

They especially had the durian rice for dessert. So good!
author: Tung D.

description: Food was very good. I ordered a Pad Thai. The total was $14.05. It is a bit expensive compared to other restaurants but the food was great and it was a good experience. Employees were nice. I would come back.
author: Joseph M.

description: Best place for thai in san francisco! Long waits at dinner but well worth it. Pad thai is not dried up, they have exotic meats in the menu, rabbit, croc, you name it. Must try thai spot! Even if you cant you should order it through caviar app to your room once while your here in the city! Hands down this is the best thai spot in town as long as you can find parking blocks away haha. Or better to bike it.
author: Carmin W.

description: Lers Ros is the best Thai food in San Francisco. I've tried many different places on recommendations from others, and I always come back to this place. They serve authentic Thai food in addition to pad Thai derivatives. Anytime we want efficient fast food, they also deliver through the apps. Will be back.
author: Michael G.

description: I absolutely loved the shrimp green papaya salad. The crispy pork belly with rice was the perfect portion size and was really good. It was one of the best authentic Thai restaurants that I've been to in a long time.
author: Dana C.

description:
Tried the beef pad see yaw, which everyone recommended. It was pretty good, though slightly oily. Meat was very tender. 

They also have more 'exotic' ingredients like alligator, venison, frog, etc - looks interesting and would try next time!
author: David Y.

description: This is some of the most authentic Thai food I've had (who knew there was so much of it in SF!). The atmosphere and decor are clean and modern, and the menu huge and authentic. My dining companion and I arrived for lunch as they opened and ordered the papaya salad (som tum) with raw crab,  duck curry, and a dry noodle dish called Lek Tom Yum Haeng--and there wasn't a single dish that wasn't amazing. The papaya salad was nicely spiced and the funky aroma of the raw crab was a great complement. The duck curry was delicious and full of unusual vegetables (though the duck was a little bit fatty for my taste), and the noodle dish came with the most delicious, crispy (and not overly fatty!) pork belly I've ever had. I will most certainly be back to explore even more of this amazing restaurant.
author: David K.

description: We came here on a Sunday evening. It wasn't too crowded and they were able to accommodate our large group. It was later in the evening so we didn't feel rushed. The menu is big and there is a lot to choose from. We ended up looking at the menu for awhile. Also, the servers came by to get our drink orders. We got waters. Some people in our group got hot water. They put the hot water also in their glass cups. It wasn't a problem, but the lady kept on saying we can put it in a different cup so it's not too hot. We said it was ok. Also, she totally forgot my cup of cold water. Everyone else got water and I was like... Where's mine? When we ordered our food I requested another cup for water. The prices are pretty high and the food was ok. The food came out pretty fast. I was expecting better quality of food and a bigger portion for the price and especially in San Francisco. The dishes were really small. You pay $17 for a noodle dish compared to elsewhere 10-12 dollars and it feeds more people. At the end of our meal since no one was coming in we stayed and chatted. The ladies/servers just stand and stare. It's weird. I looked over to my left hand side and a line of servers just stood there starring. Awkward...
author: Crissy G.

description: I've eaten a LOT of Thai food and this place was AMAZING!! The green curry blew my mind!!
author: Mark L.

description:
Let me make something clear: If your restaurant labels a section in the menu as "vegetarian," I expect those dishes to contain NO MEAT. Lers Ros USES FISH SAUCE in their "VEGETARIAN" pad thai noodles and ALL of their curries, and cannot be replaced because the sauces are pre-made.

This is FALSE ADVERTISING and extremely misleading for those who want to avoid eating meat.

I was shocked that the lady I spoke to over the phone said that other customers are ok with fish sauce in their vegetarian food. If they eat fish, they are NOT VEGETARIAN. And besides, it's not like she was the one who offered the information - I was the one who had to ask about whether or not they use shrimp paste and fish sauce in their vegetarian food (some Thai/Asian restaurants do). 

A mistake on labeling is one thing, but to know that the food contains animal product and blatantly misleading customers into thinking otherwise is NOT OK.

ONE STAR FOR THE REMAINING FOOD like Pad See Ew made vegetarian to order. Vegetarian fried rice (with no egg) was subpar.
author: Vegans Eat 2.

description:
Went to the mission location and thought it was a 4 star but man oh man the original is five star service and food. I came with a large group and they were definitely accommodating even without reservations. 

We got the red curry, green curry, pad Thai, beef pad kee Mao, fish cake, pork belly with basil leaf, pork shoulder slices, pork shoulder with eggs, and papaya salad. Man o man was everything good. Honestly the non noodle dishes out beat the noodle dishes. 

We did have one instance where the pad kee Mao was overly salted so we had to send it back. 

The service is great. For being so crowded, the wait staff is always patient and helpful. I would definitely give this place a try over the other two locations. Can't wait to come back.
author: Jackie N.

description: I love this place.. Chicken and fried rice is super duper yummy.
author: Nana N.

description:
My family and I were feeling for some Thai food so we decided to check this place out. I ordered the vegetarian pad Thai that I thought was really salty. I tried the pad kee mao which had this really nice smoked flavor. The best thing I tried was the crab fried rice, that is a definite must! 

The atmosphere was alright. It was way too loud that it made it difficult to have a nice conversation with my family. The service was slow. Overall, I thought it was an okay experience.
author: Melissa L.

description: This is so so delicious and unbelievable. So so fresh! They prepare steamed fresh fish like sea bass in unbelievable ways.  Crispy duck larb, the salad with beef-- the food is so very special and it will knock your socks off
author: R B.

description: Thai place with some communal tables and a cozy atmosphere. Meals was great and the service was fast and friendly.
author: Kaeden G.

description: The best rabbit, quail and frog legs i had. Tye alligator was really good but too spicy for me. This place is my new exploration since they have many dishes to explore. I cant leave without my fried banana with ice cream.
author: Jorge Z.

description:
Thai food review thai-me!

I judge Thai restaurants by their pad kee mao, and the version here is very appe-thai-zing. In order to be exceptional though, they would need to throw some tomatoes into the mix. Please take note, Lers Ros! 

The chicken pad kra krow and duck salad en-thai-ced my taste buds, but the most thai-riffic dish of all was the curry puff. The marriage of spiced ground chicken and flaky puff pastry left me tongue-thai'd and cross-eyed with orgasmic exhilaration. As a result, the thai-dal waves of carnal desires this dish incited made me Bangkok like a lecherous thai-ger all night long.
author: Suany W.

description:
This is my GO TO SPOT. And I keep going and going and going. Be ready to wait - there is almost always a wait if you go during peak hours. However, it is worth every minute in the cold, windy line. The food puts the smiley heart eyes emoji ( )on your belly...picture your belly with that all over .

I have tried many things on their menu and not a single one has been a disappointment. My favorites are: Crab Fried Rice, Crispy Pork Belly, Mixed Seafood in Green Curry.

Just a word of caution, when they say spicy, they mean spicy. #lerslos4life
author: Tarun P.

description: Yet another SF Thai Restaurant with BLAND TASTELESS Phad Tai Noodles.  Someone PLEASE help!!!
author: Lynne P.

description:
This place is such a little gem that among thousands and thousands of great restaurants in SF, I still find myself wanting to come back. 

Here are my absolutely favorite dishes:
- Crispy pork belly (forget about your diet, indulge in the crispy skin and melting fat for once and you'll die a happy man)
- Crab fried rice
- Shrimp paste fried rice

Other highly recommended dishes:
- Pork shoulder appetizer 
- Pad Thai
- Pad see ew

Also try:
- Garlic frog
- Curry (I forgot which curry I had, but they were all good)

That's it. I'm out of here. Writing this review makes me salivate more than I should.i
author: Mandy D.

description:
Overview:
Fun quotes and decent food. However I wish that the food would be better.  Overall, I would say that the food is probably a 3.5 stars.  There are some good choices, so just stick with those.    It does pack a lot of flavor and a lot of spicy.  Beware that some of the dishes are spicier than most other Thai restaurants.   If you do find yourself at the restaurant, here are the noteworthy dishes: 
Order:
- Spare ribs were awesome.  Flavorful and wonderful
- Get the combo platter with the chicken & papaya salad
- Get the mango sticky rice for dessert.  A perfect ending to the meal.  
Pass:
- Pork and green beans only if you like something with a hint of sweet
- The seafood soup was super spicy.  I could barely taste the flavor of the seafood and broth.
- Pad see ew was ok.  Love the salty duck egg.  

Details:
This place has quite the decor. You will find many food quotes on the walls in the restaurant.  The restaurant's name is also pretty clever too.  They also take reservations if you want to. When things I don't like about the restaurant is at the bar takes up way too much space. You can't fit a lot of seats at the bar.  Though it's nice that they do serve alcohol at this restaurant.  I see a lot of people ordering their wines with the meal.  

The food:
- Spare ribs were delectable.  Very flavorful and juicy.  All the spices just melts in your mouth.  
- The pork and green beans seems really plain.  It was also too sweet for my taste.  At least the beans weren't limpy.  
- They really overpowered the peanut sauce on the beef with peanut sauce dish.  It was really sweet and the sauce was a weird consistency as well. I wished the beef was a bit more tender.  However it's not too bad when they drench the dish with the sauce.  
- I was a bit disappointed in the seafood soup.  I always enjoy a nice bowl of Thai restaurants' tangy seafood soup.  I felt that Lers Ros' could've added more flavors & spices to the soup.  They overpowered the spiciness, but the different spices themselves didn't absorb in the soup.  I also noticed that a couple of the clams didn't open up in the soup as well.  
- I definitely enjoyed the combo platter.  The chicken in there was amazing.  Super tender and juicy.  It melted in my mouth.  The papaya salad was also better than most Thai restaurants.  Their sticky was awesome amazing.  100x better than the regular rice.  I would just order this as a meal by itself.  
- The pad see ew was only ok.  I enjoyed the salty egg in the dish more than the actual pad see ew itself.  It tasted pretty bland.  I've had better
- The mango sticky rice was awesome.  The mango itself was amazing.  So juicy and soft.  The sticky rice wasn't that sweet either.  It was a softer consistency than some of the other places I've had, but I actually like this more.  

One thing I do like about this restaurant is that it takes multiple credit cards.
author: Shirley C.

description:
The best thai food in SF! 

Be sure to come with a group so you get a bite of everything. I went to a Michelin starred Thai restaurant a few days ago before Lers Ros Thai and I thought this restaurant was WAY better! Also, after ordering 5 dishes, total was only ~$25 per person. Portions were generous and more importantly, damn delicious!

Also... you'll probably have the most flavorful SALAD of your life here. The papaya salad was sooo amazing, I'd come back for that. Even my boyfriend, who acts like a kid and still doesn't eat vegetables, really liked it. It's very spicy though, so be careful! 

Anyway, more about the restaurant... this place is constantly packed. We ate a late dinner at 9pm, and we saw people still coming in at 11:30pm! It also gets super warm inside, probably because of those soups and pots of food on top of fire (I was sweating...). The chairs there also don't have a backrest so you can't really put your coat anywhere. Service here was okay -- we were pretty much ignored the whole time.

Onto the food...
- Papaya salad: a must. I'd say it's the best papaya salad I've ever had. Even better than the one I had in Thailand!
- Pad thai: solid and delicious! Wish they could've put more shrimp in it...
- Fried rabbit: not a super huge fan, but everyone else really liked this. Especially the men. The meat didn't taste or looked fried at all. Hopefully that meant it's not too fattening.
- Green curry: I LOVE green curry. So I might be biased, but I thought it was awesome, flavorful, and generous in size. Yum!
- Pork shoulder: a must order appetizer. All 4 of us were fighting for the last piece!

I'm totally coming back here! The menu is overwhelming and I can't wait to try the rest of the dishes. I'm seeing here on Yelp that delivery is free?! Tempting...
author: Janet H.

description:
This is one of those places that makes me drool just thinking about it. I love this place. The only thing I don't love is how inconvenient it is to get here from the East Bay, but I think that just adds to how great it tastes cuz I don't have it very often.

GET. THE. PORK. SHOULDER. Just do it. When it comes out it doesn't look like much but let me tell you. The taste and texture and everything about it made my tastebuds and tummy sooooo happy. We also has the raw shrimp salad and the duck larb and ughhhh my mouth is watering just thinking about how wonderful this place is.
author: Mara A.

description:
Was surprised by the more upscale/ fast casual vibe of this place. The Thai places I'm used to at home (and the ones I find to have the best food- are typically family owned and very much so hole in the walls) don't judge a restaurant by its decor- I guess!

Drinks: young coconut and Thai iced tea- both tasty and refreshing! 

We had our standard go to Thai dishes- 
Started with the red chicken curry and chicken satay. The curry was a bit more watery for my liking- but it packed some dope flavors! The satay chicken was tender and the peanut sauce was very good. It was well balanced and tasted peanut-y- but not like peanut butter.

We got the tom ka gai- soup. It was a little more lemon -grassy for my palate. Light and simple and came in a nice hot pot with big chunks of galangal. 

Our main dish was the pad se eew with chicken- good flavor, they use Kai-lan, but the noodles were a bit dry. 

Overall, I was not disappointed and this was very good Thai. Not the best I have had- but it hit the spot and I enjoyed it very much!
author: Stefanie D.

description: Thai lunch here in Larkin location. Depending on what you order some items were tastier than others. Chicken curry average, Beef pad thai excellent, bbq chicken not bbq but tasted like baked. Ate here before and some items were excellent and some mediocre.
author: Clifford W.

description:
This was one of those happy serendipitous finds that left me so very delighted it made my night.  

After agonizing over what to order because everything looked so delicious...we decided on the yellow curry with chicken and jasmine rice and the combo plate - tiger shrimp in spicy green papaya salad with BBQ Chicken and sticky rice.

Seriously, I'm still thinking about how good it was.

I'm usually not a fan of spicy food, but even though my combo plate was "spicy" by my definition, I could not stop eating!  It was like wonderful torture.  

Service was great, price was nice, food was good...highly recommended.
author: Libby R.

description:
You know that question everybody asks you? "If you had to eat one thing the rest of your life, what would it be?"

Well, I can tell you I could finally answer that question with one of Lers Ros Thai's items: Koh Moo Yang. The Pork shoulder appetizer. It is pure orgasm in your mouth good. The taste is just amazing, and the chili sauce it comes with it amazing, too. So please, if you're able to eat pork, try it. Could I be hyping it up too much? No. I brought a friend here to try once after giving the same pitch about the pork shoulder and she also fell in love with it.

Anyway, besides that the food is delicious. Compared to other thai restaurants, they have got it down. The Pad See Ew and Pad Thai are my baseline comparisons. You can't really go wrong with it, but they have really got these dishes figured out. 5 spices duck + rice. Also great. However, I would not recommend getting the Rad Na unless they go easy on the sauce and give you more food. Too much sauce and not enough actual food.

The desserts are also amazing! Mango sticky rice etc... yum! The hot tea is also delicious, very sweet taste to it.

Apart from that, the staff is super friendly and nice. I asked them for the recipe of the chili sauce and they went and got it for me! They're always smiling even whether the restaurant is packed or during down time. The guy also commented on my tattoo and chatted a bit about it and his time studying in Thailand. Really intelligent dude. 

Come and try it. Fall in love with the place, and repeat.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Stopped in New Year's Eve for dinner and had the best soup I've ever had in my life. Served mini hot pot style. 

Great service. Plenty of tables. Trendy but very classic and clean. 

Great bar. Reasonable pricing. Just five blocks north of UN Plaza.
author: Ben C.

description:
One of the best Thai restaurants I've been to!! I love the interior, the staff are all super attentive and friendly, and most importantly the food is amazing!! I think one of the reasons why is because their dishes just taste really authentic and made to perfection. 

What I had:
Pork Belly- Tender and delicious with the sauce!
Pad See Ew with chicken- Flavorful and the noodles were cooked well
Steamed fish- The main highlight. Very soft meat and the flavor of the broth it was in was really tasty
Sticky Rice with mango- LOVED IT!
Thai Iced Tea- One of the best. I finished it way too quickly...wished they offered a large hah

I am officially a fan!
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Definitely one of the best Thai places in SF. My BF is Thai and he took me here telling me it is  authentic. Blew my face away .com. Thought I knew Thai food before this place, but mama was I wrong. 

The Tom Yam noodle is bomb AF. Greens with pork belly is also cray yummy. I can't remember the name but there's an orange soup that's also hella delish #WantToDie. 

Service here is great Omgah. Food comes out pretty quickly after order and nice and hot and phresh to death. If you happen to get alcohol here, you will be well attended for all your subsequent drinks hehe.

Been here hella times and never #disappoint. Look my food pics and you shall see!!
author: Stephen H.

description: Not outstanding but satisfying. The duck larb pictured by multiple yelpers was the best thing we ordered, albeit a smaller portion than desired - really excellent flavors! Overall, disappointed with our experience since we saw Lers Ros featured on Check Please Bayarea and couldn't wait to try it. I thought the chairs were pretty uncomfortable (no back) and it was cold- we both ate with our jackets on! The service was perfect. The neighborhood was far from it- smelling of urine with people screaming obscenities at each other (I would have felt really uncomfortable if I was not with my boyfriend). No plans to return.
author: Ladybug M.

description:
Les Ros was nicer than I expected.  The menu is very extensive with some exotic meats available.  I think we beat the crowd because we were seated right away, but during our meal the restaurant filled up.  They were really nice and attentive.  Our waters were refilled very quickly, which I greatly appreciated because I couldn't handle some of the spicy-ness.

DINNER
Duck curry- no pineapple.  
+rice
Papaya salad with raw crab- med spicy was too spicy for me!  But this was really good.
Durian and sticky rice-  don't judge!  we devoured this stinky treat

The food was delicious, nice ambiance, and great service.  All in all a solid meal.
author: Lyn C.

description: I'm shocked that this place gets 4 stars, especially in SF where the food standard should be higher. I tried the other location in Hayes a few years ago and it was fine, but not particularly good enough to go back to. I decided to give the Larkin location a shot and regretted it. I ordered the duck dish and ended up with literally just fat and skin. Only 2 slices of the duck had some meat. I also ordered the eggplant dish, and it was more like a carrot and tofu dish. The pad see ew had over cooked, chewy beef and chicken. The food here is garbage. Avoid.
author: Valerie D.

description: Stopped by to do some work on the door and all I can say is A+ customer service. While working, our stomachs were grumbling with the delicious smell of the food. Will definitely come by for the lunch special. Great people + Good Food = Winner!
author: David S.

description:
This is a great Thai restaurant.  It can be a bit warm inside, but on with the food.

Crab fried rice, moist, crab pieces and great flavoring.
Pad Thai not too tangy and served with shrimp as the selected option.
Green curry a bit spicy, but still good.  Chunks of fig in their, that was a positive surprise.  

They didn't ask for spice level on any of the dishes, not sure if they forgot, or they just give it to you as is.
author: Kent H.

description: Hands down the best Thai food outside of Thailand and I should know, I ate my way through the whole country while all the other guys were chasing girls and drinking. I win! Try duck curry, duck larb, papaya salad with prawn, Chiang Mai sausage, Garlic Quail, Moo Gratiem.
author: Chazz D.

description:
The ambiance is cute and modern! The bathrooms are a maze to get to and super small. Got the beef pad Thai and the Tom Khan? Soup... It was the Tom coconut soup lol. I normally get the tom Yum soup at Thai places but the coconut was highly recommended, not disappointed with either dishes! The egg rolls for apps for meh, no meat...if there was then hardly any lol

4 stars for the atmosphere!
author: Isabelle C.

description:
Been here a few times and have never been disappointed. One of a few decent restaurants open late in the area if you don't feel like eating bar food or pizza.  Came in after an evening Giants games for a late night bite. My favorite item to order at Thai restaurants is always papaya salad and they have several options here, raw crabs, grilled prawns, and salted eggs. We shared the prawn papaya salad, medium spicy.  The prawns were huge and plenty. The dressing was a nice balance and medium spicy was not taste bud numbing spicy but just right.  
The other dishes we've tried are the duck larb, green curry, pork belly, and sticky rice with mango. All tasty. They also have frog and rabbit dishes.
author: Naty D.

description:
Typically I call in take out from Lers Ros over the years and they were polite, the food, tasty. 
TL/DR if you want to skip the attitude and tourist prices go around the corner to Sai Jai https://www.yelp.com/biz/sai-jai-thai-restaurant-san-francisco?hrid=4apRb41o8Vzv8N4ZVd6u3g

The service 2.21.17 10 PM was poor from the start the hostess acted like a clerk from Macy's all indifference and passive aggression I sat solo at the bar and I can say they didn't give me equal treatment.  It was a super weird vibe uncomfortable but I was hungry and got it over with. The food is ok of course but come on the world is full of good Thai food.  I had number 77 and some white house wine.

The night wait staff with the exception of one woman who wears black thick framed glasses were stiff as cardboard no smiles no small talk unless I started it so I'll be skipping the attitude and tourist prices for Sai Jai Thai up the street on Larkin around the corner on O'Farrell better bang for your buck and less I'm smelling myself attitude.

Go to Sai Jai instead for some down to earth Thai goodness 
https://www.yelp.com/biz/sai-jai-thai-restaurant-san-francisco?hrid=4apRb41o8Vzv8N4ZVd6u3g
author: SF T.

description: I remember coming here three years ago and it was good, but I recently came back and it was nothing like I remembered it.
