They had a good selection of pork/chicken/beef/seafood entrees, salads, curry, noodles and other special dishes. I ordered the pad see ew and it was not flavorful at all. The noodles had an awful texture, all mushed together and just broke down like a noodle boiled in water too long. I also got a beef plate with peanut sauce, which I thought was better than the noodles, but still nothing too special. Pricing was reasonable & they have a long wine selection. Perhaps I went on an off day tho, so check it out because I heard some good things about it.
author: Vivian L.

description:
,This is one of my most favorite Thai restaurant in USA!  Very authentic n has such a variety. Everytime I come, they never disappoint me. 
My favorite are:
 Pad Ped Moo Pa (spicy wild boar),  stir fry with authentic Thai chili paste in Thai herbs (hard to find a place that does it perfectly).

Tom Sap Spare ribs (spicy Thai soup with either pork or pork spare ribs in Thai herbs). 

Their special Crab cakes with plum sauce (just like Thailand)! 

I would usually pair them with Singha beer from Thailand, enhances the flavor even more. 

If u  are looking for an authentic Thai restaurant n great service, can't come to San Francisco n not stop by. I recommend making reservations on the weekends. Definitely long wait.
author: Mary J.

description: Crave-worthy pad see ew. I've had this dish all my life and it tastes the best from here, IMO. Not in the safest and not in the cleanest neighborhood. Bring cash even though they accept cards. The pad see ew is delish and it's not cheap! All in with tax is $13 for the tofu version.
author: Alias A.

description:
Group of five got dinner here after another place that we were going to go to was closed. Got seated relatively quickly. Interior decor is very cool but it's definitely intimate. Service was fast and efficient. We ordered the following:

- Tom Yum soup: very good - perfect for a cool Bay Area night
- Spring rolls: excellent appetizer
- Pad Kee Mao: I ordered a veggie one and though it was good it wasn't amazing. Still solid though. 

Prices were fair and the portions were generous. Would definitely recommend to everybody.
author: Izzat A.

description:
This is one of the best Thai restaurants out there. The pork belly appetizer dish rivals the taste of the equivalent. Do yourself a favor and step outside your "Pad Thai" comfort zone in your typical Americanized Thai restaurant and order some crazy dishes. The larb is also amazing here as well as the Tom Yum noodles.

My Thai wife straight from the old country gives this two huge thumbs up. One of the best San Francisco has to offer.
author: Doug R.

description:
Breathtaking, my whole palate has been re-synchronized because of "Lers Ros." It's listed in the San Francisco Chronicle as one of the top 100 Bay Area restaurants of 2014. I don't know about anybody else, but this is in my top five of cuisine revelations. The Chef Recommends something like twenty items -- off the list I know I have to come back and try Pad Cha Rockfish Fillet, Steamed Seabass with Lemongrass & Lime, Stir-Fried Pork Belly with Basil, Thai Herb Sausage, Garlic Quail and Pad Phed Alligator. Because I'm the adventurous type, that's why. 

Problem is I already got a number one:

House Special LEK TOM YUM HAENG -- Steamed skinny rice noodles with ground pork, sliced fish cake, crispy pork belly, and dry tom yum noodle (tastes like crushed peanuts, it adds an elegant crunch to each bite). I love noodle squishiness, I love spongy fish cake, I love ground pork quaintly fiery, I love pork belly tamed fatty with that crispy-scorched outside. You put all those element together, and you have enchantment. Funny how there's not a lot of reviews that mention this dish, so I'm glad it's in mine. We discovered it by accident ("Let's try something new!" and so we chose randomly). It's a problem, if you were wondering, only because it's gonna be a must-order dish every time I come in now, pushing everything else to second priority.

I have had several other dishes. I don't need to get all blustery about what else is good. This is first-class Thai, everything is excellent. But sure, any coconut soup or lemongrass fish or ground pork or prawns with specialty sides is going to be magnificent. Just don't order something you can get at any old ordinary Thai restaurant. #classiceats
author: Sean C.

description: Waitress was pleasant but had a hard time understanding what a side order is. We each ordered an appetizer and entree but my date got all his food a full 10 minutes before I got anything I ordered. The larb was delicious but too spicy to eat. People who really really love hot could probably tolerate it (I have medium-low tolerance for an Asian). The rest of the food was good but not great. It cost $90 for 2 people at lunch, which felt like a ton of money for the food and experience we got. It felt like what I could get for half the price at other good Thai places in the city. Interesting menu offerings though, so I might consider coming back and ordering just one thing or other, but then again that feels a bit restrictive. Maybe not worth the effort.
author: Kris F.

description: The service is good. But the food is not that great. Is definitely not the best Thai restaurant in sf. Pad kee mao is very very ok. Same case with tom yum soup. But the whole fish tilapia dish was amazing if not for the bones.
author: Ash M.

description:
Their menu is crazyyyy.  So many choices.  If you must get one thing, you have to get the lek tom yum haeng, which is basically their version of dry tom yum noodles.  The flavors are multi-faceted (nutty, sweet, citrusy, herbs!) but not overwhelming, and the pork belly is yummy.  It might sound boring or plain, but this is delicious!  You won't regret getting it.

I also tried the pad see ew, which is good (not too salty or sweet, fluffy and cooked to perfection), but I would not go out of my way to get this again.  

I wasn't a big fan of the papaya salad with raw crab either.  The raw crab is kind of like really mushy raw scallops, and the salad itself was drenched in dressing (too salty) and covered with pepper flakes.  We asked for medium spice, but this was very spicy for papaya salad!

I would definitely come back for the lek tom yum haeng, and probably try another untraditional pick versus the usual Thai staples.
author: Lily N.

description: AMAZING, AMAZING, AMAZING. Trust me, I've had PLENTY of Thai Food, some great, some not so much but this place IS THE BEST IVE EVER HAD! The Pad Thai was sooooooo delicious!!! Even had the best Thai Tea ever. Our server Moss was super friendly and attentive which made our experience perfect. Thanks again, I'll be back tomorrow, and the day after that!! :)
author: Angela S.

description: Lers Ros Thai was a long awaited experience for me. Luckily there was no wait when my friend and I came here for lunch on a Friday. I ordered from their rice plate lunch specials and chose the Kha Na Moo Krob (Stir fried crispy pork belly with Chinese broccoli and garlic) since I heard it was one of the dishes they are best known for. It was without a doubt delicious, perfectly seasoned with great texture! The only thing is the dish was a little on the oily side. Otherwise, I would gladly come back to try their other dishes!
author: Debra T.

description:
I parked a little too far and found myself walking for too long down SKETCH streets. I always thought Lers Ros Thai had a similar vibe but walking into the restaurant, found a nice bar, modern tables and clean walls!

I had to get the Duck Larb ... thought it was good but came across a few unwelcomed bones. Messy but a refreshing salad/app. I then went pork crazy and had both the Pork Shoulder and Pork Belly. I was anticipating a fall off the bone pork shoulder. It was cooked differently than anticipated and although good, nothing special. Threw some thai chili sauce on it and moved on. The Pork Belly was the winning pork dish! It was fatty, flavorful and came in sauce perfect for rice. This was a lot for just 2 people!! Still.. my Thai staple is Pad Sew Ew and i ordered it anyways. Can't go wrong with this dish anywhere. 

I don't know if i have to go out of my way to eat here though but i can see the edge over places such as King of Thai or Marnee Thai.
author: Samantha L.

description: My hubby grew up in Thailand so we love Thai food.  Our gold standard is Marnee Thai on 9th Ave. We tried the fried rice and pad thai. The fried rice was just okay but the pad thai is the best I have ever had in the city. I will be back to discover other dishes.
author: C L.

description: Definitely too expensive for the quality of the food and the location. The soup was good.
author: Riccardo B.

description: Thank you Yelp for helping finding this place! This place is awesome!! Probably the best I've ever had and I eat Thai quite a bit! I got 76) Pad Kee Mow, freaking amazing. My teenager got it too with medium spice, was too hot for him, but he ate it. I got medium spice too and it was perfect for me! I can't imagine what hot would be! Probably still good, just would have to have a glass of water after every bite. Love this place, yum!
author: Heather E.

description:
Ever since I saw Lers Ros on Check Please, I've been wanting to check them out. Back in July of last year, I finally did when I was at a gf's house. Since she lives in their delivery zone, we ordered delivery.

*Duck larb: a chunk of roasted duck mixed with rice powder, chili powder and lime based salad dressing http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lers-ros-thai-san-francisco#FLgbN0LydgnwrW-x5FJY_g
*Grilled pork shoulder salad: spicy lime dressing and roasted quick marinated pork shoulder, basil leaves, chili & rice powder http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lers-ros-thai-san-francisco#uFRNr6ODmlBbYtc07ooGfA
*Papaya salad: shredded green papaya salad with chili, tomatoes, lime based salad dressing http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lers-ros-thai-san-francisco#hATIFWIMyKbkbAZ44k0yNQ
*Steamed sea bass: steamed fresh bass with chopped chili and fresh lime juice http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lers-ros-thai-san-francisco#NmXYa3s8NQMJJLHh1YKKzA

I was super excited to try the steamed sea bass. I love steamed fish! It had a great spicy sour flavor to it. And the fish was super moist and tender. The papaya salad was good, but we ordered it spicy, so I wish it was spicier. Both the duck larb and pork shoulder salad were good as well, but the fish was really my fav!

Since I was helping out my gf, dinner was on her. Can't say no to that! Now if only Lers Ros delivered to my neighborhood! Wishful thinking I guess!
author: Elena N.

description: Had the chicken pad Thai here, which might have been the best pad Thai I've had in this country. It was the right amount of spicy, juicy and flavorful. Even the date couldn't stop herself from asking for more bites of my food, that's how good it was. The location is also just about right and the staff is very welcoming.
author: Shiv W.

description:
After a crazy day of walking and exploring one of my favorite cities, I was craving some good Thai food. The reviews don't lie...Lers Ros is pretty incredible. Since I had 2 little kids with me, we just picked up the food to eat in the hotel, so can't comment about the service or the restaurant itself. The food, though, was delicious. 

We ordered the crispy pork belly, pad see ew and crab fried rice. The pork belly was pretty good and the fried rice came loaded with crab meat. Both these dishes were tasty but not spicy at all. The pad see ew on the other hand was amazing! It was so spicy, I was in heaven!

I liked the Thai ice tea here as well...unlike most places, this one wasn't overly sweet...was perfect.

If you are carving good Thai in SF, look no further. Lers Ros did not disappoint!
author: Ratika N.

description:
Thai is ALWAYS my go to when seeking a place for dinner, so when I was visiting San Francisco my friends were wise to select Lers Ros Thai. We waited a bit to be seated (I actually kind of dig how intimate the seating is), and eventually got a table. The first thing I noticed was how loud it was - this isn't necessarily a bad thing, especially considering the amount of people in a small space. This just took a minute to get used to, but I barely noticed anyone else once we were situated.

 We were swiftly brought water and our server opened our wine while we perused the menu. We opted to start with one of the papaya salads (one of my friends ordered this for the table and I honestly could not tell you which one, but it was good AF). For an entree I got the Kang Dang Pak. This was exactly what I was looking for - red curry, tofu, spiciness, veggies. It was delicious, and my only regret was having to each the whole portion in one sitting (it was SO much food but I couldn't take my leftovers to go). I can't recall the other dishes on the table but I vaguely remember yellow curry and a chicken dish with rice. The food overall was banging to say the least, and it goes without saying that BYOBs rule the dining world. I would definitely recommend Lers Ros Thai for good service and delicious food.
author: Tommy M.

description:
My Thai friend took me here a few years ago. Food was good back then. However, I ordered the same food tonight that was horrible. 

Seafood noodles with red sauce: Extremely salty. Portion is small. I would say any thai restaurants can do a better job than they do.

Squid salad: it's tasteless. There was a time I thought the chef forget to add any seasoning into the salad.
author: J L.

description:
Everything on the menu is delicious. I love that the "spicy" is really spicy but still flavorful. Staples are great-pad Thai and curry. 

There's typically a wait. I sometimes get take out which is pretty quick. One star off because the restaurant has a fishy/sour smell that is really unappetizing to me. Not sure if I'm the only one it bothers but it's noticeable when you first enter.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Service was very slow but worth the wait

Only a few minutes at the door for three on a Sunday night in a packed and very hot space for maybe 50ppl. After 8 minutes we were ready to order but no service. About 4 minutes later, we had a server. Man, I'm sweating from this heat and could use a cold one. So glad you made it. Better order everything now, before she leaves. 

Pork meatballs were delicious, melt in your mouth good
Mango or something like that salad. It was that memorable
Green curry was as expected
Porkbelly is the WINNER

The food was fantastic!
The service was crap. 
Averages out to 4/5 because of the food/cost. You get more than you pay for in fabulous food but you wait for it.
author: Mark F.

description: If I could add another star I would!! Great service and the food was seasoned to perfection! I couldn't decide so I got both (Total $30.27) !! The fried chicken with fried rice (best fried rice I've ever had in my life!) and also the Ton Yum soup to start (deliciously sour and spicy)!
author: Lóla A.

description:
Me and my friends literally came in to eat a late dinner at 11:49pm and they close at 12am! Haha whoops, we felt bad we were so hungry! But they were so nice and friendly that they let us in to eat anyway. 

I got the pad kee mow which is spicy flat noodles. I'm actually kind of craving it right now while I'm writing this. I got the vegetarian option which they just put tofu and broccoli in the dish instead of meat. I love how the noodles are actually spicy! I hate it when restaurants write that a dish is spicy and when I eat it, it has like no spice to it whatsoever. I wish they could have given me more tofu and actually put in an egg. I noticed that when my friends ordered noodle dishes that they didn't get egg in it either. In all the other Thai places that I've eaten at, they always put egg in their noodle dishes. I promise it tastes better with an egg!
author: Christina G.

description:
Got a craving for some great Thai Food? Well, you found the place! Lers Ros Thai is a small little restaurant about 7 blocks from the heart of the city. 

Ordered: 
Pad-see-ew w/ chicken $9.95 
Yellow Curry w/ Prawns $12.95
Thai Iced Tea $2.50
Brown Rice $2.00

Serving Sizes: I would say moderate. It's not a huge serving, but it's just enough. 

Final Thoughts: The Pad-see-ew was good, but not the best dish I've ever had. You can definitely order this dish elsewhere and get a bigger serving with better flavor.
author: Briana H.

description:
To be honest I was under the impression that SF, despite its abundance of fine dining, was totally hopeless when it came to fast and affordable Asian food options. It didn't even have very good EXPENSIVE Asian food (I'm looking at you, R & G Lounge). Enter Lers Ros, which I ironically only discovered via their shameless Virgin America promos.

I was feeling lazy so I had an order of Pad See Ew delivered via Caviar (https://www.trycaviar.com/san-francisco/lers-ros-thai--mission-1897) and it was deeeeee-licious. The portion was sizable, the noodles were perfectly al dente and they were smothered with a traditional sweet Thai soy sauce. I was in total heaven. I basically never need to leave the house again.

Can't wait to go in person and try their BOAT NOODLES! My fave, yum yum. 
5 stars and a very happy :)
author: Jackie C.

description:
3.5 stars
This is better the usual Thai food. We started with the curry chicken puff with peanut sauce which was light and flaky. We then had the chicken in yellow curry which was good but a tad on the hot side for me. The spare ribs were also spicy, yet I expected it for was this dish. The meat was delicious. And the shrimp with asparagus was also very good. Portions are a tad smaller than usual. I'd like to try some of their noodle dishes.  With very attentive servers, nice hip vibe I can see why this place is popular.
author: AB H.

description:
Came here for a work luncheon. We had reservations for 7 at noon. We arrived a little early and the place was quite empty. By the time 12:15 rolled around, the restaurant was packed! Even the bar area was full.
I was so thankful that we did "family" style and everyone got to order a dish. Coming here, I was wanting to try a little bit of everything. No one was adventurous to try the frog or alligator. There was sooo many items on the menu. Took us at least 15 minutes to look it over. 

Here's what we had for the table:
Appetizers
Fried Rolls - Super hot! I chose to eat my egg roll with a spoon and fork for fear that I'd burn my tongue.
Nuer Tod (fried beef)  - Reminded me a lot of beef jerky. It came out warm and was quite tasty!
Garlic Quail- As adventurous as our table got. I had a small serving- tasted just like chicken!
Som Tom Koong Yang (papaya salad)- As soon as it was brought to our table, I smelled the fish sauce. And talk about flavor overload! Spicy/sweet/refreshing and very good

Main Dishes
Pad See-Ew- Both noodle dishes were fantastic. Somewhat sweet .
Pad Thai- Plenty of large prawns
Kai Yang- BBQ Chicken
Nuer Yang- (Top sirloin beef) One of my favorite dishes, the meat was very tender.
Pra Ram Nuer (Beef in peanut sauce) Reminded me of the Filipino dish, kare kare. I loved the peanut sauce and was pouring it over my rice!
Koong Priew Warn (prawns in sweet and sour sauce)

Everything at our table was just about finished. This was probably one of the best Thai restaurants I've been to. I'd love to come back and try one of their curries.

As for service, getting our orders taken was somewhat slow. But, as soon as the order was taken, our food came out very fast! 
It's in a sketchy part of the TL and can easily be missed- definitely worth trying out!
author: Mimie L.

description:
Such cool decor -- trendy community table in the middle, writing and quotes on the walls.

Extensive menu -- exceptionally creative dishes that aren't on a standard Thai menu. My dining companion and I loved the unique Lek Tom Yum Haeng which was definitely out of the ordinary. Steamed rice noodles, minced peanuts and chili powder, ground pork, fish cake. Sounded like a weird combo but when we mixed it all together it was delicious.

Weird things to try -- garlic frog and pad ped ALLIGATOR?!

Big portions -- oh yeah, it's the American way.

Great prices -- $10 to $15 for dishes, typically with all my favorite noodle dishes only $10.

On a recent Saturday night around 6:30pm, we were seated right away at a spot in the community table. About an hour later there was a huge line of people waiting outside.

TIP: The rad nar, the slightly soupy noodle dish I always get at Thai restaurants, was on the sour side. Surprisingly didn't like it all that much.
author: Peijean T.

description:
I went here to eat dinner with friends in person. I had a good experience, so I thought I would UberEATS with Lers Ros. Rookie mistake...Pad Thai was not flavorful and portion side was significantly smaller than the pad thai I was served in the restaurant. 

TLDR: don't UberEATS here
author: Lucas C.

description: Very loud even though only 1/2 full when I went.  But, the noisy guests were probably the cause as much as acoustics. I had heard the food here is so amazing, I was disappointed that the curry was quite thin.  It's a pleasant space and the food is good enough, but there are better options for Thai food in my opinion.
author: Jill G.

description:
I like going outside of my comfort zone every once in a while when it comes to food. Who would have thought that a visit at a city-wide known Thai restaurant would make me do that?

Ready for some exotic stuff? Let's get into it:

YOUNG ALLIGATOR ($21) - if you've never tried alligator (I don't blame you) then this is your chance. The meat has a nice texture to it, and it reminded me of chicken (sorry, alligator fans). Super spicy and yes, enjoyable.

GARLIC FROG ($9.95) - Unless you're from Gilroy you probably don't get in touch with garlic too often - this portion of meaty frog and garlic will blow your senses. The frog meat comes in a bone, so just imagine it's Frog BBQ and enjoy it. 

CRUNCHY RABBIT ($15.95) - deep-fried rabbit in a garlic-pepper sauce. Something to chew on as it's deep-fried, I was told it's one of their specialities. Interesting taste, reminded me of Christmas. Yes, Christmas.

Less exotic, but really good were the TOM KHA BOWL ($13) with tofu and mushrooms, and the THAI SHRIMP ($15) with sticky rice and vegetables. 

Unleashing my inner Indiana Jones I have to say - delicious! 

One last note from your friendly neighborhood frog-eater: Make reservations. For one reason or another this place is POPULAR.
author: Sebastian F.

description: Amazing. In and out in 30 minutes. Also some delicious food. High recommendation to anyone looking for good Thai food for under $20.
author: Emily W.

description:
Came here for dinner one night. I ordered the Pad Kee Mow, one of the spicy noodle dishes with pork. It was super great! The portion size was pretty big, and I was definitely full by the end. If you're not used to spicy food, watch out though. Some of my friends found the meal too hot to handle!

One weird thing was that the waitresses handed us our checks even before the food came to the table. Throughout the night, they also kept grabbing at the checks to see if we had paid yet, both before we'd gotten our food and while we were still eating. I think they were trying to push our group (7 people) out fast, but it still was quite rude and detracted from a welcome experience overall.
author: Jen A.

description: I asked Andy Ricker (my all time chef-restauranteur crush/Pok Pok owner) a recommendation on thai restaurants to eat at in SF. He recommended a few including Lers Ros and I was stoked to eat here after looking up the menu. The service was  on point and the food was even better. I ordered the Tom Kha Khai (with a side of sticky rice, never forget the sticky rice!) Tom Yum Koong, and the Kao Pad. Every dish was fresh, flavor-filled and mouthwatering. This will be my stop every time I go back to San Fran. Period.
author: Coco L.

description: def unique with the menu selection, cooking was good too. just a bit pricey regarding the portion.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Everything here is SOLID! I liked that they even had unique dishes on their menu like frog, alligator, and venison. Came here on Sunday night around 6 pm and there was no wait for a group of 4. The ambiance of the restaurant was nice despite a not so nice neighborhood in the Tenderloin and the service was quick.

We ordered a ton of dishes and they came spaced out so I was really full by the time the last plate came out. Some highlights of the meal:
 
Garlic frog ($10) - ordered this since I rarely see frog on menus and wanted the others in my party to try it. The sauce and seasoning were great. Frog tastes a lot like chicken with a slightly fishy taste - it wasn't the others favorite but I liked it a lot.

Duck salad ($10) - the pictures of it on Yelp looked good but to be honest none of us were very impressed by this dish

Green curry with chicken ($11) - really delicious curry but the dish was pretty spicy for me I could only eat a little

Pad See Ew ($10) - SO DELICIOUS I was really sad that this was the last dish that came to our table because I was so stuffed I could only have a couple bites of it but one of the best pad see ew I have ever had!

Definitely check this place out!
author: Linda X.

description:
Arrived for a late lunch, and it wasn't crowded at all! We were immediately handed the lunch specials menu. Lunch Specials include two items, white or brown rice, and a salad. I liked that they had so many items available to choose from for your entrée items. My friend was really excited to order the crispy chicken that he had tried the first time he came here, however, they ran out! He was pretty disappointed, especially since we came here just for that!

Service:
Servers were polite and friendly, and the food came out pretty fast.

Food:
- Cashew Chicken - Chicken was tender and juicy! The sauce was light yet flavorful. It was also mixed with cooked onions and carrots.
- Tofu with Vegetables - Tofu was soft and was cooked with carrots and lettuce.
- Yellow Curry - Comes with chicken, carrots, and onions. Very tasty! I definitely made sure to pour the entire bowl over the rice!
- Fried Tofu - Outer skin was crispy. Comes with a sweet and sour peanut sauce for dipping.
- Side Salad - I really enjoyed the sweet dressing!

Overall, I really enjoyed the food! I will definitely be back when I am in the area!
author: Lisa Y.

description:
After quite a while we finally made it to Lers Ros for the first time! Though we had a reservation we still had to wait an additional 20 mins. Though not ideal, not a huge deal.

Food was pretty authentic, high quality and very tasty. Portions were also pretty good for almost all dishes... almost:

- Papaya salad with prawns - 4/5 - high quality, fresh, good portion
- Pork shoulder - 5/5 - really really good!!! BEST DISH OF THE NIGHT
- Duck Curry - 3/5 - reasonable taste but hardly any duck in the curry
- Pad See Ew - 4/5 - good quality
- Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (Pork Belly) - 5/5 - very good!! crispy pork belly - SECOND BEST of the night ;)
- Dessert - fried banana - 3/5 - pretty average

Now here's what I didn't like... waiters kept coming pushing to take out dishes even when we were still eating / there was still food left. 

All in all pretty good food. Worth coming back.
author: Nuno S.

description:
Popular place, long wait, but the dish that I had was really good! 

I got the Lek Tom Yum Haeng which is their dry version of a tom yum noodle (which I love!). The sticky noodles were cooked perfectly, the crispy pork belly was amazing, the flavor was on point and the ground pork, and fish cake was good and the peanuts added a perfect crunch. 

Overall, you bet I finished that dish. I would come back for a another bowl.
author: Sophia Y.

description: Went here yesterday with some coworkers. Ordered two chicken pad thais and one chicken pad see ew togo. My coworker said the pad Thai was tasted fishy. I was like no way. Pad Thai fishy? Then I ate mine. Extremely salty. Drenched in sauce. I love thai food also. I have eaten them everywhere in the city. I have never thrown out my thai food till now. My other coworker said the pad see ew was bland. Maybe someone random was cooking because I had better from here but Im ok with not coming back.
author: Michael L.

description:
I've eaten dinner here three times now, and it's been consistently mediocre. I've mostly tried the tofu-based starters, the spicy stir-fried noodle dishes like pad see-ew, and soups like tom yum.

As one example of what I mean by mediocre, a fried tofu "wings" starter always comes as a pile of bland hunks of tofu accompanied by a small serving of a bland, sweet sauce. Other Thai places offering this dish seem deliver theirs with flavor through-and-through.
author: David S.

description:
Best Thai food I have ever had!  The wait staff was attentive and polite.  Their menu selection and drink selection are huge with all your favorite options.  

The lunch specials are $8.95 and come with a side salad with a lightly flavored coconut vinaigrette.  You can select two main corse lunch items.  

The green and red curry are delicious and creamy with fresh vegetables and thinly sliced meats.

Best Pad Thai ever!!! The Garlic
pork was super good too!! The atmosphere at lunch time on a week day was really loud.  We arrived at 11:45 AM and the place was empty; within 30 minutes the place was packed...a large group arrived with about 30 people and they had their table set and ready for them with food.

Great place, great food!!
author: Kim K.

description:
Really great place to grab Thai Food at SF. Awesome service, we were 13 of us and they got us seated together after a 5 minute wait. 

As for the food, we didn't order anything off the ordinary like the rabbit or alligator etc. Rabbit meat was a lil rough but the rest of what we ordered were awesome. Had a good time catching dinner
author: Sebin K.

description: I came here for lunch after hearing such good things about this place. We ordered Pad-e-seew with beef, green papaya salad with raw crab, duck larb and tom yum soup with shrimps. I gotta say everything was AMAZING! All of them were very flavorful and tasted about just right. However, our server was a bit not "friendly" so i took one star off. Another star off was because i found a small piece of aluminum in one of my dishes, which i think could be from opening a can or something. They ended up giving me that dish for free. Overall, great experience, good food and i might come back if i was in the Bay again.
author: Polly T.

description:
I simply don't get this. Not just about this restaurant but every other over hyped and over priced restaurant in the city. Forget the hype and the price for a moment. The food was pathetic. 

I asked for an order of cashew chicken and spicy tofu. I asked them to make it spicy. Order taking and pickup was all smooth. Food though was terrible. Absolutely no flavor. The cashew chicken looked white with zero spice and zero taste. Tofu was dry and had no flavor as well. C'mon restaurant goers - be honest with your reviews so that restaurants don't get away with murder. 

Go somewhere else for Thai food! This is not even close to Thai!
author: Arun M.

description: Good restaurant, suggest to come before 5:30pm. The restaurant will get really crowded after 6:00pm.authentic Thai food, good service, everything is great!
author: Echo W.

description: Their noodles aren't bad, but I've had a big issue with their tofu. One time they made it really dry, and another the tofu didn't taste bad but they barely included any within my dish.
author: Alan B.

description: This is one of the best authentic Thai restaurants in SF. They have amazing stuff in the menu. I recommend the crispy pork belly, deep fried tilapia (or flounder) and their Tom kha gai (should be its own food group, IMHO). Service is better than your average Asian establishment but can be slow when they are busy. Great value for the money.
author: Andrew S.

description:
We ate here on a Tuesday night at 6:00.  We liked the ambiance when we walked in.  Although the noise level is 8 bombs.  Our server didn't understand English very well and that was a bit frustrating.  They have a good selection of wines.

We didn't get our itemized bill back with our credit card slips so I can say exactly what we had.  We had the chicken puffs to start at they were 10 stars.  We had a chicken dish that I liked but my friend thought it was bland.  We had a duck dish that was way too salty for me.  They also had whole hot red peppers in it.  Thankfully I saw them and picked them all out before one of us put one in our mouth. (Been there, done that and it was no fun).
author: Jan F.

description: Best thai I have ever had, pad thai pak was amazing as well the starchy yellow curry.
author: Chris M.

description:
This place is surprisingly not expensive , we had diner for two people with alcohol ( 3 bears ) and a dessert and we end up paying only $60 
I tried a few different Thai restaurants in the city , this one was the best so far ! 
Highly  recommended,very good food !!! 

if you end up ordering a papaya salad ( make sure you have three glasses of water because it's hell a spicy )
author: Alex B.

description:
Lers Ros is Damn Good.
This is a solid establishment that is a must for fans of Thai food!!

Their Khao Pad Boo is great!! The rice is cooked perfectly and there is plenty of crab in it. Add a little lime and a little prik nam plaa for added taste and it's heaven. It might be the best I've found thus far.
Their Khao Moo yang is off the chain though. I mean this dish is a Mike Tyson uppercut to the jaw knock out taste. This is probably the best dish I've had from them. Beautifully cooked pork shoulder lightly coated with lime and mixed with chilli, green onions, thai basil, and so on. This took me back to some of my favorite culinary spots in Bangkok, Amphawa, and Cha'Am. 
Heck even the Thai Iced Tea "Chai Yen" is great. It's not too sweet, but just sweet enough. They give a good amount of it and it's not ridiculously expensive either.
Also the sticky rice with Durian is friken insane. It's absolutely delicious. If you try it and you don't like it you need to scrape the taste buds out of your mouth and find some new ones because this ish is crazy good.  

Now, because I'm a bit picky I have a few gripes & suggestions. 
The staff can be a bit cold. They need to work on their people skills a bit.

Also, for effect, I wish they played more, if not all Thai music. Stream some Green Wave online and it's all good. The brilliant tastes  of Lers Ros have already transported me to Thailand. Let the music keep there. 

The decorations are a bit weak. Chairs & tables allow for many people but they're a bit uncomfy & the cheesy quotes on the walls need to go.
author: Gilbey G.

description:
I usually want to review a restaurant before I even finish eating for two reasons:
(1) I don't know what I just ate and have just become really concerned for my health (2) The food is delicious and I can't wait to tell the world 

You probably already guessed from my rating that it's the second reason in this case. Lers Ros probably has the best thai food I've tried in the Bay Area!

What to order:

Lek Tom Yum Haeng (special): this dish will give you a taste of their signature pork belly and it has a funny combination of sweet salty and spicy.

Papaya salad with grilled shrimp (#13): its light and filling. Great as an appetizer to share.

Pork shoulder appetizer (#9): what meal is complete without some pork?
author: Vivian W.

description:
i've only ever ordered from here on uber eats and never been to the physical location so this is just a review for the food - which is so flipping good! 

i always got the tom kha ga soup with veggies and tofu, the shredded papaya salad, and the green curry with veggies and tofu. everything is so flavorful and so fresh with the perfect amount of spice. the soup has a variety of mushrooms like wood ear and oyster which is rad for a mushroom lover like me (you could call me a fungal).

one day i'll visit the brick and mortar and update the review accordingly but for now, food wise, 5 stars!
author: Gaby K.

description: Really cute place! Long lines on weekend and has a packed but lively feel to it. Absolutely good food to boot my fellow yelpers. I've had better thai but I eat thai a lot so I have high standards. Recommended as a good spot that hits the spot ha!
author: Sarah M.

description: We went on a weekend night and it was crowded and noisy.  Had a lousy table right in front of the main door.  Food was good.
author: Jim L.

description:
Was told this place had the best Thai food but I was a little disappointed. Maybe the food wasn't as good bc i didn't eat it there and had it delivered to me.

For delivery: free delivery starts at 5. It takes an hour for them to deliver even though ure only a block away.  However, they make it to you in an hour exactly.  

Pad see ew chicken:  generous portion size, lots of chicken!!! Noodles had a chargrilled taste- it was almost too smokey for me.  Noodles were soggy.  Overall dish was too salty.

Crab fried rice: again, generous portion size, lots of crab meat! Better than the pad see ew! Less salty and not as soggy as the noodles!
author: june k.

description:
There are a lot of great Thai restaurants in the tenderloin and I would not consider this place to be one of them. We were seated right away and our drink orders were taken. They brought my friend a cup of hot water (rather than iced or even room temperature).My friend and I both ordered the pad see ew, yet hers got to the table about 15 minutes before mine and was a really small portion. When mine finally arrived, it was at least double the amount for some inexplicable reason. The food itself was fine. The green vegetables were undercooked and bitter.

The seats don't have backs so there isn't anywhere to hang a coat or a purse, and they seated people literally at the table with us despite most of the other tables in the restaurant being open which was really awkward.
author: Madeline S.

description:
Spot on Thai restaurant in SF hands down. A late night joint for foodgasm after a movie in AMC Van ness.

- Closes at 12 midnight. Definitely good news for SF which hardly has any late night spots
- Extensive menu list, so much to choose from
- Serve good portions of food
- Exclusive range of meats available. This is the place to try rabbit, alligator, boar, frog 
- MUST Try  #9 Pork Shoulder Appetizer, #62 Pork Belly w/ Pork Rinds & Basil, Stir-fried Pork belly w/ Crispy Rinds
- Good news for the vegetarians - have good veggie options too
- Accepts credit card
- Not in the best of location - Tenderloin. 
- Ambiance modern, clean
- Service is fast and attentive.
- FREE delivery over $25 within 2 miles of their locations, but be ready to wait for an hour
author: Payal B.

description:
Best Thai Food in California that I have tried so far. Oh how I wish this place was closer to me.

I really like how they have some "strange" things on the menu and it's not just the typical chicken, pork, beef choices. They had boar, alligator, rabbit, frog, etc.

Here is what we got:
1. Garlic Frog (we had 2 people in our group that have never tried frog and I'm glad that this was their first experience. Delish and the sauce perfectly complimented the frog)
2. Boar - tender and flavorful.
3. Pad Kee Mow - you can never go wrong with this dish :)
4. Clams - SO FREAKING GOOD!!! We ended up putting the sauce all over our rice!!
5. Pork Belly - we almost didn't order this dish because our whole group was over the pork belly craze, but the server recommended it. THANK YOU SERVER!!! It's not the normal pork belly you get....this one has a VERY crisp outside which totally makes this dish!

I highly recommend Lers Ros Thai!! You won't be dissappointed.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
I've been eating here for years. I recently gave up meat, so naturally I peeped the vegetarian section of this menu. I asked the waitress if the vegetarian dishes have fish sauce. She said they do.

Can we please clarify this terminology? For vegetarian folk, we usually expect no animals (like fish) in our food.
author: Scott R.

description:
Great Smelling and Tasting Food.
Super Pricey. 
Spacy and beautiful dim lit room.
If your Gonna eat hear, go for your The Good Stuff.
I smell it everynight because I work Next Door.

Gave them a try the other day.
Special plate-papaya shrimp, two chicken thighs and sticky rice with raw cabage. Good.

Pork belly in garlic basil. Good taste lot of yummy sauce. 10bucks.

Extra rice 3bucks.
Thai tea about 3 bucks.
Total around 42 bucks!

Round2-feeling gipped.
Today I had the Garlic Frog ti go. Almost 11 bucks.
Small pieces of fried frog and garlic. few piece of cucumber with sweet dipping sauce on side. This is definetly not worth it.

Garlic brocoli with steam rice. Almost 11bucks. You can get garlic brocolli and rice at a Chinese fast food joint for 5 bucks. If your gonna charge that much, it better be filled to the top!

Giod for Budget Fancy Date.
author: Hung L.

description:
I don't have a death wish or a craving for heroin, but I did want to try this highly reviewed place for a long time....you can seriously witness , be the victim of or commit a crime in this area and no one will care! At least that's the feeling that ran through my mind and body when walking to this place. Parking was easy because my family member drove us and she has a disabled placard. All awful feelings dissipated once I walked into this place. A bad feeling came back when I saw the "exotic" meats on the menu though...I didn't try any of those. 

I moved out of SF and never tried this place til now that I've been gone three years...and boy I really wish I tried it before. It is delicious! It's flavor capitol of all Thai restaurants in SF!!!! The #16 shrimp salad is a flavor explosion like none other!!! The basil chicken was not overly spicy and I lived the texture of the basil chicken. My other dinner companion had shrimp asparagus and that was ok....not that great flavor. My man had crispy chicken over garlic and ginger rice and that really good. Crispy chicken. ..I think it was thigh meat. 

This shrimp salad though....it has lemon grass, mint, purple onion, green onion, lettuce and this amazing acidic spicy dressing that is to die for!!! The prawns were butterflies and grilled....very special dish! But then again a lot of their food seems to be very special!

I hate that this place is in such a forsaken place!!! And their stool chairs suck! The wall has cool quotes from cool food people like Thomas Keller!
author: Yva D.

description:
Blown away. I never thought I could like Thai food this much, but Lers Ros Thai completely changed that. 

We ordered the pad see ew with beef and the popular pork belly that most of the Yelp reviews allude to, and they were both delicious. The pad see ew was packed with flavor and not too salty like most other Thai places. The noodles were also cooked perfectly, whereas most other restaurants I've been to tend to overcook the noodles to the point of being soft. My +1 enjoyed the pork belly more than I did, but that's just because I don't enjoy eating pork belly that much in general. But even with this constraint, I noticed myself reaching for more. I also had a thai iced tea which is probably the best one I've ever had. Oh and did I mention that they have live music in the back?

I was skeptical of all the hype before, but now I'm a part of it :)
author: Claudia C.

description:
I love Lers Ros. Their lunch fare is affordable and delicious ($9 combo last I checked), and their dinners are unique and filling and delicious. 

Last time I was there, I came on a Sunday night, and while many other places in TL were empty, Lers Ros was bustling - we got the last open table - a testament to their quality and deliciousness.We ordered a special that was the Shrimp Paste plate. It was unlike anything I've ever ordered - two fried mackerels, these egg and broccoli cakes, a bunch of steamed veggies and oh - this shrimp sauce that had a spice like nothing I've ever experienced. When we first ordered it, our server warned us - "this thing is stinky and spicy" - it sounded like a challenge! It was awesome, and went well with our other things we ordered as well.

My only complaints are that their chairs don't have backs to them and the waitstaff seems a little young. When I was taking my friends over for the first time, excitedly explaining how tasty the food was, my friend asked, "Are the chairs comfortable?" and I had to say that they were not. My friend felt the chairs were fine when we got there, but they don't have backs to them and are just simple wooden stools really. It's unfortunate b/c it's great to be able to relax at a restaurant, but I guess the little stools mean more people can fit in the restaurant.

And the waitstaff looks young. My partner noticed it, and its hard not to. I don't want to make any assumptions, but its hard to not wonder if the young women working there are there of their own volition and not part of some work in America indenture-esque arrangement. There are all these rooms upstairs that are locked. 

Anyhow, the food is incredible, the chairs and other things less so.
author: Ari F.

description: Decent Thai food and the atmosphere was really nice, however there are also a ton of Thai restaurants around the area so I respect this place for holding its own! It can definitely get crowded though so make sure to watch out for that!
author: Lena T.

description:
One of the best thai places in SF! 

The wait however is quite long on weekends especially Saturday night. Inside the restaurant there isn't much room for people to wait & standing outside at night in the TL district is pretty bad. 

However, the service is great & the food is delicious. The quail dish was my favorite! It was bursting with flavor & the dipping sauce had a kick to it. It could serve about 2 people, 4 is pushing it. 

My second favorite dish is the pork belly! It was delicious! And went along great with white rice. 

The Tom kha soup was a bit too sour & maybe Limey? But the presentation was beautiful. Anything with fire would grab my attention! 

The portions looks smaller compare to my king of thai spot. However, I was surprised that there was a ton of meat in the dishes.
author: Kathleen U.

description:
Glad that guy is gone. Now im coming back more often.
More variety on the lunch special please.
author: Alvin Z.

description:
Went for my birthday on a Saturday night.

- decent food and portion size 
- bench seating 
- too many employees being unproductive/inattentive 
- nice ambie
author: Joanne M.

description: This is really authentic. I go to Thailand once a year and this is the real deal. The fried rice, the papaya salad, the curry. It doesnt matter. I loved every dish I have had here. The place is not big and really loud. But it just adds to this fun experience. I want this place in South Carolina...sigh
author: Bla B.

description:
If you don't mind the Tenderloin and you like Thai food, then you gotta come here. 

Trendy appearing on the inside, unfortunately no A/C, making it quite warm. Impressed with the service, had myself a Thai Iced Tea, and spilled a little. Someone came immediately over and helped to clean it. 

This place is legit. Thai iced tea was not watered down at all and it's richly flavored. Kudos, not every place can do this without sacrificing cost. 

We had the Pad Kee Mao with chicken and green curry with pork.
1) Pad Kee Mao - Oh yeah. This was good. Ordered medium spicy, and should have known that medium spice level at an authentic thai restaurant means hot. However, you could taste the wok hay. Delicious.
2) Green curry with pork - also medium spice level. More tolerable. Packed quite a bit of flavor that went great on the white rice. 

We'll be coming back for sure. Best thai in the city thus far. Looking forward to trying the other locations.
author: Edward L.

description:
Came here for a quick lunch bite

Quick - was seated right away
NO AC - today was a hot day in SF.. Kinda was a drab that it was warm inside..
Food 4/5 star - ordered the chicken Larb with rice powder on the side (beware these "powders" can definitely chip a tooth if you dig into the food carelessly!), BIG portion and chicken salad was seasoned well - loved the lime juice 
Service 3/5 - didn't like the fact that my dad's dish came 5 minutes before mine, while I was waiting hungry.. Workers are nice but not as attentive as I'd like 

Overall, good place for a lunch, I'd rec the lunch specials for the best bang for your $!
author: Jean K.

description: Their delivery portions are significantly smaller than their dine-in portions. Such a rip-off. I went there last night to pick up couple of take-outs and the portions are disappointingly small.
author: Ken W.

description: This is a more upscale Thai restaurant. Prices are higher than your local Thai place. Service is prompt but they don't check up on you after the food comes out. Came here for dinner and ordered beef pad see ew and red curry.  Portions were on the smaller side but the flavor was there.  Both dishes were great.... except for the beef (?)  WTF is that meat? It was completely unedible; chewy and mostly tendon. I had to scoop out all the beef in the curry because I couldn't eat it. Maybe it was an off day, maybe I should've ordered other kinds of meat. However, there are too many good Thai places out there to be back.
author: Yenn T.

description:
Sketch part of town, parking wasn't too bad though. Inside is kinda meh, lacking any real ambiance or warmth. Service was decent and pleasant. 

The portion of curry is laughable. They charge almost $13 and it would maybe fill a teeny bowl. They serve it in a large plate with a dip. Barely enough sauce for 2 people to enjoy it. The red curry was so tasty, but so not worth that price for that portion. They need to stop being so skimpy. Also, pretty sure they overcharged us (should have been less for the veggie curry).

The pad see ew is pretty good, not amazing. Larger portion which was nice to see after the curry debacle. 

I would hesitate to go again given how pricy it is for such small portions. Great Thai food at a lower price can be found.
author: A S.

description: Ordered the sweet and sour chicken, garlic frog legs, and pad kee mao for home delivery. The sweet and sour chicken tasted like it was heated leftovers that were several days old and the portion was miniscule. The frog legs were fried to a point where they were hard enough to damage my teeth. I was wondering if this was to hide that they weren't fresh but I couldn't tell since all taste was gone. The pad kee mau was decent but nowhere near good enough to make up for the other two disastrous meals. This place used to be fantastic but something has changed.
author: Stefan L.

description: My 4th Time here...This place's very Consistent in their food Presentation.. Food taste wise .. YES .. Good thing I have my Thai Roommate who knows how to order.. There are tons to choose from .. I'd say everything that I tasted was GOOD..  I'm very particular about what I eat .. But when I'm here .. I indulge on Brown Rice ..to go with almost all Thai Dish.. Try to explore the menu and you won't regret it.. Did I say Fried Frog !!! Is Good !!!!
author: Donovan L.

description: Everyone I know (4 people, hyperbole is fun) recommended this place as the best Thai in SF -- and after going to all of the locations at least twice, I would have to agree. They occasionally have live music playing which is lovely and the food is always great. Also, my boyfriend has a bunch of serious allergies and they're always willing to accommodate us which is nice.
author: DeAnna C.

description:
Like everyone else, I was impressed by the food here at Lers Ros. It was pretty crowded we were able to get a seat for two relatively quickly. It's not super cheap even thought its near the Tenderloin, it's just that popular and good. The tables in the middle are funny because they can squeeze so many parties, you can make friends if you want! 

For two people we just ordered Pad Thai (omg so basic, whatever sue me) and it was probably the best I have ever had so far, as well as the yellow curry w/ an order of rice (5/5). This was definitely enough for the two of us. I'm no expert on Thai, but I can still appreciate the flavors and goodness of this place. 

In the city and in the mood for some solid Thai food? I would definitely check out this place and see what the hype is all about.
author: Amanda H.

description: Great quality food. One of the best thai places in SF. I would say this location is the best Lers Ros Thai. They do have other locations but the consistency and quality is better here than the other spots for some reason. I had the Pad Thai with beef and it was amazing.
author: Mel S.

description:
Having been to Thailand, this is pretty authentic. The portions looks small, but you will feel very full upon completion. 

order: Pad See Ew, Pad Thai, red/yellow/green curries

There will be a 15-30 minute wait during weekday dinner hours (6 pm), so come early (5 pm) for no wait.

Also, there isn't good cell service in the restaurant.
author: Jackie W.

description:
This place had such good reviews, I was so excited to try!

Here's what we ordered:

Tom Kha - extremely Limey and salty
Pad See Ew - pretty good, nice and chewy
Pork belly - this is all the rave, good but super fatty

Unfortunately, I'm going to have to knock down 2 stars.  First, we wanted the durian rice which took forever to come.  Then, I find a piece of hair on it.  GROSS!  They come back and tell me that they ran out.  Disappointment.
author: Michelle T.

description: We went to this restaurant before the Aladdin show.  This place made me feel cold and unwelcome. Not a single waitress smile to us.  Seating is horrible, no place to put our coat and bag. The stools are very uncomfortable to sit for a pleasant meal. Foods are overpriced with blend taste. I will not recommend to this restaurant.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
On Saturday night a group of 5 of us went back to Lers Ros Thai to try some of the other items. We got reservations at 7 pm and luckily found parking near by. The place was packed with people waiting outside. We were seated right away. We had the following:

pork belly
steamed fish
shrimp papaya salad
duck larb
duck curry
eggplant and tofu

All of dishes were terrific. The service was good but the place was so packed when we asked for dessert the waitress said the Kitchen was trying to get all the food dishes out to the other diners and that dessert would take a long time. We opted to go for some froyo instead.
author: George F.

description:
Ambiance: This is the original restaurant located in the middle of the tenderloin district, which means as a woman I wouldn't walk here alone at night. We were approached by intoxicated individuals even in broad daylight. Despite that,  the inside of the restaurant is relatively nice and you forget the outside atmosphere. There are both regular seating options and traditional, where you sit at a long connected table alongside other patrons. If you order more than 3 dishes, this may get a bit tight and you'll have to adjust so that your dishes dont get on to the other table. Inside: 3 stars, outside: 0?

Appetizers: We started with the curry puffs which is like a puff pastry samosa with a satay style curry sauce to match. It was hot, fresh, and had a nice flavor. Next we ordered the tom yum soup with vegetables. The presentation was great; it comes in a simmering hot pot with a fire underneath and literally was boiling! Great for cooler weather. My only critique would be that the soup was a bit too lemony/sour, even for a dish that is supposed to have a lemon grass and lime flavor profile traditionally. 3.5 stars

Main course: We had the prawn pad Thai which was better than average, with fresh shrimp, but once again I felt that one flavor overwhelmed the rest -this time it was too sweet. I think if the sweetness was less, I would have enjoyed it much more. But overall it was fair. Others in the party had the basil chicken and also thought it was fair, not amazing. 3 stars

Overall it was a good experience, better than most, but imo the flavors could be improved.
author: Sara A.

description:
Food here is very tasty, and I love that the lunch special allows you to choose two dishes and a salad. They gave a good amount of vegetarian selections and generally service is pretty fast. Portion sizes are on the large side so you won't leave hungry.

A few drawbacks : a bit expensive for lunch, sometimes they stagger service so you and your friends are eating in sequence rather than simultaneously, and seating is not the most comfortable.
author: Olivia D.

description:
I think I have a new favorite Thai place.

Their menu has many interesting things beyond the typical Thai restaurant repertoire.

I particularly liked the appetizer choices

Curry Puffs - Very Good

Pork Shoulder with chili and rice powder sauce - very good, but make sure you finish it, it is not as good reheated the next day. It get s very tough when reheated.

Thai Herb Sausage - Awesome, love the strong lime flavor.

Pork belly with crispy rind - very good

Even better this awesome food is available till midnight. I love it!
author: David T.

description:
Best Thai in SF (can't compare it to SE Asia) but the prices were cheaper than Tara, and Basil but the quality and variety was a lot better. Porkbelly (#62), pad kee mao (#76), and steak pieces (stir fry sirloin) were amazing. The seating was crowded but the turnover on a monday at 7pm was faster than expected.
Went there another time and the wait was 15 minutes so it really wasn't bad on a Thursday night at 8pm. The quail appetizer is super crispy and the meat is tender. THe green curry (#100) with seafood was great and had a strong kick to it. The chicken (Kao Kai Yang     served with sweet chili sauce) with garlic and you can get it a la carte was super moist and delicious.
author: Lily P.

description:
Among the best thai restaurants that I have had the pleasure of eating at, Lers Ros is a beacon in a a dark, seedy Tenderloin. The food is nothing short of amazing. 

The shrimp pad thai will blow you away. The sweetness of the shrimp, noodles, and egg are really unique - I know only one place that makes a pad thai in this style and that is the thai restaurant at Public Market in Santa Barbara. 

There are other great items on their menu, such as their fried rice, but get their pad thai. It is phenomenal and you won't regret it.
author: Aiden S.

description:
Stopped here to grab veggie Thai food with my family (4 adults and 2 kids). Great Service, Great Food.

Love the words on the wall.
author: Pranay D.

description:
Food = good. 

#27 Tom Kha Kai (Coconut milk soup with chicken, lemongrass and kaffir lime leaves) = Tangy, spicy, and served in a flaming pot. I would have preferred more tartness. $12.95 

#62 Kra Prow Moo Krob (Stir fried pork belly with crispy rind and basil leaves) = great, crispy, full of flavor, and must have some rice to soak up the sauce.  $13.95

#71 Kuay Tiew Look Chin Pla (Special house boiled soup with noodle, pork and fish balls) = simple, comforting and hearty.  Choice of thin or thick noodles. $9.95

#76 Pad Kee Mow (Spicy pan-fried flat noodle with basil, bell peppers, bean sprouts and choice of chicken or pork) = slightly sweet, and the cool bean sprouts offset the spiciness.  $10.95

Jasmine rice = $1.50

Thai Iced Coffee = strong, creamy, and sweet. $2.50

Seating = plentiful. There's a 2-top, a few 4-tops, and several long tables, which makes great use of the space and perfect for large parties. There's also bar seating (4-5 seats), and they have two TV screens. 

Service = friendly, polite and attentive. 

Prices = moderate. Dinner for three came out to $56.33. 

I heard about this place getting packed but we arrived at 6 p.m. on a Friday and it was dead.  But by the time it was 6:30, it was definitely packed with a crowd waiting outside.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Im being generous with this one star this one evening. My guest and I were seated at a shared long center table not more than six feet from the unobstructed front door. The tungsten lighting should have been soothing but the noise and cold outside breeze was overwhelming for both of us.
.
Among rice and soup we tried two specials. The Garlic and Pepper Rabbit which, was what I imagine a boney rubber would be like, just awful. I included a close up photo of a rib cage to show this rabbit couldnt be much bigger than a mouse.
.
The Pad Ped Alligator had a green peppercorn flavor that out-weighed the entire dish. I have had plenty of alligator in Thailand yet this seemed awful to me.
.
The rice was just that, rice, nothing extraordinary.  The Tom Kha Kai broth was very salty yet watery, it had no potato or other vegetable other than some very nice mushrooms and its chicken was tasteless. It seemed as if It and been taken out of boiling water and dumped into the soup.
.
$75 later (a decent tip included) and tails between our legs, we left looking for a burger on our way home.
.
So much for their motto: "...excellent taste of food" not at all.
author: Caesar A.

description: It was a good experience. Price is fair, food is good, not amazing. Service was ok, but I would still recommend. I'm not sure if I'm going back so soon, I rather try new places than return.
author: Rafael M.

description:
Red curry was legit - right amount of spice (you have to ask) 

Entrees run $10-$15 each
author: Tricia C.

description: I got myself a order of the coconut milk section order#37 an A La Carte for lunch and it was delicious! Loved it so much! I also ordered soup (forgot which one but I will update my review once I do some small googling lol) but that was really good too. Downside was when they got my bf's mom order wrong lol but that's cool haha I loved the Thai Ice Tea too! Would def come back to order some more food :)
author: Jen Z.

description:
One of the best authentic Thai Restaurants out their in SF.  Place is very unpretentious, too many panhandlers around, very hard parking.  Situated between a massage parlor and an Asian grocery store.  It opens at 5 for dinner, but once you get in, it's like your in another world.  The mood changes and also the ambiance.

I came with a Thai-Cambodian friend, so we ordered what we want in a flash, we got our food very quickly, and it wasn't the usual Americanized-Thai dishes. The people on adjacent tables who came in together with us hasn't even decided what to order, and they are staring at us because we were very very happy eating what we got.

The bomb was the roasted duck laab. I think everything on the menu is very authentic Thai, but they came in little portions, so be ready to order extra.
author: Monina Y.

description:
We're out-of-towners, but we each have really high expectations for eating Thai--this place did not disappoint. Although we were inebriated, we somehow magically found this place...

We ordered Duck Larb, Green Papaya Salad (both Thai-spicy), and 2 orders of sticky rice--each dish was outstanding, and although Green Papaya is one of our go-tos, the Duck Larb stood out to both of us as the show-stopper. Through the pain, sweat, and tears we devoured all of it, downing much water along the way... I really can't put into words how delicious it all was. Such vibrant, flavorful, fresh ingredients--this was our standout meal in SF (we also did San Tung, Yuet Lee, Good Mong Kok for dim sum, and a few Latino joints for good measure)

There's nothing this good over here, total bummer--we'll absolutely make a point of going back whenever we can--

Cheers!
author: Justine S.

description:
I'm not 100% sure about whether or not their "Vegetarian" labeled food is in fact Vegetarian as in without fish or oyster sauce, since I didn't ask. Double or triple check with the kitchen before you order.

As a Thai fiend, I don't know why it took me so long to finally try out Lers Ros seeing as I often see it on many "best of" lists. Thai food had long been my favorite until recently being displaced by Vietnamese. Lers Ros is trying to win me back.

Since Thai Idea was closed, we ended up here for an Independence Day meal. At first I was disappointed I didn't get to take my babygirl to try  the Vegan goodness of Thai Idea for her first time. But then we tasted the food at Lers Ros...

The prices are pretty reasonable and the interior is a lot nicer than the gritty TL neighborhood location would suggest. I don't feel like I have to worry about fish sauce in the "vegetarian" dishes as you sometimes do with lesser Thai places that use a pre-made curry paste. These reasons alone would place Lers Ros high on my list. Oh but the food...

The Pad Thai came out perfect and looked every bit as good as it tasted. I rarely order Pad Thai anymore and I don't know why. This dish brought me back to why I love Thai food. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lers-ros-thai-san-francisco?select=Mv5EeBsxgZ0qhZEzpdraxg#Df-wQc6TCbYViX31yu_Ang

I usually judge Thai restaurants on their Green Curry since it's my favorite thing on the menu. Lers Ros' version did not let me down. At first I thought the color was a bit off and more brown than green. Then my girl fed me the first bite and I realized the only thing that was off was my eyeballs... I can say Lers Ros green curry is the best in SF! While it was a bit thin at first glance, the flavor more than backed up Lers Ros street cred as best Thai restaurant in town. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lers-ros-thai-san-francisco?select=Mv5EeBsxgZ0qhZEzpdraxg#AjoWkVxZshlN3os_c3omLw

We chose to end our substantial meal with an order of mango with sticky rice. Not because we were so much hungry, as rather we wanted to try more food to make sure we didn't miss anything. Especially since we didn't know when we would get another chance to come here. Maybe not the wisest move, yet I managed to stuff the majority of that sweet, cocnutty rice and mango down the hatch before I succumbed to the effects of all that I just ate. Totally worth it!

The only downside is it can get pretty packed thanks to its popularity. Fortunately if you manage to score a table, the small army of waitresses should be able to handle the entire room with little trouble. I believe I counted ten of them for such a small space. I guess they're ready to handle the responsibility that comes with being #1. Yes, even better than my beloved Thai Idea.
author: John B.

description:
Wow, just wow. Every time we are in SF, we always have to stop here for foods. Everything was fresh and delicious. Green papaya with blue crab is amazingly refreshing, boat noodle soup and Shrimp paste fried rice are too die for.

The only thing I don't like about this place is the communion table. I always order so much foods and it's mostly end up on strangers side of the table.
author: MamaRed P.

description:
As soon as I tasted the Basil Fried Rice, I knew this was a 5 star place. The egg on top was really nice! And  I wasn't expecting it to be spicy, but that's what made it so awesome and unique. 

I ordered beef with broccoli, but it was different from the 1000s Ive tried, the meat stood out more, and the broccoli really had the stew flavor. 

I also had some spicy beef with a curry sauce and stuff, that Im not use to, so it was different. But I love  how authentic this place is, almost missed this place because of the sign wasn't clear. 

The interior is modern, despite the neighborhood looking a bit run down, so it's definitely a gem. 

Would definitely come back!
author: Kenneth H.

description:
Not sure what happened to their flagship dish which made them so famous, the crispy pork belly. When I first ordered from here 2 years ago, 90% of the cuts melt-in-your-mouth crunchy, juicy meat. 10% were break-your-teeth crunchy, dry meat. Gradually, the ratio of good to bad plummeted. Last weekend I went there and 100% of the cuts were break-your-teeth crunchy. 

I also noticed a very interesting trend: Even though the Crispy Pork Belly used to be the most often-mentioned/praised dish and #1 Review Highlight in the reviews in 2014, it is not even on the radar today. Maybe there are still a few great things on the menu, but it appears their signature dish of old is no longer the masterpiece it once was.
author: Max L.

description:
Lers Ros Thai was everything I wanted for my sister's birthday dinner.  While doing research for a place with good, delicious food that's close to Bourbon and Branch, where I was taking her afterwards, I remembered that my good friends John B and Rachel C had recommended this place as a vegan and omni friendly place with excellent dishes when we were trying to find a restaurant to double date.  I read John B.'s review and I was like um good pad thai and green curry...SOLD!

Five of us came here last Saturday  and the place was PACKED!  Even though we were 20 minutes late for our reservation (damn you parking in the TL!), they seated us within 15 minutes of wait.  The space was tiny and they only had stools at the table, no chairs.  So the minor annoyance was that we had to hold our coat and purses on our laps.  But that was forgotten the immediate moment our dishes arrived!

We ordered:

Spicy Chicken Fried Rice
Tofu Tom Yum Soup
Green curry with tofu
Papaya salad with grilled prawns
Tender beef, stir-fried with fresh chili, bell peppers, yellow onion, bamboo shoot, basil and hot chili sauce

Everything was tasty to the max! My favorite was the vegetarian green curry, my oh my, one of the best green curries I've had.  The tom yum soup was well flavored and super tasty as well.  The "worst" dish was probably the Spicy Chicken Fried Rice because I found the chicken and rice both too oily and the chicken a bit on the fatty side.  I realized also that their mild is something like medium spicy elsewhere.  Next time I'll ask for extra mild, my poor stomach.  

Ulcer or not, I fully enjoyed the meal at this awesome place.  I asked for an order of Mango and Sticky Rice with a candle for my sister and when they brought it out, they dimmed the restaurant lights, how thoughtful!

The bill came under $100 for 5 people. The service was fast so we ordered and ate in just around 1 hour.  5 Stars!!!!  We carried our full, happy bellies down the street to our next destination.  Lers Ros, thank you! We'll be back!
author: Yue L.

description: Be ready for pain the noise level was close to unbearable! Also be ready to be uncomfortable as you sit on a wood stool with no back! What a horrible experience this was, the food was not that good either and the only thing that was good was the wine! They would have to pay me to eat here again!!!
author: Jerry G.

description:
I was squealing like a little kid on Christmas Day when I saw the little Michelin man posted just outside the restaurant. This place draws a pretty hearty crowd so if you're starving or just don't have the patience to wait for a table, I suggest you get your food to go. It's kind of in a sketchy area so yeah. Get your food to go.

Pad Kee Mao -- Deliciously made drunken noodles stir fried to perfection with soy sauce, slices of beef, and basil. Although the noodles looked to be overly drenched with soy sauce, the dish was seasoned perfectly. It had a bit of a kick from the chili but it also had the fresh aroma from the basil and the saltiness from the soy sauce to blend into a perfect noodle dish.

Crab Fried Rice -- A simple dish dressed up with some crab, onions, and tomato. I love Thai's take on fried rice. They like to add different kinds of flavors into the mix to keep things interesting. Their halved tomatoes gave the rice a bit of juiciness along with the crunch of the sliced onions. Really tasty fried rice but I found myself packing their hot sauce to bring up the spice level a couple notches.

You know the food is good when you're willing to go to the sketch part of the town just to eat there. I saw a number of questionable people yelling at innocent pedestrians, and at times, ended up yelling at each other. Kind of scary. Le sigh, the things people will do for a good meal!
author: Jennifer L.

description: The food here is great, but for some reason the staff here think it's acceptable to lie about the possible choices: I requested panang curry but they brought me red curry ( which is great, sure! ). However the server did not mention that this was not an option and thought that lying would be a sufficient option. Please be honest about your services. This is not an acceptable business practice.
author: Jason R.

description: First thai place I have tried in San francisco.  The service was good and the food was excellent.  My boyfriend said that the pad thai was just like he had in thailand.  The fried tofu was also very tasty.   The soup was a little too spicey for me but flavorful.
author: Rakhi B.

description:
Nice place. Service was good. Food was alright. It wasn't as good as I thought it would be. I ordered Koh Moo Yang (grilled pork shoulder with chili and rice powder sauce), garlic quail, Larb Phed Yang (duck salad), and chicken Pad See-Ew.

Only thing that stuck out to me was the pork shoulder. That was really good! Everything else was just okay. I was pretty disappointed.
author: Salinda N.

description: Stale pre-cooked pork skewers with about a 50% fat to meat ratio: no thanks. This place used to rock, now it's all about the revenue.
author: Adam S.

description:
********************* 1269 ********************** 

   "Lers Ros" mean "excellent taste of the food." They surely deliver each and every time. Even Andrew Zimmern came here each time he visits San Francisco. Lers Ros Thai is in the middle of Little Saigon in the Tenderloin is truly a hot destination for spicy food lovers and Thai Food lovers. The restaurant is serving authentic, unique and fresh Thai dishes. It's always clean look, with delicious quotes on the wall, 2 communal tables in the center, a few seats at the bar, and a lot of servers.

  Even when it's a busy lunch hours. The food comes out quickly. The menu is extensive, the wine list is short but definitely good wines from Sonoma and Napa Valley.

  There is a few dishes that I enjoy very much and always order when I come here. 

#9 Koh Moo Yang - Smoky and Tasty! Grilled slices of pork shoulder, w/chili and rice powder sauce. Sliced thinly, perfectly pink, dip in their spicy sauce, oh it's simply the best dish here. 

#3 Fish Cake  - Ground fish with full taste of house made chili paste, served with cut cucumber in sweet chili sauce, tasty.

#11 - Garlic Frog - House special dish, fried Frog with a rich flavor of garlic, served with hot sauce. I love garlic in chunk and this dish would give you that,

#21 Yum Woon Sen - Silver noodles, ground pork, sun-dried shrimp, peanut with chili and lime based salad dressing. Always 1 of my favorite dish here, I like to order it at MED spicy, expect to be tearing a little :-)

#29 Poh - Tak - Traditional spicy and sour soup with assorted seafood, lemongrass, basil and kaffir lime leaves. Pour this soup over steamed rice, you have a bowl of heavenly soup, a perfect pot on a cold raining night or a hangover morning! 

#106 Pad Kra Prow Kob     $14.95 Minced OR chunk FROG both bone in, with basil leaves. I'm drooling as I'm writing about this dish. 

  Last but not least, the CRISPY PORK belly stir-fried with basil, garlic and sometimes with MORNING GLORY veggie, ong-choy (chinese)  Rau-Muong (Vietnamese). This dish would make you gain 2 lbs, but it's worth the run the next day. It's all worth it.

   The food is delicious. The service can be hit or miss on the busy day. CHEAP EAT, generous portion. If you like quiet place, this is NOT for you. It's super loud here when it's only 2/3 full so imagine a full house, you will be yelling at each other, we did! 

   Well it's in the Tenderloin, so parking is a nightmare, so PARK YOUR CAR at COVA HOTEL on Larkin or on the ELLIS side, 1 block up on the same side of Lers Ros, only $3/hr valet parking. It's safe and convenient.

   NOTE: they DON'T OPEN all day as Yelp hours stated here. They closed from 3-5 PM
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
I have to give this place 4.5 stars. Besides the fact that it's pricey, this place does an excellent job at keeping the authenticity of Thai food without any fear of  repelling the general audience. If it wasn't for the wait, this place would've been a 5 star in my opinion.

I was upset that they took forever with our foods. I understand we were a group of 8, but the time the first and last person got their foods was about a 30 minute difference; that's a huge variation. And it took almost half an hour for the first person to get his food. I was one of the last ones to get my dish and my friends were already ordering desserts. Huge upset. In addition, I made reservations a few days ago but when I arrived, they didn't have my reservation! Fortunately we arrived early enough that they were able to seat 8 people. On the contrary, I made the waiters wait additional 30 minute for my friend to arrive before we started ordering. So they were patient and kind on their end. 

Anyways, my pad kee mao with chicken medium spiced was huge! Surprisingly I ate all of it, including the huge amount of bean sprouts that came with it. The medium spice level actually really spicy! I LOVED IT. I'd advise the non-spicy lovers to get mild. We had tom yum soup with prawns earlier, medium spiced, which was a bit spicy! Everybody enjoyed the soup. One of the best I've had in the bay area. 

My boyfriend ordered the beef sirloin in some pepper sauce; that was bombtastic. Everybody enjoyed their meals and would come back. If I am ever in the city, I would come here over the other Thai places!
author: Rita K.

description: Even with reservations, if your full party isn't there, they won't seat you. So, prepare to get seated later than the time you want. I was also disappointed it took them 20 minutes to get dessert to us. I wouldn't say I had the greatest service this time around, but the food is still good.
author: Moua L.

description:
If you love AUTHENTIC Thai food, this is the place to go! I've been to other Thai restaurants in the city and this one is the best by far. If you've been to Thailand, this restaurant will bring you back to those memories. They know how to cook Thai food. I even think the entire staff is from Thailand.

Amazing service as well and they are very quick. Never disappoints!
author: Chisholm T.

description:
The first thing I noticed on the menu was alligator meat, right then I knew this was no ordinary thai place. 



And I was right, this was one of the more authentic thai restaurant in the city, but because it became so popular, they opened up two more branches! 

On to the food:

Pad Thai: excellent, my friends usually don't get the pad Thai but they even raved about theirs! I'm a pad Thai connoisseur, and this one is definitely one of my top 5!

Green curry with shrimp: very flavorful, definitely spicy! 

Papaya salad: I love the nuts with the salad combo, but we got medium salad and its so super spicy!  Next time I'll ask for no spice at all! ( as you probably know by now, I definitely cannot tolerate spiciness)
