My husband and I shared the vegetarian yellow curry and an eggplant tofu dish (both a la carte) with brown rice and sticky rice. The curry was smaller than we were expecting. The eggplant dish was quite spicy. Overall, we liked both dishes. 

The big complaint I have is that there were a lot of dishes listed in the vegetarian section of the menu that had fish sauce... For example, the yellow curry was the only one of three curries listed that could be made without fish sauce. This was misleading and had us changing our choices on the spot. Please list the details on the menu or don't put it under the vegetarian menu!!!!

Otherwise, I would have given it four stars. Service was polite and food pretty good.
author: S S.

description:
This place has thai cuisine down! It definitely lives up to the name Lers Ros which means tasty cuisine. I had come here with my family on a busy Friday night. We had called in and placed a reservation an hour ahead and had no issues getting a table at 7:30. The service was friendly and food came out promptly. We had ordered the green papaya salad with shrimp (som Tom koong yang ) and Tom kha Kai vegetarian which were both a delight. Watch out for the spice level on the salad. The medium spicy was quite fiery! Their standards are probably straight from Bangkok. The soup was wonderful with the oyster mushrooms. As for the dishes we had the red curry vegetarian , garlic chili basil eggplant with tofu, BBQ Thai chicken , and pad thai. All were made to perfection. This place has the best pad thai I've tried thus far. Absolutely divine. 
Oh and did I say we had dessert? 


Mmmmm yesss we had the mango sticky rice of course. A family tradition whenever we fine thai. It was impeccable. Keep it up. I will definitely dine here again.
author: Vikram G.

description:
Good - not great.

I came here for a lunch mtg. the other day. Getting a table for 6 wasn't a problem. And there's a cheap parking lot a block away ($3/hour). 

Needless to say, the neighborhood ain't great. Lots of hobos and junkies. The restaurant itself is nice. Nothing fancy; no white table cloth or anything like that.

They have a large menu. Personally, I'm not a fan of restaurants with over 100 menu options. Seems a bit excessive to me. I ordered the #93 ( stir-fried beef, bell peppers, onions, garlic, and basil chili sauce). It was a generous serving. And I ordered a side of brown rice to go with it. But to be perfectly honest, the spiciness of the sauce overpowered everything. And they certainly didn't skimp out on the garlic. Thank God I didn't have a date that night.
: )

My co-workers ordered Pad Thai (which looked good), spring rolls, and a Tom Yum soup (beautifully presented, but rather bland in flavor).

The service was fine. The waitress kept refilling my water glass every five minutes (she must have known how spicy my dish was). 

All in all, Lers Ros Thai is a decent lunch option in the Loin. It's not as Americanized-Thai as Osha, but it still delivers stellar food at a reasonable price. But unless you're in the neighborhood, I wouldn't venture out here for a meal.
author: Kevin B.

description:
My favorite Thai restaurant in SF. Have ordered take out many times and it is just as good as dining in. This is the best location in my opinion. I've come in on weekend nights and the atmosphere is loud, crowded and bustling. You may have to wait a bit and the food can take a bit to come out on busy nights but it's worth the wait 

I come here to order better versions of typical Thai restaurant favorites. The menu also has many more authentic Thai dishes which I have heard are fantastic as well.

Fried Rolls: Veggie fried rolls that are a step above your standard Thai fried rolls. The rolls themselves are thick, crunchy and seasoned well. They aren't overly greasy and the dipping sauce is good too. 

Kang Daeng: This red coconut curry is fantastic. Sweet, creamy coconut with the a nice amount of spicy heat. One of my favorites. 

Rad Nah: Unique Thai dish of pork and gravy over noodles. Wasn't what we were expecting. Very soupy. It was good but not sure if we would order again.
author: Ana D.

description: Rarely give places five stars but I loved everything about this place. The ambience, the service and of course the food. We sat at the community table and heard the musicians play beautifully. We had prawn asparagus, red curry chicken and steamed rice. The prawn asparagus was a daily special and it was delicious. We also had coconut water from a real coconut. It's surprising to find such an amazing joint in tenderloin.
author: Joyeta S.

description:
The food here is delicious!!! Came here on a recommendation from a Thai friend of mine. She told me this is very authentic Thai food so naturally I had to come down and try this! They have a lunch special where you can pick 2 items from the menu for less than 10 bucks which is a great deal. The lunch special also includes rice and a salad. I got the green curry shrimp and another item which I can't really remember the name of (sorry guys). I tend to have a very sensitive palate to spicy foods. Even though that green curry had me sweating, it still tasted delicious! I have to admit when I first received the plate I thought I would be deceived, but I was way more than pleased. 

The only complaint I have about the place is the music. Why in the heck was I hearing cheesy American country music and terrible r&b the whole time I was in a Thai restaurant? Beats me...it was a bit annoying to be honest. And its the only reason why I'm not giving this place 5 stars. And they could definately turn down the volume for people who are not enjoying the music. Kind of kills the vibe when you're enjoying your food and you have to listen to music you can't stand...
author: Jini Y.

description:
Amazing. 
Simply delicious food, fun upbeat atmosphere, and the service didn't pale in comparison to the food. It's a no brainier...just go.
author: Laura W.

description:
Although not in my most favorite 'hood, Lers Ros serves up some pretty delicious (&spicy!) Thai. My face lit up with joy as I walked in and spotted a ginormous pot of this Thai guava candy that I love- a server immediately walked over and gave me a handful of the treats :) Very sweet of her!

Great job of refilling our waters since the spicyness got me chugging. I ended up getting a Thai tea to soothe my tongue.

Just don't step in any puddles of urine or barf on your walk over here and you'll be golden.
author: Jenny Q.

description: I suppose I expected a lot since the reviews on Yelp raved about this place. Unfortunately, the quality of the food while great just wasn't excellent. When I come to San Francisco and dine at the highest rated Thai restaurant I am expecting excellent and this place just did not deliver. We went with the customary pork belly -- which everyone raves about. Don't get me wrong, the pork belly was great but it wasn't mind blowing like I expected. My daughter had the Thai fried rice which was really good. A good fried rice needs to taste burned, as in the charred taste of the rice against an incredibly hot wok. Most places cannot pull this off but this one did. My wife ordered the pad kee maw and it was just good but again not amazing. Overall I have it three stars because I was underwhelmed from what I expected. I admit it's not fair but then again life isn't either.
author: Rasi W.

description:
What can i say about the restaurant that has not been said by the many yelp reviews? Other than how affordable, authentic and absolutely delicious this place is, here is what you should try and order:

1.Pork Shoulder (Their dipping sauce is amazing)
2.Fried chicken with garlic rice
3.Drunken noodles

I've had a few other things here (I can't quite remember the exact names) but those three stood out the most to me. Let's just say my bf and I didn't have any left overs :)
author: Shirley N.

description:
Pathetic service, rude waitstaff, non-apologetic, food ordered about 1 hr ago and still waiting on the order to come out (pad see eww: easiest dish ever to make)

Food was delicious:
Shrimp fried rice
Friend trout
Chicken satay
Pork ribs(took 40 min to come out)
author: Yash M.

description:
Awesome 
Awesome 
Awesome.

Some say it's the best Thai in the city.  I think it's up there with Kin Khao (I like really spicy food).
author: Daniel Y.

description: Some of the dishes here are even better than the ones in Thailand. Get their spicy clams with extra basil. Grilled pork shoulder is a must and so is their grilled beef salad. Rad nah noodles are very soft and full of flavors. Their sautéed eggplants with extra basils are the best I've ever had. Service is always excellent. I love this place.
author: J.J. P.

description: Best Thai food in the Bay Area, hands down. Food from this restaurant is the epitome of "HURTS SO GOOD" and very reflective of authentic food in Thailand. My favorite dishes were the som tom poo (lol.. papaya salad with raw crabs), tom yum gong, and whole seabass steamed in lemongrass broth. Everything was so spicy and sour, just perfect. I don't think I will be eating at any Thai restaurants except this one from now on!
author: Betty T.

description:
Delicious Thai food in the super seedy and sketch Tenderloin district - I walked here from my hotel in the Financial District for lunch.  I would advise taking an Uber or cab if you are coming for dinner, because I frankly would have been a wee bit terrified making the trek on foot after nightfall.

Got the papaya and grilled shrimp salad, medium spice.  I was sweating while eating this, it burned!  But in a really good way - it's tangy, spicy, and super refreshing.  But as many others have warned, it is SPICY. So glad I got the medium spice, I'm not sure if my taste buds could have handled full spice (and I LOVE spicy food). I also got the five-spice duck over rice, which was also delicious, warm, super flavorful and fatty in that good-duck-fat way. Really paired well with that zinger of a salad.

I sat at the bar counter since I was dining alone, and the waiters/waitresses were really attentive and friendly.  Will definitely be coming back the next time I'm in SF!
author: Natalie C.

description:
I walked all the way to the Tenderloin from Lombard Street to try Lers Ros Thai and my efforts were definitely rewarded =)

There was only one other customer inside when I arrived at Lers Ros, which was surprising given it was prime eating time on a Saturday afternoon. I was seated promptly by a cordial waitress and she handed me the ridiculously long menu that contained hundreds of delicious sounding dishes. How was I supposed to choose? Thank goodness I had the advice of dozens of other Yelpers who had tried this place before me, so I went with the Pad See Ew with chicken. 

I immersed myself in my book for about 10-15 minutes, and then a giant plate of yummy, steaming noodles was placed in front of me. Thankfully the waitress had given me a glass of water when I sat down because I was parched from the long walk, so since my thirst had been quenched I didn't wait to dive into the delicious looking food! The noodles were perfect, there was lots of chicken and the veggies were great too. It wasn't spicy of course but the flavors were divine and although I wanted to eat the entire plate (more like platter), I held back and saved the rest to bring home for my boyfriend. The prices were reasonable and the waitresses were super nice =) I'll definitely be back but next time I'll bring some friends to enjoy the food with me!
author: Sam F.

description:
Love Lers Ros so much so much so much. I live very close to this place and was told by a random stranger once long ago on the street that they had the best Thai food in the city. I didn't believe them at first because this place is legit in the Tenderloin and why would this random place have THE BEST Thai food in the city when there are such nicer restaurants in Fidi or Soma? 

Well nicer doesn't always mean better! Lers Ros is much tastier than Osha in my opinion and they have free delivery after 4pm. I've ordered countless takeout pad thai from here and I've yet to grow tired of it. 

I stopped into the restaurant once with my boyfriend and the interior was pretty nice! Complete with mini waterfalls and all. The Thai tea and the pad kee Mao are also my favorites. I'm sure everything on this menu is good! Can't go wrong with Lers Ros!
author: Vidya K.

description:
The better Thai food I've had in SF. 

Duck curry was tasty but be careful with the heat level - I ordered medium and it was already really spicy (I have good tolerance for spicy). Also got a beef dish and while the meat was marinated well, it is too salty (why haven't health conscious SF peeps complained?:p).

Menu is pretty extensive for a Thai place, definitely got potentials so I'll come back if I'm in the neighborhood. Speaking of which, not a great neighborhood it's surrounded by.
author: Heidi B.

description:
I had lofty expectations for Lers Ros, since it's lauded as the best Thai in SF. However, I was a little disappointed after eating there.

I came with my wife and my parents, as they were visiting from out-of-state. While my dad and stepmom enjoyed their meals, my wife and I were not as impressed. I had the Pra Ram Pak, which tasted good, but just didn't have the "it" I was hoping for and expecting.

I'd probably give it another try, but with lower expectations.
author: Ezra B.

description:
Really nothing I can say that doesn't involve "yum nom nom noms" about this place. I always get the pad see ew with beef here because its my favorite thing to eat and it never disappoints. I've tried some of the other "more exotic" things that they offer on the menu (which is actually pretty extensive and more exotic than I expected as well) such as the alligator and the rabbit, but I always come back to the simple things. Most dishes are about $10. 

It can get pretty crowded at dinner but I never feel claustrophobic in this space. It's kind of in a sketchy neighborhood, so be safe if you're walking to/from here late at night. I've been here for normal dinner with one other person and also for a birthday dinner with 8 people and was equally comfortable with the seating for both. They also have a bar if you want to just sit at the bar and eat (pretty comfortable actually!). 

Simple, delicious beers also available.
author: Lai-Nin W.

description: I like the fact that we dont have ti wait in line for hours to get good food! We came around 2 pm on sat afternoon and they were not busy at all. We tried pad thai, pork  belly rice plate, and tom yum soup. They were all really tasty and flavorful! I also love love the peanut sauce coming with the chicken satay; it is so creamy melting in your tounge with a piece of chicken~~~. The service is good too! Maybe we come when they are not busy? ;)
author: Jenny N.

description:
The best pad thai I've ever had. 

There's a lot I don't care for about this place: it's loud, seating is cramped and crowded, and there was a decently long wait for a table. 

But with food like this, I'm willing to overlook  all those gripes. Everything I tried was fantastic, and the prices were quite reasonable. I wish there I had a place like this near me; I'd be there all the time.
author: Groucho N.

description:
7x7 100 Best Thing to Eat in SF Before You Die

#45 Duck Larb at Lers Ros Thai

11) Garlic Frog 
House special dish, fried Frog with a rich flavor of garlic, served with hot sauce

25) Larb Phed  aka Duck Larb
A chunk of roasted duck mixed with rice powder, chili powder and lime based salad dressing

52) Kao Kai Yang 
BBQ marinated chicken, served with sweet chili sauce

77) Pad See-Ew
Pan-fried flat noodle, served with chicken or pork (beef / prawns 9.95 , seafood 11.95)

Frog: garlicy, seasoned well, tender
BBQ Chicken: good flavor, on the bone goodness, roasted well
Pan Friend Noodles: cooked relatively well, again seasoned good

The main star of the hour Duck Larb. In my opinion, it is over hyped, I found it to be way oversalted, too much fish sauce or something. The acidity from the lime dressing was unplesant and did not marry well with the saltiness. The actual duck was fine but I much rather have Chinese Duck.

Service is spot on, very attentive and efficient. 

Overall Thoughts

They take card, which is such a rarity in that area. Food is reasonably priced and the portions are good but I don't think the Duck Larb alone is not worth the trip
author: Eddie W.

description:
Favorite Thai place in the city. Came to this location a year ago for the first time during a convention at the Hilton. Borders on the seedy Tenderloin.

The ambiance is simple but clean. Green Papaya Salad, Pad Thai, and Sweet Rice with Mango.

Washed down with a Thai Ice Tea.

If you want Thai, this is a great spot. If you want to avoid the ghetto atmosphere, head over to their Hayes Valley or Mission location.
author: Julia P.

description: This is probably my newly found favorite Thai spot! I've been on the search for authentic Thai boat noodles for a while now in SF and I'm glad to say I have finally found my spot! It's not located in the best area, but the food is definitely worth it! The best food are always located in the sketchy areas lol. I've also tried the basil chicken my sister ordered and it was delicious! Definitely gonna order  that next time I'm back in the city. Love this place!!
author: Heidi L.

description:
The green papaya salad is to die for

The pork shoulder appetizer was also great - but very fatty (as you'd expect pork shoulder to be)
author: Andrew Z.

description:
The variety of food is amazing, with exotic meats such as alligators and quail. The flavors are extremely strong and unique.

With that said, the pork belly was the best and I would have loved the sea bass even more, but the fish was not properly descaled.

An unusual warm day for the city nonetheless, but seriously no AC? I asked if there is AC, the waitress said no. But in 10 minutes I started feeling some cold air circulated, but not nearly enough.

My whole dinner party had minimal appetite due to the heat. 

Needless to say, the resutaurant gives me no reason to return.
author: DSC H.

description:
The food was great.  Everything we ordered was super flavorful and had interesting preparation.  

We did a pickup order that took 1.5 hours to prepare - hence the 4 stars.  But, they were super busy in the restaurant that evening too.  

Our old standby was Little Thai / T2J until they closed.  Lers Ros is a great alternative but it's a long way away and a bit more expensive.
author: Xaman E.

description: Probably my favorite Thai restaurant in the city! Great service, 10 minute wait, wonderful ambience and delicious curries and noodle dishes. My only recommendation is to ask for less spicy because our eyes were watering from the Green Curry!
author: Jane H.

description:
The food was excellent. Granted, My husband could eat Thai every night of the week, and I'm a bit over it right now, but I had to admit that this place was REALLY good. 

Our waitress had  a bit of trouble understanding us, but that's ok, she seemed to be Thai, so she repeated everything back to us. There was a bit of a wait for some of the things and the entrees came out staggered between the three of us, so that was kind of odd, but the food was GOOD.
author: Dianna B.

description: This place is my favorite Thai Food around. Their Tom Kha or Tom Yum and Pad Seew is a must try! Extremely flavorful and full of authenticity.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
The food is good. Noodles, salads, soups, everything. The only issue is the service. It is just sloppy. The team is nice, they try hard. But they forget to bring water, they forget about your beer, they drop a plate on your table.. if that annoys you you likely to be displeased.

And yes it is in tenderloin, so.. you know.
author: Victor N.

description:
* Yummy green papaya salad with grilled prawns. Good dressing~
* Red curry with roasted duck was delicious. Lots of fresh veggies used in it
* Pad Thai tasted great, it was mixed well and every bite tasted consistent. Overall softer/juicier than some places where you can pick apart individual noodle strands 
* Great service - they're very friendly, welcoming, full of smiles, and offer fast service! 
* Super cute, clean, simple decor (read the walls :))
* Yes it's in the tenderloin, but there's plenty of street parking & people around. Don't worry, just go enjoy some Thai food!
author: Tina K.

description: Their curries are amazing. I haven't really ventured out from those because I am such a fan, but it's also worth stating that the Larkin location is open late on the weekends. Such a great late night option.
author: g b.

description: This place has the best yellow curry we've ever tasted. The som tom koong yang (papaya salad with grilled shrimp) was also fantastic. Spicy, but very good.
author: Andrea M.

description: First of all, horrible dirty neighborhood... Would NOT recommend walking to or from here.. Uber it! Once inside, nice & cozy. We were the only non Thai peeps in here so we knew we were good! Lol.. Ordered # 8, spare rib  & crab cake appetizer. I wanted to like it but the spare ribs were microscopic & dry . Dinner was shrimp pad Thai & another shrimp dish.. Good,  but not fabulous as this restaurant is rated in the top 5. Probably would try another Thai restaurant for comparison.
author: Jan S.

description:
Food is delicious but the place has no AC, it is hot inside. Service can be improved. It takes a while to get ice water and refill. We were here at late lunch hour, so the place is not full/busy. 
We are eating our delicious food with sweats rolling down our faces.
author: Ira S.

description: I've had thai food in a few areas in CA and HI, I must say this place is by far the best I've had. Even though food took a little longer than expected, the wait was totally worth it.
author: Jessica M.

description: Very good customer service.  We enjoyed the pork belly and the steamed striped bass but the rabbit was a no go.
author: Toblessedtobestressed G.

description:
I'm so confused, last time I went to lers ros and ate there it was really good.. But this time we ordered for delivery and it was disappointing.

We got the som tom koong yang salad medium spicy and it was pretty good, but very spicey. We shared two entrees, the pad see ew with chicken (the noodles were way overcooked and mushy & not much flavor to the dish, it had sparce greens that tasted like they hasn't been seasoned at all... To be honest we left this dish on the  ) and the pad Thai with prawns (this was better, but I added a lot of chili to it for flavoring .. Although the bean sprouts added a nice texture mix). I also got a side of sticky rice and it didn't come with mango :( 


Sad to say, but I won't be ordering from here again.
author: danielle a.

description:
I loved almost everything we ordered! 

Steamed sea bass over fire - I don't think this was sea bass but it was good.  The fish was cooked perfectly and the broth was deliciously sour. Watch out for bones! 

Tom yum khoong - a delicious coconut based soup with shrimp. It was creamy and flavorful, where medium spicy actually was medium spicy. The spicyness opened up my senses, so that I could fully enjoy every flavor that I was tasting. Shrimp was fresh and big. 

Boat noodle - one of the better boat noodles that I have tasted but was hard to share or enjoy with 7 other people. It was filled with so many ingredients, beef balls and strips of beef among other things. The noodles were a little clumpy, the strands sticking to each other.  Don't order this one if you're eating family style. 

Crispy pork belly - pork belly was cooked down, tender and soft and fat was oh so good. Cooked in a delicious sauce that can be perfectly enjoyed drizzled over white rice. 

Pork shoulder - this one stole the show for me.  The pork shoulder was thinly sliced and grilled, where you can taste the char.  It's served with a spectacular dipping sauce. I think I could eat this one all by myself but I decided to share.  Sharing is caring right? That way I can still have room to sample the other delicious dishes. 

Duck larb - this came in a close second.  I love larb and I love duck. This was a perfect typical but atypical thai dish. Most restaurants serve pork or chicken larb but this duck larb was amazing. All of the flavors came together so well: sweet, sour, and salty. 

Papaya salad - great salad but I find this one hard to mess up. I think I've only been disappointed once and it was when I tried to make it at home. You have to order papaya salad if you eat thai food.

Fried banana with ice cream - good but nothing spectacular.  It's exactly what it sounds like, banana is covered in breading and deep fried.
author: Theresa D.

description:
I was in town visiting and my friend wanted to go to his favorite Thai place in the city.  I was a little skeptical when I saw the address but he promised it was fabulous so we headed out.

There was about a 25 min wait at 7:30 on this Saturday night which wasn't bad.  We were seated toward the back at a table for four and I immediately ordered hot jasmine tea (it's a compulsion).

My friend ordered for us so I'm not sure of the exact names of the dishes but we had a spicy chicken and basil dish that was pretty tasty.  We also had a spicy tofu dish that was pretty good.  Then came the pad Thai.  It was fantastic. Just delish.  It was good enough that I would come here over and over and order the same thing every SINGLE time.

Why only 4 stars?  No coconut ice cream.  I would go to a place with inferior food if I could eat coconut ice cream after.  Yeah, I'm weird.

Will be back!
author: Heather K.

description: Authentic food, warm & friendly service. I spent a month backpacking in Thailand, and found the flavors at Lers Ros to be quite authentic. Though it might not appeal to most, I urge readers to try the duck larb. Most people think of duck dishes as fatty, but this was clean, lean and perfectly cut with its acid-based dressing.
author: Mella Y.

description:
Really good food and really friendly service.

-Langon: If you're Filipino, this drink kinda tastes like sago.

-Shredded Papaya Salad with Shrimp: Great crunch, peanuts add a nice texture, maybe just a tad bit too vinegary.

-Duck Larb: Loaded with citric acid which really cuts through the duck fat.  I preferred to eat it with rice than in a lettuce cup but hey, I'm Filipino.

-Stir-fry Pork Belly: Again, if you're Filipino, it's just like Lechon Kawali but with a lot of citric acid.  Totally, totally delicious.

My family and I really liked the food and wouldn't mind coming back here again.
author: Rose A.

description:
This restaurant was good, but it did not live up to its fabulous reputation here on Yelp.

Our server was friendly (we sat at the bar due to the restaurant being crowded, even though we called asking for a reservation and were told it was not necessary). The restaurant was generally clean, but the bathrooms were tiny and dirty.

We ordered a Papaya Salad to start, and we requested mild spice. When it arrived, the presentation was lovely, but the spice was unbelievably hot! We found ourselves desperately chugging our beers and had to ask our waitress for water.

Next, our Pad Thai arrived (our waitress highly recommended it), and it was pretty good, but nothing worth returning for. My boyfriend found his chicken to be bland, and my shrimp was quite fishy.

I am not a picky restaurant goer, so this 3 star review is a big bummer. We were so excited to be wowed by this place, but we left unsatisfied.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I absolutely love Thai food and I am glad to have found what may be my new favorite spot in the city.
This restaurant is tucked away near downtown San Francisco in the TL. 

Pros: The establishment is rather large in size and has a full size bar, they also have a lunch special that runs until about 3pm. The food is delicious! I ordered the pad ke mao and it was very much to my liking.

Cons: the restaurant closes from 4pm-5pm for dinner but doesn't have a sign posted anywhere. my gf and I came here around 3:30 and felt rushed to leave within the hour. Small portions and this place is a bit pricey. The staff seemed to be in a rush to close and they didn't get my gf's order right (she asked for extra spice and instead they brought the condiments out for her to apply it herself) thus why I gave them 4/5 stars.
author: Mel L.

description: Bomb ass food really a secret spot in the sfo if you want spicy and real deal come here
author: Shamal S.

description:
I've only been here once, but I'd definitely come back. Great place for a group dinner or date night.

+ Quick and friendly service
+ Great setting - trendy atmosphere and vibe
+ Good food - we ordered the crab fried rice and the pad with prawns, would recommend both. Their menu seemed to offer a great selection for both food, drinks, and dessert.
author: John H.

description:
This is my new favorite Thai restaurant in SF. On this particular Saturday night we were thankful we made reservations as it was a zoo. 
The fried spareribs were meaty and the dipping sauce was perfectly zesty. The Spicy Prawns in Basil Sauce were spicy(meaning if you order spicy be prepared for it tobe actually spicy), and the flat noodle with chicken was flavorful and had a nice blend of textures between the soft noodles and moist chicken.
Service was fantastic as they kept filling our water glasses and our dishes were immediately cleared after we had cleaned off every last bite.
All of the wait stuff we dealt with seemed to posses genuine smiles(yes, I can tell the difference). Based on my first experience here, this place is as good overall as my go to favorite Thai restaurant in the South Bay(New Krung Thai). I can't wait to come back to try more of their dishes especially some of their signature dishes I have heard about.
author: Dennis W.

description: Best Thai food I have had in America! Full of flavour and fresh. Great menu and the best service - will be back for sure when I'm in town. Priced well and just so tasty!!!
author: Danielle D.

description:
A friend of mine, originally from Bangkok, recommended this place. Pretty good food, unique dishes. Only thing I don't care for its questionable location. 

Anyway, we got veggie rolls, pretty good! Sauce was yummy. Coconut juice was fresh and good. I got a lunch special with two sides - nothing phenomenal but good. The chestnut dessert we wanted, they didnt have it, we got something else which wasnt bad. 

Overall, good and different kinda Thai food.
author: Rocking V.

description:
The food is authentic and delicious.

I order the basil chicken, and green curry everytime, then try to add something different to find new stuff.

The service in the restaurant is really good, and they'll help you find new dishes.

Over the phone, they are crazy busy so it's best to check out the website before. The delivery service is really great, but can take a long time during peak hours.

Still the best of the Ler Ros locations even as they have made it fancier and expanded fast over the years.
author: David K.

description:
I was very excited, after reading reviews, to dine here.

The lunch special is a fantastic deal for $9.

I got the chicken satay and red curry with chicken. I also ordered a thai iced tea, which was mediocre (trust me, I have drunk thai iced tea from many, many places before). The chicken satay was above par, but far from great. The curry was, honestly, bland, but enjoyable.

Overall, a solid experience. I will definitely be returning. A great value, but well below my expectations.
author: A. Wolfram K.

description:
I'm surprised this Lers Ros location is more highly rated than the other two locations. I was definitely disappointed by the service here. 

Came here on an average Sunday night with a large party of 7. The wait was short and we were seated quickly. However, service all went downhill from there. It took a while for our waiter to take our orders. Afterwards, food arrived in a timely manner.. but only for HALF of the table. The other half sat there and waited at least another 30-40 mins for our food, while everyone else finished eating. Always an awkward situation. 

We asked at least 4 passing waiters/waitresses to check on our order, but most of them just dismissed us, if not straight up ignored us. 

Food was decent, but the horrible service already left a bad taste. I ordered my usual, the kha moo (pork leg stew), which was good but the meat to rice ratio was poor and the egg was overcooked.

My recommendation: avoid this location and go to the Mission or Hayes ones - no wait, better service, and just as good food.
author: Vivian H.

description: Overall bad atmosphere and bad service.  We had dinner tonight at 7pm and made dinner reservations for 6 people.  Started out good with apps and then downhill after that.  They delivered 5 dishes and did not acknowledge that they forgot my order.  After 20 minutes and the rest of my party were done eating, my pad thai arrived overcooked and sweet.  No apologies and didn't even remove it from the bill.  Never will go back.  Really awful.
author: robin m.

description:
A solid thai food experience in a somewhat sketchy part of SF. Beautiful restaurant once you get inside though. 

The menu, as people have mentioned, is huge. Tons of great stuff on there. I really like the combination of more adventurous dishes with stuff that my less adventurous stuff would also enjoy. 

The papaya salad appetizer was great, a bit on the spicy side for some, but I loved it. We also got the whole fried trout, which was delicious and a great value for the money compared to some of the more pricey whole fish options. Love that stinky fish sauce! Yum. 

Overall, all the options that our party shared were great, although some were clear winners. Can't remember all of them as our party of 6 ordered a lot of stuff. The pad see ew was rich and flavorful. Usually I have to add a lot of spice to my stuff to get it to a level of hotness I'm good with, but not here. This mean that for the weak of spice, you may be a bit overwhelmed, so order accordingly (stay away from papaya salad!).

The service was good. They were johnny-on-the-spot with the water and to-go boxes. Didn't really need much else from them, other than a beer. :)
author: Brian B.

description: Excellent Thai. Veg Tom Yum with coconut milk was fantastic - veggies cooked perfectly, soup great complex flavor. We tried the duck curry, pork belly, veggies, and papaya salad combo with chicken. All were excellent. We recommend this place and look forward to coming back.
author: David F.

description:
I stopped by here with a friend because we were in the area and starving.

Nothing about the place has changed since my last visit. It's still quite nice inside and the service is still nice and attentive. 

We ordered Thai tea, salt & pepper rabbit, brown rice, and duck larb.

The Thai tea was good. I like it because they give it to you in a pretty big glass and it's authentic Thai tea so it's flavorful and awesome.

The salt & pepper rabbit was okay. I've never had rabbit before so I can't compare but...not sure if that rabbit we had was not meaty enough or if rabbits are just always really bony. It got really irritating to eat it with so many bones and not too much meat. The way it was cooked wasn't especially exciting. Just fried and seasoned with salt & pepper. By itself, it was kind of dry but it went well with the sweet and spicy sauce. I expected something better (or more) for the price. 

The duck larb was by far my favorite dish. They give you a good amount of duck pieces in the entire salad and it's flavored really well with tons of lime and hints of green onions. There were bits of cilantro everywhere which is a plus for me. Definitely the best larb dish I've ever had. 

Overall, great restaurant but some items on the menu are hit or miss.
author: Sofia R.

description: Food was delicious! Service was good! Lots too chose from, will definitely go back! #believethehype
author: Rosey S.

description:
My husband and I made reservations in March to dine at this upscale Thai establishment on July 30. However, upon entering the facility, I realized I made reservations for one instead of 2. The host was extremely helpful and sat us down within 3 minutes upon arrival. Not only that, but the host (male, didn't get his name) was able to accommodate other couples (walk-ins) in a speedy fashion. I haven't been to many restaurants that are as flexible and accommodating as this one. Don't speak Thai? No problem, the restaurant has #'s next to each dish.  Be prepared to sit next to complete strangers at this establishment. The long tables in the center of the restaurant are 3-4 tables joined together. So while you and your party will be at one of those tables, it is possible that someone else from a different party will be sitting next to you. I will say that most of the restaurants we visited during our stay in SF had close seating with limited privacy tables. I enjoyed making friends at each restaurant, but if compact spaces are not your thing, you may want to ask to sit at the bar which has seating for 4. I knew from the previous reviews to order the #12 Som Tom Poo, papaya salad with raw crab. The crab is raw and does come in it's shell, but if you are used to eating sushi, then order this dish. The flavor combos are surreal. I tasted ginger, soy sauce, fish sauce, chili pepper, and possibly lemongrass. My mouth is salivating as I type. The salad is on the spicy side, most likely a 5/10 on the hot scale. Don't fret if spicy is not your thing, they give complimentary water and with as many refills as necessary. The menu features 80 options but is organized in a way that doesn't give anyone an anxiety attack. I recommend viewing the menu ahead of time to get a consensus of what you may order to save time. The wait staff is very helpful in answering any questions so feel free to ask away. I ordered the #34, yellow curry with prawns and my husband ordered #35, beef red curry. We both ordered hot. We probably should have ordered Thai hot because it was not that hot, but the depth of flavor was on point. The yellow curry had almost a sweet taste to it which was delicious. Vegans and Vegetarians: there are menu options for you and if you don't see something or want a dish without meat, they can do that for you, just ask. If we ever visit San Francisco again, we will be sure to come back. Hopefully we will save room for dessert next time ;).

Price 5*
Taste 5*
Service 6* (accommodations)
Atmosphere 5*
Options 5*
author: Kristina Nichole D.

description:
I have yet to visit Thailand but everywhere I go I seek out Thai restaurants. Lers Ros is hands down the best Thai food I have yet to find. We went on a Saturday night and the place was so crowded that after waiting almost an hour we gave up. We returned Sunday for lunch and had no trouble finding a seat.

The Pad Thai, drunken noodles, and red curry are all superb. The service was second to none.
author: Justin R.

description: I'm no expert in Thai food but my taste buds are. After further discussion with my buds (taste) we came to the conclusion that this place was worthy of an open mouth policy. I've had the traditional plates and they have not disappointed yet. My yummy monsters need to be fed daily, so when I toss them some Larb, they rejoice in their cave and leave the villagers alone.....until they are hungry again.
author: Charlie S.

description:
Good solid Thai food.  Huge menu with all your Thai favorites done well.  

Pad see ew was really good.  5 Stars

Service was 5 stars.
author: Paul W.

description:
This is another one of those restaurants for true foodies! I mean who else is going to trek to the 'hood for good Thai food? 

I've been to Lers Ros a couple times but I decided to order delivery from now on because I just hate the neighborhood it's in. However, the Hayes Valley location is completely different. Very nice, very safe.

The first time I went was with an old law school classmate, who is also a food lover! We feasted, we loved it! Everything is good but definitely try the Duck Larb (YUM!) and red curry (Spicy goodness)! The duck larb has a lemon-lime tanginess to it. The meat is also coarsely chopped not finely minced, like I've had in the past. 

Now the reason I say it's for the true foodie & not the faint of heart is because I took my family here for my graduation and they couldn't even sit in the restaurant for 5 minutes because they thought it had a foul odor. It does stink. It smells like fish & other sea creatures. I didn't even notice it smelled until they pointed it out. Granted they are originally from the midwest & used to burgers & shakes not authentic Thai food but the place does stink. However, the food is great. I am still very much a fan & would go here again.  

The decor is simple. The restaurant is clean.
author: Tasha T.

description: My second time here today and I really enjoyed eating here, just like last time.  Koh Moo Yang is still my favorite appetizer... service was friendly and fast.
author: L D.

description: Very popular, very crowded, very noisy restaurant with about a ten-minute wait at dinnertime. Attractively designed and decorated in a modern style. The food was well-seasoned and delicious although the curries were on the sweet side.  We had Green Curry with Chicken and a duck curry. The chicken, which was in strips, seemed to have been cooked in advance because it was dry and a little hard. All in all, Lers Ros was an enjoyable dining experience.
author: John B.

description: I was visiting for a day and looking for a good Thai food and my friend recommended this place, the service was good and the food was excellent! Most authentic you can ever find I believe! If I ever visit San Francisco again I will definitely eat here. You can never be disappointed.
author: Sivimol M.

description:
Best Thai food I've ever eaten. The Kra Duk Moo Tod (spare ribs appetizer, number 5) is a must. It comes out in bite size pieces but, kind of awkwardly, with the bone still in. You have to get in there with your hands. It's mess and oh so worth it. 

I also had the Kao Pad Kai Tod (crispy chicken with sweet chili sauce over fried rice, number 55), which might just be my new favorite comfort food. The flavor wasn't as powerful as the spareribs, but it nonetheless made my stomach very, very happy. 

I can't wait to come back here and try new things!
author: Megan B.

description:
Lers Ros is like that well polished sand dollar that you find hidden in the dunes at the beach. Except, instead of a sand dollar, it's a restaurant that's stowed away in the Tenderloin. Let me start off by saying that, LR is a well oiled, clean, and tasty cooking machine!

The ambience is pretty relaxed. I dig the wide open boxed dining area with the family style tables that jet down the middle of the restaurant. The service is good, although when it gets busy, things can sometimes be forgotten, such as water or chopsticks.

The pork belly dish is decent, but definitely not my favorite. The pad kee mow was tasty with the right amount of seasoning. The boiled chicken with garlic rice was the best plate out of the three dishes. Tender, flavorful, and the accompanying sauces do a great job of bringing out the flavors of the dish. 

Overall, a great spot to come with friends and family. Major points for who ever put together the soundtrack, because it was non-stop edm untz during my meal :D
author: Josh S.

description:
I've never been one of those people who dream about going to Thailand, even though I constantly hear from co-workers and friends that I ABSOLUTELY have to go there. 

Wow. 

After a meal at Lers Ros Thai, consider it done!

We ordered a bunch of dishes that we shared family style: crispy fried tofu with peanut sauce, tom yum koong served in a flaming pot, pad thai with crunchy bean sprouts and juicy chicken, spicy pad kee mow, mouth watering pork-belly that was a special of the night. Order a couple rounds of the sweet thai iced tea and you're good to go.

The fried tilapia in a house chili sauce has to be my absolute favorite! beautiful plating, with bell peppers and onions. I do have to admit that I ordered this for the shock value (we had a foreigner dining with us) and this getting served with head on was quite a shocker for him. Let's not count the fact that another friend was raving about eating the best part: the eyeballs. I was DYING inside laughing because our visitor had this look of disgust on his face. Oh, what a kodak moment! ;-)

You'll have a hard time deciding what to order since they must've 100 dishes on the menu. Whether it be the usual chicken or something exotic such as frog legs (doesn't taste like chicken) or alligator (tastes like chicken), Lers Ros has bold flavors that will make your meal an unforgettable one.
author: Janice C.

description:
Lers Roi.. thought this was more of a fusion restaurant upon seeing its name on yelp, but fortunately it wasn't. Definitely one of the best experiences I've had with Thai food.

The restaurant was surprisingly not full of people when we got here for New Year's day lunch, but eventually the place got so packed!! I wanna say there's room for about 50 people as they had communal seating in the middle (thumbs up). 

on to the FOOD:
ordered the Thai iced coffee for my dose of caffeine (way too exhausted from nye) and it was yumsies.

got the Tom Yum soup with prawns, which was amazing as well, lemongrass and other spices were so pronounced, but I wish we ordered the super spicy. (we got the medium spicy just because my boyfriend's mum might not be able to handle it lol)

FAVORITES:
Duck Larb salad (larb phed yang) - I have no idea how to spell or how to pronounce it on the menu but the server was too kind to explain what it was to me and boy, was I glad that I ordered it. The roasted duck had the right amount of sweetness and tang to it (thanks to the lime salad dressing) to wake up your palette! :) 

Rad nah - seasoned flat noodles smothered with a gravy-like sauce. noms. comes with ground pork too.

finally the star of the meal:
my pad kra pow moo krob - tender, tender (did I say tender?!) fried pork belly with crisoy pork rinds doused with a secret sauce and spices. uggggh. 

so so glad we ventured to this side of SF (I heard it was somehow ghetto), learn that it has a Michelin star, and chose this as our first meal of the year!


p.s. Happy new year everyone!!
p.p.s. I'm back on the review train!!!
author: Chesca L.

description: Lers Ros serves hands down the most phenomenal fish I've ever had. This steamed fish is served whole with a ginger, garlic, chili and lemon paste on top. Watch out for the bones though! Lers Ros is pretty amazing for Thai food. They have a few restaurants throughout San Francisco. The best branch is on Larkin street.
author: Sahiba J.

description:
With a reservation we were seated promptly on a very busy Saturday night. Our service was excellent and all suggestions were right on spot. My favorites of the night were the Black pepper beef, Red curry with duck, and the Pork Belly with chilies was both crispy and tender at the same time. Even though it was very busy we never felt rushed or hurried at all. I would highly recommend
Lers Ros Thai restaurant.
author: Charlie B.

description:
My main memory here, of the two times so far visiting this restaurant, was waiting at least a half hour for my stir-fried boar dish (the Pad Ped Moo Pah) to be served while my date got served within five minutes and ate their heart out. Yes, I understand it was busy that night. And yes, it was still delicious. But, it was also a work night and we ultimately had to get my dish to go, so I didn't even get to consume it that night. More of a grab-n-go occasion for us that particular evening...

Still, we love eating at the several locations of Lers Ros in the city for Thai food restaurants. Yes, we have been back to this one with some other friends, and had a much more pleasurable experience.
author: Garett T.

description: Great food and service. The portions are on the smaller side, but love the options available.
author: W D.

description:
Stopped into Lers Ros Thai a few weeks ago after being mildly curious about delicious Thai food and 7x7's reference to this place.  We came on a Friday night not really knowing what to expect, and knowing that they don't take reservations.  When we got there, we were cramped into the doorway waiting to put our name down.  After waiting about 30 minutes, we were finally seated in the front corner of the restaurant, which was actually kind of nice since it was away from all of the big groups of people there.  Anyway, after sitting down and having had a long time to peruse the menu, we decided on the following dishes to share:

-Nuer Yang (Broiled top sirloin beef, sliced and served with lime juice): One my favorite dishes at Thai restaurants, and this certainly did not disappoint.  In fact, I think it was one of the best things we ate!
-Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (Crispy pork belly with a side of rice): Well OF COURSE we were going to get the one thing that is advertised as being absolutely amazing here!  This dish was also delicious, and I finished the whole thing almost by myself.  I guess the one tiny hang up on this was that some of the pork was overcooked so it was incredibly hard to chew through a few of the pieces.  That being said, I would certainly recommend trying this dish!
-Chicken Pad Thai: This was Greg's dish, and he asked for chicken since he's not a fan of prawns.  I was too full to completely try this, but Greg's first impression was that it was too sweet.  That was before he knew to squeeze the limes over the dish.  After doing that, he said that it was the best Pad Thai he's had in San Francisco.

For the three dishes and three or four beers, the check came out to being fairly reasonable.  In my opinion, dishes like Pad Thai are difficult to elevate.  That being said, other dishes such as the beef and pork dishes we had were what made Lers Ros Thai the best place for Thai food in the city.  We don't always have the itch for Thai, but when the craving hits next, we'll hit up Lers Ros again.  


ps. They do delivery - winrar!
author: Lisa I.

description: I love the restaurant! We ordered Thai sausage and grilled pork loin for appetizer. It was very authentic and very good. Theses fish were better than the food we ate in Thailand!  I highly recommended this restaurant! But, you had better make a reservation first. I guess this restaurant is popular among locals and very crowded.
author: Cool K.

description: Perfect place. I'm a vegetarian and so usually when they replace the meat it doesn't taste as good. But this place was wonderful and really pretty. Definitely recommend.
author: Sahib K.

description:
Late night delivery which is fantastic.  Tom yum soup is very good and spicy, with good mushrooms and de-shelled shrimp.  

Pass on the Thai iced tea.

Pad Thai had too many bean sprouts and could use more meat, but was otherwise okay.  

Spicy minced beef with basil was tasty.  Rice is an extra ~$2, can get brown rice.
author: Vanessa O.

description:
The best thai food I've had in north America so far.

The chicken curry puffs, the curry and the papaya salad were impressive. The pad Thai was not the best, but not bad either.

Portions are not small, price seemed reasonable.

The place seems always crowded and there was no ac, it was quite hot.
author: Xavier R.

description: Didn't like it, meet and poetry full of skin , bay too much spices, up to level that you feel sick with spices, customer service not bad , don't try coconut soup with shrimp , center of salt and lemon + spices.
author: Danipal B.

description: Two words Pad Kao! Crab fried rice is delicious! I'll be back to try the Prik King Chicken. Best Thai in the city right in the Tenderloin on Market. Area is grungy but the establishment and food is amazing.
author: Mone J.

description: This is a very clean and modern Thai place. They have really cool meats like rabbit, frog and stuff. I ordered the pad Thai I think with shrimp. Kinda bleh. It was good but I felt like it was just soy sauce. My bf got the beef soup. Sooooo yum. A bit heavy on the cumin but still very flavorful. There was so much meat and tendon in the bowl!!! I felt like they just took the whole pack of beef and tendon and put it in there. Definitely worth the $. I also wanted to get their long on drink to go but the server said I couldn't. They definitely need to have to go cups!!! The weird thing was they couldn't wait to fertilize their bamboo with chicken poop after closing hours. We were sitting by the door and could smell it. Wouldn't come back here. Just a meh place.
author: Lynn C.

description:
45 minute wait even though I made reservations ahead of time AND they called to confirm earlier in the day. 

Food was good but way too spicy for my liking. Maybe I'll try some other items on the menu next time. 

Extra star for their durian sticky rice!!! ;)
author: Mary M.

description:
Not what it used to be.

Ler Ros was once an oasis in a desert full of OSHAs and King of Thais where you could go to get food that was true Thai but the food has unfortunately gone downhill since. The balance of sweet, salty, and sour that is so integral to Thai cuisine is now gone, scrapped in favor of what is perceived to be the white man's affinity for sweet flavors, a sentiment echoed by many in the local Thai community today. Ler Ros once served food that was true to it's heart, but it now takes the same route as many of the other "Thai" restaurants in the city nowadays, watering down it's flavor with too much sugar.  Put it simply, the food is just too sweet now, and has lost the authentic edge that once set Ler Ros apart from the others.

Where the crowd of diners inside the restaurant was once an eclectic mix of Thais and the adventurous, you will now only find "foodies" who don't have the slightest clue what Thai food is.

Despite the food not being as good as it was when Ler Ros first arrived on the scene, credit should be given for the fact that their menu still offers dishes far beyond your typical pad Thai, curries, and basil stir frys, and presented in their original format as well (no carrots or peas in your tom yum here). Portions are still generous in comparison to other Thai restaurants as well.
author: Mike A.

description:
Larb Phed Yang (4/5) the duck salad is PACKED with flavor. At first the lime dressing surprised me, but I liked it more and more with each bite.

Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (5/5) - like everyone has mentioned - the crispy pork rind is to die for : ). what a great complement to the fatty pork belly. A MUST TRY

Tom Kreang Nai (3/5) - there is a good amount of kidney.

Koh Moo Yang (3/5) - the pork shoulder was tender : ) and chili rice powder sauce was delicious. Fish sauce, but better and with a kick.

Definitely go with the sticky rice.
author: Leslie K.

description:
Sketchy neighborhood, but amazing (and reasonably priced) eats. You can't really go wrong with anything on this menu. Their soups are my fave on a chilly night!

They're always busy, so make sure you get there early!
author: Diana C.

description: Amazing food. Authentic and well spiced. I am definitely getting my thai food from here next time.
author: Nala T.

description:
LEGIT THAI FOOD
(4.25 stars)

 If my Thai homegirl says this is really good Thai food, it's LEGIT!!!!

- FOOD, good
- PRICES, decent
- SERVICE, good
- AMBIANCE, cute, clean and small

One of my closest friends from Seattle was in town and her request was "Asian food". I immediately thought of the Tenderloin. The crowd is mixed, I can trust a spot if I see non-Asians eating at a Tenderloin restaurant. We were immediately seated and looked at their great select and the special menu (alligator, rabit, etc). Interesting items on that special menu. However, we let my homegirl who is part Thai do the ordering. The staff never rushed us out and we took our time eating and catching up!! Damaged done was nearly $80 bucks but my friends said it was well worth it.

GARLIC FROG ($9.95) - House special dish, fried Frog with a rich flavor of garlic, served with hot sauce. FYI, I DON'T EAT KEROPPI, SO I PASSED. However my friends were trying it for the first time and they were huge fans of it. I just couldn't do it.

SOM TOM POO ($9.95) - Shredded green papaya salad with chili, tomatoes, lime based salad dressing and RAW CRABs. She asked for "Laos" style which I have no idea what the difference is but the wait staff new what she was talking about. I've never seen papaya salad with crab but I think this must be normal in Thailand. I dabbled in it since my friend order it extra spicy and it was pretty tasty. We ended up getting two orders of this.

KUAY TIEW RUA ($8.25) - Native Thai style herb & meat boiled soup with noodle. I think my homegirl was expecting something different as she had this in Thailand and said it wasn't the same but it was still good. Just reminded me of Korean chicken soup.

NUER PAD PRIK ($11.95) - Tender beef, stir-fried with fresh chili, bell peppers, yellow onion, bamboo shoot, basil and hot chili sauce. This was pretty good. It has a little bit of heat but the good kind of heat. 

PAD WOON SEN($8.95) - Silver noodles stir-fried with Prawns, Eggs and Napa Cabbage and Tomatoes. I think I have the right dish down. At first glance, it really looks like pancit (Filipino noodles) but the taste was different and SO GOOD. It looked so simple but tasted really really really cracking!!!

KAI YANG ($11.95) - Marinated barbequed chicken, served with sweet and sour sauce. Reminded me of baked chicken. nothing really special. The only thing that stood out was that the chicken was very tender and easy to eat. We got two orders of this and not sure why when we only could finished one order.

Will I be back? YES.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
With all the staff you would think the service is great. Well attentive, but rude and the food did not come out anywhere near the same time. Our group got irritated, asked why the dishes were only coming out one at a time very spread apart? All we got was an eye roll. 
The food was good, service was abnormally rude. These dishes did not look like it was meant to be shared and we were never given sharing plates. Very weird, but I would come back.. However, I will make sure to say everything out at the same time
author: Tim V.

description: Best Thai food in San Francisco. Well, technically it's the only Thai food I had in San Francisco.. So I will rephrase and say it's the best Thai food from San Francisco all the way east to NY. So spicy, so good
author: Joey D.

description:
This is one of the best Thai places that I've been to. I don't really like to eat Thai food, but I can see myself coming here often. I didn't even know about this place until I saw a huge crowd of people waiting outside at 10pm on a weekday. Ever since then, I've been wanting to try and I finally did yesterday. I went around 6pm with two of my coworkers and there was no wait!

We started off the raw shrimp salad. I really liked this dish. The sauce that came with it blended well with the shrimp. The server asked how spicy we wanted it from 1-10 and we said "7." And it was pretty spicy... but that good kind of spicy.

For our meal, we ordered the quick fried fish, yellow curry with chicken, and pork shoulder. The quick fried fish was my favorite dish. It was a whole fried trout, and it came with a mango sauce that was just amazing. The yellow curry with chicken was just alright. Maybe it's cause I usually don't care for curry. The pork shoulder was nice and tender. The sauce that came with it paired well with it too. Its originally an appetizer but we asked for it to come out as an entree.

I really liked the decor of the place. The place was very clean and modern. The service here was excellent. Our server was very helpful when deciding what to order, and he consistently checked on us during our whole experience. I will definitely be back to try more items on their menu.
author: Derek T.

description: I ordered the Pad Kee Maow one time and the Pad See Eew another time. Both are flat pan fried noodles. They were absolutely delicious, and flavorful, however the portions are small.
author: Lily S.

description: Was recommended as a local favorite so we gave it a try. "Meh"... was ok. Expected a bit more flavor and Thai taste. Was on a busy day so kitchen staff may have been cutting corners to get the food out. Atmosphere was average given the area/zone. Service was lousy. Waiter had trouble managing the seven person table and he lied/did not understand the question about not carrying "Thai Milk Tea" when asked for it. Before leaving, we saw another table drinking it. Took forever to get the check when we wanted to leave. Would not recommend this place at all! Summary...food ok and service was lousy.
author: John J.

description:
My first time here was definitely a 5 star experience. We are all Thai and we know what good time food is (my parents being chefs and all)
Everything we ordered the first time was amazing and we couldn't stop eating and complimenting. I swear on everything, so of the things we ate tasted better than food in Thailand. 

But the second time we went, it wasn't that great. Our server mentioned that sometimes there is a Mexican chef working, and sometimes there is a Thai chef working...I don't know who was on what shift but the food was not as good. 

We ordered pretty much all the same dishes because we enjoyed them so much the first time..but sadly a lot of the flavors were not there. 

I hate inconsistencies in restaurants more than anything. Especially when we traveled so far expecting the same amazing meal.
author: Ness H.

description:
Some of the best Thai food in SF in my opinion. I've been here a couple times now and the flavors are always spot on and consistent. The gf and I came in on Saturday night after  day drinking at a wine festival and we needed something to hit the spot. 

Location is in the TL  but that shouldn't scare you away from trying this place. Just mind your business while walking around and you'll be fine. The service is good and they try and accommodate you as best as they can. It also gets pretty busy so a reservation is highly recommended. The atmosphere is fun and loud and you constantly catch people looking at other tables to see what they ordered. They have tons of items that look appetizing so it's hard to choose if you're a bit confused. 

My favorites: 

Larb Phed Yang (Duck Larb Salad) - It has the perfect mix of sour, sweet and spice. The thai basil's flavor is pronounced but not overpowering and the duck is perfectly cooked. 

Tom Kha Kai (Coconut Sour Soup) - This is a MUST try! The soup is light but creamy with the coconut milk. It was so good, that we literally finished everything and I jokingly asked the waitress if she had a straw so that I can finish the rest in the pot!
author: Andrew S.

description: No meats in my soup, only 5 shrimps with some mushrooms and THAT IT! The proportion of the dish is SO SO SMALL! I've ordered myself extra 2 bowls of white rice to eat full! Won't be back!
author: Xihou Z.

description:
This place is super crowded. I suggest you come early or make a dinner reservation. It's also not an ideal place to have a conversation with someone even if their sitting across or next to you. The music is blaring loud and the crowds line up. I think most people are talking over the music to hear the person across or next to them, which probably adds to the fact that you can't hear.

The ambiance of the restaurant reminds me a hip version of thai restaurant. For one, they play like hip hop, pop music. I mean I could hear lil jon' over the speaker saying WHAT? YEAH OK! as I'm eating my Pad Thai yelling what did you say across to my friend. It was quite the experience.

The dishes.. .they serve a wide range. Alligator, boar, pork, chicken, frogs... etc. They have it all. I didn't dare try outside my comfort circle. We ordered the basil shrimp. It's spicy, but pretty okay. Not an array of veggies as I would've liked, but it does the trick. The crispy chicken over fried rice was also delish. I really liked the fried rice. And we also ordered the pad see ew... it was good. A bit too salty and saucy for me. so next time less soy. The chicken noodle with flat rice noodles was also good. A small is good for two people to split. nothing too crazy.

For 5 dishes and three people we paid $60.
author: Nathalie N.

description:
I've been here several times and most of the dishes were very tasty. My favorites are the duck larb, crispy chicken with garlic rice, and chicken cashew.

The place can be busy, so it's not uncommon to wait for a table of 2. My only dislike is the seats are backless and the tables don't have hooks, so the only place to put my coat or bag is on my lap or the floor.
author: Pamela N.

description:
Delicious Pad See Ew and Iced coffee and the service extremely fast.
Plus, the prices are pretty awesome.
Would definitely be back!
author: Dominique F.

description:
Was not impressed with my first visit here but willing to come back again because of all the rave reviews.

+Papaya Salad with Salted Eggs- way too spicy and WAY TOO SALTY. The egg was completely inedible and tasted like a ball of vinegar.
+ Spicy Eggplant with Tofu- pretty standard and decent dish that we enjoyed with rice.
+ Rice for 2 people was too big a portion and we didn't end up finishing it.

Service:
I made a reservation here and was promptly seated at 6:30. The restaurant was bustling, so I'm glad that I made a rezzo before coming! The staff were very friendly and smily and very attentive to our needs even though every single table was taken.

Ambience:
Not as hole in the wall as I imagined. Actually a very cozy and romantic little restaurant. It does get pretty loud and if you're forced to sit at the long communal table in the middle, I could see where it might not feel as intimate.

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description:
The first time I went I really enjoyed it, got a good variety of food and everything was so tasty!

The second time, I got the Larb Phed Yang- duck salad, very tasty!

The Tom Kha Kai soup with prawns was disappointing as there wasn't really much content inside. Some prawns and mushrooms but mostly soup. It could do with more vegetables.

A "scoop" of rice is actually quite large  and can be shared between two people of medium appetite. My friend and I regretted not sharing.

They are super busy so they may rush you a bit to allow customers in- a bit annoying but understandable. 

Overall a good experience!
author: Vivian D.

description: As recommended by a Friend to try out. Not A fun dinner night. They rush you cuz people are coming in. Do they charge you for water??? Are you kidding me. We don't even ask for it. Please change the ribbon of your receipt can't read if it's 18 or 15 dollars.
author: Peepeye L.

description: Very extensive menu! Probably, best Thai food that I've had in SF. Service was exceptional as well. Will definitely be back.
author: Chris B.

description:
Highly recommend it.

Went on Friday night around 8 pm and we had to wait 25 minutes for a party of 2 but it was worth it. They had live music. 

Recommendations:
# 77  Pad See-Ew (vegetarian) - I think this was the best  Pad See-Ew I have ever had. Really soft noodles and the entire dish was very delicious. Must try!

#50 Kang Dang Pak (vegetarian) - Loved it! I asked them to make it medium spicy and it was actually spicy. Very flavorful. The only negative is that the curry sauce was too little to eat with rice. Lots of vegetables. You have to purchase rice separately. 

Price is not bad at all!
author: Hiral P.

description:
Decent Americanized Thai food served by friendly, if somewhat harried-looking, staff. 

My friend and I grabbed a quick dinner here before heading to Symphony Hall to watch my favorite Hitchcock movie, Vertigo, with music performed live by the SFS (NB: If you've never seen Vertigo, you are truly missing out--esp if you live in SF). This restaurant knows its patrons, and we had only to mention that we had a show to attend for our waitress to promise our food would be out quickly.

Unfortunately, said food wasn't so great. We got the shrimp asparagus, and noodles with pork belly and bean sprouts respectively. His dish (the former) was better than mine by virtue of being a straightforward stir-fry with a little sweet and spicy mixed in. Mine was a special and just didn't work because there were all these weird shallots mixed in with the noodles that gave everything a funny taste. 

Decor is lovely in that sleek 'n' chic kind of way, and as mentioned, service is pretty good. Prices are what'll probably tip the scale toward dining here over other Hayes Valley/Civic Center restaurants when you're in the 'hood to see a show.
author: Josephine L.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for a while thanks to fellow yelpers. All of you did not disappoint me at all; thank you!

I decided to take my mom here for Mother's Day, and I love it here. The service is great, the staff is attentive and quick to answer questions I have, and they are patient with my indecisive self. Inside looks very modern and clean unlike some of the other restaurants around here. 

The food is delicious. We ordered the spicy eggplant with tofu, top sirloin beef, and #64 (sorry, I don't know the name of the dish), rice with garlic and ginger. The rice is awesome...super oily but tasty. I really like all of the flavors and the spiciness of the dishes. 

I am definitely coming back here and hoping to try their other dishes! Thanks again, yelpers!!
author: Jen T.

description: Not sure why the Larkin Lers Ros always get my order wrong. The other establishments are all fine. Today I had lunch with some coworkers and the waitress took 45 minutes to tell they just started to make my salad. Seriously?
author: Calvin B.

description:
Delicious food, totally flexible and able to make you an impressive catered (and delivered) meal in no time.

Love 'em.
author: Ian T.

description: Very very good Thai food! Curry has a lot of coconut flavor and everything is so good!
author: Monnikka M.

description:
Papaya salad and beef noodle soup - SO GOOD!

Thanks to Yelp, I just found another gem.
author: Carol S.

description:
I've been here a handful of times. The food is great, but the service is poor. 

Last time I dined here, I waited over an hour for my meal, and when it arrived I almost finished the entire thing before my friend had received her meal - and we had ordered the same thing! The woman next to us said she waited over 75 minutes for her food and her boyfriend had already finished his meal long before she got hers too. This was completely unacceptable, and the waitresses didn't seem to be very empathetic to the situation at all. I was very disappointed, because the food here is good but they should also be providing a good experience to the customer with regards to attentiveness and timing of the meal. Otherwise the food was great, but I had a poor taste in my mouth after waiting forever for my meal. 

Also good to note - the place gets very crowded and if you sit by the door you're going to be bumped by other people and cold due to the air from the street and alley across the way. if you can sit elsewhere, you should ask to do so.
author: Claire S.

description:
I finally tried this place out back in June. I've been hearing from various friends that it's THE BEST Thai place in the city. They have several locations in the city, but I was told that this location in the 'loin was the best. 

We went here on a Friday night and had an early dinner reservation. The place wasn't that packed yet since it was only 6 PM. We ordered a variety of dishes:

1. Garlic Frog (Sounds gross but garlic on anything is amazing. This was crispy, tasty and not too spicy.)
2. Kang Keaw Wan, aka Green Curry (This dish was a little spicier but was a well made traditional green curry.)
3. Rad Nah (House secret gravy sauce and marinated pork topping on the seasoned flat noodle, pictured below. That pork was so crispy I felt like I was eating pork grinds! This was a little spicy as well but by far, my favorite dish so far here). 
4. Sticky Rice with Durian (Durian! OMG, they have durian! My friends had never tried durian before. 1 hated it and the other 2 were indifferent. That just meant more durian for me! The durian flavor wasn't even that strong compared to it's fresh form but for all you durian lovers (vs haters) out there, this is a must try. They add coconut milk on it, so the flavor is sweeter and definitely less intense).

Tips for this place:
1. Make a reservation (so you don't have to kill time in the Tenderloin)
2. Come hungry
3. Go with at least 3-4 people so you can try many dishes

I took the bus here, but I'm assuming parking shouldn't be too much of an issue in this neighborhood. The location may be sketch, but at least the food is amazing and there's a good chance you'll find parking!
author: Sophia H.

description: Amazing food, courteous and friendly service, and fun atmosphere. We came with a group of 7 on a busy night and a) everyone loved what they got, b) they made a table for us on a very short notice and were super patient with our indecisive ordering.
author: Alina B.

description:
This place gets pretty busy during dinner hours and we waited about 30 minutes or so to get seated. And the wait was definitely worth it. They're known for the wild and extravagant meats, but we decided on a more traditional Thai dinner.

We had about 5 dishes for 5 people and each share was about $16 each...and we were stuffed and satisfied at the end of the evening. One of the dishes we had was this seafood soup, but it was quite spicy for some, so be advised if you order this.

My favorite was yellow curry. And that yellow curry can be pretty much added to some of their other dishes. And it wasn't as spicy as the soup either.

The servers were super friendly, focused on customer service and were super cute too. Parking can be issue in downtown, so you'll just have to drive around until you find something.
author: Mike C.

description: Best Thai food ever. I love thai food and I am very picky eater. This place was just amazing- ambience, price, food, customer service- all 5 stars. Cant wait to go back.
author: Koh Mal K.

description:
I gotta say, I wasn't impressed. Maybe we ordered the wrong things, or it could have been all the hype from Yelp. We asked the waitress for popular dishes and her recommendations and she sped through about 12 items on the menu (which all have crazy Thai names), leaving us more confused on what to order. 

We ended up deciding on two standard Thai dishes: pad thai and beef fried rice. Both were mediocre at best - the pad Thai was salty enough that I couldn't get through half of it and the fried rice was bland (think like plain oatmeal). Not terrible per say, but definitely didn't live up to its 4 star reputation.

May or may not come back to try what seem to be the more popular dishes on the menu. Probably not (or maybe after I learn some thai).

Plus points for speedy service.
author: Avery H.

description:
This place is so loud! It has granite tiles on the walls that amplify sound like a drum. So everyone talks at the top of their voice in order to be heard over the general roar. I'm getting old, but I couldn't wait to get out of this place. 

The food was good which is why I'm giving it more than one star.
author: Tim O.

description: Best Thai food in SF. This is where everyone I know from Thailand that lives in SF goes to eat. They have two more locations now too that aren't in the worst part of the tenderloin. So that's a plus.
author: Andrew M.

description: Fast service, good food, and they generally do a good job accommodating me, given how busy they are. It can get noisy though.
author: Rish M.

description: Has tables and bar. It's a great place for watching games with friends! I really like the coconut milk soup and the pork shoulder BBQ with spicy sauce very much. The green curry (medium spicy) is much more spicy than expected but it still doesn't hurt the flavor of it.
author: Qi W.

description:
**3.5**

Wow, i thought the line out the door on Larkin St was for a night club. Nope, It was actually for Lers Ros on a Saturday night. If you go during prime dinnertime, expect to not be able to hear what your table mates are saying to you... definitely not a place to eat at if you're trying to hold a proper dinner conversation. However, despite the very long wait and disregard for our reservation, the food was pretty good and did not disappoint. Service was acceptable.
author: Diana K.

description:
We ordered food for pickup - 3 Pad Thais and one Tom Yum Koong. I called at 12:11p. They told me 25-30 minutes, but not over thirty minutes over the phone. Okay great! I walk over there, thinking okay it's been only 20 minutes, so I know I might need to wait another ten minutes. After fifteen minutes, I ask them about it. I figure since three are the same thing, it really shouldn't take that long. They're packed and I understand that they're busy. It's about 12:40 and my coworker had to go back. I ask them where it is and they just said it wasn't ready yet. I waited there until 1:05 before I got my food, which is about an hour from when I ordered it! By the time I brought it back, we couldn't eat it immediately because we had a schedule to keep. 

When we finally were able to eat it, I would say the food was pretty good overall. I would probably go there again if I had more time or if I decide to get lunch for the crew, I'd probably order it before noon. Maybe it'll be faster then.
author: Amy N.

description: I was looking forward to try this restaurant because they seemed to have many Thai dishes, much more than the usual pad Thai and curries you see everywhere. And they do, actually their menu is almost too long for me, there are so many options it is hard to make a choice. The food was good, and I liked that it had Thai flavors but allowed us to discover different dishes. If you come here, I'd recommend to order from their specialties or the authentic Thai flavor section to get a taste of something different. I particulalry liked the raw prawn "salad" (not really a salad), it was a very interesting appetizers with strong flavors. The quail dish was very messy to eat, don't order this if you're on a first date. The service was great, even when we came 45 minutes late on our reservation they tried their best to sit us right away. The only thing I really didn't like about the place was how loud it was. I could barely have a chat with my boyfriend. They try to fit as many people as possible in a rectangle room and as a result you can't hear yourself talk. Thankfully the food is good.
author: Helene P.

description:
AMAZING. I love this hole in the wall. The decor and atmosphere was completely different from the neighborhood outside.
