My bill came out to be $1.00 more before taxes than the advertised low price of the lunch special of $8.75.  I didn't ask why but guess when waitress asked if I wanted white or brown rice she failed to tell me they charge more for the brown.
Not the best Thai around I am sure but certainly good enough to leave full and happy.
author: Alexandra C.

description:
3.5 but rounding it up to 4 because I'd be down to sample their extensive menu again.

I came here earlier this month with a friend.  Venturing to the TL can be quite an experience, but on the several times I've been (and sometimes even stayed) in the area, I haven't had problems.

We had a dinner reservation for a Monday at around 8 p.m.  Originally the reservation was set for earlier, but I was able to change it because we were running late.  The ease with which I changed it made me think that it wouldn't be super busy.

I was wrong.

The place was packed when we arrived.  I thought maybe there wouldn't be room, but we were seated.  It's a small restaurant, poorly lit, and pretty cramped, so except a fairly intimate dining environment.

We ordered the tong yum gong soup, som tom koong yang (papaya salad with grilled prawns) and the pad ped moo pah (stir fried boar).  

The soup and the papaya salad were good, although I don't know if I'd make a trek out just for them.  It was true that the ingredients tasted like they were of better quality than some of the cheaper Thai joints, although I'm not sure if the price point matched the level of premium ingredients.

We ordered the stir fried boar because we knew that Les Ros was well known for their more exotic meats.  It was thinly sliced and came with a splash of vegetables and Thai spices.  In some ways it resembled Sichuanese food, and the actual meat itself was kind of gamey as you'd expect.  

Service:  They're extremely busy here.  You might have to be a bit on the louder end to get someone's attention.

Bottom line:  Not the world's best Thai - perhaps the city's? - but I'd be back to sample more of their exotic meats.  It's certainly a step up from your neighborhood Thai hole in the wall.
author: Denny C.

description:
Best Thai restaurant in SF :)  (in my opinion) 

I love this restaurant because everything tastes very authentic. I've actually been to Thailand once and tried their dishes, and have also tried most of the Thai places in SF. This spot is definitely the best. 

Here's what I've tried and how I liked it:

-Som Tom Poo  - Shredded green papaya salad with chili, tomatoes, lime based salad dressing and RAW CRABs 
*So yummy! Great dish to start with, Raw crab actually tastes pretty good! 

- Tom Yum Koong  - Traditional spicy and sour soup with Prawn, lemongrass, mushrooms and kaffir lime leaves
*Delicious soup, highly recommend!!! 

-Pad See-Ew  - Pan-fried flat noodle, served with chicken or pork (beef / prawns 9.95 , seafood11.95) $8.95
-Pad Thai  - Traditional Thai style pan-fried rice noodle, Prawns; serve with crushed peanut, Bean sprout and sliced lemon
*Can't go wrong with either of them.. both very flavorful. 

-Tom Yum Pla Kra Pong  - Whole fresh sea bass in spicy and sour soup
**This is a hit or miss, the first time we tried it, it was cooked perfectly. But the last 2 times, it was a little overcooked and made the fish very chewy. 

-Thai Iced Tea is also good 

Aside from being in the middle of the hood, this place is well worth trying. Service is always great here.
author: Cara N.

description:
I was excited to try Lers Ros because I've only heard good things about it. Well good to know it's not just hype.. it's the real deal. This place is awesome!

Arrived for dinner on a Saturday around 6:30.. no reservations.. we got a table right away. Maybe 10 minutes later the place was  PACKED. Wow we were so lucky haha

Although we were tempted by the frog, crocodile and other exotic meats.. ok not! ..maybe next time.. we ended up ordering the Nuer Tod for appetizer (fried Sun dried beef). I really really really loved it!! I'm still dreaming about it today. I can't wait to go back and have it again. So yummy.. but then again I love jerky so maybe that's why haha. For main dish.. so much to choose from but ended up with Pad Thai (my partner's way to test how good a Thai place is) and I had the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (stir-fried pork belly with crispy rind and basil leaves). Pad thai was prob the best we've had, and the pork belly dish was awesomely delicious. We cannot wait to try the other items on the menu!!

So glad we live just a couple of blocks from Larkin because we'll be at Lers Ros as much as possible!
author: Vol T.

description: What rhymes with Duck? The duck curry sucks. Also, there's the f word. Anyway, here's a picture of 1 of 4 peices of duck in the duck curry, the other three weren't much better. All gristle and cartilege.
author: Jon S.

description:
Came here quite a long time ago. Forgot exactly what we ordered. One thing I will never forget though - I ordered the crispy poke belly after reading all the wonderful reviews. So good!Will def go back next time I'm in town. Once again, it proves one theory- you don't go to a nice neighborhood for authentic Asian cuisine, except for sushi.

We were there on a Sunday afternoon so there was no line waiting which was nice. I'm not used to the downtown SF parking so I was quite shocked to find out how expensive it was to park on the street. One quarter only gave me 5 mins lol. So it's $3/hr. And yes, you do have to feed the meter on Sundays..If I knew that earlier, I would have parked my car in the garage somewhere close by... Just saying..
author: S C.

description:
San Francisco....Thai Food? Its like....everywhere. How do we decipher what is good and what isn't in this dense community of "good" food? Its tough, I'm from LA and the food in SF is suppose to be superior...I've heard. Not convinced at all, yet.  Especially when everything in SF is 4+ stars. As Jay-Z says, "overrated or underpaid." I guess its the motto here. SF is overrated for its local rating system. I can argue that most people don't have a car or don't want to go far in the city to get good food (since there is traffic and no place to park), so it boils down to what is good by proximity, which then elevates the value of the eatery. Bogus! 

But wait, there is a place! I'm down with this spot. Not the best papaya salad compared to most. But I will give it to them for handling their business on a staple - patai was pretty darn good, I would argue some of the best in the city or any other spot. Good job. 

Shady neighborhood, but its the city. The eatery it self is nice, cleaner and newer paint. Friendly staff and a lot to choose from on the menu.

Other than the papaya salad and patai, I had the pork shoulder, this was good too. The people around us all seemed to be getting the noodle soup. Probably a good call for next time. 

Full service bar.
author: Baron C.

description: 2 hour wait on simple delivery downtown without any warning (I didn't ask how long it would take, so I guess that's my bad). I called the restaurant after 1.5 hours to check on my order, the lady replied "on its way" and hung up on me - literally. Food was absolutely delicious so unfortunately I'll be back, but the delivery service really pissed me off tonight.
author: Eli W.

description:
Fun to try. We were in an adventurous mood tonight, so we got:

Alligator: favorite! Good seasoning, the meat juicy similar to the texture of shrimp or fish.
Tom Kha soup with shrimp was very good, I like how clear the soup, not over-crowded by the spices. Just shrimp and mushrooms, with a ton of flavor.
Salt and pepper Rabbit: pretty good, nice marinate for the meat.
Garlic Frog: least favorite, I love frogs, but these were dry and overcooked.

I guess I don't really understand the hype either. Expensive cars parked in this rough stretch in the Loin, waiting outside in nice outfit, for a no where near upscale Thai food? Interesting. We decided we'd go back to Pagolac if we were nearby and need food.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
My review is not about their food!!  

When I received my credit card bill, they had charged my credit card twice.  When I told them about their mistake they refused to correct it and just told me without researching that they only changed my card once.  Thus I had to resort to calling the credit card company to file a dispute on the extra charge.  So definitely check your credit card!!!!!
author: Michael L.

description: This place hit the spot! I have ordered Thai from a place I won't mention on Polk street many times and thought that was the best I could find in San Francisco When I heard about Lers Ros Thai I figured I would give it a try and now I will never go anywhere else. Thanks!
author: Kevin J.

description:
A very good Thai Restaurant.  Finally decided to write a review since I pretty much tried half of their menu last night.  We got here around 6 on a Tuesday so it wasn't too busy and we were able to get a table for 9.  

We started with appetizers which included a papaya salad, the curry puffs, fried beef, and duck larb.   Most of it was really good.  The papaya salad we got had the raw crab.  A bit on the sour side, but still good.  The curry puffs were so, so, nothing spectacular or worth ordering again.  The fried beef was really good, pretty much the same thing as a Cambodian beef jerky I used to eat at home growing up.  And of course the Duck Larb is still the best thing their menu!  So flavorful with the complex mix of onion, herbs, duck, lime, and ground up roasted rice!  

For the main entrees we had the Pad Thai, Pad Kee Mow, Fried Fish, Steamed Fish, Pork Soulder, Pork Belly, Fried Quail, and Friend Frog Legs, and a couple of more things i don't really remember.  Let me just focus on the standouts.  

The Fried fish was really good.  Although it was fried, the meat inside was still moist and flavorful, not fried flavored, which is good.  The Pork Should we really good, but not quite as good as Sai Jai's, more fatty and the dipping sauce too sour.  The Pork Belly was a stir fry with fresh peppers.  This plate was really good, but I was at the point where I was just picking at food when it came out, but still took 2 or 3 more bites that I should have.  Every thing else was solid, just not exceptionally good.  

The staff is really friendly, but pushy when it comes to telling you how much food to order (they always err on the too much food side, not a bad thing I guess, haha).  They are also quite a bit eager to clear your plates, even plates that were only half done.  They don't really ask, they just take, so be vigilant if you are saving any last morsels.

A very good, solid Thai place, will definitely come back.  A notch above most places, and a price that makes them competitive in the TL!
author: Veasna H.

description:
BEST THAI FOOD OUTSIDE OF THAILAND! 

i came here on recommendation from a thai friend and was not disappointed. the food here is absolutely excellent. we ordered a bunch and it was little affordable. the pad thai and peanut sauce was just as good as in thailand.
author: Mandy A.

description:
Best Thai Food!  The pork belly was sublime.  The combination of chicharron and pork belly melded with the sauce - lip smacking good!  I just couldn't get over how awesome the flavors were.  All of the dishes we ordered were scrumptious. The price of the meal was so reasonable given the quality of the food. 

Go early because this place gets packed!  Service is friendly and attentive.  (The neighborhood is s little dicey, so be cautious.)
author: Bruges L.

description: ZERO STARS. Mediocre at best. Food was not good, zero flavor. My friend had a hair in his plate and when he complained the cook came out of the back and stared at us like we committed a crime. The waiter was nice but you can tell he has not been a server for long
author: Michael G.

description: Pretty good pseudo-hipster Thai place in the 'Loin.
author: Dan E.

description:
Their food is soooo amazing! The best Pad Thai I have ever had. It's got just the right amount of spiciness and veggies (as I usually order it with Tofu). My next most favourite is the Spicy Tofu with Brown Rice. 

Pad Thai and Spicy Tofu with Brown Rice is the best combination! Leftovers are plenty for the next day as well.
author: Sun B.

description: It was a shot in the dark, but a culinary bull's eye. A friendly patron recommended the Pad Kee Mow noodle dish with flat pan fried noodles. We got it with beef and it's the definition of comfort food. We also ordered the pork belly with basil, Pad...Krow...Mob. Delicious! A bit heavy of a meal when ordered together. Dinner and drinks for two adults for under $50 in Hayes Valley...not bad at all!
author: Nia D.

description: I love the food, but the delivery was THE SLOWEST IN HISTORY, and the restaurant didn't handle the food being late very well.  I called after the food was ten minutes late, then when it was twenty minutes late.  Finally, the food came over thirty minutes late (and that's after I ordered on their online system and it gave me an estimated time of an hour!)  Would be five stars if it were only about food.  Would be one star if it were only about service.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
THE MOST FOODGASMIC SALAD YOU WILL EVER HAVE. PERIOD.

Ok, ok so I know "orgasmic" and "salad" is an oxymoron but Lers Ros makes a salad that will tantalize your taste buds, set fireworks off in your mouth and make your eyes roll the f*ccccck back into your head. 

Yum Koh Moo Yang (Pork Shoulder Salad w/ Spicy Lime Dressing - $9.95) is all you need to know. It even has "yum" in its name so know it's YUMtastic. No worries if you can't pronounce it, just say "#17" (or #9 if you just want the pork shoulder).
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WFgRFq_KxIs2fkYo1iD6Tg?select=vP7ZLTSK_IHBmfobDRs-cA
You think the best pork dish in SF is from NOPA? Honey, you haven't tasted "pork" until you've tried the pork shoulder from Lers Ros. Slightly caramelized and crisp around the edges, the marinated roast pork shoulder is a taste and texture sensation in your mouth. The well-seasoned slice packs an intense rich buttery mouth-feel (not oily or greasy) full of subtle spices with a tinge of garlic. Each slice will leave you salivating for more. The lime dressing hits the pork with a fiery citrus punch while the basil, scallions, and cilantro give a fresh herbaceousness. As the icing on the cake, sprinkle some crushed peanuts for a nutty crunch. BEST. SALAD.EVER.

ORGASM GUARANTEED. DIET-FRIENDLY? That's why you walk 9 blocks back to the office like my FAT (      I      ) did. 

OTHER NOTES: 
*Open every day till midnight.
*~45 people seating.
*Prompt, friendly, and attentive service.
*Featured in The NY Times, LA Times, SF Chronicle, SF Weekly and 7x7 as the best and most authentic Thai restaurant in SF.
*Stick with their specialties (this is not the place to order Pad Thai): #4 Thai Herb Sausage, #9 Pork Shoulder, #25 Duck Larb Salad, and #62 Pork Belly w/ Pork Rinds & Basil.
*2nd swankier location is in Hayes Valley (opened 11.11.11).
*$15 minimum for FREE delivery. 
*CC's accepted.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I ordered pad see ew with prawns and it was mediocre. I was disappointed after reading good reviews as people said this was one of the best thai restaurants around with authentic thai food but based on my experience, it's not as good as everyone made it seem. I traveled from Seattle and chose this spot for dinner. The presentation was nice, I'll give them that. But that's where it ends. My plate of pad see ew was insipid but I finished it anyway because I was hungry and didn't want to order something else. The location is sketchy af since it is in the tenderloins so I would recommend getting dropped off by uber or something lol
author: Melissa C.

description:
I could eat here every day. Top dishes:

- Pad Thai
- Thai Sausage
- Tom Yum
 - Red Curry Chicken
 - Pork Belly

This is definitely the best Thai place in the city. Make sure you have a reservation because it is always crowded. Service is great and they also have a decent selection of Sake and Asian Beers. 

Flavors are very authentic and this location is very cozy (despite the neighborhood). It is the first thai restaurant that comes up on Yelp for a reason!
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Can't believe I've never written about this place! It's about a block away from us, and when we have guests coming over, we try to make it a point to take them here.

Things I recommend:
Nuer Tod (fried sun-dried beef)
Yum Koh Moo Yang (pork shoulder salad)
Larb Moo (roasted duck salad)
Pad-See-Ew (pan fried noodles, beef)
any of the Coconut Milk Curries
Steamed sea bass (although pricey, it's insanely delicious and worth a try)

so many choices on this menu, it's hard to keep up, but we keep trying different things.

and it's always a must to get the sweet sticky rice for dessert :)
author: Abigail W.

description:
This review is for their delivery service. They were running over an hour late and so I called and the woman kept saying it would be there soon. However when the delivery person came, an hour and a half after I placed the order, I only gave her a dollar tip because I was unsatisfied with their service. She kept ringing my doorbell and demanded more money saying she needed to pay off loans. I was saying that they need faster service and she kept repeating that it was not her fault and asked for more money. I gave her two more dollars so she would stop bugging me. 

The food was ok, but by that point in the night I was just so upset about how long we waited and their poor service.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Bummer--the food was pretty good, but I think I have a major msg hangover, because I drank 4 cups of water during the meal and still woke up with a pounding head.

Garlic frog - okay, but couldn't taste the garlic on the frog itself
Garlic quail - better, but tons of bones in both these dishes
Pork shoulder - amazing
Pad see ew - at first there was a strong mushroom (shiitake or something else) odor that made the taste weird. When it cooled off, it was easier to eat. Plate sizes are also inconsistent. Be prepared to be jealous when your friend gets a much larger portion than you did!

The extensive menu is pretty exciting, but other than that, I'll pass next time.
author: Steph M.

description: There is not much more to add, but I wanted to make sure this awesome place gets the recognition it deserves. Best Thai in the city. The parking is always easy for us later on week nights. Highly recommend the yellow curry - delish.
author: Noelle F.

description: I love their lunch special. You definitely will get a meal here for a cheap price. During lunch special it's under $10 and their food is amazing and comes in large portions. I keep coming back here when I crave Thai.
author: Francis D.

description:
Stick with chicken and Sake. it can get any better than that. The price is decent and the food is very good.

Visited October 2014
author: Matheus G.

description: Im a fan.   Item  62 the crispy pork was so great we went back a 2nd time during our trip to SF.   Highly rated and I am a fan.
author: Mark R.

description: Good place to come for lunch special.  Always order the 2 piece chicken with mince pork and brown rice. Came for dinner and had to wait 20min to be seated. Found out they do take reservations. .
author: dave w.

description: A stuff crowded place, the air smelled of old oil, and folks are here from everywhere just not the neighborhood. They follow the spices: the red green and yellow curries, the delicacies like the crocodile meat and lamb and quails... And the most magical of all the young green peppercorn (a south East Asian way to enjoy sichuanese people's favorite roasted red peppercorn). It's a sharper sensation, flavorful and a great addition to creamier food. Don't forget, this place has a great wine selection and excellent service. Did I mention, it's a Michelin recommended hole in the wall in the tenderloin.
author: Dilys S.

description:
Here's the deal... I don't understand these high ratings for Lers Ros.  I went there earlier in the week before going to the Symphony and felt it was nothing special.

To be straight forward, I will mention that I consider Thai food to be among my favorite categories of food.  On this occasion we arrived without a reservation and were met by a woman with a very arrogant attitude who at first said she couldn't seat us without a reservation and then seated us at a very cramped table by the door.  We weren't attended to in a reasonable amount of time (another table actually walked out without being served and, as the host chased them down to tell them a server would be with them, they said they waited too long and wouldn't be back).  While I was given water when I was seated (I also ordered Sake), I was never revisited for a refill the entire length of the visit.

For an appetizer I had Fish Cakes.  They were average at best and were slightly rubbery but had a nice flavor.  Surprisingly, they were lacking in seasoning.

I then had a Venison Curry while my companion had a Fish Curry.  The Venison was presented like Steak'ems (Think thinly sliced, frozen meat) and was extremely tough to chew.  I was actually thankful that there were so few pieces because I hated having to endure eating them.  There was a severe lack of vegetable on the plate and so I ate the few slices of meat I was allotted.  Additionally, the curry was very spicy, which normally would have been fine, but as I said earlier, I was never visited for a refill of my water and so it was borderline excruciating.

My companion's Fish Curry had a very nice flavor and wasn't very spicy.  The problem was that the fish was also chewy and overcooked.

I would normally give the restaurant one star, but I have added the extra star because:
1)  We were seated without a reservation on what I surmise to be a busy night
2)  The decor was very nice
author: Jonathan M.

description:
I've been here a few times, before they got really popular and very recently...


Pros: 

Food is still good. Service is average, but not bad. Selection of dishes is nice, along with some things that you can't find easily.

Cons: 

At this point, they may be a victim of their own success. It's crowded, and that takes a toll. Longer waits, a crushed staff, rush, rush, rush and noise levels through the roof.

They changed to these bench seats that are, imho, horrible. Why? Who knows (maybe to squeeze more people in?) There's no where to hang your coat (or purse for folks that use 'em), and the benches are hard. 

Give me a regular chair any day. And yes, that in addition to the other factors made enough difference to me to scratch them off my list :(
author: Kenneth T.

description: My friends and I keep trying the three different locations of Lers Ros Thai.  While they are all simply amazing and flavorful, I think that the Larkin Street location is the best for ambience and cuisine. I don't know how they prepare their Tom Kha Gai, but I would love to sneak a peak to find out their secret for perfection of this amazing soup. Every dish has always been great, and if you're with a group, this is a great chance to share your dishes with one another and get a flavor extravaganza.  Even friends from Thailand have told me it doesn't get any better. While we will always miss Suriya's, this has become our favorite place to eat in San Francisco.
author: Smudge T.

description: I go to this place almost every other month. The Pork shoulder and the raw prawns are my favorite. It's better for you to make reservation because this place gets packed all the time. Another thing I like is they close at midnight!
author: Jen C.

description:
The Papaya Salad here is fantastic. If you do not like spicy food, I would recommend you stay away from it. But if hot food is your thing, then the Papaya Salad is to die for. The food here in quite authentic tasting in general as well. The Pad Ped Aligator is also a great option to try. 

It can get very crowded during the weekends. So recommend reserving a table before going there.
author: Shringar P.

description: Food here is mediocre . It is a bit on the pricey side and portions are reasonable. They do offer alternative meats like alligator, frog,rabbit and venison.   Extra star for having sticky rice on the menu . We asked for a sample of sauvigon blanc from their wine selection and it didn't taste to well, so we passed on the wine. Overall this place has a great decor and ambiance with plenty of tvs and top 40 pop music to keep the customers entertained.
author: Brian L.

description:
Lers Ros Thai is my favorite thai I've tried in San Francisco. It's hard for me to choose thai in Little Vietnam since I love pho so much but Lers Ros is worth it! Everything I've tried has been amazing. I particularly loved the veggie tom yum soup and now get this every time. 

The menu has some crazy items too - alligator, frogs legs, etc. It's a very thorough menu with so many great choices!

They have great Barberra wine by the bottle for about $30 too. 

The wait staff is funny - their english is not great but they are very smiley and they try to clear your plates as quickly as possible. Watch out or your plates might disappear while you're still working on a dish!
author: Meghan P.

description: Awesome. Great meal! Came here on a Friday night after a few drinks and was very impressed by the food. Very authentic Thai restaurant. A few wines and beers to choose from, but the main event here is definitely the food. We shared a bunch of dishes: fried tofu, chicken skewers, Papaya salad, chicken pad thai, chicken thai basil and 2 types of  pork spear ribs. I have to say that everything was delicious and very flavorful and I'd love to come back! You can easily walk by the place and not think much of it, but looks can be deceiving and I'm telling you to go in and give it a shot.
author: Nicole S.

description:
This is among the best thai food I've ever had - the only other place that compares is Sri Praphai in New York.  

The restaurant is not located in the greatest area so we tend to do takeout.  Word of warning - delivery is typically one hour plus regardless of day/time.  The food is worth it though.  Dishes I like include the green papaya salad, green curry, red curry, pork larb, tom yum pak soup, pad broccoli, and the pad kee mow.  However, I'm sure pretty much everything else is great too - this is just what I've tried so far.  Also, the portions tend to be on the larger size. 

The restaurant itself is nice and the service is standard.
author: Andrea L.

description:
Satisfaction...

That is what you get when you dine at Lers Ros.  Atmosphere is great, food is mouthwatering, selection is spot on, service is fantastic, prices are good, and overall experience is 5 stars.

make sure you try the pork belly.

when you're heading out the door, make sure you grab a couple guava candies on your way out, eat only one in a sitting (or else you'll get tired of the flavor).

only bad thing about this place is that it is located near the sketchy part of town and parking could be a little hard to find.  oh and there will be a wait if you don't get there by ~6:15PM
author: Mike L.

description:
What a gem!

Nice upgrade from those Osha chains around the city that are becoming Thai fast food restaurants.

Food is tasty and unique - you're not stuck with a menu with only yellow chicken curry, pad thai and pad see ew.

ORDER THESE DISHES:
-pork belly
-duck larb
author: Melody T.

description:
Grabbed lunch here last week after hearing all the rave reviews from my boss ever since our office moved to San Francisco.

We took a Lyft from the FiDi (about an 8min drive or so) and got there around 11am on a Thursday. It was empty--we were probably the first or second group there. It def filled up around noon, so if you want to beat the crowd, head there early.

We ordered the duck larb, prawns asparagus, and green curry with beef.

At first we ordered the pork belly stir fry since the server said it was his favorite. We waited for our food for a while, but 5 or 10 minutes later, the server came back and said something about not being able to do the pork belly. Not exactly sure why. But we got the larb instead.

The duck larb turned out to be my favorite dish. It was super flavorful with lots of depth and spice to it. Not like any other larb I've had before. I'd go back here just for some of that stuff.

The other dishes were good too. Green curry (always one of my favorites at any thai place) was delicious and flavorful. The prawns asparagus was all right but didn't really live up to the hype that I heard about it. Or it was just overshadowed by the larb and the curry.

For two people and 3 dishes, it came out to about $46. Pretty pricey, but you do get quality food. For my regular thai cravings, there are definitely places just as good for cheaper. It's still worth a try and would be nice for more special occasions. Careful though, cause the area did seem a little sketchy.
author: Evelyn S.

description:
Don't even know where to start... obsessed.

- red curry 
- pad see ew
- coconut soup
- pad thai

its all amazing.  and they deliver! love this place, they never let me down.

Fun atmosphere inside too. communal feel
author: Andrea Y.

description:
Venue: very loud so if you're coming with friends to catch up you may have to scream to hear each other. Try and get seats against the wall because if you sit in the middle of the restaurant you may get kneed in the back due to the tiny aisle way and heavy flow of foot traffic between the kitchen and restrooms located upstairs. 

Food: Delish, well prieced, and many vegetarian options!
author: Josie C.

description: Found them on Yelp during our San Francisco vacation and they were absolutely outstanding!  Next time we're in town we have to go back!  Especially loved their appetizers!
author: Mike W.

description: Best Thai food in town. Bold and spicy flavors in all dishes. Lots of game and exotic meats - from frogs to alligators. Fast and quick service too- don't know how they serve such amazing food so fast!
author: Fahmid K.

description:
These are my two absolutely FAVORITES on their menu.  I wasn't sure if I was being overly generous with the 5 stars but after going to 2 different Thai places in the last month and attempting to order the same dishes, this place is the best if you're craving  these: 

1.  Tom Kha Kai  - Coconut milk based soup with Chicken , lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves Choice of Tom Kha with Prawn -  the soup is rich and flavorful.  every sip is a blast full of lemons, coconut, mushroom and chicken flavor.  i am SO addicted.  it comes out hot and it makes your belly warm and comforted.  it's got a little kick to it too so don't think you can order it when you're feeling sick because it will probably make u feel worse.  it's slightly spicy, but very subtle so you get the full effect of flavor in every spoon.

2. Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob  - Stir-fried pork belly with crispy rind and Basil leaves - CRUNCHY AND DELIGHTFUL!  wowowowowow.  it's pretty difficult to make pork belly that is juicy but has the full crunch to it and they definitely do the job.  i am such a fan!  the other two places we went the meat was either dry or the skin soggy but they manager to do both.  it's got the right amount of salty and i cant' seem to get enough.  again, it's got a little spicy kick to it too so it gives it an extra yummyness.  basil leaves + pork belly = a winner as well with it's full flavor and brings out more of the fatty taste.

I WANT TO GO RIGHT NOW!
author: Sandy L.

description: Delicious authentic Thai food. Very friendly staff and casual atmosphere. The Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (No. 62) and Kao Pad Moo (No. 54) are exceptionally tasty. The whole fried tilapia (No. 114) looks as impressive as it tastes.
author: Wei X.

description:
Yey. I love dis Thai joint. 

Everything is super tasty. Order everything. 
The service is really nice and polite too. 

Get anything here. Seriously. You will not be disappointed. 

I vaguely remember that lers ros and a few other thai restaurants help out in thei cultural communities. I am down with that. 

Big thanks to my old boss for reccing this place :)
author: Margaret S.

description: Rd curry with brown rice and pad thai.  They deliver!
author: Hanah L.

description:
Stopped in for an early lunch with no reservation and there was no wait. Definitely a Thai restaurant with a more exotic menu than the norm. 

The duck larb was a solid choice with an interesting blend of spices and lime. The pork belly special proved a bit greasy but was good nonetheless. 

My friend vetoed the frog legs but was a fan of the oh so infamous durian with sticky rice.
author: Leo H.

description:
I ate here on a Saturday night around 8pm, and the place looked so busy from the outside I had to get out of the car to put my name down while my boyfriend drove around trying to find parking. The wait for a table was between 20-30 minutes, and it took that long for him to find a spot (which ended up being across the street lol). I really liked the interior of the restaurant, however I took off one star because the tables are so close together I could hear the people next to us, and the stools they have to sit on became uncomfortable throughout dinner. The restaurant chatter was fairly loud as well.

We ordered the tom yum soup, the pieces of duck over rice, and a beef dish with bell peppers, bamboo shoot and basil leaves. The soup was delicious and had the perfect amount of spice to it. I loved the duck rice plate, and the beef dish was good as well but I wasn't able to have too much of it because I was starting to get full. Our waitress warned us that the beef dish was spicy and it couldn't be prepared mild, so we were a little hesitant to order it. But yolo, we got it anyway and it wasn't extremely spicy at all. Thanks to the waitress for mentally preparing us.

Overall, I enjoyed this restaurant a lot and I'd probably come here again if I was craving Thai.
author: Sabrina P.

description: Not as authentic as other hole in the wall Thai restos but food is also very good. A bit pricey but i believe its because you are paying for the ambiance. Good music, solid venue they even host private events! Ideal for a date or when you want to take guests from out of town. Otherwise, I would stick with the hole in the wall.
author: Miguel Y.

description:
Yummmmmmmmmmm  

Ps the service is hit or miss. Not for out of town new money spoiled privileged bratts!
author: Fredo L.

description: The food is pretty good. I like the frog legs a lot! The Tom yum soup they serve is in a hotpot, which makes the soup always hot during the meal. I really enjoy this in such  cold weather. Not a big fan of the rabbit dish though.
author: Sishi L.

description:
I really thought that LRT was going to knock out THE (Thai House Express) as king of late night Thai food dining, when they first opened last year. THE was open until 1am, while LRT decided to stay open until 2am. LRT has an extensive menu and many unique items, plus the place is new so decor is nicer & cleaner inside. But in the end THE steady cooking consistency prevailed.

Please note that they both have since revised their hours, to close at midnight.

When I first dined here some time ago I would have given LRT 5 stars, but after months of late night (after 10pm) dining I have to say that the late night kitchen crew just doesn't measure up. THE's late night kitchen cooks are more experienced, so food consistency is way better than LRT. Some of the irregularities I found were that:

1 - the chicken meat on curry dishes was a little dry. Meat cooked in coconut milk should not be dry, unless it was precooked and combined later - I think that the night kitchen crew precooked the meats to save time. Chicken green curry (#36) dish http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/QUFC-saM20oGdnrF3SdcoA/l

2 - so far, the night cooks just don't know how to do stir-fry noodles right. I ordered a few stir-fried flat noodle dishes during several days, and they always came out clumped, even the soupy Rad Na (#79) dish had clumped flat noodles. Worst version of a Pad see ew (#77) dish I've ever had - edible, but with mushed and clumped flat noodles. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/fRgMUz-N4rsJkXxJkJWHow/l

But don't get me wrong, I still consider this restaurant a favorite (2nd best Thai place, behind THE). Friendly and pleasant service, in addition to an extensive menu (can be overwhelming) that includes many unique dishes not found elsewhere, plus items like rabbit, frog, venison, alligator, etc. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/FxSPi6lVEOshX1Iv5kEM4w/l

My favorite appetizer is the pork shoulder (#9), although the sauce can be a little gritty. And it takes some time to make, so it often arrives after the entrees. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/uNFrKF-275yaP41J-EWTmw/l I don't mind since it's that good (when done right). http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/cLgDmm4yHFR0hdqRfrmA2Q/l

Among the starters, the chicken satay (#2) is very tender and tasty, http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/cpHZUcLskWsr4kmCPTDu3w/l and the Thai curry puff (#1C) is also good, similar to a samosa. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/F1ZZoFTKm7eYSYEdSJtArQ/l The herb sausage (#4) has good flavor and was not greasy. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/4bgvTr-ivtpAquSyXw6T8A/l

One of my favorite entrees is pork belly with crispy rind (#62), http://media4.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/RmiiK5RI77VG5rRQVAQyGQ/l meaty cubes of pork w/crispy skin, http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/kD8usyczXVVKMYISwPwJXA/l delicious! http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/akFi_TN0pK2Bqd2uKgR89Q/l

Most customers order the rice plates (#52-65). Pad kee mow (#76), noodles and bean sprouts, http://media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/o6ckrAceCa-TlW2nr5baEg/l is another standard dish that's good when done right.

Among the specials, garlic & pepper rabbit was deep fried too long (dry), and has a lot of small bones. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/_sTtaR2lxO3MxJTkh6-h8Q/l And Pad ped pla lai (eel with peppercorns and spicy chili) is somewhat difficult to eat because the eel has not been deboned, but sliced cross section. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/XSTF1PNp7Y29Z7WepcNFkw/l

Venison pad prik thai had the potential to be a winning dish, but it contained too many whole black peppercorns that had no flavor or spice (maybe too old, or not stored properly). http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/q2IxIN9bVN8oWs6j4wx26Q/l

The deep fried trout special was well made, crispy and tender. It's deboned, so you could eat everything including the crispy small bones at the edge. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/tS6fh5RIQlBeRtdq8Ix1uQ/l

Similar to THE, the restrooms are upstairs but u don't need a key.
author: Luis C.

description: I was very happy with the "Koh Moo Yang" and "Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob". The staff was friendly and the ambiance was great. The food was quick, fresh, and delicious. This is excellent Thai food and I will definitely be back!
author: Mike W.

description:
The first couple of times I came to Lers Ros, I really liked the food, but I can't say I was amazed though.  Everything was pretty decent, but there was always something that either held the food back, or wasn't enough to get them over the hump to "awesome".  That is, until my friends and I dropped in for dinner last week.  Maybe it's because we did a better job of ordering this time around, but I was pretty impressed.  I guess what they say is true - the third time really is the charm!

Compared to my first couple of trips, people have definitely found out about Lers Ros.  While the wait for a table wasn't terrible, the place was still pretty darn crowded!  After we got settled at our table in the back, we put in our orders: 

- Koh Moo Yang (Grilled Pork Shoulder appetizer with Chili Sauce) - one of my favorite Thai dishes anywhere (Chan Pad Poo at Marnee Thai being another).  I've had it every time I've been to Lers Ros and it has never failed me.  Tender and perfectly seasoned, the spicy chili sauce isn't necessary, but adds that much more flavor.  Freaking delicious!

- Kang Keaw Wan (Green Curry with Thai Eggplant, Red Bell Peppers, Kaffir Lime Leaves and Chicken) - maybe it's because of the coconut milk base, but I loved the the richness of the curry.  It's got a little heat to it, but in a good way...one of my favorite Thai curries.

- Pad Krapow - (Ground Pork stir-fried with Basil and house special sauce) - really savory and oh so delicious.  Their house sauce is really what makes the dish, and whatever they put in there is definitely special.

- Rad Nah (Marinated Pork with House Secret Gravy on Flat Noodles) - a little different than I had expected (didn't expect there to be THAT much sauce), but still liked it regardless.  A little heavy on the white pepper, but I was okay with it.

In addition, we also ordered a couple of vegetarian dishes, but I held off from trying them to make sure our friend had enough to eat.  From what I could see though, both looked pretty tasty (one was stir fried eggplant, the other Pad Kee Mao?).

If it weren't for the neighborhood (on the edge of the Tenderloin), I would probably come here all the time if I could.  Even though there are plenty of good alternatives in SF, I haven't found a place that can match both the authenticity of their food and the quality of the dishes.  Now, I just have to wait until their Hayes Valley location opens up!
author: Mike L.

description:
SS was craving Thai... I was a little worried about places being packed over Memorial Day weekend, so we ended up with reservations at this location.

AMBIANCE: The interior is clean and pretty modern looking.  I wasn't a huge fan of the stools used for seats, but its a minor quibble.  The area is not the nicest, but you wouldn't be able to tell at all from inside.

SERVICE: Friendly, but required prompting to refill water glasses.

FOOD:
- Yellow curry with chicken: A bit watery.  We were informed this was "mild" (we had someone in our group who cannot handle spice), but I thought it was fairly hot for that label. 
- Pad kee mow: Yum!  A bit greasy, but still good.  Hard to go wrong with this dish.  Wish it were spicier.
- Pad thai: One of the better renditions of pad thai I've had recently.  I'd come back for this.
- Stir fried beef & broccoli: Meh.  Standard.  The beef was on the tough side.

OVERALL: Food was good.  SS & DM raved about how delicious it was.  I thought it was better than the average Thai place, with the standouts being the noodle dishes.  I'd like to come back and try some of the other curries (which we didn't order for fear of being too spicy for DM).
author: Susanna W.

description: Watched a NFL playoff game here and had some good thai food. Had the pad thai, nothing special. Also had a sake bomb, which was delicious. The waitress was skeptical on giving our group sake bombs, but she gave in.
author: Arsalan H.

description:
I wanted to like it more, but I can't.

Location: kinda shifty as it's in the TL.. one star off for that.
Food: was not AMAZING. i only come to the TL when the food is worth risking my life for, nahmean?

Yellow curry: potato was not cooked all the way thru. BIG no-no! Same for the carrots.
Pork belly: blehh I didn't like it. reminds me of the chinese roast pig so it wasn't that special to me.
Papaya salad: decent.. I don't remember it that much.
author: Emily C.

description:
I'd passed the beautiful interiors and long lines and wanted to give it a try.

My hopes were high upon receiving the curry puff appetizers - crisp, flavorful, reminiscent of Taiwanese curry pastries but with a nice peanut sauce.

After that, it was downhill. We got the simpler dishes since we weren't in a fancy mood - a Pad See Yew and a Crispy Chicken over Fried Rice. Both were really greasy and didn't actually taste that different despite their supposedly very different components. The chicken had a surprising amount of gristle and was just battered and a little soggy. The noodles in the Pad See Yew were really overly soft - no firm al dente bite. 

I was going to give this 3 stars, but now that I'm feeling sort of sick from all the grease, I gave it 2 (especially given the inexplicable spate of 5-star reviews). Granted, we didn't get their signature exotic meats like alligator, but honestly, I can't imagine it being very good if they can't get the basic proteins right.

It bums me out that it's so popular since there is actualy a really awesome Thai place literally half-a-block down called Krua Thai - much much better food.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Lers Ros is the place I recommend to out of towners when they ask for the best SF restaurants. It's fantastic -- I order via Try Caviar from them all the time, but going in person is really the best approach.
author: David V.

description: I just had one of the worst delivery issues ever. I was told that there would be an hour and a half wait... Which considering the deliciousness of the food I was willing to wait. Three hours later, still no show. Unbelievable!! So unhappy
author: Megan R.

description:
Caveat: I'm a longtime vegetarian and a longtime Thai snob. This review is a bit of a split between the one or two stars I would give it for my own food and the much higher rating I expect I would give as a carnivore. 

The vegetarian options are, at best, lazy. The selections are relatively minimal and not especially interesting. They also did the thing that drives me nuts where they a) throw the same kitchen sink of vegetables into every vegetarian dish regardless of whether the specific vegetables belong in the dish and b) don't make any effort to prepare their tofu. The Thai food I cook at home is better and I don't think I'll be coming back again.

That said, the menu clearly emphasizes meat and those dishes look much more interesting and well prepared. While I obviously do not recommend this spot to fellow vegetarians, the meat dishes appeared to be four or five-star worthy to me (and, no, I am not secretly hankering for meat).
author: Jesse W.

description:
My G/F and I can both cook Thai food fairly decent - so, if we go out to eat Thai we normally eat things that are too complicated to cook at home.
THIS is the place we love most. Been here several times, and in spite of the San Franciscan pricing on the menu, we've never had a complaint. Anything containing duck, the som tom, stir-fry, and even the frogs legs are all excellent, and we WILL return!
author: James M.

description:
Awesome food!  I couldn't stop eating my Prawns and rice dish!  My kids had the Pad Se Ew and really enjoyed it.

The staff were very nice, professional and accommodating to our family.  Spilled water from kids jumping around, the staff cleaned it up without hesitation and offered a new cloth napkin.
author: Paula M.

description: Went to dinner with some family friends, and overall it was a really great place!  We got there without a reservation not realizing how popular the place was, but we were seated in about 15 minutes and the staff at the bar was very nice in the wait time.  I got the pad thai with chicken, which was everything I hoped it would be.  My boyfriend originally ordered a meal with catfish, not realizing that the fish had not been deboned.  We felt bad but after taking a few bites and having small bones poke into his cheek, he asked if they could replace it with red curry instead.  The staff was incredibly nice about it, and he was extremely pleased with the curry.  The staff were very attentive, and overall we had a great night out!
author: Kristen T.

description:
Best thai food I ever had! The shrimp was cooked perfectly and they are not shy about how many they give you =)

I also had to try their duck and I could separate it with my spoon! Sooo good! I think I actually came here two days in a row.
author: Sophia G.

description:
Yes again, I found this place in Yelp and took some food recommendations from yelpers! Yay!

Service: our server was rather pushy. She was extremely eager to take my plate away every few minutes, even though I was done yet. She was very soft spoken and I just wish she spoke a little louder, hence, the place was filled with people and loud on a Friday night.

FOOD: so, decent on the food, but nothing so surprising.

1. Chicken coconut soup: 4 stars. More sour than usual compare to other thai place.
2. Papaya salad with grilled shrimp: 5 stars. Very good. Sour and spicy. Just wish they had added more grilled shrimp... yum.
3. Pork belly dish: 5 stars. Little chunks of crispy pork skin soaked in their spicy basil sauce. Now, you can't go wrong. 

DRINKS: we ordered beer and I wasn't too impress by the small glass they put it in - less alcohol. Sigh. 3 stars.

**OVERALL: if you like spicy and sour, try this place! 4 stars.
author: Mindy Y.

description: It just took 2:45 hours to deliver after they promised 1:30 hours. And they got the order wrong. Never again!!!!!!
author: Tim F.

description:
This place is nice. I would give 4.5 stars!

We went there around 4 PM on a Tuesday. We ordered Chicken Noodle Soup, Pad Thai and Green curry with seafood.

The Chicken Noodle soup was exceptionally good, so was the green curry!!

However, the only thing that I would dock half a star for would be for the shrimp. It was not de-veined. 

Other than that, no complaints, the waitstaff was fantastic and so was the food. I would definitely recommend!
author: Rupayan H.

description:
This is a great spot for a food adventure. 

Nestled in the Tenderloin's asian corridor, across the street from all sorts of Vietnamese sandwich, pho restaurants, hostels, and Asian massage parlors lies Lers Ros Thai. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WFgRFq_KxIs2fkYo1iD6Tg?select=1qgr7hU12rIfzk6JdlcAVA)

I brought my boy Calvin here to catch up since he just got back from the Dominican Rep. He wanted to eat something different and this was the perfect place. Thanks to good Yelp friend Daniel L for this authentic Thai suggestion. 

Here you'll find some of the tenderest loins the TL has to offer and I don't mean massage parlors. I do mean tender "boar" loin from the #105, Pad Ped Moo Pah - Boar stir fried Thai Style. Well, I'm not sure if it is exactly from the loin but the boar meat was chopped in bite sized pieces stir fried with Thai chillies and galingale - which is a type of Asian ginger. (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/iJvptQhbk_-xTrsX8VlmJQ/l) Not too spicy but the flavors, like most said are purely Thai and unique.  

Also ordered the 5 spice duck over rice with chili sauce.(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WFgRFq_KxIs2fkYo1iD6Tg?select=X4qPyfrrFZeg5Islc8-Zbw) Delicious. the duck was fatty. I really liked my roasted pork leg It was super tender and juicy. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/WFgRFq_KxIs2fkYo1iD6Tg?select=DEMhdRuxpdSGgW65WWWqww)

I really like the flavors and I'll definitely be back to explore the rest of their overwhelming for a first timer menu.

This is a good spot to take a date, because if you can take her here for dinner in the TL and she's still wants to be with you, then she's a keeper.
author: Earl G.

description:
Very good

Papaya salad, tom yum, prik khing
author: Arjun K.

description:
We chose this place based on the various online eating-in-SF lists and they lived up to those reviews. FYI - We are vegetarians.

Excellent food - Tom yum soup, green veggie curry and fried banana with vanilla ice cream ... Yum yum yum!!

Even more excellent service - we almost felt we had one person dedicated to serving us :)

Ambience is decent but not bad. 

Overall would have given 5 stars but dinged one star due to the strong (and uncomfortable) smell from adjoining tables ( We are vegetarians ).
author: Rohan B.

description:
Duck larb, delicious. Pad thai, ok. Tom Kha Kai, very good.

Good food, nice people, great location. :)
author: Jeanette L.

description: I have yet to find a place in this part of town that is better than Lers Ros. The classic curries are delicious with just right amount of Thai spice and flavor. The pad see ew and pad kee mow are fantastic noodle dishes. Tons of great appetizers and more traditional dishes that look super amazing.
author: Derek S.

description:
3 Friday's in a row....and still loving this place.
Little loud but worth it.  Line out the door. Best Thai food out there....
Never disapointed....
XO
S
author: Scott T.

description: The food is the best Thai in all of San francisco but only for this location only not the other sister restaurants in the city.
author: N A.

description:
Have had the pleasure of dining at Les Ros multiple times since moving to the neighborhood and not once have I been disappointed (they also do delivery until midnight if you live in the area)! Fresh herbs and spices accompanied by perfectly prepared proteins seems to be the theme here; they definitely pack on the flavor and are not shy with their use of spices. The duck larb, sun-dried beef, catfish salad and Yum Woon Sen salad are a few of my favorites and I always get one of these items each time I go.  

Being adventurous pays off in a big way at Les Ros. Don't shy away from exotic ingredients or modify dishes -- their plates are very well balanced as they come. Two things to keep in mind: many of their fish, frog and quail dishes come bone-in which can be difficult to eat around though worth the challenge. They do have many of these dishes available de-boned if you prefer. Also, I am not kidding about the spice factor, I love spicy food and can't order anything above medium spice. 

 Oh, one last thing, ALWAYS get the sticky rice!
author: Elisa P.

description: This used to my husband's fav Thai in town. Brought family of six here last night, very disappointed! Fry banana was raw! Tom yam and Tom kai soup were extremely sour, even for someone who enjoys sour flavor. Chef must put a lemon tree in there! Sticky rice was very dry. The frog legs have almost no meat at all, even for Chinese who enjoys bones. The top tenderloin beef with garlic is not tender and soaked in soy sauce. The one star is for the service. Oh, the best part, we all got diarrhea next morning!
author: Lucy L.

description: Only two out of five of my duck stew were eatable.  Three of them were pure fat.  The kitchen doesn't care if customer eats their food or not. l asked the waitress to change the pure fat meets, she refused.  I give two stars for the two duck stews I ate.
author: Maggie L.

description:
been here once, might come back when I get a chance.

service: the main reason for the low star. The servers were all unhappy on that day, I did not know what happened, but all of them were grumpy.

environment: four star.

noise level: normal.

food: 3 stars on most of the dishes.

price: $$ a bit pricey.

proportion: okay.
author: Zack Y.

description: The duck larb is the best entree here! This place delivers so if you want to avoid dine-in, it's perfect. They also have a lunch special for $8.95 where you get to try two different mini-sized entrees (rice bowl size). Though, watch out because the food can be somewhat spicy. For a safe and tasty bet, get the duck larb!
author: Brandon P.

description:
As noted by every other reviewer--it's a busy place. But they take reservations, which just means this may not be a great impulse/drop in dinner spot. Although I think it may actually be worth the wait! 

Split a few dishes--one of which, a special fried rice w/ pickled egg--was particularly delicious. Really one of the better Thai places we've tried. Not the most romantic restaurant on the planet; they really pack everyone in at the shared tables! But the food is standout. So if you think romance is enhanced by some delicious Thai food and strangers, this is your place.
author: Saskia S.

description:
This review is so overdue. I come here ALL the time. Even the leftovers are something I get excited about eating when I'm like "Hmmm, what should I eat tonight...OH yeah! I still have food from Lers Ros! *happy dance*" 
I love this place.

So flavorful and picante. I ask to make it extra spicy though hehe ;)
author: Cha C.

description:
One of my favorite Thai restaurants ~ modern . comfortable . clean . friendly & efficient service .

I really enjoyed the Pad Makuer Tofu (eggplant, tofu, bell peppers, chili garlic sauce and basil) and the Pad Kee Mau (pan-fried noodles, onion, bell peppers bean sprouts, basil - choice of chicken, pork, seafood, or vegetarian). They have an extensive menu, viewable online ~ it all looks so good! http://lersros.com/menu.html

It's on the edge of the Tenderloin and the sign (when I went during the day) was a bit difficult to see. It helped that I had the address on me ~ 730 Larkin, between O'Farrell & Ellis. It has an awning and the entrance is between two large potted plants. 

PS: It's walking distance from the AMC 1000 Van Ness movie theater. Hint hint.
author: Cathy K.

description: Good food. Ordered papaya salad, tom yum soup with pork and rice noodles, and pad thai. Everything was good. Medium spicy is spicy, but delcious. I love spicy so it wasn't super spicy for me. The waitresses were nice. One lady needs to smile a little bit more though because she didn't really look like she enjoyed working there. It starts to get busy around noon so gotta be sure to come in before then. They have a mini bar for people who wants to sit and have a drink during lunch or something.
author: Lina D.

description:
FAST, CLEAN, and just a spot on Thai restaurant. 
Might I say, Thai food is one of my favorites of all time. Been to many, and fell in love with many, but this place gotta be my all time hands down favorite thai place ever! My family and I come here whenever we're craving Thai foood.

Their Thai fried rice is BOMB. It's light, but very flavorful. Just a perfect rice plate that compliments any meat or vegetable entree. We like the shrimp one btw! Super good and they put a generous amount of shrimp!

Thumbs up for their Pad thai, hands down has to be one of the best pad thai's ever. Normally, I don't really like Pad Thai because the sugar and starchiness from the noodles, creates a brainy texture of the noodles and it's just not my style, BUT Ler ros somehow perfectly creates their dish. ALL their meat dishes are going to be really good, so don't even trip about trying something new, it will always be SUPER good. Trust.

One of my favorite aspects of the restaurant is that they have crushed peanuts in one of their sauce containers! So I always OD and pour that shiet all over my Pad Thai :)
author: Joyce L.

description:
Before Lers Ros Thai, I thought that all Thai restaurants tasted the same. Oh how wrong I was. One sign that I was entering an authentic joint - other than the taste of the food - was the fact that when we asked for our food to be at the level of spicy, they delivered. I wished they had milk on the menu to help with the spice level so that we could continue to eat more!

I've been here multiple times and haven't had a bad meal. If you're adventurous, try items on the chef's specials. I highly recommend the whole fried tilapia. $16 for a large whole fish fried to perfection and topped with sauce made me wish my appetite was larger. 

Don't let the neighborhood scare you away. The best food places tend to be in the seedier areas. I haven't had much difficulty finding parking but beware every spot is metered. The place fills up quickly so don't expect to walk in at 7 pm and immediately get a table. We barely made it at 6 pm without a wait and by 6:30 pm, people were crammed at the door waiting for a table.
author: Gwen L.

description:
Yelpers - please pay attention to the health score.  

It's 71 !!!! 

Here's what that means (these are all their violations - right off the Health Department's website):

 
Inadequate washing facilities or equipment Low Risk              30-JUN-15
Foods not protected from contamination         Moderate Risk      30-JUN-15
Improper thawing methods                          Moderate Risk      30-JUN-15
Inadequate and inaccessible handwashing facilities Moderate Risk       30-JUN-15
Unclean or unsanitary food contact surfaces HIGH RISK      24-JUN-15
Unclean or degraded floors walls or ceilings Low Risk              30-JUN-15
Improper storage of equipment utensils or linens Low Risk      30-JUN-15
Wiping cloths not clean or properly stored or inadequate sanitizer Low Risk 30-JUN-15

If you want to see the details of a health score, go to the site for the San Francisco Department of Health and search for Restaurant Safety Scores.  You can enter the restaurant's name and see the score and report.

Fortunately, the scores are much much better at the Lers Ros on Hayes and on 16th.  Go to those instead until this place cleans up its act!!!!
author: R. P.

description:
So far I have been here twice and would consider this place is pretty good.  Would give it a 3.5 star if given the option.
1.  Pork Shoulder:  Was cooked well.  The meat was still moist with decent flavor.  I would say worth trying.
2.  Garlic Pepper Rabbit:  First time eating rabbit, so did not know what to expect.  It was not my favorite dish.  The meat slightly gamey but I am ok with that.
3.  Fresh Raw Prawns with chili, lime, and lemon grass:  This was good, but pretty spicy. I usually can handle the heat but wow one shrimp with several diced up piece of chili had my mouth burning.
4.  Garlic and ginger rice:  The rice was ok, just a hint of garlic and ginger flavor.
5.  Durian Sticky rice:  I have always loved durian.  This was pretty good, the durian was ripe but not stinky for those who can handle the smell.  Worth a shot for people who want to get an idea what durian tastes like but cant handle the smell.
author: Richard M.

description:
Love the rice soup and black preserved egg salad. Grilled pork shoulder also to die for!!
This is one of those super authentic places that Thai people love going to to get those dishes you can't find anywhere else. And they're open late and deliver in the evenings!
author: Nicha K.

description: This review is only about takeout. Just received my takeout order and am extremely disappointed in the serving size. For $10 for Pad Makuer Tofu, this is about a third of the size of food you can get from any other good thai place in SF. Description says "Stir-fried eggplant, tofu, green bell peppers, with garlic chili sauce and basil. There were literally 5 pieces of tofu, 2 tiny basil leafs and not one bell pepper to be found. The flavor was really great so its too bad I'm left starving after ordering. I can't comment on the dine-in experience but my suggestion to everyone would be get take out from any other good thai place in the city.
author: Mon M.

description:
Very clean and nice looking restaurant considering the location. By 7:30 line is out of the door on a Monday night, so come early. 

Loved the pork shoulder - fatty meaty goodness!
author: Ashley Z.

description:
Whoa!  How did Thai food this good end up this deep in the Tenderloin!

I live just uphill from Lers Ros, and I'd heard about how fantastic it was, but I already had a handful of go to Thai places.  However, we decided to try something new, and yeah, Lers Ros is something special.

I can't speak for any of its authenticity, or the food's origin of inspiration, but the flavors are so complex each bite was amazing.

We started with the Garlic Frog, now I'd never had frog before, and yeah, it tastes like chicken.  But the seasoning on it was delicious.

I then had the Pad Phed with Prawns, so good and eye opening.

I'll be back, and will continue my report....
author: Jonathan B.

description:
"Ay, why 'ont'chu give my homeboy his change." Well, this IS the Tenderloin, so I suppose it wouldn't be too far removed if I got all Menace II Society at the end of the meal. Or maybe I should switch it from the inner city to the bayou, seeing as this restaurant features rabbit, alligator, and frog.

Among other dishes, we got the frog and alligator. They were both pleasing, but the alligator couldn't be tasted through the spiciness, which we happened to have requested. At least we know this place will give you food that's verifiably spicy if you ask for it.

Something I found interesting was the setup of the staff. When we walked in, 4 or 5 servers were standing in one spot toward the back. Every once in a while, one or more of them would walk to another area, pause for some length of time, then repeat. They resembled non-playable characters in video games. Speaking of games, can the servers instead drive go-karts around the tables and throw turtle shells at each other? I'd pay extra to see that.

We incidentally paid extra anyway, for it wasn't till after getting home that we realized our servers never brought us change from the bill. We should've paid some attention along with that extra cash. I believe most or all of the overflow was indeed intended as tip, but still. Sometimes I like going through the motions of paying, getting $ back, then leaving some on the table.

Either way, they didn't ask us. So maybe they're the ones who got gangsta. After all, their uniform was red shirts. I'm kidding. I hope.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Shirts_(Thailand)
author: Dan B.

description:
Garlic & Pepper Wabbit, Garlic & Ginger Fried Rice... Koong Chu-Chee (raw Prawns in lemon juice, garlic, ginger n Chilis)

Great food as long as you can overlook the long wait and slow service.
author: Madhusudhan R.

description:
Its really hard to get good thai food in SF.  Who would have thought? Finally my quest for the best pad thai and pad see ew has ended.  Lers Ros made all my wildest noodle dreams come true.  

Other good dishes are the pork salad & duck noodle soup.  Looking forward to going back here and trying moarrrrrr.
author: Nho C.

description:
Whatever you do order the Crystal Chestnut dessert. It always runs out! Come early if you can because it gets crowded. If you can't come early don't worry, Ler Ros Thai is worth the wait. 

I love Lers Ros Thai so much that I make the trek from Civic Center Bart through the tenderloin just to get here. This restaurant was recommended to me by a woman from Thailand who let me know that the food is pretty authentic. 

Food here comes out hot and spicy. I highly recommend the fishcakes, Larb Moo/ Larb Kai, Tom Kha Kai and Pla Kra Pong Nuang Manow. The fishcakes are homemade. I personally enjoy Larb Moo/Larb Kai more than papaya salad although both are good. The Tom Kha Kai is really delicious because the soup is a nice consistency and the mushrooms are especially good. The fish is really fresh, which is why Pla Kra Pong Nuang Manow is a winner.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I absolutely loved this place. L-O-V-E! 

I will not lie to you. The wait was difficult. I remember it felt like forever. Then again, this place was crowded for a reason. At like 8 o'clock, it was still so busy! Thankfully, we weren't super hungry...

Maybe I knew it was love when I found candy in this huge pot during our wait. When I left, my friends and I took two hands-full worth of guava candy. And up to this day, all I want is their guava candy. OBSESSED. 

I was also obsessed with their pork belly. OHMYGAWD, that was bomb. The flavor of the sauce is addicting. Sweet and sour! But not too empowering. The pork belly itself was perfection. I especially loved the crispy (unhealthy) parts. Ugh, so good. You must get this. 

We also got the beef pad see ew, and okay...pad see ew is pretty good in other restaurants, but here? I still wanted more the next day. Something about it was just better than any others! Maybe it was the sauce? Idk! You should also get this as an entree. 

We also shared the papaya salad with prawns and tom yum soup. Papaya salad was spicy but refreshing. Both the soup and salad were yummy - would recommend both as well.

I hate to admit this, but we spent the whole day eating (went to the Eat Real beforehand). So even after all the various nomings, this definitely stood out. I want to come back so bad! 

:)
author: Stephanie B.

description: Dam good Thai food in authentic style. Get a reservation. This place is always so full.
author: Dheeraj M.

description:
Over 500 reviews and a 4 star rating.  There really isn't much I can add.

Thank you for the delicious multiple porkgasms in my mouth.  Swallowing is easy when you have something this succulent in your mouth.
author: Luis M.

description: Best Thai I've had in SF. Very tasty and really cool staff.
author: John S.

description:
Delicious food! Fast delivery. My husband said it was the best thai he ever had. I had a chicken curry soup. He had fried pork bits for an appetizer and duck curry for an entree. He loved it.
We went back a few days later to eat in the restaurant.  Waited about 30 minutes. Sat at the bar. I ordered the duck salad and he had the same duck curry. Both were delicious. Instead of eating it as a salad I used the lettuce to wrap pieces of duck in it and eat. So good!
author: Shanell P.

description:
Came here on a fluke, I'm not really a fan of Thai food but my cousin from out of town wanted it. Location sounded kind of sketchy since it's in the Tenderloin but after eating here, I will definitely be back! 
The food was fresh & tasty. The service was attentive & the ambience was nice. 
**The only reason I didn't give it a full 5 stars is because although we asked for mild spice  the first dish came out with ATOMIC burn your taste buds off HEAT!! The "mild" was over the top spicy so we had to tell the waitress to bring the rest of the dishes out with "no spice" which still had a little bit of a kick, which was fine. Even though the first dish was so spicy that we couldn't finish it, it still had great flavor! It's was the Green Papaya salad with grilled shrimp. We also ordered the Duck salad appetizer which was so yummy! The duck tasted like crispy pork and it's served with lettuce cups which I love! Next was the Pad Thai, good..then the Prawns on Garlic Sauce, tasty..then my FAVE the WHOLE SEA BASS, super FRESH and citrusy yummy! For dessert we wanted the Sticky Rice with Mango but they were out :( soo we got the Fried Bananas with Pistachio ice cream!!..it was the perfect way to end the meal. 

All in all the tastiest Thai Food I've had & now I'm a fan.
author: Luz T.

description:
The neighborhood is a little on the skeevy side, but the restaurant is not. A gem in the rough even. Great food and amicable service. We arrived on the early side, by the time we left the place was packed. Get a reservation if you able to.

We were a large party, I tried a variety of dishes. I think my favorite was the Chicken Tom Yum soup (if you like it spicy, eat the hot peppers). I'd definitely recommend Lers Ros Thai to anyone looking for a meal in SF.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Believe it or not, I had the best Thai food living in Florida. Since I moved to CA twelve years ago, I have not found anything remotely close to the places I used to go to! Then a few years ago I went to Thailand. It was even more difficult to find decent Thai food! 

Finally, after many years of searching, I found a place I can go to! I was craving Pad Thai, basic Thai food. I did a search, found this place, checked with a few colleagues and off I went. I called in a To Go order. I was impressed with their phone etiquette. They verified which location you wanted to pick up from, repeated the order, etc. I am not one to say much about the phone stuff, but this is worth a mention for sure.

When I arrived, I was immediately greeted by the bartender who promptly guided me to the back counter for pick up. The decor is simple- deep reds, wood furniture, varying levels and very clean. I will go back for a sit down for sure. Everyone was polite, wearing clean uniforms, and definitely not standing around! I was handled immediately!

I had chicken Pad Thai with medium spice. definitely not a complicated dish! It was amazing - lots of chicken, noodles, and sprouts, with egg and other stuff. The portion was generous. The dish was flavorful. Though I will caution, their medium spicy is probably more spicy than you might think. It was perfect for me and you could still taste all of the flavors without your mouth being on fire. You can tell it was made fresh too.

I will definitely be back!
author: Krysten L.

description: Great thai restaurant on Hayes St! I went during lunchtime around 12PM and got seated in 15-20 minutes. I recommend the Shrimp Pad Thai. Noodles were fresh and sauce was delicious. I also recommend the Tom Yum Koong. It's spicy, but a delicious soup. Service was good and attentive. Price was affordable for the meal.
author: Will T.

description: The best thing by far was the Thai ice tea !The food didn't live up to its description at all...spicy tofu was not spicy ! Wait staff kept trying to take away our plates before we were finished. Not an authentic Thai experience.
author: Renata R.

description: Came for a super late lunch/early dinner, and got our pick of seats. Don't think that's the normal status. Their famous duck larb was super flavorful, I can see why they're known for that. Lots of meat too. Their pad kee mao and curry were kinda just okay, sweeter than I'd like and nothing was nearly as spicy as hoped. Would love to try some of the more adventurous dishes and ooh a whole steamed fish when we have larger appetites (or more people)!
author: Vivian H.

description:
Great food. Come early and come often.

We came five minutes after they opened on a Saturday evening and there were a dozen waitresses lined up like solders. Since we were the only couple in this spot we thought it a little strange. Twenty minutes into our meal every seat was taken and all the help was moving like lightning. 

The food here is excellent and I only take off one star because the feel of the restaurant is that of a cafeteria with the plain design and florescent lighting. 

The menu is huge and every plate we saw come out of the kitchen looked amazing as was our meal. We are really looking forward to returning in the near future.
author: Justin S.

description:
Dear Lers Ros,

Do you feel happy for getting a free $18 for leftover rabbit bones and pieces? Thanks for checking over the phone that you have enough bones to fit a small take out dish. Thanks for taking advantage of delivery and for treating me as  I'm some distant out-of-sight consumer who won't ask for a refund? Well, you've lost a customer permanently who otherwise talks highly of restaurants he enjoys to his friends. I don't care if all your other food is potentially delicious, as your morals are in the trash. 

- Highly disappointed customer



::Pretty much I ordered delivery because I didn't want to spend $20 minimum for 2 portions of food for delivery. Since it was 11pm when I felt hungry, I ordered from Lers Ros as they deliver until midnight and had $15 minimum. Sadly, they just delivered a pile of bones. The rabbit meat was tough and even if it were a bigger portions, it wouldn't have been worth the price. 

All in all, poor morals on food (don't say you have it if all you are serving are bone scraps), and poor rabbit meat quality. 

AVOID IF YOU'RE DOING TAKE OUT.
author: Lars B.

description: Good, delicious, fresh and priced right. The service is sub-par and food came out 10 min apart. A little awkward to be sitting with someone while their food gets cold while they wait for your food to arrive.
author: Rebekah R.

description: Was told Lers Ros was the best Thai restaurant in SF and I agree! Flavorful and tasty food. Loved the fried rice! Will be back here every time I visit.
author: Kyle D.

description:
Absolutelyy delicious...met my expectations 100% (the food part of it)

Food was awesome...papaya salad, red curry, pad thai everything we ate!  

The only reason this place gets a 4 star is cause it was a bit too noisy and the tables were too small. We were a party of four and we literally had to try not to spill over things off our table.

Otherwise overall experience was AWESOME!

Going back there for sure!! :)
author: Supriya M.

description:
Solid Thai spot; a small enclave of cleanliness and decent refinement on a street of rough sidewalks and private-room massage parlors. It can get crowded but it's definitely a step above the numerous Thai places in the vicinity.

I try something new every time I go back, and each time I regret not getting what I had the first time, the Pad Thai.

You can gain a measure of the establishment by their treatment of the flagship dish of their culture's cuisine, and this Pad Thai is the best I've had so far in the city. The noodles are fresh and hold sauce superbly without congealing into a thick, sticky mess. The sauce is not overly sweetened, allowing the underlying layers of umami fish sauce and garlic/pepper spice bring balance to the dish. I appreciate a dish that lets the ingredients talk, rather than assault you with sugar and spice as a cop out. 

Bottom line, this is a solid spot. Portions are large and service is good too. The pickled jalapeños on the side are super tasty and not spicy, either. 

If you're curious about the prawn/garlic/mint "salad", first it's not a salad so much as butterflied raw prawns with mint leaves on top. Second, be prepared for almost a clove of raw sliced garlic on each prawn. It tasted like a mouthful of fiery raw garlic with some slimy mid-quality raw shrimp and not enough mint to cover up the terrible experience. To each his own.


Irrelevant to the food: The waitress tried to teach me how to pronounce "Lers Ros". It sounded nothing like how it was written on the wall (in IPA) and I still have no idea.
author: Eddie L.

description:
After spending all morning at the Ferry's Building Farmers Market and all after noon touring the new Exploratorium  at Pier 15, my partner and I decided to get in on an  an early Saturday night dinner, with a craving for Thai street food.   

The choice couldn't have been more solid.  And because the service was just too fine  and the dishes too flavorful, I just felt compelled to let the world know about it.   

Greeted at the front door by a smiley waitress, and was then offered a seat towards the quiet back area near the kitchen.   Specials of the day was fried cod (#16 on the menu; a must try!) with lime chilly dipping sauce with plain brown rice to pair.   A simple but complex in flavor meal for a rainy San Francisco night.
author: P T.

description:
Tom yum goong served up in a pretty firepot..... a spicy, deep-flavored soup that hit the spot on a coolish night...stunning!!

Attempted more specialty dishes such as wild boar, rabbit, etc.... the penang curry was very good too. Rabbit bit dry, and boar was in the spice realm that I couldn't even touch with a 10 foot pole. Tis shame. 

Of course, the staple: pad thai, as well as a yummy brasied duck dish. Some perfunctory greens order, and a satisfying meal for 6 had by all late in the night, after a MOMA viewing and some shopping at Westfield!
author: Jana C.

description:
TLDR:
- Sometimes strong flavors, sometimes flat flavors, and mostly too sweet.
- Big menu.
- Clean and modern.
author: Christopher L.

description: Omg this place is mind blowing! Unarguably the best Thai I have ever had in north America! Every dish we got is amazing and there are so many other interesting dishes on the menu we wanted to try... The price is very reasonable too.  Will come back!!!
author: Kathy Z.

description:
