A bit of a surprise to me.   Whatever you might imagine a place might look like in the tenderloin, Ler Ros is beautifully appointed, clean and welcoming.  And service was perfect.   My server asked whether I wanted everything at once or sequenced.  I asked for and received the latter.  Bravo Ler Ros.  

Larb salad with duck was lovely.  Crisp duck.  Some spiciness.  And beneath it all a blast of astringency provided by a lime based dressing.  

A whole fired trout may have been the slightest bit dry.  But the fish was crispy and could be consumed bones and all.

All in all a very nice, well-priced meal.
author: David D.

description:
I have to jump on the hipster bandwagon and say that this restaurant in a sketchy neighborhood really does serve fantastic food.

The nam prik was delicious!  The green curry was also very tasty, although a little on the spicy side. We had two orders of the much-hyped pork belly. Oddly, one of the orders was incredibly good, but the other had been cooked too much and the skin was more hard than crispy.

They don't seem to have air conditioning, and it was a hot day so it got somewhat uncomfortable, but the food was so good I'll be back. Besides, how many hot days are we going to have in SF?
author: Mara S.

description:
I know i've given a lot of 5 stars! But trust me, I wouldn't give 5 stars if I don't LOVE it!

If you consider yourself an adventurous eater, then you will love what I'm about to show you!
When people talk about thai food nowadays, you always hear the usual "pad thai", "pad see-ew", "tom yum soup", "pad kee-mow", "fried rice", etc. Well, they aren't that adventurous, are they now?
I'm sincerely asking you to have an open mind and try all the amazing stuff here at Lers Ros Thai!

- frog legs
- quail 
- rabbit
- pork belly*****
- pork shoulder*****
- crocodile meat*****

I'm sure by now a lot of people have stopped reading, oh well, their loss! If you are still here reading and curious, go to Lers Ros thai and try all of the above. They have variety ways to prep all of the above and they are orgasmically amazing! Oh La La~
I've taken some of my picky eater friends here and they absolutely loved it, especially the pork belly and pork shoulder! It's so tender and flavorful! The pork belly has this crispy skin attached, adds texture! The pork shoulder is so tender and juicy, eat it with Lers Ros' special sauce and some rice! 

All the other usuals are amazing here too, I just think the exotic meat worth mentioning more! I still got love for you tom yum soup and pad kee-mow! Tom yum soup here is authentic! I've traveled to Thailand more than 20 times and i know what real Tom yum tastes like! Same as all the other yummy food! 

Lers Ros, you make my tummy happy, make me drool every time I mention your name and think about what you offer! mmmmmmmm.... ;)
author: Mindy C.

description:
It's okay...

I dunno why I just didn't think anything i had was that great...

I liked the clams but then a lot of them had grit in it so I lost my appetite.

The pork belly was okay...

The papaya salad was whatevsies 

My sister ordered this sour soup that tasted like it was straight tamarind powder..

I did like the cashew chicken...but then again I like cashew chicken from Panda Express so I can't really judge...

Oh well, more for everyone else.

Btw the bathroom sitch is ridic...obese people totally can't use it...that's not cool.  Big people need to use the bathroom too!
author: Anthony N.

description:
Had a really great dinner here tonight. 

 The spicy papaya salad with shrimp was so flavorful.  We loved the  fried pork spareribs (they had a unique dry rub that was soooo good),  the Green curry with Thai Eggplant had an addictive delicious sauce, and we liked the brown rice and the sticky rice.  This iced tea and Thai coffee were perfect.  Others had beer and wine.

The Steamed fresh bass with chopped chili and fresh lime juice was just ok considering the $30 price tag.  It was good.  We ate it.  But nothing special.  We enjoyed the other dishes way more.  And it was presented kinda cumbersome with a huge tray and a fire burning under it. The contraption made me nervous. It was tipsy.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Went here with my brother after he heard wonderful things about the place - particularly that it has authentic thai cuisine that rivals restaurants in Bangkok. With an endorsement like that, the bar was set pretty high. 

I definitely wasn't disappointed. The restaurant was modern, clean, and beautiful. we came at noon and both times were seated right away (although half an hour later I noticed a line out the door). Bonus: You can make a reservation online so if you're worried about waiting, just hop on the web to make a ressie. 

I've been twice and tried a variety of dishes. My brother ordered the papaya salad to start which was SPICY but delicious. He raved about it. Apparently it was pretty bomb. We also had chicken pad thai which was pretty good although I can't say I thought it was too different than pad thai I've had at other restaurants. 

The standout dishes included a thai fried chicken with ginger rice - not something you find on many thai restaurant menus but authentically thai and absolutely delicious. I also had a dish with black pepper, and green and white onions which was so so so good. Red Curry also made an impression with plenty of protein, veggies, and the perfect amonunt of spice.

Service was decent, although during busier periods, it may take awhile to get water or other things requests after you've submitted your order. 

All in all, the food at this place was spectacular and the menu was extremely comprehensive. I need to make several more trips to try the pork belly and the spiced roast duck.

PS. The restaurant is in the Tendorloin but on the outskirts of it so it's slightly less sketch than the other parts. There's only street parking but I didn't feel worried about leaving my car unattended, unlike most places in the 'loin. Food was definitely worth a trip out there.
author: Carmen K.

description:
Came here to see what all the fuss was about. I made a reservation on Thurs for Fri night at 8pm. I ended up pushing the reservation to 8:30, then to 9pm, and arrived late at 9:30... yeah we were lagging. When we arrived, I was pretty sure we would have to wait behind the other 15 people outside the door, but they sat us in 5 mins. 

The food came really quickly. We had the Yum Pla Duk Foo (duck salad recommended by the waitress), Koh Moo Yang (pork shoulder appetizer), and Pad Thai (big surprise). Between the 3 of us small asian girls, we finished all of the dishes.  The duck salad was pretty damn salty, but it was delicious. The pork shoulder appetizer was flavorful and drenched in fat/oil.... The pad thai was pad thai. There were more bean sprouts on the side and I didn't know if I was supposed to mix those in... since there were already some mixed in the dish. 

Overall, it was a great thai meal, however, not recommended before going bar hopping because it really makes you feel bloated, especially with the salty, carb-loady dishes. I am anxious to compare Basil Thai in SoMa.
author: Kari K.

description: I love Lers Ros! I always order the clams and it never disappoints.  The heat and spice is always on point.
author: kathi k.

description:
Second chances sometimes do pay off. It's taken me almost two years to venture back into the spice jungles of Lers Ros, but this time I emerged blister free and very happy.

The hostess on the phone (I had delivery) hesitated when I asked for my mixed seafood salad to be prepared mild. She then said "You want no spice at all?" sounding disapproving. I sensed her sincere concern. I replied "Well, no I do want some spice. A little, I want flavor." Then I just blurted it out "The last time I ordered from you I got the green papaya salad and it burned the sh*t out of my mouth. It was scorching. I had blisters. I don't want that."

She said. "Oh yes I see. Okay." So - an hour later my mixed seafood salad with lime/chili dressing, shrimp pad thai, fresh coconut drink and ice tea arrived. Thick, juicy, fresh slices of coconut in the drink, nice, savory pad thai with well seasoned shrimp and the PERFECT amount of spice in the seafood salad. Not what I would call "mild". Definitely what i call delicious. A little nose running - no blisters. So refreshing and great. 

The girl on the phone cared. She steered me in the right direction. Second chance - this one worked.
author: wendella a.

description: This is my go-to spot for Thai in the city. It's just an all-around good fit for all types of occasions. Great for groups if you make a rezzie in advance, and fine to just pop in as a party of two. Lers Ros is also my default takeout place for those "I'm hungry but I can't decide what I want to eat" nights. On my last visit, I was feeling slightly under the weather due to seasonal allergies (I'm getting old) and their version of a Chicken Noodle Soup really hit the spot. Other favorite dishes I frequently order: the minced pork over rice, crispy pork belly & basil, the pad see yew, and the green curry.
author: Susan C.

description:
holy crap my crispy pork thing was amazing. little chunks of crispy pork skin with bits of tender meat still attached in a thin fishy spicy basily sauce is amaaaaazing. Really just the mix of textures and bright flavors takes a fatty pork dish and almost makes it taste light. Unreal.

Larb is also actually spicy. This so far has been a rarity.
author: Misha T.

description: Yes the yelp reviews and rave reviews from my friends were all correct, this place is pretty damn delicious. I have to say it's right next to being as good as my favorite Thai in SF, Ploy II. Everything was so intensely flavored. The pork shoulder was salty with a yummy dipping sauce. It was good wrapped in the cabbage provided in the papaya salad. Papaya salad mild spice was exactly that it made my nose run but wasn't crazy spicy. Red Curry Chicken had a strong kick of basil flavor, it was $1.50 for a a side of rice. it was a lot of food and our bill came out to around $38, not bad.
author: Karen T.

description: Love the grilled shrimp papaya salad and their trout with mango. The service also good, they're so nice. Will definitely come back
author: Linna S.

description: Love that place!!! Amazing food.  Absolutely loved my green curry with chicken.  Got very crowded around 7:30-8.  We got there just before 7 and we seated right away.
author: Anna H.

description:
This place has tasty dishes but my experience could have been better if the service improved a little. 

Our group of 4 waited 10 minutes for a table and we were behind a couple that got sat at a 4-person table instead of the 2-person table that was clearly available. This was a minor thing but we were all pretty famished. 

At first, I was kinda digging the cute little wooden chairs thinking that it was unique seating, but once we were sat, I realized how inconvenient these stupid chairs were. I had to sit on my coat, scarf, and purse because there were no backs to the chairs nor was there a coat rack or anything. I looked around and saw people with coats on their laps but what a terrible idea for me since I tend to spill. 

We asked for straws for our waters and our server clearly forgot so we asked another passing server and when she finally came back with our straws, she saw that we now had them and threw them down with a stink face. Oops. Well we wouldn't have asked a second time if we had gotten them in the first place. 

I usually order green curry, my favorite out of the three kinds, and usually the spice level is pretty mild, but not here. The flavor was really good but much too spicy for me to enjoy so I thought to ask if they could lighten it up with some coconut milk or something. The server said they can't do that because the curry was premade but I could swap it out for yellow curry instead. I was a little reluctant but went ahead and was pleased with the trade. This transaction went mostly smoothly but I always hesitate a little before sending food back thinking I had offended someone and then subsequently having spit in my replacement food. I'll never know.

Service got slow towards the end when we wanted to ask for boxes and then the bill. But overall, this place is pretty solid if you want spicy Thai food and can overlook minor seating details and service issues.
author: Rita L.

description:
Can you say SPICY?!?!  My goodness, this stuff is HOT!!  Unlike most restaurants that have a little chili pepper indicating that a particular dish is spicy, this place doesn't....just assume that almost ALL the dishes here are hot hot hot!!

I am not a spicy person myself and often times when I come here, I forget to tell them mild.  I then end up with a super spicy dish that numbs and burns my mouth, but their flavors are sooo amazing that I just let my stomach suffer the consequences later.  :P  

Overall, this place is a pretty solid Thai restaurant, with an extensive menu and very authentic dishes, catering to both family-style and rice plates.  Like most yelpers, #62, the pork belly w/ basil (crispy with super amazing flavors) is a must each time I come here.  I always try to change things up each time I come here, but their duck noodle soup, papaya salad with shrimp, pad woon sen (silver noodles), larb phed yang (duck), and pad thai are some of the other dishes that I enjoy when I am here.  Not sure if I'll ever be daring enough, but they also serve alligator, wild boar, and rabbit on their "special" menu.

Lunch can take rather long at times, so I suggest dining here at dinner instead if you have a short lunch break.
author: Janetto L.

description: Great food and great customer service.
author: Berna V.

description: The fried tofu for $8 did not have much taste but the sauce was good, my beef #93  Nuer Pad Prik , $11.95 - Tender beef, stir-fried with chili paste, bell peppers, bamboo shoot, basil -  was quite spicy and the red curry chicken was coconuty yummy.
author: Magda G.

description: The food was good. Didn't take too long to come out. Waitresses were nice and refilled our drinks. Cool vibe spot. Straight to the point if in the area. Although open late, the area can be sketchy late at night. go in a group, or if bold...walk fast and alert LOL Thai food was tasty, I'd come back :)
author: Jordan P.

description:
LOVE this place. the neighborhood gets a bit sketchy and the place looks small from the outside, but once you step in the restaurant is a pleasant surprise - spacious, clean, and cutely decorated. 

My favorite dishes were duck larb (also featured in 7x7) and pork belly rice. thai ice tea was strong, just the way i like it! the place is also michelin recommended.
author: Miri Kwon R.

description: Maybe it was too much anticipation, because everyone raved about this place as the 'best Thai in the city', but we found it pretty blah. Plus they doused our soup in MSG (!people still use that?!) so it had to be replaced...luckily with a much tastier one. Though the flaming cauldron they serve it in is kind of nerve wracking, smells bad, and overcooks it. We won't rush back, and not just because of the 'hood.
author: Be F.

description:
They are so incredibly fast at bringing out your food!

Any of their delicious flaming soups are a great option.

Portion sizes are a little large imo, but others probably like that.
author: Anisa A.

description: Used to live in Mae Sot, Thailand on the Thai/Burma border. Have also spent a ton of time in Bangkok. In my opinion, this place is hands down best Thai in SF. Get the duck laarb salad and sticky rice. TRUST. JUST DO IT!! Nom, Nom, Nom.
author: Rachel P.

description: Great service, very clean, awesome food, and great environment!!! Must visit if you are in San Francisco! We found it by accident and we will be back !!!
author: Ada O.

description:
probably the best thai food in the bay.  the menu is extensive, it's open late, and the service is excellent.  

recommended dishes:
-red duck curry - they're very generous with the duck and the curry sauce itself is probably the best i've ever had at a thai place 
-crispy pork belly (#62) - again, very generous with the meat portions.  most places use chinese broccoli as a filler but lers ros just gives you a dish full of pork.  the skin is extra crispy if you eat it right away.
-pad see ew - not the best i've had, but it's extra sweet which is how i like it.

not recommended:
- venison - tastes just like beef, but costs way more
-anything steamed fish related
author: Mason T.

description:
For whatever reason, the first time that I ate here I didn't think much of it.  In fact, I don't even remember what I ordered.  I dined here again tonight with the Mr. and a couple friends and now I see what folks are talking about.  Though they offer the popular Thai standards, they also have a lot of specialty dishes.  The menu is huge, but that only gives me more reason to come back again and again to attempt to try everything!  

Tonight we had:

- Pad kee mow:  Very well done standard
- Kao Mun Kai Tod (Garlic and ginger rice with crispy chicken, served with sweet chili sauce):  loved the rice and the chicken was perfectly crispy and delicious
- Koong Kra Prow (Prawns stir-fried with BASIL and hot chili sauce):  really flavorful and super spicy!
- Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (Stir-fried pork belly with crispy rind and basil leaves):  I loved the crispiness and, at times, toughness of the pork rinds.  We asked for Chinese broccoli instead of the basil leaves.

Everything was very good.  I look forward to coming back again soon.
author: Thi D.

description: Arguably the best Thai in SF. Everything I have had on the menu has been great, but the curries are their strong point. If it was possible I would give them 4.5 stars due to the fact I have had some better noodle dishes (house of Thai) in the city. Overall great spot and will not disappoint.
author: Maxwell W.

description: I've been here a couple of times because it's a popular place to go but I am not impressed. The food, although tasty, is heavily garnished so the portions are very small for the price. I also noticed that if you go during the day when it's not busy, you'll be very lucky to get friendly service from the whole staff. Will not recommend to others.
author: Miko L.

description:
I was so excited to try their alligator and made a reservation a month in advance.
So, I flew to San Francisco and headed there with 3 other friends.

The interior is pretty simple. I liked their silverware and thin white plates. The place is pretty busy and popular.
The wine and appetizers were pretty good but pretty classic too.

So, here comes the main dish: alligator!
Well, as we were ordering, we tried to change the sauce, so it wouldn't be spicy. We were told that it couldn't be done. Makes no sense to me! But we asked to make it as less spicy as possible. So, we get the alligator and:
OMG! I couldn't believe how spicy it was! UNBEARABLE! It was not just my opinion, 3 out of 4 of us had to return our dishes because we simply couldn't take another bite from them.

Well, the waitresses were nice and accommodating.
But we still left hungry and disappointed :(
author: S ..

description:
These guys went above and beyond when it really counted. When I sat down, I have to admit I was a little underwhelmed by the service. They did not seem to have communication among the staff and so we had three different people ask us if we wanted more beer, but didn't get a single one until about fifteen minutes later, and then there was still a mistake with the number of beers actually purchased.

However, where they really shined was with my order. I ordered a catfish dish they have, unaware that it was full of small fish bones. When I realized, I was less than enthused. However, when I told the staff, they suggested the idea of my getting something else, and cooked up a totally different dish for me in about half the time our other food took (take that as you will). Either way, these guys really stepped up their game to make sure I walked out happy. Definitely worth the visit. Also, they had $4 singha beers. Got to love it!
author: Michael Z.

description: Outside of being in a shady area, the restaurant is well managed and looks great. The chairs don't have backs, more authentic stool like seats to sit on. The service is excellent and many waiters/waitresses attend to you needs at once. Food was delicious. The papaya salad was amazing, we ordered medium spicy and it was very very spicy but so good. A few of our favorites from the night were chicken satay, curry puffs, sweet and sour tofu (these were all apps), and for entrees, the tofu and veggies and ginger chicken were great. Not very spicy in comparison to other Thai restaurants but the serving size was great, plenty of food for family style. Def. recommend this place for yum Thai food!
author: Shikha S.

description:
As Thai food goes, this place is pretty authentic. I definitely heard Thai being spoken among the staff, and the taste  was pretty damn good. The portions were a good amount. I appreciate that this Thai restaurant has not "american-ized", i.e. small portions, high prices, waterdowned food, and "fusion." What we ate:

- duck larb - meh, it was on the 7x7 2011 list, and i wasn't impressed
- tom yum - yum! good amount of lemongrass, basil and well nice and sour and spicy! the "firey" pot was unnecessary as it made the soup difficult to get to after awhile
- pork belly w/ crispy skin - whoa! the highlight of the meal. Def delish and highly recommended. 
- chicken satay - pretty good, not amazing. plus that the chicken breast was not dry
- sticky rice - didn't like it. the rice cooled down fast and then it was hard to eat. did not understand the obsession

Overall good food. Make reservations as it gets BUSY. Food is spicy, basically EVERYTHING.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
The sizzling beef platter was my favorite. Sorry, forgot what the thai name was but it was yummo. We were adventurous and tried the frogs legs and aligator, but didn't think it really stood out.

They have a very surprising large wine selection. 

I tried durian for the first time. It was good although some of the people that were at our table thought it tasted like toe jam. It has a savory taste in the beginning which turns sweet. I rather liked up.
author: Kenson K.

description: Best Thai in the city - avoid the expensive entrees and get the good stuff, Pad See Ew and Curry Cakes.
author: Kyle H.

description: One bite and you know you are at the right place to eat!!  No kidding! :). I had the alligator dish and it was great!  Be careful with the Medium Spice.  It is pretty hot :)
author: John S.

description:
My tongue was on fire, and it was all worth it.  Just to let you know, they put fresh chili peppers (you know those mini ones that burn forever and a day) into every dish

Pork belly was super crunchy, my friend thought he was crunching on some bones.  if you have fillings that might possibly dislodge, this is the dish that will do it.  the pork belly was greasy and tasty, but not good enough that i would get it again

The duck curry is probably the best most flavorful curry i have had in a while, and it is packs more of a punch than the one at thai house express up the block.  the duck is fatty but just so buttery and good.  I would certainly get this dish again

Combination papaya salad with roasted chicken and sticky rice.
- papaya salad  rivals king of thai's in north beach.  the kick of the lime juice and the extra salt/chili makes it my favorite papaya salad in the city so far.
- roasted chicken had good flavor however the meat was a little dry.  the skin was perfectly crispy on the outside however

overall, it's a great place for some pre-clubbing dinner, similar to osha in the TL  just be prepared to spit fire by the time you are done with your meal
author: Tina A.

description: My bf and I are in San Francisco for a few days.. today is our last day and we've been craving Thai the entire weekend.. I found this place on yelp and walked from Union Square. The food was amazing! The staff is also very friendly. They were PACKED but we got seated very fast and served fast as well. If I'm ever back in SF, I will definitely stop by!!!
author: Leslie M.

description:
Sorry Kermit.

Couldn't help but think of my favorite Muppet while digging into the Pad Kra Prow Kob (frog). Your choice minced or chunk. Bone in either way.

Made for some careful and challenging eating. Tough meat. Flavor not far from chicken. Would I have it again? No. Glad I had the chance to explore? Absolutely.

Speaking of poultry the Kao Kai Yang was the highlight. Dish features two huge pieces of sweet chili sauce infused BBQ chicken. Brown rice on the side. How sweet it was.

Dining companion went with the Kaeng Keaw Wan Talay (seafood medley). Green curry has a bit of a kick. They say there are plenty of fish in the sea. Here too.

Space felt freshly and newer than I would have expected. Staff welcoming and focused. They needed to be considering it was already packed by 7pm.

$40 plus tip for all the food felt very worth it. Though Kermit might disagree.
author: Jason B.

description: Bland food/horrible service.  Screwed up order and refused to make it right.  Many Thai restaurants in the area.  Don't waste your time with this one!!!
author: Lynne P.

description:
This restaurant can be a bit of an adventure in more ways than one -- if your only exposure to Thai cuisine is Osha's volcanic beef or crab fried rice and/or if you've never hoofed it through the T-Loin much.  Neither of which are the case for me however.

Lers Ros is the spot to go to for Thai food when you don't want Thai food like pad thai, pad see ew, green curry, etc.  This restaurant does make the aforementioned standards, though in all honesty it's not my go-to spot for such dishes, but they also do so much more and it's evident by their à la Chinese-restaurant-sized extensive menu.

Frog legs, quail and rabbit?  They serve it.  Haven't tried it yet though.  Recently had the stir fried pork belly with rice, the five spice roast duck over rice, and the duck larb.  The stir fried pork belly is excellent -- diced and cubed juicy pieces of pork belly with crispy and crunchy rinds.  The five spice duck meat is juicy and very flavorful.  The duck larb is vinegary, fish saucy, basily, and flavorful meaty goodness.  Red curry with duck is also very good, though quite spicy.  I highly recommend these dishes.

Overall, the food here is very good, it's reasonably priced, and service is pretty friendly.
author: Erich D.

description: Really quite consistently good. When I'm able to operate a motor vehicle and leave the Castro for dinner after Happy Hour takes its toll on me, this is often my go-to. It's a bit better than other local Thai places I've tried (though my heart still belongs to Spicy BBQ in Hollywood Thai Town, LA).
author: Sean B.

description: Found this place off yelp and didn't fail to impress.  I'll admit, I was a little skeptical about how good this place must be in the Tenderloin area.  Glad I went in.  The food was superb.  Oh, and the friend banana with ice cream is a must try :-D
author: Yisel F.

description:
Excellent thai but the sweet and sour chicken needs a bit more sour. 
Too many vegetables in the sliced beef. 
Very good overall.
author: Richie A.

description:
Hands down my favorite Thai place in the city!

Well-kept restaurant with a friendly wait staff and amazing food.  It's easy to miss and even though it's located in the tenderloin, Lers Ros has a more high-end feel to it than the other thai places but it's still definitely casual.  It's cute that they serve every individual rice and sake when ordered.

Last time I went here, we got the duck larb salad (#25), crispy pork belly (#62), pad see ew, yellow curry, and their papaya salad with shrimp.  Everything was soooo good!!  My fave was the duck larb salad, which is on the 7x7 list also, and I could've inhaled that thing if we weren't doing family style.  Almost everything had a little bit of a spicy kick to it, so be warned if you can't handle spicy.

I only wish I lived closer...they would suck my wallet dry.
author: Jane N.

description:
There is a lot of good Thai places in the city so it's hard to pick just one but this one is up there. It's located in the tenderloin but its very clean and surprisingly spacious... or at least feels spacious. I had the crispy pork belly, the duck larb salad, and the pad kee mow. The pork belly and duck larb salad was delicious. The pad kee mow was mediocre. I'll definitely be back to try other things especially since this is the gf's favorite thai place and she lives right down the block.

MUST HAVES:
Duck larb salad
Pork belly


PS. the pad kee mow is wayyyyy better at basil thai.
author: William L.

description: Too busy. Every time I try to order take out from here the wait is longer than 20 mins. Other nearby Thai places are less than 15 mins so I've never gotten to eat here :(
author: Mike V.

description: A very mediocre restaurant. The cucumber salad was swimming in the syrup and was too sweet. The beef in Pad Thai was of a cheap cut - with giants pieces of fat.
author: Faina S.

description: Just order it on Grubhub. Hands down, the best thai food you can order when you're laying on the couch.
author: Wendy K.

description: Very, very good. Real Thai staff and the green curry is top notch perfect as though I were still in Thailand. Pra ram was ok but nothing special. Pork belly quite good, they have amazing skills at perfect sauces. Definitely a repeater.
author: T J.

description:
I never heard of this place until my Executive Director told us to meet here, but I'm sure glad she did. We arrived before the dinner rush and were seated right away. 

Their menu is pretty extensive, so I'll have to come back and try their other dishes. However of the dishes we ordered, I enjoyed them rather much. Our order consisted of:

Papaya Salad
- Fresh, tangy, crispy and sweet.

Pad Thai
- A common favorite, the sauce and noodles are done right.

Pork Belly Stir Fry
- My personal favorite! The meat is very flavorful. Each piece is fried on the outside, so with each pork belly bite you're left with the mixture succulent crispy flavor.

Marinated Short Ribs
- Made with a savory marinated sauce that is prefect to pour on your ride.

Of all the Thai spots in SF, this could easily become my favorite. They're open till Midnight but it gets busy after 7pm, so be prepared to wait during the late night dinner rush.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Catered from this place for a party of 12! Awesome service (although I initially talked to somebody who didn't really speak English) with Ann who helped me order the appropriate amount of food and the right dishes (I made some changes to the ones that they list on their web site). 

I asked that the food be delivered between 615 and 630 and it was delivers at 630! It was perfect! Packed without any leaking (curry) and with enough napkins and utensils for the group!

Food is amazing! We have eaten at the restaurant numerous times and loved it every time. Take out/catering is just as good. 

Definitely ordering from them again!
author: Em D.

description: Great atmosphere, great ambience, great food! The meat was tender, the flavors really popped. I would definitely come back.
author: Jim G.

description:
Wonderful take out Thai. For only $30, we got 2 great plates and a dessert. 

I really enjoyed the prawns and asparagus. 

The mango sticky rice was to die for! 

For pickup orders, go to the table/counter at the back of the restaurant, so you don't wait with people who want a table.
author: Aaron S.

description:
I love this place! One day, I complained to my BF about why SF doesn't have any good Thai restaurants. So we went on yelp, and lo and behold, Lers Ros poped up as the first search result for Thai food. We checked out some reviews and decided to give a try. It definitely hit the spot!!! 

The Grilled Slices of Pork Shoulder were tasty and delicious, especially the first bite! Pad Ped Nok (Stir Fried Quail) was not bad eithher. Pla Rad Prik (Whole Fried Tilapia) was the bomb! It was giant, we couldn't finish the whole fish, had to pack the leftovers to-go. 

The service was ridiculously nice. I was going to give 5 stars to this place, however I ordered Pad Kee Mow to-go othe following day and it came with a side of raw bean sprouts, it was weird to have bean sprouts in it. You really could only taste the sugar in the noodles, there wasn't any fish sauce or basil favor.

Other than the Pad Kee Mow, all the other things were good. We'll definitely be back to try all the other great dishes on the menu.
author: Chloe B.

description:
Had dinner here last night. Despite our poor planning and lack of reservations, they were able to seat our party of 6 within 15 minutes. 

The wait staff was friendly and attentive (and they were able to help me out with finding gluten-free/safe menu items to cater to my Celiac disease). I started with the Koong Chae Nam Pla and then had the Pad Thai. Both dishes were slightly altered so that they would be gluten-free. 

Although I RARELY go out of my way to hang out in the TL, I was so impressed with the staff and the food and I can't wait to go back!
author: Megan C.

description:
so this is definitely the best thai food that i've ever had. made a 730 reservation for 2 on a friday night and still waited about 15 mins. not too bad. 

- pork belly - so awesome. crispy chicharron-like skin. favorite thing hands down. 
- pad see ew - good version
- green curry - loved it
- pad prik king - only thing i didn't like. some type of flavor/seasoning that i sometimes get in thai food that i'm not a fan of. 


food comes out super quick. hard to take your time.
author: J A.

description:
Tom yum noodle (not the noodle soup, but the "idea" of Tom yum noodle) is really good.  The deep fried garlic and crispy pork skin are super good.  The texture of the noodle itself was good too.

Other things that were good:
- Papaya salad with salted egg
- Kra Pow (pork) with rice plate (didn't try the beef, but I would assume it's good too)
- Khao Kha Moo
- Boat noodle soup (but the one at Zen Yai is a lot more flavorful)
- Crispy chicken -- super good but not enough


Green curry was OK.  Not bad, but not as good as the dishes listed above.
author: Amanda B.

description: Came here on a Sunday night around 7pm, no wait for two - yeehaw! My dining companion ordered the Lard Na, I had the fried chicken over fried rice with chili sauce. Both were very, very good - I was wanting some comfort food, and boy was it comforting. The fried chicken was so good. Straight up goodness. We were obviously hit and run eaters - just water, two entrees, and check. The service was very fast and accommodated this - can't wait to come back and try again!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Shoutout to the best friend for suggesting this place for dinner because the food was stellar.

+ Som Tom Koong Yan ($9.95) - light and refreshing papaya salad with a generous amount of plump prawns cooked to perfection. Great start to any meal.
+ Tom Yum Koong ($12.95) traditional spicy and sour soup with prawns, lemongrass, mushrooms and kaffir lime leaves. It was delectable with a slight hint of spiciness but I think I still prefer the traditional Thai coconut milk-based soups because they're creamier and more filling.
+ Koh Moo Yang: ($9.95) - grilled slices of pork shoulders with chili and rice powder sauce. Super tender and melts in your mouth! Favorite dish of the meal - it's a must try!
author: Annie S.

description: Excellent food & great customer service. They even gave us a complementary dessert for my husband's birthday.
author: Misgana B.

description:
Who else serves pad phed alligator in this town???  They should get 5 stars alone for making that available.

I'm not too fond of the noise or the location, but they sure make a good som tam and gai yaang.  :D  I also like their khao niaw, especially when not everyone makes it right.
author: angel a.

description: The pork belly and rind dish #34 will change your life. This is some of the best Thai food I've ever had. Absolutely fantastic and the rind is so crunchy and incredible. Easy to give 5 stars.
author: Mike J.

description:
Thai restaurants in San Francisco are a dime a dozen, but Lers Ros Thai is definitely worth a try. Located in the TL, there's actually a good amount of street parking relatively close by which is always a huge plus. The tables are very densely packed within the restaurant and it is hot / stuffy as s* in the restaurant so be prepared. All the waitresses seem to be Thai and the hospitality is Thai quality (as in very very good).

Here's what we tried:
- Chicken laab (ground chicken salad): We asked for medium spicy because quite frankly, I'm scared of "Thai spicy" although I'm an avid spice-aholic. The laab itself was good but I probably could have gone a little spicier. You should definitely try this with some sticky rice. The two are perfect complements.
- Pad kee mow: I loved loved loved the noodles here! Often times, pad kee mow can be drenched in sauce or oil, but the noodles here were extremely flavorful sans excessive sauce / oil. The noodles themselves were perfectly cooked and not clumped together (another problem that I've experienced with this dish at other places).
- Garlic quail: Super flavorful with clumps of fried garlic on top. The quail was tender and finger-lickin' good.
author: Grace Y.

description:
First time at Lers Ros Thai in the Tenderloin.  I thought it was ok.  I was the first customer at 4:30pm since I didn't want to walk around anymore.

Waitress gave me FREE iced water while I waited for a friend.  Menu is Huge.  They have appetizers $5.95 - $7.95; salads $6.95-7.95; soups: $6.95-7.95; coconut milk curries $7.95-8.95; Vegetarians $6.25-7.5; Rice plates $6.225-7.95; noodles $6.95-7.95; pan fried noodles $7.5-7.95; house specials $7.25;  original thai style $7.25-15.95; rice soup $1-$7.95; drinks; wine; beer; sake; side orders; desserts $3-4.50.

I picked these items:

#12 Som Tom Poo Dong $7.25-shredded green papaya salad w/ chili, cherry tomatoes, lime based salad dressing & crabs.  She asked how spicy we wanted - we said medium and it's Spicy!  No crab meat at all, just some shells & what tasted like raw crab.  Gross.  Shredded green papaya was just ok, didn't have cherry tomatoes - more like boring tomato.  Skip this dish.

#105 Pad ped moo pah $7.50- boar stir-fried w/ a house made chili paste & galingale.  Boar was chewy & not very tasty.  I liked the sauce.  Not much else.  Portions on the small side.

Rice: got 2 orders, one for each of us.  Tasted fine.  $1.50 ea.

Subtotal $17.75 + $1.50 tax = $19.25 Before tip.  Credit cards taken.

I'll probably visit here again one day since maybe I didn't order the best dishes, just not in any hurry.

Bathrooms: Up 2 flights of stairs in the back, separate bathrooms available.

Hrs: 11am-2AM!!  

730 Larkin St (between O'Farrell & Ellis)

FREE delivery: Minimum order $15
author: Ann L.

description:
My wife and I decided have lunch here after numerous reccs and positive reviews on Yelp.

We went pretty authentic and ordered the following items.

Som thum poo - papaya salad with crab.  I enjoyed more than my wife but she did appreciate the large chunks of crab that she could gnaw on.  Thai people love that stuff!!

Lahb phet - spicy duck salad.  I loved it!  But my wife didn't think it was authentic.  They used roast duck instead of minced.  Flavors leaned more of a Chinese - Thai hybrid. But I thought it was wonderful.

Thoam yum poat thak - spicy seafood soup.  I thought it was heavy on thai basil.  But the shrimp and clams were nice and succulent.  Calamari a little tough.  Broth a little too forward forward for my taste.

Gai yahng - grilled chicken.  Very disappointing.  Took a while, tough, dry and uninteresting bland flavor.  

Considering a rather hefty lunch price tag, we expected more.  Perhaps you guys may think otherwise.
author: Art R.

description:
I did enjoy the green curry, although the portion was smaller than what I am used to. 

We didn't really like the Pra ram. The peanut sauce was a bit spicey and more savory than sweet. It was good, but not how we traditionally like it. 

They have brown rice, and several other types of rice, which is nice. They had some yummy salads- we got this papaya one with prawns that had a pretty spicey, but light, dressing on it. Really good, however I ate a lot and my mouth was on fire! Not a salad to eat as an entree unless you like the heat!

We will be going back to try the Pad thai.... Everything looked really good though. 

Make sure to make reservations - place was PACKED and you need a reservation so you dont have to stand in the cold, in the LOIN!!
author: Tosca B.

description: I was staying at a hotel closely and decided to yelp for food. It was walking distance about a block away. I was expecting it to be an ok restaurant but as soon as the food came out it was delicious! we ordered pad thai, yellow chicken curry, and pad see ew. Everything was great and tasted fresh
author: Jas L.

description:
Excellent food - best Thai food I have ever had. 

Recommend the pork shoulder appetizer, the pork belly, and the boar was pretty good too!
author: Trevor C.

description: omg that sliced bbq beef dish is amazing. and the thai eggplant... where has that been my whole life?
author: Love U.

description:
the pork belly was like overnight chinese roast pork, it did taste good though

not sure why this place is so highly revered, i havent had a bad thai experience yet, but i havent had one that was stellar, this place fits with the rest
author: Long C.

description: After reading the reviews I was expecting to be blown away. The chicken satay, was obviously barely okay. The Tom yum soup was excellent as was the papaya salad. Things took a south turn when the main dishes showed up. This is the same old Americanized Thai food you get everywhere. As I love Thai food I could still eat it, but you could tell that the recipes are not authentic. The red curry was orange and it was full of carrots!! The eggplant with chicken was bland and sweet and the pad Thai - my fault for even ordering it. Sorry- this place is average at best.
author: Karan K.

description: Flew into SF late night and was looking for some belly-lovin' food with flavor and spice. Found it! Extensive menu, charming staff, and surprise live thai instrument quartet! What a find. I could eat here all weekend (did I mention the crispy pork belly?). Do yourself a favor: go to there!
author: Zara H.

description:
Notables:

11:59AM : out of sticky rice? But they opened at 11AM.. 

Thai iced tea: not too sweet, a large cup of it! Yummy :)

Food: probably the closest Thai to the food I had in Thailand! Authentic Thai food :) I had the Tomyangkoong, Somtom with prawns, BBQ Chicken. 

BBQ Chicken - good, nothing too elaborate. 
Tomyangkoong - Similar to soup in Thailand; thought it was a bit too sour. For people who don't like herb-y foods, I wouldn't recommend! 
Somtom - one of my favorite Thai foods! This salad was good, with big pieces of prawn. Light and refreshing, with a hint of spice.
author: Christine Y.

description:
I have been there before and loved this shit out of everything  that they slapped down.  But Their take on Rabbit and Alligator is some perfect ish.                    

Not sure how often alligator make it out this way, albeit it was some smallish gator,  but I was still happier den a toofless kid in a  Bayou skunk shop!!
author: Dru P.

description: 4 stars because of location but the food is hands down THE BEST Thai food I have ever had! We're visiting the city and asked a few locals about Thai food and they all recommend this place! Worth the travel!
author: Ana marie d.

description:
THEY DO NOT BELIEVE IN AIR CONDITIONER!

I don't know if it's because SF is always kind of chilly or it's because the AC was broken. but it was a hot day when I went and it was HOT inside. I asked the lady if they can turn on the AC a little higher, and she looked at me like I was crazy and said "NO" 

Food is ok, the heat was just unbearable took my food and left,
author: Eve W.

description:
My friend and I were happy to find a chill place open late. I don't eat Thai often and this was her first time. We were able to find fresh, authentic tasting dishes that we could identify with, and the late night crew was attentive and polite.
We will definitely be back.
author: Danee C.

description:
Since this place is so fantastic, I'm on a personal mission to try everything on the menu!  My progress so far:

Favorite Dishes:
Chicken Satay-the best of your life
Nuer Tod (fried sun-dried beef)- chocolatey beef jerky
Yum Koh Moo Yang (pork shoulder salad)- reminds me of Korean Bulgogi with Thai spice
Larb Duck  (roasted duck salad)- best salad of my life, I get it every time
Tom Kha Kai - an awesome lemon grassy spicy broth soup with chicken.  Every time I get it my throat has a little mini-orgasm.  
Tom Yum Pla Kra Pong (sea bass in tom yum soup)- tart lemon grassy soup with a whole fish! Best enjoyed as part of a group.  Pricy.
Pad-See-Ew (spicy pan fried noodles)- Delicious spicy noodles 
Kang Daeng (red curry with eggplant)-Wow, organsmic curry!  We licked the bowl clean.
Kao Pad Kai Tod (crispy fried chicken over rice) -  Delicious spicy-sweet chicken with the savory fried rice!  I never would have tried it on my own, and I am glad I did.
Thai Herb sausage-very spicy, lemon grassy pork sausage.   


OK:
Pra Ram Pak-basic steamed veggies slathered in peanut sause.
Pad Thai- This is a safe choice for the less adventurous eaters in your group.  I know several people judge a Thai restaurant by their Pad Thai, but If you only try the Pad Thai here, you are missing out on an unique dining experience.

Did not like:
Fried Tofu- bland triangles of fried tofu, devoid of all taste.
Som Tom Poo (green papya salad with raw crabs)-the crab is difficult to eat and hurt my mouth.
Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (fried pork belly in basil leaves)- the pork is fried to a crisp, chewy, candy like texture unlike anything you have eaten.  Kind of like pork candy. 
Moo Preaw Warn (sweet and sour pork)-reminded me of cheap Chinese food complete with pineapple.
Garlic and Pepper rabbit- too many bones and over fried.

Still to try:
Kao Na Phed-(five spices duck over rice)
Som Tom Koong Yang (green papaya salad with prawns)
Nuer Pad Prik Thai Ooan (beef sir fried)
Pad Ped Moo Peh (Boar stir fried with chili paste)
Lers Ros Special Combination plate

Can't wait to come back!
author: Nicole R.

description:
we came here to eat dinner last night around 7:30pm. the place was packed, but we were offered seat at the bar which was alright with us. service was great. food was also good. 

1. som tam: (papaya salad) a staple in Thai dish.. I thought was a bit too sweet than the traditional way. they also used dried red peppers aside from fresh crushed Thai chillies. I did not like the robust taste those dried chilly flakes gave to the papaya salad, it just wasn't authentic.  

2. crispy pork in basil was a piece of heaven.. very tender pork and crispy pieces of pork skin. yumm 

3. crab fried rice was just ok. 

4. catfish salad was also ok. 

I wanted to have the iced chysanthemum drink as offered in their menu but was turned down, "we ran out". then I asked for the iced longan drink and they also ran out.. boooooo
author: Steve S.

description:
Location is a little bit off the beaten path for me but is really wanted to try it out and went one early evening after visiting friends business around the corner. 

Kind of noisy and a bit rowdy but our selections were delicious. The menu has a great variety of Thai choices I've never seen before. We'll definitely be venturing this way again.
author: Brad C.

description: Awesome Thai food! Get the duck larb salad to start. It'll tickle your tongue tasters for sure. The five spice pork was also very good. Great food for a great price!
author: Sherry L.

description:
This is the best Thai place in the city!  My previous favorite was Marnee Thai, but after some inconsistent experiences there I vote for Lers Ros! Ways great, fresh food and wonderful service!

The Good:
 - service
 - fresh vegetables
 - flavorful and spicy entrees
 - consistent

The Bad:
 - wait/line
 - take-out

Try it and see for your self!  It's worth the wait!
author: Amy P.

description: Ordered from their site at 6:15pm on 10/11. Food took over 2 hours to arrive--and was cold! Either sat for a long while in the kitchen or in the deliverer's car. Called the restaurant after an hour and a half and they said it was being delivered. Should've cancelled then. Never again will we order from Lers Ros. For the price they charge for common Thai dishes, food should be delivered hot and in a timely fashion. Hopefully for future customers' sake management addresses this common problem (read other 1 and 2 star reviews).
author: Eric D.

description: Very good Thai food. It was hard to pick a place, since there are so many Thai restaurants in SF. I'm glad I chose this one! The food was great! Get there early for lunch. It started getting very crowded by 12:00.
author: Sandra H.

description: I'm trying to give fewer five star reviews, but this place really has its act together. The fried frog appetizer was an exotic treat you won't find elsewhere. Thai standards were generously portioned and well prepared and presented as well. I also like the attention to detail, like the chilled glass for my beer. Five stars-krap.
author: Nick C.

description: This place is far too overhyped. The takeaway: good portion sizes, good for groups, and reasonable. Nothing special food wise.
author: Regina D.

description: This food was worth every penny and the wait.Walking by all harmless tenderloin crackheads and drug dealers will not hold me back from my thai fix. The food, service and restaurant is great. We will be back!
author: Susan S.

description:
Food here is okay, but probably not worth what you pay. The lunch special is probably the only way to make this place a worthwhile deal. Flavors won't blow you away but at least with the lunch special you'll get to try multiple items.

This is probably a good place for lunch with a group if you work nearby since it does have a nice atmosphere, but I'd probably go with Thai food in the avenues if you want cheaper and tastier food.
author: Allen C.

description:
Due to our busy schedule preparing for our wedding stuff, we were not able to eat since lunch and it was 11PM at night on Sunday. We were starving but we still want to eat good food. So this restaurant came up on Yelp and we were very happy that this place still open! YAY! (2 thumbs up for that) I was expecting more hole in the wall type of thing but when we got to the restaurant, it actually a nice looking restaurant. I think this restaurant is good for a casual date night, as I saw some couples in the restaurant. Not too fancy or too dingy. Though I don't mind going on a date to a dingy place as long as the food good and won't give me stomachache.

Food: I like the PORK BELLY!!! I like how they make the skin very crunchy! Reminded me of suckling pig from bali! No this is not a diet food to lose weight but whatever! 
GARLIC and GINGER RICE is better than a simple plain rice but still simple.
PAPAYA SALAD, Very fresh and it has shrimps in it. 

Service: Very quick (as me being so hungry) 

I need to go back to get Pork belly and try other dishes!
author: Fenny G.

description: Wow this place is incredible! Best spring rolls I have ever had in my life, hands down. Everything was amazing! I need to go back.
author: Chelsea S.

description:
Best Thai food I have ever had! With great service! And good prices!

Had the papaya salad, pork belly dish, green curry, and pad kee mow. All very delicious.
Papaya salad was refreshing, spicy, great appetizer for great entrees. Pork belly dish was recommended to us by the waitress. Very surprised by the dish, crunchy, tender, good sauce. Highly recommended dish. Green curry tasted like it should, best we ever had it, not too sweet or salty; and the pork was good tender (unlike other thai restaurants that serve overcooked meat). Pad kee mow tasted like it should as well, best we ever had, not too salty, meat was also made very well.

Service was excellent! Water was full all the time. Waitresses came when they were needed and did not hover over us.

Would DEFINITELY come back again and try other dishes!
author: Calvin W.

description:
I went to Ler Ros with a large group on a Saturday night with no problems.  I do recommend making reservations as they are super accomdating.  Just don't be late to your reservation..

[64 - Pad Phed - Full taste of house chili paste, kaffir lime leaves, young pepper corn, and gallingale]

Ler Ros menu is different as there are several thai dishes I have never seen before. For the Pad Phed I aded some extra deep fried tofu to it.

Pad Phed is basically a dish of spicy death.  Super delicious, spicy and painful, but you just want to go for more.

[curry puffs]
Kind of interesting.  Like a empanada kinda with curry inside.  Pretty good.

[overall]
Ler Ros is one of those places where you can't stay and mingle with friends.  There is a long wait if you don't make reservations, so I suggest coming in to eat some great food, then heading out afterwards to relax to do something else (Yamasho perhaps?).

Food is really great on the slightly bolder disposition with stronger salt/sweet/umami flavors.
author: Dan Q.

description:
Best Thai food I've had in SF.

Everything was cooked to perfection and the waitstaff was attentive and smiley.

Nothing else to say.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Lunch with two friends from middle school. 

It was a nice surprise when we entered from the ghetto, run-down streets of the tenderloin. It is spacious, well-lit and clean. 

We were immediately seated and handed menus. I was going to get the 7x7 duck larb but it was under the salad category. Didn't feel like a salad so I ordered the lunch special as did my two friends. 

Lunch special $7.95. Your pick of two sides on a list of 15 - 16 items that ranges from curries, meats, and veggies. Comes with a big mound of rice and a side salad. The salad came with a sweet fish sauce which was good but it was just clumps of lettuce. Overall it was a great deal. $9 out the door. I finished everything except for the rice. A little less than half was left over. I was satisfied till dinner time which was at 7:30pm.

I would definitely want to come back and try some of the more traditional Thai dishes. 

The waitresses allowed us to make change twice so we can split the bill.
author: Sarah C.

description:
when I miss REAL Thai test I always go there!
some dishes you can ask for REAL Thai spicy and I LOVE THIS PLACE!
author: Fah Z.

description: Food is good, no doubt about it. However they are two for two in royally screwing up my phone order. Paid for items, never received. Have not spoken to one person over the phone or in person who is able to speak or understand English well so it is not surprising that I've struck out both times trying to order. Only to realize the mistake upon arriving home. Calling to complain is a complete waste of time because they do not understand what they did or why I am upset. Not sure I will ever order again, it's too frustrating.
author: Kevin K.

description: I understand why this place is so popular. The food is great. The service is excellent. It was just a little to noisy for my taste, I've never been to a restaurant that was so noisy. I guess it's probably because it a tight open space. I still enjoyed myself though.
author: Tracy M.

description:
Highly recommend:

- green curry with chicken (be careful - can be very spicy)
- thai style pork belly (very crispy and flavorful!)
- pad see yew
author: Karen K.

description:
Good service, nice ambiance. Most of the chairs have no backrests, FYI. 

Yes, get the pork belly dish. 

Everything was a tad too salty, but not more than any other usual place. I'd go back, especially given the late hours. Neighborhood is dirty, but probably not dangerous.
author: Los Angelin O.

description:
My girlfriend and I come here frequently since it is just around the corner from our apartment. We have both dined at Lers Ros for both lunch and dinner. 

The lunch menu is very cheap. At under $10, you have a choice of various appetizers and you select two entrees. (also served with rice) 
However, the ambience and quality of food is almost night and day. The fluorescent lighting cheapens the environment and although we ordered the same entrees both times, the food was much more flavorful at dinner. Coming in at dinner, the environment is much more warm and inviting. 

Some of our favorites...

Tom Yum Goong (Hot and sour soup with shrimp) 
Great if it's cold out, or if you're catching one.
Avoid it if you do not enjoy eating cilantro or lemongrass. The presentation is pretty exciting. 

Sticky Rice is one of our favorite cause it is very authentic and made the same way the local Thai's serve in Thailand. Especially paired with the next two entrees below.

Som Tam (Spicy Papaya Salad) A good indicator of a good Thai restaurant is their som tam. This dish is the best papaya salad I've tried in the City. *It can get VERY spicy, and I'd advise you to get it mild and don't forget to add the shrimp!

Kai Yang (Thai BBQ style chicken) is another delicious dish and it goes very well with the Papaya salad. However, it is very filling. 

Thai Iced Tea pairs well with the dishes, especially the spicy ones. However, I would forgo getting it to-go because comes in a cup half the size the one they serve in the restaurant.

Overall, we have not had any bad experiences with Les Ros and would highly recommend this place. I think it is best if you share the dishes since Thai food is meant to be shared with other people. 

kap pun kap,
h n l
author: H N L.

description: The food here is seriously crack. Everything is good. Their Pad Thai was great - authentic, perfect amount of heat and spice. Pork belly was amazing as well.
author: Carolyn H.

description:
I was nervous because fine-dining Thai food in the bay area and especially in the TL doesn't mean shit compared to the smaller and cheaper spots. The prices are a few bucks more, but I'm gonna say it's well worth it. 

I portions looked small, but it turns out the bowls and the food is piled high. The Pad Kee Mao was so tasty, we ordered a second one half way through our meal. The Green Curry and Eggplant dishes were awesome, too. Our two dinner-mates were meat eaters and they liked the four dishes they ordered. I can only remember the red curry, which looked bomb.
author: Camille R.

description:
The food--if and when it arrives--is very good and for some dishes, excellent.  But the service was just terrible.  I'll be specific.

We ordered two different appetizers.  Half an order of the first one came soon, but the second half never came, nor did the second appetizer.  We asked the waitress and she said the second half was coming, which it did, just as the entrees began to arrive.  The other appetizer never came, and when we reminded her about it, she said we never ordered it and then brought it halfway through the meal.  One of the drinks--an iced tea--never arrived.  We reminded the waitress three times before she finally brought it.  Each time she acted as if we had never ordered it and never asked for it the previous times.

One person ordered sticky rice, which arrived ten minutes before any of the food and was cold by the time the food arrived.

The entrees came out over about a fifteen minute period.  Two different dishes were delivered that weren't ordered, and two entrees didn't arrive.  When we asked about those, the waitress said the one was coming and insisted we hadn't ordered the other.  (The computer-generated bill showed the correct order for everything, and we had given the number as well as the name of the dish when ordering to be helpful.)  After a long argument she agreed to bring that one, which eventually came.

The other entree never arrived.  On the second reminder, she again said it was coming.  On the third reminder, she asked what dish we were talking about and suggested we hadn't ordered it.  The fourth time we asked the host to intercede.  The last entree finally arrived after everyone else was done eating (the person who ordered it is somewhat limited in what he eats so was not able to borrow food from the other dishes ordered by others in our party).  The waitress did not apologize or offer any explanation and, indeed, seemed at best disinterested and at worst put out by us from the beginning.

We were a mid-sized party and had ordered about half an hour before the dinner rush really got going.  We sat next to a much larger party that arrived after we did, got its food before we did, and seemed to have no issues with service.  They had a different waiter.  

The host was aware of the service problems we were having but made no effort to correct them or to offer an explanation.

We will not be returning, which is unfortunate because, as I say, the food that did show up was quite good.  But midway through the meal we realized we had to focus not on our conversation and the cuisine but on watching for the waitress to keep trying to fix the errors, which by the end had become a real distraction and disappointment.
author: Larry D.

description: It hurts a bit having to give Lers Ros a 3 stars, but based on my most recent experience, I can't give it more. When I first had Lers Ros' duck curry  in 2011, I literally dubbed it the best thai duck curry Ive ever had in life...the curry was noticably thicker, the spiciness and flavor were perfect, and the pieces of duck were a good, soft texture. Fast foward to 2015 and it's just not the same.  The curry's texture was pretty thin in comparison/noticably on the watery side,  and, while the pieces of duck were much bigger, the meat was tough to the point that it didnt feel blended with the curry or part of the dish. The flavor was fine, but the change in consistency made it less enjoyable.  It's 3 stars in that...I mean, it still tastes pretty good,  but I just use to remember it to be mind blowing.  Can't say anything about any other dishes that I haven't tasted.
author: Frances L.

description:
I got the chicken satay and chicken yellow curry. The satay was amazing but I feel like there wasn't enough chicken or potatoes in the curry. I ended up with a ton of rice at the end smothered in sauce. The beer I had was good too. And I liked the service. The waitress was apologetic that it took so long to get my food but I didn't think it took long. I was just bored cuz I was eating by myself. 

It's a smaller place and it was busy in a Tuesday night.
author: Cy D.

description:
I am eating my delicious leftovers from Lers Ros as I type, and honestly, there ain't nothin' better in the world than leftover Thai food (at least at this moment).

I have never actually stepped foot into Lers Ros, but I've used their delivery service a handful of times and their food has been consistently scrumptious. Be careful if you're sensitive to spicy foods - this place shows no mercy when it comes to laying on the heat. I personally love my Thai food flaming hot, but my body usually reprimands me in the hours following my meal..

I stick to my favorites when it comes to Thai food. Lers Ros has yet to disappoint

- Papaya salad with grilled prawns: one of the better papaya salads I've had, but it tastes like they put EXTRA CHILI PEPPERS in theirs so watch out
- Pad Thai: delicious
- Pad See Ew with tofu: dericious
- Pad Kee Mow: DELICIOUS. and hot hot hot
- Green curry with tofu: coconut milky, with a good kick of heat. they seem to make their curries slightly thicker than most thai places, which I really like.
- Stir-fried eggplant and tofu (Pad Makuer tofu): best eggplant dish ever
- Mango sticky rice: c'mon. can't go wrong here.

Their delivery speed is usually quite fast, unless it's a holiday. On normal days, it takes them about 30-45 minutes to get the food to my door. On New Year's day, it took them 1.5 hours but I know they were slammed that night so I'm grateful I was able to get my food at all.
author: Amanda C.

description:
The best Thai restaurant in the city. I have never been to a restaurant which consistently upholds its quality of food and efficiency of service so perfectly. 

Yes, it is not situated in the best neighborhood but the food and attentive service are worth a visit
author: Robecta M.

description: love love love the food here. Especially their rice, I know its cooked in fat, but its so delicious. pair the rice with their fried chicken and you'll be sitting happy. This place gets pretty packed but I've always arrived earlier in the evening and never had to wait. Defiantly a place to try if you're roaming around the TL.
author: Serena L.

description:
After having a friend from Taiwan make some legitimate Thai food - with heat - I've surged into a new love for Thai cuisine. I always liked it, it's inexpensive but so often unremarkable. 

So where do we get real Thai food with heat and spice - got on yelp and found Lers Ros Thai - this place is awesome. Took the advice of others on here and started with Fried Quail - which was good for 2 of us, the sauce was delicious very slight kick, next time ask to spice it up, 

Appetizer #10 Garlic Quail with hot sauce (not very hot but delicious) 
Then we shared:
#62 Pad Kra Prow Moo Kro - Stir Fried Pork Belly w/ Basil Leaves. 
#98 Kong Chu-Chee - Prawns topped w/ red chili, coconut milk and lemon leaves. (this one was the spiciest) 

All excellent and the waitstaff is great, very friendly and adorable yet efficient. Everything was very good, the place got quite busy however it wasn't too noisy. 
Love the place - Hoping next time to raise the heat/spice level.
author: Rew C.

description:
Incorrect information on Yelp and on their website

We wanted to try Lers Ros today, because we were longing for Thai food.  We missed the usual lunch hours, but Yelp said this restaurant was open (it was Sunday 3pm).  First, we called to see if we can get some delivered, but they said they only do it after 5pm (their website said 4pm).

We decided to get take-out instead, and got ready in about an hour.  When calling again around 4pm, they told us that they close every day between 4-5pm.  Again this is not on Yelp or on their website.  (Website says they are open 11am-midnight.)

As such, we could not try their food, but got burned twice.  Would have liked if they told us their hours on the first call.
author: Lajos M.

description:
The only reason why it's not a 5 star is because of its location. 

Be warned: don't dress up, don't walk at night alone, a Lyft is totally worth it! 

My favorite dishes are: the grilled pork shoulders & the Tom Sabb soup!!!!!!!!

Drooling now just thinking about it. 

It's definitely a favorite Thai go-to place of mine. 

Awesome, hip ambiance too! 

Best to RSVP because it can get quite busy!
author: NhuNhu N.

description:
Hot darn the pork belly is good. Thanks Yelp Review Highlights!

The pad kra prow moo krob is everything pork belly should be. It's crispy. It's chewy. It melts in your mouth. Its name is fun to say. 

The accompanying vegetables are light and played well with the savory pork- totally delicious  The sauce is pretty thin, not sure it's necessary to order rice with this one. But go for it if you feel it's right.

Prawn tom yum was also exceptional. The sourness of the broth was great, and they gave way more than I'm used to getting. Loved the 'shrooms in it. They do half-orders of the soup (although it's not listed on the menu).

Will be back soon.
author: Ryan D.

description: Phenomenal!  We wanted Thai food and went here based on reviews.  We brought our friends and they said it was the best Thai food they ever ate.  It is definitely among the best for my husband and I as well.  And he lived in Thailand for 3 years so he is VERY picky when it comes to Thai.  It was busy, the waitress and us sometimes had a hard time communicating but I find that very cute.  Service was very good and friendly.  The chef is top notch.  And the prices are VERY reasonable.  I was shocked how little the bill was considering there were 4 of us.  We had appetizers, beers, and entrees.  Although, it was mostly all vegetarian.
author: Kristina t.

description:
This review is for their food delivery. 

I actually have never been to this restaurant, but we have ordered many times of delivery food from them.  NOTE: they only start delivery from 4pm.  

We typically get papaya salad with shrimp (i think it's the best choice). one time we wanted to be adventurous and ordered raw crab instead... big mistake... :(

green curry with pork: also so yummy, even after sitting in the car for the driver to deliver it to us..   the pork is still tender, the coconut milk is still so creamy... 

pad thai: hit or miss.  it is tough with noodles to be delivered.. i am sure it tastes a lot better at the restaurant. 

There are so many thai restaurants in SF, and this is one of my favorite restaurant, at least for food delivery! :)
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Great authentic thai in the most random spot ever. Don't be intimidated to venture into the TL city newbies, we were so excited to see that there are fantastic spots south of Post street! Larkin is actually a great strip of ethnic food!

The papaya salad + prawns is surprisingly spicy and REALLLY delicious.

The Five spices duck was tender and good, although I felt like the "5 spices" in the name was going to pack a little more flavor punch.

The pork belly was kind of a let down, as it was either over crunchy or super fatty. Not my favorite pork belly ever, but everyone else at the table liked it. I had a hard time eating it, and I'll eat just about anything.

Overall, I liked it enough to return and try some new dishes. Great vibe, it made this NY transplant feel right at home. :)
author: Haley J.

description: I have a friend from Thailand who told me about this place. The food was delicious, and definitely one of the better Thai spots in SF. The pork shoulder is simply amazing and a must-have when you go.
author: E M.

description:
Food was delicious, unfortunately I had a bad reaction to the raw blue crab that my table ordered or was it the raw shrimp?!. It was my first time eating a raw crab. 

After our meal, everyone looked at me and stated I looked pale. I felt a little sick and excused myself from the table and went to the restroom. My body instantly rejected my whole dinner at Lers Ros Thai. 

I have never felt this way ever in my life. No more raw crab and no more Lers Ros Thai for me.
author: Chanel L.

description:
Name is difficult to pronounce correctly, but food is easy to love. Get the duck larb and pork belly! Both are out of this world. Pad thai is pretty good too, but I thought the curry was a little watery and lackluster. Green papaya salad is spicy and will kick your tastebuds in the butt.  The interior of this restaurant is clean and service is very friendly - very different from the neighborhood outside.

P.S. Eve W. - most restaurants, bars, heck buildings in SF do not have air conditioning because 11.5 months out of the year, they've got the marine layer/Karl the Fog to keep temps cool. Chill out :)
author: Bella L.

description:
We came into this place on a Wednesday night at around 7pm, and it was absolutely packed! Not surprising considering how many standing ovations it has received on Yelp. I must say that the reviews are mostly true. We ordered the much hyped-over Pork Belly, Green Curry with Chicken, and Eggplant. Every one of those three dishes were extremely well done. I especially loved the Pork Belly and Green Curry. Even though I did not consider the portions large, and two of us had no problem going through three dishes, I must say that this restaurant is great value for money as well! Three dishes and a glass of wine each put us back only around ~$30. Not bad for the best Thai meal I ever had in the city.

Service was great, and especially considering how bustling the restaurant was at that time, I didn't expect the food to arrive so promptly.

I will highly recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for good Thai food in San Francisco.
author: Clarence C.

description:
Went for dinner with some friends on a Friday night at 9:30pm. We were seated relatively quickly, and the service was very attentive.

I was impressed with their selection of dishes, I definitely had a hard time trying to choose what I wanted. Everything looked really great. I finally settled on the Cucumber Salad and Original Thai Style soup #109 ( I don't remember the full name) It was basically a seafood and vegetable medley in chili paste soup.

The soup was very disappointing. While the flavor was decent, it was mostly just broth and barely any filling. There were about 4-5 prawns and a couple florets of cauliflower. For 13.95 I was extremely disappointed. My boyfriend had ordered the Garlic and Pepper Rabbit special and while the flavor was good, the meat was extremely tough and a bit dry. Not very much either since they left all the bones in. The Garlic and Ginger fried rice was very good however. Another friend ordered the #58, 5 Spice Duck over rice. When her dish came out, there was about 1/2 a cup of diced duck on top of 4 cups of rice. The duck was also overcooked to boot.

I had heard a lot of great things about Lers Ros and I really wanted to like it, but the experience was really upsetting and the food was average at best. I could have gone to King of Thai Noodle or Osha Thai for better food at a better price. I'd give the place one more try, maybe it was just the things we ordered, but at a restaurant you shouldn't have dishes that are particularly bad anyways.

I will try the Hayes Valley location next time and see how that compares.
author: Maggie T.

description:
Hands down the best Thai food I've ever had - and it's cheap! A bit of a wait, but they do takeaway too.
I'd go for the crispy chicken over fried rice anytime.
author: Ruben B.

description:
Upon first entry, you'll hear the music. It's Top 40 music, with the likes of Katy Perry and Selena Gomez. You'll see the televisions playing NFL. And there's a bar if you desire some happy drinks while you chow on Thai food. For me, Lers Ros Thai missed that one critical element of being a good Thai restaurant, and it's the feeling that you're in Thailand. This place is great for late night post-clubbing/bar hopping bites, but it felt odd eating here on a bright Sunday afternoon. 

The food is okay. The Pad Kee Mao came with large portions and was overall delicious, albeit a bit pricey for being in the Tenderloin. It also came with a heaping portion of crunchy beansprouts. I mixed the plate's contents together, but a crunchy side salad might be yummy too. 

The Pad Phed was pretty good. Very flavorful with okay amounts of meat. But overall nothing spectacular.

And what's with waitresses asking for their chili condiments back while you're still eating? I just think that's unnecessary, especially when there aren't even that many customers in the restaurant. LET ME HAVE THESE GROUND PEANUTS.
author: Jason T.

description: One of my favorite Thai places in the city. Really fun atmosphere. Great presentation of food and definitely quality Thai food. Love the green curry.
author: Yasi N.

description:
The steamed whole sea bass here is the best!  Just based on that dish alone, I love this place.  A little pricey at $25, but you do get the whole fish and its super yummy.
I also had the chicken satay and pad thai - both of these were really good.  I was here on a Sunday evening and it wasn't crowded at all.  Service was great since they had so many servers but only 4 tables.
author: Michele S.

description: This place is my favorite Thai spot in SF. The pork shoulder appetizer is perfect -- love the sauce and it's just the right portion size. The lunch specials are also great. What I wasn't a fan of was the duck over rice (didn't like the sauce) or the infamous crispy pork belly as it was way too much fat. But, overall the place has an extensive menu and the service is excellent. The wait is usually long for dinner but I'm glad to see the place doing so well!
author: Siv L.

description:
These guys have a great menu with more authentic looking dishes than you can usually get at your run of the mill Thai joint in the USA. And as such, I would recommend to anyone trying this place for the first time to venture beyond their comfort zone. We got some interesting things like sauteed rabbit and spicy alligator (!) And of course on a menu that large there are going to be some duds. We tried this deep fried pork thing that was really bad because the bones were actually still in some of the pieces. We left that but seriously we had 9 other dishes that had rocked our socks off so we weren't about to make a stink about it.

I don't know whether I like this place or Sai Jai Thai better.. but they're so close to each other, who cares?
author: Josh K.

description:
We came here on a random Sunday night for dinner thinking it'd be slow, but the place was packed. We got lucky and got seated right away, but there was a line of people waiting after that.

We ordered the duck larb, pork belly, and pad kee mao with chicken. The duck larb was fantastic. Each piece of duck had a perfectly crispy piece of skin with all the fat rendered off and the flavors just blew me away. The pad kee mao and pork belly were good, but not as good as the duck larb.

Our server was really nice and patiently answered my numerous questions about the menu (it is quite extensive and can be daunting to pick a dish).
author: Jessie L.

description:
Oh my word! This restaurant's reputation totally precedes itself, so you better believe there will be a line out here for dinner on a Friday night. I felt like I was experiencing legitimate Thai home-cooking! The dishes I've had from Lers Ros Thai were savory with the perfect complement of spices and a very generous amount of vegetables served with the dishes I ordered. 

The dining space is small, well lit, and the servers do not fail in keeping your glass of water full along with their almost-tiresome questions of whether you're enjoying your food or not.

They definitely had the health concerns of  a patron in mind when they decided to toy with the menu! I recommend eating here if you're vegetarian, they are willing to substitute some un-vegetarian friendly parts for your dietary restrictions.

I would also like to give this place a recommendation for the adventurous foodie's stamp of approval since this restaurant serves frog, eel, alligator, and other unique Thai dishes with exotic meats on the menu. 

Order from their specials & "Original Thai Style" section if you want something new to grace your taste buds, and with that, I recommend trying their pad ped pla lai (thai eel), & krang phed yang. 

*thumbs up*
author: Jaye C.

description: My first review. Had a late dinner with a good friend here tonight. Was introduced to the duck curry it is delicious.
