The pad see ew is like any other Thai restaraunt (I can't complain I have to have it anytime I  have thai). Did not enjoy sitting on their chairs. I like the set up of the place as well.
author: David N.

description: Had a delicious Pad Thai here. I have tried several Thai restaurants across the US and this is one of the best. The portion was very filling. If you don't like spicy, ask specifically to have a nonspicy Pad Thai. I would come back here to try other items on the menu. Location is very nice and personnel kind.
author: Fede D.

description:
I had been griping for months that I was tired of the lunch places around my office.  But I read about this restaurant in a local magazine and ventured two blocks past my comfort zone and it was well worth it.  

They have great combo lunch plates offering a choice of two entrees with rice for $7.25.  The food tastes fresh and healthy.  The restaurant is clean and not overly crowded like the restaurants closer to the State building.  I also appreciate the attentiveness of the staff. 

This restaurant is now on my rotation and I can't wait to try their noodle dishes next.  I spied some at neighboring tables today and they looked yummy!
author: Jeannette W.

description:
It's as Thai as it gets!

The food was good and SPICY!  It's spicy even if it doesn't mention that in the description of a dish.
The staff was friendly.
For me personally, a big con is that it's in the Tenderloin...I think I must've gotten high just from smelling all the weed while walking a few block down from California St.
author: Dasha B.

description:
This place takes the cake!! Love love love.

I was in town for bay to breakers weekend and we were craving thai food! My friend suggested this place and after looking at reviews it was a no brainer we were going to try this place. 

Our group was pretty large and on a Saturday night, this place was PACKED!!!! We ordered about 6 or so dishes and everything was freakin amazing.  The tom yum soup had that spicy kick to it but it was SOOOOO good! you must get and they are known for their pork belly! 

GET IT GET IT GET IT! 

Overall this place is amazing.  I definitely recommend it to anyone and it is in the loin.  They also have one in Hayes Valley but this place is nice too.  Reasonably priced too.
author: Anna B.

description:
i went here for dinner...i love this restaurant so much..i ordered crispy pork which is good, the pork shoulder is also good..the pad see ew were perfect..and what i like the most is the steam sea bass..staff were friendly..

CONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED!
author: Aris L.

description:
Just popped in for a quick/late dinner alone.  

Had the herb sausage followed by the pork belly with basil, both on the nice waitress' recommendation.  Both very delicious.  Pics posted.

I can only imagine the rest of the food is as carefully prepared.  I'll be back.
author: Andrew R.

description:
We had the crispy pork belly!!!!! OMG, how can you go wrong with crunchy/crispy skin, meat and this yummy sauce? SO GOOOOOD

Red curry with duck: nice consistency in the curry. The perfect amount of thickness and the bamboo taste comes out really well. They didn't skimp on the duck meat either!

Other dishes I were the pad thai and papaya salad. Nothing too memorable about them. They were good, but nothing to rave about
author: Priscilla W.

description:
An impromptu Monday night dinner for 11? Not a bother for Lers Ros.

Pad Thai? Absolutely craveable (some of the best I've had in recent memory.)

Splitting the check over three credit cards and a pile of cash? Easily done and without a hint of attitude.

Likelihood I'll return? High.
author: Miriam W.

description:
I'm surprised I have not yet written a review for this place. I've come here twice - once on a date with the bf and the other for my law school grad dinner. This is also my roommate's favorite place.  I've always had a pleasant experience here, despite the long waits.  And you will most likely be waiting for some time before you get to eat.  The prices are a little on the high end for a Thai restaurant but I think most of what you are paying for is the experience to try exotic meats and dishes you normally wouldn't find in any other Thai restaurant.

The Garlic Frog here is great.  It's chopped up into small little pieces, fried, and served with a Thai chili sauce.  Frog can sometimes taste a little fishy yet retain the texture of chicken.  I didn't get that awkward fishy taste here and the meat was pleasantly juicy.
I've also had the Pad Thai, though I won't go into it since it's fairly easy for Thai restaurants to get right.  Let's just say that it was good.  

The duck curry is the bf's favorite here.  Sadly, they don't give you a lot of duck meat.  But whatever bits of duck meat you are able to scrounge up, you'll find that it is fairly tasty.  The curry itself is good - pretty consistent with every other Thai restaurant I've been to.

The Tom Yum Pla Kra Pong is terrific.  It is a whole sea bass in a sweet and sour soup served in a tub.  The fish is fresh and the soup goes so well over rice.  My mom also loves this dish, and that's saying something because she can cook her ass off in terms of this dish.  Well, my mom's cooking in general rocks but you get the gist.
I've heard the Duck Larb is the thing to try but surprisingly I have yet to try it.  I guess I have to come back soon!
author: Linh V.

description: The best Thai restaurant I have ever been to. Highly recommend the pork belly, fried crunchy chicken, and the pad see ew. The cucumber salad is extreme refreshing. Not in the best area so if you can drive or Uber, do.
author: Christina H.

description: six:thirty weekday arrival...tables available, but quickly filling...starting on slice pork shoulder $nine-ninety-five wonderful...perfectly cooked medium-well and tender meat...koh moo yang served with tasty seasoned fish sauce...sweet, tangy and toasty flavors...fried whole trout $sixteen.ninety-five a must order...crispy and simple salted...spine a crunchy treat...similar saucing compliments...delicious trout...pad see ew with chicken $nine-ninety-five...standard taste and preparation...larger portions being the benefit...red curry tasting typical $thirteen.ninety-five, but addition of succulent large slicing roasted duck a huge improvement...side of rice $one.fifty for curry saucing...this is great thai...$sixty-five total and enough food for three people...
author: Hen A.

description:
food is delicious here but the area is sketch!! I feel like it got more sketch but it could be just this night.  I loved the pork shoulder, tom yum soup, pad see ew with beef and the curry!!

I would suggest getting here either late or early becuase at dinner time it was packed!!!!
author: Toby I.

description:
I think it's good but I've had other better Thai in the city. The restaurant seems optimized for quick service and fast turnover, which is a good thing. The bathroom is located up a flight of stairs and down a hallway. There are no paper towels. On the bathroom wall someone wrote something like, "Can we have paper towels!?" Right underneath another wrote, "Wipe hands on pants. Save some trees." I agree that they need paper towels or at least some kind hand drier.

I had the beef green curry rice plate. The white rice was super fluffy. I'm not sure how they made the beef so succulent and flavorful. Overall the curry was tasty but the veggies seemed like an afterthought.

There are two flat screen televisions to entertain. One counter for the singles. I must say the service is excellent. I think the waiters were bored because it was an early dinner time. My glass of water never hit the halfway mark.

__

Good thai but I've had better. Maybe I'm missing something better on the menu. What's amazing is that they're open Monday thru Sunday 11am-12am.
author: Michael H.

description:
Delicious Thai with rich flavor that tasted like the real thing. We had papaya salad with salted egg, spicy and yummy though wasn't a star dish. Green curry with beef on garlic and ginger rice is fantastic. Pad kee mow with chicken was also top notch.

Funny location in mid TL, quite loud and tables are close together, but food is delicious.
author: Aki N.

description:
In the last year or so, Lers Ros has steadily risen to the top of my favorite restaurants list.  It's our go-to for take-out, but I find myself eating at the restaurant quite often too.

This is the place to go for real Thai food, not overly sweet, overly fish-sauced, and spicy enough to have me mopping my brow and shoveling the rice in as fast as I can.

Beloved dishes (more listed in my old review), include the curry puffs, fried sun-dried beef "jerky", green curry with fish paste, silver noodles, Poh Tak (Tom Yum with seafood) soup, spicy noodle soups, and favorite of all favorites and the most amazing dish ever: whole steamed sea bass in Tom Yum soup. 

Drool.  Love this place.
author: Joanne G.

description:
Finally tried this place out after one of my friends raved on and on about the food here, boasting about how he eats here on a weekly basis. And wow, my tastebuds were doing a happy dance throughout the whole meal!

Based on his recommendations, we first ordered the duck larb. So flavorful! In all honesty I had no idea what larb meant (I had to look it up), and to save you any confusion, it's kind of a sour and kinda spicy meat salad. This was my favorite dish of the night. A MUST try if you haven't already!

The pork shoulder was also amazing. The meat was already delicious on its own, but the sauce that it came with definitely knocked it out of the park.

Pork belly was perfectly cooked. The skin was nice and crispy while the meat was tender and flavorful. 

We also ordered the Pad Kee Mao. While it was a solid dish, it paled in comparison to the other dishes we ordered, and I would not likely order it again.

Neighborhood is not so great since its in the TL. (Is it just me, or are there a lot of really good restaurants here?) The wait time for two was fairly fast, but I'm not sure how long it would take to seat a larger party.

What I really like about this restaurant is that they serve tons of Thai dishes that I have never been exposed to. While they do still have your standard food (pan fried noodles, fried rice, curry, etc.), the stars of the show are all the obscure, less well-known dishes, which speaks volumes about the restaurant's authenticity!
author: Sally T.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant in the city his far. People say Thai food is all the same, pad see ew, pad thai etc. But this place is legit, they even serve the weird stuff like fermented veggies with innards soup! If you follow me on yelp you know I'm all about the adventurous dishes. The must try for me is the pork belly appetizer, the texture of the meat fantastic and the dipping sauce is a delicious pairing. Add a side order of the garlic ginger rice and you're set! And don't be scared of venturing to the tenderloin for this place, but if you are there's also two other locations in the city
author: Samantha C.

description:
After recovering from the devastating loss of my mayorship here, it's finally time to sing the praises of Lers Ros Thai, a frequent weekly stop. 

Is it in the Tenderloin? It sure is. Is it worth possibly getting mugged? ... maybe. Okay, yeah, yeah it is. This is Thai food that will blow all other generic places out of the water. 

When you step in, the place is bustling with activity, football flashing across TV screens (it is SF after all) and smiling servers. Reservations are smart for Fri-Sat but on weeknights, I've been able to walk in without a problem. Following are my fav dishes:

- PORK SHOULDER (salad or appetizer): The meat is perfectly tangy and fatty with a deep flavorful depth in each bite. There's plenty of slices for 2 people to share but paired with a side of rice, it's a great stand-alone entree
- PAD THAI: It's a classic for a reason and comes with a generous heap of bean sprouts
- PAPAYA SALAD: Beware of making it too spicy. The last few bites had me deliciously wailing but the flavors were fantabulous
- CRISPY CHICKEN OVER RICE: It's a little plain so plan to order some veggies but the tender breaded chicken completely melts in your mouth
- All of their curries and pan fried noodles are better than most Thai places you've been to, guaranteed
- Remember to top it all off with a refreshing glass of Thai Iced Tea

Next on my list is trying all of the game meats (boar, alligator, quail, etc) with a fellow adventurous soul. Hopefully with no vegetables in sight!
author: Faith Y.

description:
This restaurant is quite cool. It reminds me the way the area used to be before gentrification. Boy! this part of downtown has been severely gentrified. 

PROS: food is actually tasty and relatively easy to digest. Well balanced. Good to the nose and the mouth. Thai ice tea is balanced (not too sweet; just right). Menu gives you so many options in such an obscure language that pad thai is a good choice. Portions are big. Watch out.

CONS: found 2 pubic hairs. One in my little bowl of soup and one floating on my Thai Iced tea. I munch on people's ass. Couple of hairs is nothing. He he he... 

In summary:  I had a good time with plenty of food. You should too.
author: Emir A.

description:
*4.5 stars*

Lers Ros Thai may or may not be the best Thai food in the city, but it's definitely the most exciting. It's like homecooked Thai food amped up ten-fold -- there are Thai dishes I've never seen on a menu before, and there are variations to typical Thai staples that will blow your mind. The pungent flavors and fire-hot spiciness here are phenomenal, packing punches harder than with any Thai food I've had outside of Thailand. After my first visit, I was absolutely hooked, and now when I feel like eating Thai food, I'm essentially saying that I feel like eating Lers Ros.

------------------
FOOD:

Crispy Pork Belly = It's weird, this dish lacks consistency, even within the same plate. When the piece is done right, it's possibly the best crispy pork belly in the city. The spice, the intense flavor, the ultra-crispy skin, the tender meat -- it all just blends together perfectly. However, within the same plate, there are also pieces that are too tough, too dry, and too overcooked. There are also other pieces where the skin is soggy rather than crispy. It's really strange and somewhat disappointing. But because I know how DELICIOUS the good pieces are, I always keep ordering this dish and will probably continue to order this dish for as long as I eat at Lers Ros.

Yum Koh Moo Yang (Pork Shoulder Salad) = Tender pieces of pork shoulder that go incredibly well with the salad.

Papaya Salad w/ Grilled Prawns = My vote for the best papaya salad in SF. The spice level here is through the roof, making this a dangerous dish for people who can't handle their peppers. The prawns are well-cooked, the papaya is nice and crunchy, and everything just works together excellently.

Fried Quail = Pretty good. This dish rides a dangerously-thin line, since it could easily be tough and overcooked. I had pieces that were, for sure, but when it's done well, it's delicious.

Green Curry = Very good. Green curry is one of those dishes that's tough to get wrong, and Lers Ros definitely doesn't get it wrong. Again, the intense spice is what makes this a winner.

------------------

Lers Ros Thai breathes unique and exciting life into your typical Thai fare. With Basil Thai and Marnee Thai, among others, there's tons of great Thai food competition in the city; but Lers Ros is definitely the one that stands out for its ingenuity and boldness.
author: Roy C.

description: My favorite thai restaurant in San Francisco. Both TL and Hayes Valley locations are great. Definitely get the duck larb and pork belly. Branch out too because the offerings are huge.
author: Anthony D.

description:
Looking for Thai food but too drunk to walk or drive to pick it up? They deliver! They quoted one hour delivery time, but they delivered in 40 minutes. 

After reading the reviews I decided to give it a try. We ordered Pad Kee Mao, Pad Thai and Mango Sticky Rice. All 3 dishes were delicious! The Pad Thai had a rich flavor with a bit of sweetness. Add a dash or two of lime and it has a perfect taste!  

When I'm in the area and craving for Thai, but too _______ to pick it up or dine in this will be my go to spot for delivery!
author: Joanne C.

description: If I was reviewing this place so my toddler could understand:  Noodles and sweet & sour chicken ok.  Sticky rice with mango sweet good.  Papaya salad yummy fresh.  BBQ chicken sauce finger licking.  Lots of  money.
author: Peg S.

description:
Second time here. Food was awesome. They ran out of trout, so we ordered the sea bass, it was hugeeee... There were three of us we were overdosed with sea bass. 

2nd time:
Steamed Sea bass: 5 stars
Duck Larb Salad: 5 stars
Tom yum soup: 3 stars

1st time:
Crispy Pork Belly: 5 stars
Whole Fried Trout: 5 stars
author: Lyn X.

description: I ordered the prawn special that was flavorful and tasty. The ambiance was fun with live Thai music. Service was excellent and the menu had a great variety. Although I would have wished for more curry options, I love red curry and there was only one choice and it didn't interest me. The prawn dish was good with a nice spice and large prawns. I appreciated the beer selection as I hadn't had a singha since I was in Thailand. My friends had the rabbit and yellow curry which tasted mediocre. My husband had the beef onion pepper special and it had a nice taste too but not spicy at all. I'd return to this place again.
author: Gina B.

description:
first, lers ros should be pronounced 'LERD RODE'. it pains me every time to say 'LERSE ROSS' to people.

but lers ros is easily the best thai place in sf. adventurous authentic thai dishes. if you come here, you order the dishes that you're not familiar with. for example,

raw shrimp salad
crispy pork belly in basil sauce
po tak (spicy and sour soup with seafood)
nam prik (spicy spicy chili paste - thai version of hummus with tons of flavor)
steamed whole fish in lime sauce 

the list can go on and on. i love this place. they dare to make dishes that are more challenging and go beyond basic thai take-out menu.
author: Te R.

description: Experience here is always exceptional. Normally I like the fantastic whole fried fish but not tonight. Tom ka expertly seasoned and satiating ( for an omnivore eating lightly now), vegetarian fried rice: remarkable so much so I wanted to comment to my vegan friend it rated like it was tossed in duck fat. Amaze balls. To finish: sweet sticky mango rice. Delish flavors and the mango was very Mure and marvelous however the rice could've been a bit softer.
author: Aaron G.

description:
OVERALL:3.4   FOOD:3.5   SERVICE:3.5  AMBIANCE:3   VALUE:3.5

Underwhelming.  Was expecting fireworks and bells & whistles, based on the Yelp raves.....but only experienced lukewarm satisfaction.  Interior is a little stark, and definitely built for functionality and efficiency: hard plastic chairs, borderline cramped table layout, pretty barren floors & walls.  Not a deal breaker, but clearly less cozy than King of Thai (http://www.yelp.com/biz/king-of-thai-noodle-house-san-francisco-7#hrid:n6k58xksNR64R0KXM70yBw) & less chic than Basil Canteen (http://www.yelp.com/biz/basil-canteen-san-francisco#hrid:PJ6kQbodcHSx6z7v4xEE2g).  Hmmph.

Food was just OK.  Pretty disappointed with the Tom Kha Gai soup, which was eye-wateringly sour.  Got the distinct impression that they just sprinkled in a bit of coconut milk for color into Tom Yum soup...cheaters!  Wouldn't come back, except to try the weird animals on the menu (alligator, rabbit, etc).
author: Amy K.

description: Tried a few different items on the menu so far, all taste fantastic. Definitely recommend trying out. I have usually visited on odd hours,(late afternoon, before dinner) so there were no crowd and very little wait.
author: J Y.

description:
Ordering delivery from them has always been a pleasant experience. Plus they put the noodles and soup in separate containers when delivering so you know that they've got it all figured out.

But seriously, that beef boat noodle soup is laced with dope. I'm filled with a deep contentment as well as a slight drowsiness after just having finished a bowl.

It is not the best Thai ever, but it comes close.
author: Janet K.

description:
Despite the price increase (probably due to their second store in Hayes Valley), I am liking Lers Ros more and more.

What to Get Here:
Duck Larb (10.95) on 7x7's 100 Big Eat List!
Red Duck Curry (13.95)
Pad Thai (8.95)

The duck larb superbly demonstrates a dish that intricately balances thai herbs, flavorful sautéed duck, refreshing lime dressing made to be eaten in a lettuce wrap.  My review on the Red duck curry still stands!  It is well done and one of the best I've had in a Thai restaurant.  I loved the fresh bean sprouts in the pad thai - It made the entire dish refreshing not heavy or overly sweet.  The best pad thai I've had in San Francisco period. 

What to Skip:
I still don't get the hype about the pork belly.  Skip it!  Trust.

Lunch Specials:
A great deal available on weekdays!  Your choice of 2 items with house salad and steamed rice.  The above goodness, however, are not included.
author: Fei L.

description: Beef jerky was delicious! And my beef Pad Thai was amazing. Plus the variety of options available... Staff very friendly. Great find!
author: Vika S.

description:
As my first meal back in the Bay Area, I figure I should probably grab a bowl of noodle soup in the city.  For some reason the place I normally go to was closed, so we had to think fast about where to go.  Unwilling to give up our awesome parking spot, we noticed a little Thai noodle house down the street so we decided to grab some lunch there.

Seeking something relatively uncommon, I ordered some Thai duck noodle soup.  The duck was extremely tender but the portion was very small.  The same could be said about the portion of noodles as well.  The soup was pretty good but I think it was just a tad salty and wish there was a bit of sweetness to offset the flavor, but otherwise the meal wasn't half bad.

While it was unfortunately that our regular noodle soup restaurant wasn't open, there is such an abundance of good restaurants in the city that you could also pick just about any place and enjoy some pretty good food.  While not necessarily a standout, the bar is set so high in San Francisco that Lers Ros definitely gets a passing grade.

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 5/10
author: Joe M.

description: Had late dinner with friends here. It was super easy to make a reservation on their web site, and when we arrived, a table was ready. The 5 of us ordered 4 dishes (crispy pork belly with Chinese broccoli, papaya salad, pad kee mao, and pork larb) and a dessert (mango with sticky rice). Everything was on point in terms of flavor and presentation. We ended up paying about $14 per person excluding tip, which is pretty cheap for SF! I would totally come back here next time I am in the Bay Area.
author: Melissa S.

description:
I would give Lers Ros negative 5 stars if there were such an option!   Worst Worst Worst customer service I have experienced.  I don't trust a restaurant like this that treats its customers like they did to me.
We were hosting the one-year-old birthday party for my daughter, and we reserved Lers Ros for catering about 2-3 weeks before the party.  When I asked whether the restaurant could handle the catering, I specifically asked them (multiple times) if they were going to be open on the day of the party, and the answer was YES.  However, when I called to confirm my order 2 days before the birthday party, they first confirmed my order, but then just 5 minutes later, they called back and said they couldn't do it, because they were "remodeling" their kitchen.  We were totally shocked!  The woman I talked to on the phone had no explanation for why Lers Ros hadn't bothered to inform me about this before.    
So if I hadn't called to confirm my order, I'd have ended up having NO FOOD for my kid's party?  This is totally not acceptable.  We had to scramble over the weekend to find a replacement caterer.
author: Elena L.

description: Nice place but the two dishes I had were over the top spicy. Like "I can't feel my mouth I can't eat this anymore" spicy. I'm pretty good with eating spicy foods but this was so much that it totally affected my dining experience. And first impressions are important. I had the green curry and the spicy pad see yew. I didn't specify that I didn't want it that spicy but I've had enjoyable green curry at other thai places. My experience here wasn't enjoyable bc my mouth was on fire. The ambiance is nice though and servers are friendly. The service was fast. I would specify next time NOT to add the spiciness. Also the thai iced tea was $5 which is pretty expensive... They also charged $1.50 for the rice that is supposed to come with the curry. Like what!
author: Cherie L.

description: This is my go to Thai place recently remodeled it gets busy on Friday and sat night. My fav dish is the papaya salad soo good, all of the curries are amazing as well. Pra ram, pad Thai and pad se you also great. Must order mango with stick rice if in season.
author: Ribec F.

description:
I am amazed at how different this place is during the day versus the night.  The first time I went here was mid-day on a Saturday.  We were the only ones there and it looked like any other small restaurant in the tenderloin.  At night - the place has a totally different vibe.  Both were fantastic. 

Last night I got the duck larb after reading numerous reviews.  I had no idea what Larb was, but I'll try anything once.  I think I have a new favorite Thai dish.  It was spicy but sweet, too - crunchy and warm.  Listed in the salad section, I wasn't sure it would be enough for dinner, but it was perfect.  I opted for the sticky rice as per the waitress's suggestion.  It was a little difficult to eat wrapped in the lettuce provided, so I opted to just go at it with a fork.  I ate everything on the plate (save for the 3 chiles which were big enough for me to see and avoid).  There's a reason this place and this dish are so popular.

The place was busy but we didn't have to wait long for a seat.  The staff was so nice - helping us choose our dishes (and the best way to eat them).

Definitely going back soon
author: Lilly N.

description:
Take out order took over an hour to deliver eight blocks, pricing was completely different from the price listed on the website and the portions didn't even fill up the take out containers (see pictures). ????

Delivery guy apologized for the delay and said he would tell the manager to update the website, which is apparently months behind the new prices. Cranky but starving, we open the chicken satay, tofu pad see ew, pad makuer tofu and kai himaparn. 

Um.

Yum.

Best thai I've had in SF so far.

The portions are dinky though and be patient when you order take out.
author: Kim K.

description:
Was in San Francisco for a few days, tried different restaurants in the are, this was probably my favorite. For those unfamiliar with the area the area immediately surrounding this place is not the safest area in town at night. Prostitution  and drug use are common just a block or two away. 

But when waiting outside or eating inside the restaurant there were no issues. It's a great Thai place. The line was long when we arrived but the food moves fast and so do the tables. Tons of different dishes to chose from and they were all great. Highly recommend to anyone coming to the San Fran area looking for an authentic feeling and authentic Asian food location.
author: Paul T.

description: A teacher of mine recommended this place when she found out that I was going to San Francisco, and boy am I glad that she did. My red curry had tons of flavor and spice, just the way I like it. My friend also liked her pad see ew with beef. Cute place and good service. I would recommend trying this place out.
author: Sienna S.

description:
Food looks traditional , but the appear is really fusion.  This place is the bomb. I love the food and the people work there. Also, the food came out really fast too. 
I order the Kao Kai Yang. it's BBQ marinated chicken, served with sweet chili sauce rice plate. I have the brown rice rather than the white. The chicken wing is huge and really tasty, I love it.
author: Isabelle L.

description: Hands down some of the best Thai food I've had. I had the Pad Woon Sen and pork balls and they were delicious!
author: Janie G.

description: Really good food but the service is pretty slow.  No one tells you what's going on either.
author: Elsie T.

description: Pad See-ew medium is pretty spicy. Kao Mun Kai Tod, the chicken is good but a bit off, can't really put my finger on it, most likely the batter they use. Overall great Thai food!
author: Mason T.

description: Absolutely amazing.  I highly recommend this place to any and everyone. If you love Thai this is the place to go
author: Kristin V.

description: Excellent Thai food..... the wild boar was excellent as was the pork shoulder, especially the dipping sauce. The yellow curry had a very rich flavor, lots of coconut milk, which I really enjoy. Lots of color and flavor on every plate, with very friendly and prompt service, and good prices to match. So far, my favorite Thai in the city.
author: Robert B.

description:
The power of Yelp to bring people together can never be underestimated as I had the pleasure of joining a total of 25 Yelpers from Stockton, Los Angeles, East Bay and San Francisco at a recent Private UYE that included Maybelline C, Anthony N and his sister Linda, Valerie C,  Jenny B, Shannon F, Amy C and her boyfriend Jason, Tom R, Toni M and husband Alan, Paul K, Tammy C, Marti L and boyfriend Sam, Danny L, Jonathan W and girlfriend Marie G, Maureen G and husband Bob, Hube N, Manabu M, Sarah O, and Alma R. Everyone arrived promptly and we were seated at the center table which was vertically arranged that stretched from the kitchen door all the way to the front entrance. With seating arranged by the level of spiciness, I had the pleasure of surrounding myself with Toni, Alan, Manabu and Shannon. 

By studying the menu in advance, we were able to order 20 family style dishes with many that were doubled to feed the size of our group. To name a few highlights, I enjoyed the Chicken Satay, Thai Herb Sausage, Fried Spare Ribs, Pork Belly, and Ginger with Chicken, Sliced Tender Beef with Young Peppercorn and Galingale, and chunky Frog with Basil Leaves. My absolute favorites were the spicy fried Tilapia and tender Sea Bass where the meat fell off the bones ever so beautifully. The Red and Green Curries and Curry Puffs that looked like samosas were really outstanding too.

The dishes that I thought needed improvements were the Green Papaya Salad with Raw Crabs and the Spicy and Sour Seafood Soup which was too sour for me. The Beef Tendon Stew was not a good choice as it was difficult to share, and I thought the Eggplant was decent but not the best I've had. I didn't have a chance to sample the Pad Thai and Pad See-Ew but they looked pretty good too. Several people had complained about the clams, but otherwise people were super full by the end of the meal. My side dish of prik nam pla was powerful as I always appreciate the chance to boost my level of spiciness up another notch. 

Service was a bit inconsistent throughout the meal. They were a bit understaffed and the wait time between each dish was filled with gaps here and there. On the other hand, I also appreciated the fact that they went out of their way to buy crabs from the market in the morning just so we could have it, and they were extremely generous for not charging us a mandatory gratuity and cake cutting fee in the end. They went above and beyond to serve us by keeping our fresh cherries and saint honore cake refrigerated, and without asking they provided us fresh plate settings whenever it was needed--including dessert which we didn't order from them. In the end we had the chance to get out of our seats to mingle with each other, and this also allowed us to take over the entire restaurant with plenty of room to roam. The restaurant was also airing the World Cup at the time which further added to the festivity as people reacted to the different phases of the game.

It wasn't a perfect meal by any stretch of the imagination. I think their evening chef might be better but I also believe we couldn't ask for better service given the size of our group. In the end we each paid $27 including tax and gratuity--not bad considering the range of dishes we were able to cover throughout the meal. I'm very thankful for all the Yelpers who attended the event, and for Jonathan W's fresh picked Brentwood cherries and Manabu M's invitation to hang out at the rooftop of his home to overlook the skyline afterwards. Maybelline, Anthony and Valerie were wonderful organizers that brought everyone together. It was a memorable meal as Lers Ros has once again proven to be my #1 go-to Thai restaurant ahead of all others.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I stopped by my favorite Thai restaurant in the city around 8 PM on a Thursday night and slipped in with a party of 3 with no wait at all.  The service was quick and attentive, love this place.  We ordered chicken pad thai, two servings of brown rice, red curry with roasted duck, and the pork belly (Mmmmm pork belly).  Everything was delicious, per the usual.  Yes this place is in the sketch TL, but if you're headed to Larkin and O'Farrell you should know what to expect.  

But for those who are still squeamish about making the trek to this part of town, there's always the Hayes Valley location or better yet this fine establishment also delivers....Hello pork belly heaven in the comfort of your own home!
author: Monica C.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in SF.  Of course, it's located in the Loin.  Doesn't scare me during the day, but scares the bejeebees outta me at night.  Do not park "around the corner" and attempt to walk here alone at night unless you are armed with some nunchucks and a machete.  Don't let that stop you from coming though, the food is delicious!

The two best things at this place:
* Thom Kha Kai, a perfect blend of spice and coconut milk.  It comes out in a flame pot and stays hot the entire meal.  Do NOT reach across the middle...the flame is blue and almost invisible.
* Crispy pork belly. Delectable!

Add these two dishes to a noodle and a rice dish and you will have yourself a perfect thai meal.  Noms.
author: Susan L.

description:
I walked in and Lers Ros smelled like fish sauce, and I knew I had finally found great Thai food in the US.  The menu is exciting and reasonably priced.  We shared the Pad Kee Mao with chicken, Green Curry with chicken, and the Pad Makuer Tofu (eggplant dish).  Everything was delicious.  I could have used some more heat on the pad kee mao and the green curry, and wish that they had the chili flakes/vinegar/sugar/fish sauce condiments that are everywhere in Thailand.  On the other hand, I wasn't crying from the spice level so it was probably for the best.  

The place was packed by 7:15pm on a Monday night, so I recommend making a reservation.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Rachel A.

description:
I'm feeling generous today.. so Lers Ros gets 5 stars from me. I've been here about a handfull of times and all times have satisfied me immensely. Although, the last time they were out of Thai Curry Puffs which was disappointing, but I found a way to live. Haha. 

I've tried a variety of things on their menu and I've enjoyed most of what I have ordered. My personal favorites are the Thai Curry Puffs for appetizer (a delectable treat, enough to go around), the Pork Belly which is yummy in my tummy, the Duck Larb which is a hit (I always order this when I bring someone new here), and any fresh fish dish. I'm a big seafood person and I love me some fish. 

The only downside of this restaurant would be the parking, it's a hit or miss. Some days are good and some days are bad. The neighborhood can be questionable at times, but please don't let that deter you. There is 'usually' a wait and if you're lucky, no wait or a very short wait. But again, don't let that deter you. It will be worth it. It is one of the better Thai restaurants I have been to and that is around. It is the closest to authentic with a warm welcoming environment (because the staff is always friendly) and the food is always good. Can't get much better than that.
author: Rochelle F.

description:
The Gist:
I came here after watching Check Please! Bay Area. I loved the Herb Sausage. I wasn't impressed by the garlic rabbit or the spicy noodle, but I shall return!

The Tale of the Girl Who Dined with Peter Rabbit Before a Giants Game:
After watching, Check Please! Bay Area, I had to check this place out. Boyfriend and I got off Civic Center and walked over and arrived at 4:50pm on a Tuesday. 

We ordered the house special, Garlic Rabbit and Spicy Noodle. We also tried out one of the recommendations from a Check Please! reviewer: Thai Herb Sausage.

I appreciated that the food came out in good time.

The sausage was definitely the highlight of the meal. I liked eating the sausage with the dainty slices of chili pepper, mixed with some cilantro, peanuts, and ginger. It was spicy! The small pieces of lime helped quell my self-induced, tongue-burns, however as dainty as the lime slices were, it was kind of annoying how small they were, and they were difficult to hold onto while peeling the lime flesh with my enormous teeth. Maybe I should have just popped them in my mouth. I might have misjudged the significance of dining etiquette. 

Boyfriend was quiet throughout dinner, thinking about the Thai Iced Tea that never came. 

Next we had the spicy noodle, which maybe after the awesomeness of the Herb Sausage didn't really compare. We were looking for something new and interesting. Spicy noodle wasn't that interesting. It had a few bits of red bell pepper. 

Simultaneously, we had the Garlic Rabbit. It tasted like chicken. I've had a similar Filipino chicken dish. Small pieces of chicken deep fried golden. And just like in the Filipino dish, there were small bits of bone shards once every 6 pieces. I was eating the meat carefully, because I didn't want to eat bones. I had to carefully eat around the bones, even though they easily could have chewed. Eating the small bits of rabbit took a long time. Can bone shards cut your GI epithelia? **

In fact, after one minute of waiting to see if the waitress would look over to figure out we wanted our check, I walked straight up to the lot of them huddling in a circle and held out my card. Then, we sped walked to AT&T park to get our free snow globes. Almost missed the snow globes by 10 minutes(I watched from above timing it). And exactly at bottom of the 6th inning, I finally dislodged the last of the rabbit bone shards from my teeth.

Like the last two reviews I've posted recently, I would come back! Even rabbit bone shards have not pacified my interest to try out new menu items! (Eating REAL Filipino food emboldens me to try out anything!) I wish more Thai restaurants would offer more interesting things!

And like my last review, I'm holding out on my 4- or 5-star rating until I'm really impressed. For the credit of the Garlic Rabbit, if I was at home with my family, watching the game on my couch, I probably would not have minded snacking on Peter Rabbit.

** http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1790837/
author: Poiuytrewq A.

description:
(See pics)

Came back here for Daniel L, May C, Val C and Anthony N,'s UYE, a party of 25. It was a fantastic union of food and other Yelpers and friends.

They were so nice to line up tables in 1 long row with one end spicy gradually progressing to the non-spicy. The restaurant was very accommodating to set this up so that we are all sitting together like a private dining room!

This time I got to try out so many dishes and they were all very good and authentic. We had so many dishes that I could not remember most of them but see pics as my phone got fat with me! The spicy dishes were perfect without burning your palate but made you dream and experience the cuisine like you were transported to a foreign land.

Service was impeccable as they came in appetizers and soup, then main courses with a break and change in fresh silverware and plates 3 times! We all felt like we were at an Asian banquet! And they always serve food prompt and with a great friendly smile.

They even helped keeping a cake that the great Yelpers provided in the fridge so that we all can have the really fancy dessert!

Above all, great thanks (hands clapping) to Daniel , May, Val and Anthony to show us such a great place with your love, setting up, ordering all these wonderful dishes and all the mingling with everyone!
author: T L.

description:
It's real Thai food!!

Well, I just have to say that this is one of my favorite Thai restaurants in SF. They even serve other authentic Thai dishes not listed on the menu!!

I've never had a bad meal here. Everything is reasonably priced and the portions are very good. The food is always fresh and the flavors are robust.
It's one of the few restaurants where you can't go wrong trying anything on the menu.

The restaurant is clean and easy to find, right in the heart of the loin, and the staff is always friendly and helpful.

My fave is the cat fish salad along with the usual gai pad ga prow.

Me love you long time!
author: Sam H.

description:
Great if you like your curries rich and spicy!!! I get the green curry a la carte with a side of rice and it is enough for two full meals. For a price range on par with other Osha's, Lers Ros just simply tastes better. 

The place is popular and has always been packed, so I recommend ordering to-go.

Small caveat: the eggplant used in their dishes are the small round kind, kinda tough and full of seeds (which are edible though).
author: Monica Z.

description: Really great place! The service was fast and the atmosphere was pleasant. Tom kha kai soup was delicious and plenty for 4 people, pad kee mao and pad see ew were delicious along with red curry prawns. To a degree, Thai food is Thai food, but this place is a definite spot to hit despite the neighborhood.
author: Priya S.

description:
Happened in on this spot on a walk from The Phoenix. Had a different destination in mind, but the vibe emanating grabbed us and brought us in.

Favorites were a Papaya salad with raw crab, spicy and tangy, and trout with mango sauce that was a beautiful combination of sweet and salt.
author: Kandace B.

description:
How to review a restaurant when it's the site of a terrific UYE??  Daniel L and Maybeline C were the fantastic hosts of a lunchtime gathering at this restaurant today.  We had a loooong table and the spice level was graduated.  On our end was mildly spicy and the spice level increased progressively down the table.  

The food, which Daniel and May ordered ahead of time, was flavorful and varied.  I can't describe all the dishes, but there was nothing I tasted that was less than unique and flavorful.  We started w/ a clear seafood soup w/ lemongrass flavored broth full of prawns and fish balls and calamari.  It was wonderful.  There were two different fish dishes, a chicken satay, a green papaya salad w/ crab and more interesting and varied dishes than I can recount.  Suffice it to say we were well fed.  

The World Cup was on the TV and those facing it could keep up w/ the USA-Ghana game.  Some were very engaged w/ the game while others weren't, but it provided an interesting counterpoint to the meal.  There was a charming contingent of Yelpers from LA, which was cool.  Service was quietly attentive and efficient.  It was a lovely, festive gathering and Alan and I were happy to be included.  I enjoyed meeting Tom R. in person and having more of a chance to chat w/ Shannon F. and Daniel as well as to meet folks who were new to me.  Daniel and May were the consummate hosts and the food was stellar.
author: Toni M.

description:
Didn't get the chance to try the food, but if you want delivery, try somewhere else! 
I gave the address to 4 different people, each who put me on hold after I gave them the address. One seemed like she just put the phone down mid conversation to ring a customer out. Extremely rude on the phone and very apparent they did not want my business. 
Ended up hanging up and called King of Thai Noodle House. The lady who picked up the phone was EXTREMELY friendly, took my address down in one try, and got my order in swiftly yet friendly. 
Would not order delivery from this place, or even think about going in if they don't care to take in my business. Try somewhere else, there's plenty of Thai places around here with better service!
author: ANHDAO N.

description:
Hands down amazing. This little gem is a must-try and I want to come back and eat every dish they make. I am a sucker for thai food and this one stands out to me as exceptional.

So besides the amazing delicious food (I had Pad-Thai-Pak and shared some of the shrimp curry) the presentation is very good, the ambience is nice, though a little strange the way you sit shoulder-to-shoulder with strangers, and the service was great!

Please do yourself a favor and try this out.
author: Nick F.

description:
Not sure that I'll add much that hasn't been said already, but so grateful to have found this place. Thanks Yelp!

We're back home in SF after a few years in NYC (where there didn't seem to be any truly excellent S.E. Asian food) and set out to find a new favorite in SF for regular take out Thai.  

This place has exceeded all hopes that we had: I've eaten many home-cooked meals in Thailand and the flavors at Lers Ros are reminiscent of those amazing Thai dishes.

We've had fewer than 10 meals there, so I can't recommend too many specific dishes yet, but a few early favorites are:

-Eggplant stir fry with tofu: the scent of it alone is off the hook.
-Pad See Ew with chicken: Just right, not too heavy, greasy or overly browned like some others'.
-Papaya salad: spicier than most and very very fresh.
-All three of the "primary" curry colors.
-Their sticky rice has been perfect every time.

For the sensitive: their food runs authentically spicy; some items can be dialed down on request, and some cannot.

We're loving this place, and hope that they maintain this level of quality for many years to come.  Now, if I could just find somelace that offers an authentic Thai massaman curry...
author: David B.

description:
There are SOOOO many items on the menu, its really RIDIC!!! Makes it incredibly overwhelming and frustrating if its your first time and you all you want to do is eat! 

I quickly scanned the menu featuring something like a whowhos list of zoo animals rather than Thai dishes: alligator, rabbit, duck, boar, venison, pork shoulder, pork belly, sea bass, frog, whattttt?? Omg and then there was the fried curry puffs and the other usual thai go-tos. 

Ughhhh.. you know what, self?? This is freaking STRESSFUL!!! I GIVE UP. I'm just going to order a Thai iced tea cause I'm thirsty as hell and I will let the bf order whatever he wants. I looked across the table at him- his eyes were slanted, his eyebrows furrowed, wrinkles formed across his forehead studying the menu like his life depended on it. He closed his menu, set it aside, and said "I GIVE UP. I CAN'T LOOK AT THIS. YOU ORDER."

DAMMMNITT!!! He beat me to the punch, so I had to order... 

Pork shoulder "salad", which was really a ton of pork shoulder served on top of a pc of romaine lettuce, mixed with herbs and dressing. Delicious nonetheless. Smoky, spicy, crunchy with a fatty lining. Mix with rice and you're gold. 

Pad see mao served with a ton of bean sprouts. It smelled delicious the second it was placed on the table. But wait for the...

WHOLE DEEP FRIED TILAPIA!! is awesome for good eats on the cheap cheap. They GUARANTEE your fish is fresh ta death everyday too!! At $13.95, this thing is a BEAST, perfect for sharing, or if you're a beast, you can have it all to yourself, head, fins, eyeballs, tail and all. O yea, other tables will be eye-fcking your tilapia with jealousy and you'll just look back at them like o yea buddy. That's right. Don't hate.

I ate so much I started seeing double. Doubles are good. 

Brown or white rice available.
OPEN TILL 12AM EVERYDAY!!
author: Angela W.

description: In the Tloin.  Quality ingredients and real Thai not American Thai.  I had the alligator and the veil.  Definitely worth a visit in sf for a spicy meal
author: Michael O.

description: Saw their ad on a seat back TV on a United flight to LAX. Was looking for a group dinner restaurant in SFO later that week so we made the reservation. 8 people all had great meals. Lots of positive comments and two meals taken to go for others. Great job Lers Ros, we'll definitely be back!
author: Dan O.

description: The food was great, I'll definitely go again. Our server decided that she no longer wanted to care of us and ignored us.
author: Claire R.

description:
My go to neighborhood Thai place. This place gets a bit busy at night so I usually order take out. Large menu with very authentic food from what I have been told. The pork belly is fatty but oh so good. 

Pad Thai, Pad See-Ew, Fish Cakes, Tom Yum Koong are a few of my favs. 

Way better than Osha and King of Thai. Area is sketchy but the food is worth it.
author: Linda L.

description: Back for more of those Koh Moo Yang.
author: Taffany H.

description:
My fans know I'm a Thai connoisseur so when I heard of Lers Ros I had to try it. Restaurant was packed on a Sunday night with lots of big families: first good sign.  Since it was our first time I decided to go with some basics although the menu is pretty amazing, not your typical Thai menu. Ordered: tom yum with prawns, fried rolls, smoked pork, pepper beef, pad Thai, seafood in curry and for dessert fried banana with vanilla ice cream. 

TOP 3: soup, smoked pork, peppered beef
Ok: pad Thai, fried rolls, fried banana
Won't order again: curry with seafood

You have to get the Soup!!!! Best I've had. Their pad Thai could be seriously improved. They were out of sausage and coconut ice cream :(


 Good prices and friendly service. I'm coming back to try other stuff. 

Thanks Lers Ros!
author: Fabiola H.

description:
Came here with a couple friends for dinner and had a great time.  Our waitress was very attentive and got us our food pretty quickly.  The plates were very large, which made the food look kinda small, but the portions were decent and the food was delicious.

We had the alligator special 'cause I thought it sounded cool, but it was really chewy, so it kinda just tasted like chewy chicken or something.  Kinda meh.  Our favorite dish was the fried sun-dried beef appetizer that we ordered.  It was like beef jerky, but juicier and very nicely seasoned.  

I'd definitely come check this place out again, but it was a bit pricey (or maybe that was just 'cause of the alligator...)
author: Keith C.

description: So this place is in the tenderloin so I was apprehensive, but when I got there they were packed! They have really good food and even better pricing. They have good lunch specials. Their portions are a little small but the food is good. Excellent peanut sauce, even better chicken satay. The food took a little while to prepare but when it came out it was good.
author: Jannet H.

description:
Where is a wheel barrow when you need one? Well that's what we could have used to have hauled all of our overly stuffed self's away form this fabulous place! 

Thanks to Daniel L, maybelline C. Anthony N. and Valerie C.They really did a fantastic job on finding a perfect gathering place for us yelper's to indulge in some wonderful food. 

This place is cute and small but with a decent amount of seating. It's certainly nothing fancy though, nice and well kept. 

I really can't recall what half of the dishes were called, though I do believe we just about covered every item on the menu. 

There seemed to be about 20 people that joined us this day, as well as 20 different dishes we indulged in. 

The appetizers were delightful. Our first trying was of some sort of stuffed puff treat that came with a dipping sauce- It was soft and chewy and incredibly flavorful. The Thai Herb Sausage was quite tasty though, a little too spicy for my liking. The Chicken Satay was great -Chicken was cooked well, flavor was nice and the peanut sauce is always a great companion. 

Garlic Frog (My first trying of frog legs) was surprisingly delicious- Crunchy, yummy and jam packed with savory flavor. 

The Som Tom Poo- Which is shredded green papaya salad with tomatoes and raw crabs. This was nice but definitely not my favorite- The salad had a nice fresh flavor unfortunately, I just really was not crazy about the raw crab parts mixed with in it (which seemed to have a scarce amount of meat as well) 

The Phad Thai was phenomenal! I have only had Phad Thai a few times and this one has to be one of the better ones I have tried. 

There was some kind of Lemongrass soup with scallops, clams and shrimp that was tasty in a very refreshing way, a little overwhelming with the lemongrass, though still light and flavorful. 

A Red Curry dish that was incredibly delicious - Still on the spicy side though not enough to push it away-very nice!! 

A sea bass dish that was outstanding!! The fish was cooked perfectly to where it just fell of the bones and the flavor was fantastic!! 

Overall, most of the dishes were outstanding! The service was exceptionally attentive as well as genuine and sincere and of course mingling with the ever expanding family of yelpers was the highlight of the day!
author: Shannon H.

description:
Wow. Seriously best Thai food I have ever had.  The place is always packed and the waitresses are so so kind.  I don't even know what to recommend because everything is amazing.  
Definitely order the brown steamed rice instead of white.  I don't eat pork but my friends were dying over the pork belly dish.

Best Thai!!
author: Veronica J.

description:
Lers Ros. Best Thai food I've had in my LIFE. This place screams authentic and you can tell that right away by glancing at the menu. You can't read any of it!

Of course there's always a wait for good food, but one thing you'll notice is how LOINY it is. I think we waited a total of 20 minutes...not too bad.

We relied heavily on Yelp to help choose our dinner and the outcome was this:

DUCK LARB and the PORK SHOULDER are a must order! These 2 items are the reason why Lers Ros shot up to the top of my Thai restaurant totem pole. I can't even explain. Just order it and embrace the delicious experience.

We also ordered the PAD KEE MOW and the PORK BELLY. These dishes were really good as well. I guess not everything can be amazing, but they were for sure high quality Thai dishes.

It was a bit cramped inside, but it is the city so don't expect to be able to do cartwheels. I will definitely come back to Lers Ros soon!
author: David P.

description:
Best Thai I've ever tasted.

Word to the wise: order the tom kha with prawns and the crispy pork belly with basil.
author: Jay S.

description:
Duck Larb.

Honestly, I'm really excited to write this review. I loved the Duck and I'm excited to come by another time and try out other things from their pretty extensive menu. Unforunately, I am not an SF native, but this place is definitely on my list to come back to!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: we have lunch at Lers. we ordered fried fish, duck salad, chicken xx(in appetizer), sticky rice with mango, and fried banana with coffee ice cream. They served quickly. They are all good. I love duck salad. But, my friend love their fried fish and fried banana very much. We made a right choice to eat there.
author: Xiuxiu X.

description: I wish this place was closer to me otherwise I'd probably go there every day! If you want authentic thai food this is your place. The menu is extensive with so many things to try. When i was went we ordered something with the pork belly ( sorry I cant remember the name) but i was the best because the pork belly was fried. We also ordered the coconut soup ( sorry don't remember the name of this one either) which was spicy. If you are brave enough to come to the TL at night you have to check this place out. They always have a long line to get in so please plan accordingly. Trust me you won't leave this place unsatisfied.
author: Matthew L.

description: First time having Thai food and it was great! This place has a cool environment & the food is very traditional. Came in on a Monday and it was quite busy.
author: Syboney C.

description: The Tom Kha Kai soup was really good and hit the spot for me.. esp on a cold SF day. It seemed like a Olive Garden's endless soup deal!!! We split it amongst just two of us, and had 3 bowls each and it didn't even look like we made a dent! Fantastic! I love the little hot pot concocotion that it was in! The Rad Nah was good, a bit salty and didn't have enough noodle to pork ratio. The bbq chicken and chili sauce was good but overdone. Customer service was great!
author: Jenna L.

description:
I just came here on a Saturday night and the place was packed! Despite the crowd, we were told that we would have a table in 15 minutes--which was unlikely, and turned out that we waited much longer. Much. 

Despite the long wait, we then treated ourselves to some of the best dishes on the menu. 

The Duck Larb - Still a favorite! Little diced pieces of duck combined with cilantro, red onions, and spices in a lime dressing is excellent. We tend to eat it like lettuce-wraps, but that could be just us. 

Pork Belly - After a whole evening of discussing when we first discovered our love of pork belly dishes--we had to give this one a try! This was not a disappointment--in fact, there was just the right amount of crispness to the pork belly in a spicy sauce. 

Tom Yum Soup - This was a tad a bit too spicy for me. As much as I enjoy Tom Yum, I could barely taste it over the spice. I will remember to tell them to tone it down next time on the soup. 

As for desserts....

Fried Banana with ice cream - The fried bananas were in crispy shells with ice cream on the side. Did I mention there are ice cream choices? Vanilla, Pistachio and Toasted Almond were among some of the choices. We went for Toasted Almond, and it went perfectly with the friend bananas. 

Crystal Chestnuts - I've never seen or heard of a dessert like this before, but it showed up on so many foodspotting pics we had to check it out for ourselves. It's a dessert dish with shaved ice and coconut milk with gel-covered chestnuts in the dessert. I actually liked it but I think my friends weren't superfans of it. Once the fried bananas showed up, they were all over that, instead. Whatever! More for me! 

All-in-all a great place for food. As an afterthought, we considered whether it would be a great date place. All things considered, if you're still getting to know each other, it's a little busy and loud to go on one of your first dates, but if you're just there for good food and don't mind a wait, this might work out for you.
author: Lorraine D.

description: Went here with a group of 5 and did family style. The food came out very fast comparatively to most Thai restaurants and the dishes were all on point. We had the Tom Kha Kai soup (delicious), green curry, pork shoulders, pad see-ew, and another pork dish. Most things were spicy but tasted authentic from what friends said. The service was also excellent. We went during prime time dinner and they still made sure our meal was what we wanted and checked in with us at the end. Will definitely come back.
author: James L.

description:
We came here once and had 3 solid dishes:
- chicken satay was perfect and tender with loads of flavor. The dipping sauces were good, not watered down.
- pad see ew was stir fried well, but the veggies were underdone. Imagine chomping down on hard pieces of Chinese broccoli.
- pork and bell pepper stir fry dish my husband got was delicious and spicy.

My annoyance is when an Asian restaurant nickel and dimes their customers. Rice: $2. Tea: $1. Sheesh. At least tell us it cost extra?!
author: Wendy T.

description:
DELICIOUS!!! Do not be scared to come here because it is in the Tenderloin!

I have come here twice and both times, I have left very satified. The Tom Yum Koong (lemongrass soup) is the best! The soups are big enough for two people.

The rice dishes also look very tasty.
author: Tania D.

description:
I wanted to like Lers Ros. After reading glowing reviews, I was prepared for an awesome experience with great food. The reality is that Lers Ros is OK at providing meh service and OK food.

My first major complaint is with whoever is in charge of seating customers. I get that it can be incredibly hard to take down a list of walk-ins and seat guests based on availability. I am super patient and have no issue waiting 20+ minutes to be seated - I get it. What I am not patient towards is when the individual in charge of managing that list seems incapable of doing it correctly. On two separate occasions I have arrived, put my name on the list, and watched as my wait time moved from 20-50 minutes as groups who arrived after me were seated. Both times when I complained I found my name had already been scratched off.

As for the food - it is just OK. Is it the best Thai food I have ever had, no. Is it worth a 30-40 minute wait in the tenderloin, no. In fact I would say it is comparable to Osha Thai, with the addition of more frog and alligator on the menu. 

Finally, they have done a great job making the dining area look great (except for the backless stool tables) - However, I wouldn't recommend using the restrooms. The process of navigating to them and their upkeep is what made a 3 star review a 2 star review.
author: Joseph A.

description:
I hate to give bad reviews, but I had one of the worst meals here. I'm sure they have delicious options on their menu, and I usually like to compare places based off a common dish i.e. pad thai, but this time I made the mistake of ordering something off their current "Specials" menu. Their Lers Ros combo platter was underwhelming for the price, but the most disgusting dish was the garlic pepper rabbit. Something that is considered a delicacy should never be fried to oblivion where you can no longer tell what it is. There was no mention on the menu that it was deep fried and that it had so many bones. There was so little meat in all the fried gunk that Panda Express orange chicken can put this dish to shame. Having more fried gunk than meat is a complete cop-out to hide something that clearly tastes unfresh. I cringingly ate half of it because I was starving and tried to give it a chance. DO NOT ORDER their specials here. Literally one of the most disgusting and laughable excuses for a dish served at a reputable restaurant. Maybe they should saute or broil the meat so you can actually taste it? What are they trying to hide?

Overrated.
author: Jon T.

description:
Very authentic Thai food in San Francisco. 

Make sure order mild if you can't eat spicy food. Their spicy levels are mild, medium and spicy. If you don't ask them, they make it medium spicy for you. I'm Thai and feel their medium is sometimes too spicy for me.  

My favorite dishes here: BBQ pork shoulder (the secret sauce is called "Jaew"), Pork belly with basil, steamed bass with garlic and chili. 

Minus one star for use of MSG. I'm allergic to MSG. You can tell them not to add MSG to the food.
author: Saran R.

description:
Clean/modern little Thai restaurant, right in the hood.  If you don't mind passing crazy people talking to themselves, this place is pretty decent.  

My husband isn't a fan of Thai food, but he loves crispy pork belly in any country, prepared any style.  Since we saw they had this on the menu, we decided to give the place a try.

Avoid the curry puffs. They're kind of gross.  Pad Kee Mao was decent.  Papaya Salad was good.  Crispy Pork Belly was pretty dry.  

The service was kind of weird.  We were the only other table there at 4pm on a Saturday.  There were about 3 girls in red shirts, 3 in black shirts, and one guy in a red shirt.  When we asked for a refill on the beer, it took 3 different people telling each other..before one could come up to get us a beer list and beer.  

Total for our meal w/ 2 beers was $60.  There's so many other places to eat in the city, I don't think I'll be back.  But my husband did say this was his favorite Thai place to eat in SF....but then again, the only 2 other places we went to were at 2am, post partying...
author: Vi Y.

description: Best Thai food in the city! I've been looking for great sticky rice and i finally found it! Red curry was comforting, the tom yum came heated on a burner and the fried noodles were consistent. This is now my go to Thai food spot. Can't wait to go back
author: Leslie S.

description: We ordered the Stir fried traditional quail with brown rice. It was delicious. Spicy and rich in flavour. I would have loved it more if they were able to provide boneless quail.
author: Amrita G.

description:
HUGE menu unlike any I've ever seen at a Thai restaurant- a wide range of meats (including eel, chicken entrails, quail eggs, just to list a few of the more obscure), plus soups and rice dishes and noodle dishes....we hardly knew where to start.  

We got the fried rolls for an appetizer. Best rolls I've ever had because they had SO much flavor and a variety of veggies- not just the usual bland carrots and cabbage.  Then I had the tom yum soup (the coconut milk based soup) and it was enormous with an incredible range of flavors.  My boyfriend got some spicy eel dinner that he said was phenomenal (I can't eat hot spicy food), though a little hard to eat the eel chunks that still included the bone (though the waitress warned him when he ordered, so he knew what he was getting into).   

The location and the restaurant itself weren't anything to brag about, but the menu is huge, the prices are great, and they are open until midnight.
author: Luthien N.

description: My friend and I ordered two dishes to share...the food brought out to us was neither of the dishes we ordered. So, service certainly needs improvement as many others have noted. However, the food we were brought was so incredibly delicious we didn't care. The Tom Kha Gai was absolutely amazing, I'm still drooling from it!!
author: Erika W.

description: Best Thai food I've ever had in my life. Seriously. Everything tasted so so good
author: Jackson M.

description:
In the last 25 years I have tried a lot of Thai food here in the Bay Area and in Thailand.  Theses glowing reviews amaze me.  It was j u s t OK.

Neighborhood 1 star
Parking 1 star
Ambience 2 stars
Service  3 stars
Vegetarian Red Curry.  2.5 stars. Not hot enough. Mostly carrot.  Small serving
Yum wun sen noodles.  3 stars
Green papaya salad.  2 stars small serving. Too salty & overpowering lemon.

Pra ram sang (peanut sauce) 2.5 stars
author: ruby l.

description: A surprisingly filling Thai restaurant that completely obliterated my past experiences of mediocre Thai food. Great lunch special with the appreciated option of brown rice. Rich flavors without being too salty. All around delectable with a classy yet laid back Ambience.
author: Max R.

description:
Menu;Vast, reads like the who's who in the Thai Food Cuisine Kingdom. 
Food; texture, taste, layers of flavor, perfumed with bouquets of Thai herbs, broth and sauces, dense with ginger and lemon grass and flavors of Thailand. 
My favorite dish hands down was the fresh Sea Bass. It was presented in a fish shaped aluminum server with candles underneath and bone in. The candles kept the broth bubbling until there was pretty much nothing let but the bone of the fish that gave his all for our lunch! 
We had a massive group and impressively the food was fairly well timed. The silverware was another story. 
Overall, I enjoyed my dining experience and would return if the occasion presented itself.
author: Maureen G.

description: Their green curry was so good. And the rice plate was enough to stuff both me and my girlfriend. In response to another review I read, rice is included if you specifically ask for the rice plate.
author: Lee H.

description:
When you eat somewhere two days in a row, you know it's Yelp-worthy.  

Best thing on the menu is the flash-fried trout.  Add the spareribs and the papaya salad and you're all set.  Trust me on this one - I've tried many other, less noteworthy dishes, and this is THE formula for delicious.

Also of note! - This location's food is spicier than the one in Hayes Valley.  Which, in my opinion, makes it the better one.
author: Allison B.

description: Probably one of the best Thai places in SF (and they deliver!). Have ordered from here a couple different times and it has always been delicious. Eat here!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Visiting from the east coast and heard this was the best thai to be had in San Fran. Given the people waiting in line at the packed restaurant, we assumed this would be true since it is surrounded by other thai restaurants. The interior is simple and clean, the location pretty sketchy. But the food....I get the exact sane thing at every thai restaurant, and I eat thai at least once a week. Hands down the most flavorful Tom Kha Gai I've ever had, perfect blend of flavor and spice. Definitely the best green papaya salad I've ever had, many thai places make it so spicy it ruins the rest of your meal. This was spicy but you could still taste the absolutely perfect dressing with salted eggs... Fabulous.

Our local thai restaurant Thai Square has them beat on the red curry with chicken and thai iced tea. The red curry had sliced carrots which I felt added an odd flavor but it was still really good. My husband had Seafood Pad Thai and decided it was the best he's ever had. Since he's probably had over 1000 pad Thais, that's a pretty high compliment. Definitely recommend making a reservation and making this place a destination. We had really high expectations and weren't disappointed.
author: Abby S.

description:
BY FAR the best Thai restaurant in SF! If I had to pick only one restaurant in San Francisco to exist, this would be the one!

The food is just plain top notch! Make sure to pick some of their specials and not the usual stuff you could get in any other Thai restaurant as well.

My absolute favorite starters are: Sun dried beef, the garlic quail and the grilled pork shoulder - if I could get the chilli powder sauce coming with the dried beef as a commercial product, I would ditch any Tabasco or Sriracha immediately; it is so addictive.

Try their house special dishes like boar, frog, trout and alligator - I am always a little wary when restaurants offer "fancy" dishes, but at Lers Ros, these are to die for! Give it a shot even if it sounds too exotic for you.

Location is crappy Larkin street but that just makes it more of a gem in this street.

Doesn't hurt that the waitresses are cute as hell and always extremely friendly. ;-)
author: Tin Yan C.

description:
I had lunch here and I really enjoyed my meal. When you first walk into the restaurant you probably won't be blown away by the interior. The place looks rather plain inside. If I was choosing a restaurant solely on looks, I wouldn't choose this place.

 I ordered shrimp with asparagus, which was divine. I only wish they provided more of it. My meal was rich with flavor. I was honestly a little sad when I finished it. 

I liked the fact that the restaurant had lunch and daily specials as well as a full menu available for lunch time - so many options!  This is a perfect place for lunch and the food is so good that you forget about the lack of decor.
author: Abena O.

description: I enjoyed everything,very good food I got the combo,grilled chicken with green papaya salad.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Ok so this Thai food was the best I have ever had. The serves was good! I loved the fact they bring fish sauce to the table. They had a lot of different traditional dishes. If I lived here I would be coming back often.
author: Rhonda H.

description: Delicious food, relatively inexpensive, and cool atmosphere (although the EDM music is a little aggressive). Next time I'm getting the alligator. Pad kee mow is on point.
author: G D.

description: My friends wanted to try this place. I must admit, im not the biggest thai food fan but I was pleasantly surprised! The food here was quite yummy. We got the tom yum soup and 3 other dishes and the duck salad to share. I liked the soup a lot. It was on the pricier side, but it was definitely interesting and very asian. The duck salad was pretty good as well. and the last dish that stook out to me was the pork(?) I forgot what the dish was called but it featured little pork, or maybe it was chicken, grounded and mixed with vegetables.
author: Annie Z.

description:
I absolutely love this Thai restaurant!! The friendly, efficient service is always consistent. The atmosphere can be casual to romantic. The food is delicious! Out of the dishes I tried, the yellow curry and frog legs aren't the best dishes to order. However, the pad thai and fried chicken over fried rice are two of my favorite dishes. The Thai iced tea is fragrant, not too sweet, and not too milky. It's just right! The prices are decent and totally worth the taste and portions of the dishes. 

It gets super crowded at dinnertime on the weekends, so I suggest making reservations. Finding street parking around this area isn't too bad either.
author: Tracy F.

description:
Solid 4, maybe even 4.5.

I love this restaurant. I found Lers Ros during my last trip (a month ago) to San Francisco and went there twice.
I am already back in San Francisco and have already eaten there both last night and tonight.

A few dishes feel more Chinese than Thai. Avoid those.
I wonder why they have those dishes. Anyways, there are plenty of authentic dishes here. You can even enjoy some dishes like boar, venison, quail, rabbit, etc. that you can not find in other Thai restaurant.

Service is a delight.
Brown rice is delicious.

Thai herb sausage is delicious, as is the duck larb. The whole fish is amazing.

Everything I have had there is really good. Minus the one time they recommended a dish that felt more Chinese or too Americanized.

Ok, I go back now and add one more star, changing my original 4 stars to five.

Cheap eat. Delicious. Rather rough area (tenderloin).
author: Mehran F.

description:
This place gets 5 stars for being the best Thai food that I've ever had.

Since the place was packed and I was alone, I sat at the bar. The gentlemen on either side of me were quite amicable and we shared our food. I was also able to try the pork belly and the Thai Herb Sausage. I ordered the Pad Kee Mow with chicken (pan fried noodles). 

My noodles were spicy and delicious. The pork belly was amazing! I'd never had pork belly before but both the gentlemen on either side of me said that it was the best they'd ever had. It was crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. The sausage was good too and had a very basil-y taste to it.

Also, everyone working the room was female and drop dead gorgeous, from the beautiful femmes serving to the cute little butch hostess. That was certainly a nice touch but even without the Thai hotties this place would still get 5 stars. It wasn't too expensive, it was pretty quick and most importantly the food was delicious. I highly recommend this place.
author: Vivian A.

description:
Good food, but overpriced and small portions. They got popular among the foody trend-oids and the prices shot right up. 

The name is pronounced Lert-Rote. Another mangled transliteration.
author: James B.

description:
So what's all the hype about?

After a recent "Check Please" episode, I was looking forward to a good Thai meal.  Meh.  There's no commotion here.

For lunch, we decided to order the combination lunch plates with basic Thai standards to establish a benchmark. 

Curry chicken:  thinly sliced chicken breast that were dry.  A little mix of dark thigh meat would have enhanced this dish. **

Kai Yang:  BBQ Chicken - bland and dry.  Quite possible the chicken had been sitting on the side of the grill for a final finish. You'll know when BBQ chicken is fresh off the grill. *

Moo Gratiem:  Overly sweetened soy sauce on slightly overcooked pork strips. Strangely reminded me of a touristy Chinatown dish. *

Pad Kra Pow Gai:  Probably the best of the four dishes.  ***

The service staff appeared tired and showed little emotion toward providing the customer a positive experience.  Mechanical would be an appropriate word.

Overall, the food and experience was unremarkable.  The competition amongst Thai restaurants is keen and I've had better examples of Thai food elsewhere.
author: Joe R.

description: My husband and I needed a place to eat yesterday before the Janet Jackson concert and he found this restaurant.  We absolutely loved it!  My husband had the alligator w/ brown rice and he loved all the flavors-he asked for spicy and that's what he got!  I love the option of spice level you prefer.  I had the Pad Thai (one of my all-time favorite dishes) and they did not disappoint!  The flavors we're perfect!  It's one of the best I've ever had!  I noticed an earlier review mentioning that the Pad Thai had no flavor...which I TOTALLY DISAGREE. Also, you can taste the high quality of the ingredients they use in their food.  We are definitely going back for more! Also, I typically don't post comments but this was worth taking the time. Oh, I recommend making reservations, they get busy!!!
author: Estella S.

description: I don't know, I wasn't sold. I was expecting way more quality and oomph, I guess. The portion sizes were okay, but I didn't like either red or green curry. Veggies with peanut sauce were great though. I think I'd need to come back during dinner and try their exotic meats before making a final decision on this place.
author: Olga A.

description: Went to this restaurant twice in one week. All dishes are fabulous but the pork belly is even better.  Learn duck salad (lettuce wrap) was delicious - flavour sensation. Pad Thai was tasty and green curry was spicy and delicious
author: Sarah B.

description: Would not recommend ordering online. The eta was already 90 minutes after I had placed the order, but it was an additional 45 minutes late. When I called to speak with the staff regarding updating the delivery time, she just said- we are busy. Poor service. Food was cold.
author: Ketki K.

description:
In town for the weekend for work. Yelped this location and decided to try it out.
We had the fried pirk belley and the #77. Both were delicious.
author: Jamie O.

description:
Best pad thai in the city hands down.
Yeah, I just said that.

Probably have eaten about 100 times and I am finally writing a review:
Fried tofu is delish. I mix peanuts in the sweet chili sauce or dip it in peanut sauce.
Papaya salad with grilled shrimp is amazing! Usually very spicy. Love.
Sub your plain rice for garlic ginger rice. You won't regret it.
