Peanut sauce on rice is fantastic. Peanut sauce on garlic ginger rice is heavenly.
Flaming coconut milk soup with shrimp is wonderful. Great flavors.
Whole fried fish is very tasty. Especially with the chili sauce that accompanies it.
The ladies are always very sweet and attentive.
Absolutely love this place. One of my favorite restaurants in the city.
Boyfriend loooves the pork belly.

Enjoy ;]
author: Miss P.

description:
Quite possibly the best Thai food I've ever had (outside of Thailand)! 

Came here for the first time last week and was warmly greeted by several servers who gregariously provided recommendations, all of which turned out to be on point. We got the asparagus shrimp, green curry, chicken pad see ew, and the famous crispy pork belly. Every dish was delicious, but what really stood out was the crispy pork belly, which was equal parts crispy and buttery. It also had a nice spice to it. My second favorite dish was the pad see ew, which was really flavorful and had big juicy chunks of chicken. 

The wait staff was really friendly and attentive, coming by often to check on us and refill our water. The food also came out really fast, like 5 minutes after we ordered. 

The price was definitely reasonable for the quality and amount of food we ordered, with the final bill coming out to $52 with tip and tax. 

I definitely will be coming back!
author: James C.

description: I know delivery times may vary but they told me an hour on the phone and my food arrived in 30 minutes. It tastes so fresh. AMAZING! My new go-to thai spot after moving to SF from Boston. 5 starts for this gem.
author: Natalya C.

description:
Lers Ros is really good! Why did I wait so long to try this place?!

We ordered garlic frog, clams, intestine soup with square noodles and mango sticky rice. If you like seafood, get the clams. The soup was too rich for me. Perhaps I'll get the clear broth next time.

The mango sticky rice with was not sticky. Flavor was good but texture was odd.

Summary: Interesting dishes for the adventurous eater
author: Jeanne C.

description: Potentially great place, depending what you order. After a regular customer swore to us that this was "the best Thai food in San Francisco," I wanted to be blown away. But, to my disappointment, that didn't happen. Soup was great but my main was SO spicy that I couldn't finish it. While it was supposedly medium-level spiciness, it was 5x hotter than the other medium dishes at my table. Otherwise, great service and clearly a hot-spot, but not yet deserving of Best Of title.
author: Robin R.

description: Very poor service, waitress couldn't speak English well, and I couldn't understand them either. I asked a straw and beer and she walked away and forgot to bring them in literally in a min. Then brought wrong rice We asked water and waiter was just walking pass by. I never got what I asked for at first time hot sauce and etc....there was 3 or 4 waitresses and they were all seemed busy in the kitchen. There was only 3 customers!! I gave them 2stars only because food was not bad.
author: May Y.

description: I am a huge thai food lover and this food did not dissapoint! The food was out of this world.  We went at 10:30 at night on a Wednesday and it packed.  Reservations would be a good idea.  The food was surprisingly inexpensive for a place right in the middle of San Francisco. Would definitely eat there again.
author: Chad P.

description:
I really really liked this. And as you can read in my profile, something that I don't usually tell people is that I don't like thai food. I had too much crappy thai in the TL during finals to put me off it for a good 2 months. 

But lunch today made me change my mind. Lers Ros was delicious!!! 

I went to lunch with Steph A. and DJTINACHRISTINA. They have a lunch special at Lers where you get to pick 2 items with a salad and rice for $7.95. 

I picked the chicken satay (yum) and the chicken with ginger and vegetables, a name I cannot pronounce. (also yum) 

We all agreed it was really good. But we also all agreed that the salad dressing was not the best. But then again I don't like honey or sweet sauces. 

They had good post-check candy. 

As far as thai food goes, this is now my go-to.
author: Emily D.

description:
Some of the best Thai I've had in the Bay Area. All the dishes I tried had a complexity of flavors that blew my mind. Highlights were the chicken satay, the pork shoulder salad, green curry with chicken and calamari with chili sauce and peppercorn. 

I'm still thinking about the calamari. Those buggers are hard to cook and Lers Ros' version was tender, a nice mix of spicy/flavorful (due to the galangal I think), and beautifully presented with sprigs of green peppercorn.  This is the best kind of eating-- no-frills dining with superb food at reasonable prices. The timing of everything is a little off, but if you're sharing plates it gives everyone time to try a little before the next dish is out.
author: Emily L.

description:
A place that already has such high ratings is almost a deterrent to not write a review, but why not?! 

Lers Ros you satisfied my thai curry craving and so much more! A group of 5 of us went together on a Fri night, we were able to get seated in about 30 mins *worth the wait*

We ordered a few appetizers and were very pleased, fried egg rolls and chicken larb both very well made.

For entrees we ordered and ate family style *each entree can serve 2 easily, 3 if you order an extra.

We had something similar to a seafood stew item 100, surprisingly spicy but super delicious!
The seafood pad thai was a hit along with the eggplant/tofu
Someone ordered sweet and sour seafood which was a surprise to the palate after the spicy seafood curry! #76, 96 and 100 will be enjoyed once again!

All washed down with a bottle of Chang's!
author: Kiran J.

description:
If you are looking to eat dinner here, I recommend coming a little early and beat the crowd, because this place tends to get full fast. 

Although I've only gone here twice, the food and service is consistently excellent. I would personally recommend the Garlic Quail and Pad Thai. Both are the very best I've ever had.
author: Jamison O.

description:
I have been to approximately 2 or 3 dozen Thai restaurants in the East Bay and the city, and maybe a dozen in Sacramento and elsewhere in Northern California, and perhaps a dozen places in Bangkok and Chiang Mai, Thailand.

This is as good as the best I've had in Thailand and better than any other place I've found as of yet in California.

Everything was perfectly authentic, down to the smoky heat in the eel, the perfect texture of the peanuts and green papaya in the som tum (with salted egg - yum), the absolutely perfect house-made fish sauce, the right peppercorns, the right amount of vanilla in the ice tea. The seafood was eminently fresh - the clams, fish, eel were all absolutely perfectly fresh, as if they had just been caught.

I wish I lived closer to Lers Ros. I'd come here once a week if I could.
author: Moses H.

description: Maybe go eat to the actual restaurant, but do NOT get DELIVERY ... waited two hours for two miserable plates of COLD food ... AND they're actually not ashamed to charge you "delivery fee" of 10% ... sorry, never again ...
author: A B.

description: We waited about 30 minutes to get a table but it was well worth the wait. The service was by far the best I've ever had. The food was delish. I love hot tea, and most restaurants give you one cup and thats it.. This place refilled my tea without me asking about 4 times. As soon as we put down our cups it was refilled instantaneously. I would wait an hour for a restaurant with such great food and service.
author: Anna V.

description: Excellent food at a reasonable price. Some places in San fransisco are very expensive for no reason, but this place was totally reasonable. 1 app and 2 entree and a soda cost 37$ and it was phenomenal. Check it out
author: John R.

description: I had the rabbit which was featured in thd specials. I sent the first plate back because it was so overcooked and had no flavor. The second plate was not much better, plus, there was a hair in it. I was totally done! Yuk!
author: Carol S.

description: Great vegan options (we had the Pad Kee Mow and Pad Makuer Tofu) and a nice atmosphere.
author: Josh B.

description: This place serves good Thai food. I forgot what I got but it was a dish of sauteed beef with sauce and rice. It was so yummy. The atmosphere is very quiet (I went on a weeknight) and dim. You could get decent amount of food for about $10.
author: Suhana A.

description:
We came here on a rainy Wednesday night a couple of days before new years eve and the place was packed! Considering that it's on Larkin Street where it's pretty dead after 9pm Lers Ros is one of the only restaurants open after awhile. We've been wanting to try this place because it consistently has a full house.

A party of 3 of us we waited about 20 minutes for a table. Service is typical Asian but they did come back to refill our waters several times.

Food:

Coconut soup-Very delicious! It had just the right amount of sour and spice and mixed with the coconut milk it definitely cleared some sinuses.

Pork Belly-their signature dish. It is basically the same thing as the roasted pork at Sam Woo or a chinese bbq place but they cut it up. The skin was very crispy and the dish was flavorful. 

Pad Phed with chicken-SPICY wow, this was definitely giving us major burn but it was very flavorful. If you can't eat spicy food don't order this dish.

Pad Thai-tasty

Overall, great experience, will definitely come again to try more dishes!
author: Betty C.

description: Unbelievable! No words! The chefs special fish paste plate was to die for. Extremely loud restaurant but the food and fast s revive make up for it
author: Daya P.

description:
Seriously, I think this is the best Thai food I've ever had. I'm a bit new to San Francisco, so I'm not as used to REALLY good Asian food, but Lers Ros really takes the cake. I've had Lers Ros multiple times and it never fails to amaze me. 

I usually order the pork belly. It's spicy and incredibly tender, but the crispy outer layer is the best part. The only thing that I've had here that I didn't like was the chicken satay, but usually don't like it, so it's not even a factor. The portions aren't over the top generous and the pricing is either average or a bit above normal, but it's not bad. 

The service is INCREDIBLE. We once had a group of 8 once for lunch. They were very fast with the orders even though the place was packed. The staff was also incredibly friendly.  I've also had the food delivered and they were exactly on time, so no complaints there. 

One of the nicer aspects of Lers Ros is that it takes cards, which in San Francisco, is a pretty rare occurrence. 

In all, I'd eat here all the time if I could and pretty much do eat here about once a week!
author: Sonia J.

description: This place has got it all: wonderful food, affordable price (very large portions), attentive service, and an enjoyable atmosphere. Look forward to coming back.
author: Sierra S.

description:
My favorite Thai spot in the city. Their pork belly especially is unreal, but I've yet to have a bad dish here. That includes papaya salad and pad thai, neither of which I'm typically a fan of. I still don't love their pad thai, but friends usually end up ordering it and theirs is not too sweet, which is a common complain I have.

Much better food here than at the Hayes location, but this one is in a sketchier area and the decor isn't as nice. Much more of a hole in the wall feel. Depends on what you value.
author: David C.

description:
Lers Ros is definitely not a place for those that are mild-hearted. First, I'm sure there are those "scared for my life" types that will be put off by its T'loin location. Second, this place is slightly more heavy handed in the spice department than other places, so keep that in mind when you order.

It's hard to differentiate Thai food because from a flavor profile standpoint, there isn't much variation. Ask me what the difference is between Osha and King of Thai, and I'll quickly reply "price." With Lers Ros, there's something about the cooking here that leaves an extra lushness after you take a bite that stands above other Thai restaurants in the City. I guess the equivalent in today's urban lingo would be, and I hope I'm creating a new phrase here, "flavor swag." 

I must confess that I've only limited myself to a couple go-to dishes because they're frickin' delicious (hence the four star rating). However a quick survey of the menu clearly shows a wide variety of standard Thai dishes found in any Thai restaurant, and ones truly unique to Lers Ros (i.e. boar, frog). I almost always end up getting chicken Pad Kee Mow and the crispy fried pork belly dish. They just never mess these two dishes up for me. I tried the duck larb that was noted on the most recent edition of the 7x7 list, and they clearly missed the mark by not putting in the crispy fried pork belly. While the duck larb was fine, it had a strong vinegar flavor that made continued eating less and less enticing. 

$33 should get you 3 standard entrees. They deliver, so that's also a plus. 

Oh, and to those "scared for my life" types, Lers Ros opened up a location in Hayes Valley. Same food, but caters to the wine-cheese/future internet mogul crowd.
author: Lael A.

description:
You know a place is good when there is a queue out the door for dinner and people are willing to wait outside in the brisk, windy 40-50 degree SF weather. Be prepared to wait an additional 30 mins even with reservations. This place is bustling but well worth the wait because of the food.

5 stars for the food and taste. I went with a friend that's been to Thailand several times and eats local food when he is there and he exclaimed the taste was very authentic. We had Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (pork belly & basil), fresh whole sea bass which was really good. Som Tom salad with salted egg but kinda wished I tried the crab or prawn instead, however still good. I like spicy food but their regular spicy is pleenty spicy! I managed to gulp down 2 thai ice teas and full pitcher of water on my own. So if you can't handle too much spiciness I would definitely tell the waitress while ordering. 

2 stars for the neighborhood. It's definitely not in the nicest part of town. I would not recommend walking there from Union Square which is what I did especially being a female, unless looking for the true SF experience. But a gem found. 

4 stars for wait staff and service once seated. They are attentive but note it's always busy. 

All in all, the experience was enjoyable and plan to return for the food!
author: Judy C.

description: Food was ok. Service was horrible! Waited 10 minutes after being seated and got completely neglected. Ended up having to tell the hostess to send a waitress over. This was 8pm on a Sunday less busier night. I can imagine how much worse it is on a busy night. servers never stop to check on the table. They forgot my drink order. Had to remind them 10 minutes after my food came. If you're big on service like I am, this is NOT the place to go!
author: Travis M.

description:
FANTASTIC Thai food, but because it's located in the Tenderloin, make sure you come here with company (about ~10 min walk to nearest train station)

Plenty of seating, so I was able to sit down though my friend was late. Go for their special combination plate. Amazing papaya salad, yummy sticky rice.

Unfortunately, I forgot what I'd ordered (been putting this review off for way too long!), but it was some kind of pork, and very flavorful.
author: Shang S.

description: Best Pad kee Mow I have ever had in my life. If u like spicy Pad Kee Mow, this is the spot.
author: Shaleek F.

description: We waited for more than 1.5hrs, but the wait wasn't worth it. It was like any other thai restaurant, but with tiny tiny stools where we had to squeeze and huddle. The portions and the menu options are plenty, but for the wait. Don't even think of going here without a reservation.
author: smitha k.

description:
Most Thai joints in the city offer up greasy, bland, americanized fare so gross it makes my heart hurt. I've been on the hunt for something authentic for the past seven years, and I'm happy to say that I've found it at Lers Ros. 

When I went, they were very busy and the staff looked frazzled, but once we sat down to eat, it was so easy to understand why. The Tom Yum soup comes in one of those flaming bowls, so it stays piping hot all throughout your meal. The pork spareribs were spicy and tender. Then we ordered some brown rice pilaf and a red curry with chicken. We gobbled that down quick. 

Also, everyone is not kidding about the sketchy walk to this place. I'd recommend avoiding Ellis if you're coming from Powell. Might be best to take Geary. The TL crackheads are the scariest/most aggressive, so be careful.
author: Christina S.

description: Wow!  The whole fried fish smothered in flavorful sauce (it was over a month ago so forgive my lack of specifics) was amazing.  The other dishes, including a tofu dish and vegetarian offerings were tasty and a nice balance to the fish.  Clean, light and bright flavors in all the dishes that ordered.  The curry puffs were some of the best I have ever had and highly recommended.  The waitstaff was helpful and super friendly.  Seems like I have to get the pork belly next time (I'll return with carnivores)!  I will definitely be back to enjoy this gem of a Thai restaurant.
author: Dimitri S.

description:
First off, I came at about 9 on a Tuesday and it was PACKED with 5 tables ahead of us. Not to worry though - some sake at the bar and half hour later, I was chewing on fried quail.

my dining partners (in crime) ordered the Pad Si Iu, as well as a noodle dish with basil and chicken. Both were out of this world, with Wok Hei and just the right amount of seasoning and texture of the rice noodles. I ordered the tamarind spicy seafood soup (# 106 I think), and it was great. It is spicy, but not painfully so, with a good amount of fish sauce. Next time I will try something more rounded with additional herbs, as that soup didn't have too much "grassy" or herbal notes to it.
author: Jonah N.

description: WOW! Was in the need for Thai food and this place delivered! Food was awesome, wait staff was excellent! Coming back very soon
author: Parker S.

description:
I started coming here a few years back with a Thai friend.  Ever since that first day at Lers Ros, this place is my FAV Thai restaurant in the ENTIRE bay area (from the various places I've tried so far in the bay area).  They have become quite popular over the years, and even have a place in at least one major SF Street Food event every year.

This place looks to be a hole-in-the-wall in the Tenderloin neighborhood of SF, but don't be fooled.  It's very clean and well maintained.  Most of all, the food is amazing.  There are a variety of dishes that you will not find in most other Thai restaurants.    

I hear friends and associates rave all the time about other Thai restaurants in the area (I've tried most of them too), but after coming to Lers Ros, no place can match. 

I try to order different dishes when coming here, but the two "side-type" dishes that I really enjoy and are usually on my personal list to order and share are:

- Pork Shoulder Salad w/ Spicy Lime Dressing 
- Papaya Salad with Salted Egg 

Other than that, I've been happy with just about every dish I've tried here, except for one:

- Kaeng Pah Pla Dook (Sliced Cat-fish (Bone-in) in broth).  

I had to struggle eating this as I was constantly picking at all the bones in the fish.  I've had catfish many time before so I'm not sure if they use this same type of fish all the time, but it has TONS of itty bitty bones.

Anyhow, the service here is great and I keep recommending this place to more and more friends in the city and I haven't heard anyone complain yet :)
author: Marie N.

description:
*** # 300 review for Maile N. ***  Yippee, yay!  :)

So I wanted to pick a special place to write my *300th* Yelp review, and Lers Rose Thai is an excellent pick!!  We came here for dinner with a couple friends and had an absolute blast!  Our food kind of came sporadically so it took a little while for us all to get our dishes so we could start digging in together.

We had a version of Thai "boat soup" (beef, noodles, spices - yum!), fried fish with mango sauce (yum!), pad see ew (flat noodles with chicken, eggs - yum!), and top sirloin in lime juice (yummers!!) with some jasmine rice.  We all enjoyed our meal so much, and I got to taste a little bit of everything and then devoured my top sirloin (great taste, tender beef) with a glass of merlot.  

The service was good and it was nice to glimpse the Winter Olympics on the big flat screen TVs while we chatted and ate.  A great place to catch up with friends over a very tasty, reasonably-priced meal.  And darn! I forgot to grab a to-go menu because they do deliver (yes!!) -- oh well, I can see the menu online too I'm sure.  And yes, it's in the Tenderloin which I'm always a little if-y about going to, especially in the evening, but I'll take my chances because that's where the best Thai and Vietnamese restaurants are in the City!

Dinner for 4+tax+tip = $60
author: Maile N.

description: Delicious Thai food. Some items were great, some we would not order again. For example, our ribs were too tough. But overall very good.
author: Ben B.

description:
Upside: Lers Ros Thai is a departure from some of the utterly westernized restaurants that lurk here. Their food is delicious, with a traditional Siam touch. 

Downside: Their delivery is dismal.
author: Jessica C.

description: Love this place! It can get pretty noisy at night but I dont mind it. Parking might be a hassle since its in the TL but if youre in the area and youre craving thai food, Lers Ros wont disappoint =)
author: Julie H.

description: Great, great great food. We went for lunch during the day, so the area wasn't that bad. I took the train in from the Tri-Valley and it was a short walk from BART. I got the Pad Thai and it instantly took me back to Ko Phi Phi. They say this is the best Thai in SF , and from what I have seen so far I would agree. The inside of the restaurant is really chic and modern, which I really liked as well. The outside sign is small and hard to find, but that is truly the only thing I could find wrong with this restaurant. Highly, highly recommend this place, for lunch for sure.
author: Douglas C.

description:
Cheap eats and as authentic as it gets. 

The french red blend wine is really good and goes very well with all of the food my almost drunk friends and I had.

We ordered the sour soup, drunken noodles, pineapple fried rice, the pork appetizer and a few other dishes that I can't quite remember. But as an overall experience, this place serves a wide variety of thai food and there wasn't anything I didn't like.
author: Angeline H.

description:
somewhat quick, late dinner before heading out

ordered:
-larb phed yang: roasted duck w rice and chili powder and onions.. the lime dressing was perfect for this salad dish..my fav dish out of the three

-koong chu chee: prawns, red chili, coconut milk, lemon leaves.. this was ok

-nuer pad prik thai ooan: sliced beef stir fried with peppercorn and galingale

wash it down w thai iced tea and iced chrysanthemum tea
author: Raquel T.

description:
Was walking around the tenderloin looking for a breakfast/brunch place that looked decent and didn't have a long wait (oh how tedious this process is in SF - there's so many good places...but also some decently long waits.. woe is me!). By the time we were walking around it was around 11:10AM, and Lers Ros had just opened, since we were getting hungry and getting over our breakfast search we thought we would look at yelp for some place nearby with good reviews and stumbled on Lers Ros Thai.

What we got:
Tom Yum Koong - Tom Yum soup which is lemony and spicy (their standard is to serve this at medium-level spicy) with oyster mushrooms and prawns. Since it was rainy outside this morning, this really hit the spot. Their medium was... on a thai level though, which I am okay with since I LOVE spicy things, but something to keep in mind if your palette cannot take spice too well. I'm a soup person so - 5 stars

Pork Shoulder Appetizer - SOO delicious, make sure you get this if you like pork shoulder, I would come back again just to get this! It comes with a dipping sauce, but I think it kind of overpowers the pork so I ate most of mine without the dipping sauce and if I used it - I would just use a smidgen to make sure it didn't overkill the pork. This was amazing, do order! - 5 stars

Pad Kee Mao with Beef (Medium Spicy) - This was good as well, with most places the proportion of noodles to meat is often heavy on the noodles side and barely any meat. At Lers Ros, I would almost say the beef to noodle ratio was even. This was great in my opinion since I'm trying to cut back on the carbs. -5 stars

Really glad we stumbled upon this place, I will have to take note to come back here soon!

Handy Tip:
I think their spice levels are a little skewed towards the spicy side so make sure your take that into consideration when you're ordering. Also, I read in some other reviews that there was a long wait for them, try coming on Sundays for lunch! Even when we were leaving at about 12:30 ish there was still no wait.
author: Melissa L.

description:
My girlfriend and I ordered Pad Kee Mow and Red Curry (both vegetarian). The noodles were spicy but very tasty. Beware of the chopped chilies they have in there, they're extremely spicy! The portion of the noodles was perfect for 2 hungry people or 3 portion-controlled eaters. The flavor was on point, but I could've done with a little bit less vegetables. 

The soup was delicious, and although we ordered medium spicy for both items, the soup was much less spicy. We got our tofu fried and it was delicious. Make sure to order the "a la carte" option for the soup if you want to share. 

The service was good and the food was served pretty quickly. I definitely recommend this place, I will be eating here again.
author: Shriraj S.

description: Once you're inside its all good! All the soups are hot and the service is prompt. If you love spice this is the spot for you. They use a lot of fresh chillies might open you up a lil bit. Keep your head on a swivel cause when you step outside you're waking into a drug war zone.
author: Mikey S.

description: Consistently good and better than any Thai restaurant in the area. Been to the Hayes Valley and Larkin St locations, think I like this one more. But I'm bias as a local. You can feed 2 for $20, or share plates family style. Wait staff is always friendly and accommodating, even when you come for take out. Get the fried chicken over garlic rice and pad Thai, which is not too greasy and very tasty with good shrimps in it. Usually busy for dinner but you could get in without a reservation, though you're safer if you make one.
author: Dan U.

description: Yup 5 count them, so amazing why was it not crowded I don't know. Roast pork appetizer, aka pork belly just awesomeness.  It 's  big for one as an appetizer but I put it away anyway. Then to the gator, really! It's like New Orleans in Bangcok ! Where else in the hell can you even find this sH#t? Amazing dish made more so  with the green peppercorn strands, yes strands!i I didn't even know they grew that way, and where in the hell would you even find them??
author: Rob B.

description: The food was too salty and the staff didn't tend to you. They need to be told what to do. I was waiting for 7 staffers to get me some tea.
author: Daniel K.

description: Wow, my mouth is numb from the spicyness, but good spicyness.  Had #21 Yum Woon Sen, Silver noodles, ground pork, sun-dried shrimp, peanut with chili and lime based salad dressing.  Missing was the peanuts!  It came with lettuce and a great portion.  Great flavors!  The tofu was good, and so was the soups.  Despite the neighborhood, it is so close to public transit.  I must have walked passed this place so many times and never noticed.  The menu is so extensive- meanny meanny mighty moe (ever wonder who started all that meanny meanny mighty moe?).
author: Helen L.

description: Love the community table vibe! Each dish was excellent! Especially loved the coconut soup!
author: Miss H.

description: One of the best Thai food restaurants I have been too. We ordered the duck larb, and the whole steamed fish. The decor was very pleasing, but the seats could be a little more comfortable. I can hardly wait to go back.
author: Monique D.

description:
I've lived in S.E. Asia and traveled to Thailand many times, so I know what authentic Thai food tastes like. It's so hard to find legit Thai food in the U.S. but Ler Ros blew me away. We ordered so many dishes and not a single one disappointed me. The dishes that stuck out in my mind are the grilled sliced of pork shoulder, the fried sun-dried beef, and a minced pork dish. 

This place was packed when we came and there was still a line outside when we left around 9 pm. Make sure to come early!
author: Amy N.

description: Every single flavor in this place is amazing! Just a little bit of salt in the papaya salad but the rest is super good!
author: Carolina P.

description:
The first time I came here, it was with a huge group and we had reservations.  That is the way to dine at Lers Ros (Lerhh Rohh).  You want protein entrees, family style.  We had pork belly, the papaya salad, the seabass, the duck, the boar, pad thai, and red curry.  It was awesome.  

That said, it is not for those who can't handle their spices (me).  I ate through my tears for most of the meal... this is spicay food, but it'll wake anyone up who has been numbed by the numerous Oshas and King of Thais in SF.

I like the food at this location better than the Hayes Valley location.
author: Erika C.

description: Pad Thai was really good, but make sure if you can't take spicy foods to not get spicy at all. My friend and I asked for spicy foods, we were dying!! I was sweating so much and water wasn't helping haha. But the flavor was really good.
author: Charles Z.

description:
Hands down the best Thai restaurant in SF! We ordered:

BBQ chicken
papaya salad
pork shoulder
pork belly
pad se ew
fried rice
red curry
quail 
beef steak
durian sticky rice

My favorite was the pork shoulder (i loved the fish sauce that came with the dish). The staple Thai dishes (i.e pad se ew, curry, fried rice) was very good and definitely better than Osha. The BBQ chicken was a bit dry and I would not recommend this dish. The durian sticky rice was not bad (i love the durian) but it is definitely an acquired taste since I don't really like the taste of sticky rice as a dessert.

The only con was that the food took a very long time. 

I would definitely come back again just for the pork shoulder!!
author: Rosanna T.

description: Got the alligator. Tastes better the day after as leftovers, which helps the flavor sink in!
author: Monica S.

description:
Came here after my sister told me to check it out since we usually go to Thai House Express.

Definitely some good thai food here. Neighborhood is a bit sketchy, but once you walk inside, you won't really notice you're there anymore. Service is great here, pretty tentative here. Quiet, clean, and the food is good. Just keep in mind though, the chefs here are heavy handed on their spices here... so be sure to tell your waiter to make things mild or something.. or you're going to be asking for refills like crazy.

Tried the papaya salad.. it was good, tasty and spicy. Got the tom yum soup... soooo good. But soooo damn spicy. hahha. I was sweating like crazy and my party stopped drinking it after they realized it was so spicy.. ended up taking that to go but it was good at home still! Got the yellow curry.. it was an okay dish.. the potatoes could have used a little bit more boiling since it was still kind of hard. Got the pad see ew and that was good and tasty too. The crispy pork belly was one of my favorite dishes.. a very nice crunch to it and its really flavorful. Ordered this other dish with beef and spinach.. it wasn't spectacular but it wasn't horrible. 

Overall the meal was great. Service again, is excellent. A huge menu selection, so I'll definitely be back to try the other stuff!
author: Johnson S.

description:
One of the most authentic Thai restaurants in the city -- definitely spicy unlike all those run-of-the-mill places you typically see. 

Was recommended by a mutual friend from Thailand, who insists on only eating here if eating Thai.

Best if you come in a larger group -- that way you get to try more dishes! Don't get the typical dishes, as some of the more unfamiliar dishes are really standouts, particularly the fish dishes.
author: Elaine W.

description: Based on great review from Check Please BA, we paid a visit for a meal.  Décor is simple and the place looked clean.  Food is OK but definitely not to die for.  We may or may not give it another try if we are in the area.  Papaya salad had good spice but too salty and drenched with dressing.  Had to hold up each bite for awhile before eating.  Fried pork did not looked fried and very salty.  Perhaps the server took the wrong order but hard to imagine since I was pointing out the number on the menu. Steamed sea bass was cooked well with nice spice however once again too salty and killed the real taste of the fish.  At $32 price tag, I expect better.  Green curry was the best part of the meal.  Good flavor and not heavy.  Overall we found the dishes too salty to enjoy the flavors.  I suppose people that are used to salty restaurant foods may not be bothered by it.  No wow factor but just OK place.
author: Aden G.

description: Fantastic Thai food! The green curry is dank!
author: Vicky A.

description:
Wow really unclear why I haven't reviewed this place before. Oh, maybe because 650 other people did. Wait, that's okay because they probably have about that many items on their crazy big menu...

Lers Ros is one of the few restaurants that consistently makes me "best of SF at the present moment" list. It's quick, it's tasty, it's reasonably priced, it's spicy, and they deliver free to my place in the lower haight. And they have ridonculous dishes I've never seen at most other thai restaurants.

Yum Koh Moo Yang - as long as you couldn't care less about eating healthy, this is bomb. crispy pork belly with lime, basil, and chili. can you say "yum?" if you wanna be slightly nicer to your life span, then maybe consider Yum Nam Tok which just has regular pork or beef

Any of their larbs are like eating heaven. Or crack. 

Pad See Ew is awesome and has rescued my taste buds on several occasions when I someone can't stop ordering everything else hella spicy. Love the healthy does of green veggie (spinach?) they put in.

and my absolute favorite #110 Kaeng Som Cha-Om Khai Tod Soup. Awesome in the flaming hot pot when you eat in, equally delicious at home just without the fire. It's got tasty little egg omelet type nuggets in a spicy-sour broth with tamarind and acacia. It's definitely a party in your mouth that you don't wanna miss.
author: Monica C.

description: I am sad to say that although the food here is amazing tonight on my 3rd visit sitting at a table (my first 2 visits I sat at the Bar) I was completely turned off to see not once but three times servers clearing tables by putting there hands inside the top of dirty glasses when clearing tables and then seeing them handle clean silverware right after..I think your staff should get food handler certification (it is the law)or you will be shut down by the health department ..Gross I am not eager to return.. This is how people get sick.. :-(
author: Mona L.

description:
I've lways passed by this place and made a mental note to one day try it, it looks so modern and clean and nice. So late one night I went on yelp to look for some thai food that would deliver and this popped up! So we tried it and heres my review::

Ordered the pad see ew and spciy beef with garlic and onion.

The former was great, but not any better than any other thai resto in the city.
The latter was quite oily and definitely needed some rice with it.

Delivery took 45 minutes.

Good quality, overall good food, no chopsticks provided, portions on the smaller side.
author: Ash R.

description: If you want Thai that feels authentic and minimally greasy, this is your spot. The ingredients are fresh, the noodles are cooked to perfection, and everything was perfectly seasoned. As someone who has been to Thailand on several occasions, I can say with confidence that Lers Ros has got to be a 9.5/10.
author: John M.

description: The noodle soup was as authentic as what you can get from a Bangkok street vendor. Our entree had complex flavors and was delicious-- I only wish we ordered more so we could have tried several dishes. Alas, we were only two and had to show some restraint. The staff was very friendly and welcoming. A wonderful find!
author: Sharon D.

description: Came in here with my boyfriend and his mom for lunch on a cold day. The atmosphere is nice, the wait staff was very attentive and polite and I also enjoyed the food! All three of us had really good dishes and I would come here again. Solid spot.
author: Kaitlin T.

description:
The food here is excellent. I've spent time in Thailand, and more importantly, in the Nob Hill area where all the Thai restaurants are clustered. While there are some consistently excellent options, Lers Ros is the best by far. The menu contains more than the standard items (Pad See Ew, Pad Thai, Pad Kee Mow, etc) and the quality of ingredients and flavor is really top notch. I rarely have great things to say about food places, but I have to tip my hat to Lers Ros, it's got great food.

One thing I'm very unhappy about is their reservations. Two or three times I've asked to make a reservation for two, and they insisted that it wasn't busy and to just come in (I live close by). Every time it ended up being a 30-45 minute wait, and that is really unacceptable. So insist on them giving you a fucking reservation, even if they claim it isn't busy.
author: L T.

description:
A much better than average Thai restaurant, likely in quality, and definitely in selection.  Exotic carnivores rejoice in alligator, rabbit, boar, frog, etc!

I ordered the Duck Larb, which is on the 2011 7x7 list.   FYI to everyone (since it took me a while to find on menu), it's called "Larb Phed Yang", #25.  A chunk of roasted fatty duck mixed with rice powder, chili powder and lime based salad dressing.  A lovely mix of textures & flavors.

Pad Ped Moo Pah (boar stir-fried with a house made chili paste and galingale, #105).  The boar was super chewy, kind of like a mix of fat with a tendon-y squid-like texture.  It was still tasty in its own way, though not what I expected.  Be prepared to cut it into small pieces.  The sauce was actually pretty spicy (as were the spices in the duck larb).
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Tasty tasty Thai food!!  Not sure how I managed not to know about Lers Ros given my love of Thai food, but so glad it's now on my radar!!  The food is unbeatable.  So much "flame" in it's Thai dishes!  And so much of it.  Price appear higher than some Thai places in the city -- but portions are much bigger.

A few of my table (presumably Thai newbies) ordered generic dishes like Pad Thai, Pad See Ew, and Broccoli Beef which were good -- but I would recommend trying something more unique so you can taste what Lers Ros has to offer above your normal Thai takeout place.  Consider doing family style.  The menu is a bit insane and it'd take a while to try it all, but what we had I loved:
--Garlic Quail ($10) -- like a teeny tiny bucket of KFC, but extra miniature and covered in garlic goodness.  Not much meat here, but oh so tasty.
--Papaya salad with raw crabs ($10) - yes raw, and no I didn't know you can eat crab raw either.  But it tasted like a yummy Thai ceviche.  
--Crispy Pork (not sure where it is on the menu or costs, but it was amazing) Basically super fatty and yummy crispy pork "Siu Yok" in a chili sweet basil sauce.  a MUST get.
--Whole fried Tilapia with house chili sauce ($16) -- giant fish served whole and fried, covered in a tangy chili sauce.  Very fresh.  Lots of bones to navigate but well worth it.

Staff was attentive though at times seemed a bit overwhelmed and scattered.  I think the restaurant has a few more tables than it should, as I got my share of back bumps  from those heading to the washroom.   And hopefully they'll considered a coat check at some point since the stool seats forces you to hold your coats and get all kinds of yummy sauces on them... But otherwise, everything was good!

Note:  Medium spicy was more than we can handle....so mild eaters definitely take caution!
author: Kendra W.

description:
We came here on a recommendation. Honestly, i was not expecting much. We have some favorite Thai spots in San Diego and we rarely find Thai food as good. We have become very selective. This place deserves the hype it has received. Not only is it very authentic Thai food but it was prepared perfectly. Everyone's dish at our table was great. There was not a sour note in the evening. 

For appetizers we had the Garlic Frog and Fried Rolls. The Garlic Frog was excellent! Perfectly seasoned and sumptuous and the fried garlic was such a nice complementary touch. Great pairing of tastes.

Two of our party ordered from the pan fried noodle section of the menu. One got the Pad Kee Mow and the other got Chicken Pad Thai. Both were just delicious. The noodles themselves in both dishes were spectacular. Perfectly done, perfectly married to the sauce and seasoning . . . simply perfect. That, folks, is how it is done!

I ordered off the daily specials and had: Kra Dook Moo Pad Ped. This is tender pork spareribs stir-fried with their house made chili paste, young pepper corn & galingale. These tastes mixing the lemon grass . .. dreamy. Thai comfort food! This place really is a can't miss place for those who love Thai food. 

the menu is extensive, the tastes are fantastic, the prices are great. The staff was attentive. The ambiance was nice.


Cons: the neighborhood sucks. While we were eating this fantastic fare, the view outside the windows was of homeless men fighting, pigeons picking at garbage, and street walkers (that looked like post-apocalyptic movie extras) working the street. 
turn your back to the street and its a 5 star experience.
author: Russell H.

description:
I deeply appreciate how clean this place is. 
They've got a wide menu. Alligator? Rabbit? Sure! 
Couldn't order it for lunch because i'm in a rush, but I had the pad thai and it was very flavorful. 

I'd definitely come back, especially since they are open till midnite, accept ATM cards AND DELIVER! Not many joints do so in the TL..
author: Susy C.

description: I had never eaten true Thai cuisine before but Lers Ros Thai came highly recommended by a friend who lives in San Francisco who said it's some of the best Thai food he's ever had anywhere in the world. Needless to say, Lers Ros Thai had a lot to live up to. On a Sunday night the place was packed, with those waiting to get seats standing awkwardly at the front of the restaurant near the door. Just hope that when you are seated you don't get a table near the door because these waiting people will be literally standing right next to you while you dine. We ordered two appetizers and two main dishes to split among two of us. The Koh Moo Yang, with its grilled slices of pork shoulder was so tender and was perfect when dipped in the chili and rice powder sauce. The Nuer Tod (fried sun-dried beef) was delicious. Though the restaurant was busy our waitress was very attentive and pleasant. If you're looking for authentic Thai food in San Francisco, definitely give Lers Ros Thai a taste.
author: Matt P.

description:
Definitely the best Thai restaurant that I've ever tried in SF.  

Went there with one friend on a Thursday around 5:45pm.  The restaurant was empty and we were the first party there.  The service was awesome.  Everyone was so friendly and welcome.  Like other Thai restaurants, they are also very effective and attentive.  

The menu is very extensive.  They even have a lot of special dishes that I've never seem it in other Thai restaurant.

Since we were not super hungry, we ordered:

#12 Som Tom Poo (green papaya salad with chili, tomatoes, lime based salad dressing and RAW CRABs) - Very good.  It was crispy and fresh.  

#77 Pad See-Ew (flat noodle, served with chicken ) - The portion was smaller than other Thai restaurant but the flavor was pretty good.  The chicken was not too dry.  

9) Koh Moo Yang (Grilled slices of Pork Shoulder) - OMG it was so good.  The pork was so tender and seasoned well.  

Next time, I will try more of their specialities.
author: Liza T.

description: VERY plain restaurant and chairs with no backs.  Not a big fan.  AMAZING food however.  The pastry puff appetizer was AWESOME. The "medium spice" papaya salad with prawns was BEYOND hot--watch out for this--and I ain't no spice wimp!  The red curry with chicken needed salt too--but really tasty.  Decent service.
author: Dre C.

description: Omg!!! This place ... Where do I begin? I came to visit here back in April on a trip and I heard about this place from Vice. I loved this place. The atmosphere was nice and the night scene there was pretty cool. The waitresses were really sweet and helped us order a few popular items from the menu. I loved their pork and sausages. My friends got Phad Thai and I got Drunken Noodles. They were all so yummy. I loved the seating, it was very different. I really want to go again when I visit San Fran! Next time I'll get a drink.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Even though they did not honor my group's 6:30 PM reservation, I still forgive them. Even though they brought out my dish after my entire group finished eating, I forgive them.  Why?  Because I love their food.  

After eating authentic food in Thailand, I have to say that this is the most authentic I've had in the US.  And it's cheap.

Beware of how crowded it gets on Friday/Saturday nights.  The waitresses try their best honestly, so I don't blame them.  

This is my default Thai place that I take everyone when they want Thai food.
author: Anna T.

description:
4 stars is for their food.  Service would be 1 star.

We came around 2pm and the place is only half filled.  We were promptly seated and quickly forgotten.  For 20 minutes, not even 1 glass of water; luckily we had our water bottles.  I kept trying to make eye contact with the 3 wait staff bustling about, to no avail.  

The place came highly recommended through some Thai co-workers, so we stuck it out.  Although, the food came really quickly after our order was taken, and the food did not disappoint. 

Will come back to pick up order next time.
author: daphne w.

description: It has been 1.75 hours since I placed an order for delivery (1.6 miles away from the restaurant) and 6 phone calls to them later I am still without food. They need to fire their delivery driver.
author: Kimberly R.

description:
My favorite Thai food in the city.

I believe I tried a significant portion of their menu by now and everything was good.
Mainly I recommend trying the unorthodox items they offer like their bomb pork belly and shoulder.

They deliver almost everywhere in the city, but I still recommend swinging by for dinner as the service is also excellent.

5 stars
author: Assaf B.

description: great food, decent prices but the wait staff had a very put off attitude. I think that's most of San Francisco though so far IMO. The pork belly was amazing!
author: Natalie C.

description:
I came here to meet my friend up and some of her friends.  Luckily reservations were made or we would've been waiting outside like the other people I saw.  We did get the stink eye from those folks since most our party was late.  Service is "interesting." You have to flag down a server to get anything and even then they ask you to kindly wait since they were running around with other orders and/or dishes in hand.  

We ordered different things and shared amongst the group.  Things that stood out to me were the curry, pork belly, and pad see ew.  It was generally enough food for me but I think some of us in the group wished dthere was more.  I want to give this place 4+ stars but what caught me by surprised is when I was heading home I was sooo thirsty.  Not from the spiciness but it was like a dry feeling..something I only get when I eat something with massive amounts of MSG.  =/
author: Kim D.

description: It's pretty damn good, yet I've had better Thai, as I'm sure most have.
author: AJ V.

description:
Amazing food from amazing Thailand! 

There are so many choices, I always get stumped when I'm ordering here. But the food is authentic, and believe me on that (I'm Thai and work at a thai restaurant so I know what's up). My favorite by far is the Neur Nam Tok which is a grilled beef salad. This, my friends, is the best one I've ever had outside of Thailand and LA. The spicy lime dressing and oh man it is just too good to be happening in my mouth ;). You know they're not lazy when they GRILL the meat instead of boiling it. 

The pad thai is tasteful, yen ta fo is awesome. I'm pretty sure the soups are great even though I have yet to try them. Every time I eat here, I'm always telling myself, "man I'm so damn HAPPY I made this choice!" They don't give much for the single sticky rice order sadly. So If you eat a lot of sticky rice, I'd get 3 or 4. I'm not so sure about the jasmine rice though.

It is clean, compared to some places! Yummy yummy in your tummy! They also deliver! Oh, what a plus! The service is nice. It's in the Tenderloin which is interesting and they close late! Go here if you want some real Thai food.
author: Nandiya A.

description: I love their food! It's as authentic as you can get in the Bay Area, but it's only 4 stars because of how packed the place is and the wait. Food is definitely 10/10! :)
author: Tara P.

description: The BEST Thai food ever! Awesome laab, duck or chicken.  Papaya salad is so delicious.  Pad see eew is the best I've had. Definitely worth the drive from LA.. Better than Thai town in Hollywood!
author: Edwina Y.

description: To be fair the food was great, the choices were wide and they had some cool things like rabbit, alligator, and raw crab...the services was fast. The only thing that really bothered me was the blaring noise level, it was deafening! Not sure why, maybe the layout but it was hard to enjoy my food and conversation.
author: Dang L.

description: Had lunch here on a recent Saturday. Ordered 5 dishes.  All but one (fried rice with crab meat) were too salty.
author: Ky E.

description:
I've been here twice. The first time was pretty long ago but I remember it being quite delicious. I went here two weeks ago though and it just so happened that it was their 4th year Anniversary. CONGRATS LERS ROS! They had an open bar for the customers so that made the dining experience especially wonderful. We ordered the larb, panang and pad thai which were pretty typical Thai dishes. All three dishes were so delicious, every flavor that is expected of the dishes was there.

The customer service was great as well, not to mention they gave us a free chopstick set which doesn't sound so glamorous but I assure you it was really pretty.

Overall, I can say that once I reside in the city for grad school this will become one of my go-to places for my Thai dining needs!
author: Jimmy H.

description:
I picked this place for dinner with my co-worker.

We ordered BBQ pork skewers for appetizer, Tom Ka Soup and pad Thai. 

Pork skewers dish was average. Soup was delicious and pad thai was below average. All noddles in pad Thai were stuck together like they were prepared long time ago and were just sitting in the kitchen 

Pork was ok, but chewy.

Soup was hot and spicy. We ordered it with shrimps and mushrooms and were lucky to split 5 shrimps and 3 mushrooms between two of us...

Service was quite strange first they ignored us for a while, then brought appetizer, soup and main dish at the same time... 

I had better Thai...
author: Anelya S.

description:
After an early party in the city, we headed over to this Thai place for some late night grub.  I heard this place was really good from multiple people, so had pretty high expectations.  We ordered some fried rice, red curry with duck, pad see ew, duck larp, and mango sticky rice.  Everything was pretty good - I especially liked the duck larp (Larp Phed Yang).  It was served with lettuce, and so was really refreshing while also having that awesome duck richness. 

My least favorite thing there was the mango sticky rice.  The mango was super small, and the sticky rice was super liquidy.  Meh.  I've had much better mango sticky rice than that.  But that being said, the rest of the food was much better than a lot of other places I've eaten at, so it evens out.
author: Jenna L.

description:
Came her for a birthday gathering and they definitely did their best to accommodate us...well all 20 of us that is.  Not an easy task I know.  

The place is rather clean like others have pointed out bringing a nice atmosphere for new and improved thai dishes but keeping some of the traditional aspects of the environment and the menu.  

After hearing that they had some exquisite stuff like alligator and rabbit, I had to try it.  I was determined.  But to start things off, I went with a raw crab salad and followed it up with the rabbit dish which was a deep fried rabbit over some rice and sauce.   

Frankly, it didn't look like rabbit and it seemed a bit dry.  I wanted to like it but can't justify wanting to order it again.  Everything else seemed ok and fairly good from everyone's expression, but with a new thai restaurant amongst the 20 billion King of Thais and other establishments like San Jai Thai and Thai Stick, or that other one down the street, there's gotta be something to make this place stand out.  

But sorry, it didn't leave a mark on me to venture out here again.
author: Vincent K.

description: Attended a show at Great American Music Hall last night.  Searched Yelp for nearby restaurants and discovered Lers Ros.  Arrived at 745 without a reservation.  Restaurant was full (a good sign) but we were seated promptly.  Excellent food, friendly and efficient service, and good value.  Was pleasantly surprised to find this little gem in the Tenderloin.
author: Bill C.

description:
Came here for lunch with a friend.

The two-item lunch special (w/ brown rice as an option for $.50 more, was delicious.  There were lots of choices, incl. several vegan/vegetarian ones, and the serving of rice was extremely generous.

Minus one star for iceberg lettuce salad and the extremely loud dining room.
author: Jane D.

description:
Two words: PORK SHOULDER.  

God, that pork shoulder.  It's like bacon, but better.  Here's what you need to order when you get here (besides the pork shoulder, of course. That's a given):

- Sun-dried beef
- Tom yum soup 
- Stir fry chicken with the fresh peppercorn

My Thai friend introduced me to this place, and man, this is the real deal.  Don't come here if you're scared of bold, flavorful spices.  Seriously, one of my friends once asked the waitress to make it "less spicy."  The waitress gave him a look that said "you're in the wrong restaurant buddy" and replied, "Let me ask."  The food here is unapologetically authentic, and that's why it gets 5 stars from me.  Love it!
author: suzanne l.

description:
Mind. Blowing. Thai.
I went on a whim. Won't bore with extraneous details that nobody cares about. Just know that the pork shoulder larb was quite possibly one of the best things I have ever put in my mouth. 'Nuff said.
Per the friendly server's recommendation I tried a beef dish with peppercorn. It was good but not the best. It was truly all about the pork shoulder larb, folks. That will have me dreaming of Thai and coming back for more for a long time. This place truly is everything it's cracked up to be. I don't even know how to explain how the larb is 50 thousand times better than the best larb you've ever tried but it really is. It is an absolute explosion on the palate of lime, spice, crunch, and whatever else makes larb so absolutely amazing. 
I hope to be a regular here as it's within walking distance and a new all time favorite.
author: Matt H.

description:
I LOVE this place!!! I bring every out of town visitor here for dinner. I think I can safely call this a tourist attraction. The pork belly item is one of my favorites. I cannot recall the name, but it's listed underneath the "appetizers" list, and I think it even says 'amazing! pork belly' in the description. Real talk. 

The papaya salads are spicy but packed with flavor while still seemingly light. If you go, I would definitely make these two mandatory orders... I've been here about 10 times, but I haven't explored their 100+ item menu much. I always get the two noted above along with yellow curry, pad see yew, tom yum gah and fried rice. Whenever I go to a Thai restaurant, I try to order as many duck dishes as possible. Thai duck is amazing!!!

Lers Ros Thai, thank you for opening my appreciation to Thai food. 

Forever Satisfied,
Emily
author: Emily L.

description:
I'm probably not anywhere near qualified to christen this restaurant "authentic," but from what I've heard/tasted, this place rises far above the standard americanized fare you'd find at most other area Thai restaurants. More exotic proteins like alligator, frog, boar, and rabbit feature prominently on the menu. Pad Thai and Pad See Yu don't. You get the point. Do yourself a favor and branch out.

The pork belly appetizer, green papaya salad (with raw crab), and Tom Kreang Nai soup are all excellent. Fried quail and house special frog are great. BBQ chicken is good.

I've come here three times and never had anything bad. Some dishes are better than others (I think this place probably suffers a little bit from having such an extensive menu instead of focusing on doing a few things great), but just tell one of the servers what kind of food you're interested in and they'll help you hone down your choices. Happy eating!
author: Kyle M.

description: Great food, received a recommendation from a passerby on the street. Would definitely recommend going in for a meal as the decor is well done, if not delivery is a very speedy option.
author: Krish P.

description:
One of the best Thai Restaurants that I've been to! I enjoy all of the different flavors in the dishes. The menu is very extensive which makes it kinda hard to decide what to get. Customer service is great, they greet you and try to accommodate you if you don't have a reservation. I had a party of 5 which was odd for their tables because they mostly fit 4 unless you combine some tables, but they asked if I would mind having a seat on the side, which was fine by me. Throughout the experience, they always had someone check up on us to see if we needed more water or napkins. What impressed me is that since I had a seat blocking the way of some other tables, they always walked around to fill water or supply napkins without inconveniencing me. 

I love spicy foods so this place is perfect, if you aren't I would suggest to you to express your spicy level otherwise you won't be able to enjoy the food. My party couldn't take the spicy-ness of the seafood soup, so I ended up drinking it all hahah... 
 
If you have a large group, you better make reservations otherwise you can expect to wait at least 30mins and don't complain. I love how this place takes reservations when other places are good but have a small seating area and don't take reservations. As good as they are, I don't like to wait to be seated when I'm with a large group.

Last off, I work in the customer service field and a Thai customer of mine agreed with me that Lers Ros is one of the best and it's hard to find really good Thai Restaurants, so give this place a try! I bet you'll love it too! This was a great recommendation from a coworker and I love bringing people here =)
author: Jeffrey W.

description:
Feels like this is the only Thai restaurant around the immediate area filled with Vietnamese restaurants. Or maybe it's just me.

It was a casual dinner with my friends and I thought that I would have to order my usual Pad See Ew. Nope! Browsing through the menu, I discovered a couple of exotic dishes featuring meats like rabbit and alligator! One thing I love about eating is trying new and unusual dishes!

We went for the Red Curry, Stewed Pork Leg and the Pad Ped Alligator. The Red Curry was well-executed with good consistency flavor. The Stew Pork Leg was served on a bed of assorted vegetables ranging from simple greens and pickled vegetables. The pork was very juicy and moist as was the skin of the leg. Even so, the skin and fat could be somewhat overwhelming on its own unless eaten with something else like the rice or vegetables. The gator was quite an adventure! From the looks, you might think it's pork or dark chicken meat. The texture is similar to pork, but the flavor is funky. In a way, it's gamey and has a flavor of where its been. The chili peppers doesn't really help with masking that gaminess, but it's good in its own way. 

The service was efficient and friendly. No problems there. Parking might be since my friends had to park some distance away. Overall experience was pleasant, but I would love to try their Sea Bass next time.
author: Jeremy L.

description: Everything we had was good. Roasted duck salad was my favorite. The pork belly added a nice crunchiness to the dinner. Pad Thai and curry were good but nothing to write home about. Will definitely come back.
author: Trinity N.

description:
About as authentic a thai restaurant that i've found in the city so far. And I've tried about 7 of them so far. I know there's more, but i'm working around to it.
Some of the best stuff there are their soups. Very good and very authentic. Spicy! If you've ever been to thailand you know that not many places allow you to request spice levels. Try it out! You'll be happy.
author: Flocculator T.

description: One of the best Thai food in this city.  Even better than original Thai food in Thailand for some menu.
author: Ekasit J.

description:
We threw a party for 30 in Riverbed office. 
Everyone loved their food and gave me compliments for picking this vendor.  As a Singaporean who grew up eating Thai food, I liked their curry puff and curry.  I love their bigger portions of curry - bigger than Osha's and better quality. They have vegetarian curry in contrast to Osha who does not.  
Their steamed sea bass was huge - I think enough for two or three people. I did not eat it as I'm a vegetarian.  It looked wonderful though.
Papaya salad portion was large.  Be sure to order rice - as they don't come free with your dishes.
One of our party goer is a repeat customer of theirs.
I passed their business card and menu around.
author: Honest O.

description: Great food and great location. Ate there early so no wait and quiet.
author: Jaclyn M.

description:
This place had been popping up on my radar for about a month, so I suggested it when a friend asked where she was taking me out for my birthday. I was not at all disappointed and now understand the hype.

The service was above reproach, even when the place got really busy, not long after we arrived.  Food came out quickly and everything was superb. The stuffed calamari soup was fascinating and delicious, the papaya salad with prawns surprised me with it's fascinating flavors and textures that I didn't think possible in a simple salad, and the pork belly was incredible. I still think about the pork belly every day, with it's incredible crunch and sweet and salty sauce.

I was a little disappointed that our soup came out in one of the flaming pots, but without the flame. It wasn't crucial to the dish, but I'll admit that I was jealous of other tables' towering infernos.

Overall, a superb experience and excellent food.
author: Quinn S.

description:
Best Thai restaurant! 
Our usual orders: Tom Yum soup, Pad Thai, pork belly, and fried fish. 

Authentic and SPICY. Let them know if you want it mild. 

Be careful parking and walking in the neighborhood at night.
author: K C.

description:
Perhaps serving the most authentic-tasting Thai food in the area, Lers Ros always takes you back to the streets of Bangkok. I love the fact that they can make their food so spicy it gives you the shivers just by thinking about it. Seriously, try their Som Tum extra spicy and see what you'll get. I got to be a wimp about it. The raw crab they put in there, it's delicious. You can opt the crab out if you are a straight vegetarian, or dislike fishiness in your salad. 

Another thing I like about this place, is that they serve rice soup and little plate dishes to eat with your soup. Just like how the traditional families do it back home. Service is extra friendly and super efficient, given the number of waitresses working in the small restaurant.
author: Rika P.

description: Got a great recommendation from an SF friend.  Had the Tom Kha Kai soup -- best I've ever had.  Also the Pad Thai was AMAZING.  I will be back!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This is the only place for Thai food in SF. Lers Ros is in the Tenderloin and some may find it sketchy, I don't. The Tenderloin is the real deal, life and death, high crime. Drugs, pimps and ho's. This is the melting pot of SF. Some of the best ethnic eateries are in the Tenderloin. 

A word about the Loin. If you look frighten, you'll attract attention. If you are trying to be too cool,  you'll end up looking like a fool. I'm serious on this. Walk fast, look as if you are going somewhere. Try say hello to someone in passing, you just might make their day and you will begin to relax. This part of the Loin is tame, Larkin and Eddy no big deal.  

A friend took me took me to Lers Ros about 3yrs ago, I was hooked. My friend lived in Thailand for 2yrs and discovered this place by just walking the Loin. Outstanding food, cute little space, clean and well lite during the day. I have taken many of my friends to eat there and they too are hooked.  

This is  as good as it gets, forget the rest. I prefer the Larkin street location over Hayes street. The food is better for some reason and the corkage fee is still $9 a bottle vs $15 a bottle at Hayes street. I don't want to recommend food items here, everyone's taste is a bit different. The menu is unusual, go see for yourself. 

The restaurant can get a bit crowed, make a reservation, smile and go with the flow.
author: Lorna R.

description:
This review is based solely on delivery experiences.

Great Thai delivery!! I've ordered delivery only from the Tenderloin location but have eaten at the Lers Ros in Hayes Valley.  The Hayes Valley location is good Thai for a good price and has a nice atmosphere.

Food is never as good delivered compared to dining in, however delivery from the Tenderloin location is pretty good and consistent.  Lers Ros is my go-to thai delivery spot.  They have a large menu including soupy noodles!  I LOVE LOVE noodles and in the winter I find myself craving soupy noodles constantly.

The highlights:  consistent quality of food, delivery always on time or within estimated time given by person taking the order, food is yummy, delivery is FREE with a $15 minimum, soupy noodle delivery!

If you're feeling lazy...you can't go wrong with Lers Ros delivery =)
author: Becca L.

description: The food itself is not too bad, but for the price, the portions are quite small. Good for a 100# person, but not a 200# man. Carry out portions are smaller. The servers are always very nice and welcoming, but I can't eat there. It's always very crowded and very loud, everyone trying to speak louder than the other people at the table. Two long tables make it feel like a school cafeteria, everyone eating elbow to elbow. Not a place for a cozy quiet dinner. Three times didn't charm me. I'll move on.
author: Mikie E.

description:
One time I was eating here,  about a year and a half ago, and I saw a former student of mine there and said hi. He's Thai and said that Thais kinda consider Lers Ros place their secret. Looking at the number of reviews, I guess the secret is out. (Click on the "Trend" link in the ratings chart above to see an unbelievably consistent and high set of recent ratings)

Another Thai friend of ours feels this place is off its peak form--she's disenchanted. But my GF and I both still think it's great. Sometimes people of a given ethnicity are hypercritical of restaurants that serve the food from their homeland.  For instance, I basically disagree with about 2/3 of my Chinese GF's opinions about Chinese restaurants--the unkindest thing she can say is that it's Chinese food "for Whities." But those are the places I like! Bone fragments, bizarre sea creatures, duck's tongues and such hold no romance for me.

What was I writing about? Lert Rote (that's pretty much how it's pronounced in Thai, we're told). Good place. I like the BBQ Chicken, the sticky rice, the green papaya salad. This is the kind of place you take out-of-town guests: unique, reliably delicious,  clean, a degree of casual elegance, excitingly iffy location.

By the way, how come yelpers fairly commonly describe my Excelsior/Crocker-Amazon locale as "ghetto," which is bullshit, and not a word here about the undelightful array of TL semihumanity seen shambling down Larkin?
author: John H.

description: Reviews sound good and app says they are open but all locked up and dark at 8pm on a Tuesday.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Fantastic! But make reservations or be prepared to wait. We had combo platter (BBQ chicken, green papaya salad), shrimp fried rice (med hot) and pork belly with dry tom yum noodles...washed down with Chang beer. 
Service was on point and very friendly.  Prices were good too, you get lots of food.
author: Greg W.

description:
OK, so over 500 reviews later, I finally jump on the Lers Ros boat.  but what a fine boat it is!

I love me my long time favorite place a few blocks away, but have stopped since an order of pad thai for lunch costs $10.  Just not exactly a quick affordable bite for lunch, if you know what I mean.

the big thing is lunch specials for $7 something.  You get your choice of 2 entrees off a large list, which comes with rice and a small iceberg salad.  I am not complaining at all I got the chicken pad kra prow (my personal favorite, ground meat w/chili & basil) and pad makuer tofu (eggplant/tofu in garlic chili basil sauce).  Even though Kra prow is a cheap and quick homestyle kinda meal, I am never tired of it.  And although I understand you can make it with slices of meat, I love it minced.  Here and at my Oakland favorite Chai Thai Noodles.

Well, when I'm too lame to bring my lunch, I'll be hard pressed to decide between my pho shop on the corner or here!

I ran an into a work associate who mentioned that this is also his favorite place & that he routinely orders delivery here.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
Excellent soup, but weak curry, and too spicy overall (they didn't ask how spicy we want it either).

2.5 stars
author: Captain B.

description: Papaya shrimp salad does not disappoint!! We got the pad Thai and Tom yum soup as well
author: Tam B.

description: came in w/ my sister because it's one of their favorites & they live nearby.  we ordered the papaya salad, mixed seafood curry w/ sticky rice, garlic rabbit & noodle dish.  I thought everything was tasty but the rabbit that we were most excited about was dried out & over cooked & the portions are very stingy including the sticky rice. but I guess we could all use a little less right? lol... not!
author: Judy S.

description:
lers ros thai came onto my to eat list a while ago. so far,  the logistics of getting there has eluded me. i was delighted to see them at  sf food fest 2011(8.20)

sampling:  their signnature chicken larb (3)
-pretty good portion, marinated, tender chicken had a tartness and slight spiciness 
-thai tea(2) seem like a small portion, passed..

foodnotes:
-line moved first, lers ros had their own people and they were sychronized
-some cuties working the booth, only noticed them after i started eating, was checking out how the food was being prepped and the cuties were blocking my view.
-definitely will try out more at the eatery, if i can.
author: Victor G.

description:
Came here with family and had a really nice dinner. Service is extremely attentive, and amazing. Food was good, but not the best Thai food in town.

Papaya salad was not in season so we had the raw mango salad, prepared the same way, very spicy with salty blue crab
Chicken Satay was really good, moist, tender and came with awesome peanut sauce
Chicken Cabbage wraps was flavorful and came with a lemony spicy sauce
Shrimp Pad Thai tasted sweet, and came with bean sprouts on the side/not mixed in
Beef Pad See Ew was bland to me, but others at the table enjoyed it
Fried Catfish was really tasty and came with spicy pickle sauce
Pork Shoulder was tender and good, but not spectacular
Chinese Broccoli with fried pork belly was okay

Heard a lot of good things about this place. I will have to come another time and try other items on the menu. I regret not ordering curry, and not ordering duck.
author: Nancy F.

description:
I've always known that all the best Thai places (not to mention late-night dining) are in the couple of square blocks at the Civic Center / Tenderloin area.  Apart from occasional post-club grubs, I never really set aside a time to venture down here for Thai food.  First off, parking is a pain and I'd rather circle around in the inner sunset for the tried and true Marnee http://www.yelp.com/biz/marnee-thai-san-francisco-2#hrid:Y2cwuQUkqpWFY625h9Ihfg/src:self - but I have to admit, maybe it's to do with the neighborhood, but the Thai food in the Civic Center / Tenderloin area tends to be way edgier (read: spicier, tangier, and packed with more punch). 

I've always known that Lers Ros Thai is the alpha restaurant in the area.  Who haven't coughed after the first bite of their famous Duck Larb (concoction of leafy green, almost-crispy bits of roast duck and lots, and lots of peppers)? Or swooned over their stir-fried pork belly with basil?

There were tons of servers milling around, all of whom are friendly and more than willing to top up your water to calm the burning sensation in your mouth / give you the extra napkin to wipe that sweatin' forehead / what have you.
author: Ange L.

description: Horrible dinner last night thanks to Lers Ros Thai. We ordered green papaya salad with shrimp, pad thai and a veggie soup with kaffir lime leaves. The salad resembled soup and was so tremendously hot that I couldn't eat it. It should have been called chili salad with a little papaya and shrimp. My bf said that the pad thai was ok but not great (he didn't finish the dish meaning, it was bad). The soup was also swimming with chilis...and an overdose of kaffir lime leaves. Ew. We ended up throwing the dinner out (we'd done delivery) - headed out for frozen yogurt to calm our tastebuds...never.going.to.lers.ros.thai.again.
author: Erin W.

description: This is a consistently good Thai restaurant with really great lunch specials.  Our office ends up there about once a month for a group outing.  It's an easy choice because it has good food for the people who want quality and good prices for the people who want to eat lunch on the cheap.  I haven't been very adventurous with the menu, but I did have a good time with a bowl of flaming soup once.  I'm not a big fan of their table setup though, it fits more people than it used to but the hard bench seats are really tough to sit on for a long time.
author: Diana W.

description: We were extremely disappointed with this restaurant when our family party of 4 visited last week. We were told we would be seated in 10 minutes upon arrival. An hour later, we left to go elsewhere after 10 people, three tables, who arrived after we did were seated before us. We asked the hostess why and she didn't respond.
author: Susan A.

description: There are moments in our lives that we eat something that we never ever will forget.  For me that moment was at Abacus in Siem Reap, Cambodia.  I had grilled alligator tail and it changed the way I viewed the world.  Ler Ros Thai had an alligator dish that took me back there.  That accompanied by rice and coconut milk soup with shrimp completed a meal that made me feel like finally, there was a restaurant that understood the true meaning of authenticity.  If you really like Thai food, you already know that this is the place to be.
author: Lama B.

description:
A friend and I were on a mission from GOD.  To find something to eat.  We were walking aimlessly around, racking our brains.  Finally I uttered, "Thai?"  While this isn't normally on my friend's foodie agenda, he shot me a mischievous look and asked, "you wanna eat at my favorite Thai place?"  D-U-H!

Grubbing at Lers Ros is such a cool experience.  Like, I honestly don't know what it is about this place.  It looks normal enough but then there is the odd, neat little decorative things that stand out from the normal Thai experience.  I hesitate to call it 'Americanized', but you'll know what I mean.

I don't remember exactly what I ate but it tasted so fresh and the menu was so non-traditional I was really blow away by the choices they offered.  I'll go back and review the food soon.
author: Lily E.

description: 5 star food, one star customer management. If I have a 8pm reservation, and you can't find the wherewithal to get my party seated until 8:35, there is a serious problem.
author: Alexander S.

description:
Lers Ros Thai activated taste buds on my tongue in areas I didn't know existed. Thank you for that. The starting larb salad was deliciously SPICY, flavorful, and zesty to the max. 

But the fun didn't stop there -- the pork belly was DELICIOUS as everyone else has raved. Even though Michael Bauer has recently talked about being tired of pork belly, the pork belly with crispy rind at Lers Ros Thai is SO GOOD. 

In fact Michael Bauer gave Lers Ros Thai a good review recently on his blog Between Meals: "I was impressed by the spirit and execution of the food prepared by Tom Silargorn. The various dishes were distinctive, a vast improvement over places such as Manora Thai where most dishes are washed in sweetness." Read more: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/mbauer/category?blogid=26&cat=637#ixzz0XeVuVFSS

Liberal use of roasted rice powder, flavor, and spice at Lers Ros Thai. Best Thai food in San Francisco, hands down. Great open hours and super nice staff to boot.
author: Angie C.

description: We had lunch at this place. We ordered the Koh Moo Yang which was delicious, the Pad Thai and the Green Curry. Food is really good although the service was extremely bad. We had to wait almost 30 min between plates, we had to ask 3 times for a knife, and they brought the wrong Green curry, so we had too wait even longer. We recommend this place but do not go at rush hour or busy days.
author: Alvaro A.
