description: Food was good and service was great!  Had a beef pad prik Thai and it was perfect with they would've tossed the glass noodles with it but they said they couldn't and brought them separate, also had the sweet and sour chicken and it was good!  Thai tea was perfect!  Nice dinner and nice place!  Would definitely come back for more!
author: Hugo C.

description:
My favorite Thai restaurant in the city.  Its the most authentic one I've found.  The food is just consistently awesome, and the menu has amazing options.

My top picks:

*Papaya salad with prawns (keep in mind, even when you ask for mild here, it will still burn your mouth!  But they give you a big chunk of cabbage to chew on to help ease your fiery mouth, it really helps actually)

*Yum Woon Sen - silver noodle salad with dried shrimps, mushrooms, peanuts and ground pork (its da bomb, and mild will also burn your mouth)

*Pad See Ew - always delicious, the chinese broccoli is crunchy, and the noodles are perfectly seasoned

*Green Curry - they use Thai eggplants, which are a small green circular vegetable, and I love them! my only complaint is that they don't put more of those in the curry. I usually get it with chicken or pork.

*Clams - I've never seen clams on a thai menu before but these ones are good! They have a unique thai flavor to them.

*Fried tilapia or sea bass - they serve you a whole fish (bone included) and its always super tasty.  I tried the steamed sea bass last time, and i think the fried is better

*Pork belly with rind - everyones favorite, its just so damn good

Soups:
Unfortunately i am not a big fan of their Tom Yum or Tom Kha, i think they are way too salty.
Their noodle soups are really good though, they are in a different part of the menu than the other soups.  Reminds me of noodle soups I would order on the street in Thailand.

Enjoy!!!
author: Liz C.

description: I used to be a fan;  tonight's post-meal bathroom explosion changed that.  Guess I should take the health score of 71 more seriously...
author: dark l.

description:
Lunch specials here are amazing. $7.25 for a two different items with enough to take home. Also a great place for larger parties - I came here with six coworkers and had lunch family style with a few a la carte dishes with two orders of the lunch special. Broke down to around $10/person. 

We ordered fried trout was really delicious with extra crispy skin and a flavorful dipping sauce. The papaya salad with shrimp was also really tasty. 

I think the best thing about Lers Ros is the variety of dishes. It's not just the regular Pad See Ew and Yellow Curry type of place (although those options are available), so if you can get over the fact that it's deep in the TL, then I highly suggest stopping by. 

(Lers Ros recently opened another location on Grove and Hyde right next to The Grove. Their lunch specials are $9.75 for the same combinations)
author: NickJess S.

description: Absolutely wonderful. Their Tom Yum soup was a perfect balance of lemongrass, spices and the flavor of the prawns.  The Red Curry is creamy, flavorful and melts in your mouth. This restaurant has communal seating, something I do not care for, but the quality of the foods overpowers that negative.
author: Anna C.

description: food here is good, but i don't see what the hype is all about.  i've had just as good thai food elsewhere and for cheaper as well.
author: Wayne C.

description: Fantastic food. You do pay the price for quality however- it's not your typical cheap go-to Vietnamese food. I'd like to give the tom yum soup a special shout out as well as the garlic frog app. The standard dishes were good but not so much greater than ur normal spot (so if ur just looking to eat pad thai or something typical, save your money, get something else) . But it gets 4 stars for nice ambiance and solid food- ultimately it's a good date night spot!
author: Joana Z.

description: Just left their anniversary special tonight. It was my first time here. Amazing food! Service was great and to really heighten the experience, free drinks and anniversary swag ! love this place. Will be back for sure!
author: Linh V.

description:
I don't like to go out for Thai that often, but ever since I've found this place, I can't stop eating here.


Everything is really good, but I usually get the Pork belly A la carte, pork shoulder appetizer, dried tom yum noodles, and any of their soups/curries are delicious!


The portions are okay, definitely good for groups that want to eat family style.


The wait can get a little hectic on the weekends, so if you don't like to wait, try eating here for lunch or pick up to go.
author: J V.

description: Great food and friendly staff.  Delicious and authentic Thai food and price point is as expected. Definitely recommended
author: SeniorMcDicker P.

description: How I didn't know of this spot being so close to my house is so embarrassing! I went here with my fam bam around 3 on a Sunday and it was packed, which means its good. The pricing was fair, service was good, portions were huge and flavors were spot on. This has now become my go-to for thai!
author: Donna H.

description:
One of my top 3 fav go to for Thai in SF! Friendly and attentive staff. 

These are my favorite dishes:
pork shoulder!!
duck larb
pork belly
crab fired rice
lemongrass seabass

Make a reservation or expect to wait 45-?hours.
author: Maggie L.

description:
Hands down the best Thai food outside of Thailand. Delicious and clever use of thai spices that produce bold, not-your-run-of the-mill flavors. Usual Thai staples ( very tasty curry--just be advised of the spicy kick!) with some eclectic items thrown in
( alligator, rabbit ,frog ). MUST TRY ITEMS: ) #6 Nuer Tod (Fried sun-dried beef) & Fried banana with toasted almond ice cream.
author: aj s.

description:
I was disappointed from all of the great things I had heard and read and watched about Lers Ros Thai (Lers Ros was featured a few years ago on Check Please!).

I ventured down to Lers Ros recently after seeing the pre-Broadway preview of "Beautiful", the story of Carole King (which started off slow, but improved).  One of the truly great things about Lers Ros is that it is open until midnight, and when I arrived, slightly after 10:30p, there were quite a few tables for that time of night still occupied.  I sat at the bar.  I chatted in my pigeon-Thai with the servers and asked them if they could prepare vegetarian food for me (without fish sauce, without oyster sauce, and without MSG).  I knew they could; I've read the reviews.  I also wanted to know whether they could make the food really spicy, as I'm a sucker for spice.

At the direction of my server, I ordered the Por Pia Tod Jay (vegetarian fried spring rolls) and the Pad Kee Mao (sometimes referred to as "Drunken Noodles").  The spring rolls were impressively plump, served piping hot, and full of a lot of ingredients other than just noodles and cabbage.  There was a staleness to the flavor, however (I'm not suggesting they weren't fresh, but maybe the oil was overdue to be changed?).  The sauce didn't taste homemade either, as it was too artificially sweet.  I wouldn't likely order them again, but in theory, they could be good.

The Pad Kee Mao was super greasy.  There were a good amount of vegetables in the dish -- which I liked -- and the portion was large, but it was just so damn greasy.  I compare it to recent noodle dishes I recently had a two Thai restaurants in Los Angeles (Bulan Thai and Bodhi Thai), and the amount of grease was striking.  Can't say I'd order that again either.  I may try -- particularly if it's a late night and nothing else is open -- a curry or a spicy basil tofu dish should I ever return, but I can't say that this was a particularly memorable outing.  In fact, it was exactly on par with all of the other overrated greasy Thai joints that pepper the Bay Area but that everyone seems to love so much.  I ate at three different Thai restaurants during my latest visit to Los Angeles, and while each had its shortcomings, each was more satisfying and less greasy than my experience here at Lers Ros.

I'm kinda bummed.  I would have liked to have finally found a go-to Thai place.  I haven't been to Modern Thai in quite some time and I've only tried Marnee Thai and Thai Idea once.  I wonder how those would stack up should I revisit.  

For now, Lers Ros is only going to be a late-night Union Square/Tenderloin backup, should I need to get a later-night fix on Thai delights.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description:
Food.... 4.5
Service ......minus 3

I don't care if you're about to close .. You don't take away my food without asking me if I was finished !
author: Demanding T.

description:
I came here a number of times and Lers Ros ( which means delicious in Thai) has never captivated me.

The first time that I came here was right when this place had  just opened and they just had their " Grand opening". Back then, there were a big buzz around Thai community about this place and how "Exotic" their food were (they indeed had a lot of Thai Exotic foods in their menu). But once I tried  their food, I really felt that they were  just OK for me, not super bad but I really had better Thai food  from other Thai places. 

   Months later when another friend of mine (who had not tried this place yet) also wanted to come to this place, first I refused base on my first experience but I decided to give them a second chance since by then I had read a lot positive reviews about this place and thought that they had changed or  improved their food. On that day, we ordered a lot of food as my friends intended to take the left over for her next meals. And once we tasted the food that we ordered, I realized that nothing had changed around here.Especially a fish disc that we ordered was so salty, we could not eat it. At the end, my friend decided  not to take any left over home.

    Their service was pretty good but for me, as a Thai,  It' s all about the food. I always have my own high standard for Thai food. As I believed that  I really know what a great Thai food tastes like.... In my book, it doesn't taste like this.
author: Dom G.

description:
So, my friend and I took up a night's stay in the "cultural district" of SF at what was probably the WORST HOTEL in the city thanks to our naivety in Travelocity research.

We were a little less than optimistic for our food/bar selections nearby - and the safety factor in getting there, haha.  Fortunately, my phone is GENIUS and I have the yelp app.

Low and behold, we discover Lers Ros Thai on the app.  It was within walking distance of our horrendous abode (Rodeway Inn, if your curious mind must know).  The walk through the TL to our destination was less sketch than anticipated.  It was well, well worth it.  I can't even explain how eating at this restaurant on night one of our ten day road trip from SD to SEA completely set the stage for awesomeness but it did.

First off, the prices are fantastic for a city like San Francisco.  My friend and I were delightfully full when we left and spent only a whopping $34.61 before tip.  Secondly, the staff was friendly, attentive, and helpful.  The ambiance was pleasant as was the music (ambient and well-fitting to the place without being overly loud and drowning out the conversation my friend and I were having).  

Being the pseudo vegetarian that I am, I ordered the spicy tofu with rice (#46R).  The tofu was crisped and tossed with chili, peppers, garlic, bamboo shoots and basil.  I am a huge fan of fresh basil. My carnivorous friend ordered Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (#62R), which is pork belly with crisped rind and basil leaves.  Both entrees were under $10 each.  Sapporo and sake for two completed the meal for a very nominal price.

The menu is extensive - 10 pages online alone - so there is definitely something for everyone's palate if you are even remotely a lover of Thai food.  I can't imagine any future trip to SF without this place.  I will definitely be back and dragging whoever is with me through the streets of the Tenderloin to get there!
author: nicolette l.

description:
This place has excellent food, but is so poorly run, and that is the sole reason why it only deserves one star. Don't bother trying to get delivery unless you live next door.  

Here's the story.... 

I ordered food from here for delivery after hearing from my friends how good it was, and they were right!  It was delicious!  So  I ordered again the next week, and it was equally good.  

The next week, I was craving some delicious tom yum and called for an order. I was told I was out of their delivery area.  Huh?  I tried to explain that I had ordered twice before without a problem and was told by a woman named Sarah that I was not in their delivery area.  I attempted to explain my confusion over her refusal to deliver to my house and was simply told the driver had decided my house was too far away.  What?! The driver? But I tipped so well.....I was confused at this seemingly arbitrary policy.  My house is exactly 2.1 miles from Lers Ros.....9 min away!!  Its not like I'm at Ocean Beach or Excelsior trying to get delivery, I mean, come on!! 9 min away!!

In one brief experience, they have lost my business, my money, and my recommendation.  Sorry Lers Ros, even once you open in Hayes Valley, you will not be getting my business
author: BaconLover J.

description:
This is where we had our rehearsal dinner for our wedding.  This place is pretty small and gets VERY packed, so I was glad we were able to make reservations for our party of 25 a couple weeks in advance.  Our servers were very accomodating to our group, even giving us wine buckets for the wine we brought in AND they did not charge us wine corkage fees.  They just wouldn't let us open the bottle of Grey Goose we bought because they only have a license to serve beer & alcohol.  Totally no biggy!

My husband and I had eaten there before and we can vouch that their pork belly dish has to be one of our favorite dishes of all-time!  The crispy outside with the delicious spicy sauce is just pure heaven!  So for our rehearsal dinner, we definitely let our party know how good it was.  A number of people in our party ended up ordering it and they delighted! I know a bunch of them have gone back to Lers Ros since then, too. =)  We also ordered a variety of other dishes that were all delicious; however, the pork belly just overshadows them all, in my opinion, so I can't remember the names lol.

Minus .5 star because a few people in my party ordered Pad Thai (Lord only know why when you can get that anywhere haha) and those seemed to take awhile to come out.  Minus .5 star also because it is quite a small restaurant and for dinner you can feel like a can of sardines in there.

All in all, I really enjoy this place a lot and can't wait to go back for that pork belly dish.  It's definitely worth the diet cheat day! ;)
author: Allysa H.

description: i had heard such great things about this place but wasn't that impressed.  maybe we ordered wrong.  the menu is really overwhelming and has a ton of stuff.  we got the grilled pork shoulder appetizer, which seems to be popular, and that was tasty.  then the waiter told us to get the combo which came w/ papaya salad, grilled chicken and sticky rice.  it was ok but not that exciting.  we should have probably ordered something more adventurous.
author: Helen T.

description:
Despite the location, this is one of the best Thai restaurants I have ever eaten at. I ordered the Chicken Pad Thai and it was so savory! The proportions are decent and it tasted even better the next day. They give you a good amount of bean sprouts so you can have that crunchy feeling with your noodles. 
The service was prompt and helpful. They even box your food to-go for you! The Thai Tea was delicious, not too sweet which is always a plus.
I would definitely come here again.
author: T L.

description:
BEST Pad Thai I have EVER had....and I mean EVER. This place is so damn good is ridiculous. The papaya salad was DELICIOUS and spicy just the way i like it. The red coconut curry, and pad see ew  were also great (though the pad se ew had too much meat and not enough noodles) I can't wait to go back!!!

I never thought I'd find a place better than Ruen Pair but I have.
author: Layla L.

description: We were in the city and we love Thai food so decided to try this place. We didn't wait long, which is good considering all the walking we had done before we got there. The service is what made me give it a low rating. The food was ok. We had to ask twice for my beer even though they brought the others their drink. Finally our waiter said your beer is coming and I decided then just to cancel the beer. I asked for napkins and received  none. No refill on our waters. It's always the service that makes the experience a great one or a fail. I will not come here again or recommend this place, even though they seem to have a great overall rating.
author: Foodie S.

description:
This IS the best Thai in SF. 

So, i'm at a bar near a large group of Thai girls (birthday party?) and making small talk, we start discussing food.  Most are in food service industry, "so where you do grab thai food when you don't want to cook or on a day off?"  Next thing i know, one girl starts moaning about missing home and that this is the place that reminds her most of mom's cooking! My life has never been the same, since.

So, i've never been to Thailand and my mom's not Thai, but I've been eatin' their food regularly in every city i have lived/worked: Chicago, Seattle, Portland , San Diego, LA and now SF. Although Osha's pumpkin curry w duck is amazing, when i really need to get in touch with my Siam side, i go here. 

The menu is long and i'm still working my way thru it but here is what i liked so far:

-Pork belly with basil (#62) [their best dish]
-beef salad (yum nam tok)
-lamb salad (larb phed yang)
-Rad Nah noodle
-steamed sea bass with chopped herbs (#112)
-tom sabb soup with pork spare ribs 

P.S. I hear rice soups were good, will let you know.
author: Joseph C.

description:
After watching the first 3 quarters of the Heat Thunder game and consuming many beverages my group had a strong desire for some burn your tongue off spicy thai food, with only one prerequisite...they must have the basketball game on.

This is where Lers Ros comes in.  I have no idea where the name came from or what it meant, I was pronouncing it in a french sort of way so obviously I was way off but they had the game on and it was thai so lets try it!

Plus for the game being on, plus for lots of seating and a plus for the electro pumping through the speakers just quiet enough for me to make out Kaskade and Bassnectar beats.

The menu is intimidatingly long with over a 100 different entries, but there is definitely something for everyone if you can schlep through all the entries.  They have all the basics and some more adventurous ones like alligator.  I wanted to order this and split it between the group but no one else wanted to get crazy.  I wound up settling for the green curry with chicken and a beef dish with assorted spices, onions, basil and all the normal amazing thai ingredients.

I ordered the dishes spicy and holy shit they were spicy!  Definitely the spiciest thai food I have had and it was exactly what I needed.  Be cautioned thai spicy is the spiciest they go and that has got to be extremely uncomfortable.

The curry was delicious and the chicken was perfect while the beef was just okay, the pieces of meat tended to be a little fatty and not the best quality.  We also ordered the chicken satay which was great and came with a huge side of peanut sauce to dump on everything else you have ordered.

If you are in the area definitely check it out but I recommend sticking to the chicken dishes!
author: Ryan J.

description:
I tried the rabbit meat. I felt really weird eating it but it turned out to be okay. I didn't expect it to have so many bones in it. It was deep fried with garlic and had a side of hot sauce. Mmm garlic...

We usually get the rice soup (jook in Chinese) with the sides. They have a side which is preserved duck egg with fish sauce. It was an interesting twist but it was very overpriced. I suggest you try something more unique instead of the duck egg (you could get this in the jook at Chinese restaurants).

The service is always very good and the servers are very nice. Only gripe is it's in a bad neighborhood and there isn't always parking at night.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Delicious Thai food! I came here for dinner around 8p on a Saturday night with two friends.

There appeared to be a long wait when we first arrived, so one of my friends decided to jump out of the car and put our name down. It actually didn't end up taking that long since the other parties in-waiting were much larger. By the time my other friend and I found a parking spot and walked up to the restaurant, our names had just been called.

Our waitress was quite friendly. She offered us a few suggestions - particularly on the differences between the curries. Our group ordered the green curry rice plate, the red duck curry (no rice place option available), steamed white rice and a side cucumber salad. 

The cucumber salad was decently sized for a side. I think we all managed to have a good amount. It was pretty traditional - solid, but nothing out of the ordinary.

The duck curry was great! It was spicy, but not overwhelmingly so. The duck itself was tender and flavorful - and there was plenty of it. The pineapple was subtly sweet, which was the perfect complement to the savory and spicy flavors. 

The side rice portion was huge. I thought it was a pretty good deal. 

My friend enjoyed the green curry. Since it was a rice plate order, there was less curry compared to mine. However, he thought it was just the right amount. I ended up taking a sizable portion of my to-go.

Throughout the meal, the service was top notch. They are very attentive with regard to water...we didn't stay too long, but they refilled our cups at least 4 times. We left with full glasses. 

Walking out we were practically bombarded with thank-yous. I appreciated how efficient they were without trying to rush us. Overall a great experience!
author: Alyssa W.

description:
We came back to find a packed house past 9pm last night (Thursday). I think Lers Ros is definitely on top of their game now, everything we had was excellent. We had:

Som Tum with Raw Crab - They include the whole crab in their prep, unlike Ozone which only gives you small bits of crab. The salad dressing was perfectly balanced and pungent, so much better then our first time.

Grilled pork shoulder - Really can't go here without ordering this. The sauce and pork slices are top notch.

Pork Larb - Again, spot on seasoning and balance. The hit of toasted rice powder provides a nice texture against the acidic, salty sauce.  Mint, scallions and red onions rounded it all off. This may be the best pork larb I've had.

Steamed sea bass - Nicely steamed fish and tasty slices of cooked garlic. This was good, especially if you're looking for a healthy alternative to the fried trout. But I found myself missing the crispiness of the fried prep, as well as the excellent sauce served with.

To finish it off, we had Pad See Ew and Pad Kee Mow which were both typical, but hit the spot.  I think Thai noodles are growing on me.
author: Derrick V.

description: Crispy pork belly with chinese broccoli; Thai style shrimp omelette; papaya salad with salty egg; Hot and sour Po-tak soup! If you are adventurous enough, try these authentic Thai dishes and thank me later!
author: Joelle K.

description: As close as it gets to the curry dishes i used to have in Thailand and by far the most authentic Thai resto in the city.
author: Beril Y.

description:
Awesome service but even greater food.  Concierge said it was second best in area ... I can't imagine any better!  

May eat there again this week!
author: Bruce W.

description:
Don't be deterred by the location.  The food is great!
I always thought this was some sketch place in the Loin but when we walked in, we were greated by extremely friendly waitresses, a clean, minimally decor interior and lots of people enjoying their dinners.

I like to go with the basics at a new place - if they can't get the basics right, what can they do right?

Green papaya salad with grilled shrimp (medium spicy) was tasty and SPICY! I love spicy but thank god I got it medium.  My lips were tingly and on the verge of burning so it was perfect.

Entrees:
Pad Kee Mao with Chicken and  
Koong Kra Prow( Prawns stir-fried with BASIL and hot chili sauce) were great.  

The Kee Mao came with a side of fresh bean sprouts so that was tasty to mix together.  The noodles weren't dry and totally sticking together.

The prawns were plentiful.

Avoid the sticky rice.  The portion was tiny and it looked kind of old (slightly yellow).  Stick with jasmine rice.
author: S K.

description:
After my amazing 20 minute delivery time last time I ordered, I was told tonight that I live too far away (in SoMa, about 1.2 miles away) for delivery.  The person I spoke with said that they delivered last time because they didn't realize how far away I was.

If 1 mile is the delivery cutoff that's pretty poor!  I'm sad that I won't be eating here anymore - we really liked the food and I considered it our go-to Thai restaurant.  I'm still giving them 2 stars because the food is good but I want to give 1 because I won't get to enjoy it anymore from home.
author: Meredith K.

description: Delicous! We ordered the Tom Yum Koong, Pad Thai, Curry Pastry Puffs, Green Curry, and Kang Keaw Wan (crispy pork belly). Everything was delicious, my favorite dish was the crispy pork belly! Just a side note: the Tom Yum Kai was pretty spicy, so beware if you don't like spice!
author: SuhWon L.

description: Lers ros is the best Thai food I've ever had-- and I don't even like Thai food but I like Lers Ros. The duck larb is amazing.
author: K M.

description: Im willing to give Lers Ros 4 stars for being original and offering Aligator on their menu. As for the dish itself - it consisted of ground gator and was a bit too spicy for my taste.  The set up here is pretty swanky, which is a bit weird because its in the decidedly unswanky TL. Still Lerso Ros has the potential, and as they grow and add locations i look forward to seeing the competition between Osha and LR.
author: Oleg H.

description:
Here's a list of must haves for all those first timers (I hope this would be helpful. I know I would appreciate a list like this because the other day I came here, their menu confused me - there was just way too much writing and different types of food):
- tom yum goong soup: typical soup that all Thai places will offer, but this one here will burn your tongue and stomach, but in the end, you will undoubtedly think it was worth the pain, cause it's just THAT good, I tell you.
- fried rice: listen to me and order this and tell them you want it with brown rice. Remember to ask for brown rice and you will not forget their fried rice
- stir fried pork belly: so fatty and delicious. This one's my favorite - everything about it is just great 
- catfish in spicy sauce: don't know the exact name, but this one is a must have - again, it's hot hot hot, but too good to miss out on

Before I forget, make sure you grab a handful of the candies they have before leaving because they are so good! Guava flavored candies - I think I ate 10 of them in 15 minutes haha

You can skip dessert here, because their sticky rice with mango isn't too great - there was only like...4 pieces of mango. Not worth it.
But if you must, go ahead and order the fried banana with toasted almond ice cream (I highly recommend this flavor especially if you're tired of the plain old vanilla ice cream but is not feeling too adventurous to try other bolder flavors).
Total bill for our party of 6 came up to $120ish and that was for dinner. Everyone left feeling full and content, so all is well. 
Oh, the only downside is their music playlist - they'd play Benny Benassi's Cinema, Aviici's Levels, etc, which... doesn't quite suit the whole Thai atmosphere, but I guess that's okay. And the waitresses don't speak English very well, so it was kind of confusing when she repeated our orders.
author: Melissa S.

description: This place is in the ghetto but it is GOOD! We all got different plates and shared and I was so impressed how delicious everything was. My favorite is the Pad See Mao which is like Pad See Ewe but spicy! DEF WORTH TRYING!
author: Brittini S.

description:
The best part of this place is the winding hallway to the bathroom. 

Food  is good but no better than other above average Thai places in the city. 
I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again but wouldn't avoid it if I was in the area and there wasn't a line.
author: I Like Food, Food Taste Good ..

description: We love thai food and were recommended Lers Ros by an also Thai food lover friend. The salty green curry with eggplant was the finest dish for me, followed by the som tom koong yang (spicier than i am used to, but still yummy!!. The curry in particular was wonderfull, flavourful, intriguing. Would love to return many times get to try everything on the menu.
author: Kiaan O.

description: One week earlier, I called to make a reservation for 6pm thanksgiving night. but found out it's actually closed when I arrived. I don't understand why did you let me make this reservation if you are going to close. Really angry and disappoint about this.
author: C L.

description:
Everything was good! Authentic Thai food that serves food at Thai spice levels (be forewarned.)

Duck larb - what is larb?!? Still can't tell you other than that it is D-licious. A good combo of spicy, salty duck, and vinegary fish sauce. Just as good as everyone says.

Pad Thai - the perfect dish to order as a side to cool off your mouth mid meal. Sweet and tangy, one of the best pad thai's I've had here. Not to eggy too which is a plus.

Pork Belly - spicy! Liked it but couldn't eat too much of it because of the heat it packed. Might not order it again in the future especially since they have so many other fabulous items on the menu.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I'm at a friend's house in the Haight/Cole Valley.  There's a Thai place on the corner we're thinking about patronizing...until we see it only has three stars on Yelp (lots of one-star reviews).  I trust the hip SF Yelpers, so a quick search for "Thai delivery" brings up Lers Ros Thai.  Free delivery over $15?  Yes please!

Plusses:
Although they didn't tell us when the food would arrive over the phone, everything arrived within 40 minutes (around 6 p.m. on a Saturday night).  The food was well packaged, we could pay with a credit card over the phone and add a tip on the receipt, and we got 4 dishes a la carte for under $50 (including tip).

Tofu was steamed or braised with the curry, not separately fried or added in, which was tasty and healthy to boot.  Also, all the packaging except the delivery bag was recyclable.

Minuses/things to note:
The rice plates are a half portion of food with rice, and the a la carte plates are the full portion of the entree without rice.  The default level of spice is quite spicy, even for folks like us used to spicy food.  Might want to let them know your preference when you order.

Like many places, they repeated our credit card over the phone in the restaurant as we told it to them.  Oh well!

Overall:
The menu is extremely varied, so props to them for that, and Lers Ros also makes good (and spicy) renditions of Thai stand-bys like green curry.  This will be my friend's new go-to Thai place, even though we don't know how to pronounce the name.  Plus, they're coming to Hayes Valley soon!
author: Sohini R.

description: The only reason you give place 5 stars would be because that is as high as you rank. Amazing!!! Incredible Tom Kha /prawn soup, absolute nectar of the Gods. The curry was second to none. The food is only matched by the service. Very kind and patient. First stop whenever I return.
author: H Chris K.

description:
Maybe they should rename Little Saigon to Little Siam!  Hungry after an open bar fundraiser at the Green Room, we scrambled up Larkin in hopes of some late night pho.  I must have pho-got that those places close early, but thankfully Lers Ros Thai was there for us to serve the best Thai food I've had outside of Bangkok!  With over 100 dishes on the menu, this is definitely a late night repeat.

Koh Moo Yang: Most slow roasted pork comes in the form of stringy pulled pork.  This one came in slices that looked tough, but were still melt in your mouth soft.  They described the dipping sauce as simply chili powder sauce, but it was so much more complex than that!

Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob: I am so sick of Asian joints that serve mushy pork belly.  This was chicharrón crispy even after absorbing all the awesome base sauce.  I think there were some veggies too, but totally forgot them when having all this better-than-bacon dish.

Pad Thai: Had to try this because it is the one dish guaranteed to be at any Thai restaurant.  It wasn't as sticky and peanut buttery as at lesser restaurants.  The spices and sauces were great and I liked how there were so many fresh bean sprouts on the side.

Kaeng Som Cha-Om Khai Tod: I like to call this an omelet soup.  I don't think I've ever had acacia in anything before so it was a nice treat to have it in these egg squares.   The tamarind and chili broth was full of flavor and spice.  Perfect for me, but too spicy for my dining companion.  The bland green beans were a good contrast.

Sticky Rice with Durian: It didn't make me puke!  Something with the stewing and the coconut milk and the rice contrast mellowed it.  It was like eating rice pudding made from stinky cheese.  I kind of like it!
author: Adam B.

description: Garlic frog legs were to die for! Pad thai and snapper in garlic sauce also excellent and spicy!
author: Elke S.

description:
Ate here twice within this week! Reasons why #1: introduce friend to this restaurant #2: Friend liked food and wanted to come back again. The lunch-time deal is great and though I try not to eat so much for lunch, I end up always finishing the entire thing (AND their portions are huge)!

The place is clean and spacious. The service is prompt and friendly. Food and price are aces.
author: Alisa M.

description:
I ate lunch here two Saturdays ago on the recommendation of a local shop owner.  I was surprised to find the place practically empty.  I had the alligator special, with medium spicy hotness, which was plenty hot with brown rice .  The cute waitresses were helpful and attentive.  I thought the food was plenty authentic and much better than the fake Thai food at Osha Thai.

I never worry about wandering through the Tenderloin, the punks are worried about me.  If you are not from around here, walk on Larkin and avoid Hyde Street.  A out of towner may be spooked by all the people loitering around on Hyde.
author: Coyote B.

description:
Went with a group of friends before watching Wicked.  I used my Yelp app to look for a good spot last minute.  There are a couple of Thai places around the area, but I was feeling adventurous and wanted to try this.  Boy I'm glad I did.  Thanks Yelpers!

Food was awesome!  Actually except for one that's why I give 4.5 stars.  I tried the pork belly dish as recommended by you Yelpers.  The flavor was good, but the fried prok belly was not fresh, it hurt my teeth.  Now I know when it's freshly fried coz I'm familiar with lechon kawali a Philippine dish, some yummy goodness.  I give credit to them for the good flavor though.

As for the rest of the food, awesome!  Flavor was great!  Although I was satisfied that they don't have panang beef, the other curry satisfied me well.  Good portions and quick service.  I would actually compare this to Marnee Thai, yea shoot me!  I go to Marnee Thai for their wings and panang beef, but over here... I'd go for whatever they have.  They have so many choices I'd like to try.  Plus the parking isn't bad here, it's easier to find parking, although, the neighborhood can be iffy.  Oh yea I think it's cheaper here too.

The inside is nice but crowded.  I was sitting very close to the next table.  You actually won't know what the restaurant name is until you come close, coz I believe it's in Thai writing.  But I just told my friends, find the restaurant that looks new and had red and black paint.  

I wanna come back here!  Yes I do!  I'll definitely come back and let's see if my first impression will last.
author: Claire J.

description: You know it's good when you go back to a place for round two and order pretty much the same things. When the pork shoulder hit the table, I dove right in...then I remembered there were other people at the table. The slices of meat is just so tender and there is just enough fat on the meat. Don't tell your doctor. The green curry was sweet and savory all at the same time. The pork belly has a nice crisp to it but I don't think I will order it again. It's good but I would choose the pork shoulder over it any day. The tom yum pak soup was a party in your mouth...sour, spicy and savory all at once. A favorite Thai place in the city.
author: Eve C.

description: Ler Ros kindly reimbursed us for the phone. It was very cool of them to follow through with what they promised. Can't wait to return and will hopefully get seated in the back this time : )
author: Caeli M.

description:
Woo-oo was this stuff spicy!  

The menu is more interesting than an average Thai place, and not only are they open late, they deliver late.  They had the food to us in 30 minutes on a Sunday evening.  

The pad thai was above average--good textures and flavors.  
The spicy tofu was seriously spicy, but otherwise not that exciting.
The raw prawns listed under the salad section were quite good--think Thai sashimi--but not at all salad-like.  
Boy ordered a dish with frog in it, mostly for the novelty factor.  It was also all kinds of spicy, but it turns out he's not that into frog.
author: Dana S.

description: I am thoroughly confused as to why this place is so highly rated. Maybe I got the wrong items, but typically I order two basic dishes when trying a new Thai restaurant (and explore from there). I got the papaya salad with blue crab and my first bite was filled with shell. The crab was raw as well, which was not what I had expected I guess. The shrimp pad thai lacked flavor and the shrimp still had the mud veins in it. Needless to say, I was not impressed and will not go back.
author: Sheila E.

description:
Solid food at reasonable prices. Great selection, but for the lesser firebreathers, their mild is actually surprisingly spicy. We tried a good number of the curries (red and yellow), the pad Thai of course, and the pad kee Mao. Everything was flavorful and nicely presented, and nothing was overly salty except for the appetiser shrimp cakes served with an uncomfortably lukewarm cucumber side/sauce. 

also, the restaurant smells something like worn socks, which is annoying at first but goes away as you eat increasingly spicy foods. 

overall, not bad. great and friendly service for a bustly late night meal.
author: Anthony C.

description: A friend introduced me to Lers Ros several years ago and I have to say this is one of the best Thai restaurants in the city. The food is great and so is the service. Every meal I've had has been great. We often use their home delivery service and there's never ever been a mix-up and food is delivered well in advance of the time estimate they give you.
author: Elzabeth G.

description: I  pretty disappointed with the pad thai and garlic quail we got here. The pad thai was bland, even though we requested spicy, and the quail was too dry and salty.
author: Jen R.

description:
I feel ineffectual adding on another complimentary review of this restaurant, but I was there last night and I'm freakin' thinking about going back today for lunch!  I was spoiled with good authentic Thai food by my friend Thanya Suwansawaad who owned Thanya & Salee on Potrero Hill.  Since she sold the biz my jones for real Thai only gets satisfied when I get invited to Thanya's home.  Well, sorry Thanya... not anymore.  

I'm lovin' Lers Ros... in the heart of the 'Loin we have a clean, efficient, somewhat trendy (let's get a makeover team there and make it HOT!), that serves some straight up great Thai.  The first time I went was alone on a Saturday afternoon:  needed to have Yum Pla Dook Foo and did a Yelp search, resulting in Lers Ros.  The dish is pounded, shredded catfish filet, deep friend and served atop lettuce with a side of spicy lime/fish sauce dressing. Oh my. Delish.  Only comment from me is that I think the chef should julienne the red bell pepper into thinner strips.  Less bulky, more subtle and attractive that way, pairing the julienned green mango.  

I also had the garlic fried quail. Ooooh.... little crunchable tasties.  I felt like Southeast Asian royalty daintily biting the little bird meat of the bones. Simple, fried, tasty, served with a typical sweet spicy sauce.  Not wanting to leave without another favorite in tow, I ordered the Thai home-made suausage appetizer to go:  slices of sausage on the bias, served with slivers of ginger and red onion, tiny lime wedges, peanuts, Thai pepper bits... pile all on top of your sausage slice and pop in da mout, brah! OMG.

So last night, I returned with my partner and a good friend and the three of us ordered the same apps as above on my reommendation and for dinner we had the pork belly with crispy rind stir fry, the Thai style spare rib sautee, and beef larb (which is usally a starter).  As my friend and I are both Filipino, we took to the pork belly like, well, Filipinos to pork. It was similar to our lechon kawali and oh so tasty.  The larb was good chopped sirloin, not lazy ground beef like you might find in less reputed Thai restaurants.  My anglo partner got the ribs dish as he wasn't sure about the pork belly (but after so many years together with a Pinoy, you know he couldn't say no to da pig).  

We got there around 6 pm.  In less than an hour the place was packed with a waiting line to boot.  We shared the traditional fried banana with toasted almond ice cream.  Four large rounds of fried banana a generous scoop of ice cream... large enough to definitely be shared by four people, each to have a mouthful!  They have an interesting selection of ice creams as well, including pistachio! 

Today, I'm hoping to try out the whole trout, fried and sauteed in a chili sauce since that was out-voted last night.  Call me crazy.  Call me an authentic Thai food fanatic... and I found my fix at Lers Ros Thai!
author: Ric S.

description:
When I go to Thai places, I usually get one dish only: the yellow curry dish with chicken.  The dish has potatoes, chicken, and onions in curry broth.  However, I'm really picky with how it tastes - it needs to be sweet, but not sickeningly sweet.  I've ordered a lot of curries over the past year, and some do it right while others don't.  I'm happy to say that Lers Ros did it really well!

I was here on spring break and was craving some Thai food, and Lers Ros was near my hotel.  I got the yellow curry (with chicken) with rice dish.  I think it was $7.95 if my memory serves me right.  The curry was in a small bowl, and they had a big portion of rice on the plate.  I think that they could have served more of the curry since the bowl was so small, but it was one of the best Thai yellow curries I've ever had!  You could definitely taste the coconut milk (a little creamy, which I like), but the other spices' flavors came out.  Just the right blend of sweet and salty flavors, and the chicken wasn't bad either, very chewy.

If you want more food, you might want to get the dish "a la carte" (no rice?) for $8.95

I know that if I'm ever coming back to vacation in San Fran, I will be stopping by Lers Ros!
author: Danielle C.

description: Good food, irritating service. I have been a long-standing customer of Lers Ros for 6 years, but I am fed up with the simple things that they get wrong.  I call in frequently for take out or delivery, as they are 2 blocks away, but I am completely fed up with the cluelessness that they have about that side of their business. Every time that I call, it seems like the first time they have ever taken an order. They ask me to repeat my # about 5 times (and I enunciate quite clearly), they never remember my address, even though it's simple and 2 blocks away. I'm pretty much done with them and my SO will not even consider them anymore.
author: Marc G.

description:
had the takeout.

best pad thai i've ever had in the US. i've had it on the street in Thailand, and this is the only place here that has come close.

The green curry was also excellent. I hear they make their curry paste in house, and it shows.

Also had the tom yum. This is the flavor I look for in tom yum. They definitely aren't shy with the fish sauce - that's how you know it's legit. Perhaps a bit on the salty side, but just fine for a couple bowls worth.

Will definitely return!
author: Evan B.

description: Awesome thai food and very friendly staff. Funny though, the servings look small but they are deceptively large.
author: Karin B.

description: Possibly the best Thai in SF. I recommend the Tom Yum noodle soup (with the thick noodles), crispy pork belly, pork shoulder appetizer, thai sausage appetizer, and duck larb, in that order. There's also a chili/fish sauce thing you can get on the side that is insanely delicious, and incredibly hot. My mouth is already watering as I write this.
author: Winston L.

description:
Gosh, this is a pretty delicious Thai place. 

Their pork does live up to the expectation. Yummmmm

All of their dish are big enough to share with 3 or 4 people, and it is fresh and flavor is right on.

Service is okay, because the place is busy, they really just take order, throw the food on your table, and get you on your way. 

They take reservation for 6 plus.

I don't mind, I just want some delicious food. =)
author: Alice C.

description:
Had a delicious dinner at Lers Ros Thai June 2011. Very quiet when we arrived (Early), and quite busy when we left. Very clean, plain interior, sparse and modern -  we were greeted warmly, never rushed, and our service was really nice - helpful, but unobtrusive.

If you're unfamiliar with the area make sure you note the exact street address 730 Larkin Street (between O'Farrell and Ellis) or you could easily wander into the wrong place. 

The menu is HUGE, I was very glad I had predetermined some things our party would order. 

Portions were maybe a little smaller than some Thai places, but only slightly - and it was more than plenty. I felt that the food at Lers Ros was prepared and served with care, and was also a wonderful value for quality ingredients, including VERY fresh seafood. Ask for a condiment tray to turn up the heat.

This would be a particularly great place for any party of 6 (or more) to try a lot of dishes. I personally am overwhelmed with such a large menu, so some prior menu research and a little list made ordering (by item #) fast and easy (on the server, too) and allowed us to spend more time enjoying each other's company.

I can't wait to return and try some other dishes - some pork, the chicken with spinach and peanut sauce, the curries, etc.  I loved the food at this restaurant - a really great place!
author: Susan B.

description: My new favorite Thai in San Francisco. Everything we ordered was delicious: chicken satay, pad maker tofu, pad see-ew, par ram with beef. Place looks great, service was friendly and attentive.  It does look like contemporary restaurant but the food is authentic. Strongly recommended.
author: Didi S.

description: Wow! Really great Thai food. Delicious. Sizable meals - 4 of  us  shared 3 mains and it was more than enough. Extensive menu - almost a little too much to consider. Great atmosphere. Busy late into the night. Loses points for  being extremely hot and stuffy. My party of 3 girls love being cosy but this was stifling. Open the door! Lastly as a side note - dodgy neighbourhood. Be aware of your surroundings.
author: Bryce R.

description:
First time I checked out Lers Ros, I was thoroughly underwhelmed (probably ordered the wrong things).  

But I skeptically returned for a birthday dinner, only to be thoroughly impressed enough to warrant a change of heart and a Yelp review.

We ordered a bunch of dishes but some of the standouts that I still remember a week later include the grilled  pork shoulder appetizer (Koh Moo Yang) and the red curry.  The fried pork belly was also a hit.

Decently priced and the service was incredibly patient (for a large group).

Haven't checked out the newest location in Hayes Valley but imagine it would be just as good (although I hear it's incredibly loud there).
author: F. P.

description:
My favorite inexpensive Thai in the city

- Great for groups
- Delicious soups
- All 6 dishes we sampled were delicious
author: Janett R.

description: I've travelled near and far for good Thai food, even going to the Motherland herself. I must say, the Tom Kha Pak is probably the best I ever had. The Drunken noodles was alright....I've had better...
author: Pauline J.

description: I really, really liked this place! The menu has the basics as well as a lot of dishes you don't see at your run-of-the-mill Thai places. We got the five-spice duck and a boar dish and they were both splendid. The service was also nice and efficient. I just wish it was closer for me to get to. Guess I'll have to be content with calling them for delivery!
author: Rowena L.

description: Great food here, better than I've expected, best Thai food I've had so far:) Will come back and try more other dishes!
author: Lila Z.

description:
We went to Lers Ros Thai on a Saturday afternoon on Labor Day weekend. There were only a handful of people in the place. We were seated immediately. I don't think everyone in the place speaks English...I asked if the parking meters were monitored on Saturday and the young lady that seated us just sort of giggled and walked off! (no tickets were present later so we either got lucky or they don't bother on Saturdays).

The menu is quite extensive, full of strange and wondrous things. I decided to just go with why fellow yelpers recommended. We started with some Thai coffee and Thai Tea, both of which were very good (be warned, if you haven't tried them they are different....sweet and heavy on the cream)

We ordered the Curry Puffs appetizer. It came out with four dumpling size crispy curry flavored "pillows of wonder", a small dish of the peanut sauce, and a small dish of some sort of pickled cucumber that was also very good. (get extra peanut sauce, it's very good on steamed rice!!)
Next came dinner. My wife had Tofu Curry Veggies, and I had the Spicy Chili Talapia. Ok... So I panicked...I was still reading the review from "Janice C" who was raving about the Talapia when the waitress arrived. I ordered it before I finished reading. I didn't realize the whole fish would soon be on the plate....just sitting there....smiling at me. It was actually was fairly good however, but I usually don't prefer to work that hard for my meal, picking thru the bones....I would have preferred a filet.

The service in this place was outstanding. They were all about refilling the water and checking up on you. It thought it a tad funny that the minute your paper napkin became "soiled" they were right there giving you a new one!! I was a tiny bit self conscious...the waitresses are all just kind of standing there....watching you...ya know...eat. You know the feeling...when someone you DON'T know is watching you eat....it's like "what"??!!!

We didn't stay for dessert as I was in search of a good gellato (see my Naia review) I can't speak to that area. The total bill for the two of us with the drinks came to about $50 with tip, about average for a decent restaurant. I would probably return here if I lived in the area, but there are a whole lotta other places to try in the ci-tay (ala Steve Perry) and in the end I gave it four out of five stars.
author: David C M.

description: Unbelievable! 5 star for the food (1 star for the neighborhood, 3 star for the restaurant itself, and 4 star service). It's as close as it gets to Thailand. And I have been to Thailand and to the "Royal cuisine" restaurants. Lers Ros comes close. Made me rediscover Thai cuisine. I am a fan. I prefer the one on Larkin than the Hayes valley one.
author: Nasci N.

description: I have to give the staff all the greats for the excellent meal that my friend from out of town had.  Yes, she can be a little bit demanding. But they handled it like stars.  The food was  excellent and all GOOD.  The service, 5 stars, due to my  friends special requests.  Thank you for another great dinner service.
author: Marck N.

description: Got sick after eating here. It must have been the terrible fried rabbit special, all bones and nary a meat. Or, was it the Tom yum? Squirming in my seat at the opera after the meal was a nightmare. Can't believe at all the favorable reviews.
author: Firat Y.

description:
Good freakin' lord this place is AMAZING. In terms of the Thai flavors I enjoy (spicy + sour.. aka Thai food from the Eesan region), Lers Ros HITS THE SPOT on my taste buds. I can't even.. Already drooling just thinking about it--and I went there over 3 weeks ago. Oy oy oy.

My cousin (thankyouthankyouthankyou for introducing me) brought me here.. although the location isn't too grand, it makes this gem stand out even more. Okay, I'm really trying not to exaggerate, but I almost never get to eat food like "Kaw Mu Yang". KAW freakin MU YANG. The last time I had that was either a) in Thailand or b) at home.

Kaw mu yang: WONDERFUL. This is the one dish that I for once did not feel bad about devouring all those not-so-healthy lipids because it was that delicious. 

Som Tum Kai Khem (salty egg papaya salad)-never tried this version of som tum before, but the salty egg was a very interesting contrast to the effing spicy/sour taste. 

Sticky rice:  warm, chewy, deeeeericious.

Gai Yang: Sooooo gooooood. Juicy and seasoned very well. Took it togo, and it was still good when I ate the rest at home.

Hungry.. again. If I'm pretty much dead-tired while writing this Yelp review, it must mean something.. right? Shoot, I'm hella hungry now. Thanks a lot, Lers Ros. No, REALLY. THANKS.

On a side note, the interior was modern-ish, and the plates were funky (white AND black AND a bit of red?). Not that that should affect your judgment about the food at all.

Service was good.
author: Courtney P.

description:
I heard from a friend that if I wanted legit Thai food, this was the place to go.  

I ordered an appetizer of chicken satay, which was not very good.  Chicken was not well seasoned and seemed of poor quality.  The peanut sauce was watery, as opposed to thick like it should be.

For my main course, I had the Pad Phed with beef.  The seasoning of the dish was good; the problem was, some of the seasoning should have been taken out.  What I mean is, there were pieces of bay leaf and the dish included galingale, which was good for flavoring but not so pleasant to eat. I kept having to pick these things out.  Additionally, the beef was of poor quality; really fatty. 

Overall, I was not impressed.  I don't need to travel from the East Bay to here again.
author: Cindy W.

description:
WOW! Officially my favorite Thai restaurant in town! 

I categorize most Thai restaurants around downtown as "fast food," where you want to grab a bowl of noodle or a plate of rice, get in and out in one hour! But Lers Ros is the kind of place where I would share my food family style with couple of people, and really take my time. 

They have great menu. From Alligator to Rabbit, not to mention a lot of great Pork options, seafood, and chicken (dooh!). Or should I say, their menu makes me excited! I've been here twice.. and both times I had the pork shoulder appetizer, because it was recommended. Very tender pork with delicious sauce on the side. I love love love the Tom Kha Gai. Love the clam with sweet chilli sauce. Everything else was good, but not too memorable. Yellow curry chicken, the tilapia house special, and some other things that I can't remember. I usually ask for recommendations, and the servers always seem to know their food.

I also had durian sticky rice as dessert. OMG, where else can I find durian? It is SO GOOD.

They also have great wine list which is very rare for Asian restaurants. I think there are at least 10 kinds of wine that you can get by glasses. Great selections of beer and sake too. Just too amazing.

Great service!

The only thing that I didn't like is their approach to make the restaurant more bistro-like. They are playing top 40, but the atmosphere and decor is just not there yet. Pick a side?
author: Marlis T.

description: Pretty good, and a nice beer menu for a Thai place. They have a lot of good vegetarian options. It is a nicer sit down place, not hole in the wall, and the portions are large -- my friend and I both went home with leftovers (I got the eggplant tofu, she got tom kha with tofu). The tom kha was reallllly good, they have a really good variety of mushrooms in it, not just button like at some cheaper places. Decently spicy -- I like it when tom kha has the whole chilis floating in it oozing red, and this definitely had it. We showed up just in time to not wait and they even nicely reseated us quickly when a third person showed up. It was surprisingly crowded for a Monday night so be aware. One star off because it was expensive but wasn't out of this world nice to justify the extra price, in my mind.
author: Gabi K.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco. I have never been disappointed coming here. The wait is long if you dine in especially on thurs-fri night. For apps I always get the Thai herb sausage. Curries are fantastic and they are very generous with the meat in their curry dishes. I also love the garlic quail and basil clams. I recommend the last 2 for takeout because it can get pretty messy. Seating is not the most comfortable because it's all very low seating on small stools. If you're a large person you may not be that comfortable eating here. Service is very friendly. Like most Asian places I would not recommend alcohol beyond simple wine or beer. I have yet to visit an Asian establishment that can make a decent mixed drink.
author: Mai C.

description:
For anyone to say this is nothing special is beyond my understanding. Sure I know many won't give it five stars because of the atmosphere, locale, etc...but really great food is really great food and I have to give it up for this place. This is as real as it gets outside of Thailand. I travel all the time, have eaten in Thailand and live in NYC. Thai food is not a cuisine that impresses me unless it's something special. Since I do not live in SanFrancisco I have only been here twice but it knocked me out both times!

Here are the things I don't think you should miss:

The dishes:

1) Papaya Salad w/salted Egg- seasoned perfectly and the right ingredients..ex. real palm sugar, the SE asia thin green beans. the salted egg was amazing....prepared in a way that all the moisture was extracted which gave a consistency like cheese!

2) Garlic and Ginger Rice- as far as i could tell it was simply steamed rice but mixed lightly toasted garlic and lightly sauteed ginger leaves(or stems maybe) that is a little more subtle and fragrant than using the root which gave it a little oily richness but with a nice smokey, nuttiness from the garlic. So simple and amazing yet so different..

3) Whole Sea Bass in Lime and Chili- (check the picture, I have it as my profile picture...it say's it all!!) I almost feel like I don't have to say anything if it wasn't so mind blowing! On the menu the guarantee that the fish is fresh each day...they didn't lie. Comes out basically cooking in this broth of lime and other juices that I believe are just created with the various herbs that are in there like whole sections of lemon grass, slices of garlic, what looks like the top parts and leaves of celery stalks but may be some other herb that i'm not recognizing, chili and some other things minced that may also be pre-sauteed because there is a little oil in the broth all mixed with the natural fish juices. Comes out cooking in that stuff and just the smell knocks you out. It's like a whole fish in a SE Asia bouillabaisse. As you eat the fish you can and remove the bones and drink the soup...it's crazy good! and spoon some of that garlic ginger rice in there...oh man!! 

4)Tom Yum Soup- a classic but an amazing version. super fresh lemongrass. lime leaf and galangal and a fresh Thai mushroom that i had to look up because i never have seen it before called "hed lom" or "wind mushroom"...the stuff is obviously imported but how it's so fresh i don't know...? maybe the old couple in the kitchen grow the stuff or something..??


Somewhat of a hidden gem in SF I believe. You won't be disappointed!
author: David A.

description:
I'm still liking this place but now that I've tried most of their menu, I can tell you what's worth getting here and what's not.


Do not order:

 * Any appetizers.  We got the chicken satay, thai herb sausage, and some appetizer special puffs.  Although they weren't bad, they were indistinguishable from any other restaurant.  If you must have them, go ahead but there won't be any wow factor.
 
 * The same hold true for the curries.  I would go so far as to say you may want to avoid them.  The curries are missing that pleasing blend of sour (lime), sweet and hot.  Instead they rely mostly on creamy (coconut) and sweet.

* The Larb Moo is okay, but like I said in my original review, not as good as Ozone Thai.  It suffers from the same flavor profile problems as the curry.  My Thai friend was really not impressed.


Recommend to order:

* Any soups.  Last time we ordered the Tom Kreang Nai and despite the oddness of the entrails (which I tried not to think about) it was delicious.  The same goes for the less stomach churning Tom Yum Koong.  The broth is perfection.  Very lime-y and spicy.

* Yum Talay.  It super spicy and sour (be careful) - very tasty.

* Rad Nah.  My Thai friend said this was just like home cooking.  High praise from him indeed.
author: Jean K.

description: After living in Thailand for awhile, it felt great to stumble across this place immediately after in 2009. The food is authentic, and great options for both meat eaters and vegetarians alike. If you really want that true Thai food experience, in San Francisco this is about as good as it gets. I thoroughly enjoy the cuisine here. Its sister over on Hayes tastes just as good, but for some reason the interior here just brings me back to my time living there.
author: Katie C.

description:
I ordered the pork belly, a pad thai, and their squid and pork soup for delivery.  It took an hour and a half, but thankfully, the food was still warm when I got it.  The pork belly order was smaller than I had expected and the pork was kind of soggy.  The soup was good although it only came with two things of pork stuffed squid, which was disappointing.  The pad thai was good but pretty standard stuff.

The lady taking the phone order was very difficult to understand and the process took longer than it should have.
author: H. L.

description:
Talk about being packed.  It was quite noisy and hard to walk through.  Kind of turned me off, but my friend told me that this spot has the most authentic Thai food that they have ever had, compared to other places.  Tried it and I would have to say, it taste the same to me.  

Had a raw shrimp salad, but where's the salad?  Why categorize it as a salad, where there wasn't a ounce of lettuce with it?  Also got the traditional coconut soup, which was alright.  Finally, got the spicy beef and tofu eggplant dish, and I would have to say, nothing out of this world for me.  Perhaps I'm comparing it to the Thai locations in the East Bay, but I rather drive across the bridge for better Thai than this. 

Lastly, they had quite a few servers on the floor.  They all looked alike, so hard to tell which lady served us, so was ignored a couple times when flagging someone down.  

All in all, it was okay, but if you want it to be less crowded, better tasting and less noisy, I suggest looking else where.
author: Janice F.

description:
Wow, the reviews don't lie people!

Duck Larb and Pork Belly are a MUSTTTT!!! Holy shit, never had pork belly that was so tasty... and I never had duck larb before but I'm definitely going to have much more of it!

This place has really exotic meats and I can see why there is always a wait. Don't be discourage, the wait is worth it.
author: Stephen N.

description:
The beef or pork noodle soup (#69) is awesome!  Apparently it's called "boat soup" if you visit Thailand.  I'll probably never visit Thailand, but I'm glad I tried it.   

Giggity (you know why)
author: Corey V.

description: My wife and I visited this restaurant on a Sunday afternoon. She went in and got a table and I parked the car. When I joined her inside for the lunch, she was already unhappy with the way the hostess treated her. Our waitress was not much happier. While the food was not terrible, the poor service and bad attitude made our dining experience here not good. There are so many good Thai restaurants in the city, we'll take our business somewhere else.
author: V J.

description:
Long story short, it I was treating a bunch of people to dinner and needed a big enough venue for about 15 people. Yelp never fails and that's how I ended up at Lers Ros...

AMBIANCE: While we were dressed casual, the table setting was not. Nice table clothes and silverware. It was initially pretty quiet at 5pm but quickly got rowdier as the night went on. 

FOOD: My buddy and I shared two dishes. 

1. Pad Ped Nok - From the menu description: "Quail stir-fried with a house made chili paste, young pepper corn and galingale, your choice of minced OR chunk (both bone in )" The dish was good and had some good spicy flavors in it but DON'T get it with chunk meat. It was a pain to pick out the bones. Otherwise, no complaints.

Whole Tilapia (Pla Rad Prik) - From the menu description: "Whole fried Tilapia with house chili based sauce (Guarantee fresh fish everyday)" By far, my favorite dish of the night. Great sauce and the fish is cooked to perfection. We ate every last bite of that fish.

PRICE: The quail was about $10 but the fish is a steal at $15. Quality and quantity FTW.

SERVICE: Cool service. The waitress was very patient as we waited for the entire party to show up. Our water glasses got filled often enough. 

THE BOTTOM LINE: One of my new favorite Thai places in the city. I will be back again...for more fish. =D
author: Jonathan L.

description:
3.5 stars for me.

Big plus for being open on the super late tip!

Another plus for being cheap and offering free delivery!

But the place falls a little flat and it just doesn't call my name.  I mean, it's hard to go wrong with cheap late-night Thai food so I'm not really complaining, but if I had to pick between Lers Ros, Thai House Express, and Osha on Leavenworth, I gotta go with Osha.   

Either way though, I'll be back.  Besides, it's the closest spot to chow down after I get drunk at Olives ;)
author: Angella S.

description:
Thai food makes my stomach very happy so whenever I'm somewhere new I have to try what their city has to offer in terms of Thai food. 

Ler Ros Thai does not disappoint, they had the best tasting Green Curry Ive had. The balance of flavors was spot on and I really liked how their veggies werent mushy as it gave a nice consistency for the dish. My only regret is not ordering more stuff, but I'll be back soon!
author: Nick K.

description:
The steamed fish here is one of a kind that I never find anywhere else in any other restaurant. It's spicy and tangy and the fish is so fresh and sweet. Best part - the whole fish is only about $25.

I had ordered some disappointing dishes before - like frog legs and pork belly. The frog legs were bony and the pork belly was just like Chinese roasted pork, nothing special.

I really loved the eel dish and the spareribs. The eel is a little hard to eat because it is not boneless, but the way they cooked it was simply delicious. Spareribs were very meaty and juicy. So good. 

Other than the fish, the other dishes here are quite expensive, actually. Every dish costs about $15 in general. 

As for service, they can be slow when it is busy, but they are always polite and friendly.
author: July N.

description: Perfect for your semi late night Thai cravings (after a concert or something). Usually there's a table ready to go when I drop in after a show at night, the service is fantastic (friendly, enthusiastic, water refills), the atmosphere is a little more upscale than your hole in the wall vibe (they play modern day music like fun. and Bruno Mars), and the food is piping hot, delicious, and fresh. Pad Thai is yum - not too sweet -- quite enjoyable. The Pad Kee Mow is even better! I didn't try the spiciest but I will next time -- the mild wasn't too spicy.
author: Jonny A.

description:
AWESOME AWESOME AWESOME. 

I visited this place once in person and order take out once. Extremely long wait so prepare yourself, but apparently you can reserve online now. The servers were all extremely attentive and recommended us dishes that suited our liking. It was just an amazing experience as it was not easy to find a good thai place for us. I can't really take spicy food so they made sure my dishes were made to that instruction. We have ordered a variety of dishes (Chicken Pad Thai, Tom Yum koong, Pad Makuer Tofu (eggplant/carrots/tofu),  Nuer Pad Pak (beef with veggie stir fry), fried rice with chicken (which was AMAZING - will def order again). All dishes were all outstanding so we have made a decision to come back again. The delivery took a while and the portion was smaller than what we expected, so it would be best if you could dine in at their location.

Definitely will recommend others to try this place.
author: J P.

description:
Summary based on 1 lunch eating a la carte, not from the lunch special menu:
--great, non-Americanized food
--will cook off the menu (that is, make Thai dishes you can describe)
--ok, helpful service. Helps if you speak restaurant Thai.
--nicer than usual décor, especially for the area
--clean bathrooms
--metered street parking not impossible
--5-10 minutes walk from Civic Center BART

Some of the best spicy/sour prawn soup, called tom yum koong here, that I've had anywhere.  Ha ha, has stir fried alligator and venison.
author: Rich H.

description:
During daylight hours, the folks at Lers Ros rely on their harsh, fluorescent bulbs that unfortunately do nothing for the relatively bland décor.  It's only when the sun starts to set in earnest when the mood lighting comes on, dark and dim, casting a reddish-brown glow on everything and everyone, toning down the bare walls, hiding most things but the glare of the 2 television sets with sports or news.

But no matter, one does not come to Lers Ros for the décor or atmosphere - one comes for the complex, spicy and ultra-flavourful thai offerings.

We started with the fish cake and Some Tom Khai Kem - green papaya with chili, lime and salted eggs. The papaya salad was one of the best thai dishes we've ever had, flecked with the yolks of delicious salted egg-- but was so spicy we had to make a concerted effort to drink our thai iced tea and take bites of the fish cake in-between to try to calm the fires. Our lips numb, we made a mental note to ask whether they'd be able to tone it down in the future.

By comparison the rest of our meal was manageable in terms of spice/ heat.

Even though the Pad Kee Mow was listed as being spicy, it didn't even register in contrast to that fire-alarm-inducing papaya salad.

The star of the evening was, yes - the Pad Kra Pow Moo Krob - skin-on crispy fried pork belly with a thin brown sauce, thai basil and peas.  We chose an entrée portion and placed some of it atop steaming, sticky and nutty rice, it was the most perfect dish of all. 

They deliver, but will they deliver to the Inner Sunset?
author: Claudine C.

description:
Somehow their menu ended up in my lobby so we decided to order take out one night and give it a try. I ordered the chicken padthai and the BF ordered duck over rice. It arrived promtly and the food was pretty good. The padthai came in a container and almost half of it was filled with bean sprouts (which i ended up tossing..hate it!). 

Will definitely try again!
author: M W.

description:
They have very good foods and service . I really like all the foods that I try today.
It's my first time to eat at this place , But ~ I  really like the foods . YOU " MUST TRY "
NUMBER 25 & 62 . Appetizer :  GARLIC  FROG , Dessert  : MANGO  WITH STICKY RICE .
author: Wing G.

description: First spot I hit up after returning to SF. The whole experience was top notch. The food and service were five star. The surrounding area is not so pretty but this is one of several gems hidden in the rough part of town! Try it!
author: Celine A.

description:
Well we ate at the sister spot to this in Hayes Valley last week.  So I knew what to expect.  Great food, great service, and decent price.   I had the yellow curry with sticky rice.  Fantastic.  Flavors were well developed in the curry and it was just the right consistency.  Loved it... our new favorite spot for Thai.  Thanks Jason C.  

The Skull knows best!
author: Christopher F.

description:
The food is pretty good. I tried the green curry, pad thai, and a deep fried fish. The price is reasonable as the dishes are between $7-$12. The specials sound really good. I would definitely want to try the dish with alligator.

I liked how the restaurant was able to accommodate our group of 20. The restaurant is really small. 

Decorations are minimal at this restaurant. I'm surprised that there is a wide screen tv in the restaurant. 

Don't expect much with service as this place.
author: Jackie S.

description:
Must've walked past this place at least 20 times. Never noticed it. Came here finally.

First impression: Dead empty. Radio music blaring out of the speakers. Clean. Love that giant fountain next to the cashier. Nice.

Food was great and came out fast! We ordered so much food that we had to eat fast to make room for new dishes.

9 people, family style, we ordered:
+2 orders of Fish Cakes ($6.25/order) served with sweet&sour sauce - very tasty. love the sauce.
+Green papaya salad with chili, cherry tomatoes, and prawns ($7.25) - didn't try, but others said it was delicious & spicy!
+Silver noodle salad with ground pork, dried shrimp and peanut chili dressing ($6.95) - didn't try either. it didnt make it to my end of the table!
+Coconut milk soup with chicken, tofu and mushrooms ($6.95) - still debating about this one. it looks like coconut milk, but its sour.
+Green curry with chicken, bell peppers, bamboo and basil ($7.25) - soo good, but soooo spicy. everyone started drinking water and blowing their nose
+Stir fried tofu with bell peppers, and mushrooms ($6.95) - yum!
+Stir fried eggplant with tofu, bell peppers in garlic chili sauce ($6.95) - *drooooools* i love eggplants
+Pad See-Ew with beef ($7.50) - i'm used to the ones that are gravy laden, but this one is good too. Sweet, totally helped after eating the green curry!
+Pad Thai ($7.50) - can't never go wrong with pad thai
+Steamed sea bass with chili and lime juice ($15.95) - so fresh and delicious. mmmm...
+4 orders of Fried Banana w/Ice Cream ($4.50/order) - i'm salivating just thinking about it. the banana are freshly fried with black sesame seeds served with coconut ice cream topped with roasted peanut. heaven!

The bill came out to be around $160 before tips, including drinks and rice. The best part: it was a lunch meeting! Whoohoo! Not that it'd cost a lot per person. But free makes it much much better!! Plus extra food to go!

By 1:30pm, the place was pretty packed.

New lunch spot!
author: Marti L.

description:
Pork leg thing, Fried trout, sampler, pad thai

This place is amazing. When in SF this is a routine stop.
author: Kevin V.

description: I have come here before a few time the food is always great. I especially liked their stinky soup, i forget the name of the dish but that just a way of describing it. The staff is very friendly but a bit slow.
author: Joji V.

description:
This place is a winner in my book.  Some of the most authentic Thai food you'll eat in this nook of the bay.

I've been here three times--once for takeout. Once in November. And once last night. In fact, I still have a takeout box of leftover pork belly sitting on my desk that I'm drooling over. 

Since I'm from across the bridge, I like barting into Civic Center and walking the few blocks up to Larkin for the chow-down. I always like starting with a salad of some sort. The papaya salad with the raw crab was RIDICULOUSLY spicy...oh my god, that thing annihilated my mouth. I cried my friend a river. And I think that was only medium spicy. I think spicy-spicy would have burned a hole through the lining of my stomach...geez! I've never had raw crab before, but it was damn tasty. I kind of slurped the flesh out of the shell as my tears mixed with the lime dressing. It was insane. I also tried the boiled calamari with spicy lime dressing.  Tart, spicy, chewy but not too chewy. I would order it again. The pork belly really is that good. The piece of the fried pork rind is chewy and full of porky deliciousness. #62, people! Eight dollars. So good. 

Very attentive service. Apparently Thai women are very high up on the list of efficient people. Their goal is to get you super-tasty Thai food super-fast. Which, last night, was mission accomplished. 

Civic Center Bart Station. Raw Crab Papaya Salad. Pork Belly with Basil. Mild spicy if you're a wimp like me, medium spicy if you've got a stomach lining of steel. 

Do it.
author: Sandy T.

description:
Excellent service, eclectic to some, but authentic to others. Upon research I realized that fish cakes are common in Thai cuisine. Go figure.
Here's what we had:

Garlic Frog - ehh yelp reviews swore by it, not as impressed. frog was succulent, but a bit over-fried on the outside.
Papaya salad with grilled prawns - tasty tasty tasty, perhaps a bit too pickled. Had lots of kick from Thai chiles.
Green curry with fish cake - odd at first, but very good, the only place I had better green curry is Siam taste in Sunnyvale.
Stir fried pork belly with crispy rind - tasty, crispy, artery hardening.  

Service was great, they didn't rush us even when we spent 2 hours there.

I would come back just to try the raw crab and alligator.
author: William H.

description:
I had dinner this Monday and ordered the pork belly dish.  The pork was lovely - but the RICE that came on the side had the consistency of RICE JELL-O.  Disgusting - and really a bad decision on behalf of the cooks to serve up rice that had obviously been made with WAY too much water.
