description: The restaurant is located near civic center. It wouldn't be safe to walk in this area late at night. The restaurant has a casual updated feel to it upon arriving. We started off the dinner with a Thai beer and glass of house wine. The wine tasted like a cheap version you would get at the local liquor store around the corner and was way to sweet. We actually had to send it back and just stick with the Thai beer. For dinner we had the pla koong (salad), tom kha gai (soup) and the seafood in green curry sauce. All the food was fresh, authentic and tasty but it was just way to SPICY for me. I am sure we ordered some spicy dishes but it just seemed all these dishes were overdone with the chili flakes ! If you like extremely spicy Thai food, then you will like this place.
author: Kevin B.

description:
The service has greatly improved. I love the servers! They are really sweet. I think they might know me by now because I go pretty often. 

My favorite thing here is the red curry with duck and pineapple. It is a hearty curry, probably enough for 2 meals. It has bamboo shoots in it too. At $10 not including rice it's a little more than other places (with rice, I usually end up paying 13-14 including tip/tax). Still, I highly recommend it!
author: Cathy S.

description:
My overall experience was probably slightly less than 2 stars, but I'll round up.  The food was pretty good but not amazing- we had seafood hot and sour soup and pad prik khing with chicken. Both dishes were pretty tasty but not anything too exciting. The service was generally very good- they were attentive and were great about refilling our water and tea cups.

My complaint comes at the end of the meal and makes me not want to come back here. I ordered sticky rice with mango and they were out! On a Friday night at 7 pm BEFORE the dinner rush and they've already run out? Strike one. So they bring us the bill since we don't want any other Dessert and we pay it and stay and chat for maybe 5 minutes. They start taking away our placemats and all our stuff basically pushing us out. I recognize they're busy, but that was just rude. They also allowed one of their waiting patrons to stand next to our table that was in the back of the restaurant and hover pressuring us to go. This was really inappropriate and causes them to deserve this two star rating. The rest of the experience is what keeps them from 1 star.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I think this place is slightly overrated; either that or my expectations were skewed thanks to positive Yelp reviews. Whatever the reason was that brought me here to eat lunch yesterday, I cannot see myself coming back.

I give this Thai restaurant 3-stars because it truly is just average. My workplace is located around Western Addition/Fillmore and occasionally likes to order here for lunch parties (not to say this restaurant caters--my office just eats family-style). Yesterday, I trekked down to this restaurant for a pick-up order. As I like to do whenever I venture to a Thai restaurant I am not familiar with, I order my stapple: Pad See Ew with chicken. 

My issues with this restaurant:
1. Their website menu is not up to date in prices and there is no price differentiation for lunch and dinner. I ordered my Pad See Ew from their website expecting it to be $8.95 (pre-tax) but I was annoyed to find out when I paid that it cost a smidgen short of $10 pre-tax and over $10 including tax. 
2. The size of the take-out drinks are about half the size of dine-in drinks. 
So I initially ordered only Pad See Ew but after seeing so many Thai-iced teas around me as I was paying, my inhibitions gave way and I ordered one for myself to-go. OH man was I disappointed. The to-go cup was PUNY! I brought this size difference to the waitress's/cashier's attention and she just tried to explain it away saying the amounts that the dine-in glasses and plastic to-go cups can hold are the same. I wish I had taken a picture of the cup size difference or wish I had asked the waitress to literally demonstrate for me that the volume of the dine-in glasses and to-go cups were the same. 
3. Location is not the most ideal.
I suppose since it is located near the 38 and other bus lines, it isn't a horrible location. But you have to walk through a decent amount of the less-than-glamorous side of San Francisco to get to it. To top that off, the only parking nearby are meters and overpriced parking lots. 

Overall, I wish I had gone to a different Thai restaurant, especially since the quality of the Pad See Ew is comparable to King of Thai and other chains like it but costs more for lunch. The time you would spend getting to this location plus the smelly, dingy, less-than-safe state of its surrounding area makes it not worth the trip to pay for average-tasting Thai food.
author: Stephanie C.

description: I can tell you with conviction that this is one of the best places to eat I have ever been to. Everything on the menu is spot on and loaded with flavor. I like spicy food and the meats offered here are done just right where the spice does not overwhelm and only enhances the flavor. Go there and enjoy!
author: Steve M.

description: My favorite Thai place in the city! It was a recommendation from a good friend who is Thai, which obviously means it's authentic and delicious.  I usually order off the daily specials menu and it never disappoints. The green curry is amazing and if you like pad thai and pad see ew you need to try them here.  It's kind of in the ghetto but super cute and nice decor inside.  Side note...Beware of the fountain, I've definitely seen people get soaked on their way in and out of the door!
author: Bobbi R.

description:
After discovering that I am allergic to tree nuts, in a manner painful and memorable (at least until I forget), I sought comfort in the arms of wok-fired noodles.  Or is it wok-fried noodles?  

I got the pad see ew.  With tofu.  Lou got the seafood noodle soup with the rice noodles.  I ate one of his fish balls.  It was delicious.  

My pad see ew was ok.  Noodles are my comfort food.  I like them alot.  They will generally be a-ok in my book.  But I long for the day that one is GREAT.  This was not such a day.  It was only ok.  I think they should use smaller plates to make the portions seem larger.  Because even though it filled me up, I did eat all of it.  And when compared to viet restaurants, the same amount of cash would feed me for 2 days.  

Miserly, me?  Yes.
author: Christina C.

description: It's weird, I did not like the new Lers Ros Thai on 16th at all, but this one here in the Tenderloin I only have good memories. I don't know if the food is actually different between the 16th street on the location in the Tenderloin but the latter is just so much better.
author: Hendrik G.

description:
The red duck curry - so good!  Please order!

Went with two of my friends and had a great time.  Quick, fast, efficient service.

Quail - spicy.  I am weak and feable so I can't handle the spicy of the spicy.  And this was that.  The quail itself was yummy, but it's a small bird, so you're really struggling to get at that deliciousness.  Without burning your tongue off first... (I'm probably exaggerating the amount of heat, but I thought it was quite hot!)

Noodles (I can't remember which one I ordered... perhaps Pad See Ew?) - Oh, I don't think I lucked out on this one, it was still yum, but not really that super special.

(Plus their menu is pretty extensive...)

Any place that I go to that plays good old 90s (Backstreet's back, alright!) has pretty much stolen my heart.
author: Carolyn L.

description:
I'm Thai. And as many people said, this place gives authentic Thai taste.

I'm one of their "almost" regular customers. Go there like once a week, either alone or with friends. Delicious and inexpensive.

Set lunch: highly recommended. 2 items with rice and house salad at 7.25 $. Worth it.

I love all the stir-fried basil sauce (Pad Gra Prow with protein of your choice). It's exactly the taste we eat in Thailand. Might be a little too spicy for non-Thais, but the waitress will ask you the desired level of spiciness. 

For soups, the "Tom Saab" (hot & sour clear soup with pork spareribs) tasted just right. Most of the appetizers are good, not great. 

Yum Pla Duk Foo (Fried minced catfish salad with lime & chili dressing) was great. Again, a true Thai taste.

The only thing that disappointed me was their Pad Kee Mao (spicy stir-fried noodles). Too oily.

Nice service (prompt + attentive). They will come around every now and then to refill your glass of water and ask if you'd like anything more.
author: Sue R.

description: I saw this place on munchies.  Anthony Strong from Locando eat here with his peeps.  I wanted to order everything on the menu but the lioness said no.  Lame.  I need to find some fatties to eat with me.  The pork belly dish was pretty good.  Its pretty much chinese roast pork in thai sauce.  Nom nom.  This place is pretty busy during weekday nights.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Their lunch special is great!

For about $8 you can choose two items from a long list of dishes, rice and salad are included too!

Yellow curry with chicken--No complaints, it's your typical meat and potato yellow curry dish.  Nothing in particular stood out to me compared to other Thai joints that I frequent, so the yellow curry is A-ok with me.

Eggplant and veggies--A spicy stir fry of eggplant, tofu, and a veggie assortment.  Perfect over rice.

I am definitely coming back to try the rest of the combination lunch special.
author: Matt S.

description: Wow, everything we tried here was delicious! The papaya salad, the boar, etc... everything we tried was fragrant, breautiful to look at, and had bursts of flavor! I do have to say, that for even someone that's used to spicy food, some of the spice here will upset the most delicate palates. However, i'm sure a simple 'not too spicy' will suffice.
author: Vittorio L.

description:
I highly recommend this spot.   Good Atmosphere (bonus, they had an NFL game on the tube), Good Service, Good Food.

What I ordered:  
app) Pot Stickers

35) Kang Daeng 
Red curry with Thai eggplant, bamboo shoot , red bell peppers, kaffir lime leaves and sliced chicken   A La carte $10.95 

62) Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob 
Stir-fried pork belly with crispy rind and Basil leaves A La carte $10.95  


Notes:  There is often a wait line so be prepared to wait on weekend evenings.  Oh yeah,  its in the Tenderloin so if you scared go to the new one in Hayes valley.
author: Cesar V.

description:
I've only been to the actual restaurant once, and it was a pleasant experience, besides the fact that there was a girl across the way that would stare at me every time I put food into my mouth. I mean, I suppose it could have been a lot worse, but I felt like she was still hungry, and I wasn't sure if I should walk over to her table and give her some of my food. Besides that, the prices are reasonable, the staff is friendly, and the place is clean. Don't let the area fool you. All the great eats are always hole-in-the-wall joints, or in the Tenderloin. Haha.

Anyway, although I've only paid them one visit, they have paid me many visits. Why? Because I order for delivery here at least once a week. Sometimes 2. Or 3 if I'm feeling thin. They already know who I am when I call... A tad bit embarrassing, but a thumbs up for great memory and customer service.

My recommendations:

Shrimp Pad thai ($7.50)-- Even though I'm allergic (shrimp), and immediately break into hives and look like a kitten with fleas, it is worth every itch.

Pra Ram Kai ($8.25)

They're open everyday from 11am - midnight and deliver after 4pm with a $15 minimum.

5 stars!
author: Charmaine A.

description:
This is one of my top favorite Thai places to go .
We ordered the trout. It was cooked to perfection. We had pad Thai
.it was one of best pad Thais ever ! And we had the tom yum noodle soup.
It was delicious. The soup was savory and flavorful.  I highly recommend this place .
author: perla w.

description: Checked this place out for a late night dinner (sketchy neighborhood).  Flavoring was very spot on.  Huge menu with a variety of choices, including vegetarian choices.  I normally don't order Pad Thai because it is too sweet at most places, but decided to go for it and was super satisfied.  We ordered pad thai, red curry, and the coconut soup.  We'll be back.
author: Teresa C.

description: Lots of tasty options and a very interesting menu. Only three stars because they were late on getting us our reserved table and because most of the dishes we ordered were too spicy. Still a solid Thai spot.
author: Rob R.

description:
Four stars for the food, but I'm letting the skeezy neighborhood, the sterile and outdated decor, and the unknowledgeable servers fly by the wayside. 

But the food really is good. Someone in that kitchen really knows what they are doing so it would be a shame to let any of the other factors deter you.
author: Joanne S.

description: i ordered the Kao Pad  Kai Tod  which was very favorful.  It was hot when come out  just by a little bit.  I was here with my trying it but i remembered coming here couple years ago.  The severvice was good probadly  it was not crowded.
author: John F.

description: Went to Lers Ros yesterday with 6 of my family members. We had a reservation at 2:00 pm but were not seated until 2:30 pm. We did not get our food until about 3:10 pm. Our server was not that friendly or helpful even when we asked for her recommendation on some good dishes. Basically we did not get any service. My brother asked for the thai tea without ice but sure enough the drink came with ice after an hour of wait. The food was nothing special. We all left the place feeling uncomfortable from that greasy food. If you visit the restroom you will whiteness the cleanliness of this restaurant. I am sure the kitchen is not very different. I will not be going back there and will not recommend this restaurant.
author: N P.

description: Went in November 2012. Memorably good, but that's partially because it was a great first date. Plenty of interesting options you won't find at other places, very tasty. They had mango sticky rice on the menu, but said the mango wasn't any good so they weren't serving it. Main complaint is the location. Waiting for the bus afterwards was kind of romantic because it was kind of... scary.
author: Sam Z.

description:
Simply delicious Thai food, no frills.  Very attentive service.  I almost don't want to talk about how good it is because if the masses start coming and I can't get a table, I'm going to be pissed.  Maybe I should highlight how sketchy the neighborhood is instead...  

But seriously, I don't think I've ever had a better pad thai.  And I also cannot get enough of the curry puffs, wow!  Basil leaf chicken is spicy, but tasty.  And the fried vegetable rolls are perfect (not at all frozen).
author: Julie H.

description:
First and foremost, this is in the Tenderloin. If that stops you from coming here, you're making a huge mistake.

I want to get a couple of things out of the way about this place. First and foremost, and I feel the need to reiterate:

1. It's in the Tenderloin

Yeah the neighborhood isn't too nice and finding this place wasn't the easiest process in the world, which brings me to my second point:

2. The sign is written in Thai

Yes ladies and gentleman, the name and sign are not written in English and because there are so many Thai restaurants on this street you may walk into the wrong spot which would be a shame because:

3. The food is bomb

Like out of this world bomb. Like if the Hydrogen bomb and the Hindenberg had a lovechild it would only be half as bomb as this restaurant. We had so many dishes and not one of them was even ok, everything was fantastic, and one of the other great things I'd like to mention about this place:

4. It's a traditional Thai restaurant

So you get service like you're a king. If your water cup gets 1/4 of the way down, they top it off. As soon as you finish a dish it's taken away to make room for more. The staff is attentive and the service is excellent.

I brought my parents here for dinner, and while I normally have reservations about bringing them into the TL, I'll happily make an exception for this place any time.

TL;DR: Possibly the best Thai food in SF, amazing service, fair prices, great place to eat in SF.
author: Joshua G.

description: I had been meaning to try this place since i saw it featured on "Check Please Bay Area". I hate to say i was very disappinted. We went there for lunch. I picked 2 items from the lunch menu: Spicy Tofu and BBQ chicken. Spicy tofu was not spicy and it was tasteless. BBQ chicken was just awful.  I'll never go back.
author: mitra g.

description:
I've only dined here once, so as much as I'd love to crown it 5 stars right away, I'll hold back.

Okay, to put things in perspective. I've just spent an incredible-and-amazingly-out-of-this-world 2 weeks to Laos and Thailand; so yes, SF SE-Asian cuisine just all tastes disappointingly sub-par since my return (It was almost painful as I attempted to finish my former pho ga favorite at Turtle Tower). 

Enter: Lers Ros! My awesome Thai friend (who's an excellent chef herself) raves about this place, so I knew I had gone to a good place. 

I got #73 Kuay Jub noodles with Five Spices broth, at $7.95 a pop. It was simply amazing!  The square rice noodles were perfectly al dente and had an interesting texture as the flat square noodle sheets curled up into strips after cooking. Pork entrails with sinfully crunchy skin, boiled eggs, cilantro, and sliced liver pieces all swam beautifully in the traditional Thai broth that was full of flavor and complicity. This soup, for the first time since my heart left Laos and Thailand, satisfied my palate.

Light and fragrant Thai Iced Tea too. 

I can't wait to go back and try the huge selection of dishes! They even have the more 'exotic' offerings if you seek 'em: alligator, rabbit, venison, frog, etc. 

Just my cup of tea.
author: Jing D.

description:
Had an awesome meal here with some friends on a Wednesday night. Called in a reservation earlier in the day and was seated very promptly. Really liked the papaya salad (w/ salted egg), pad thai (I like the sticker consistency), and tom yom soup (just the right amount of kick!). 

Also had the braised pork, a fish dish (trout?), and chinese broccoli, which were good too, but they don't particularly stand out. Would definitely recommend this place!
author: Aaron L.

description: This is hands down the best Thai food in San Francisco. I love to bring large groups of friends here and then order a ton of dishes for the entire table to share family style.
author: Brian J.

description:
I really have nothing constructive to add to the reviews other than "I like this place" and "I like going here." I've never had to wait a ridiculous amount of time to get a table, and the food is consistently tasty. We usually get some kind of duck something or other and oh man it's soooo good.

This is totally my go-to place for Thai food when I'm not sure where to go.
author: Reese W.

description: Any restaurant on SFs essential 38 should be amazing, right?! Well, It just wasn't memorable for me. The infamous pork belly was either fatty or so crispy I thought I might break my teeth! And the seating is TOO tight.
author: Nicole J.

description: Very fast service. Food was great!! Had the chicken pad Thai and fried rice with pork. Friendly staff. Definitely will be back here again.
author: Manny R.

description:
My friend and I came on a Friday night around 7PM. The place was packed and we saw a huge group in front of us, so we thought the wait would be really long, but luckily there was only 2 of us and there just so happened to be a table for 2 open! 

We had the garlic frog, fried trout, and pork belly. The garlic frog came with a sweet and sour sauce mixed with sriracha. I liked that dish a lot. The fried trout came with a citrus-y mango sauce with shredded green papaya which was really good, but the trout was over fried :/ meat was too tough inside, so I had to drench it in the sauce. The pork belly with crispy skin wasn't what I expected it to be although it did taste good. It was basically Chinese roast pork (the ones you see in Chinatown where whole pigs hang by the window). They offered brown rice and white rice. I wanted brown and my friend wanted white-- who knew the waitress was going to bring over two pots of rice out for us! It was definitely enough rice for 3 meals!! I was pretty satisfied with all the dishes, so I would come back next time to try the duck larb which was recommended by others!
author: Cindy L.

description:
We made reservations for 5 people at 6:30 on a Sunday. The place wasn't super packed, but by the time we were finished, there were only a couple of empty tables. You can tell that Lers Ros is authentic by the amount of tables that were speaking Thai. Just from looking at their menu, they had a pretty large selection of dishes, including dishes that you wouldn't normally find at a typical Thai restaurant.  

The appetizers were pretty solid. 

1. Larb - Probably my favorite dish of the night. It's an eastern Thai dish with ground pork, basil, green onion, lemon juice and other spices. Hard to describe, but if you like Thai papaya salad, and you like meat, I would recommend this dish. Order it with sticky rice to balance out the spiciness. Also, if you can't handle spicy food, make sure to specify - mild. 

2. Chicken Satay - It's pretty hard to mess up grilled chicken skewers and peanut sauce, so I'm not going to rave about this dish. The chicken could have been cut thinner, but it doesn't ruin the dish. I would order it again. 

Main Course 

1. Kuay Jub - I believe this is the first Thai restaurant in the bay area to serve this noodle soup. This is my favorite noodle soup by far, and it is pretty decent and Lers Ros. It's a little on the sweet side, so I think I will ask for less sugar next time, but I would still order this again. I don't like eating organs (intestine, blood, liver, etc.), so I ordered it without. This soup is a brown broth with rolls of rice noodles, crispy pork and egg. I normally eat it with dried red peppers, but it also goes well with the vinegar jalepeno sauce for those with an affinity towards sour foods. 

2. Pork Belly - Fried pork belly with a brown sauce. Decent entree. Pretty lean meat. 

3. Pad Thai - Standard dish everywhere. Not the best Pad Thai I've had, but it is definitely tasty. 

4. Khao Mun Gai - Hainanese Chicken - I was actually too full at this point to taste the dish, but a heads up - In Thailand, this dish is normally served with boiled chicken, but some vendors will boil the chicken and then fry it with salt and pepper. When you order the fried khao mun gai, that isn't what you are getting. You are actually just getting a breaded fried chicken with sweet sauce, and not the spicy brown garlicy sauce that it is traditionally served with. Ordering the regular khao mun gai next time.
author: Melissa M.

description: I eat a lot of Thai food in SF, and I mean a lot. Have tried many Thai restaurants, and every time I have a craving for pad thai it seems like a risk, and it's always disappointing. I was soooo happy when I tried the pad thai at Lers Ros - it's really good!! The curries and papaya salad are delicious as well. We tried the other Lers Ros location as well - good, but maybe the Tenderloin location is best. Enjoy!
author: Ayumi R.

description:
My friend and I were rushing to a Warriors game one night and we needed to eat prior to the game so we don't end up eating cold chicken fingers at the Oracle. Thai food is my default. I love it and I can't get enough of it. Lers Ros, I can't pronounce it, but I've heard good things. Let's see if they hold true.

So someone said pork belly. Pad-see-eww. That's probably not how you spell it. We got papaya salad (my favorite thing ever). We then got in my car, walked into bart and had the papaya salad in the Bart station. It was spicy. I loved it, but I never feel like there's enough! I don't want a huge cabbage in my papaya salad!! Give me papaya! The train arrives.

30 minutes later, we're holding cold thai food as we're running towards the arena. 35 minutes later, we're eating cold thai food in front of the oracle. BUT: It was still so good!! The pork belly was still crunchy! The noodles were not mushy! There was enough salt to dry up a driveway worth of snow, but it's OK!! The food was a great call. I'd come here again to try their Pad Thai (another favorite, dumb, typical Americans!). Hopefully it will be a 5 star experience. 

Ps. the place is really cute. People should know that.
author: Camille T.

description: We ordered the pad see ew and yellow curry, both dishes were really flavorful. I liked that you could taste the curry in the yellow curry, sometimes Thai restaurants use a lot of coconut milk.  Not this place. Plus they didn't skimp out on the chicken! Definitely recommend checking it out.
author: Anisha A.

description: Excellent Thai food! I went with the safe choice of Pad See Ew, but I got to try some of the Pad Thai as wel - the appetizers, namely the Pork Shoulder was extremely good. I'll definitely be coming back, but it does a bit out of the way for me...
author: David T.

description:
Good Thai food!

I tried the pork belly entree which is basically Chinese Roast Pork.  But this is the best part of the pig and they made it with a great sweet and slightly spicy sauce.

Their short rib soup had a good broth.

Staff was nice but when we ordered Garlic/Ginger rice on the side (which was very good) they gave us TWO orders for me and my lady friend. This was way too much rice ($3.50 each!!!). We should have just ordered to Rice Plate if they were going to charge us that.....
author: Eddie C.

description:
Read someone's review on Yelp, came to eat at Lers Ros after happy hour at Olive.  The food is not bad, but it's not spectacular.  

I just moved to the city from SoCal and maybe I've been spoiled with tons of delicious Asian restaurants, Thai food included.  The prices here are cheaper than other restaurants in the city and the food is more authentic.

The service is average.  The dishes are slightly dirty.  Had the pad thai which seemed to be the same as anywhere else.  Also had the papaya salad--a very common Thai appetizer.  It was yummy, but steer clear if you can't stand spicy because I had to drink half a cup of water after every couple of bites.
author: Suzi F.

description:
Authentic. Delicious. Affordable. 

Lers Ros has definitely landed itself a spot on my list of favorite Thai Restaurants. The restaurant is very clean and the service is friendly and quick. 

My roommate and I came here right after the Giants' World Series Parade. We were starving and although the restaurant was packed, the wait was no more than five minutes. We ordered two types of curries and a pad see eiw and spring rolls to share. Although it's a very casual restaurant, the presentation was nice. They also have great lunch specials! We finished our food within minutes of receiving it.. Yea, it was THAT good.

I'll definitely be a regular anytime I'm back in the city.. Lers Ros is definitely a reliable lunch spot.
author: Tammy S.

description: Yellow curry, pad Thai, garlic pepper rabbit, coconut soup- all excellent, especially the curry. Please come patronize this business, it is Thai food done right- balanced spices leave nothing wanting.
author: Benjamin L.

description: I don't understand why some people give this place a good review. I had a terrible experience with the food and service. I got their vegetarian pad thai. Later on I found tofu in it, which i ve never asked for, instead of actual vegetables. The pad thai was so oily and so burned. And then as I was eating, i found these strange little bones in the pad thai that I'm guessing were a fish bone.   Then the bad service from a short haired thai little woman who was ringing me up. She didn't understand English. I kept telling her I don't want a bag. They charge 10 cents for a bag. She kept arguing wt me over it. I told her 100 times, I don't want a bag, and then i see her charging me 10 cents for a bag, and then she puts tax over the 10 cents. I had to wait there for 10 minutes, explain to her what she did, to get a 10 cents back. but she still charged me tax over that 10 cents. terrible food, terrible customer service.
author: Sarah K.

description: This was a date night spot with the hubs in our search for our favorite Thai place in the city.  If the hubs were rating, I'm sure it would be a perfect 5, however seeing as this is my review, I give it a solid 3.  The food was good and the service was ok.  Do I crave it and want to come back immediately? No.  Would I come here again? Sure. Maybe.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Best Pad Thai I ever had. And the duck appetizer was amazing!
author: Luis C.

description:
Wow!  What can I say about this place!  This is not your ordinary thai restaurant.  The food here is really authentic although I've never actually been to thailand.  But it's WAY better than your typical pad thai.

Thanks to a couple of friends they did all the ordering.  I don't remember the names of the dishes.

1.  Some kind of sausage which I thought was alright
2.  Raw shrimp with garlic marinate in a spicy sauce YUM!!!  one of 
     my favorite dishes of the night
3.  Papaya salad with raw blue crab.  first time I've ever ate raw crab.  
     it was good but not as good as the shrimp
4.  Coconut soup with chicken
5.  Salad with roast duck, onions, and cilantro tossed with chili, lime, 
     and fish sauce.  
6.  Curry chicken
7.  Whole sea bass in a fish shaped platter on a burner.  I don't 
     remember what they topped the fish with but it was very very good

If it weren't for my friends I would've never known about this place.  I was kind of hesitant when they said we're eating at a thai restaurant in the tenderloin.  I would've missed out!  I can't wait to come back here.  I'm getting hungry right now and I just ate here last night!  definitely deserves 5 stars!
author: Samson M.

description:
The first time I ate here, I sat next to THE ANDREW ZIMMERMAN from Bizarre foods.  I had the alligator amongst other things. It was OK. 

I am a regular here for the Pork Belly salad and Quail. They use countless spices and peppers, so beware if you don't like spicy and celebrate if you do!

Everything else is basic Thai food. Nothing less than delicious. Get my regular and you'll be fine.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Good food and ambience.
Removed star as they brought entree before soup and were surprised that I wanted it later.
author: Vishal K.

description: Really delicious and a wonderful atmosphere. The curries are a delight, and the staff is always extremely pleasant. Very warm and sunny interior as well.
author: Jerry G.

description:
This is a pretty solid place to go if you're ready for a night out on the town with the mates or if you want Thai cuisine with a little more atmosphere.

The servers are all very sweet and gentle, but forgot about our table several times. We ordered the papaya salad with raw blue crab, and it was excellent. I loved the spice, they don't hold back. The raw blue crab was delicious and exceptionally fresh, giving the right amount of sea-salty goodness to the dish.

We also ordered the curry puffs, which were good, but not mindblowing.

My friend ordered a duck rice plate, which she said was delicious. 

My vegetarian pad thai without egg was a disappointment, though. The rice noodles were not cooked all the way through and the vegetables were still raw. Perhaps another 5 minutes in the wok on med/high heat would have been sufficient to tenderize the veggies and soften the rice noodles. 

Flavors were good overall, but the pacing and execution of some of the dishes need work. We got our appetizers, and then 2 minutes later, had our entrees plopped down on the table as well. It was difficult to work with 4 plates AND our appetizer plates on a two-top. 

When I start eating meat again, I'll go back to try other specialties.
author: May T.

description: Fantastic food. I can see why people complain about the service just because they don't really come over unless you signal them but they were definitely overly friendly and our server answered my naive questions as well as suggested great dishes for us when we asked. I love that they have a decent selection of alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages as well.
author: Caleigh E.

description:
Amazing fish, thai thè so good. Staff so kindly and soft-lights atmosphere.
Prices for everybody!
author: Davide milidolo R.

description:
I'm really glad I didn't read the reviews before I tried Lers Ros ("delicious") Thai or I probably wouldn't have tried it.  Many of the complaints are simply mistaken:  the authentic Thai food apparently has not been sufficiently Americanised.  Too salty?  Too spicy? Welcome to Thailand!  Not enough meat?  Try no meat!  Too little English?  Stay away from Asian restaurants.  Too noisy?  Welcome to San Francisco! 

OK, it has been Americanised that way, but it's no noisier than dozens of other, less appealing places.  So blame the clients who insist on shouting, not the restaurant, which has actually installed baffling in the ceiling.

This place is especially appealing to vegetarians, who know that good vegetarian food isn't simply replacing meat with tofu, and that eggplant doesn't by itself make a vegetarian dish exciting.

This was a fantastic experience.  Moderate prices, large portions, great taste,  beautiful presentation, excellent service.  Woohoo!  It doesn't get any better than this!

Incidentally, I'm normally quite conservative in my ratings, rarely giving five stars.  In fact, compared to most ratings I see, I should have given this six or seven stars, since we all know that five doesn't really mean "as good as it gets."
author: James G.

description: As much as I love their other two locations, I was very unhappy with this one.  It was unbearably noisy between the music and people having to talk louder to be heard.  The food wasn't good either.  The coconut soup was watery.  Two dishes were too salty.  The fourth dish was fine.  The service was very good, particularly one waiter. However, I will not be back.  The place was packed w. people.
author: Nora S.

description: Ordered a bunch of takeout from here for girl's night. We had the pad thai with chicken, the red curry with chicken, green curry with seafood, papaya salad and the basil chili chicken. Beware, when they say the food is spicy, they're not kidding. I was chugging down rice to put out the flames. I love that they have a pretty extensive menu and will try some more exotic items when I visit with my more adventurous friends.
author: Alice W.

description: This place is really excellent for thai. If you're going to Great American Music Hall, you should eat here. The boar is good and so is the pad Thai.
author: matthew m.

description: I came here with a group of friends prior to going out for drinks brvsuse of all it's great reviews. Most of us ordered pad see ews, while a couple of people ordered pad Thai. The food was decent but definitely not the best I've ever had and I probably would have preferred something like Ozone over Les Ros.  Their portions could have been bigger too I felt.
author: Stacey L.

description:
LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE.

pork belly - so freakin good. cooked well and had just enough spice
pork shoulder - had a nice smokey flavor and goes well with the sauce
papaya salad with salted duck egg - very fresh and the salted egg added a nice contrast to the lime and spicy taste of the salad

the service was very well done, they kept on refilling water and was promptly seated. alittle noisy during peak hours but well worth it for the food.
author: Q L.

description:
Lers Ros came highly recommend by my fabulous Thai sister. I knew I'd be in for a treat, so R and I braved the streets of the TL and made our way over from Union Square. I think it's a good idea to make a reservation, as waiting can take up to almost an hour on a busy night and you really don't want to be 1. waiting inside and smelling all the tantalizing food or 2. nervously huddling outside of the restaurant in the dark night. 

I wish we were hungrier so we could have eaten more. I also wish they weren't out of the Thai herb sausage appetizer. We couldn't bear to replace our order so we just went without it while wistfully wondering what it would have tasted like. More incentive to come back!

We got the Pad Thai (I know..but the articles outside mentioned it and I had been harboring a longtime craving!) with prawns, and the pork belly, which upon reading the reviews was a MUST GET. Also what you MUST GET with the pork belly is rice. 

I loved the Pad Thai! It was absolutely tasty and each element was flawless, from the crunchy bean sprouts to the chewiness of the noodles. 

The pork belly was surprising to me, first because I'm not used to having such a large platter of pork belly, and second because the crunch took me for a loop. Each piece is like a little party in your mouth. First comes the crispy layer, then the soft, fall apart in your mouth texture, and then the melting of the fat on your tongue... oh my my. The flavor is marvelous and there is the perfect amount of heat in this dish. However because it is so flavorful, don't skimp on the rice!

Anyway I wish we came on a less busy day, I wish we had a better table, and I wish our appetites were bigger! But all of this does not mar my impression of Lers Ros and I will definitely be back to try the other goodies on the expansive menu!
author: Lydia W.

description: Amazing!!! I left already planning my next meal there. The service is incredible too. Best coconut soup I have ever had.
author: alissa a.

description:
FINALLY!  Thai food, real, authentic usually aMAZING sometimes strange and every once in a while WTF, no, sorry i will NOT eat that animal but i appreciate you offering because that's exactly what they would do in Thailand.  

though i don't generally appreciate the holier-than-though attitude of "i've BEEN there so you must now bow before the might of my opinions," i HAVE in fact been there, basically lived there for 18 months, and you are welcome to totally disregard my opinion but this place is spot on.  but it really doesn't matter and i would tell you to eat here if they served this same food and called it ethiopian because it's THAT good.

thai food in thailand is spicy, it is served in portions about half the size of those in the US (though to be fair it is also offered at about 1/10 the cost) and sometimes includes animals, and parts of animals, you've never thought to eat and some you (or me) just don't want to.  thai food in thailand is also wonderfully varied, and extends well beyond the pad thai and the red-green-yellow rainbow of curries.  it includes strong, fragrant fresh herbs, a huge selection of vegetables straight from the morning market and is meant to be shared family style.

at Lers Ros this is exactly what you get.  fresh peppercorns, gently wilted basil leaves, and meat and veggies combined with thoughtfulness in each dish.  the flavors are bright and oftentimes unexpected.  they make me lust for the days i was sitting on (or rather sticking to) a red plastic chair in 100 degree temps and FULL humidity in clouds of exhaust on the side of Bangkok's streets when OH MY GOD, drop that thought, what IS this absolutely amazing flavor(s) in my mouth that is SO different then anything i've had before.  and dear, wonderful thai lady, do you have any IDEA what i will have to pay for this stateside, if i can even find it. 

GO HERE NOW.  with several people.  order an absurd amount of food.  pick at least two things you've never had before.  and do not leave until you order #62 (pork belly).  because i say so.  and i say so not because i've crashed a moped in thailand (i have).  i say so because it just SO DAMN GOOD.
author: Amy M.

description:
Very yummy Thai food!!! Reminded me of home back in Bangkok.

They have quite a few traditional dishes, only the SF foodies can handle. That probably explains why they don't have a place like this in the OC or not even Thai town in LA.  It seems to become less and less authentic as the year goes by. Makes me sad.

Definitely loved the spicy boar!!! Or so called pad ped moo pah. 

I heart SF
author: Pam K.

description:
try the raw crab green papaya salad- amazing
the house specialty fried trout with mango, also green, was super good too

they take reservations, but beware, if you arrive even 7 min late (as we did) you will be moved to the bottom of the wait list
author: Pepper B.

description:
After years of trying different Thai food establishments and always getting the same type of good, but uninspiring food, Lers Ros was really an unexpected surprise.  I have eaten a lot of Thai food, both in the States and in Thailand, and I must say that this place was up there with the best from my humble experience.  

First off, I love spicy food and restaurants that aren't scared to serve it hot.  The medium-hot heat level was even good enough to get the nose running a bit.  The PAPAYA SALAD was fresh and crispy with the perfect amount of heat and fish sauce taste.  The popular crispy PORK BELLY dish lived up to the hype with its flavorful buttery soft meat and a crispy skin.  As a basic baseline for comparison I always order some PAD THAI, and this place was better than average - fresh, not too greasy.  My favorite dish was the PLA RAD PRIK (WHOLE FRIED TALAPIA) - beautiful presentation, and a taste to match.

I thought the service and ambience were both great.  With a large staff of uniformed waitresses, my water, tea and beer were always refilled before they were half empty.  I am definitely coming back again.
author: Greg P.

description: The quality of food here is excellent. It's difficult for me to find new Thai restaurants that I like with all the great ones that I already frequent, but this one definitely ranks up there.  Their quality of food is great, and the prices aren't outrageous.  My only complaint is they gave me grief about waiting for the rest of my party to arrive.  The restaurant was empty when I got there, so there wasn't a demand for seating, and they were a little rude that I was waiting for the rest of my party to arrive.
author: dAvid s.

description: My family and I have Thai food at least once a week. We are here this weekend visiting San Francisco and decided to have Thai food. This place is amazing. Come early if you have kids because the place get crowded. Roasted duck is amazing. Also had beef with peanut sauce on bed of Spinach very delicious.
author: Ivan C.

description:
I went here on Thursday night. Here was choked up with customers even before 7pm. By the way, the counter seats were, too.
I could sit down due to the reservation. 

I think that a space between each table is a little narrow.

I tried the dish of deep-fried frog leg. It was soft and juicy meat with spicy seasoning, like chicken. Please try it by all means.

And I recommend also tom yam soup, because it comes in a exclusive pot that has hole to let fire trough. So the soup is kept warming up while we are eating. That's why we should feel more hotter the soup.
author: Yuri R.

description:
I'm not entirely sure how much I like Lers Ros. The office ordered take out for a small lunch party so I can't be entirely certain of what I got to sample. I do remember thinking that the portions seemed small (for take out at least). Here's what I (think) I sampled:

Crab and green papaya salad - I have to echo another reviewer on Yelp that said this was salty. To me this was VERY salty for a salad and it overwhelmed the refreshing green papaya.

Red chicken curry - This was pretty tasty, I love having curry sauce and rice. I hate curries that are overladen with coconut milk.

Deep fried pork - I'm not a fan of Chinese roast pork and I wasn't a fan of this. I actually found it to be overcooked because the meat was sort of hard. I imagine this may be a hit with others though.

Pad see-ew - This tasted average, nothing special and the noodles were a bit clumpy.

Pra ram kai (chicken, spinach, and peanut sauce) - This was also tasty, the peanut sauce wasn't too sweet and the spinach tasted pretty fresh.

Lers Ros website has their entire menu with pricing and I don't think the food I tried would compel me to seek out this restaurant in my spare time just to try it again. I have no idea how authentic the food is here, it doesn't taste bad but I think the pricing is too high for the portion/taste.
author: Monica W.

description:
I have ordered from this place several times and thought I would write a YELP review.  The food is pretty good, I like how you can request spicy and the dish actually comes out SPICY.  The papaya salad is SUPER good.  My favorite dish is the pad see ew, it is cooked perfectly and never too greasy.

So why 4 stars and not 5 you may ask.  Well it seems the portion sizes are getting smaller and smaller over time.  I remember going to this restaurant when it first opened and the portions were HUGE and I had to take part of my food home.  Perhaps trying to make more profit they have reduced the portion sizes.  In any event some really GOOD Thai food.  Just remember to lock your car door.
author: James E.

description:
Food Excellent !! Grill prawn papaya salad was out this world... the dressing was so refresh and tangy. Garlic quail was very tasty. Everything was good, it would be nice if my server have a smile on her face while serving us food.

 Wood stool instead of chair in the restaurant..ohh.. after a long walk from shopping at the union square, I would definitely need chairs with back to lean on and relax with my meal...the restaurant ambient is decent, modern, and warm. Beware, if you decide to wash your hand after meal or use the restroom, you will be walking into another zone... old dingy stairway that lead to the restroom, filled with graffiti, rolls and rolls of toilet paper for hand dry instead of paper towel, the restroom really turn me off from there on. I did mentioned this issue with my server but not sure if she would relate this matter to her management team...
author: Ttt C.

description:
Lers Ros has the most delicious, mouthwatering, can't-wait-to-try-more Thai food you'll ever eat in San Francisco. It boasts a menu of over 120 items but some of the dishes are so tasty and memorable, you'll have to fight every urge not to stick to your favorites. I've been here 2 or 3 dozen times and never been disappointed.

I have a weakness for pork so my favorite starter is the Koh Moo Yang (#9, $8.25). Grilled, smokey, tender pork shoulder is thinly sliced and fanned over crisp lettuce leaves. The melt-in-your-mouth unctuous fat on the pork is cut with an intense tart, spicy chili sauce with bits of red onion and cilantro for that perfect punch of tang, heat, and freshness.

My brother is a connoisseur of Lark Kai salad (#24, $7.25) and during a visit from out of town, he claimed Lers Ros' rendition is the best he's had outside of Thailand. Minced chicken and onions are mixed with chili, mint, rice powder, and lime juice dressing. It's savory, it's tangy, it's fresh, and oh man, is it spicy! It's an exciting taste and really perks up the taste buds for entrees.

Their signature dish is the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (#62, $8.95). Frequent visitors know to order this piece of porky heaven by its number: 62. Ever seen the huge slabs of fatty pork with glistening fried crispy skin hanging from hooks in Chinese butcher shops? Yeah, they take that and stir-fry it with a mix of red bell pepper, diced green bean, garlic, and strands of green peppercorn bound with a savory, dark, braising sauce that begs out to be ladled over rice.

I've made many a late night run for the Kao Pad Kai Tod (#57, $7.25). Crispy, sliced strips of battered, golden fried chicken are rested on moist egg and onion fried rice. A small dish of sweet chili sauce is served on the side for dipping the fried chicken but I find it ties the whole dish together so I just drizzle it all onto the dish.

My dining companions rave about their Pad Thai (#78, $7.50) and say it's a notch above the Pad Thai at the other independent and chain Thai restaurants around town. The chicken Tom Kha Gai soup (#27, $8.25) is rich and creamy and a great way to start the meal. It's served in a circular firepot which never fails to draw glances from other tables. When eating with a large party (I've been in a party of 14 here and they don't break a sweat), you can try the Pla Kra Pong Nuang Manow (#112, $23.95), a whole sea bass with chili and fresh lime juice. The fish is cooked in a light sauce and is wonderfully moist, tender, and light. I would prefer that they use a different sustainable fish but the occasional indulgence is to be enjoyed.

On a recent visit, I tried the Pad Makuer Tofu (#46, $7.25) and while the eggplant, bell peppers, and tofu were cooked nicely with a garlic, chili, and basil sauce, they lacked the punch of other stellar dishes. Subtlety isn't an asset on their menu: order with gusto and don't look back!

Lines can get long on Friday and weekend evenings but after you've put in the time, got a table, and ordered, the plates come out fast and furious. For a small, busy restaurant, the service is attentive and efficient. Glasses are refilled without having to look around and they even change your plates following appetizers and soup.

Best of all, they even offer delivery until close at midnight. I can't think of any other "Best of" restaurants, let alone decent restaurant that serves and delivers food this late.
author: Patrick W.

description: I've been to this place now several times. I just love it. The Pad Thai and Curry dishes are amazing!
author: Tobias V.

description: First, I'm not the biggest fan of Thai, but there are some good dishes out there. At lers ros we ordered 3 entrees and 2 apps. The entrees were by far the best Thai I ever had.  The curry puffs were a nice way to start the meal and the spring rolls were good but I was eating them while they were hot and there was something I didn't love in there
author: Sara K.

description: The food was excellent and VERY affordable. Atmosphere is tight seating but no issues with holding a conversation
author: Gina M.

description: Awesome food..  service could be little better. But authentic Thai food.  Their Thai tea is great
author: Brijesh C.

description:
the place looks very cool. modern, stylish but warm as well. food was awesome, I had some of the best curries I've had in a while and my wife said she loved her pad thai too. staff was friendly too.
and those candies on the way out are indeed very delicious
author: Johannes V.

description: Remember those four people that complained about tom yun koong. That's me. Stop charging osha thai prices when you cant provide the taste, quality and the portions. Their a la carte portions are smaller than normal restaurants single plate portions.
author: Geezy L.

description: I have to agree with the rest with this one. This restaurant's reputation totally precedes itself. Probably the best Thai food I've had in the Bay Area. There's always a line, but the pork belly, pork shoulder, and duck larb is definitely worth the wait.
author: Katheryn H.

description:
Service here was weird. . . One of the waitress wasn't really all there always looking in to space and instead of asking you to move over she shoves right through till she gets there. . . pretty funny, I didn't wish her to fall but it was hilarious, I had to ask my sister to move. I guess she was merely waiting on that since a chair is up in her back shoveling through. 
 
I had the 

chicken fried rice  
(I give it a C, the meat was taste less and flavorless) 


beef friend rice 
(I give it a C, the meat was taste less and flavorless ) 

pad thai 
(I give it a B, the noodles were just right not too hard or salty and was not too sweet. But it was salty, had to mix it with the tasteless rice) 

bbq beef 
(I give it an A, texture and flavor was just right) 

shrimp green papaya salad 
( I give it a B, very fresh on the veggies and shrimp but very salty) 

tom yum kai soup (If I spelled that correctly)
( I give it a, C it was very milk kind of weird, and was missing that zing it was suppose to have and didn't have a wow like other places) 

*****Portions are small so it is a bit more expensive then other places*** 

But at least the place was clean. . .
author: Sanora A.

description:
Very enjoyable meal.  Tried the yellow curry, a spicy beef dish, chicken satay, and spring rolls.  Everything was expertly prepared.  Not in the best part of town, but worth going back regardless.  I'll probably take a cab next time, rather than walking, lol.

Oh, they have some interesting items on the menu for those seeking some adventure--they have frog, alligator, venison, and more.
author: Jason H.

description:
This place is solid but I'll tell you what gave them that 5th star - Best. Spareribs. Ever. Seriously, just go there and order 3 plates of the pork spareribs (#5) for the table. The rest of the stuff is good but pretty spicy so make sure you can take the heat or let them know if you need it a bit milder. And don't let not being crazy about pork stop you from ordering the spareribs. I'm not a big fan either but even I go apeshit over this dish. 

Other than that it's a spacey hole in the wall with great service. Take home message - Order the ribs..thank me later.
author: Shreya C.

description:
The best Thai food I've ever had. Fresh, spicy and quality ingredients. I don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu, so try something new like frog, rabbit, alligator, venison or boar. They are all on the menu.

One thing I will specifically recommend is the pistachio ice cream with peanuts and honey. So simple, so creamy and oh so good.
author: Scott M.

description: Normally good, but not today. Quoted 30 minutes for a pickup order, didn't have the right noodles anymore, took 50 minutes total to complete order.
author: Alex D.

description:
This place is the hang.

Tom Kha is incredible. Fire volcano serving bowl!? Dope. Not to mention all the flavors shine through and sing in harmony.

All the dishes I had were hella flavorful and totes tasty on the heck-of.

The sweet rice and durian desert was awesome but the fried banana and pistachio ice cream is unbelievable.

Get there early because the crowd gets crazy.
author: Jason M.

description:
Darn good Thai food close to my house!!! Black awning with red letters - that's how you know you've arrived. Went at 7pm, Monday night & the place was already packed. 

Ordered Chang & Singha beers - both light & refreshing with the food.

Appetizer: #3 Fish Cake
YUM!  A bit on the greasy side from being fried but solid. 4 little fish rounds served with a side of addicting cucumber/sweet chili sauce. The cukes are thickly sliced, the oil is perfectly balanced with heat & sweet, & the crushed peanuts on top add a little crunch. 

Me: #25 Larb Phed Yang
Really? I had no idea Thai could be this GOOD! I usually get pad thai or chicken curry but I was blown away by the subtleness yet complexity of this dish. Duck wasn't overly fatty, seared tender, flaked & served (including skin) on a bed of iceberg lettuce, herbs & (beware!) whole chili peppers. I didn't touch them (I'm a spice-wuss) but they were small, red & fiery-looking. 

Ordered sticky rice which is what is just that: sticky. Served in a cute woven basket, impossible to spread like regular steamed rice. It's a glob that's more texture than taste. My favorite presentation: take a section of iceberg, slice of sticky rice & top with duck larb...insert in mouth & enjoy! 

Him: #34 Kang Karee (I think)
I had 1 bite of his yellow (orangish to me) curry with chicken & it was good. I've had good curry before so I didn't taste anymore. Nice sized chicken pieces with chunky veggies. Steamed rice was also ordered for this which was served in a pretty silver bowl. 

Only spoons & forks brought to table though, we never had a knife offered. A little different but I used 1 spoon as knife & all was fine!

I will happily go back again & again as the menu is impossibly long (usually something I stay away from but they seem to know what they're doing). Everyone should go here & keep them around for a long, long time!
author: Marissa H.

description:
Lers Ros is one of those hidden gems in the city.  I must admit that when I first saw this place I was skeptical.  Come on, good Thai in the Tenderloin?  Well, fortunately i was grossly mistaken!

The accommodated our group of 14, which was quite difficult since we took up half the dining area.  Kudos for that!

-The Papaya salad is very good!
-All the currys were amazing.  Both the yellow and red curry are super good!  
-Pad Thai.  While not the best I've tried, the dish was definitely very tasty. 
-Pad Kee Mow  Was very good, the spices were aromatic but not overpowering.  Just the right amount of spiciness.
-Pad See Yew Also very good!
-The noodles were the perfect consistency and the sauce was well done.

If you want good authentic Thai at very reasonable prices this is your joint!  Just remember to bring friends since you'll be walking in the TL!
author: Anthony L.

description: Went here reluctantly for lunch, and I LOVED it this time! Coconut water was amazing, I don't remember what I ordered (beef and vegetables in some kind of bean sauce?), but it was very tasty and I'm definitely going back.
author: Martie K.

description: First time having yum koong haeng and I loved it, I will be going back for more. Not a full 5 stars because their cucumber salad was awkwardly sweet, I don't like sweet vegetables.
author: Kelso H.

description: Really good food but wish they would have shared the wifi password with us since we couldn't get reception while inside.
author: Kyle C.

description:
Alligator, rabbit, boar, frog, quail...coming here is like going to a zoo, except you can eat the animals.

This is the BEST Thai restaurant I have ever been to, including actual restaurants in Thailand.  The price is very reasonable, and I especially love the BBQ chicken salad and the gizzard stir-fry. 

I'm not vegetarian.

BUT.  there are plenty of vegetarian options, too.  After all, this is San Francisco.  Great place to come before going to a show at the ACT or anywhere else in downtown.  My favorite place by far in the Tenderloin, along with Shalimar.
author: Mochi N.

description:
Hell yes. Gosh-damn-yes. Oh, hell yes this place is good. 

I used to refrain from strolling up and down Larkin - but I have no hesitation anymore knowing amazing food awaits - especially the food and the friendly service of Lers Ros Thai. 

We've tried most of the below or know that a friend has tried and loved.
$20-25/person (food+beer+tip, if you don't eat like a garbage can)

Starters:
#25 Larb Phed Yang ($7.95) duck larb - juicy, flavorful, makes your mouth tingle and sing with delight.
#9 Koh Moo Yang ($7.25) (sliced pork shoulder with side of dipping sauce)

Dishes:
#62 Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob ($7.95)  crispy pork belly with basil and red pepper
Pork belly with chinese broccoli
One of the crispy fish options - i think we had trout - just ask the lady for a recommendation, they're known for their whole fish.
pad see ew or pad thai. We Loved their pad see ew because it was dry-fry'd perfect.

Soup: tom yum or the seafood soup

The people here are great, the restaurant is clean, the music is even better (a mix of Celine, Mariah, Peter C., Sarah M., Chris I.) as it sets the mood for you to break out into karaoke numbers or romance. =) 

Come here late night, with friends, twice a day like we did the first day we tried it, with out of towners, you know what - this place is great for any and all occasions! This place is mid-block, just look for the red and black signage if you can't read Thai - which would be MOST of us.
author: Jessica C.

description:
After reading all the rave reviews about Ler Ros, my friends and I decided to go there for a co-workers birthday. I didn't do any of the ordering but my friend (who's been here before) shot called for everyone. 

We got garlic quail for apps and I was perplexed with dish we recieved. It looked like my leftovers after eating at KFC. Alot of small bones and no meat. 

Then came the curry puffs and papaya salad. Not bad but nothing to rant about.

Entrees included pad see ew, pork belly (a little over cooked), whole fried trout, whole fried talapia, and chicken tom yum. All of them where tasty but portions seemed on the small side. 

Decor is modern and service wasn't bad so I might come back to try other items.
author: Harry Y.

description:
Lers Ros is about authentic a thai place as I have ever found. Huge menu with the standard issue thai cuisine, but then there are a bunch of exotic surprises. 

I tucked into the Garlic Fried Rabbit first...outstanding little pieces of pan fried  goodness with a spicy/sweet dipping sauce. After than came the Red Curry Duck...beautiful color and rich flavors were enhanced by nicely cooked fatty duck sliced. The final treat was spicy boar...this was really unique. The boar was a little tough but the flavors were gamey and exciting. 

As if that wasn't enough my dinner guests and I had to move onto the ultimate...DURIAN...the waitress asked us multiple times if we wanted to do it and we had to twist her arm a bit. She gave a us a nice little bowl of fresh durian steeped in a sweet coconut sauce. The durian was as promised...stinky and rich.
author: Paul S.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant in SF.  They serve real, traditional Thai dishes at a reasonable price, not like the overpriced, Americanized Thai food they serve at Osha. If this is your first time going to Lers Ros, I would recommend their go-to dishes - pork belly, duck larb and pork shoulder salad.  I typically order these when taking friends here who have not been before.  All the other dishes I've tried are also delicious.  I would also recommend the clams (cooked in a spicy thai sauce), fried tilapia (whole fried fish for under $15), pad kee mao (very spicy!), soups (comes out in a huge soup boiler), beef with galingale (not sure what galingale is, but another spicy and good dish), creme of sum yong gai (jk, don't order this). I should also note that its in the heart of the Tenderloin District.
author: Grant L.

description:
AMAZINGGGGG! Best Meal in San Francisco! GO!

 I'm from Florida and like Thai food, but not enough to go out of my way for it. I'm glad I did! This is not the Thai that you see in most Americanized Thai restaurants. Yes, they have curry and Tom Yum soups  (much better though), but their specialty is pork. Listen to the other yelpers and get what they are suggesting - the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob. And try other pork dishes and soups! YUMMMMM. Open late and so, so cheap!
author: Kristino K.

description:
Oh YES, Lawrd!  Quaint diner-like place.  Tom Yum soup & Glass Noodles.  THE BEST THAI FOOD..UH...EVER!!!  I went on their web site and see they deliver as well.

I read on here if you mention Yelp, that you get a free spring roll.  I mentioned Yelp and only got a quizzical look.
author: Elisa A.

description:
So far, this is the best Thai food I have had in San Francisco. 

Here are my thoughts:

Thai iced tea:  Seriously good.  Strong tea flavor with just the right amount of sweetness...not cloyingly sweet, like some other Thai iced teas I have tried.

BBQ Pork kabobs - I would come back again just for these suckers...had a niced smoked flavor to them.

Yellow curry with chicken and potatoes - #34...perfect.  Medium spicy.  The potatoes complimented the yellow curry dish.  It was a simple meal but deliciously excecuted.

Green curry dish with seafood medley, bamboo shoots, and basil -#100 -- a little on the spicy side, but in a good way.  a great medley of flavors.

Would definitely come back here to try some less spicy dishes (e.g. pad thai, for example) to sample their large and diverse menu.  Service is friendly and quick...the waitress was very helpful in helping us navigate the ginormous menu.  You can find something to please everyone (even those who are less tolerant to spices) at this place.

My only complaint is that the neighborhood where this restaurant is a little seedy at night...but the price is reasonable and the food is amazing, so it's definitely worth a visit...or two or three....
author: Nina B.

description:
The primary reason to write a review is to add it to my list of Authentic Thai food in SF.
This is as Thai as it gets; practically what you get in Bangkok. One of the best meals I've had was on the beach in Pattaya... if you have ever done that, you know what I mean! Well, food at Lers Ros is very reminiscent of that.

I like everything but the whole trout, the kaang som (traditional Thai soup) and of course the pork belly (made famous at Lers Ros because Michael Bauer mentioned it) are some of my favorites.

There is no doubt that this might be the most typical, original Thai food in San Francisco. It might be a bit pricier than other places, and for that price some people might expect a fancier decor and fine dining service. Decor is not bad, but nondescript, service is decent but nothing out of this world; but who cares? What you really pay for is the food which is excellent.

3 minuses: parking can be a pain around there, neighborhood is a bit shady and there are a couple of tables in there where you can always feel a little draft.

Oh, and if you are wondering how to pronounce Lers Ros, it's "luht lot" :)
author: Vithiet L.

description: Excellent food! No wait to be seated, truly my first enjoyable Thai experience!
author: Lindsay B.

description: It's decent Thai; not my favorite in the city but it's definitely good!
author: Brandon G.

description:
Awesome, authentic, and reasonably priced Thai in the city, albeit in a sketchy part of town.  Came here on a Saturday evening and the restaurant was packed.  Make a reservation!  We were late for ours and had to bide our time with some Singhas at the bar which was more like a half-bar before a table opened up.

We ordered the papaya salad with salted crab, duck larb, pork belly, tom yum koong, some beef stir-fry dish (the name of which escapes me), a curry dish (good, but was probably erased from memory by a little too much sake), and the steamed chilean seabass cooked in a broth that I would've unsophisticatedly slurped up had I been eating in private.  Everything was fabulous and had just the right amount of kick, more on the spicier side than not.  Nom Nom Nom. :)

Loved it and will definitely be going back soon.
author: Liz N.

description:
WOW. SPICY SPICY FOOD - I LOVE IT!!

Salad with crab (forgot exactly) but wow this was so spicy I had to drink water. I can actually eat VERY VERY spicy, but this salad was pretty spicy and yummy. 

Ordered the green curry chicken - since I LOVE green curry - the spiciness for this dish was just perfect

Clams with sweet chili paste and basil - sauce was spicy and very tasty with rice

Pork shoulder - Tender meat and very yummy sauce for my rice


Will definitely come back here again for some spicy thai food!
author: Willa L.

description:
Very authentic.  So delicious.  Be prepared for spicy.

Must have the seared pork tenderloin, grilled prawns, garlic roasted quail, steamed sea bass, papaya salad and soup.

Looking forward to taking my folks here for dinner one night. :)
author: Sabrina F.

description: The food wasn't bad, and it wasn't great. I had the calamari, and it was perfectly cooked, but something was missing flavor-wise. My partner had the chef's special - roast chicken, sticky rice and a side of papaya salad. It was fine. Service was ok. The live music was the best - I really enjoyed the skills of those four young musicians!
author: akaya w.

description:
2nd visit.  If you go here before 9, prepare to wait for seats.  If you come after 9, the place seems to magically clear out and leave as much seating as you could possibly want, even on a weekend night. 

I got a hot & sour coconut soup.  The soup was pretty good but a little more sour than I prefer.  I really enjoyed having a magical firey pot to keep it bubbling while I ate.  It was enough to bring home for another meal.  We had to save some room anyways to try the deep fried banana with ice cream.  I think I've had better- this was small pieces of banana with more fried texture and less banana than I've had elsewhere, and the honey with the ice cream made it a little more rich than I liked, but we were splitting it and it balanced the sour soup I just had, so it was OK.  They definitely had a million more things I wanted to try so expect to find us there again soon.
author: Pat L.

description:
Disclaimer: My ratings are based on value compared to other restaurants of the same cuisine and of a similar price point.  A $10 meal could very well score 5 stars if the restaurant delivered excellent value.  Similarly, a $100 meal could score 1 star if the food was dismal compared to its similarly-priced brethren.  For the most part, my ratings will be based on the quality of the food, unless I explicitly comment on the service or the decor.

I have decided this will be my go-to delivery restaurant from now on.  I ordered the pork belly and duck larb that everyone keeps talking about (order came to just under $20), waited for the friendly delivery man to arrive and wham! instant yummy food.

I'm not normally a big fan of spicy foods, but the flavor more than made up for the burning sensation on my tongue.  Two quibbles: better lettuce with the duck larb please and it'd be great if the pork belly could have a little more fat (though the crispy skin was great too).
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
Best Thai in the city.

Coming from Sydney - the city where every second shopfront is a thai restaurant, and being a traveller of Thailand in the past, I know what Thai food is supposed to taste like. Lers Ros is the first place in San Francisco I've found that hits that nail on the head. The relief I experienced upon finally finding some decent Thai food is enough to warrant 5 stars.

The flavours are intense and balance salty, sweet, spicy and sour. They have all the trademark thai spices and flavours in abundance. Top points for the little green thai eggplants and green peppercorns! 

Another plus is that it's clean and fresh interior wise. I'm not usually fussy about where I eat as long as it maintains a modicum of sanitation, but Lers Ros is a nice change from divey dingy ethnic eateries in this part of town.

Go here, gorge yourself, and feel full and happy. Order the duck larb, it was the best of all the dishes we ordered.
author: Leah R.

description:
Boring, bland and flavorless, asked for extra spicy, for dishes already listed as spicy, no chile flavor to be found at all. It lacked any Thai flavor what-so-ever, just salty-no savory, nothing. It clearly wasn't cooked correctly, seemed like the basil(was it even Thai basil?) was added later instead of flavoring the oil and dish.  Did not resemble Thai food at all. 
The service was excellent, but we did go at an off time. 
Very disappointing.
author: Bill K.

description: Thanks for the recommendation, Yelp! Husband wanted Thai food, so I yelped best Thai restaurants in SF, and aso watched the "Check, Please" episode featuring Lers Ros. I already wanted to order 5 things before we even arrived. We were quoted a 15 minute wait at 7ish on a Saturday night, but maybe because there were only 2 of us, we only waited about 5 minutes. We had the duck larb (so good - even better than version made in a Thai cooking class I went to in Bangkok), tom yum soup with prawns, and red curry with duck, with a side of brown rice. Everything was so flavorful and fresh tasting. Service was friendly and efficient. Hot tea was a little weak, so I'll get the Thai iced tea next time. Can't wait to go back!
author: Natasha D.

description: Get a reservation or use their delivery service; very busy, but for good reason. Absolutely delicious food (though definitely on the spicy side). Had the herb sausage, garlic frog, stir-fried boar, special alligator, chicken pad Thai... All of it was great, and service was very accommodating considering how busy they were. Kind of sketch area, but I would definitely recommend. Just under five stars due to being a little crowded and noisy.
author: Steve R.

description:
I highly recommend Lertros. This is the most authentic Thai restaurant in the city.
The servers are very quick, organized, and sweet. They know exactly what ther are doing.


I am Thai.....trust me!
author: Ari C.

description:
We ate  (fried mackerel, boiled vegetables, and Nam Prik Kapi or shrimp chilli paste) and  (Tom Zap with pork ribs). Both are awesome and authentic. Extremely delicious and well presented. The waitresses are well dressed, friendly, and professional. 

Not a cheap place. But the food is worth the money. 

Restrooms are upstairs and kinda small and shitty, though. (not too dirty, but looks very different from the beautiful dining room.)
author: Arthur D.

description:
My favorite Thai restaurant in the city.  Exotic dishes, funny music that doesn't necessarily go with the setting (a lot of 90s R&B)...killer food with nice presentation that's very reasonably priced.

I love the pork belly salad with spicy lime vinaigrette as well as the spicy pan-fried noodles.  I ordered a chunk-frog dish that was also really delicious.

There are so many options on the menu (somewhere between 110 and 120) that even the most adventurous of palettes will never run out of new exciting things to try!
author: Laura L.

description:
I've been a few times now and a very embarrassing thing happened to me. We just finished paying and I went up the stairs to use the bathroom. The mens room was full and I really needed to go so I used the womens room. Not only did I leave an unpleasant smell but I used too much toilet paper and clogged up the toilet, to be fair the toilets at Lers Ros are weak. I opened the door and a woman was waiting for the bathroom and gave me a dirty look when she saw me leave, If you've been there you know how narrow that hallway is so we were up close and personal. I got down the stairs and told my friend that we were leaving and I went out the door and waited around the corner. 

The most recent time I was there I was a little less blown away by the pork belly but had a salad that was incredible. 
17) Yum Koh Moo Yang:  Spicy lime dressing and roasted quick marinated pork shoulder, basil leaves, chili &rice powder. I've had this many places before and Lers Ros cuts their pork a little big to wrap the cabbage around but the flavor is so amazing I didn't even care. Good call on the Salad Lillian
author: Manny F.

description: Food was great! Had the pork skewers as an appetizer - loved it ...then the basil pork and my wife had the basil chicken - both great! As for the interior and utensils ...better cleaning would be advantageous.
author: Dare A.

description:
Food is soooo good! Recommended by a Thai friend who swears its the most authentic Thai food you will find in the city. Never had a bad dish here so I'm sure anything you pick will be yummy! 

Only warning is the wait and reservations- especially if you have a large group. We had reservations for 7 people at 8pm on Saturday, everyone was there on time, but didn't get seated till 9:45pm! Manager told us it was bc another large group ended up bringing 8 additional people so they gave them our table! Got to talking with others waiting and heard some walk-in's got seated before others with reservations. 

Luckily we had ordered food well before we were seated so as soon as we got our table, all the food was ready and delicious! Definitely a must try but eat a little ahead of time, just in case you end up waiting a long time for your table!
author: Karen L.

description:
I can't get enough of Lers Ros. They have great service and the staff and owners are really friendly. 

They have some great house specials but I'd have to say some of the basic Thai dishes here are my favorite. The tom ka soup, larb, som tum salad are all amazing. Lers Ros has two locations and they are both fantastic.
author: Mark R.

description:
Really amazing Thai food.  Pricey though for the sizes.
Curry puffs. Amazing.  Appetizer $8
Papaya salad combo with chicken and sticky rice.  Nice presentation.  Chicken was good and on the bone.  Not enough food though for $15
Spare ribs special.  Amazing. Probably my favorite dish.
Tom Ka Gai soup- great but overly salty.  Not necessary.
author: Rhonda N.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal here. 

The restaurant is pretty big. Very chill environment inside...outside: not so much since its smack in the Tenderloin.

Prices are decent. It's about $7 and up for entrees. But come here for the lunch special and you can get 2 items, rice and salad for under $10. I got the spicy chicken basil and basil eggplant. Both were damn tasty and spiced just right. Everything was full of flavor and brings back memories of Thailand for me.

Service here is attentive and quick. The waitresses are very nice. There's also a really tall hot waiter, Joe, who works here. I thought I should add that.

Anyways, come here if you want try something other than King of Thai and if you're fine with it being in the TL.
author: Van D.

description:
Fried Pork Belly
Crispy, Interesting, Delicious
author: Gary B.

description:
My favorite Thai place in SF.  In a sketchy part of of town but that is part of its charm.   Good amount of seating, so perfect for larger groups. There tends to be a wait during peak hours (7 to 9p) on the weekends.  

Best Papaya Salad-a tad tooo spicy, so i always get it "not spicy" but it comes anyway with some spice. Better then when i say MILD and it comes spicy!  

Pad See-Eww has just the right ratio of meat, veg, noodle and grease.  

Curries-Mmmm so yummy.  Highly reccommend that Green Curry w/ Chicken. 

This place rocks. Just go and eat there!
author: Ka C.

description:
My favorite Thai spot in SF. 

My recommendations:

pork larb 
crispy pork belly
papaya salad w/ crab
author: D L.

description:
One of the most expansive menus I've seen in a Thai restaurant.  They offer the usual curries, noodle dishes, and papaya salads, but what really will strike most first timers will be the things like alligator and rabbit that make appearances on their sizable menu.

Coming in with my friend Miyuki who's been here all the time and always brings in new friends to eat, I let her go to work on the dishes.  She ordered the house specialty steamed seabass and pork belly.  I chimed in with the staple red beef curry, which was perfectly satisfactory, but lacked the luster of the other two dishes.

The seabass melts away so well and the pork belly.. well, there's nothing bad that could be said about pork belly.  I was warned that everything will be served on the spicy side, but things actually came out rather mild.  Just be wary if you're looking at ordering some of the more naturally spicy foods.

I'll definitely be back next time I'm in SF and hankering for some good, authentic Thai fare.  Or if I'm feeling adventurous for some alligator curry..
author: alex C.
