description: Wonderful place. Food terrific. Same for the service. Too loud, though.
author: ronald w.

description: The curry puff was definitely my favorite appetizer. I would like to return someday to try more entrees.
author: Kosmo Z.

description: It was good.  The dish I ordered, was with rice but I wouldn't do it again.  The main course settles into the rice and disappears... I like to have my rice and entree separate.
author: Michael C.

description: We're repeat customers of Lers Ros, but last night we were treated so badly by their receptionist. We arrived around 9:30 and were told we would have to put our names on the list and wait 10-15 minutes-- which is fine, we've been there many times so we know the drill. Then after around 10 minutes a tourist bus with around 30 passengers pulls up and after a quick interaction with the tour bus leader the woman in charge tells us she would have to sit all these passengers ahead of us because "they showed up early." I informed her that we've been waiting, and we were here first so she should seat us first following the "first come, first served rule" but she just wouldn't acknowledge our pleas, though clearly we were in the right. She told us she'd sit these 30 people ahead of our party (and everyone else after us on the list) and we would now have to wait another 15-20 minutes. She kept apologizing yet would not do the right thing-- clearly she prioritized the larger revenue to be generated by this group of 30 rather than doing what is right, which is to adhere to their first come first served rule. Their food is excellent, no doubt-- but they sure know how to piss off loyal clients in the name of a few extra bucks. Will never return to this place.
author: Ulysses L.

description:
This is one of the cases where you really wish there were half stars. Three isn't quite enough and four is just not right. So...

I was at Lers Ros a few nights ago with my daughter who spent three months earlier this year living in Thailand. From the get-go she said this was the most authentic Thai place she's visited in the US. Everything from the music on the radio to the Chang Beer logos on the cooler. She was smiling ear-to-ear. We got the (voluminous) menu and began ordering. I started with the Larb Kai (chicken) and then I went with the Rad Nah (#79 - "house secret gravy sauce and marinated pork topping on the seasoned flat noodle"). I ordered a Fat Tire Ale.

The ambiance is what I would call serviceable.  The service is what I'd call serviceable although the place was packed and there were lines at the door so I really can't complain. In true Thai restaurant fashion, there were TVs on the wall. The food came in a few minutes.

The Larb Kai was very favorable for the first few bites. Then the heat set in. Now, I think I have a pretty manly palate and can handle heat but when sweat is running down the back of my neck and my scalp is damp I'd say they were serving up the heat. Throwing sanity to the wind I finished the salad and waited just a moment for my entree to arrive. Now, ya know when you've eaten really spicy hot food and the beer isn't doing the job of quelling the fire and the next dish is really steaming hot? Just how difficult that is to eat? Ah. That's where I was. Now, the Rad Nah was very good...delicious for the parts of it that I could actually taste. I managed to eat most of it through long sips of beer and ice water. So...lessons learned?

The food here is good but be careful of how hot it can get. Have cold water on the table just in case. Make a reservation (it seems to have a large fan base). Enjoy.

3.5 stars.
author: Gary C.

description:
My favorite go-to restaurant when I want out-of-the-ordinary thai food late at night in the Tenderloin.

Some of this stuff is mind-blowing spicy, especially the salads.  It's suck-on-ice-cubes for 20 minutes until your mouth works again spicy.  It's you-know-it-the-next-day spicy.  It's sweaty scalp, drugged out euphoria, six-napkins of drippy nose spicy.   But so tasty you eat the whole thing.

The "immature peppercorn" dishes are spicy in a whole new way.  Other things, like the porridge soups (very not like jook) and the fried tofu appetizer are not spicy at all.  I really like the pork leg over mustard greens.  If you're adventurous you can have eel, boar, vennison, and lots of other game meat.  If not, they do have some of the typical thai dishes, though cooked with a twist that makes me think it's either extra-authentic or regional.

Staff is friendly and sweet if not super-attentive.  Decor is straightforward Asian restaurant, though dim enough that it has a bit of class.  There's a one page list of beer, wine, sake, and miscellaneous nonalcoholic drinks.  Food comes out fast.  Prices are reasonable - $6 to $9 for the standard fare, and up to $20 for things like a whole fresh steamed fish, also highly recommended.

It's good for large groups, also good to come alone, although the portions seem geared to share.  I've already been here seven or eight times in the past year so it's safe to say I'll be back.
author: Gil S.

description: Another quick update- we tried the 5 spice duck in the roasted style. Now you might think this would be too similar to your generic chinese roast duck to be worth trying. You would be dead wrong. This is roast duck PAR EXCELLENCE.The duck is moist and soft and flavorful inside and out. The dipping sauce is exceptional as well. Expensive but it's a must try item. The deep fried frog in the starter section is also pretty good.
author: Jesse L.

description:
If you like amazing Thai food and amazing service, this is where you want to be!  My only criticism would be the lack of decor.  Everything else was beyond exceptional.  

This is a place where the food and the service are the star!  I would absolutely go here again.

Just went back to Lers Rose for a second time and i must say still  tremendously tasty and the service has never lost a beat.  I did think, however, that the pad Thai was too oily.  Papaya salad with grilled prawns is definitely one of my favorites, as well as, woon sen salad, and whole fried tilapia.
author: Pizzle D.

description: This place is a good value for its lunch special. The food is real good but the sauce is a little too heavy and salty in the dishes. Recommend!
author: Ben U.

description:
Yum Yum Yum! I came here last night w a bunch of my friends. At first I was like..hmm I'm not that hungry so I will just get a coconut drink. As food started coming, I couldn't help myself! haha Here are some of the delicious dishes: 

1) Pork Shoulder: Very tender and Juice dipping sauce is awesome 
2) Thai curry Puff: love the peanut spicy sauce. 
3)Pork Sausage: I actually did not care for this, but my friends liked it 
4) Yellow curry with chicken: the curry sauce was very good, I had it all over my rice. 
5) Crocodile curry: I had a bite of this just to try it out..tastes like chicken but more chewy. 

The service was good and the price was also decent. For 6 of us we paid $22 each. Not bad. 

The restaurant is really clean too!
author: Sandy L.

description: I ordered Pad Thai. The service was fine, the ambiance was neat, but the food wasn't great compared to what I paid for it.
author: Adam F.

description:
Finally came here to try this restaurant. I have bookmarked this restaurant for half a year..........well almost. Fellow yelper, Derrick V, have told me about this place to try. 

This place is located in one of the toughest area in the city, the tenderloin. I personally don't mind the elements around here because I have lived in the city for a long time and I have a pretty thick skin. 

This is probably the cleanest Thai restaurant in this area. It's as authentic as it's going to get and their menu is very extensive. They have frogs, boars, fresh fish, etc. The sauces and ingredients are fresh and vibrant. Their food is probably on the more refined and higher end, upscale Thai cuisine. 

We had the fried talapia and the green curry and pork. Both were very tasty and good. Coming here, you feel as though you were at a different part of the city. It's a real eye opener.
author: jason g.

description: This place is great, the food is really tasty, the staff are friendly. It is also great value. This is going to be a regular on the way home
author: Neil A.

description:
Okay I've been back a handful more times and this place ROCKS.  You gotta know what to order, but boy when you do.... it's just outstanding.  Go to items: pork belly, pork shoulder, whole fish, pad siew, salted egg papaya salad.

It's still very pungent and fish saucy but it works on the dishes we tried the second and third times.
author: Calvin N.

description: First time delivery, it took 2 hrs!!!.. i called 4 times to confirm and they kept saying food is on its way but never came,!!!... and i am just a block and a half away!... I ended up odering from another thai restaurant next to them, SAI JAI THAI. Very BAD experience !!!
author: Aiko Marie E.

description:
This is hands down the best Thai in the city. And it isn't just me who thinks so--all my Thai friends agree...as do all the friends I've introduced to Lers Ros. It has become a staple. My favorite is the papaya saiad with shrimp; it is so tasty and spicy your eyes will water helplessly for more. The service is quick and sweet, and the head waiter is a gem who will remember you the next time you come in. 

And in regards to all those reviews with fearful gripes about the neighborhood, the reviewers must all be tourists who aren't used to the grit of San Francisco. While Larkin is a little rough around the edges, there is little need to fear for your life as some might suggest: a little dirty, stinky, and sketchy--yes; dangerous--absolutely not!
author: Troy S.

description:
This is my first time going to Lers Ros. The area isn't the safest, but I've definitely seen worse. 

We ordered multiple dishes, including: 
- bbq chicken
- fried fish
- roasted duck
- pork
- duck fried rice

All dishes were yummy, but i feel like it was on the pricier side of what I would usually pay for Thai food. Nonetheless, I think it's definitely a place worth checking out. =)
author: Sharon G.

description:
My friend who has never been to Thailand kept on texting me about this place - "let me take you for authentic Thai." I was like "OK, whatever dude." Well, dude was right. (I have no idea how he knows what authentic Thai is, but who cares?)
Hell yes. This place rocked. This was the first Thai I've had since returning from Thailand and it was truly the bomb.
We had:
Papaya salad (crispy, fresh, great prawns)
Red curry chicken (big portion, yummy lil' eggplants)
Pork belly stir fry
Pad thai (authentic - with plenty of bean sprouts, tamarind concentrate and al dente noodles)
Whole fried tilapia in chili sauce (SPICY!)
Fried bananas.
Even the Jasmine rice stood out. And the Thai Iced Tea.
I was bananas over what we had. The location was sort of sketchy, but inside was a clean, bustling oasis.
Prices were outstanding. The four of us ate to our hearts' content (well figuratively at least) and we spent $20 each incl tax/tip.
author: Andrew K.

description:
It's been a long journey through servings of gloppy pad thai, flavorless green curry and greasy fish cakes, but I have found my favorite Bay Area Thai place.

In a sea of run-of-the-mill Thai restaurants, Lers Ros offers unusual dishes that are flavored with fresh ingredients. 

The #21 Yum Woon Sen is a tasty glass noodle salad with veggies including wood ear mushrooms, shrimp, peanuts, and this chili-lime dressing that gives a wonderfully citrusy punch and goes well with the spiciness of the dish. 

The #25 Larb Phed Yang is an amazing combo of tender chunks of roasted duck that contrasted well with the fresh lettuce, onion, Thai basil and a rice powder-chili-lime sauce. 

I like Thom Kha Kai (#27). It's my Thai restaurant mainstay. I find that often the broth is overly sweet, way too thick and doesn't pack the lime punch on the end that I love so much. The Lers Ros take on Thom Kha Kai pushed me over the edge of Thai dining heaven. The broth was perfectly coconuty without being too sweet, had a great lime flavor and was full of fresh ingredients including fresh mushrooms and bamboo. No canned ingredients here, although I do like canned straw mushrooms in my Thom Kha Kai. The use of fresh lemongrass, chilies, galangal, lime and basil really gave the broth a depth that I haven't tasted in other versions of Thom Kha Kai. 

There were about five other menu items I wanted to try, but my dining partner kept me in check and reminded me that I can always come back another time, which is what I plan on doing; many times.
author: Lee H.

description: The food was A-Ok. I found it to be quite on the greasy side. And dont feel like it was cooked with "love" if you know what I mean. I've def had way better thai food! :)
author: DeesQue N.

description: It is easy to walk by Lers Ros and you cannot tell how popular the place until you step in.  Their menu is extensive and goes beyond your typical Thai restaurant.  This has become a popular place for those who want to go beyond pad thai, larb & curry.  Service is friendly and engaging.  The hostess Gigi who just moved here from Dallas was extremely helpful. I am sure she'll increase business at this restaurant.  If you are a big fan of Thai food, I would whole-heartedly recommend this place for you.  They have dishes like raw blue crab papaya salad and pork rib delicious that will surely satisfy you.
author: Laurence H.

description:
order: kaprow chicken, pad see ew
veg: tom saab (with mixed veggies), pad kee mao veg

got the pork belly at everyone's rec. but it wasn't particularly good. then went back again to give it another shot... YES. this place is good. i agree you should venture out to try something new when you come here, but make sure you at least get one of the staples that you're comfortable with.

like i said, none in our party was very pleased by the pork belly and we're all pretty well versed in thai food, americanized anyway. the pad kee mao was quite good, the tom saab was absolutely delicious (we got it with mixed veggies and it tasted healthy and still spicy) and the kaprow (basil) chicken was spicy and delicious over white rice. 

this is our favorite thai in SF.
author: Niket B.

description:
Went there because it was highly recommended for being "authentic" by a trusted amigo. Unfortunately, was thoroughly disappointed. Here's why:

1. Chewy Rice/Pad Kra Prow (basil beef with special sauce)
2. Tom Kha was too sour and was lacking the sweetness and the richness of coconut milk
3. Red curry was bland 
4. Shietty location. 

I was really looking forward to exploring this place because I am a big Thai Food aficionado - too bad...
author: Seema H.

description: This place is ok.  Better than most small Thai restaurants but not as good as OSHA.
author: M S.

description: Delicious but nothing special.  Larkin St. location has better food for some reason when having it delivered.  The shrimp on the green papaya salad can be a bit muddy tasting sometimes as if from a muddy lake.  The sun dried beef appetizer is tasty.  The meat served when you dine in seems to be of a higher quality compared to take out or delivery.  I guess because you can't send it back?  I no longer order meat unless dining there.  This is a good option for me since I am in the area but would love to have a better option without venturing into the TL.  The service is OK.  They are always busy in the evening and I can feel the stress coming off of them when taking your order.  It's sort of noisy/loud.  The sticky rice with Durian or Mango is very good so you might want to save room for dessert.
author: emily b.

description:
It's about the food.  

Authentic.  Not trying to meet Farang expectations. Straight-forward. Spicy,... or just spiced.   Sweat-inducing spicy fish soup cooked when ordered. Lots of choices which are not just re-combinations of the same three ingredients. A complete lack of steam-table feel.  Inexpensive, but not cheap.

The restaurant has the atmosphere of a high school cafeteria. Only much cleaner.  And, with beer and wine.  But, instead of being annoying, the absolute lack of fluffy decor in this place adds to the feeling that you've discovered a sliver of Thailand in the middle of the Tenderloin.

Wow.
author: Galen W.

description: My favorite Thai food in SF hands down! The pork belly is a must try! And the durian sticky rice though!
author: Mason I.

description: This is hands down the best Thai food I've ever eaten.  You must try the flaming pot soups, and the crispy fried pork belly with basil and a fried egg, will make you denounce your favorite Thai restaurant.  Period.
author: Gregory E.

description: It was.....yummy!   I did feel like it was a knock off from the Slanted Door. What was unique was their daily specials menu with an alligator stir fry item and a rabbit item.  I did not have either.  I had beef with black pepper and onions.  I sent it back because I like my meat well done, and this was a bit rare for me, but it was tasty once it was cooked to my preference.  The seating was not the most comfortable as the chairs don't have backs, they are stools and they do pack as many tables as possible into the place. I was inconvenienced a few times by people walking behind me and "bumping" into me while doing so. The staff was friendly and efficient.  I would give their food four stars but the atmosphere reduces the experience to  three stars for me.  Still I  would definitely eat there again and recommend you give them a try.
author: Nur Ein M.

description: Man this place is good. Best Thai food I've had in the Bay Area. And very very nice staff. All around great experience.
author: J T.

description: The food here is generally great. Soup is awesome. Curries are very good. Service is nice. Though, the alligator curry was strange. I'd give a solid 4 stars if they provided towels in the bathroom. But, since the bathroom has no towels, and there's no way to properly wash your hands, they go from 4 to 3 stars. I don't know whether or not the staff has a different station for hand-washing after using the bathroom. I sure hope they do. According to Modernist Cuisine, more than 90% of all food poisoning is caused by fecal-oral contamination. That means, a restaurant worker wipes his or her ass then prepares your food with crap on his or her hands. Wiping hands dry with towels is part of the cleaning process. So, do the workers use a different bathroom or clean their hands somewhere else? If the answer is no, then this place should not be able to pass a health inspection.
author: Eater S.

description: Was missing the curry puffs in Singapore. The chicken and potato ones Lers Ros served up are surprisingly good. I was not disappointed. What is up with their Pad See Yew?  Bland, noodles stuck together, terrible presentation.  The noodles are part white and part brown which means that they are not all evenly cooked with the sweet dark soy sauce and the light soy sauce.   I'm convinced Thai House Express serves the best Pad See Yew in the bay area. But Lers Ros is the only place that serves a decent Kway Chup and so here I am slurping up the five spice soup noodle dish.  Skip the disgustingly sweetened coconut juice and the red ruby dessert.  Also if you can, skip the lunch specials with two items and rice.  So boring and dry.
author: X L.

description: Good Thai food and nice atmosphere. It seems like a popular restaurant. I'll be back!
author: Jolie S.

description: My FAVORITE Thai place in the city right now.  I grew up in Bangkok Thailand and so am very picky about going to Thai restaurants.  While the city has many Thai places, the vast majority of them serve crappy, "americanized" Thai food (don't even get me started on Osha which SUCKS!).  Ler Ros is the real deal.  While the ambience, decor and Tenderloin location are negatives, the food and service more than make up for it.  Get the papaya salad (som tum), the Tom kha gai soup, pad woon sen noodles or kao kah moo (pork leg stew).  I've been almost 10 times and have never been disappointed.
author: Toby C.

description: This place is delicious! I've loved every dish I've gotten, and the wine list is really good. Their spicy sauces are not for the faint of heart!
author: Kristina B.

description: Trendy looking Thai place as they usually are lately. This one however, is in the heart of Tenderloin. Food was really good and service was great. Will definitely come back if I'm in the area.
author: Patricia L.

description: This is my favorite Thai place ever.  I dream of their lime sauce.  It is soooo good.  Order anything that has lime sauce, it will blow your mind!  I specially like the papaya salad and the meat with the lime sauce.  The pad thai is really good too.  Not too sweet.  One recommendation: make reservations or the wait can take hours.
author: Dulce F.

description:
My husband and I have to continue our search for Thai. :( We were really disappointed with our pad see ew (chicken) and beef with onions/peppers and chili sauce. The chicken was very dry and the noodles were all clumped together. The beef dish was EXTREMELY gingery to the point I could not eat it after ONE bite. Not sure what went wrong but we can not get delivery ever again. Sadly a huge waste of money... I would have sent it back if I was eating in but gotta accept the risk of delivery sometimes. 

Back to the search for a great Thai place... suggestions welcome!
author: Ami D.

description:
I have stayed away from Thai food for years, ever since I tried it for the first time in college, a not-so-great experience at a dumpy Thai restaurant in Berkeley.  It was so bad then that I felt like puking, and vowed never to touch the stuff again. It put me off not just Thai food but most curries in general (at least until I got more into Indian food).  Over the years, I would try it again once in a while, trying to keep an open mind, and while those experiences were not bad, definitely not even close to the first time, I was kinda meh about the cuisine in general and I never craved it.

That is, until I tried Lers Ros!  This place is famous at my other favorite foodie online hangout, Chowhound, that when I got the chance I figured I'd give Thai food another try.  I was in the Nob Hill area and initially wanted brunch-y food with my friends, but after unsuccessful attempts to get tables at Canteen and farm:table, we wound up here.  We started off with a spicy coconut soup...it came in a cool container with a flame in the middle to keep the food warm.  I'm normally not the greatest fan of coconut, but I think the spiciness of the dish made it work.  We were all a little hung over from the night before so we all opted for the greasy stuff to coat our bellies.  I doubled up on the fried stuff, getting the fried rice AND the fried chicken.  It totally hit the spot in the best possible way, and settled my queasy tummy immediately.  The rice was just so flavorful, and the chicken very crispy and juicy.  The sweet chili sauce that came with it was good but I needed a bit more of a kick and added some of their chili paste (they have 4-5 different condiments on the table that you can add).

The meal was very cheap, wound up costing under $15/pp.  It was the perfect hangover food, but I would enjoy it even if I wasn't hung over.  I definitely want to come back and try more since I've only had a small piece of their very extensive menu.  I might just learn to love Thai food because of this place.
author: Arlene M.

description: Unbelievable food, had the yellow curry with chicken and pad Thai and they both blew our minds. Would love to come back next time we are here in San Fran.
author: Bryan F.

description:
Thanks to Daniel L's recommendation, we decided to check this place out this afternoon.  

I think this is my new favorite Thai restaurant!  The place is a bit sterile and it's not in the best neighborhood, but the food is fantastic and it's  closest thing to the food I had in Thailand in the Bay area.

After some research online, we ordered:

#25 Larb Phed Yang ($7.95) - a spicy duck salad with lime & chili dressing.  The duck is slightly fatty with onions, cilantro and lettuce.  The flavors are bold which reminds me of the salads in Thailand.  Fantastic!

#62 Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob - Pork belly that's deep fried with crispy skin.  The pork belly is then cubed and stir fried with basil and bell peppers.  The pork belly itself is a lot like Cantonese suckling pig.  Again, the flavors are very bold.  It's outstanding!

#80 Pad Woon Sen -  Stir fried mung bean noodles with eggs and prawns.  It's a nice dish to go with the spicy pork and duck.

I am very excited that there's a Thai restaurant that serves authentic Thai food.  I cannot wait to try their other menu items.
author: Paul K.

description: we lucked out... after we stand down, at least 5 tables came... portions are good size.. the only thing we did not like is the fried stuff....i.e. fried quail... sorry, when u fry a quail, there is just no meat to eat... we also did not care for the pork shoulders on the appetizer menu. That said, I would say just order from the entree menu... you can't go wrong.. everything on the entree menu was delicious and good portion. We tried a curry dish... very very good... the spice was perfect... the pad thai...very tasty...tum yum... yummy...they have the most extensive menu we have ever seen. We'll have to go back to try the alligator and frog legs.
author: Jay S.

description:
Best Thai Place in SF
Casual, Great food, and Friendly Staff 
I really recommend the tom yum soup and red duck curry - delicious!
Price $10-15 for entrees, they do take reservations, great for large groups.
author: Sophie S.

description:
After seeing all the good reviews we ordered up some delivery, pad kee maow, green curry, some salad and tom yum.  The food was all pretty bland and disappointing.  We ordered it spicy and it came fairly spicy, but I expected more considering all the emphasis I put on it and more from the dishes themselves.  Everything but the salad was boring, most people who have a taste for the real deal should steer clear.  

It's probably a safe place to take your relatives from Idaho.  If you've ever ordered something "phet phet mak" to drive the point home though there are better options.
author: Scott S.

description:
We had reservations. They had our table ready at 6:30 pm.  We ordered a variety of food for 13 of us.  We started out with appetizers, fried tofu and fried dumpling (our fav).  The green papaya salad was ok, it was too spicy for us and we love it hot!  We would recommend the pad thai, stir fried chicken/ spinach, yellow, green and red curries, definitely enjoyed each one of them.

Worth the visit.
author: Lori L.

description: Really enjoyed the food and the service. Had duck larb, which was nicely spicy without burning; rabbit with garlic, tasty if bony; and stir-fried prawns, not over-cooked. The sticky rice with mango was delicious and not too sweet. Service was very friendly and attentive, with water refilled often.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Three letters...OMG!

Delicious and even better...when English isn't the primary language being spoken and white people aren't the majority. You know it's good!!!

We had the pork shoulder, which was amazing! A little fatty, but sooooo good!

We also had a green curry and a stir fry veggie dish, which were also yummy!!

The two of us ate 3 dishes, brown rice, and each had a beer for less than $30!

I will definitely go back! Good stuff!
author: Pam W.

description:
I am so excited to have found this place!  You know that I am always looking for something sublime to stick in my mouth and this place has amazing food.  Each dish is carefully made and well balanced and I love all of the unusual ingredients- alligator, frog, quail, venison-awesome!!
You must go try this place.  And best of all, it won't make a hole in your wallet;-)
author: Holly L.

description: food, service and value are all top notch at Lers Ros. when you're not in the mood for anything, you're in the mood for Lers Ros. I could literally be on my death bed without and functioning digestive system and if someone set down an order or vegetarian pad see ew in front of me, i would will myself to live just long enough to lick the plate. also, take it on good authority, that Lers Ros has the most amazing peanut sauce on planet earth. they also have a quality beer selection and tasty desert menu. this brings me to the service which is unfailingly cheerful and attentive. overall top brass!
author: danicka h.

description: Two venues, Hayes Valley is nicer but I prefer the original in the Tenderloin. Really fresh, high quality and good price. Wide choice of traditional plus new takes. The whole sea bass is fantastic.
author: Paul V.

description: Place is a legit Thai place having been to Thailand a number of times. It's a no frills kind of place. It's a great for a casual date and/or to bring someone to show how hip you are to an authentic place in SF. Every time I have waited for a table but never too long. It's in a dodgy neighborhood but Olive across the street is a great place to get a drink before or after.
author: Kim M.

description:
Just real, excellent Thai food, among the best in town-- the right ingredients make all the difference.  They're not afraid to make it authentically spicy but flavorful in the right ways.  Kafir lime leaves and juice, galangal, oyster mushrooms, fresh curry pastes, Thai eggplant, real hot chilis... I'm eating leftovers now...

After eating there I don't remember the neighborhood or much about the decor-- the food is the experience, worth 5 solid stars, and excellent service that gets finished dishes to the table right away, hot and aromatic, I can smell it on my clothes a few hours after leaving which only makes me hungry to remember...
author: Jeff S.

description: Terrible service and when given a chance to rectify they didn't. Pay for overpriced thai food elsewhere.
author: Jessica S.

description: Gone downhill recently.  I don't know what happened, but lately the meat has been tough and the flavors just aren't the same... maybe they send the best ingredients to the Hayes location now.  Very sad.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Very impressive restaurant.  A Thai friend of mine with very good taste told me this was the best Thai restaurant in the Bay Area.  After trying for a while to come here and giving up due to the lines, we finally got in.  We ordered Red Duck Curry, Fried Pork Belly, and the green papaya salad.  All three were exquisite.  The key thing here is that the food doesn't have just one overpowering flavor, but each has a complex and subtle flavors that come out throughout the meal.  

Oh yeah, and the Thai Iced Coffee was one of the best I've ever had.  The price was not cheap, but then again, for the quality, it was definitely worth it.  

Highly recommend this place!
author: Kryzak K.

description:
The food here is pretty pricey except for their specials.
If you come for lunch it's an affordable place to eat with a good variety of Thai dishes

The curry is a very good place to start and their basil chicken is delicious.

I've seen the fried trout and really want to give that a try next time.
author: Jason K.

description:
Simply awesome in nearly every way.

I ate here with three friends last night on New Year's Eve.  Not only had Lers Ros Thai not jacked up their prices like so many other places do on this night... they even gave everyone in our party a complimentary glass of champagne.  Now that's classy!

That was just the start of a very fine evening here.  No, wait, that's not quite true.  I had called them no fewer than four times to inquire about reservations, make reservations, change reservations, etc.  And each time, they were unfailingly helpful and polite.

When I came in to the restaurant way earlier than my friends and waited for them, they brought me my champagne early, plus water, and lots of smiles.  These folks are attentive, friendly, and helpful!

All our dishes were tasty, but one of them -- the one I requested to be "medium spicy" was, for my friends and I, just too spicy.  When I mentioned this to the waitress, asking if there was any sort of add-on to make it less spicy (like yogurt in an Indian restaurant) she said, no, no, let us make you a brand new dish that'll be better for you... any dish you want, free of charge.  I was stunned and couldn't decide so I had her pick a different beef dish, and oh boy, did that beef just melt-in-your-mouth (and yes, it was much less spicy!)

And wow, everything is so affordable!  Most entrees are around $8-$9, with just a few dishes (particularly specials) being appreciably more.  Much of the wine is a reasonable $5/glass.  Take THAT, mostly-overpriced-SF-Thai-restaurants!

Sadly, no one else but me had room for dessert so I passed on it as well... but next time I'm getting the fried-banana-with-mitchell's-ice-cream!

Only nitpicks?
- Mints with the check would have been a nice touch.
- Dangit, why isn't this in Mountain View where I live?! :D

I can't wait to go back!
author: Adam L.

description:
DELICIOUS! By far my favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco. I highly recommend their pad thai & pork belly. Depending on what time you get there you may have to wait a while, but it's worth the wait.  

The only drawback is the location. If I can't find street parking on the actual block, I don't eat here. At night the people wandering around are pretty sketchy. The only time I parked over a block away I returned to a group of people just outside of my car with items strewn around & my side mirrors pushed in.
author: Tori P.

description:
Thai in the Tenderloin is only a good idea when the restaurant has 4 stars. Even then, its always an adventure worrying if someone will bash your car window, if a tranny will solicit you, or if a crazy bum will yell at your face for no reason. Luckily, my friends and I escaped these threats along the way.

The restaurant is organized and clean and the waitresses are very nice people. Menu has a huge selection; it took awhile just to look through the items. It features very traditional dishes and some I have never even heard of. They have weird meats like rabbit but they also got the typical Pad Thai. I went for the seafood curry which was very mediocre. The curry itself had great spices and flavors but the seafood sucked. It consisted of mostly fishballs and like a shrimp. Osha Thai still has the best one in my book. The sticky rice was cool; it comes in a little cylinder box and was sticky as hell. Pad Thai was also legit, doesn't taste like ketchup like at other places. Being more adventurous with the dish selection (ie. ordering something you have no idea what it is) will lead in better results.
author: Ed L.

description: Dined for lunch on a Sunday.  Not very busy at 11am.  Started with the garlic frog legs, then ate Tom Kha Gai, and finished with a beef/spinach dish in peanut sauce. The frog had great flavor. The soup portion was very generous (enough to share with 3-4 people) and the flaming pot was cool. The beef/spinach was very good as well.  One of the best Thai places I've eaten.
author: Steve P.

description: More late nights of drinking should lead to Thai food. Lers Ros offers quick, delicious staples with appropriately lit seating and prompt service.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
Best Thai joint in the city. SF has some god awful thai places that border on Chinese food. Real thai food smells funky just like any other real Southeast asian cuisine with Fish sauce being the offender. We've ordered deliver 5 times now and every time, it's been awesome. Pad Kee Mow, Prawn Papaya salad, Beef Salad, Grilled prawn salad, Yum Nuer. All tasty.

Lastly Peking Duck is a Chinese dish. Please don't call a Thai joint for Chinese food and then to have the nerve to bitch about not wanting to look at their menu. You sound like a dumbass to, Brian G. You might as well bitch about how Lers Ros doesn't have Bangers and Mash or Shrimp Po Boys.
author: Andy L.

description:
Very satisfied. I went with a party of 15 and we were given proper attention. The servers seemed patient when we took a long time to order. 

We ordered the whole zoo: rabbit, venison, crocodile. They were all fun to experiment with, but they were all generally pretty chewy, and I don't know if I would order it again. But I mean it's not every day you eat that stuff so it was worth it. 

I guess the worst part was that the plates were huge and barely fit on the table, but that's not so bad.

Everything else looked tasty and authentic. I'd go again.
author: Justin D.

description:
Delivery took an hour, taking longer than places clear over in Chinatown. Wow. That kills one star.

Otherwise the food was very tasty. The tom yum soup was very powerful, maybe a bit too tangy, but spicy enough. The green curry was rich and full of veggies. The spicy tofu was good, but nothing to call your mom about.
author: Mark F.

description: Food was very tasty.  Didn't think the portions were that big and certainly not huge as a reviewer mentioned below.  Tried the alligator with chili sauce and the red chicken curry and both had lots of great flavor
author: Ken Y.

description:
So where oh where could one find some decent Thai in the city by the bay? Well, thanks to the almighty power of Yelp the Dynamic Duo of J. Drew decided to hit a popular choice, Lers Ros Thai. In a nutshell (how did I get into this nutshell?) we thoroughly enjoyed what Lers Ros had to offer. Quite flavorful and boldly spiced, both dishes were spot on and we will definitely return. 

The place was packed upon our arrival with a young, hip crowd present in the dining room (BTW, where do the old farts dine in San Fran?). We quickly were seated at the last available table and tried to make some sense of the immense number of choices available. If you are adventurous they do offer quail, boar and frog. (Pass, pass and um, yeah pass).

The beautiful J. of our tandem went with # 76, Pad Kee Mow with zero meat, all veggies. (She is a vegetarian after all, well except for bacon, pork carnitas and all forms of hamburgers). She loved it and devoured her dish with great aplomb. She ordered it medium spicy and reported it as being perfectly spiced. Her cleared out sinuses have never been happier! 

Myself, I went with the #114, the whole fried tilapia. I saw a few other diners had ordered it and it certainly looked divine. It was indeed ripe with divinity and enormous in size! My tilapia was just slightly smaller than a large pizza. Either that or in a tragic accident they actually caught Charlie the Tuna the mascot for StarKist and fileted the poor bastard. Regardless it was very good but the secret ingredient that totally kicked it over the top was the Chili sauce that came on the side. It was awesome! It looked good, smelled great and tasted even better. I think it would be the perfect companion for any food : nachos, popcorn or tilapia. It made the dish and gets the highest possible recommendation. After the meal both of our noses were running faster than a scalded dog. In a good way!!!

Service was very good and efficient. Our waitress took good care of us despite having to work with a huge party of 15 hot twenty-somethings (Wassup Rose K.) And to top it all off the place was pretty damn cheap. Two meals for under $25, in San Fran???

Rock on wich yer bad self, Lers Ros Thai!
author: Drew M.

description: Tom Yum Pak and Yellow Curry are best in the city
author: Verdi E.

description: I highly recommend this place to anyone.  The food is so good...it practically melts in your mouth.  I am so amazed on how good this place is...and how easily accessible the parking is.  I was so surprised on how great the food taste.  This place has awesome lunch specials and all the selections are a must.  I heard the pork belly is super good. I definitely would love coming back here when I'm in SF.
author: Karissa B.

description:
WOW, this place is awesome! One of the first stops in my new 'hood--I was intrigued because the sign outside is basically only in Thai (OK the English is there too, but the Thai is much more prominently displayed) and I had seen Thai-looking people speaking Thai coming in and out every time I passed, and that's all gotta be a good sign, right? RIGHT!  

We were sat at the bar right away walking in on a Friday night and decided to eat there rather than wait for the table. I was immediately impressed with the menu--Alligator, Venison, Frog--hello? I love unusual menus and this was by far one of the most unusual I've seen in an American setting. However, they have "regular" dishes too. We had:

Thai Curry Puffs (recommended by our server) --YUM. Seriously one of my favorite things I've had.

Crispy Pork Belly (don't remember the full name) - My companion liked this better than me--in fact he LOVED it and was raving about it for days. The pork was indeed crispy. 

That was it--it all tasted extremely fresh and was definitely some of the best Thai food I've ever had. 

Also unlike another reviewer, I actually loved the ambiance. Kind of hip and urban feeling--like a late night bar in Bangkok--and the place was FULL of Thai people! Also the prices are very reasonable.

I will definitely be back for some of the more unusual dishes. Man, this street is such a wonderful hidden gem....
author: Jille E.

description:
I came here last night after a short night at Holy Cow. I left for Holy Cow RIGHT after getting off of work... needless to say, I was starving the whole night. I was suffering and I kept thinking about food while my drunk buddies were drinking their lives away. I somehow convinced them to leave Holy Cow and join me in a food adventure. :)

My buddy yelped "Thai" and with Yelp's handy-dandy "Open Now" option...we found Lers Ros. Lers Ros is nestled in such a shady area. I'm not from SF, but I know how TL gets down. Right when we parked our car, a bum approached my friend and said, "Gimme $2 and I'll watch your car... I been getting $2 all night!" My buddy says, "Nah, it's cool. We got it, but thanks." THE BUM THEN SAYS, "GIMME $2 AND I WON'T BREAK INTO YOUR CAR." My buddy says, "Damn, here's a dollar... it's all I got." The bum then takes the dollar and shouts out... 'I'M GONNA BREAK INTO YOUR CAR" and walks away. Oh, and he took the dollar.

Okay, now for the food review...

We ordered: 

Pad Thai: SUPER freakin' flavorful, but really on the salty side. Pad Thai doesn't need explanation. Almost everyone I know knows what Pad Thai is.

Pad Kee Mow: Same as the pad thai. Full of flavor, but leaning towards the super salty side. The menu didn't indicate that it would be spicy, however the Pad Kee Mow had quite a kick to it.

5 Spice Duck over rice: I didn't get a chance to try this, however my buddy ordered this and seemed to really enjoy it.

Red Curry: Bleh. I was really unimpressed with this dish. The vegetables were still hard as if they were undercooked. 

The portions here are also really small, however the prices of the dishes here are low so you're really getting what you're paying for. Also, the lady who was helping us (Oct. 9th at 1am) wasn't as friendly as I wanted her to be.
author: Lena L.

description:
DEE-LICIOUS! much thanks to jeremy h. below for the enthusiastic recommendation of lers ros, his (and now our) favorite thai place in the city! the menu selection here is crazy--they've got everything from the standards to more exotic things like venison and rabbit.

i am head over heels in love with the five spice stewed pork leg... how is it that they can make it so tender and delicious and still bring it out to your table in record time? the papaya salad and duck larb were also great... very spicy too so be careful! other yummy dishes we had included the SPICY green curry with real fish paste, rad na, and crispy chicken over fried rice (which was excellent!). will definitely go back in a heartbeat!
author: Andrey C.

description:
Great first impression- Their menu is gigantic! 

We dropped in here the other day for late lunch around 3- the place was practically empty. Both of us ordered from their generous lunch menu- two small entrees of your choice with salad and rice for $8- so that we could have a taste of four dishes. This turned out to be way more food than I needed. 

Salad= lettuce with sweet vinegar dressing
Yellow curry was tasty
Chicken skewers were tasty
Veggies in peanut sauce was tasty
Stir fried pork was my favorite.

The sauces were all pleasantly more spicy than I've become used to- which was great! 

My friend approved of the clean, cold, all-tiled restaurant interior and reminisced about meals she'd had in Thailand. The service was attentive but a little slow, which I attributed to the time of day. 

I'll be back for more.
author: A S.

description:
yummy rabbit, alligator and frog on the menu. definitely coming back. 

It's located in scary neighborhood so I had to make sure I had to male buddies with me whenever venturing in the TL. this time we there were blocks roped off by the cops. nice!
author: Chris M.

description: Most authentic delicious affordable thai I've had in the city. Can't wait to go back!
author: Ben J.

description: Beware, if you like cleanliness! Their restrooms are mighty filthy, with either no liquid soap or no paper towels! Utterly disgusting!! Their whole space is not really clean. Their food is OK, but not great. Not cozy, the ambiance is more that of an eat-fast-and-leave joint. All this is enough to take two or three stars off their rating! For goodness sake, restaurants in SF should all be impeccable!! At least, they all should have decent restrooms. This city is filthy, indeed; I need to go somewhere else.
author: Raymond F.

description:
Really excited to try this place. It seems like a lot of the hype about this place comes from the numerous non-traditional Thai items on the menu, rather than the acutal quality of the food itself.

Got the crispy pork belly, which, while was very good itself, needed more flavor in the dish.

My friend got the green papaya salad, which was inedibly spicy, and once you got past the spiciness, all you tasted was fish sauce. He also said he wanted to add chicken to the salad, so they gave him two obscenely large pieces with it.

I guess I'll go to Thai House Express next time, which, even still, isn't great.
author: Mark A.

description:
Was in on Sunday evening on June 9th.  Food was fair and nothing extraordinary and have had better Thai around the city. 

I would give it 3 stars but our server was not very friendly and rushed us to get out.
author: J W.

description: Had the grilled pork shoulder appetizer with spicy rice powder condiment; meat was nicely cooked but absent the needed char. Also had the green curry pork; it was very plain because they left out the eggplant, which they denied at first, then brought me a small dish with 5 pieces to add to my dish (very poor, and a small portion overall). Their prices have increased considerably over the last 2 years...it's now over-rated. Had an impressive meal at Pagan in the Outer Richmond, will try them again soon
author: Andrew H.

description: The Hayes Valley location is so much better & nicer, I am surprised to see that this one has higher ratings.  So I always get the same dish and substitute prawns with chicken.  At the other location which by the way I go every week,  its not a problem.  At this one, the chef just wont do it.  I can't understand what the big deal is, so I most likely wont be back to this one unless they decide to someday make an exception.  It's a little more convenient for me to come here because its close to my job, and sometimes after work I just want my thai food, but nope!  Not gonna do it.
author: Coraly S.

description: Papaya salad is amazing. Noodles are decent. Tilapia is fantastic. Great service.
author: Jordan R.

description: What was I thinking with a 3 star review?!  I'll admit, I was being a tg... this place is definitely four stars- a go to, late night, quality thai delivery place.  Yeah, the portions may not be as big as other places, but the quality of food easily makes up for it.  I probably wrote that last review after I finished my food and was still hungry---- :/
author: Clarissa P.

description: The food here was delicious and so reasonably priced!! We had a 7.45pm reservation but I'm not sure reservations mean that much when the place is as busy as it was.  We managed to get two seats at the bar by 8pm so it wasn't bad at all.  My friend and I shared the vegetarian spicy tofu and vegetarian green curry. The portion of rice was huge! We ended up taking a lot home because the portions were so generous. The restaurant was quite noisy (it was a Friday night) so not the place if you want a quiet evening, but definitely a great place to catch up with friends and eat yummy food! I loved the proverbs all around the walls. A great touch.
author: P G.

description: Had the pad see ew with seafood and the eggplant. Also the garlic and ginger rice. Not bad, but the noodles were extra greasy. Great service!
author: Maximillian M.

description: Best thai place Ive been to in the city and great birthday dinner :) Totally worth the walk through the tenderloin.
author: Christy D.

description: The culinary highlight of our recent trip to SF.  Best Thai we've had--the pork belly was transcendent!
author: Nicole A.

description: Great Thai food, the whole fish was very well done.  Plenty of yellow ginger and lemongrass, both is costly in the US.  Many restaurants we find skimp on them.  The best place we have found in SoCal and NorCal.  The whole sea-bass was very nice they made it the level of spicy we wanted.  Plus, they did not make the dishes overly sweet.  This was the best Thai food we have had since we went to Bangkok.
author: Don F.

description: I had a lunch special for $8.95. You get a choice of two items, white or brown rice, and a small salad. It's a good value. I had special "I - Kai Yang" (BBQ marinated chicken with sweet chili sauce on the side) and "O - Pad Spinach" (stir-fried spinach in bean sauce). Both were very good. Service was speedy and the staff was very attentive (I don't think the level of water in my glass ever fell below an inch before it was refilled). I'd go back.
author: Paul L.

description:
Lers Ros Thai serves up Thai food that is as authentic as it gets up here in the Bay Area.  I have been exposed to authentic Thai food, from Thai Town in Los Angeles to the Thai Wats throughout California. Every time I go there to eat it's like an adventure,which you can always count on being a great one

Nestled in the Tenderloin, Lers Ros Thai lives up to the saying how some of the best Southeast Asian Foods come from the "Loin".  Having a meal during the day you see a lot of Thai Natives, mostly students, and at night you would see the same type of students with the addition of chefs/servers from "OTHER" Thai Restaurants.  Now that tells you something doesn't it?  For sure.  The food is so good there.

Some of my favs:

Kor Moo Yang (Grilled Pork Neck/Shoulder) is a MUST.  
Pa Ped Moo Ba (Wild Boar cooked fresh green peppercorn) is so deliciously exotic.
Yum Pla Dook Foo (Fried Catfish Salad) will blow away your tastes buds as you try to figure out where the fish is.
From time to time they will have some authentic kanoms (desserts).

There is so much more to order, but you can't go wrong trying anything on the menu.  I guarantee you'll have fun in mapping out your own meal.  Enjoy!!!
author: Timothy W.

description:
FINALLY, a Thai place in SF I can really recommend!

A caveat: this is based on a limited selection of dishes, and some heavy recommendations from friends.  However, two of these dishes blew me away.  I just kept saying: "Wow. Wow. Wow."  And this was because they tasted like dishes you would have in Bangkok, at really good places.

So far I've had 6 dishes:

1) Kha Nah Moo Krob.  Confusingly, they put this on the menu under "Rice Soup."  Unappetizingly, they call it Stir-Fired Pork with Crispy Rind.  But it's awesome -- the fatback pork is freshly fried to perfection, the chinese broccoli (that's the "kha nah") is fleshy with perfectly peeled stems, and the sauce is not just seriously umami -- it's also spiced in a way only confident Thai cooks will dare.  My friend says she gets this dish every time she goes, and I can see why.

2) Kao Kha Moo.  Officially, this is whole stewed pig leg on rice, but if you can find it at all in the US, it's generally a pleasantly spiced simmered pork chopped into small pieces. (The flavor is a mixture of star anise and five spice, I believe.)  Here, though, it's a real piece of pork leg, slowly cooked in a five-spice mixture until fork tender (yes, it's Thai, you can use forks) -- and the kicker is the big layer of brown rendered skin with it.  It's soft and collageny and yummy... reminding me of hot evenings at the night market at Soi Thonglor.  And there was a lot of it.  (No hard boiled egg, which is normally standard, but I don't give a rat's ass about egg.  Fat is where it's at.)

3) Koh Moo Yang.  This is grilled side of pork, very simple, with a spicy sauce that reminds me of that perfect sauce made by a Thai lady who used to grill chicken on top of the klong (from a cart perched on a large plywood board over an open sewer.)   This is an excellent and brutal dish, hotter than most things you will ever eat in US Thai restaurants.

(A tip to all of you: "moo" means pig/pork. Yes, it's confusing to Muslims. Anyway, I think these guys know pork. Look for the "moo.")

4) Pad See You.  The standard classic with pan-fried wide rice noodles, meat, egg, and a green vegetable -- Chinese broccoli in this case.  This was good rendition -- fairly "burny" -- but not as good as Thai Noodles.  The pork, however, was very tender, which reminded me of Bangkok.  I don't know what they do to the meat (maybe I don't want to know), but it took me back.

5) Radna.  This dish (the simpler, weirder sister of Pad See You) is composed of a wide, chow-fun style rice noodle, stir fried with pork and chinese broccoli, and covered with a kind of gravy.  I've generally found that it is impossible to get a good version of this dish in the US -- usually the meat is overtough and the gravy is thin and insipid.  Sadly, I still remain unsatisfied -- while the meat was tender, the gravy had the usual problems.  On the other hand, there are two awesome dishes just waiting for you.

6) Pad Ka Prao Krung Nai Gai.  This is basil stir fry with chicken entrails (gizzards, livers, etc.).  A very bold, spicy dish, but unfortunately, you almost never get real, licoricey Thai basil in the US -- and you still don't here.   However, this one is about as fierce and chewy (mmm, entrails) as you will ever get in the US.  Throw a little sugar or vinegar on to mellow this one out.

So the top 3 dishes both whipped the pants off my usual fave, Thai Noodle -- and the others were quite authentic too.  So San Franziskaners: forget Osha, Thep Phanom, and all those other places, and go here.  It's cheap and the menu is huge, with things I've never seen outside of Thailand. Oh, and they have one of the best selections of availabe condiments I've seen in a restaurant here.

See you there!

To see my other Thai food reviews, see my Thai Food list here:
http://www.yelp.com/list_details?list_id=9hnaS-bdeM5uKzKSgGBAOg
author: Daniel S.

description:
Best Thai in the city; and very affordable for the quality and standard of Thai food. There's nothing 'fusion' or fancy about this legit place in the Tenderloin
It's my go-to place and i've been there countless times; below is a quick summary of my faves

Summary:
- Fish Cake- good, juicy but fairly normal. nothing spectacular
- Pad Thai- a tad better than Most pad thai i've had in this country. definitely fried with tamarind and NOT ketchup (thank you). but it was little too sweet for my liking
- Fried Garlic Frog- yummy; sorry to say it tasted like chicken, but it really did. it was deep fried, garlicky...but the only thing that was a little  awkward to maneuver was the little bone in the middle of the chopped pieces
- Crispy Chicken on Fried Rice- YUMMY. the chicken was delish and the fried rice was pretty standard, but in a good way
- Stewed Pork- I've never had this before, and i was cautious...but it was very tasty; sweet and fell right off the bone
- Rad Nah- OMG. SO good. had a great wok-fried taste to it; tasted like authentic street food in Southeast Asia. YUM YUM. Still dreaming about it
- Pad See Ew- Very tasty dish; we had it with shrimp, which was great. Flavorful, again, great wok-fried flavor and done perfectly
- Red Curry with Roasted Duck- YUMMY. Very flavorful, roasted duck was so good
- Larb with Roasted Duck- Wow. Best larb i've ever had. i've always had mediocre and much-too-salty larb; this larb was So juicy, flavorful and just plain yummy
- Green Papaya Salad with Salted Egg yolk- I had a small portion of it since everyone had Inhaled it right away; but the slivers i got were very tasty
- Thai Iced Coffee- fairly standard, not too sweet. Good
- Crispy Pork Belly: Absolutely delicious

Super efficient; you can get in and out of this place in less than 30 mins for a full meal
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I went to dinner with my aunt and her friend. My aunt is a really picky eater and she ate everything we ordered. We started with the roast duck salad, followed by the spicy pork belly and the whole tilapia. Everything was yummy and everyone cleaned their plates. Enough said....
author: Yoon P.

description:
Right now I feel like I cheated on my usual favorite neighborhood Thai restaurant Thai House Express. Most of the time when I'm craving Thai, Thai House Express is where I go. The last time I went and walked past Lers Ros Thai, it was packed! I made a mental note to try it out. 
One Thai craving later, I ended up here. First things first- the decor and atmosphere. It was kind of early for dinner (5:30pm) so there were only 2 other tables occupied. The furniture was meh and it kind of smelled funny. Funny smell aside, I was hungry and ready to let my eyes do their thing and scan the menu. I had read about the pork with crispy edges but the green seafood curry caught my eye and made my stomach tingle with delight. The bf ordered crispy chicken over fried rice and we shared a chicken satay appetizer. 

Appetizer- 4 pieces of yummy chicken, peanut sauce and cucumbers with red onion. Really good altogether. 

Green seafood curry- surprisingly big. No rice and kind of spicy so I had to order a side of rice (which is really a container of rice, like 2 servings). It included squid, prawns, bamboo, bell peppers, basil and fish balls in a deliciously fragrant and flavorful green curry. Yum! I couldn't finish it all so I took it home and it will get in my tummy tomorrow for lunch. 

Crispy chicken over fried rice- ok portion of strips of crispy chicken with sweet & sour sauce (bravo on the sauce!) over fried rice. Pretty darn good! The bf saved some peanut sauce to pour over his rice... so smart, that one. 

Service- above average. She was very attentive and I didn't have to search long to find her when I needed something. 

Drinks- an unusually large variety of alcohol! They served reds, whites, sakes. They also have a bar despite their small size.

A note about the menu that a few of the other Yelpers have already mentioned but I will echo- the menu is definitely more adventurous than usual Thai restaurants. There are the usual pad thai, pad kee mow but I also saw alligator over  fried rice and frog leg appetizers. 

So... definitely worth trying, especially if you've done the Thai thing more than a couple times in the neighborhood.
author: Amanda W.

description: Ler Ros Thai serves up authentic dishes and offers an expansive menu.  I consider it to be one of the better Thai options in the TL.  In contrast to the nearby Osha Thai location which consists of more Americanized dishes, Le Ros has a combination the usual Thai staples as well as the more obscure dishes that you normally won't find.  If your craving Thai food, Ler Ros is a great choice.
author: Wei K.

description:
I've never actually stepped foot in this restaurant even though its just blocks away from my house. I'm a habitual user of their free delivery service (don't judge me, its hard to get dressed & go out for food when there's an SVU marathon). 

It's always kind of like playing roulette when I order because there's so much crap on the menu! Many of the items are pretty unique & things I've never heard of, so it makes experimentation pretty fun. 

Stand-out dishes for me were: tom yum soup, fried rice, larb & pork belly. I would skip on the rad-nah, grilled meatballs & marinated barbecue chicken (boring). The pad see ew is just okay. I don't know if its different for dining in, but I feel like the delivery portions are a little bit skimpy. The delivery boxes are the smaller kind & even then, my pad see ew order didn't quite fill the box even half-way. & for larb & sliced sirloin beef orders, the meat portion can fit into a small rice bowl, so it comes with a huge wedge of cabbage takes up most of the space. 

Delivery can be really slow sometimes (up to an hour & a half!), but I really like the food & prices.
author: Ruby H.

description: Enjoyed our meal .  Brown rice was nutty and rich to compliment the curry. Flavors were great and pad Thai with tofu yummy.
author: Liz V.

description:
Larkin Street is where it's at.
Some of the best Southeast Asian eateries are in the 'loin and Lers Ros Thai is definitely up there. I'm by no means a hardcore Thai critic nor have the taste for "extremely" exotic ingredients, but I've eaten at enough Thai places to know what's good and what's not.

At a glance, I liked how this place is cleaner and larger than some of the tenderloin eateries and the servers were all very friendly.

Now, the food-
Pad Thai (no ketchup B.S.)
Curry puff thingies -kinda like samosas (this appetizer was my favorite) 
Pork belly -OK, sorry, I ate 2 bites and gave up...it was NOT succulent and it had a flavor that I just do not like. Next time, I should try Koh Moo Yang instead. 
Papaya salad -Really good, but next time I'll order it without the salted egg. 

I'll definitely be back to try some other things.

p.s. I hope you like Hall and Oats type music...it's all about the soft, adult contemporary sailing music here.
author: Aya C.

description:
Via the fabulous Yelp iPhone app, my friend and I found this place as a likely lunch joint. Neither of us are familiar with San Francisco, and as we were walking I realized we were heading straight through the Tenderloin District. A little shady but not so different from Boston's Chinatown so we kept on walking and almost walked past Lers Ros.

Lers Ros is a slick modern place with a cafeteria-style feel to it, with tile on the floor and black plastic and chrome chairs and  tables. The menu is chockful with tasty Thai treats that we hardly knew what to order. We settled on sharing the Pad See Ew and the red curry with duck and pineapple. Note: rice does not come included in the price of curry but is an extra $3. That being said, it was a super-generous serving of rice, plenty enough for the two of us to soak up all the delish curry sauce. The food was well were generous portions; the curry was extremely flavorful and I enjoyed the duck, though there were a few too many hunks of fat. The Pad See Ew was a savory combo of noodles and vegetables, a solid comfort dish. We left completely satisfied, and waddled back through the Tenderloin contentedly.

Oh, and it only cost like $30. Amaaazing.
author: Calli C.

description:
I came here a few days ago with friends because we were about to go movies at AMC and needed to eat asap and we decided to come here. It was around 4pm and we came here for an early dinner or late lunch. 

The ladies that were working here are nice and attentive. I ordered the pad thai with beef along with a Thai iced-tea. The pad thai was priced at $7.50 which is pretty reasonable. But I was disappointed at the serving size ]: Half my plate was pad thai and the bigger half of the plate was just bean sprouts! Waaaaaah! I want more noodles and what not more than just raw bean sprouts...

The Thai iced tea was normal, I asked if I could take the rest to-go and they put it in a to-go cup for me! But the serving size is kinda small for my taste. I've had better pad thai ! Maybe if I was eating here in the nighttime it would be more fun since it was so packed at night and the place was dimly lit!
author: Alice Z.

description: Really good experience here overall - great food and great delivery.  They took my small order and didn't mention anything about a minimum.  They mentioned that it would take 45 minutes to an hour (totally reasonable), but it ended up taking less than 30 minutes - amazing!  My order was still almost too hot to eat, it was so fresh.  I ordered the pad see ew which was good (good balance of all ingredients) and not too greasy.  I also go an order of the fried rolls which were good and had a bit of a spicy kick.  I will definitely be ordering from Lers Ros again!
author: Shirley B.

description:
Hot damn, this place is good.

I've ordered Thai food here 4 times in the last 3 weeks for delivery.  It may cause me to grow my hair out long and become a recluse.

It seems to keep getting better every time I order from here.  Also, they make it SPICY. Not fake American spicy.  They will make it Thai spicy if you ask.

My favorite menu item this week is the Larb Kai (spicy chicken salad). Light, spicy, crisp.  Delicious.  

I'm hooked.
author: Sean L.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE.  It is hands down one of the most authentic Thai restaurants I've ever been to.  I think it even had my restaurant (when I had it) beat.  I could learn a thing or two.

4 stars:  Clams, Pork leg, Papaya Salad, Pad Thai, Fried trout, Thai Iced Coffee
3 stars:  Sausage links, Pork shoulder, Fried chicken over rice, 
2 stars:  dessert

I had to wait over an hour for a table of 5.  Super crowded fast.  Best times are before 5 and after 10.  It stays open until midnight, delivery ends at 10.
author: Walerz B.

description:
Four stars for the great food, another one for unusual selections on the menu (not your typical Californian Thai). 

We came to Lers Ros because our friend, Leslie told us, "there's this hole in the wall place, kinda ghetto, but the food's awesome, this is where Thai people go..." well, before head in, I had this image of a "ghetto restaurant' in T-district of SF, which is TOTALLY not the case. 

You can't call a restaurant with beer & wine selection like theirs (not massive, but come on, we are not in a French or Italian restaurant) and TWO flat screen TV a ghetto place. The dinning room is clean, contemporary and easy to fit large party. 

Menu items include all the standard and typical things you expected, plus some exotic selections like venison, alligator, frog and such. There's also a section of "rice soup" with tapa like dishes, which is similar to Chinese congee except the dishes are flavored in yummy lime, chili and peanuts. I would recommend you try that at least once for the experience. 

Parking is actually not a big problem for me there since there are small st like Olive? (or Olivia) which I can always find parking, just make sure you bring enough quarters with you. 

Service is decent, but not great, is what you kind of expected in the Asian restaurant. The plus side? they open until 2AM every night!!!!
author: Alice L.

description:
I cam here twice.  It's great at night and is very bad in the afternoon.
At night, I don't like Thai food, but I like this restaurant.  It really good.
Papaya salad is papaya salad.  Good.
Garlic quail is delicious.  Very little meat, but very tasty.
Fried chicken fried rice is good.  Pretty much the best fried rice I've had at a Thai restaurant.
Pad Thai is better than most Pad Thai I've had. 
Tom yum soup is pretty much the best I've had.
Steamed sea bass is good.  The meat is a little over stiff, but the taste of the soup is very complex.  Sweet, sour, and spicy.  They put a lot of ingredients in there.
In the afternoon after I was duped by the great experience at night..
I ordered chicken pad thai and pad khed pork rice plate. The chicken was very dry and hard!  The pork was all fat and old meat.  This food is destined for the landfill.  The spice is good, but there's not much worse than eating old fatty meat.
author: Byron L.

description: I have been here TWICE in Three DAYS!  lol... I ordered the whole deep fried tilapia fish.  OH-MM-GEE.  It is almost like the real deal in Thailand, except the sauce is on the fish rather than the side.  Doesn't matter to me though... I love it just the way it is!  My parents have lived in Thailand for the past 5 years - they just recently came back and I can't wait to take them here (of course once they're ready to have Thai again!)
author: Noneya B.

description: I went here with group of friends. The service was ok. One of our orders came 1st and 10 min later the rest...that was odd.  I don't know how they manage the kitchen. Also I didn't really taste any spices. I like my Thai food spicy and it wasn't. But I would go here to try something else, since I didn't get sick the next day.....
author: Paolo D.

description: I don't know about y'all, but I'm loving their Pad Kee Mow. It's really spicy! At first glance, it looked like regular pan-fried flat noodles but once I took a bite of it, an explosion of heat fired up in my mouth. I shrugged it off as nothing and continued to eat but the more I ate, the spicier it got! I've got to say, I'm impressed because this is what I'm talking about -- spicy thai food! And the thai ice tea looked very eye-appealing. I could actually taste the tea, which is the point of thai ice tea, am I correct? I also like how they offer a lunch menu where you can chose two dishes (rice and salad included). I tried some of the fried tofu and it was very crunchy. The ambiance was enjoyable, seeing as the restaurant was halfway filled. I love how Lers Ros looks so modern and chic but homey at the same time. The service was somewhat quick but I was glad the Olympics was on to distract me. The prices are so-so but the food is tasty!
author: Vicky P.

description:
Ler Ros Thai is a nice place to grab a quick fix but I wouldn't say it's the best in SF. 
Visited this place because of all the great reviews on yelp. Sadly this place lacks 5 stars that a lot of people gave it.
The staff was nice and the inside of the restaurant was clean but the food was as good as any other "whatever" Thai place. Had the pad se ew with beef and it was Meh. Friend had the cocoanut soup & that was good. The mushroom in the soup was crunchy which was strange. 
Idk, if you are looking for amazing Thai and you actually know what amazing Thai taste like then this is not the place.  If your looking for a nice Thai place then this will do the trick.
author: S.M. W.

description: I love this place and especially love this spicy brothy beef noodle soup (no.69). It has greens, garlic, beam sprouts and beef balls in it.
author: Emm C.

description: Open late...Duck Laub is the business. Good flavor, great spice....Papaya salad is one of the best I've had. Made with fish sauce, and sweet penuts, and the spice is kickin. Love it!.... Pad Thai was good flavor, could have been more so, but was quality. I higly suggest any one of these dishes and go home a happy diner!
author: Brandon Z.

description:
In general I like Thai food, but I LOVE the Thai food from here. I dined with a party of 15 and we ordered over 20 dishes, so I tried a lot of their expansive menu. 

The highlights were... 
#4: Thai Sausage, the most unique sausage I've ever had, very light and fresh tasting. 
#62: Thai style pork belly, crispy rind and succulent meat 
#112: Whole Steamed Sea Bass: strong lemongrass flavor, fresh and the meat, literally melts in your mouth 
#114: Whole Fried Tilapia: It's the opposite of the steamed fish, but just as delicious, crispy and spicy.
author: Rose K.

description:
Lers Ros Thai came highly recommended from a friend, so we checked out this Larkin Street establishment one Saturday evening before heading over to the AMC theatre on Van Ness to catch a movie.

I was actually quite impressed with this place.  The interior of the restaurant is very simple; it's a long, narrow space with some long tables down the middle and smaller tables to the side.  Our group of 7 was able to sit all together in the middle of the room.  

The food really spoke for itself. The menu was very wide-ranging, and a lot larger than what I'm used to seeing at thai restaurants.  With entrees that incorporated alligator and rabbit, it definitely appeared that the chefs were experienced and knew what they were doing.  I stayed away from anything too exotic, choosing the garlic and ginger rice and crispy chicken.  The rice was very flavorful and the crispy chicken was perfectly cooked, very crispy on the outside but moist and delicious on the inside.  I also had some brown rice on the side which was quite good.

The portions were very generous, the service good, and the prices reasonable.  I'll definitely be back the next time I'm looking for some quality Thai food downtown.
author: Tim N.

description:
I'm upgrading Lers Ros back to 5 stars. I came here with another large group (7) on a Saturday night and the service was fine. 

Of course, the food was delicious as usual. I also found another dish to add to my growing list of favourites. The steamed sea bass was ridiculously good, almost melt in the mouth texture, and the chilli/lime was delicious.

My friends also really liked the Thai sausage and the yellow curry, which I thought were just OK.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
Lers Ros is my new addiction, I've been ordering deliveries from LR for weeks now, and i think I'm about to max out my credit card from doing it.
LR has the best meat ever, esp. their pork shoulder is my must have item every time i went there. Their pan fried items are great, you know some of the places their pan fried stuff is either not enough flavor or just too much? LR has theirs just right with a ingeniously hint of "burnt", the good kind of burnt of course. The portion are great and the price are reasonable. If you really want me to pick something bad to say about LR, I'd say, the only bad thing is I have no idea how to pronounce their name correctly :)
author: Bruce L.

description: Atmosphere could use a bit of a tune up but the food was amazing and all of the waitresses are very nice and friendly!
author: Patrick B.

description:
I love this place. Best Thai food in the city, and one of the places that makes me miss living in San Francisco.

Aside from the food, the service is always friendly, prompt and helpful, and they've always been very accommodating to special requests. The dining room is beautiful and worthy of a date night.
author: Danielle W.

description:
Bangin'. Best Thai food I've ever had. 

Don't sleep on:
Duck larb
Pork belly
Steamed whole fish
Chicken with garlic and ginger rice
Chicken noodle soup

Sleep on:
Meatballs (sorry, Asians, you guys make weird/bad meatballs compared to the Italians)
Fried whole fish (too fried, overcooked).
author: Max B.

description: The lunch specials here are great! I love the combo, totally affordable.  Service can be kind of terrible, but the food is good.
author: Samantha C.

description:
This is one of my top 3 Thai restaurant in the city.  I hesitated to try this place for a while because of the area.  However, I keep coming back since I tried first time 5 months ago.  

My favorite dish is Pad Kee Mao.  I always order Pad Kee Mao at any Thai restaurant.  This place has the best in the SF and South bay.  The noodle is always seasoned perfectly, not too spicy yet not too mild, just perfect.

Another favorite item is Pla Rad Prik which is Fried Tilapia.  This is slightly greacy, but highly recommended for fish lover.
author: Suki K.

description: ...first time...will definitely go back...food, service, and decor all working...
author: Bob L.

description:
Glad we came here on a friend's recommendation.  Dinner for 4 cost $60 including tip.  Overall we enjoyed the food very much. It's as authentic as we can get outside LA.  :-)  

We ordered crab fried rice and chicken satay for the kids. Wife had kuay teaw rea and (boat beef noodle soup), I had crispy pork stir fried with Chinese gailan (Chinese brocolli) and kang som cha-om tod (sour fish curry with cha-om fried with eggs dipped in the curry). Cha-om is a vegetable common to Southeast Asia. I believe it is frozen then exported to the US since it can't be grown here.  It is authentic. 

Parking can be a problem but if you overcome that you will enjoy the food. We will be back again. Although not late night since as with any place in SF, lots of homeless. They scare the kids.

Hope this is helpful.
author: Prat P.

description: YIKES! We came here because of all the positive yelp reviews. The poor service was the least of our disappointment.  I ordered vegetarian pad woon sen spicy #8.  When I got it, it was FILLED with eggs. I tried to pick them out but they literally sauteed the noodles with it. I did return it which is extreme for me but it taste and smelled like eggs.  She gave an attitude about it and brought me a new one which was no longer pad woon sen; it was steamed veggies with but clear noodles...Cold!!  They never came back to ask how it was ans we finally just paid and left. Never again!
author: JJ R.

description: Great food and the service was by far the best for any Asian style restaurant  I have ever been too. Great wine selection and the sticky rice with mango is a must try. Minus 1 star only because the food was incredibly spicy despite asking it not be. Clean restaurant too
author: Jack L.

description: I don't know where to start describing how good this place is.  Five stars.  I went with three Thai friends and all of them attest to how good the food is.  The place serves up very authentic dishes that you may not see very often outside of Thailand.  The crispy catfish salad is a must and a dish that I have only seen in Bangkok.  I have tried a range of dishes from the friend fish to the sautéed Chinese broccoli with pork belly.  The stir fried noodles also have a nice carmelization on the outside which is a sign that they have a really hot burner in the kitchen and they didn't rush the cooking.  All of the dishes all had a very nice balance of crispiness of texture with sweet, salty and sour flavors layered in.  They also deliver a good amount of heat with the dish.  I could say so much more about this place, but everything that I had was executed just right.
author: Scott C.

description: I'm way too wimpy to have anything beyond their "mild" level of spiciness. But I'm way too addicted to stop returning. And, hello, a place that has the balls to serve awesome steamed fish? I'm hooked.
author: Aiko S.

description:
Authentic spices.
Helpful servers.
Delicious food.

On Monday, July 6, I went here with a group of friends for my birthday and everyone enjoyed their meals. Since I had a chance to sample a lot of my friends' dishes, my favorite dish, although arduous to eat due to tiny bones, was the eel special.
