description: Highly recommended among native Thai and locals alike. It gets busy so make sure your party is on the ball. Having lived in Thailand for six years, I can't recall a place where I'm happy with everything.
author: Mark O.

description:
3.5 stars.

This is probably one of the better Thai restaurants I've been to in the city, and these are the reasons why:

- great service: friendly, helpful and attentive.
- very reasonable prices.  I appreciate great Thai, but at the exorbitant prices some places charge these days, it doesn't make me a happy camper nor does it make me inclined to go out of my way to eat it (I don't live in a neighborhood that has particularly many Thai restaurants).  For the two of us, the total came out to about $30 for an appetizer and two entrees.
- DELICIOUS drunken noodles - you have to try them here as they have just the right amount of spice and the noodles are cooked well
- fast and efficient!  we came for dinner on a friday night and we were in and out of there in less than an hour.

I do have to say, however, that I was underwhelmed by the fried tofu app (flavorless without the accompanying sauce) and red curry entree (not spicy enough and not the greatest flavor) that we ordered.  I was also turned off by the fact that they charge $1.50 for a cup of tea.  Many other places I've been to give you free tea, even when you are getting food to go!!  However, like I said, the noodles were great and I'd come back here just for them.  We looked around at what other tables ordered and the veggie dishes looked really tasty so we'll probably order some of those next time.  But there are so many other items on the menu - I don't think you can go terribly wrong.
author: Kira K.

description:
Im really happy to see a new tasty Thai restaurant open up in my Hood!
Everything we ordered was so tasty - Big bonus for having Chang beer as well :) Some favorites were the crispy pork belly w basil, red curry, and the Fried whole Fish! mmmm..I am sure to come back and give the other entrees a shot.
author: Christian S.

description: I love thai food but this place is not high on my list. We tried several recommended items from Yelp. Nothing struck home. Won't be going back.
author: Cindy W.

description: I was very buzzed when we arrived, but I'm sure the food was as good as I remembered.  The pad thai was delish.  I wish I could remember the 3 other dishes we ordered...
author: brewgirl b.

description: Wonderful place to eat! And if you all haven't noticed...the Tenderloin is full of great restaurants! The restaurant is neatly decorated in red, maroon and black. Service was pretty quick. All the servers dressed in red shirts and black aprons. I had the fish cakes and the stir fried egg plant w/chicken and brown rice. Spicey and delicious and it hit the spot is all I can say!
author: Mike L.

description:
Tried a new-to-me item from the specials board, "Shrimp Paste," $16, which is similar to the prahok dish at Angkor Borei. A bowl of intense sauce made of chiles, shrimp paste, and who knows what is accompanied by sliced raw cucumbers and cooked broccoli, cabbage, bamboo shoot, acacia omelet (same as in #110), and two fried mackerel. If you like spicy fermented-fish stuff, you'll love this.

Also tried #96, stir-fried prawns with sweet and sour sauce, because I walked past a table that had it and it smelled fabulous. The shrimp were perfectly cooked and the balance of flavors was very good but the pineapple and tomatoes were canned--polished it off with gusto but I'd order something else next time.

Also got #20, squid salad, great version of this classic. I'm not sure if it was $7.25 and the prawns were $8 or vice-versa.

Best Thai food in the area, and open till 1:30am daily. The place was fairly full when we walked in around 10pm and people kept coming in.
author: Robert L.

description:
Food is fantastic and definitely for the more adventurous palate.  The crocodile is fantastic, tender and delicious.  The balance of the flavors is great each dish meats the, sour, sweet, spicy, flavours required in Thai cooking very well.  It gets quite busy at night and on weekends so lunch if you can is more recommended.  The service is prompt and non intrusive.  

The presentation on the dishes is lovely and they use some items that you rarely find outside of Thailand.  

It's difficult to do the restaurant justice without smell-o-vision or taste-o-vision.  If you enjoy Thai food and enjoy the more exotic offerings then Lers Ros is the place for you.
author: Lin C.

description: As the name means "Excellent tasty food".. it was actually written on the walls.. everything we order was wonderful.. we went with two lunch combos and one ala carte item.. the minced chicken does carry the nice smell and flavor.. red curry with shripm is good.. definitely going back..
author: Yugandhar P.

description: this is my go-to place to bring people for inexpensive non-traditional thai food. I love the pork shoulder appetizer. must visit.
author: Jeff Y.

description: Good music, good food. The pad Thai and curries were amazing - awesome hole in the wall location. Me and my friends being starving before finding it probably contributed
author: Louie L.

description:
This is definitely the best Thai restaurant I've been to. My Thai friend brought me here and ordered dishes that I'd never heard of; needless to say we didn't have pad Thai but I did hear it was quite tasty. 

We started off with the Thai sausage which was really tasty and I'm not even into sausage (don't go there!). The next appetizer we had blew my mind. It was the most tender juicy roasted pork (#9, I think) I've ever had. I threatened to eat the entire plate myself. The duck salad was quite good and definitely packed a punch. 

The fish cake yellow curry was super tasty and sweet. I must say that I loved the crispy pork belly with gai lan. Being Chinese, I've had my disproportionate share of dry nasty roasted pork belly in my day and this dish put it all to shame. The last time I had crispy pork belly this good was in Hong Kong. 

I can't wait to go back and try other things on the menu however it will be hard not to order the two pork dishes I love so much. Pig, what a magical animal.
author: Monica L.

description:
For me this is personally my favorite Thai joint that I have ever ordered from.  I agree with Brandon L. and if you are going to eat here you should step out of your comfort zone.  Don't order Pad Thai.  We had the pork belly, fried quail, and a soup the last time and everything was delicious.  The Mrs. likes Basil Canteen better, but I like Lers Ros.  

It is one of the few restaurants that has such an extensive menu you can go there once a week for a year and never have the same dish twice.  I also like the fact that they deliver.  The pork belly was the best that I have had since moving to SF the skin is crispy the fat is tender and the meat has just enough toothiness without being tough at all.

Great place.
author: Anthony Y.

description: Our fav spot for yummy Thai food! Our only problem is we dont know what else to order except crispy pork belly :P YUM!
author: Van W.

description: I've eaten here several times, awesome tasting food! The BEST cashew nut chicken dish that I've ever had at any Thai restaurant.
author: Omen N.

description: Outstanding service! We had red curry and  Moo Gratiem (Pork stir-fried with garlic) outstanding!
author: L C.

description:
I've got pretty high standards when it comes to Asian food in general, but after reading Michael Bauer's review of Lers Ros figured I would try the place out.

The food at Lers Ros has a ton of flavor and is legitimately spicy. Both times we've ordered the Quail legs appetizer which is fantastic; probably our favorite thing. Would also reccomend the Talipia, which comes out whole. One of our friends was literally picking every piece of meat off the tiny bones by the end. Tried both the beef and venison versions with galingale and young peppercorns, which tasted great though the meat was a little overcooked on both occassions. The Tom Kha soup was also a favorite, though I thought it was just ok. After all the great things said about the pork belly, we got an order of that too, but had mixed reviews. Apparently (I dont eat pork) it was a bit fatty, but a couple folks liked it.

In the end, probably the best Thai I've had in SF in a while. Beware the spiciness though because the place is legit. The first time we asked for medium-hot with folks who like extra spicy and it was pretty good. Asking for extra spicy might send you over the top.
author: Scott C.

description:
My husband and I LOVE this place. It's close to our house and we never miss an opportunity to drop in if we are hungry and don't feel like cooking. 

The restaurant itself has somewhat of a modern decor, and I will admit that the smell inside is a bit funky, but the food it TO DIE FOR!!!! Their curries are soooo yummy, their food is always fresh, and not one dish has disappointed thus far! It is a bit spicy, so you have to watch out, but they can accommodate any tastes. Definitely a must to visit!
author: Yelena K.

description:
Someone show me a way to get outa here...'cause I constantly pray I'll get outa here...please won't somebody say I'll get outa here...I'll do I dunno what to get outa skid...people tell me there's not a way outa skid...but believe me I gotta get outa skid rowwwwwwwwwwwwwwww. 

That's pretty much what the walk to Lers Ros felt like, with a little less choreography and a little less Rick Moranis. OK, I might be exaggerating a little bit just to help paint the picture, but trust me when I say, TAKE A CAB! I'm from Chicago, so I know what them there streets is like. And even I was a little worried I was going to die in San Francisco and nobody would find my body. Once our lunch group reoriented ourselves and found our final destination, it was like we ALL died...and went to Thai heaven! 

We feasted. We were so hungry from fearing for our lives, and eating like it was going to be our last meal, I can't even name all of the dishes we consumed. Big winners that day included the Papaya Salad, Fried Tofu, Tom Kha Kai soup and something delicious with prawns. Everything was really good, and the portions for the price were excellent. We definitely ordered WAY too much, but that's the fun of having lunch in a group where nobody really has any specific requirements and you can just sort of pick things off the menu that you think sound good. 

The only drawback is the service, which is practically non existent. I don't think they are in the business of serving, which is fine, they make damn good food, it just means you need to speak up, ask for things twice and don't expect to rush in and rush outa the place. The food more than makes up for the sketchy walk and having to flag a "server" every minute. Really! The risk of getting stabbed in the thigh by a dirty needle and having your wallet stolen while you lay in a pool of blood has never tasted SO good!
author: Corey D.

description: This is quickly becoming one of my favorite Thai restaurants in the city.  The flavors here are bolder and more piquant than at other Thai places and  yet very familiar.  I love spicy food and do they deliver.  The papaya salad had a much more spicy and pungent lime and fish sauce taste to it  (which I loved) than other salads I've had.  The sauce is just the right thing to sop up with balls of steamed sticky rice.  I always order Pad Kee Mao when I eat at any Thai restaurant.  It was very good but not as spicy as I had hoped.  One of my favorite things on the menu is the Tom Kha Kai, sweet and sour chicken soup with coconut milk.  Tangy, rich, brothy, coconutty, creamy, spicy, the taste of Thailand on your tongue.  That is some bomb ass soup!  Don't trip about it being in the heart of the Tenderloin.  Bottom line, I'ma keep coming here.
author: P.J. D.

description:
This is the best Thai restaurant I've eaten at in San Francisco.  That doesn't really mean much as I've never been to Thailand and don't really have a palate developed for Thai food, but this is Yelp and it's full of people spewing unfounded opinions onto the webernets, so why not write a review?

I've eaten around 20 of the 100+ dishes on their menu and so far I've enjoyed every one of them.  I think the only thing I haven't been thrilled with is their rice, but it's no worse than any other thai restaurant in SF and I doubt anyone is going there solely to eat steamed rice.
author: Umetaro J.

description: Small place, but food is pretty good.  There was a 30 minute wait when we went.  Portion sizes are small, and prices are a little on the high side for thai food.  Location is in a scary area where there is a lot of crazy people.
author: Sw H.

description:
I went for lunch yesterday and was surprised by a lunch menu with great choices (select 2) which come with rice for $7.95! I had broccoli with bean sauce and chicken in green curry. The servings were generous and delicious. I will definitely return and bring friends for lunch or dinner. It's pretty great!

Comments like - "...and I'm like...neighborhood not the best" or "...and I'm like...near the tittie bar" are ridiculous comments. (BTW, is that really what you're like??) This is SF...don't be an f'ing snob. There are all kinds of neighborhoods in SF and precious few really bad ones, including this one.
author: Phil S.

description: The stir fried pork belly is to die.  It's nice and spicy, and the basil adds a really nice and fresh element to the heavy pork belly.  The pork is amazing.  The top is like a pork rind, and the layer under that is like bacon, and then the one under that is like ham. yuuuuuummmmm.....
author: Jannea T.

description: Great atmosphere and food displays. Some of the best Thai I've had period. But recommend making a reservation so you're not stuck outside looking in while waiting in line.
author: Britton F.

description:
I am so glad we went to Lers Ros - also glad that they deliver (which I haven't attempted yet). The papaya salad was SPIIIIIIICY! Just the way I like it! We had the clams which were awesome and I can't remember for the life of me what our other dish was. All I know was everything tasted great and it was quite cheap as well. 

I'll definitely be back!
author: Natalie G.

description:
Food: 3.5/5
atmosphere/decor: 3/5 (typical asian place, so not complaining)
service: 5/5

Lers Ros Thai is a place that has has authentic thai food.  When you first walk into the restaurant, the waitress is quick to greet you. I'm not sure this place is really clean, because my friend killed a spider on our table after we sat down. The waitress came and gave her another napkin right away because I think she was watching my friend kill it from the cashier table. She took the squashed spider napkin away. Other than that, everything went smooth.
     I went with 3 other people and we all ordered lunch specials. All dished are spicy even though it is not stated in the menu. When spicy is mentioned in the menu, that means its REALLY spicy. We had three different chicken dishes and they were all great. The lunch specials come with rice and a side salad. It is a lot of food and you definintely get your money's worth. My only problem was that I'm not very tolerant of spicy food and everything on the menu is spicy.
author: Cecile S.

description:
An amazing Thai Restaurant in Little Saigon!
The service was prompt and very pleasant.
We ordered the Tom Kha soup that was served in a metal flaring dish. We also had one of their curries that was absolutely delicious!
author: Moira I.

description:
I lived in Thailand for a while and got completely hooked on excellent Thai food. (Not the Americanized over-sugar, under spice, hold the lemongrass & forget the thai chilies stuff).

My first visit was terrific.   I could easily have mistaken the whole vibe for a place near the Sukhumvit complete with Thai music and lots of smiles.

Rock On!
author: mario w.

description: Four stars for  doing what they do well. Tasty food, quick service and all at a fair price. Staying at the St. Francis on a work trip and wanted exactly that and they delivered. The duck curry was very good and better than the veggie dish which was fine but a bit bland.
author: Ph B.

description:
LATE-NIGHT THAI WITH LONG MENU

Went here with a friend and we both thought the food was pretty good and reasonably priced.

Larb Phed Yang
We enjoyed the larb with duck.  It was well-seasoned and fresh.

Red Curry with Prawns
We asked them to make it spicy, it was not spicy.  The curry consisted of five overcooked shrimp topped with a cup of bamboo shoots.  We were not impressed with this dish.

Pad See-Ew
This dish was all white, noodles, bean sprouts, and chicken.  No flavor and no spice.

With all of the good reviews here on yelp, we were expecting more.  Maybe the kitchen was having an off night so three stars for now.  I look forward to trying other dishes next time on their extensive menu.
author: Rob L.

description:
I am always looking for new Thai in our fair city, and rarely am I so pleasantly surprised as I was today.  I sat at the bar for lunch and asked the server what dish sets this place apart.  She quickly said the pork belly.  Pork belly?  I'm in!  She was so right on.  I was in hog heaven.  An older Thai man joined me at the bar and we had a great conversation about Thailand, food and the fact that he eats there every day.  He even offered to share his bottle of wine with me.  
The place is clean and the staff very nice.  I will be back but I have to bring more people so I don't end up with pork belly every time.  I'm sure their Thai standards are great too, but this is the kind of place you want to explore, dish by dish.
author: Clarity T.

description:
To be fair, this place probably deserves better for all the things they are good at .. except, of course, that I didn't order the alligator or the frog on my first order... preferring to judge them by how they prepared some of the basic staples of their cuisine. I *know* these people should have the talent to pull it off, but really, for one reason or another, they failed to properly prepare the basic staples of their cuisine... and in the case of their chicken coconut soup, they were amateurishly off the mark. 

Their mild yellow chicken curry was about a medium. That, in itself, is forgivable.  What isn't is that their food evidenced quick & dirty cooking techniques that noticeably detracted from the experience, as if several of the ingredients were thrown in at the last minute... bland chicken and undercooked boiled potatoes. The end result, ulttmately, is a distinct lack of the richness you would get by cooking it all together. Compare this to those places that lightly brown the potatoes first, then let them simmer in the curry, giving you a richer taste and better texture and the difference becomes obvious.

Likewise, their chicken coconut soup felt similarly thrown together. While their mild was, in fact, mild in this case, the chicken had no flavor and didn't taste like it simmered in the soup, there was a distressing lack of vegetables other than mushrooms, and nary a single piece of galangal, lemongrass, or kafir lime leaves were anywhere to be seen, while the best places put it in the soup and expect you to deal with it, because the flavor is simply is much, much better that way.  

Really... what shortcuts did they do to avoid actually seasoning their soup properly? Rather than having the lemongrass, galangal, kafir lime leaves, heat, and coconut milk driving the flavor, the broth's taste was driven primarily by nam pla -- fish sauce.  Mmmm... fishy flavorless chicken soup?! Not!  Really, it's inexcusable, and simply not the dish that was ordered by the standards one would expect of a real restaurant. 

Definite props for having delivery... but something tells me that this place is either horribly inconsistent, cutting corners, or a victim of their own success if they can't be bothered to nail down the staples. I suspect the frog and alligator are better, primarily because they're actually bothering to cook them without all the short cuts.

I might try the place again someday, perhaps... but when I do, I will be sure to order in-house during off-hours, in the hope they will actually prepare my meal.
author: Mark K.

description: Currently my favorite Thai place ever. Am crazy for the crispy garlic quail wings / legs. Seriously delicious.
author: Christopher F.

description: Food was so good-- the tum yum seafood soup was delicious. But the best part was the service!!  And they are all so pretty!
author: Caroline B.

description: My favourite thai place in the city. Authentic! Duck Larb is mouth watering, they also have hotpot, frogs, rabbits, aligators on their menu. We've tried lots of different things on their menu, and have never been disappointed.
author: Kate J.

description: Very interesting menu. First time Ive seen dishes that include frogs, rabbit, venison and alligator at a Thai restaurant. Had the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob - stir fried pork belly with crispy rind and basil leaves. All I can say is that it was mmm good.  As soon as i read pork belly a with crispy rind I knew I had to have it. Pad Spinach - stir fried spinach in bean sauce. Rad Nah - house secret gravy sauce and marinated pork topping on seasoned flat noodles. I liked the gravy and noodles but not the pork.
author: she q.

description: We ate at the Hayes St location.  The ambience and plates are lovely.  Once the food was on the plates, there was, again, artistry.  It made for greater disappointment for what we experienced.  The whole bass ($29?  You must be kidding!)  was fried, and had perhaps 3 tablespoons of fish on it total.  It was described as a fish that could be shared.  They knew how to make the fish look like it was going to be more. meaty.  They put greens and striking sweet-red peppers on top.....  Fooled us.  The sauce was that same sticky rendition of chili flakes and sugary something that accompanied  the meatballs and the sweet-and-sour-rib appetizers.  Once again, the latter  had barely a thread of meat on them and, again, lots of deep-fried crispiness and bones, bones, bones.
author: Paula H.

description: Location had me walking fast to get to the car but overall look of the restaurant  was ok and clean. Tried both the pad see ew and the alligator. The pad see ew was good but nothing really special. The alligator however was delicious and had lots of flavor!
author: Leslie B.

description: This is a great spot.  The spartan interior hardly belies the rest of the experience waiting for you.  Fresh, delicate flavors with friendly service and, gasp, even stellar wines.  Wow.   How many other Asian restaurants serve Camus?  Anyway, I have been back multiple times.  It's service with a smile consistently.  Even better, the fresh wonderful flavors I experienced on my first visit have been unwavering.
author: Patrick B.

description:
ordered delivery. very spicy = awesome. good portions, great flavour. WIN

1 star less because it takes a while to get the food.
author: Dilip R.

description: Thai people come to eat here, even other That restaurant's owners eat here too. That's all I can say.
author: Jj M.

description: YYYYUM.....! It's hard to find a good thai restaurant that can resemble the pungent flavors of the east...that nutty taste of humidity and lime peppered with divine....YUM!...Their pad thai is on the $monAy$!!!!.... I lived with a thai chef and I became spoiled with fresh homemade pad thai from scratch .... A burden or a blessing? Now I have this wonderful woman's Arte'D'cuisine to compare to.... I squealed with delight with a fork and spoonful of Ler Ros pad thai. Nostalgic Satisfaction..YYYUM! ......they also put the Tay in sataysteee chicken skewers... A lil stingy on the cucumber salad but hey! It was stiiiiilll YYYUM !!! If you gotta pee really bad I recommend getting a head start before the others...don't hold it for a few more spoonfuls of their delicious tom kha gai soup....you'll be fighting your bladder through the labyrinth to the bathroom....and take some snacks incase you get hungry... It's a long way back to the table.... Oooooooo the table service.... It was great! Our waitress was not as flashy as the other thai girls ... I wanted to make friends :) definitely will return around 6 before the large crowd appears and when the parking meters are out... Yelp says they have a gargage but I must have missed it because you can't see it... Next time I'll ask!
author: Bee H.

description: 2 lunches.  Good food good service.  The items off the a la carte menu far more tasty and complex than the ones served as lunch specials.  Would go back anytime.
author: Ash A.

description:
this place is a solid 3.  i am always a bit more skeptical and hesitant on going out for thai food...why would you when you get it home cooked and authentic??!  but sometimes you just want to go out and not deal with dishes and chopping and slicing and all that....

lers ros thai is pretty authentic on most of the dishes we ordered.  their som tom aka papaya salad is super authentic, particularly with the salted crab.  although the salted crab was a little bigger than what i'm used to seeing added, it still gave a nice flavor.  i read in some reviews people tried to eat the salted crabs and that it was too small and salty...ah news flash people, those crabs are meant to be small and salty and not really meant to be eaten as they are there to add more flavor. 

anyhoo, i would definitely recommend the som tom.  we also ordered the pad thai.  umm....yeah i'd avoid this dish.  the noodles were so tiny and broken and overall the dish was bland....what the heck!  how do you go wrong with pad thai?  i'm not sure but somehow they did.

the bf is a big fan of the tom yum koong soup.  me not so much but we compromised by ordering that dish for him and the deep fried tilapia for me.  i must say the tom yum kong was very flavorful, the spices were just right not too much and not too little...and the deep fried tilapia...yum!  how can you really go wrong with deep fry?  the fish was crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. and the spices it was covered in was oh so yummy.

so why only the 3 stars and not more...well the service was pretty lacking. we actually had reservations, but still had to wait about 30 mins for a table.  and then once we were seated and ordered we had to wait for what seemed like eternity for our food.  i don't expect much service when you're at a restaurant in the TL, but this was a bit ridiculous.  we'll still come back...the som tom at this place is the best i've found so far....
author: Mao K.

description: Always a great meal with a lot of flavor.  Get any of the fresh fish dishes, they are all amazing.  I am also a fan of the crispy pork belly, the perfect trinity of meat, fat and crispy skin.  And the papaya salad is a nice spicy treat, as well.
author: Bret S.

description:
Well, it's good but the area is terrible. Wouldn't come here at night. They definitely have more authentic Thai dishes than a lot of other places but I honestly had no idea what to order so I went half with recommendations and half with what I usually get at every other Thai restaurant.

All in all - Pretty good but I don't like walking to a restaurant and having to worry about stepping in crap. Not dog crap either... =\ I'll make my way to Chabaa or Thai House Express instead.
author: Con L.

description:
I'm in ((LOVE))... with Lers Ros. Most of the dishes we had ordered in the last 4 visits have been consistently good. 

Some of the highlights are: 

1) Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (#62) - stir fried pork belly with crispy rind. We have ordered this dish every time. 
2) Pla Trout Tod Nam Pla (#113) - fried whole trout, served with mango sauce. Not for people who do not like to see fish head on the place. You can eat from the head to the tail since it is deep fried. 
3) Hoy Lai Pad Prik Pao (#102) - stir fried clams with chili and basil leaves. Definitely will order this again. 
4) Yum Nam Tok (#19) with pork - sliced pork with spicy lime dressing. It's basically the larb with sliced pork instead of ground meat. Yet another excellent dish that I do repeat order. 

Other dishes tried: 
- Som Tom Koong Yang (#13) & Som Tom Poo Dong (#12) - shredded green papaya salad with grilled shrimp, or raw crabs. Both solid. dish 
- Koh Moo Yang (#9) - grilled pork shoulder with a nice spicy dipping sauce. 
- Larb Phed Yang (#25) - duck larb. I liked it quite a bit, but it did not have a lot of duck meat and mostly skins. 
- Tom Kreang Nai (#30) - spicy and sour soup with pork entrails. I am not a huge fan of pork innards, but this was well executed. 
- Rad Nah (#79) - probably the least favorite dishes I tried at Lers Ros so far. The sauce is too sweet for me, and the quality of pork in the dish was a bit questionable. 
- Kang Keaw Wan (#36) - green curry with thai eggplants. Better than the version from Thai House Express, but not the best green curry I ever had either. 
- Pad Kee Mow (#76) - good, but not memorable. 

One more thing to note - I had the food delivered to SOMA once and will never ever do that again. It took 1.5 hours and the food was cold.
author: Yuko K.

description: My favorite thai food in the city -- and they deliver!  I love the pork belly, the pork shoulder appetizer, the papaya salad, and the duck curry.  It's a little pricy, and the wait can be long, but it's worth it if you go at an off-time.  Never change, Lers Ros!
author: Brian Y.

description: Had a Five Spice Duck rice plate to go.  Cost $9 with  only five pieces of duck with no bones.  Duck was just okay, but totally not worth the money.
author: susan g.

description: I've been here several times for lunch, and last night for dinner.  It's always great fresh food, and not just your basic thai food looks or tastes.  It's so much better than most places.  Service is great too.  Last night I got the pork spareribs, prawn soup, and chicken w/ yellow curry.  All awesome!
author: Jason D.

description:
Had Kao Kha Moo again. Can't get enough of it but it's my first time ordering it here at this restaurant. It was just OK. I liked the one in Thai House Express more. Their pork shoulder is not so good. THe cut of meat is too fatty and the smoke and spices are not up to par with Sai Jai Thai. I think the crispy pork belly with basil is their best dish. Wow, I've been talking about pork dishes a lot.

Despite the shortcomings, they still have a very extensive menu and they are open til 2am everyday. Soups come in a flamming pot which is very appealing. Som Tum with salted eggs are the best som tum variation I've ever had.

Never never order the mixed sweets iced with red syrup and condensed milk dessert. Absolutely horrible. The red syrup is way too sweet and artificial.
author: Ryan B.

description: I am thai and this is real thai food. They offer dishes that many thai restaurants do not offer for fear of not pleasing the western palate. We ordered the moo ping (bbq pork on skewers) and it was flavorful and moist and the dipping sauce is sour and sweet and salty (perfect balance of all three flavors). We also had kang som with egg and a yum seafood salad. Their dessert was really amazing as well, you can smell the coconut when you are eating it. Portions are good, prices are reasonable, and the interior is clean and modern. Bathrooms are a little bit out of the way and you can only get through them through a maze going upstairs but clean.
author: Tossama C.

description: Red curry with chicken, pad seew, crispy pork  belly, tom yom soup, too many to remember... open late too!
author: Geronimo K.

description:
Having just moved to SF from Hell's Kitchen, the epicenter of Thai food in Manhattan, I had my guard up when trying out Lers Ros.  However, it totally blew me away.  

I was initially impressed by the wide variety of dishes on the menu; definitely more extensive than your typical Thai spot.  Fortunately, there were 10 of us there for dinner so we had a great chance to try a bunch of dishes.  In particular, I was a fan of a few things:

-Garlic frog appetizer - lightly fried chunks of frog with a sweet chilli dipping sauce
-The duck salad and calamari salad - great balance of spice, tart, and sweet in both, well cooked slices of duck
-Pork belly - fried in a rich and flavorful sauce
-Whole fish - we got the fried trout and the steamed sea bass.  Both with great texture, fresh, well prepared/flavored, and good sized fish to boot.

We had a couple of people with less flexible palates who went with some of the Thai classics (veg. yellow curry, veg. khee mao noodle) which I didn't think were all that amazing; you could likely do better elsewhere.  But the more interesting items on the menu are truly outstanding.  I enjoyed eating here more than Sripraphai in Woodside (hopefully for you ex-NY'ers this will mean something).

Also another reason to love this spot is the value: with shared apps, a ton of food, a Chang beer, plus tax + tip: $20 a person.  Nice.
author: Arun W.

description: The best Thai food in SF! Cant wait for their new location on Franklin and Hayes! Always good, no matter what I get! The customer service is outstanding. Thanks, O!
author: Jay C.

description: Awesome Thai.  The rave is well justified.
author: Henry A.

description: The house made chili paste is on a whole different level...AMAZING!
author: Tom B.

description:
I lived in Thai Town in Los Angeles for several years and Lers Ros matches the best of them (Sanamluang, Palms, Yai). It's by far, the best "authentic" Thai cuisine in the Bay Area--i.e., spicy, pungent, peppery, rich and textured, and not drenched in sugar. 

Unlike Americanized local faves, the curries appropriately sting to allow the full intensity of the authentic flavors (e.g., galangal, kefir lime, etc.) to come through. The non-curry dishes--e.g., noodles, rice, and stir-fries--are delicately prepared with rich and subtle flavors. 

Anyone giving this place low scores simply has not had (or does not like) authentic Thai food. That should be obvious that when it's the only Thai restaurant in SF actually packed with Thai immigrants (other than for Karaoke at King of Thai Noodle, which hardly compares).
author: Ted S.

description:
The Bay Area basically sucks for Thai food: there's no southern Thai food that I know of, hardly any Chiang Mai-style food besides the occasional soggy khao soi, and the Issan food is better at Lao places. In LA or Chicago, Lers Ros might not be exceptional, but it's here, and there's no better Thai food around -- excepting, maybe, some of the temples on feast days. Lers Ros isn't Americanised or Sinicised at all (well, a few dishes are, but they're easy enough to avoid). I love that the meats have different textures. There's no tyranny of tenderness here -- they choose the right cut for the job, and sometimes that cut is chewy or gristly or squishy. I love that they realise that a high capsaicinoid count is only part of what makes great Thai food. There's a freshness to their sauces that, of the Bay Area Thai places I've tried, only Thai House Express comes close to. I love that they give you the option of having your papaya salad with raw crab, even if I find it much easier to take the crab away to eat at home.

The easy listening background music is pretty horrific though.
author: Brad L.

description: Excellent for take-outs.  Extra-ordinary preparations.
author: Paul M.

description:
This place made me feel like I was in Los Angeles again.  If a Thai place isn't open at 2am and has some questionable meats, it's probably not authentic.  In LA, you can tell by looking for a health rating below 'A' whether or not the place is any good, where in SF it's a matter of luck.  We got lucky here.  I asked for spicy, and they gave me spicy without fooling around with sauce on the side.  My meat was ground up beyond recognition in the Pad Ka Prow, and that is *exactly* how I like it.  

Update: They've started closing early!!  This is terrible for hungry post-concert people!!

  While I do like some of the yuppie places (Sabuy Sabuy II in Berkeley is excellent), I'm so glad to know that San Francisco has the sort of Thai place I first knew, if you know where to look.  This place filled a hole in my belly and in my heart :)
author: Avani W.

description:
So I've been craving lemongrass fish. I've tried several places in the city but none could compare to the yummy dish I had in Thailand.....until I ate at Lers Ros. 

I would recommend Lers Ros to anyone that is interested in eating great Thai food.
author: Jen B.

description: I challenge someone to find a better papaya salad (though a good papaya salad is a very personalized matter and hard to be objective about; depends on your experiences with different versions).  This place is not too expensive and the food is good and plenty of choices along with the main stream thai dishes.  Decor is unassuming.  They stay open late and they deliver. There's also a tv to watch current sports.  I'm going back for more!
author: H G.

description: Great place. Parking is awful. But as traditional as can be
author: Madeline W.

description: Awesome food. They have killer boar dish that's just the best! A little pricey but I think it's worth it to pay for authentic Thai food. Their food are spicy as they should be. If you can't take spicy, you better let them know ahead. I can't wait to go there again.
author: Win S.

description:
Yum and authentic.

I've been here twice with real Thai peeps who agree.  Boyfriend's mom usually orders and I just eat whatever.  

Kao mun gai is probably my favorite Thai dish.  I had it approximately a million times when I was vacationing in Thailand and haven't found it at a Thai place since....until Lers Ros.  It seems like a super plain dish - boiled chicken over garlic rice with a chili/ginger/soy sauce sauce - but it is yummy to the max.  It's really the sauce that makes the dish because it's hard to eff up the chicken and rice.  Lers Ros makes it just like Thailand pretty much

My other favorite dish at Lers Ros was the spicy spare rib soup.  I know how to say it in Thai (thom saep gadoog moo awn).  Thai people don't play around with their spicy-ness, and that is awesome.  The soup is flavorful and served over a flame to keep it hot.  The spice doesn't get in the way of the flavor at all.  

The last time I went, we also got kang ped (duck curry).  The duck wasn't extremely fatty, which I liked.  I couldn't tell how spicy it was since all of our other dishes were way spicy.  Hard to tell where the spicy was coming from after a while.

The chrysanthemum tea (and their other juices, I think) were served in HUGE mugs.  Although the neon color is off-putting, it is a refreshing beverage.  Boyfriend had the longan juice and was not impressed...

If I lived/worked in the city, I would definitely come here more often.
author: Marisa S.

description: First thai place I chose since flying in, I don't think I'll ever choose another. The pad thai was amazing and their delivery is free, straight to my hotel room.. you can't beat that. I've eaten pad thai from at least three dozen thai restaurants outside of SF and this is arguably one of the best.
author: Matthew M.

description:
Probably the best Thai food I've had in SF, and here's why:
- They have a HUGE menu, with all the usual curries and noodles you'd expect, plus some really unusual items -- quail?  alligator?  frog? pork shoulder?  Yeah, they've got that.  Awesome.
- Prices ranged from impossibly low to totally reasonable.  Most entrees were in the $7 range.  We managed to have dinner for 5, including appetizers and beer, for under $75.  Nothing wrong with that.
- Everything we ordered was flavorful and delicious.   Everything.
- Service was quick and friendly.

So why not five stars?
- A couple of dishes we had were unexpectedly spiiiiicy.  I like spicy, but I also like a little warning, or the ability to opt-out.  So, buyer beware.
- The decor is a little dire.  Not terrible, just kind of... functional.  And the two huge TVs on the wall just seem kinda out of place and distracting.

Overall though, tasty and affordable Thai, at great prices.  Hooray.
author: Andrew D.

description: Spicy deliciousness. Not fussy or fancy, basic decor. AMAZING food, more than reasonable prices. Perfect comfort food. Loved the crispy pork belly.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Just went for lunch with a group of 5, good place for the group.  Not too busy but not empty either (and enough space for a coworker in a wheelchair to have no trouble).

The lunch special is 2 items plus rice and salad, which is a pretty sizable portion (nobody with me who ordered it finished; one person had another meal boxed to take home).  The eggplant with tofu (Pad Makuer Tofu) was excellent and the chicken with basil (Pad Kra Pow Kai) wasn't bad either.

They also serve alligator, though everyone in our group decided to pass on it.  Apparently that isn't as exotic as I thought it was, but if you are looking for an out of the ordinary meat, you'll find it here.
author: Mike D.

description: Great Thai Restaurant!   They are pretty authentic and have a great variety of food.  I love the papaya salad and larb.   The staff is very friendly.  The only downside to the place is that it can get very noisy when it is crowded.
author: Paul A.

description: Ugh. Their service is so terrible, you lose your appetite just waiting for them to take your order. They only have ONE waitress for the lunch shift. -______--
author: Lindsey M.

description:
Despite being so popular and crowded, the service, the food, and the ambiance was amazing! I really judge a Thai restaurant by their Thai iced tea, and theirs was perfect. The waiters, although I'm sure super stressed by the packed place, were very accommodating and friendly.

Only downside was that it was a little scary to walk alone in that area.
author: Jay L.

description:
negative 10stars!

i just tried to order and requested delivery.
my house IS near downtown but what did they tell me?

"its too far"

Do they walk when they deliver? cuz my house is only less than 10min away from their location if you drive! this is such a BS.
author: Shine W.

description: This place had a strong odor last time I came here...like it smelled of fish paste...gone horribly wrong. Really unappetizing for reals. I usually get pad see ew as a staple when trying new places, unlike a lot of places in the area, the portions here are really small...not much leftovers for sure. It was pretty good, but I could have done without the smell :(
author: Lauren S.

description: This place is one of most authentic thai food in the bay area! Everything is very executed, and very spicy! I love their spicy claims and venison.
author: Leah C.

description: The #62 Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob/Stir fried pork belly with crispy rind, #27 Tom Kha Kai/Coconut Milk based soup and #78 Pad Thai here were what my friend and I ordered and it was all so wonderful!!  They be serving up some good stuff here - and my friend who had actually visited Thailand agreed this was one of the best he's ever tasted, and I have to say as well that the food here definitely stands out.  Got here on a Friday evening and the place was quite busy and a bit loud at times, but the food they serve is so awesome, I would without hesitation come back if I want to eat some Thai food:-)
author: Kahanalei M.

description: Holy smokes, guys. Go there now. You will be highly pleased that you braved the Loin for this restaurant.
author: Nia G.

description: Finally found Thai food in SF that resembles the good stuff from Asia. Agree with most yelpers that this restaurant's use of fresh herbs and spices really makes a difference in how yummy everything taste. The service is good though sometimes when it gets hectic I notice the wait staff is a bit disoriented. My only warning is that Lers Ros has a really extensive menu which includes venison, rabbit, frog etc. and honestly it gets a little overwhelming having to choose from it, esp. when some descriptions are like "with special brown sauce". It may help to have a Thai friend go with you who understands the difference between one brown sauce vs. another.
author: Lisa C.

description: Fantastic, delicious, fantastic.  Can we find more balanced, more authentic, more extensively prepared genuine Thai cuisine in SF?  Be cool Thai style not pushy farang and you will enjoy LR very much.
author: Michael G.

description: I'd give zero stars if I could...because that's how much food I got.  We ordered delivery over two hours ago and have nothing to show for it.  After we waited an hour, I called and asked about our order.  I was told the driver was on his way.  20 min later, called again, told driver was on his way.  Another 20 min later, my boyfriend called and before he told her the address, she said, "it's on its way".  Clearly the standard BS answer they give anyone calling about their order.  After more than 2 hours, we called again and were told that they cancelled our order.  Most unacceptable delivery experience I've ever had in the city.  Now I'm starving and waiting for a pizza to be delivered.  Sad, disappointed, hungry, and pissed.
author: Carrie L.

description:
delivery

tom kha is tangy and amazing
84 chicken cashew was my favorite. so good
93 beef is crazy spicy!! not bad
36 green curry is super good
brown rice
author: Christopher L.

description: I went here to check out the Duck Larb from 7x7's Big Eat 2011 and boy does it deserve to be on that list. So spicy but with so many amazing flavors... mm just thinking about it is making me hungry.  I also got a green curry that was pretty good though didn't stand out to me compared to other thai curries I've had.  This place is surprisingly trendy inside for a Tenderloin food joint and the service was good.  I would definitely go back.
author: Heather D.

description: I ordered the food for delivering today and everything went well. The only thing is the delivery person changed her behavior so sudden right after I gave her tip. I didn't mean to be mean or stingy. I just felt like it doesn't matter how much of the food cost and we have to give 15% calculating from the whole total. Usually, even though I order it less or more than this. I will tip $4-$5 to the delivery person. I don't think the whole cost of the food has something to do with the delivery guy. You don't have to serve, you don't have to take care, you just drop into the restaurant and pick the food up and drop it off at the destination. That's it! The cost you have is only the fuel. I used to work in the restaurant too, so I know how things work out. Next time, if you get the customer, behave yourself before and after. If you wanna fake, fake until you leave. Don't fake just when you arrive and hope for the tip, and if you don't satisfied with the amount of the tip and just ditch off without saying anything... That sucks! If you wanna give a service, understand the word "SERVICE"...
author: Abbey L.

description: Really good Thai food at a relatively low cost. Place was pretty packed when we got there. Best dishes we had were the veggie pad Thai and the veggie green curry. My only complaint was a funky smell coming from the kitchen.
author: Justin M.

description: I've been meaning to write a review for this place.  I ate here a few months ago and I was very disappointed.  First, the inside looks like a cafeteria dining room.  Second, service sucks and it took 10m to get water then another 8m to get our drink order.  Third, Our appetizer came last (Its called appetizer for a reason...it should come first) and the food was cold and very bland tasting (Our Curry tasted watered down).  Again with the service, we didnt see our server till we were done (30m) and that means water was not refilled and oh they were not busy at all.  So if you want to waste your money go on ahead but will not be going back or recommend it to my friends or anybody at all!
author: Edgar T.

description:
Like going to Bangkok.

Great food, authentically and consistently prepared.  As spicy as you want.  Friendly service, fast delivery too.  Open late.  THE place to go in SF for authentic Thai food.  Try the whole fish - amazing.

Close your eyes and you'll think you're in Thailand.  The only thing missing are those tiny post-it tissues they pass off as napkins over there.
author: Steve H.

description:
Across from dark Olive alley in the TL, an all-Thai, no-English sign screamed "Authentic!" Inside, a half-filled new restaurant of Thai patrons. 

In the mood for my usual neighborhood Osha Thai duck, egg noodle soup, I decided to cheat on her and give this spot a shot. My friendly server helped me narrow down some never-before-seen dish options to Kuay Jub. 

20 mins later, my soup bowl of square rice noodles, fried pork, halved hard-boiled egg and cilantro in five-spiced broth came out. Good flavor. And, at first, a delightful play of soft and crunchy textures. The square rice noodles eventually broke easily (But I'm not fussy about texture anyway.)

While I waited for my dish, I was entertained by Thai slow jams/pop and a flat screen tuned to ESPN. And I scanned the simple interior that houses around 14 tables.

I asked my server what she recommends for next time. Pia Kra Pong Nuang Manow (steamed seabass with chili and lime juice) and Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (stir-fried pork with crispy rind and basil leaves.)

The spot is open til 2am so Mr. Late Night creep will have to come through with the crew and try these and more.

Oh, one other note of authenticity: Chiang Mai beer.
author: Chiu Man N.

description: As a tourist in San Francisco, I look to reviews to determine where my husband and I will be eating.  This restaurant got rave reviews, so I walked 30 minutes to eat it.  About 5 minutes from the restaurant, my husband and I turned around so that we would not be mugged or shot.  This is in a terrible neighborhood, so don't go at night!!!
author: April W.

description:
this place is amazing.  the food i had was so delicious (can you handle spicy?)  my fav SF thai
open till 12 AM in a sketchy part of town but smack dab among many other tasty eateries along Larkin, and a clean ambiance with pop/80s music (uh backstreet boys?) that does not match the surrounding neighborhood
look for the black and red thai sign
so many items to pick from...shared #62 Pad Kra Prow Moo Kro (Pork with crispy rind and basil leaves) -- excellent flavor with the perfect crispy skin and fatty texture, mix with rice
is sometimes called the greatest dish of all time
#114 Pla Rad Prik (deep fried tilapia in house chili-based sauce with red peppers) -- only $10 ($15 now)...delicious and spicy, demolished it but your mouth will be burning at first -- prices up now
still a favorite, have to watch for bones
also tried #69 Kuay Tiew Rua (beef), since was looking for a boat noodle dish, just like the kind you find in LA, nice tangy, intense flavor, salty with fishball, chicharron, beef (go with thin noodle)
--went back to try wild boar with chili and galingale (ginger)
unfortunately, it was too chewy, but the spices are strong and varied
don't miss the tamarind candy on the way out
*pork shoulder appetizer #9, which was perfectly fatty, smoky, but the best part is the dipping sauce -- complexity of flavor and heat is amazing
wouldn't recommend the quail either chopped or minced because it's too difficult to get to the meat
rabbit (garlic style) also chopped and fried, with bone in
pork shoulder sometimes a bit fatty, but accompanying spicy fish sauce like still great
chicken pad see ew standard.
instead get pad kee mao or prawn pad thai with the noodles nicely done.
crispy chicken with good rice underneath -- so specifically get the one with garlic ginger rice.
larb is nice and spicy with good tang
if you're going vegetarian, then try eggplant with garlic basil
--come back here all the time
had rad na (like a chow fun with gravy)
also fried trout in a mango sauce (where was the mango?)
had the tom yum soup which is very tangy (lime) here, so better to get the more complex boat noodle soup

now in 2015, seating has changed since 2009, walls painted, still small bathrooms
and prices are up like $16.95 for #114, but still worth it.  order that plus
#69 beef, small noodle, #9, #13, #56, #62 for sharing among 4 when you're hungry.
author: Rob C.

description: Still my favorite Thai restaurant to go with my Thai boys.  I LOVE the soup here...Just wanted to write an update that  you don't have to dine here...you can ORDER pick up or DELIVERY...Just wanted to open up the options for yelpers out that ;-)
author: Hiromi N.

description: Excellent service, everyone was very nice. The food was great too. The only thing I didn't like was the fact that a side of rice was $1.50 when most thai places give you a white rice for free with your order.
author: Kat D.

description: Shrimp with veins still in. Waited 20 min to order. One entree never came. Asked 3 times for a diet coke refill. Pathetic.
author: Tara O.

description: This place is nestled in the heart of TL. My friend took me this joint. It's a very nice restaurant, the lay out is comfortable.  One of the items we tried was the duck salad, apparently it's '1000 things to eat before you die.' I am not a big fan of duck, but I tried it. Surprisedly it was tasty. When you bite into it, the flavors work together, the crispy lettuce leaf, the duck, and the spices. I was impressed.
author: SF S.

description: I went in for their lunch special, very good price ~$8 for two items, rice, and house salad.  I had the red curry and chicken satay and ordered a side of papaya salad with grilled prawns.  The papaya salad is SOOOOO good! I asked for it Laos style, which usually means less sweet more savory & spicy.  Yes yes yes, if you LOVE spicy and salty and savory, well I guess an almost umami explosion in your mouth, then try it! I want to go back soon and try it regular thai style cuz I had about five bites and my mouth was on a slow and steady burn streak.  Haha, I even had trouble eating my curry.  But anyway overall the food is really yummy and they've got a nice bargain on lunch.  One thing I didn't like: the waitresses stand around and stare at you.  They're friendly and all but yes it's uncomfortable.
author: Blia L.

description:
We really  enjoyed going to this restaurant.  They had a huge selection of dishes. We loved all the dishes that we chose.  The Tom Yum Koong soup was delicious, but  might be a little spicy  for some. We had a ginger chicken dish that was light and refreshing. We also had a pork dish that was also wonderful. Sorry I can't remember the names of the specific dishes. I  get the impression that just about  anything would be great. 
The had some more exotic fair like alligator, frog, and quail.  I heard the duck was also very  good.
The waiters were friendly and attentive. The portions were good. We had plenty of leftovers.
I have no complaints at all.
author: bob b.

description: Been here multiple times and never disappointed! I Papaya salad with crab, duck larb, crispy pork belly and friend whole tilapia, and some chang beer.  Done!
author: Shannon L.

description: YUM! Stopped in for a late night bite after stopping by a bday party at Kokos and was pleasantly surprised at the quality of the food here. Had the beef yellow curry and the whole fried tilapia. The fish was super duper flavorful - had an awesome sticky glaze and accompanying sauce and was tender, fresh and flaky. The curry was nicely spiced and was just the right consistency. Totally reasonable and yummy. Looking at the other reviews, need to try the pad kra prow moo krob and the flaming soups that looked so good coming out to other tables....and the larb!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
pork belly is always good. 
tom yum soup comes in a pseudo hotpot contraption with flames shooting out.
everything is spicy. love it.
author: Meej K.

description: Totally some of the best Thai food you'll ever have! Try the sliced pork thing, it's amazing! I know it's a bit of a cliche, but they've got great pad thai. The service is excellent, too. They must have 1/2 dozen people working there for every diner, Every time you need anything they are right there and your water glass will never get less than 3/4 full.
author: Jeremiah P.

description: Stopped in here to pick up an order heading to my girlfriend's house. The curry was good, not earth shattering but definitely better than the standard SF thai curry. The Tom Yum Kroon soup was excellent. Tons of ginger in it adding a nice spice blend that was flavor and kick, not just heat. Waiting for my food I noticed a lot of excellent looking dishes replete with vegetables, well cooked meat and sauces. I'll go back to dine in and try some of these other non-standard dishes (as in not Pad Thai, Curry, Tom Yum or Pad See Ew).
author: Chris C.

description: If you love Thai food because it is jammed packed with flavors, then you would love the appetizers and the yums (salads) here.  I love the yum nahm.  The entrees were good, but not the best I've had, with the exception of the pla rad prik (fish with chili sauce) which was delicious.  I also like that it's open late.
author: Sandy J.

description:
the 5-spice pork leg, wow.  eating this makes u a man!

a really stuffed, passed out, fat man...
author: Ethan L.

description: Wow, real Thai food!  The spices and flavors were kickin' and not watered down like most Thai restaurants.  Like the other reviews state, the pork belly was excellent., sour, spicy, drenched in sauce but still crispy.  The chicken rice (Kow mun gai) was the chicken was tender, the broth was subtle in flavor,  and the combination of the chicken, rice and broth was perfect.  Everything we had here was great..  The pleasant surprise was the Pla Kra Pong Nuang Manow.  We could tell the fish was very fresh by the texture.  I'd come here again, preferably for lunch considering it is in the hood.
author: Rob R.

description: Authentic food. Their papaya salad with crab is very tastety. I also like the grilled pork belly. And Potak soup. The servers are attentive and friendly. I visit this place around once a week.
author: Emily R.

description: Walked in at exactly 11 am on a Saturday to get a quick lunch before we left the city. We were the first people in the place. We ordered chicken satay, garlic frog, and kra duk moo tod. Service was a bit strange here, we didn't get the satay for 30 minutes. I waited to dig in(the satay was solely for me while the other two appetizers were for my bf), until my bf got his apps. Waited another 10 minutes for the other two apps, but things were looking bleak so I started eating. The satay was good, but it was cold by the time I started eating. A few minutes later the frog was brought to our table, and it took another ten minutes for the pork ribs. It was confusing to see the other tables of people who had walked in and ordered after us get there food(including their entrees, and at the same time) before we even got our three appetizers. It took about 90 minutes to complete our lunch. Timing and service needs some work on their part.
author: Bear A.

description: On my visit we enjoyed the whole fried trout. The flavors are amazing.  Even took home the fish left overs tho I knew they wouldn't be cruchy  because that sauce is special. Also enjoyed one of their very tasty soups. Damn, now I want to go back...NOW.
author: Jackie W.

description: By far the best Thai I've had in SF.  I love this place because it offers a broader array of dishes you wouldn't normally see in a standard Thai restaurant. Get the pork belly. It's ridiculous. Fatty meat and crispy pig-flesh mixed with explosive flavors...dear God it's so good.
author: ciara s.

description: Best thai I've eaten in San Francisco... maybe ever.
author: Phi T.

description: Absolutely love this place.  it can suit large parties and is perfect for a date. Their food is to die for and everything on the menu is at a reasonable price.  The atmosphere is great and you can tell everyone loves the food because they stay and chat for hours while they order more and more plates. It is my favorite restaurant in outer TL, plus it stays open til midnight!
author: Spring C.

description:
This place is good...and cheap (by my standards anyway).

What haven't I had here...?

Noodles, green curry, yellow curry, chicken, pork--I've tried about 15 different dishes here.  The Rad Nah gets a special mention because it was amazing.  Quite rich and it was more like secret-recipe soup than gravy, but so good.  The only thing I was so-so on was the whole fried fish.  I thought it was slightly overcooked.

Service can be a bit slower and dishes don't always come out at the same time, but it's not enough to take away from the food.  The waitstaff are always super-friendly.

They're open late (plus) and I live within the delivery range (big plus), so no trekking to the Tenderloin for me!
author: fi l.

description: Excellent Thai food. It's a good mix of original and authentic cuisine with a western ambiance that you won't be afraid to take your white friends to. We had their special alligator dish, the fried frog appetizer and the beef sirloin entree. All three were excellent, and definitely something I won't be able to order at other neighboring restaurants. The service was good and quick, and any waiter would help us, which is always a plus. Highly recommended, just be aware that they don't give you chop sticks until you ask and if you get hot sake, they warm it in the microwave. :)
author: Dmitriy A.

description: It's OK, but not great.  Tom Kai Gai soup was simple, chicken overcooked and chewy, very few vegetables.  Green curry tasted like they took some coconut milk and added store bought chili paste.  The flavors complex.   Maybe this was just an off night and a different chef.  Will try again since they have some really interesting dishes.
author: Robert R.

description: Great neighborhood Thai place. Loved the Pad Thai and Tom Kha soup. The spicy tofu really was a bit too much despite the fact that I'm normally able to handle my spice! Great service and they actually accept reservations which is fantastic!
author: Karishma S.

description:
w o w. 

this place just surpassed thai house express for #1 thai place in the city. 

food here is definitely spicy, which is awesome for me and may/may not be awesome for you. we went with 10 people and got to order a lot of stuff. standouts include the quail, the wild boar, fish cakes, pad kee mao, and duck larb. their thai iced tea is super strong and kept me up til 2am -- or maybe i'm just a wimp.

(update 3/2010): thai boat noodles (#69 on menu) = pho amplified... so so good.
author: Angi C.

description: we really like Lers Ros... They deliver fast and hot and their food is the best Thai I've had in SF thus far.  We love their curries and their thai basil chicken.  I think their pad thai is the best i've ever had.  and it's cheap... what more do you want?
author: ari b.

description:
this restaurant tastes different from all the other thai restaurants in the city I've been to.  And it is now, IMHO, the best thai restaurant in the city.  They use galingale instead of normal ginger, and almost always have fresh young peppercorns in the stirfried dishes.  they use thai eggplant (these little round, tomato-shaped eggplants) instead of chinese or western eggplants.  And every dish defaults to spicy, by my own chinese tastes.

I've only come here twice so far, and both on friday nights.  always the place has been full of thai people--at least asians that can speak thai.  The food is really good and seems really authentic to me, though I've never been to thailand.

Dish by dish review (stuff I've had)
1) pad ped alligator.  Stir fried in a heavy galingale, garlic, and chili sauce, this dish was quite interesting.  alligator tastes like a cross between chicken and fish, and was quite tender, despite what you might think.  quite tasty!
2) stir-fried eel.  the eel were cut cross wise, with the spine still in it, so this dish was surprisingly difficult to eat.  taste was good, and it had almost the same sauce as the alligator (except no eggplant, if I remember correctly).  
3) stuffed calamari soup.  This was kind of a chinese style clear broth--simple and flavorful stock.  Then they added ground pork stuffed calamari.  I expected them to have neglected to remove the "spine" of the calamari, but they did.  the calamari was relatively fresh and cooked to a perfect tender consistency. I'd definitely recommend this.
4) lers ros special combination:  green papaya salad, bbq chicken leg, and steamed sticky rice (aka sweet rice).  The green papaya salad defaults to SPICY HOT as my thai friends have told me it should be, so be warned.  you may want to ask to get it mild.  It comes with little grilled shrimp, slightly smoky and quite good.  The BBQ Chicken is ABSOLUTELY AWESOME--well marinated, charred, and with a great smoky flavor from being actually grilled.  And it comes with a home-made sweet-and sour dipping sauce (caramellized, and not the typical glow-in-the-dark red).  The first time I came here, I smelled the chicken grilling, while I was still outside the door, and I was hoping it was coming from lers ros! :)
5) green curry with prawns.  Pretty classic green curry. fresh and perhaps a little sweet for my tastes, but still good.  There also were thai eggplants in this dish.  great with rice as usual.
6) THE BEST PAD THAI I'VE HAD IN THE BAY AREA.  The noodles were a perfect chewy al dente, and stir-fried to perfection, with the nice smoky flavor from a hot wok.  Well flavored with your typical eggs, fish sauce, and the chicken and shrimp were cooked just right.  Raw bean sprouts on top completed it, and gave the nice fresh texture break from the perfect noodles.
7) Garlic pepper rabbit.  This was not what I expected, and a little disappointing.  They dry-fried the rabbit, without much of a batter, which was a mistake I think.  Rabbit is typically very lean and has small bones, so after frying, the outside of the rabbit chunks became hard, the meat was dry, and the small bones got mixed up with the hard "skin" of the chunks.  Made it difficult to eat, though the spices were good, and the chili sauce they served with it was very tasty.

Note, they have a bunch of offal dishes I haven't tried yet (most of my local friends are...not so adventurous), but I will be stopping by for takeout/delivery a lot I think, so I'll be trying them bit by bit, until some of my high school friends come to town :)
author: Fong L.

description: Reasonably priced.  Adequate portions.  Large menu.  Service is great.  Just not what we were looking for in the way of Thai food.  Would try other Thai restaurants before returning.
author: James C.

description: The food was soooo goood!! the staff was friendly and quick ... the bathrooms are kind of small and up these weird stairs but whatever.  the neighborhood is kind of scary but I would go back for the food anytime
author: Sukie H.

description: I think it's just about the best Thai I've had. Very spicy, very fresh, pretty presentation and reasonably priced. Everything on the plate is just right...and then they seem to insist on stereotypically bad easy-listening tunes. Which is endearing and totally fitting, somehow. Celine Dion, anyone?
author: Annee T.

description:
Wonderful Food! Very Authentic!
Silly people that can't understand the fact that they are really Thai people from Thailand... but the food can be amazing if you order like you know there is more to thai food than Pad Thai ;P
Try things you've not heard of and you may be surprised. They also make an iced Herb Drink I have only seen in Thailand- delicious.
I did have a slight edge when I have been there, I had a thai friend with me and so we managed a nice feast that could have been served on the beaches of the islands... ahhhh * pats his tummy* yummm
author: RojiFox Q.

description:
This is closer to 3.5 stars...4 stars because ultimately, as Tony, so eloquently put it,  in the battle of man vs. food, man won.  What am I talking about??

I love Thai food, I eat Thai food all the time. Lers Ros' menu is super expansive with lots of more unique offerings that appeal to my curious foodie side.  We straggled in around 10pm last nite, so we decided to opt for a smattering of the foods that have come highly recommended.  We ordered :1 ) Garlic quail which came with a hot dipping sauce; 2)Som Tom Koong Yang (Shredded green papaya salad with chili, tomatoes, lime based salad dressing & GRILLED PRAWNs); 3) the highly recommended Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (Stir-fried pork belly with crispy rind, Basil leaves, with red bell peppers, and green beans cut up to look like scallions); and 4) Kaeng Pah Pla Hed-Khon (Smelt fish in broth made from house made chili paste, young pepper corn and galingale).  The food was delicious and spicy and full of heat, save the fact for the papaya salad which was CRAZY spicy and packed with both dried chili flakes and chili seeds. The super duper heat kicked my ass, burned my throat, and left a bitter sensation in my mouth. I was concerned for about 5 minutes, as I ate the cabbage on the plate, and the cucumbers from the fried quail, all the while drinking water, as I tried to get rid of the bitter sensation from my mouth. I wasn't enjoying the flavors of the papaya salad since all I could feel was heat and the bitter sensation.

Once my taste buds came around, and the bitter sensation went away, I enjoyed the rest of my meal. I don't think I would order the fried quail again. I rather enjoy quail, but deep frying it makes the meat rather dry, and I like the meat to be more moist and tender.  The pork belly was delicious, the sauce was great, the crispy rind is reminiscent of a great Asian style roast pork.  I loved the smelt fish broth! The broth is like a spicy tom yum gong soup. The young peppercorn and galingale add a whole new level of spiciness to the soup. The bamboo shoots complimented the dish well. It was delicious.

After we both got a handle on the heat level of the food, we were able to adjust our spiciness threshold and conquer the papaya salad. Although, if I were to order that dish again, I would ask for mild (which I'm sure will still pack a fair amount of heat). We left satisfied and quite full at around 11:15pm. A family with 3 little kids came in, and other couples were still streaming in. Oh, did I also mention that a majority of the menu items (save the sea bass and trout dishes and a few other specialities) all clock in at under 10 dollars? Delicious, affordable, with definite kick your ass abilities.
author: Annie Y.

description: Spicy and yummy. The best authentic Thai restaurant. I'm from Thailand, so the taste is the closet to what I can get  back home. I always ordered papaya salad/ crab and Larb.
author: Pach P.

description: We celebrated my room mate's birthday here. They did a nice job of accommodating for our huge group. I think I got enough to eat. The food doesn't stand out but I enjoyed the time.
author: Kathleen T.

description: First time I was introduced to this place was from my international friends straight from Thailand.  I enjoy other "Thai" places that cater to the western taste, but sometimes I miss Thailand.   So I was so happy to enjoy authentic Thai food...dude...check out the menu...they have "game" meats.  Real stuff..lol  When ask for Thai spicy...it's spicy!
author: Poppy M.

description: Yum! Got take out from here last night and everything was delicious...would recommend an app other than the fried tofu, since there are much more interesting items. Had the green veggie curry and the pad see-ew, also ordered pad thai, but were too full to make it to the third dish.
author: Elle N M.

description: Great food! Great service! They add just the right amount of spice.
author: Rafael S.

description: Diverse and affordable menue, clean environment, awesome service, we loved everything we had and wanted to eat more.  Can't wait to go back and they are open to midnight!
author: Loralyn S.

description: I love this place more than words. I hate to review it because it's already quite popular. Eat here in person-  delivery sometimes takes over an hour and a half, expect longer if it's raining.
author: J.D. H.

description: This place is great!  I think it's my favorite Thai place in the city.  They serve all types of meat including rabbit, frog, and alligator (although I haven't tried any of that there).  Other than those exotic items, they also serve some really good standard Thai fare.  I love the green and red curry here.  The papaya salad is also amazing.  The pieces of papaya are really big, and you should ask for them to make it mild unless you're not scared of heat, because they make it really spicy here.  Oh, and the Thai Ice tea here is a great value.  The drink is huge... I think it's the size of two Thai Ice Teas elsewhere.  I love this place and would eat here more often if the location was more convenient.  The flavors have been consistently delicious, they're open late, the portions are reasonable, and the prices are affordable.
author: Tyler C.

description: Great thai food, friendly staff, and an awesome lunch deal to sample around.
author: Casey A.

description: Heard this place was worth checking out some from friends, they were right!  Made reservations on Friday night for Saturday night, no problem.  Called again Saturday afternoon to increase the size of the reservation, no problem.  We were seated quickly, and drinks came soon after that.  We were a party of 14, and for the size the food came fast.  Everyone loved the food, and the amount that was served.  I gave 5 stars because the quality and amount of food for the price was excellent.  Plus, quick walk to dive bars on geary afterwards!
author: Andrew S.

description: What can I say that hasn't already been said? It's great! The whole fish is amazing, the coconut soup is amazing, the beef is amazing...well, you get the point. Great service, fresh and hot food, nice and calm atmosphere, and they take card. Oh, they also deliver. Everytime I look at their menu, I want to get everything! It sounds so good, and it really is good. It's definately worth going to, and keep going back to (or ordering delivery from). I will be back there soon enough since my husband and I absolutely love it.
author: Katia T.

description: Can't really find any fault to knock any starts off!  Came here from Lafayette - one of perhaps 2 restaurants managed to find in the Bay area with frogs legs on their menu.  Missed them so much since moving from NY 12 yrs ago.  went last Sat. no reservation for 7pm, waited perhaps 10 mins seated promptly.  Service was excellent and even though not much english was spoken, smiling goes along way and received plenty of those!  Didn't have to wait for anything.  Chose about 5 appetizers and one main meal to share with 3 - some spare to take home!  No frogs legs spare though - could have done with a few  more but then that's me being greedy! Was worth the trip from East Bay for this one time - parking was easy, just 2 doors down.  You won't be disappointed.
author: D B.

description: I'm gonna guess this is what Thai food is really supposed to be. Rustic yet refined, and ultra spicy. My mind was simply blown. At the suggestion of my fellow yelpers, I tried to green papaya salad with prawns. So spicy, and packed full of wonderful different textures, with a nice smokey prawn flavor. We also decided to order some fried chicken over fried rice, the stir-fried pork belly and the catfish. I loved everything but the catfish had the skin and bones still attached to it and for novice fisheaters it wouldn't be very ideal. Also we had some of the best thai iced coffee and tea... it was amazing. The service was quite attentive, and even though we arrived close midnight we didn't feel rushed to finish our food and get out. We enjoyed a nice, long dinner and some of the best South Asian food I've ever had. I think this is my new favorite Thai restaurant.
author: Y K.

description: Absolutely the best Thai food in the down town area!  Perhaps it's not ideal for a date but if you want to share a good Thai food with your  friends, this is the place to come.  I particularly love their lunch deal - very reasonable and generous.
author: Fuschia Jane B.

description: while they've got interesting options such as rabbit and alligator on the menu, the pork belly dish i kept hearing about was really the only thing i absolutely had to order on this menu. who could resist the fatty tender rich crisp hog with a side of rice? not me. it was delectable, awesome and made me want to keel over after my meal. i can't wait until they open up their second location in Hayes Valley!
author: Regina C.

description: This is possibly the best Thai I ever ate. Wow, came here for lunch and was swept off my feet by the taste and the flavors.  We actually went back that same night as we just wanted to try out more. Their soups are simply delicious and so is the Pad Thai ... I still get water in my mouth when I think about it ... check this out but expect to wait at night as it attracks an incredible crowd.
author: Tania Y.

description: Amazing. Haven't had Thai food like this since Bangkok. Visited the place on a business trip based on Yelp recommendations and could not have been more pleased. Friendly & attentive service. Prices are great. Truly deserving of five stars.
author: Michael C.

description: I recently had my friend Nik grab take out for us from this place. I haven't actually been inside but the food was tasty. It's definitely ABOVE average thai food and moderately priced. Expected bill $8. I had pad thai and the green curry - both are worth trying. Lers Ros is in the tenderloin so if you're an uppity type person, you may want to try out Osha Thai on 2nd Street, where it's not so ghetto.
author: Tushar K.

description: It's really really spicy, and it' smack dab in the loin, if this aint your thing, there are plenty of thai elsewhere.
author: Jonas D.

description:
I've been looking forward to trying Lers Ros for over a year now, and was sorely disappointed:

Crispy pork - from other reviews this is the hallmark dish to have, but maybe we got there too early & they had to re-fry left over pork from the previous day.  The pork was not crispy so much as it was dried out like jerky.  Overlooking that, the seasoning just wasn't a showstopper.

Stir fried chicken w/ homemade chili sauce - again the sauce was nothing special even though I could see fibers of herbs and it was clearly homemade.

Minced catfish salad - the catfish was right on as was the dressing.  But the salad part was just a bunch of iceberg, a couple slices of bell pepper, a little cilantro, maybe a few shreds of papaya.  Half of it was good and the other half was disappointing.  I much prefer Chai Thai's version in Oakland.

Plus:  very friendly and very bright and clean
Minus:  a little on the expensive side

Next time we're in the area, we'll go to Sai Jai which was much, much better.  Otherwise it's back to Oakland for those A+ Laotian restaurants.
author: L A.

description: i love the crispy pork belly and the duck salad.  if you don't like the 'hood, go to the hayes valley location (i'm looking at you marina peeps...)
author: Shannon C.

description:
i've died and gone to thai heaven!!
