this place blows ALL the thai food experience i have ever had out of the water! 

the raw prawns were spicy but shrimptastic, pork intestine and pickled vegetable soup was delicious and not greasy at all, pork belly rice had just the right amount of crispiness (i'm trying to gain weight!), and the on choy was fresh and garlicy. They definitely do have the regular pad thai and curries but the other stuff is much more interesting!

the decor is modern and the service is fast! price is very reasonable in SF. LOVE IT!

i can't wait to go back and try everything.. especially the sticky rice w/DURIAN!

the only down side i could think of is that i wouldn't recommend walking in this neighborhood by yourself (especially at night!) since it's in the tenderloin district but don't let that deter you from this awesome dining experience. just bring a buddy. It's close to the Civic Center Bart Station, just go north on Larkin St and it's right before O'Farrell St.
author: Marian C.

description: I feel bad saying this because I had an excellent meal there but they served pork that was clearly past its due date the second time that I went.  Sorry but that's unforgiveable.
author: Cruz E.

description: Yum what diverse dishes. Loved the fried trout and pork belly! Tried to shy away from traditional Thai dishes but the curry was good as well. Very nice decor nestled in the heart of TL.
author: Jeanne C.

description: It was hard to find seats on a Saturday night (my friend and I were seated at the bar) but the options here are far more extensive than your typical Thai place. The pork belly was fattening and delicious, but the #69 beef soup was a little too salty/tamarindy for my tastes. We parked two blocks away and passed by two piles of (human?) diarrhea on the way there. Hooray, TL.
author: Mandy H.

description: If you're Thai, you'll know that this place serves REAL authentic thai food. Everything here is good, and the price is right!
author: Kristy N.

description: Two friends and I went there on New Years Eve day after ringing the bell at the Asian Art Museum about 3 blocks away.  For a very gritty neighborhood it was surprisingly lovely inside, clean and warm on a cold day and friendly.  The food was excellent and we were very happy with the service.
author: Stephen S.

description:
This was a pretty good place, we ordered the recommended fried rice with crispy chicken (THIS WAS OFF THE HOOK, it tasted like Angel wings, except it wasn't stuffed), drunken noddle (#76)... disappointed, basically it was dry style stir fry beef noddle, and wayyyy to spicy. Beef noddle soup (#70), and another noddle plate, which was the wet style stir fry noddle, which was REALLY SALTY!! so let's see... Wasn't crowded when we got there at 10ish, the parking was whacked,badness, is the word to describe it, 
Also got some dessert, sticky rice with durian, whoa, that smell is strong, as much as I durian, disappointment. Also, got the reguar fried banana and ice cream, I get the banana being friend and all, its already hecka sweet, no need to put more honey, making is wayyy sweet. 
Umm, one more thing, after my friend also finish his water, he was looking in his water, and noticed a fly's wing... at the bottom. We had a good time debating whether it is a mosquito, or fly, but eventually settle that is yummy protein, after rock climbing!!
author: Monika T.

description: The best Thai food I have had in the city. There have another location near Davies Hall. It is a good place to eat before a concert.
author: Will G.

description: Def. had better.  Ordered the pad kee mow.  Chicken was bland, food wasn't spicy at all, and I don't know if I have a sixth sense for this...but there was a certain smell to the food which reminded me of bad Thai.
author: akshay c.

description: I agree with Vithiet K. on the authenticity. This place is awesome. I just returned from a trip to Thailand this Monday, and had been in the northeast city of Chiang Mai two days earlier. I had the northeastern thai sausage in Thailand and 48 hours later I had the same dish at Lers Ros - it was identical. Delicious. Great service. Well done Lers Ros! My new favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco. :-)
author: Bobby G.

description: This is hands down the best Thai restaurant in the best food city in America. If you have to wait an hour, do it. You won't regret it for one second. AROI
author: Victor M.

description:
I took a visiting business associate and self-certified asian food snob here the other night.  We had the garlic frog, green papaya salad, thai style sausage (spectacular), some sort of alligator dish, crab fried rice and a grilled beef dish recommended by the waitress.

Every dish was excellent, a couple were truly stellar.  The service was impeccable, and six dishes plus 5 beers totaled $88 (lucky, huh?).  

I would have thought it was a great meal at twice the price.  I'll be a regular!
author: Ken G.

description:
I've been to this restaurant once shortly after they first opened to try it out.  Outside looks nice and the decor inside is also very nice.  I had lunch there and it was also good... (I got the quail).

It wasn't until that night that my stomach started to feel weird and it wasn't until the next day that I got a medium case of diarrhea.  I was pondering whether I got food poisoning from lunch or dinner.  I seriously doubt that it's dinner because it was all shared foods and none of my other 7 friends got sick.  So, I am pretty sure it was lunch at Lers Ros, especially since I got quail and it's probably not a dish that customers order alot.

In any case, I still always pass by this restaurant and I always have the urge to go in again but then after remembering my case with food poisoning, I decide not to take the chance.  Anyone else have a similar experience?
author: Max M.

description: My new favorite Thai joint.  Yes, there are tons out there, but this one stands out!  And trust me, in my 10 years living in the city, I've tried many, many others and have basically subdued myself to just Manora and Marnee since the rest never compared, or was just about the same.
author: Mag K.

description: They have the best Thai food I have had in SF. It is a small place, and you sometimes have to wait awhile to get a table. The staff is nice. They have a huge selection of menu items. They were even able to accomodate my wife gluten free request.
author: Lars E.

description: I come in here once, sometimes twice a week. The staff is very friendly and remembers who you are. Everything I've had has been delicious. I love the taste of the green curry and I like that they use Thai eggplant and they don't skimp on the seafood or veggies. The papaya salad is very good and I love the tom yum koong! The fried quail is one of my favorite appetizers along with the fried rolls, chicken satay, and fried tofu. The pan fried noodle dishes are all very tasty, my favorite is pad see-ew with prawns and the pad kee mow. I really love the koong kra prow which is prawns stir fried with basil and chili sauce. The kao pad kai tod (crispy chicken with fried rice) is very good too! I've never had something here that I didn't like.
author: Lucia V.

description: I enjoyed the food here.  The presentation was well-done, and the food was solid.  One of the highlights of the food was how clean, crisp, and fresh the ingredients and dishes were.  I enjoyed the pork shoulder salad.  I was less overjoyed with the pad kee mao; the noodles were good, but I got it with beef, and the beef was a bit tough (not very tender or flavorful).  Overall, it seems like a good place for decent Thai dishes.
author: Notmy R.

description: Stopped by late on a Friday night. No ambience but the food was freakin awesome! Had the chicken red curry, Tom yum soup and the whole fried tilapia. Each dish was perfect with no taste overlap.
author: Rooney N.

description: Sorry, I don't get it.  The food at Lers Ros was good, but I don't understand what everyone is raving about.  The best for me was the green papaya salad - too spicy for my dinner partner.  The worst was the frog legs, which was too bone-y and not enough meat.  The chicken curry and thick noodles with gravy (I forget the name, but it's the one that everyone recommended we order) were good, but again, not outstanding.  I liked that I could make reservations and that the prices were reasonable but this may have been another case of overblown expectations.
author: Melinda C.

description: I unknowingly did a repeat dine here, and I didn't regret it. We arrived for an early dinner at 5:30 and within 30m, the whole doorway was blocked by people waiting for tables. Good sign. Service was really fast and attentive enough. The menu is pretty overwhelming, because they have a ton of choices. Ordered combo pad thai, prad prik king (spicy green beans) with beef and fried tilapia with house hot and sweet sauce (originally ordered the fried trout with mango sauce but they ran out). The pad thai had a ton of meat (beef, chicken, pork, shrimp, and tofu) and was your standard preparation. Nicely done. The green beans were super spicy and crunchy. The fish was big and crispy. It had a decent amount of meat, but I think the pomfret that most other Thai restos use for this dish has more meat than the tilapia. They pour a ton of garlicky, sweet and spicy sauce over the fish, and it totally makes the dish. If you eat the fish alone, it's a bit bland but the sauce sends it through the roof. My only complaint is that the beef that they use (in both the beans dish and the pad thai) was so chewy and difficult to eat. They need to use a better cut or tenderize their meat. Nasty. Otherwise, top notch Thai.
author: Catherine N.

description:
I'm joining my friends Andrey C and Jeremy H in declaring this my favorite Thai restaurant.  The menu offers way more selection (in fact I was overwhelmed by the selection) than any other Thai place in the city, and the fact that it's open until 2am means that I'm less likely to hit up Osha for my late night Thai fix now.  

I went with a group of 5 and the service was prompt and friendly.   Decor is modern and clean and it really doesn't feel like you're in the middle of the TL.  5 of us shared

Every dish we had was flavorful - we had the the stewed pork leg, crispy chicken with fried rice, fish paste green curry, duck larb, rad nah, and papaya salad with shrimp.  

Some thoughts on each dish:
Duck Larb: My hands-down favorite was the duck larb - the next time I go I'm getting my own and I'm not sharing!  

Papaya Salad: I love spicy foods, and this definitely had quite a kick.  Delicious, but be warned that it's spicy!  

Stewed pork leg: I'm not normally a fan of stewed meats, but this was cooked just right  - not too tough, and not overly soft.  Subtle flavors made this a popular dish at the table. 

Crispy chicken with fried rice: they must've put crack in this.  It's definitely Asian-style fried chicken, but with a slightly sweet flavor.  The fried rice that comes with it is some of the best fried rice I've ever had - they must put crack in it!

Fish paste green curry: It's probably not a dish for everyone, but if you want green curry with non-fishy fish in chunks with a consistency similar to fish cakes this is the dish for you.  The green curry had just enough spice in it and was flavorful.  I could probably just have the curry with rice and I'd be happy.

Rad nah: not one of my favorite Thai dishes (I prefer the drier noodles), but this was still tasty with a not-too-watery, not-too-thick gravy and plenty of meat and veggies.
author: Irene W.

description: I love this place!!! I ate here for the 2nd time yesterday and the food did not disappoint. I had the duck noodle soup, salty spicy pork salad and the pork shoulder. All very delicious!!! I have family who are traditional Thai cooks and being there tasted like home. There is no better Thai food in the city!
author: Harry K.

description:
one of the best authentic thai food in sf. 

if you complain about pad thai and yellow curry perhaps you haven't really eaten thai food, only american thai. you know, a little like if you think the california roll is authentic japanese cuisine.
they have dishes here that are hard to find, not always complimentary to the american taste, but it's authentic and provides me the most affordable trip home.

be careful when you ask for spicy as your lips will be on fire.

pork shoulder, kanaa moo krob, bbq shrimp som tum, yummy hot pot soups, whole fried fish...
author: sai h.

description: tasty traditional thai food. duck larb and fried fish was tasty!
author: Daniel N.

description: Lers Ros has easily become my favorite Thai place in the city HANDS DOWN. If you want an authentic absolutely delicious and inexpensive meal there is really no choice in the matter but to come here. I won't go into recommending specific dishes because you really can't go wrong. I feel like I've tried half the menu but I don't think I'm close yet since there is so much to choose from.
author: Jon N.

description: Excellent. Tastes, variety, service and price. Most likely the most authentic and pleasant I have eaten in since last I was in Bangkok. Be prepared to wait for a table, be patient, as the service staff is most efficient, and effective!
author: Frank F.

description:
I went through an incredible "Lers Ros is crack" phase when this joint opened, and I had it delivered to my Loin apartment once every three or four days. I can't say I've tried a lot of the menu, but I do know that the Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (#62) is nearly heaven on earth. It's fried pork bellies with a delightfully crispy rind. I had no idea what pork bellies should taste like, but if this is any indication I'm going to bite the next pig I see. The seasoning is spicy but not too hot, and there's a nice amount of food given. Also, the prawn curry rocks everything you know. 

The menu's huge, and I'm sure there are some clunkers - the chicken satay is mediocre, for one. But the gems of this place are so damn good, and it's easy for two people to be completely stuffed and boozed up for less than $30. They also deliver if you're near their Loin location. Try it once. Go during the day if you're a wuss because it is a seedy neighborhood. They're also open til 2 or 4 a.m., and it makes for a great late-night much spot.
author: Marin P.

description: This place is great.  They're the Evander Holyfield of Thai, coming to knock Mike "Basil Thai" Tyson the f out. Lots of biting involved. Biting into some delicious Thai standards, and some stuff you've probably never heard of before. Eating on here is a tour of Thailand. You get to try Bangkok street food, and food cooked up north. You eat fish and chicken, but frog, quail, eel, and rabbit too. A carnivore's dream.
author: Zach F.

description: This place has a huge selection! The first time me and my boyfriend looked at the menu we were overwhelmed as to what we should try- quail? ox? frog legs? We've come back multiple times and everytime the food was both yummy and the ingredients tasted fresh. Oh! And the prices are more than reasonable.
author: Melanie G.

description: SO GOODDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDD im craving the duck larb salad right now
author: Cindy L.

description: Ordered delivery and specifically asked how long it will take as I have a little one to feed (she loves their chicken noodle soup). They said "about an hour." I requested to make it sooner if they can, but an hour is fine. An hour later, no food. I call the restaurant and the manager "Wan" says its on the way. A few minutes later she calls back and says it hasnt even been cooked yet. What? An hour later and my food hasnt even been cooked?? She says I told you it will take "over an hour." I firmly told her no, you did not. you said about an hour and besides if my food hasnt even been cooked it will certainly take an hour and 45 min! To which she said "sorry we will just cancel it." Really? After making us wait for an hour you are going to just "cancel it." She had nothing to say and nothing to offer. A decent place wouldve offered to just pick up the tab (it was only $30) or at the very least offered a discount for such horrible service. Needless to say will never eat here or order from here. Save yourself the trouble and go to other more competent and well managed Thai restaurants.
author: Ruhee R.

description: Would be nice to know I live outside of your delivery range BEFORE I give you my credit card information and wait 15 minutes.  Quite disappointing.
author: Liza D.

description: What a find! Lers Ros, while hard to say, is easy to eat at. Fantastic, authentic Thai food that you soon crave to get back to. It's a bare bones eating establishment with some iffy service, but the food is you need to know. Special favorite is the beef with lime juice. Spicey & delicious!
author: Shannon r.

description: Totally a fan! The staff is super friendly,the place was super clean, the food came fast, was super yummy and cheap! pad Thai for 6.50$ yes please! The portion was big so I felt like I got more bang for my buck. Definitely will be going back for cheap lunch specials.
author: Chris T.

description:
Damn this shit was good!
It's a pretty ordinary looking Thai restaurant - fluorescent lights during the day, somewhat fancier mini halogens at night; there's a bar on the left side that I'd be curious to see if they ever use.  But the food is where it's at.  The menu is enormous - seriously, something like 8 pages of goodness.
The Thai iced teas are big, and nice & tangy.
The Thai Puffs (on the specials list) - chicken & spices, and other assorted deliciousness stuffed inside 4 pastry puffs - are amazing.  Seriously.  I love peanut sauce; I'll put that shit on anything, but these were so good that I kept having trouble deciding whether to just eat them alone, or dip them in the sauce.
Thai herb sausage appetizer - also fantastic.  Not too greasy, and fantastic flavor.
Pad Thai - honestly, I'd never met a Pad Thai I was a big fan of before this.  It has a richness, sweetness and intensity of flavor that just really turned me on.  The only oddity was that the noodles seemed slightly undercooked (they were decidedly al dente).  Not sure if that was intentional or not, but it left them pretty chewy.
Green curry chicken - plenty of kick, all white-meat chicken, and a great mixed pile of veggies in it including red bell pepper and Thai eggplant, but the flavor was only so-so.  I think Basil Thai still makes my favorite green curry in SF (in terms of the sauce itself).

But by the end of the evening, we'd had 4 dishes, 2 Thai teas, were totally stuffed, and had a bunch of leftovers for a whopping... $30.
Awesome.
You're damn right I'll be back.
author: Don H.

description:
This was the best Thai food I've had since Thai Kitchen (Spokane) and Thai Tom's (Seattle).  And I am a pad thai expert as well as VERY picky.
We waited for our table for about ten minutes.  There was a table of fourteen taking up damn near half the restaurant, but the staff seemed to be trying to accommodate everyone.  After being seated we watched with hungry eyes as food drifted past us to other tables- including soup tureens that were flaming- very cool.
We ordered #78 (pad thai, of course), #102 (stir fried clams in sweet chile), and #62 (stir fried pork belly) and none of it disappointed.  The Pad thai came with prawns ( I prefer chicken) but once I tasted the noodles and the sauce I had no complaiints.  Perfectly cooked and perfectly spiced.  The clams were very tasty- admitedly we only ate the clams from the shells, ignoring the delicious broth and the veggies, but I still believe it was worth it.  The pork belly we ate on rice.  It was crispy and soothing- although it had a tad too much fish sauce for my taste.
We brought the leftovers back to our hotel and they will be gone very, very soon.
This place was so authentic that that the hostess barely understood when I asked for plastic forks with my leftovers.  Excellent.
Ambience:  Not good, but I don't give a crap when it comes to thai food.  The place in Spokane is an old ballet studio and the place in Seattle is literally a hole-in-the-wall.
Service:  Prompt, even if they didn't understand my request for plastic utensils they did well.
Cleanliness: VERY clean.
Would come here many more times!
Have I mentioned all of this was for thirty bucks?
author: Kara R.

description: Wow, this place is great!  Amidst all the bland thai restaurants around now, Lers Ros has a lot of creative dishes, and I've loved every thing I've had there so far.  Entrees run 7-10$.  Delivery is free and quick - they told me 45min and I had my food in 20.  Definitely going to keep eating here!
author: Stephen D.

description: pretty awesome place for cheap thai food ! this place is like half thai restaurant and half sports bar with multiple flat screens for you sports fans out there ! For me presentation plays a major role in helping me to decide whether i'll return for more or tell everyone to stay away ! The service here is not too shabby, i can always count of my water being filled after i drink it half way. The food here is great, the curry is awesome, the service is good, the waitresses there are like hawks waiting for their customers to give them a look and a whole group of them will come over to your table to help you out. more attention than we wanted, but it's cool at least it would be nearly impossible for them to screw up with more than 3 people standing at your table. street parking was pretty easy, our bill did not come out to more than 25 plus tip =)  excellent place to go to when you're working with a budget !
author: Jeff C.

description:
These reviews are part of a series where my Vancouverite friend wanted to try a bunch of food carts all weekend.  We ended up deviating to some other cheap eats.

The contestants:  Lers Ros Thai, Fritzj, Adobo Hobo, Pizza Hacker, Gumbo Cart, Lumpia Cart, Bi-Rite Creamery, El Farolito, Bacon Dog Cart, Pho Garden, Zante's Indian Pizza

This review is about Lers Ros Thai.  When my visiting friend wanted to try some authentic Thai, the first place I thought of was Lers Ros Thai.  It is just as good as Sai Jai Thai but not as crowded and I would venture to say even marginally better.  The one drawback is that it does not have Sai Jai Thai's supposedly-ridiculously-amazing mango and sticky rice dessert that Sai Jai Thai has when mangoes are in season.  (Personally don't like that dessert but even I had to say it was not bad there)

This was my fourth time eating here and my tips on food are:
Chicken Satay - pretty good but not amazing
Papaya Salad with Salted Duck egg - oh so delectable!  Maybe I'm biased because I love salty duck eggs but the salad definitely tastes better than most I've had.  I'm a glutton for punishment but for most people, their "mild or spicy" translates  to "spicy or killer"
Tom Kreang Nai - I love sour soups but this dish didn't go so well with the others
Pad See Ew - Excellent!  Noodles and Chinese broccoli cooked to perfection
Rad Nah - my personal favorite.  Take this and pour the gravy all over some of their rice (to be ordered separately).  It's the Southern gal in me coming out!
Kuay Tiew Phed Toon - nobody's favorite.  It was okay and I was the only one who kept drinking the strangely dark and full-bodied soup.  Also, I was the only one who felt sick afterwards so.... Draw your own conclusions....
Pad Kraw Pow?? -  This was one of my absolutely favorite new dishes but I can't remember the name.   It is NOT larb but is ground pork stir fried with some red bell pepper.  Will update this review when I go back but it was SO DELECTABLE!
Rice soups are okay, like a version of congee where the rice is not as mushed up.

Unless you are going in the daytime, I usually avoid this area.  Take out is always an option though!  They are incredibly fast with that!  (~10m)
author: Susan L.

description: Great food!  Great price!  Generous portions!  I often travel to Thailand, and I must say this is as close to home cooking as it gets, plus you get the American style portions.  I even had the the stew pork over rice plate of which I've never seen offered here in the states.  Naturally, I ordered it, and brings reminders of time spent in Thailand!  Highly recommended!
author: Wai T.

description:
I am not the kind of a person who sits down and write a review. So far none and this is my fist ever review about any thing because If I don't write a review I dont feel justified for THE DELICIOUS & AUTHENTIC  Thai food from Lers Ros. It was THe BEST Thai food In bay area. I lived in Thailand for 7 years and I could find none of the Thai restaurant In Santa Clara, San Jose, Sunnyvale , Stockton, Sacramento and San diego come close to the real taste of Thai food. Thank God I finally found THE PLACE where I get all the Authentic dishes with authentic taste.KOh moo yang and  Moo Krob, which, I couldn't find in any of the Thai restaurant I had been before. I do want to mention their Tom Yum Gai (tom yum chicken soup, which is not in the menu but they will make it) , which is one of the best , as tasty as you drink from a Bangkok street restaurant.  We went there yesterday ( Sunday) after noon it was not crowded, not much wait time, free parking on the street (its week end), and the authentic Thai food!! . WHAT A PERFECT AFTERNOON!!

we had,

larb phed Yang # 25 - superb!

Koh moo yang #9 -- Can't describe, Thought I was back in Thailand

Tom yum Kai  #28- the best tom yum in bay area so far

Kao pad kai thod - good'

kaeng keaw wan taley #100 - good

Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob (#62 - superb!

Fried banana  with ice cream - Aroi Mak !!!

All reasonably priced!!
author: T T.

description: This is the way thai food should be. Authentic style. Every dish was a home run. The Som Tom with the raw crabs was  wonderful.  Tom Yum was flavorful and delicious to the last slurp.  Cannot wait to go back for more.
author: David V.

description:
a new joint supposedly to be Thai-style similar to Sai Jai Thai, which is just right around the corner. 

i enjoyed the ka pao gai with two fried eggs over-easy. i usually try this dish at every Thai restaurant i go to, this one makes it pretty damn tasty. there is another dish my wife orders. don't know the name. it's a curry dish with egg and shrimp. seems this place is the only place that makes it and is pretty damn tasty too. I've only had those two dishes and i've been here like 5 times in the past two weeks.

Oh...wait...the steamed fish and beef jerky is pretty good too. had that the first time i came here.
author: Glyde W.

description:
I still have no idea how to pronounce the name of this restaurant but it has quickly become my goto Thai restaurant.  I can't comment on the dining atmosphere because I have only ordered for delivery.  I can say that their food is TOP notch and their delivery is super fast.  

One of their dishes, the Larb Duck is outstanding.  It's the best version I've ever had from any thai place.  Also good are their curries, the noodle dishes, etc.  I don't think you could go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Michael B.

description: The best and most unique Thai food I've had.  Not the run of the mill "Pad Thai" thai restaurant.  My favorites are the stir-fry pork belly and shrimp paste fried rice.  Be prepared for a little spice, but the burn is more than worth the flavor.
author: Ch V.

description: Best Thai delivery in San Francisco. Hands down.
author: Randi W.

description: Lers Ros, which should probably be spelled Lert Rot, is a great little Thai restaurant, situated right around the corner from my other favorite Sai Jai Thai.  These two restaurants, while offering different specialties, are the closest to authentic Thai food in SF.  A fairly new establishment, that offers very tasty Thai dishes at reasonable prices.
author: Gregory C.

description: Authentic beyond belief, so it's the best Thai in the city. Ask your server to explain the specials written in Thai, because they live on the border of wonderous and strange :-)  Be prepared for real Thai levels of spice - hot hot hot - so query and order according to your tastes. My favorites so far: the eel served Asian style with all bones included, adding richness and reminding me of travel in Thailand. And a Yum Woon Sen salad unlike anything else you'll encounter in SF. Great prices, and very personable staff. Yum!
author: Geoff W.

description: This is my new favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco.  Adventurous, extensive, delicious.  Nom nom nom nom nom!  Support them so they don't go away, please!
author: Jess L.

description: This place will kick your butt....that is if you like spicy food to the extreme! They are not shy with ethnic flavors like stinky and tasty shrimp paste...a definite acquired taste and not for the meek. We tried the larb duck salad and it packed so much heat I had to go towel off in the restroom. The flavors were so intense I could have eaten 5 bowls of rice with it and been done! The duck was very guttural as it was hacked into tiny pieces and there were still some bone chips in the salad. The fish cake special was the best dish we had as the cakes were freshly made and the kaffir lime leaves and chili paste added real kapow to another super-spiced dish. The curry was pedestrian and still packed a punch...and even the shrimp paste fried rice with duck eggs was over the top as I had to add white rice to it to tone it down. Most restaurants cannot keep the flavors this intense as the public milder palate will push the owners to mute the flavors but then this place is known for kicking it up a wholenathalevel! Really ***1/2 as service is very nice!!!
author: Gregory C.

description: The most amazing Thai food I've had in SF.  We drive all the way from the east bay just to eat here. I've not tried everything on the menu, but their main dishes, curries, dry noodles are amazing. I do howerver, think that their beef noodle soup (boat soup) is not as good as other places in the area.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Ordered delivery from here. Delivery service was good and prompt. 

Food was very good; but cannot give a better rating because I had problems with the value for $. Containers were small and they came half empty! 

While the food was good it was not amazing; for the price there is much better food in the city and much better Thai food
-Moo Phing was delicious (the star)
-Beef strir fried with mixed vegetable was ok but a bit bland (tiny portion)
-Chicken stir fired with ginger and onions was good but nothing special (another tiny portion)
author: ej l.

description: I usually like to go to Sai Jai for thai when I'm in the tederloin but happened upon this place and gave it a try. It was well worth it. I had a crispy chicken served with sweet chili sauce and also included garlic and ginger rice and a clear broth.Worth trying!
author: Jack B.

description: I had heard such good things about this place, so I was pretty disappointed with my experience here.  Unlike many of the other places in the immediate neighborhood, this place is comfortable, clean, has nice decor and very friendly staff.  But I thought the food was pretty uneven.  The curry puffs were fine, but a little bland.  The papaya salad with prawns was so spicy that no other flavors came through.  I had pad see ew, and the flavor was fine, but the noodles were way too soft.  Boyfriend had pad kee maw, which was also quite spicy, but the flavors of the food came through more, and it was a more successful dish.
author: Danielle G.

description: I went here for lunch.  The food was amazing!  The Duck was very tasty.  Everything we had was top notch.  Highly recommend!
author: Kayin D.

description: Lunch specials are really cool - I like that you get two options for your entrees. The food was standard and well prepared. It was worth the price.
author: Erin M.

description: Very authentic Thai papaya salad.  Nice portions
author: Black S.

description:
Great menu selection 4 stars
Free Champagne 5 stars
Service 2.5   stars
Food 2               Big let down today, will be better next time.

The expansive menu caused me to select this place out of 20 places in my bookmark. I was drawn to items like Frogs, Rabbits and steamed sea bass. When we arrived, we were given free champagne because it was new years eve. We were very happy even though it was very little like 1/4 of glass.  It is the thought that counts.

We had these dishes.

1. Papaya salad with RAW crab 
I like surprises, but this one I did not like. I got raw blue crab in shells and legs. After a long day, I just want something easy to eat, not to have to pick/dig the meat out of small raw crab.  
2. The only famous Sausage on the menu
   Two of us love it,  two of us did not like it. It was spiced well, and texture of the meat was perfect, not too chewy or dry.  I liked it.
3. Soup in flaming pot with stuffed Squid
Everybody else got a flaming pot, our wasn't flaming. That took fun out of the soup.  I can't rave about the soup. No special taste.
4. Eggplant with vegetables/tofu
   This dish was good, not too spicy. Well balanced
5. Stir Fry calamari
    We hated this dish. Awful spicy sauce. Will never order again.
6. Stir Fry calms
   Last dish and best of the entire evening. The sauce was perfect. We licked every calm and sauce.

Overall 2.5  stars for the food.
I had high of expectation from the rave reviews. But when I got there, the rabbit and frog were served deep fried. So I had to skip the dishes.
You can get steamed sea bass or steamed fish at many Chinese restaurants. The papaya salad was a huge letdown. Out of the 6 dishes we ordered, only one we really like. I tried to get our group to go back and taste more dishes, I thought maybe we ordered the wrong dishes. Nobody wanted to go back. Oh well. 

About the service. 2.5 stars
The table we had was so small it cannot fit all the food when it comes. it was so crowded my friend knock off his champagne and did not have a sip yet. We wipe the table ourselves. I ask for a table cloth, the girl came with 4 thin slices of the napkin and did not refill his champagne even though he did not even get to sip it yet.  Also, we had to bus our own table because the table was so small, we would pile up two dishes of food into one plate to make more space, and give the dirty plate to the ladies standing. 

As a result of combining two dishes into one dish;  due to the dark light, by accident, I took a piece of green hot pepper and chewed on it, and it was like someone lit a fire inside my mouth. My eyes were watering. I was purging out fire and coughing for a while. It was so dark, my friends could not see how much I was suffering.  I drink ice water for like a half hour. I would not eat and taste anything for a while. 

It wasn't a perfect evening, but hey it is the company you are with. At least that was 4 stars. 

Parking can be painful
author: A Z.

description: I've enjoyed most of the food most of the time. I come here a lot for lunch and dinner on weekends. There are a few dishes like the spicy tofu and eggplant, and my girlfriend enjoys the whole fish. If you don't like a dish, they are generally willing to give you something else to keep you happy. The service is good. It is not the most authentic Thai, but the vegetarian options are good.
author: Andrew Z.

description: i've been here a number of times, both with groups of people, and solo--and every time the service is amazing! add amazing food to top notch customer service and this is hands down one of my favorite restaurants in the city.
author: Kevin W.

description:
how about 3.5 stars?

the yellow curry is pretty decent.  its slightly spicy, and the correct consistency.  

but they dont have duck fried rice.  are you kidding me?  a thai restaurant without duck fried rice?
author: Jason J.

description:
Ever since I have been in the bay area. I havent been able to find any real authentic Thai place until a friend of mine introduce me to this restaurant. 

Most of the dishes in this restaurant are very authentic, delicious and well prepared. Even if few dishes are little bit americanized, I still think it is still ok. Also Waitresses are nice and friendly. 

My fav dishes are "Tom Saab Kra Dook Moo" (thai style spicy and sour soup), Tod man pla krai (fried fish cake) and Kra Praw Moo Krob (crispy pork basil)! 

There are a few things though that I dont like about this place

1) The restaurant is in a very scary looking neighborhood. 

2) During normal meal hours, it is very difficult to get a seat. You will have to call them to reserve a seat beforehand otherwise you will have to wait for a long time for seating.
author: P O.

description: food is great.  very authentic!  locale a little sketch, so just don't walk by yourself to/from at night.  get the pork belly dish!
author: L K.

description: this review is for the GRILLED PORK SHOULDER only. and its pretttttty darn good! =)
author: Lisa N.

description:
Two thumbs up for the red curry and the spicy tofu.  Both were very tasty.  I would eat both of these dishes again.  We came here in search of non touristy authentic thai food.  

I ordered a spicy wide noodle dish...the name escapes me.  After trying the red curry and spicy tofu, I was expecting to  be blown away by the flavors.  Instead I got what tasted like a bland pad see ew.  I started to wonder if I had the right dish so when the waitress came by asking how things were, I asked if this was the spicy noodle dish?  She said, oh is it not spicy?  I said, not at all, but if this is it, I'll just add spice to it myself.  She insisted on fixing it, so she took the plate back.  Out came a new dish with red bell peppers added to it that the original didn't have, plus more thai basil.  

The issue was it was MACH 5 hot.  You could visibly see the entire plate and each noodle coated in red pepper seeds. I couldn't even pick them off.  I tried to eat it, I swear, but after a few bites, I could no longer feel my tongue, my head was going to explode and I was sweating terribly.  My boyfriend said I looked like I was crying and VERY red.  

The waitress noticing my state comes back over and my mouth is so scorched I'm downing my beer so my boyfriend tells her its so hot we can't eat it.   So she insists on taking it back.  It comes back out with the added thai basil and the red bell peppers, and more sauce, but this time without the heat.  

All I can say is, be VERY specific when commenting about your food because the good thing is they will try to get it right, but I'm not sure what got lost in translation between the table, the waitress and the kitchen.
author: Julie C.

description: Decent food for a good price - nothing to brag about but nothing to complain about. I give plenty of praise for being the only place I've been to that doesn't have greasy fried rice! Really, it's delicious and not greasy.
author: Selina L.

description: Being Thai I'm always in search of above avg Thai food in the bay area. If you're looking for something more flavorful and different from ur avg Thai spot I'd recommend Lers Ros.  I believe It's more of a north eastern Thai cuisine so you'll get a lot of plates u don't see at other bland run of the mill Thai spots. Koh moo yang Pork shoulder appetizer is pretty money. The dipping sauce is awesome. Service had been great the few times i've been.  Give the place a try. Don't think you'll be disappointed.
author: Dirty S.

description: Went there on a Saturday afternoon, service was attentive but food was disappointing - taste was not on par with Sai Jai Thai.   The chicken in Pad See Yew was just bone dry and unpalatable, while the Yellow curry tasted overwhelmingly of coriander spice.  Food portions are extremely small for a la carte, which didn't matter even though we were four as the taste didn't pass muster.  Seating is quite cramped.  The entrees are served on large plates with little food in the center and the table just couldn't hold 4 dishes.   Given the neighborhod and decor inside, don't think Lers Ros should attempt haute Thai cuisine.   Felt let down by the very high rating on Yelp.  I would rather go to Sai Jai Thai round the corner on O'Farrell  for some succulent pork shoulder despite the ambience.
author: Ralph K.

description: we went to this place on the weekend of the sf marathon. we yelped it and found out that the most popular item was the pork dish. it didn't dissapoint. if you've ever had filipino food and have had lechon kawali, its pretty much the same thing drizzled in some sort of sauce. we also had the sweet and sour soup and it had a real kick to it but it was good. On our way out we made sure to grab huge handfuls of the tamarind candies that they have in the bowl.
author: Patrick V.

description: I have been going here for years now, a while before it became really well known.  I highly recommend the Tom Yum Goong and Gra Pow pork. I get it every time!
author: Han Myoung P.

description: i dont know what i was smoking the first time i was here. i loved the garlic frog legs appetizer and the pork belly dish. both noodles dishes we got were yummy as well - pad see ew with beef and pad thai with prawns. im still not impressed with their yellow curry though. this place was super packed on a friday.
author: Yevi A.

description: Great food. I had the pad thai and salad
author: Vivien C.

description: Very quick, "authentic" (not that I'd know), spicy, delicious. If this place really only deserves 2-3 stars in its neighborhood, maybe I should move there.
author: Chris E.

description: Went to this place two nights in a row. What a good fallback plan. It's open till 2am and delivers until 10pm. The green tofu curry was pretty good- nothing I couldn't make myself if I felt like going shopping. The fishcakes are really good. The chicken satay not so much. The ladies who work there are really sweet and attentive.
author: Kerry A.

description: most thai-like thai restaurant in SF.  Every dish was incredibly flavorful and perfectly spiced. If you want to relive Thailand, come here.
author: R S.

description: One case where yelp steered me wrong. I usually call Yukol or Little Thai for delivery and wanted to try something new. Tried this place about a month ago and I feel it is my duty to let other yelpers know that they should be aware of my experience - hence the follow up. I think the guy must have gotten lost or driven back to the restaurant and remembered my food was still in his car or something. It took 1.5 hours for the food to arrive and my vegetarian dishes were lukewarm and not even close to good. The flavoring was off and the noodles stuck together in big heaps. I have no idea why everyone likes this place. Totally beyond me.
author: Win S.

description: visiting for the weekend from Chicago. so i can't really answer to how it compares to other places in SF, but i thought they had great food. not a huge dining room, but kept neat and clean.  my wife and i ordered pad see eiw and pad thai and were very satisfied with both and had leftovers to boot!
author: Sunil M.

description: Excellent yellow curry and deep-fried tofu. That with steamed rice and side salad for $7.25 is a real bargain. The triangles of tofu are crispy on the outside, silky on the inside; the dish came with a sweet-sour sauce and chopped peanuts. A substantial bowl of yellow curry was spicy, hot and included tender chicken, onions, and potatoes. A great meal. Get the Thai iced-coffee - excellent. The restaurant is clean, bright, and has friendly staff. Obviously a popular place, and deserves to be! Muni: 19, 47.
author: Suzie C.

description: Good tasting food but delivery took over 1.5 hours when they said it would take 45 minutes . Delivering to a hotel , you would expect them to give plastic cutlery or chopsticks but we got none, hence food ended up cold after we had arranged something..
author: Joe S.

description: Good service and delicious food.  Be sure to look at the "rice plates" section of the menu, which has good stuff that you can order sans rice if you want to -- I had a dish with crispy pork skins that was amazing.  The thick porridge with preserved egg would have been excellent drunk food, if I were there at 2 AM post-Whiskey Thieves.
author: Katharine N.

description:
Based on my one meal at Lers Ros, I'm willing to wager that it's currently the best Thai restaurant in San Francisco, and probably in the Bay Area. 

With a friend to help, we ordered the fried tofu, duck larb, green curry with chicken, and pork belly with crispy basil. Every dish was a flat-out success, blending flavors and textures together brilliantly. Spicy, salty, sour, sweet, crunchy, and chewy - everything in perfect balance. 

Even those who don't ordinarily like Thai food should give this place a try, although I might prefer to have the place to myself.
author: Andrew M.

description: Thai food here is very authentic - I really like the pan fried trout, you just need to make sure to finish it because of the generous portion.  Staff is friendly and helpful.  Will definitely come back hopefully before the line starts :)
author: S J.

description: Best damn authentic Thai food I ever had.  Great services.  I got nothing else to say about this place, its so freaking good.  BTW gotta try duck curry, its the sh!t.
author: food lover t.

description: huge menu, requires much studying and consideration. then decisions are made and they've been tasty.
author: Fzarond K.

description: The dishes were not very good.  They tasted like frozen food that was reheated.  The dishes are not spicy like thai food is supposed to be.  Its very bland.  Definitely not a place I will go again.
author: Rosh C.

description: Service, cheap prices, big portions, goooood food!
author: Annie C.

description: I am addicted to their Larb Salad. Crispy tender pieces of duck with tons of chilis without burning my mouth, and the most amazing sauce/ dressing. Comes with lettuce cups to wrap with. I want to call them now. I've only delivered, tried lots of items and never disliked anything, I just have favorites. Crispy chicken with ginger rice, Tom Yum Soup, and the pork belly. Reasonable time for delivery, 30-45 minutes, and everything arrives hot. My "Go-To" Thai delivery.
author: Mel N.

description: super disappointed. we ordered delivery from this spot, it was speedy, the food was great and the prices were better! the green papaya salad was great -- super spicy! things took a turn for the worst when mid-meal, i found a hard, 1 inch long piece of plastic in one of my bites of panang curry w/ rice. we won't be ordering again.
author: Jessica H.

description: We wandered in here Friday evening expecting typical Thai fair. Little did we know there were such interesting things on the menu. After carefully selecting the alligator, rabbit and venison we were all excited. The rabbit came out first. Drenched in fried garlic, the little boned creature was quite tasty. Next the venison. This was done in a cracked black pepper sauce, with pepper corns the size of golf balls. Bite in to one of them by accident and straight to the dentist you go. Finally the alligator. Soaked in ginger and fresh peppercorn. (I have never had fresh pepper corn still attached to the branch) Pretty interesting. Overall the meal was a little disappointing. The rabbit might as well have been chicken, the venison could have been beef and the alligator tasted exactly like pork. I was happy that these items where on the menu, but was hoping for something really tasty and exotic. Overall, the dishes were simply overpriced chicken, pork and beef. 3 dishes + 2 beers = $85 including tip. Kind of pricey for Thai food. Tip: Stick with the normal dishes.
author: Howard C.

description: The food was great, and the staff were friendly. The ambiance leaves something to be desired. It just feels wrong to hear Three Doors Down under fluorescent lights while eating Thai. That said, they had many vegetarian dishes, and they were very tasty. Probably wouldn't hit this neighborhood after dark though.
author: Shawn B.

description: Went in for Dinner. Almost missed the place. Parking is an issue as usual in SF. Its a bit expensive. Food is good, service is above average, there is not much ambiance wise. The place is too small to decorate I guess. Bought a soup, Grilled chicken and Pad Thai. Soup was too much for two people. None of the waiters told me that the soup would serve 6 people, we were full by the time we finished the soup, but it was a tasty. I liked the place though, mainly because of the tasty food. Most probably will go again.
author: Ni D.

description: This place use the Mexicans off Bayshore street for chiefs! Not trying to discriminate or anything but that is just weird to me. I gotta find me one and have him cook for me. When I saw that, it surprised me. That doesn't sound like an authentic Thai restaurant to me. They have to have Thai chief, if not, they are just cooking for money and not for the enjoyment of cooking Thai food. I would not go there ever again. And I didn't even talk about the slow service and unflavored food. Jeez. Sai Jai Thai, here I come! (on 7x7 again)
author: Jimmy T.

description: If you have either visited or lived in Thailand (which I did for 2 years) it is hard to find true Thai food in the US.  Most places in the US cater to the American palate and create Ameri-Thai dishes.  Ler Ros (along with Marnee Thai and a few others in the city) do a good job creating Thai dishes.  This is one of the only places that I know of that you can get Muu Grop (fried pork belly).  The quality of the food makes it 5 stars, but the portion size is more like a true Thai portion size. This is somewhat frustrating since you pay much more for the food than you would in Thailand.  All in all though definitely worth the trip to this restaurant.
author: Joshua J.

description: For truly authentic Thai, this is one of a very, very short list in the Bay Area.  I know b/c I used to live in Thailand and have a Thai wife.  Take it from me, this is the real deal.  They don't americanize the flavors so it may be saltier, spicier and less sweet than what you'd find elsewhere, but they use real and rare Thai ingredients like kaffir lime leaves and true Thai holy basil.  Yeah, the neighborhood is what it is - it won't keep me away!
author: David S.

description: Wow, I was really impressed with the food.  It was one of the best Thai restaurants I have eaten at and they had such a wide variety of items to choose from.  The trout, silver noodles, pork belly, and chicken satay was very good.  I would definitely go back there real soon.
author: Mary L.

description: This is definitely my favorite Thai place in the city. Why? Because everything tastes fresher here. The Tom Yum is lemongrassy, hot and delicious. The noodles and curries very good, with lots of vegetables and not just stalks and canned junk (I HATE canned baby corn!). The whole steamed fish was also delicate and delectable. For those who like an adventure, there's always frog or venison or boar or something on the menu. The staff are friendly and the space clean and no-nonsense. I love this place!
author: Francine O.

description: For the price, indeed at any price, this is some of the best Thai food I've had.  Been a couple of times on this trip.  The green curry is fantastic, and the portions generous but not scary.  From what I could see, it was child-friendly and the staff efficient.
author: Samuel B.

description: Fantastic Thai. VERY authentic, open late, and they deliver. Worth the trip into the TL, or at least order in. You won't be disappointed.
author: Lauren Q.

description:
Had a lunch with three others at Lers Ros today.  My mother is Thai so my tastebuds have experienced everything that Thai food can be over the years.  Bottom line: Lers Ros definitely beats anything I've had in the Bay Area so far (excepting not having yet tried Thai House Express), but doesn't quite rise to the level of "top-notch quality Thai food" that can be found on rare occasions in this country.  As much as there was subtlety and complexity in the flavors, which were very much authentic, the interplay of spices, heat, and ingredients can be taken to another level or two.  In recent personal experience, Thai Siam in Arrington, VA (hole in the wall place with four tables run by a retired woman who grows most of the ingredients she uses and widely considered the best Thai currently on the East Coast) is dish for dish superior to Lers Ros.  That said, here's a rundown of our impressions of the dishes today - 

#27 Tom ka gai - the balance of flavors was about 90% there - chicken quality was high but a bit skimpy on the amount of chicken.  Flavors should have included a bit more intensity in the kaffir lime (and no additional option of adding squeezed lime was provided).  All in all, a fine rendition, but there was one or two layers of flavor disappointingly absent (yet more layers than I've discovered in your run-of-the-mill Thai eatery).  Perhaps it needed more lemongrass?  Or pepper?  Something...

#9 - Kao moo yang - I really enjoyed this dish.  Pork had a subtly smokey flavor to it, but not overwhelming.  Interplayed extremely well with the chili powder sauce.  I appreciated that the intensity of the spiciness was set at just the right level to allow for both the under- and overtones of distinct flavors to come together. 

#4 Thai herb sausage - judging by scoop amount, I seemed to like this dish more than others in my party did.  It was a very pleasant rendition of the SE Asian-style sausage, which is one of my favorite Asian products to begin with.  So maybe I have a lower threshold for giving my stamp of approval on this one, but I could find no faults.  Tender, juicy, flavorful, not greasy.  A winner in my book.

#13 - Som Tom - green papaya salad.  hmm - I thought this dish failed just a bit.  Kitchen really went hog wild on the spice level, which in itself is not automatically a criticism.  Problem was that they let spiciness be the one and only star here.  The prawns were flavorless, and the lime dressing seemed strangely diluted.  The dish lacked cohesiveness - all of the flavors were distinct elements and just didn't come together.  

"Chicken puff" special: samosas, basically, with a peanut dipping sauce.  The puffs and filling were quite nice - crispy outside without being too crunchy, and soft flavorful filling.  I found the peanut sauce to be lacking, however.  There wasn't enough kick to the sauce, and frankly it reminded me of the "dumbed down" version of peanut sauces one finds much too often in Americanized Thai restaurants.  Instead of a goo, in my opinion a peanut sauce that was more granular in nature, and with a brighter flavor to its base, would have provided a better texture combination with the puff filing. 

#62 Pad Kra Prow Moo Krob stir-fried pork with crispy rind and basil leaves. Unlike some other reviews, I didn't find the pork to be swimming excessively in sauce, or the sauce to be particularly fatty.  I enjoyed the crispy rind on the pork too - a nice contrast in flavor and texture.  This was a very "comforting" dish - but I could see the addition of one or two more flavor undertones would really make this dish come alive more than it did. 

#77 Pad See Ew - deliberately chosen to be our "bread and butter" dish.  One of ubiquity so as to directly compare a comfort food staple with others.  Verdict: eh.  They really phoned this one in.  I appreciated the use of gai lan as opposed to Western broccoli, but still there was nothing to this dish over that which you can find in any Thai place.  The noodles were somewhat goupy.  Kitchen really didn't do much to accentuate the complexities that this dish, despite being a dark sauce dish, can achieve if you really put some interest into it. 

#113 - Quick fried marinated trout with mango sauce - YES SIR!  This was an absolute winner, and is worth the trip in itself.  Definitely the star of the meal.  Perfectly crispy, bones, tail, skin, everything edible.  The quintessential Thai "fish and chips" (where the "chips" are actually the extra crispy parts of the fish!).  Wonderful flavoring to the fry itself, and equally wonderful pairing of mango sauce.  

Final verdict - if all dishes had been on the level of the #113, Lers Ros would be up there with some of the best I'd experienced in this country (Thai Siam in rural Virginia, the late Zab-e-lee in Atlanta before the good owner moved back to Thailand, Thai House in Anchorage, Alaska, the old Bangkok Thai Cuisine in Mobile, AL). As it is, just a notch below.
author: Michael H.

description: The staff is really friendly and warm and noticed this when I called in my order.  The green curry w/tofu and Pra Ram Pak was delicous. The green curry serving was generous but the pra ram pak was a bit small and left me craving for more which is the only reason I'm giving it a 4.  I wish there was a little more tofu in both of the dishes too but we had some green curry left overs at the end.  The green curry was a little spicy for me but I can't really handle spicy food too well. This only slowed me down but didn't stop me from eating it.  The atmosphere was nice and the place was busy for 10:15 pm on a Sunday night and I wish that we had ate it there. I'll have to visit again next time I'm in town and dine there.  I think that it would be a great place to have a late night dinner and drinks with some friends.
author: J M.

description: As I sit here still at the table due to over eating, I'm pondering my meal only 15 minutes ago and thinking...hot damn that was good! Definatly one of, if not the, best thai food I've had in many years. Easily located in downtown SF, this place really blew my mind. Started out with some Thai iced tea which is always fabulous and freshly prepared here; then we moved on to a spicy beef salad which when I say spicy, I mean SPICY. It always bothers me when restaurants claim that a dish is spicy and yet the dish comes out with very little, to no, spiciness. Not the case in this restaurant, spicy is no object here since I needed a refill of my thai iced tea to just calm my palate down. For the second and final course we ordered the fried pork belly and curried beef noodles; the noodles were a little too over cooked for my taste and were kind of lost in the sauce (which was good on its own). The pork belly was out of this world though; perfectly crispy skin with soft, dark meat underneath. All in all I would highly recommend the restaurant...
author: Andrew M.

description: Managed to fit in a large party with 1 hour's notice (which was fantastic). Food was fresh, and reasonably priced.. Having traveled extensively through Thailand, the food and spices were definitely up to snuff! And they also had lots of menu items atypical of most Thai restaurants (think alligator meat). They don't get the 5 star treatment mostly since they were pretty understaffed.. Took about 20 minutes for us to get water at our table, and thereafter refills were few and far between.
author: AC C.

description:
This is the best Thai in the city!  I am not a big fan of Thai food in general; I find the flavors generic and mundane, with many restaurants preparing food with far too much sugar (what is it about sweet Thai food?).  That said, Lers Ros is a very welcome departure from my typical Thai experience.
I have been here several times and sampled the menu.  Their coconut soup is better than any other that I've had.  Rich flavors, well balanced with good quality ingredients.  
The pork belly dish is also a must.  Tender belly fried with the rind still on, giving it a ton of flavor and interesting textures.  
For a contrast to the belly, they offer a slow cooked (I think they refer to it as stewed) pork leg that is also delicious.  Very rich gravy, tender meet served with pickled greens.
On a different note I have never been disappointed with their whole fish.  We have had two from the menu and each has been delicious.
I would pass on the vegetarian silver noodles... go with the meat-based entrees if you'd like to experience the best of this place.  
A very unique and satisfying Thai restaurant.  When I go for Thai now, I go here.
author: joel b.

description: Even though in the tenderloin, this is not a bad restaurant. The food is homestyle Thai cooking.  Very good papaya salad, red curry.. It tastes fresh and the restaurant in clean.  I was surprised about this place given the outside. A great find...
author: Razz T.

description: so i have been looking for a new awesomely great thai restaurant since osha's attitudes no longer feed my appetite. when looking up thai on yelp i see that the #1 pick in the spread is just a couple of blocks away from me. ok. ill bite. we decided to make reservations as the last time we walked by there was a line out the door. people waiting in the cold must mean that the food is well worth it. we got there and of course it was packed but that was just fine with me. we waited about 10 minutes but they were soo nice about it that it didnt really bother me much. we looked around and saw all these great pots of flaming soups so i knew we just had to get one. i dont exactly remember what we got but know we ordered  a green curry and their special which was spicy pork spareribs. im not too much into to spicy but i must say it was delish! the whole presentation and look were just great even tho it seems like a whole in the wall type of place. i am really looking forward to going back there again. reservations are a must!!!!
author: Ashley H.

description: I stumbled upon this place only because I found parking across the street.  When I first walked in, the first thing that greeted me was a real funky smell. I want to say it's the new restaurant smell of paint and construction or something real funky. Anyway, the smell went away after I got my pad thai. I must say, the best pad thai that I've ever tasted! I like the garlic chili sauce that they offer along with the other condiments if you ask for it.
author: Ravenous T.

description: Interesting takes on thai standards, and some novel ideas with not-so-standard ingredients and/or preparations. Will be going back to try much more of their extensive menu. Waitstaff was incredibly nice and (almost too) efficient. I asked, but still not quite sure of the correct pronunciation of the restaurant name...
author: Brian O.

description: On a walk down Valencia that we thought would end in a burger, my boyfriend and I decided to have a little adventure and got on the BART instead.  Destined for the TL, more specifically Little Saigon, we were in search of something great, preferably hole in the wall.  While Lers Ros isn't really hole in the wall, it was great.  We shared a Som Tom green papaya salad (very spicy) with raw crab, which was interesting--sweet, but very hard to get out of the shells.  The curry puffs with peanut sauce are screaming to be made available for street food consumption (preferably close to where I live).  I had a Tom Kha soup, which was aromatic and rich as it should be and had lots of delicious oyster mushrooms (rather than the canned brown buttons that will sometimes be sneaked in).  My boyfriend had a pork belly dish that was utterly succulent.  Next time we go back we'll be more adventurous and order some of the fried quail, frogs leg, pig entrails...well, not that last one.  Maybe this place was so good because we just happened upon it, but I have a feeling a return visit will be just as wonderful, especially since the waitresses were so nice.  And, there's always the leftovers in the fridge offering an opportunity to revisit.
author: Kathryn M.

description: Best Thai I've had in the city. Authentic, spicy, creative and great service. They also do takeout.  Cant beat this spot, plus you get the unpredictable benefit of hanging out in the loin afterwards...
author: Robert S.

description: The best Thai food I have had in the city! I'm sold.
author: Julie H.

description: ordered delivery from there last night. very interesting menu. more cartilage, tendon, offal, and unusual critters than you can shake a satay skewer at. you know you're in for a treat when you can't decide between quail or frog-- and that's just for appetizers. the food was delicious and i can only imagine it would taste even better if i was eating in the restaurant rather than having it delivered. highly recommended!
author: Brett W.

description: I think, generally, I need to stop reading Merideth Brody's restaurant reviews (SF Weekly)...this place had a decent (but gloppy) yellow curry...the Kao Kha Moo (that Brody recommended) was strange tasting and really strange looking...
author: Tonya M.

description: Best Thai food in San Francisco. Comparable to the better places in Thai Town in Los Angeles. They have unusual ingredients and delicious results. It loses one star for the neighborhood.
author: Stephen S.

description: the luster is slowly wearing off. i mean it is still real solid, but 4 star average. there are times when this place is 5 star worthy but i have been here enough in the past few months to know that it is not consistently 5 stars.
author: Jason B.

description: Pretty tasty.  Menu is huge.  Delivery is pretty sweet.  Ordered 2 things, really liked 1 of them, will definitely try again to see some different things on the menu.
author: Jesse L.

description: After checking out the reviews I decided that this looked like a good place to go.  My husband and I met a couple of friends here last night.  Upon arriving we noticed how ugly the place was.  No decor to speak of  just tables and chairs and a flat screen TV on the wall.  I decided to ignore this because the food is suppose to be good right?  Wrong!  I ordered the green curry chicken, it didn't have any eggplant like it said it would and the chicken was so tough I could barely cut it with my fork.  I was disappointed.  My husband had the tofu with mixed vegetables.  The tofu was mushy and it was way too spicy.  One of our friends had the shrimp and veggies, the shrimp was mushy and again too hot!  Our other friend had the Boar stir fry.  He liked it but when I tasted the boar it was tough, grisly and greasy!  All I can say is yuck!  If you like your Thai food extra hot great.  Maybe we ordered the wrong things?   Green curry is what I usually order and it is usually good but here it just didn't work.  Also the restrooms are up a flight of stairs so don't go if you have problems going up and down stairs. The service wasn't that good either.  We won't be back!
author: Vickie R.

description: I read the review Meredith Brody of the San Francisco Weekly and she was definitely right on with the pork dish called pad kra prow moo krob.  It was exactly as described soft pork with a crunchy top in a spicy sauce with vegetables.  I am hooked on this dish after one time!  And actually, it is more spicy than I normally would eat, but this dish is worth the added spice.  I am planning out my week this week to re-order it again.  They also deliver.
author: Bernie B.

description: excellent tom kha soup, and the best peanut sauce i've ever tried. plus a super-friendly, helpful, and prompt staff, and the menu is comprehensive. i'd go to this place every week even if it wasn't half a block away. a diamond in the TL rough.
author: emily l.
